DOC.HEADLINE: DPP congress ends with vow to build normal country, happy Taiwan

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) concluded its annual national congress Sunday, with a declaration that pledges to make Taiwan a "normal country and happy homeland."

According to the declaration, Taiwan would be able to break out of old shackles and go down its own road under its own name so long as the DPP can continue its grip on the presidency and win more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan in next year's elections.

The declaration also singles out the party's two other major tasks -- working to ensure the passage of two planned referendums on forcing the main opposition Kuomintang to return its ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers and joining the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
About 300 party delegates attended the half-day national congress, which was presided by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.
Notably absent from the session were President Chen Shui-bian, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Frank Hsieh, the party's candidate for the 2008 presidential election.
The congress was overshadowed by a controversy over a "normal country resolution" that was set to be passed at the meeting to serve as the party's platform for the coming presidential election.

Yu decided to step down from party chairmanship Thursday after the party's other bigwigs reached a consensus a day earlier to omit more hardline suggestions in the draft "normal country resolution" to change the country's name to "Taiwan" from the current Republic of China to declare to the world that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state.

Although the party's heavyweights, from President Chen on down, tried to persuade Yu to remain on his post at least until the party congress, Yu insisted on quitting at once and didn't show up at Sunday's congress.

Two versions of the "normal country resolution" were presented for discussion at the congress -- the Yu-proposed hardline version and the "consensus" version that was reached at a Sept. 26 meeting of party heavyweights chaired by President Chen.

After two hours of debate, the hardline version was rejected by a vote in which only 43 delegates raised their hands to express their support for the version that could have further upset China and even the United States.

Later on, the "consensus" version, which reaffirms the party's commitment to "push for Taiwan's name rectification and write a new constitution, " was approved, with an overwhelming majority of congress delegates applauding to show their endorsement.

The formally adopted "normal country resolution" will serve as road map for the DPP administration in its efforts to fortify Taiwan-centric consciousness and create a Taiwan identity, party officials said.

The party congress was originally designed to serve as a pep rally to boost morale of DPP candidates for the Jan. 12 legislative elections and March 22 presidential election. But arguments over wording of the "normal country resolution" spoiled the atmosphere. DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh chose not to attend the meeting.

Yeh Chu-lan, the Presidential Office secretary-general who also serves as top manager of Hsieh's campaign, said the morale-boosting pep rally will be rescheduled later as it might need more time for party members with dissenting views to calm down.

Noting that all DPP founding members risked arrest and imprisonment during the martial law ear to create the party, none of them would compromise the party's ultimate goal of building Taiwan into a "normal and great" democratic country. She called for all party members to think about policy issues from a broader vision instead of personal perspective for the sake of maintaining party unity.
Premier Chang voiced similar views, urging all DPP members to stand united and refraining from internal strife over trivial technical details.

"The DPP is a mature democratic party. We tend to have pluralistic views on policy issues. We have the ability to cope with different opinions. We should never let minor issues undermine our morale and harmony," he said in his opening remarks.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai said President Chen didn't attend the congress mainly because he was informed in advance that the pep rally to boost candidates' morale would be canceled. He said the president supports the proposal to choose a more opportune time to hold such a rally to drum up support for the party's candidates for the two coming elections.

Many congress delegates said they support the omission of the hardline clause from the "normal country resolution" because an overly provocative pro- independence platform could alienate middle-of-the-road voters who prefer to maintain the peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Judicial Yuan to get new secretary-general

TEXT.P: Hsieh Wen-ting, a head prosecutor with the Supreme Prosecutors Office, will serve as new secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan, judicial sources said Sunday.

President Chen Shui-bian once nominated Hsieh to serve as the country's top prosecutor, officially called state public prosecutor-general. But the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan vetoed Hsieh's nomination. The top prosecutorial post later went to Chen Tsung-ming.

According to the sources, new Judicial Yuan President Lai In-jaw, who will assume office Monday, has invited Hsieh to serve as the country's top judicial body's chief of staff. Hsieh confirmed in an interview with CNA that he has accepted Lai's invitation.

A changeover ceremony for Judicial Yuan president and vice president will be held Monday morning. Lai will replace Weng Yueh-sheng as new Judicial Yuan head. Weng will retire. Hsieh Tsay-chuan will be sworn in as Judicial Yuan vice president, a post that has been left vacant since the resignation of Cheng Chung-mo in April 2006 amid allegations that he had an affair with an assistant professor at a local university.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate faces tough challenges

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh faces tough challenges in consolidating party ranks following the party's annual national congress, political sources said Sunday.
Despite the passage at the party congress of a "consensus" version of the "normal country resolution" that Hsieh supports, many thorny issues remain to be resolved, the sources said.
The most urgent issue is who should be the party's next chairman if Yu Shyi-kun insists on his resignation offer.

Yu decided to step down Thursday after the party's other bigwigs reached a consensus on omitting a Yu-proposed hardline clause from the "normal country resolution" that calls for changing the country's title to "Taiwan."

Although party heavyweights, including President Chen Shui-bian, have publicly persuaded Yu to remain on the post, Yu has not been seen in public since Thursday. He didn't show up to preside over the party's 21st founding anniversary celebrations Friday nor attended Sunday's party congress.
It marked the first time in the party's 21-year history that no party chairman was available to chair its birthday celebrations and party congress.

As Yu-proposed "hardline" version of the "normal country resolution" was rejected at the party congress, with only 43 radical members voicing explicit support, party sources said Hsieh will have a hard time reaching conciliation with Yu and his hardline pro-independence followers.
Hsieh has publicly supported the proposal that President Chen serves as the party's chairman again if Yu would not return to the post. But it remains uncertain whether Chen would accept the proposal.

With the party's morale dropping to a new low over the controversy over the "normal country resolution," party sources said Chen and Hsieh should come up with new initiatives to reignite party members and supporters' passion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 1, or the 10th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA chief unveils '21st century global village diplomatic policy'

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang proposed his "21st century global village diplomatic policy" at the Legislative Yuan Monday.
While delivering a report at a Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee meeting, Huang said the new policy is an "updated, situation-coping" policy that also stresses Taiwan's distinct identity.

The policy includes four major strategies for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to follow, namely assuming a more "combative" approach in diplomatic efforts to counter China's attempts to suppress Taiwan in the international arena, adopting a "blue ocean strategy" to build relations with other countries, promoting the "Taiwan experience" abroad, and adopting an "environmental diplomacy" strategy, Huang said.

Noting that China's efforts to suppress Taiwan's maneuvering space in the international arena have reached an "insane level, " Huang said that MOFA personnel on the "frontlines" abroad must work more aggressively to pre-empt Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically.

On promoting the "Taiwan experience" abroad, Huang said that democracy, freedom and economic co-prosperity form the foundation of the Taiwan experience, adding that Taiwan has the ability to make contributions to the international community and is willing to share its experience in economic development for the benefit of the global community.

Following a "blue ocean strategy, " Huang said, Taiwan will not engage in a "zero sum" competition with China and will instead use its advantages in various fields to build comprehensive partnerships with nations around the world.

On adopting an "environmental diplomacy" strategy, Huang said it is hoped that via cooperation in environmental protection efforts, Taiwan will be able to strengthen its relations with the rest of the world.

Meanwhile, Huang said in his report that the country's efforts to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan launched this year have been a success in terms of promoting Taiwan's bid to join the world body. Noting that the number of media reports on the issue have increased three-fold, he said Taiwan's bid has been brought into the international spotlight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Commission to probe possible price-rigging by instant noodle makers

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission under the Executive Yuan will launch an investigation into possible price-rigging by several instant noodle makers, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Monday.

Shieh made the remarks following a report published in the Monday edition of the United Daily News that said prices of several brands of instant noodles are set to rise by at least 10 percent from Wednesday at the earliest.

Noting that the government is working hard to protect the rights and interests of the people, Shieh said any instant noodle makers that are found to be guilty of price-rigging will be dealt with to the full extent of the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: passenger volume on domestic flights down 22.14% for Jan.-June period

TEXT.P: The inauguration of the high speed railway has greatly affected domestic air carriers, with the number of passengers on domestic flights in the first half of this year declining 22.14 percent over the figure for the same period last year, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported Monday.
MOTC officials said there were around 119,000 domestic flights in the first six months this year, down 13.72 percent from the 138,000 flights during the same period last year.
The number of air passengers on domestic routes totaled 6.72 million in the first six months of this year, down 22.14 percent from the 8.63 million the same period last year.
In comparison, the number of international flights (to and from Taiwan) totaled 95,820 during the Jan.-June period, up 3.36 percent over the figure for the same period last year.
The number of passengers on these international flights totaled 12.01 million for the January-June period, up 4.26 percent from the 11.52 million of the first half of last year.

Transportation and Communications Minister Tsai Duei said that the official inauguration of the high speed railway in early January has affected other transportation operators, especially domestic air carriers.

The MOTC, taking the people's rights as well as the sustainable development of air carriers into consideration, has reviewed flight routes and numbers and begun working with related sectors to promote package tours, he said.
Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Billy Chang said that the sluggish economy as well as convenient land transportation have affected domestic air carriers.
As the air carriers cannot let their planes lie idle, some have been forced to cut air fares to compete with the high speed rail, Chang said, adding that "this is not a good thing."

DOC.HEADLINE: Sugar chip for cancer detection developed

TEXT.P: Researchers at Academia Sinica have completed the development of a new "sugar chip" that is able to diagnose cancer cell, bacterial, or viral infection within seconds and with high accuracy, academic sources said Monday.

The chips, based on glycan micro-array technology, detect specific interactions between carbohydrates and proteins to determine the onset of known diseases, they said, adding that in the next stage, the team at the institution's Genomics Research Center will make the chip applicable to the detection of human immunodeficiency virus and avian influenza virus.

Liang Pi-hui, a post-doctoral researcher at the Genomics Research Center, said the chip has the potential to become a very reliable detection method in clinical use, for it requires only seconds and a small quantity of sample to produce results with near-100 percent accuracy.

In addition to that feature, Liang also noted that the chip can trace even the slightest alteration in carbohydrate-protein interactions, allowing the physician to discover latent cancers or infections that would be invisible to other methods.
The advances in the chip research and development have been published in the current issue of the renowned Journal of the American Chemical Society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free flu vaccination program kicks off

TEXT.P: A free flu vaccination program kicked off Monday, providing flu shots free of charge for groups of people considered to be at high risk of influenza, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health reported Monday.

Shih Wen-yi, a deputy director of the CDC, urged these groups -- including persons over 65 years of age or children aged between six months and two years -- not to rush in an attempt to receive their shots on the first day of the program, since the vaccines will be available over the next two months.
Shih called for flu shot recipients to stay at the place where they receive their shots for at least half an hour to make sure that they develop no allergic reaction to the vaccine.

The free flu shot program is also available to first-line medical professionals, hospital volunteer workers, community pharmacists, medical lab workers, school nurses, crew of international airlines, quarantine workers, poultry farmers and bird raisers, nursing home residents, people suffering from severe injuries or diseases, as well as first-year and second-year primary school students.
According to Shih, there will be 2.73 million doses of free flu vaccine available for adults and 320,000 doses for children this year.

Shih said Taiwan usually enters flu season around the end of November, with cases reaching a peak around Christmas. The CDC, after analyzing reported flu cases between 2000 and 2006, said the incidence of flu turning into serious disease among children under 12 years is four or five times the number among people over 65, while the mortality rate is also three or four times that of the elderly, far higher than other age groups.
CDC experts said the best way to prevent flu is to get flu shots.
Paid flu shots are also available at major hospitals around the country, where ordinary people can get flu vaccinations at around NT$580 per dose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to offer loans to Ecuadorian expats to buy homes in Ecuador

TEXT.P: The International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will cooperate with the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) in offering loans to encourage Ecuadorian expatriates to return home to purchase houses in Ecuador, an ICDF official said Monday.

The project worth US$5.7 million was signed by the ICDF and the IDB Group in Ecuador Sept. 26, with the ICDF and IDB's Multilateral Investment Fund (MIF) each injecting US$2.5 million into the project, and the remaining US$700,000 being provided by the MIF and Ecuador's real estate loan granting organization Mutualista Pichincha.
The official said that under the project, each Ecuadorian expatriate is expected to be offered an average loan of US$46,000.

According to the official, 85 percent of Ecuadorian expatriates live in Spain, the United States or Italy, and the project will help Mutualista Pichincha to set up four offices in the three countries to lure more Ecuadorian expatriates there to return home and purchase houses in Ecuador to further boost the South American country's economy.

Ecuador suffered a financial crisis in 1998, which resulted in a massive wave of emigration. Ecuador's official statistics show that some 650,000 Ecuadorians, or nearly 11.2 percent of the country's labor force, relocated abroad between 1999-2004.
An average of more than 100,000 Ecuadorians have emigrated per year since 2004, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close slightly higher

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose slightly Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.98 points to close at 9,488.5.
The bourse opened at 9,523.98 and fluctuated between 9,555.07 and 9,474.4 during trading. A total of 6.16 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$165.36 billion (US$5.1 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement and textile stocks moving up the most at 2.1 percent each, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, construction stocks at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.7 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged, with electronics and machinery stocks moving down 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 983 to 834, with 272 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Country's name is ROC: education minister

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said Monday that Taiwan's national name is the Republic of China but claimed that the meaning of ROC "varies depending on differing historical situations."

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Education Committee, Tu said educators must give students around the country a "clear and definite" answer about the ROC's national territory, which he said covers only Taiwan proper and the islands of Penghu, Kinmen, Matsu and Nansha.
Tu made the remarks in response to several legislators who asked Tu about his perception of the country's formal title.
Meanwhile, Tu said that regularly monitoring the safety and security of campuses has been one of the major administrative measures of the Education Ministry.

Tu made the remarks in response to a question raised by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, who, backed up by a videotape showing a student in school uniform being beaten by a gang of his peers, said that campus violence has become increasingly rampant in recent years.

Hung said the number of officially reported cases of campus violence stood at 10 in 2004, but this number had increased to 75 in 2006, while the number of campus sexual assaults and cases of harassment surged to 915 that same year.

Hung accused the Education Ministry of whitewashing the campus security situation by simply including a sentence in its annual report saying that "the number of cases undermining public order on campuses at various levels have been steadily decreased."

Responding to another question raised by KMT Legislator Lee Ching-hua that many college students have reportedly conducted direct sales operations on campus and some have even quit school to operate businesses, Tu urged students to return to their studies, saying that being distracted from studying in the college years is not conducive to students' development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSB to take action against National Day disturbances

TEXT.P: National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Shi Hwei-yow said Monday that the bureau will take action against anyone attempting to disturb the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.
Shi made the remarks amid reports that anti-President Chen Shui-bian protesters are preparing to disrupt the Double Ten celebrations as they did last year.

Shi said the public's freedom of speech in a democratic society will be respected as long as they do not interfere with the progress of the celebrations. If others' security is jeopardized, however, resolute action will be taken, he went on.

Asked about contingency measures if someone unfurls banners in front of President Chen, Shi said that would be construed as jeopardizing the security of the nation's leader and disrupting the progress of celebrations, and therefore would not be permissible.
Legislator Ho Ming-hao of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union asked if the NSB has any information concerning possible anti-Chen "red shirt" protests this year.

Shi responded that the information so far is that the protesters will take some "sporadic" action, but as there is still some time to go before Double Ten day, the NSC will continue to monitor the situation.

Legislator Kao Chien-chih of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked about security measurers to protect the president, to which Shi responded that sharpshooters will be deployed on high buildings near the Presidential Office and there will also be anti-assassination measures in place.
The NSC has done everything possible, Shi said, although he declined to go into detail, saying only that he is confident of maintaining law and order on the day.

The "red shirt" protesters in the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign staged several large sit-ins and rallies in September 2006 that climaxed in a demonstration Oct. 10. during which tens of thousands surrounded the Presidential Office and the president's official residence to demand the resignation of Chen, whose family and close aides are involved and have been indicted over a series of corruption cases.

During the Double Ten rallies last year, opposition legislators lending support to the campaign flashed the "thumbs-down" gesture of the campaign and unfurled banners to demand Chen's ouster while he was addressing the rally.
Their actions invoked angry responses from the DPP legislators sitting next to them and brief scuffles broke out.
The campaign, initiated by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, petered out at the end of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum's annual sale to open Oct. 5

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum will hold a three-day sale from Oct. 5 to offer its publications, a wide range of reproductions of art pieces in its collection, and various souvenir items in celebration of its 81st anniversary, a spokesman for the museum said Monday.

The annual sale in the museum's Library Building will include reproductions of paintings and calligraphic works from the Sung, Yuan, Ming and Ching dynasties, as well as a famous painting by Chang Da-chien (1899-1983) depicting a stretch of the Yangtze River done in 1968.

Other items on sale include illustrated catalogues of rare paintings and calligraphy from the Sung dynasty, catalogs of ceramic ware from government- owned kilns in the imperial dynasties, and catalogs of costumes of the Ching dynasty.
The museum will also present more than 20 souvenir items featuring various art motifs, including silk scarves, vases, mugs, lacquer boxes, neckties and inkstones.

The National Palace Museum, located in the suburban Shihlin district of Taipei, ranks as one of the four best museums in the world along with the Louvre Museum of France, the British Museum and America's Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. It holds the world's largest collection of Chinese works of art -- about 700,000 pieces in all.

DOC.HEADLINE: Original opera to make debut in November

TEXT.P: "Firmiana Rain, " an original opera created by the Taiwan-born U.S.-based composer Chen May-tchi, will make its debut at the National Theater in Taipei City Nov. 1, followed by two further performances Nov. 3 and Nov. 4, a spokesman for the theater said Monday.

Japanese co-producers decided to stage the production after viewing only sections of Chen's creation, which was the only non-English opera selected for the Showcasing American Composers program organized by the New York City Opera in 2002, the spokesman said.
Chen's opera is a modern interpretation of the legendary love tragedy of Tang Ming Huang, the seventh emperor of ancient China's Tang Dynasty, and his favorite concubine Yang Guifei.

A collaboration between Taiwan and Japan, the opera is directed by Tomo Sugao, director of the New National Theater, Tokyo, and conducted by Taiwan-born Wen Yi-jen, a guest conducter at the National Theater Belgrade.

The opera uses Gagaku -- Japanese classical music that has been performed at the imperial court for centuries -- and Dun Huang Pipa music, and blends techniques of Taiwanese ke-tsai opera, Beijing opera, Kunqu opera and Western opera, the spokesman said.
Austin Wang, the opera's stage designer, said he used techniques and materials such as large projections and acrylics to show a modern and simplistic style.

Performances by musicians from Taiwan's National Symphony Orchestra, and the Chai Found Music Workshop, will all feature in the opera, as well as performances by both Taiwanese and Japanese opera artists, Tang Mei-yun, a Taiwanese Ke-tsai opera artist, and Liu Fu-hsue, a Taiwanese Beijing opera actor, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSB to heed legislative candidates' safety

TEXT.P: National Security Bureau Director Shi Hwei-yow said Monday that his bureau will heed the personal security of candidates in the run-up to the Jan. 12 legislative elections next year and vowed to step down if any of them are shot.
Shi made the remarks during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Peter Lin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party noted that the new electoral system will be adopted in the upcoming legislative elections and predicted that the competition will be especially fierce. The next legislature will see the "single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system implemented, while the number of seats in the legislature will be cut to 113 from the present 225.

Lin pointed out that every constituency will have two candidates from the DPP and the main opposition Kuomintang and said that if one candidate is shot, the election will go on, according to the existing regulations.

For this reason, Lin said, candidates will not "have" to spend tens of millions of dollars to buy votes, and might only need to spend NT$2 million or NT$3 million to hire a contract killer to shoot their rivals to ensure election victory.
Saying that he has taken note of the matter and admitting that the number of illegal guns in the country is on the rise, Shi promised to go out of his way to ensure the safety of every candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Institute for Information Industry to hold open patent bidding

TEXT.P: The Institute for Information Industry (III) will hold open bidding on patent sales and license agreements on 127 cases involving 199 projects on crucial software technology, III Executive Vice President Huang Yen-nun said Monday.
According to Huang, bids can be submitted until 5 p.m. Oct. 26, and the III will open the bids at 10 a.m. Oct. 30.
Huang noted that software development can help to increase functions and added value for products in an era of marginal profits.

Consumer electronic products such as cell phones, MP3 players and GPS devices, and businesses related to the Internet, electronic business, digital learning and business intelligence all rely on software advances for more business opportunities, Huang said.
Patent rights help to create commercial value for software development, Huang said.

A total of 22 packages of patent sales and 23 packages of license agreements are related to embedded software, application platforms of software and application solutions, including wireless communication systems, routing protocol technology, human-machine interaction technology, and image recognition technology, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate's link promise upsets Taiwan's dignity: official

TEXT.P: A direct China links promise made by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has discarded Taiwan's best interests and ignored the nation's dignity, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Monday.

Shieh made the remarks to reporters after Ma declared Saturday that he will immediately embark on pushing for the establishment of direct shipping and air links between Taiwan and China if he is elected president in the March 22, 2008 election.

Ma pledged that he will conclude bilateral negotiations on the opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links within one year upon his election and will fulfill the task by starting with weekend charter flights and expanding the service scope of the current ferry links maintained between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and three ports in China's Fujian Province -- known as the mini- three links.

Shieh accused Ma of turning a blind eye to Taiwan's national dignity and to China's ambition to swallow Taiwan when making the pledge -- something he said shows that Ma embraces Beijing's "one-China" principle.

Ma's request that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration establish direct shipping and air links across the strait in compliance with Beijing's "one China" condition is "out of the question," Shieh said.

"It is unthinkable that the DPP administration would trade off Taiwan's national sovereignty for opening direct transport links with China, " Shieh said, although he pointed out that the government has put many opening measures in place in response to the people's practical needs, such as setting up the mini links and offering special charter flight services on major festivals.

"There is a marked difference between Ma's `eventual one China' objective and the DPP government's goal of sustainably managing Taiwan," he argued, criticizing that "Ma must not threaten the government with Beijing's requests, hurting the nation's and the people's interest."

The issue of direct cross-strait transport links was put under the spotlight after Ma goaded Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate, to demand that the incumbent DPP administration swiftly realize Hsieh's promise concerning opening direct cross-strait links instead of just paying lip service.
Hsieh recently told the Singapore-based Straits Times that he would allow for the establishment of direct China links and the entry of Chinese capital and tourists if he wins the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to sponsor activity on Oct. 24 "Taiwan United Nations Day"

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will sponsor an activity on the Oct. 24, "Taiwan United Nations Day, " KMT Secretary-general Wu Den-yih said Monday.

Wu made the remarks following Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's announcement last week that Oct. 24 will be designated "Taiwan U.N. Day" in accordance with a proposal by local civic groups and that the Council of Sports Affairs will sponsor a torch relay to publicize Taiwan's bid to join the world body.
Wu said that the KMT's activity will underscore the glorious past of the Republic of China, Taiwan's official name, when it was one of the founding members of the United Nations.
The activity will also convey Taiwan people's aspiration to join the international community and shoulder the responsibility to help promote peace, prevent disease and eradicate poverty.
The details of the activity are still being planned, Wu added.

On Oct. 24, President Chen Shui-bian will ignite the torch at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the presidential office, and the torch will pass from Taipei City to Keelung City, Yilan County, Hualien County and all other 25 cities and counties in Taiwan.
That day -- the anniversary of the coming into force of the Charter of the United Nations in 1945 -- is celebrated internationally as United Nations Day.

The "China" seat in the United Nations was taken over by the People's Republic of CHina at the expense of the Republic of China in 1971. Taiwan has tried without success since 1993 to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation.

It suffered a fresh setback in its quest for representation in the world body last week when an item endorsed by 16 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the world body to address Taiwan's membership application was excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan national baseball team eyes on Beijing Olympics ticket

TEXT.P: A 24-man roster for the 2007 Baseball World Cup and a preliminary 60-man roster for the 2007 Asian Baseball Championship were announced Monday as Taiwan eyed on the lone Asian seed in the hopes of representing the nation in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

Taiwan will enjoy home park advantage throughout as both tournaments will be held in Taiwan. However, priority will be given to the Asian Championship, which is the 2008 Beijing Olympics qualifier, said Tsai Huang-lan, Deputy Director of the Sports Affairs Council (SAC).

The home team will have to beat Japan, South Korea and the Level-B winner for the title in the Asian Championship, which will be held in Taichung Nov. 27 - Dec. 3, to take the tournament championship and seize the only Asian seed in the 12-team field of the Beijing Olympic baseball event.

Kuo Tai-yuan, head coach of Taiwan's national baseball team, announced the 60-man roster, which included U.S. Major League pitchers Wang Chien-ming, Kuo Hong-chih, Tsao Chin-huei and infielder Hu Chin-lung, which will be trimmed down before the tournament.
Former Major Leaguer Chen Chin-feng, generally seen as Taiwan's top hitter, and others who currently play in the U.S. Minor League and Japanese professional league were also included.

The 2007 Baseball World Cup, which will be held from Nov. 6-18 in Taichung, Xinjhuang and Tianmu, is still important, but it will be regarded as a "warm up" series for the Asian Championship, said Kuo.

"By saying that, we're not giving up on the World Cup though. It's a special event for Taiwan, " Kuo said. It was after winning the bronze medal in the 2001 Baseball World Cup, which was also held in Taiwan, that Taiwan's professional baseball blossomed again and emerged from the shadow of the game-fixing scandals of the late 1990s, Tsai said.
Taiwan finished in fourth place in the 2004 Athens Olympics and 11th in the 2005 Baseball World Cup.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum to add momentum to U.N. cause: foreign minister

TEXT.P: The government's bid to seek U.N. membership for the county under the name Taiwan is not an emotionally charged move, and it will help add momentum to the government's drive if a planned public referendum approves of the move, Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) James Huang said Monday.

Huang made the remarks during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan in response to main opposition Kuomintang lawmakers' inquiries about the effectiveness of a government international media campaign calling for Taiwan's U.N. membership.

The government's drive to push for Taiwan's U.N. cause is not a precipitous action, but rather a move in response to popular desire to push the country to enter the international organization as a full member, he explained.

The U.N bid issue has stirred up widespread international discussion after several of Taiwan's diplomatic allies proposed in mid-September that the U.N. General Committee include Taiwan's membership application on the agenda of the world body's 62nd General Assembly, Huang noted, adding that global media outlets have more extensively reported on Taiwan's U.N. bid this year.

The latest development has allowed the voice of the people to be heard around the world, and if a public referendum -- slated to be held alongside the March 22, 2008 presidential election -- indicates approval of the government policy of pursuing U.N. membership, it will help inject greater energy into the ongoing campaign, he said.

Responding to a question on whether the United States has objected the government's U.N. referendum plan, Huang stressed that the country's U.N. cause and a planned referendum concerning the issue are two separate matters.

While seeking Taiwan's U.N. membership is a major government policy, holding a referendum to explore the public's opinion on the issue is common practice in democratic nations, he said, arguing that there is no need to regard a U.N. referendum as a move toward Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tennis duo grabs title in Seoul

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis stars Chuang Chia-jung and Hsieh Su-wei continued their winning streak over the weekend, capturing the championship of the Hansol Korea Open Women's Tennis in the South Korean capital of Seoul.
It is the duo's second WTA-level double's title since their victory at the China Open Sept. 23.
The duo defeated second seeds Elena Daniilidou of Greece and Jasmin Woehr of Germany 6-2, 6-2 Sunday to take home the US$145,000 grand prize.
In the first set, the Chuang-Hsieh team won the first four games 4-0, but lost the fifth 4-2. The Taiwanese pair then stepped up their efforts and took the set 6-2.

During the second set, the Taiwanese duo jumped to take a 3-0 lead after the first three games, and rolled on to take the set 5-1. The pair managed to grab hold of the lead and score a final victory 6-2.
The victory is expected to move Chuang and Hsieh up to sixth and 42nd seed, respectively, in the world doubles rankings to be released soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. stance toward Taiwan remains unchanged: security chief

TEXT.P: National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Shi Hwei-yow said Monday that despite expressing displeasure over Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, the United States' basic stance toward Taiwan remains unchanged.

Shi made the remarks in responde to questions by legislators from the opposition "pan-blue" alliance regarding whether the government has a contingency plan in place given the opposition from abroad, especially the United States and China, to President Chen Shui-bian's plan to hold a referendum on Taiwan's application to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan alongside next year's presidential election in March.
The U.S. sees such a referendum as an attempt to unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, while China considers it as an "important step" to declare Taiwan's de jure independence.

In response to questions from opposition People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao on whether the NSB has made any contingency plan in response to China's declaration that it has made the "necessary preparations" against Taiwan's plan to hold such a referendum, Shi said his agency has established a mechanism to properly respond to any situation.

Shi noted that although the U.S. has expressed its displeasure over Chen's plan to push for the referendum, the U.S. basic stance toward Taiwan remains unchanged, adding that at least U.S.-Taiwan communications regarding security issues remain normal.

It was reported that the U.S. government had rejected Chen's request for his transit stops in major U.S. cities or to stay overnight during his transit stops for Chen's Central American visit in late August as a way to express its discontent with Chen's intention to push for the referendum. Chen later called the treatment he received during his transit stops in Alaska "inconvenient, uncomfortable and indecent."
Shi stressed that though the United States adopted a deterrent policy to try to persuade Taiwan not to go through with the referendum, it has not changed its basic policy toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taipei Arts Festival to run until November

TEXT.P: The ninth Taipei Arts Festival, which opened Sunday at the plaza in front of Taipei Zhongshan Hall, will run until Nov. 11 and present some 30 performances by 22 domestic and foreign troupes at four locations.

The festival opened with a bang, with French theater troupe Compagnie Transe Express staging an hour-long performance of high-wire music and acrobatics and captivating the audience from beginning to end.

Other foreign troupes to perform in the festival include Musafir from India, Yohangza Company from South Korea, the Makhampom Theater Group from Thailand and Integrated Performing Arts Guild from the Philippines.
Taiwan's Contemporary Legend Theater will give its world premier of "108 Heroes -- Tales from the Water Margin" with four performances scheduled for Oct. 5-7 at the Taipei Cultural Center.

Eight other domestic groups, including Han Tang Yuefu Ensemble, Forum Music Ensemble, Shangchi Move Theater, Wind Dance Theater and the Wild Fire Music group, will give a series of concerts and dance performances at Da-an Forest Park.

From Nov. 2 to 11, three Taiwanese stars of experimental dance -- Wang Wei-ming, Yang Wen-chen and Sun Chuo-tai -- and Daniel Yeung, a choreographer from Hong Kong, will stage six performances at the Guling Street Avant-Garde Theater.
The Taipei Arts Festival, now in its ninth year, will also offer 16 workshops and seminars.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 high-tech labs to be inaugurated at Chengkung University

TEXT.P: The National Applied Research Laboratories (NARL) will open branches on nanotechnology and chip design at National Chengkung University (NCU) in southern Taiwan later this week, a university spokesman said Monday.

A name plate unveiling ceremony for the National Nano Device Laboratories and the National Chip Implementation Center will be held Oct. 3 to mark the beginning of the cooperation between the two sides, the spokesman.

According to the spokesman, the NARL, which is under the supervision of National Science Council, signed an agreement earlier this year with the university to further their cooperation in nanotechnology, advanced solar cell and chip design research.

The inauguration of the two laboratories in the university located in Tainan City is aimed at establishing a high-tech research and development base in southern Taiwan to balance the country's high-tech development in northern and southern regions, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sues ISO over incorrect reference

TEXT.P: Taiwan has filed a lawsuit against the International Organization for Standardization, widely known as ISO, over its reference to the country as "Taiwan Province, China" instead of "Republic of China (Taiwan)," an official said Monday.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, the government filed the suit with a court in Geneva July 20 after the ISO failed to respond positively to its repeated requests to rectify Taiwan's designation in the ISO 3166 country codes list.
Wang said the lawsuit was filed in the name of the government of the Republic of China (Taiwan).

Claiming that the ISO is in violation of Taiwan's name rights by using the "Taiwan Province, China" designation in its country codes list, the lawsuit demands the ISO stop using such a derogative reference and instead refer to Taiwan with its correct formal name "Republic of China (Taiwan)."
Wang further said that using the title "Republic of China (Taiwan) " not only complies with legal provisions and political reality but also meets the demands of various domestic political camps.

It marked the first time that Taiwan has taken a legal action against a major international organization over the name issue. The Geneva court has accepted the suit and the development of the issue will hinge on the court's judgment.

Over the past two years, Wang said, the country's representative office in Geneva has negotiated with the ISO authorities on many occasions and expressed the government's solemn stance on the issue by retaining lawyers to send letters of protest to the ISO headquarters.

Regrettably, Wang said, all such efforts have not received any goodwill response from the ISO. As the ISO 3166 list has been widely used in the international community, cases of international organizations and multinational business groups referring to the country as "Taiwan Province, China" have become increasingly prevalent.
"Such a development has not only invited misunderstanding and confusion for Taiwan but has also undermined Taiwan's national status and interests," Wang lamented.

Up until now, Wang said, the MOFA and the country's representative offices abroad have dealt with the issue on a case-by-case basis, asking each international organization or private corporation that refers to the country as "Taiwan Province, China" to correct the mistake.

However, such an approach cannot possibly resolve the issue once and for all, Wang said, adding that the government has thus decided to file a lawsuit against the ISO with a view to requiring it to revise its 3166 country codes list.

The Geneva-based ISO is an international standard-setting body composed of representatives from various national standards organizations. Founded on Feb. 23, 1947, the organization promulgates world-wide industrial and commercial standards. It is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.

While ISO defines itself as a non-governmental organization, its ability to set standards that often become law, either through treaties or national standards, makes it more powerful than most NGOs. In practice, ISO acts as a consortium with strong links to governments.
ISO officials once said that the 3166 list was formulated in 1974 in line with the United Nations practice of referring to Taiwan as "Taiwan Province, China."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice presidential candidate embarks on visit to U.S., Canada

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) vice presidential candidate departed Monday for a 12-day visit to the United States and Canada in a bid to help strengthen Taiwan's relations with the two countries.

Speaking prior to his departure from the Taoyuan International Airport, Vincent Siew said that the major purpose of his trip is to help re-build mutual trust and mend bilateral relations with the United States, which he claimed have sunk to a low ebb under the Democratic Progressive Party administration.
Siew, a former premier, stressed that he is not carrying out the mission for the KMT, but rather called it a task undertaken for the sake of the whole country.
"At a time when great diplomatic difficulties face the nation, any capable individual, regardless of his or her political affiliation, should act for the government," he said.

Siew was accompanied by John C. T. Feng, a former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, and Chan Chi-shean, a well-known doctor who once served as president of the Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center, among others on the tour.

While in the United States, Siew will visit officials at the State Department, the Department of Defense and those in charge of trade and finance affairs. He is also slated to meet secretarial staffs in charge of diplomatic affairs for the presidential candidates of both the Republican Party and the Democratic Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign professionals visit resource recycling plants in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: A group of foreign resource recycling professionals visited resource recycling plants in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan to acquire a better understanding of Taiwan's performance in this regard, an Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) official said Monday.

According to Liu Juei-hsiang, deputy executive secretary of the EPA's Recycling Fund Management Board, these foreign professionals came to Taiwan to attend the Resource Recycling Forum at the Taipei World Trade Center Oct. 3-5 and to exchange information on resource recycling.

Participants visiting the plants included Kenichi, professor of Kumamoto University, Hirotaka Ohki, senior managing director of Japan Automobile Recycling Promotion Center, Bertrand Schultz, president of European Battery Recycling Association, and Steve Andrews, director of Department of Enterprise, Business and Innovation of Britain.

They visited Thye Ming Industrial Co. in the county's Taliao township, which recycles about 36,000 tons of waste lead batteries per year, and an environmental engineering company that enjoyed an increase in recycling rate from 65 percent in 2001 to 72 percent in 2007.

Liu said Taiwan's recycling performance tops the world, with a recycling rate of 36 percent. The nation has over 500 resource recycling plants, and over 200 factories reusing recycled resources. It recycles about 220,000 waste vehicles every year, and enjoys a recycling rate greater than 70 percent when it comes to waste lead batteries.

The two companies these foreign resource recycling professionals visited are two of the nation's best, capable of fully displaying the results of Taiwan's efforts to promote resource recycling, Liu said. He went on that as 50 percent of waste is composed of recyclable resources, there is space for Taiwan to make further improvements.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25% of college students depressed: poll

TEXT.P: Approximately one in four university students who responded to a recent poll are constantly depressed, according to the results of the poll released by a local charitable organization Monday.

The John Tung Foundation, which devotes itself to the promotion of anti-smoking and public health in Taiwan, conducted the poll of students at 58 local universities and colleges in May and June. A total of 6,198 valid replies were collected.
The poll found that 25.7 percent of the respondents, up 1.4 percent from last year, suffer serious depression.
When in a bad mood, those surveyed said that they often deal by turning to their classmates or friends for help, or sleep or exercise, said Vivian Yeh, the foundation's mental health section chief.

In addition, the poll said that 5.5 percent of the respondents noted that they often relieved their depression by talking to their online friends. The ratio is higher than the 1.9 percent of those responding to the poll who said they would talk to school counselors about their depression, the poll went on.
According to the poll, women suffer higher levels of depression than their male counterparts. The poll also found that more first-year students than seniors are emotionally troubled.

Foundation Chairman Huang Chen-tai urged school counselors to take the initiative in caring for their students, adding that it is also necessary to help those who are depressed realize that it is not difficult to seek assistance.
Lai Tung-ming, chairman of the Good Neighborhood Foundation, for his part, noted that the foundation has designed a questionnaire to help the public determine whether they are troubled by depression.
Copies of the questionnaire have been made available at 4,000 7-eleven convenience stores around the country over the past seven years, Lai continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA rebuts Chinese FM's remarks at U.N. meeting

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) rebutted as "wrong claims" Monday Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi's recent remarks at a United Nations session in which he called Taiwan an inseparable part of China and criticized Taiwan's planned referendum on its U.N. bid as a move toward de jure independence.
Yang made the remarks in a speech delivered at a U.N. General Assembly session Sept. 28.

The MOFA rebutted Yang's allegations in a news release, pointing out that Taiwan and China have been unrelated since 1949, with no one subordinate to the other, for China has never had sovereignty over Taiwan nor has it had right to levy tax on the Taiwanese people. Taiwan is by no means a part of China, the press statement said.
It also stated that the U.N. Resolution 2758 only decided China's representation in the world body, but did not define Taiwan's relations with China, nor Taiwan's representation in the U.N.

Regretting that China and its allies have repeatedly cited the resolution to bar Taiwan from taking part in the United Nations, the statement said they have distorted the true meaning of Resolution 2758.

Moreover, the MOFA statement said China, not Taiwan, should be held responsible for causing tension across the Taiwan Strait. China's saber-rattling, missile threat and diplomatic suppression have made the two sides further apart and lack mutual trust, it added.
Popular support for holding a referendum on the U.N. bid proves that the people of Taiwan refuse to tolerate China's threats and unreasonable treatment any longer, the statement said.

It also defended Taiwan's diplomatic allies who have spoken up at the ongoing U.N. sessions for Taiwan's U.N. bid, saying that they would not stand to see the international community continually ignore Taiwan's right to joining the United Nations simply because of China's obstruction. China should not smeared Taiwan's diplomatic allies due to their support for Taiwan's cause, the MOFA statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese visitors to Taiwan this year expected to drop 30%

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to see a 30 percent reduction in tourist arrivals from China in 2007, mainly because Beijing has begun to forbid its nationals sightseeing in other countries to travel to Taiwan, a senior tourism official said Monday.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, told the Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee that the total number of tourist arrivals from China this year is estimated to be 70,000, down 30 percent from last year's 98,000.
She pointed out that China has not relaxed its policy to allow its citizens to visit Taiwan as tourists.

Although many Chinese tourists have come to Taiwan via a third country since May 2002 when Taiwan began to welcome the "second category of visitors from China," Beijing has now stepped up its efforts to prohibit them coming to Taiwan.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei told legislators on the Transportation Committee that "the ball is now in China's court."

Figures compiled by the Tourism Bureau show that although Taiwan's tourist arrivals in the first eight months this year saw a 4.5 percent increase over the same period of 2006, the number of visitors from China in the January-August period dropped 20 percent, with the total for the entire year of 2007 estimated at 70,000.
According to the Tourism Bureau, Taiwan recorded 3.52 million tourist arrivals in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president to help push for Myanmar democratization

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Monday that she will establish a network under the framework of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to help push for democratization of Myanmar.
Lu said that she will solicit support from the private sector and draw on Taiwan's experience of democratization in an effort to help the junta-ruled Southeast Asian country achieve democracy.
The DPU, an international body founded by Lu in 2005 and currently chaired by Lu, aims at promoting "democracy, peace, and prosperity" in the Asian Pacific region and the world.

Lu made the remarks at a seminar organized to voice support for the pro- democracy campaign in Myanmar. Also present at the seminar were Jerome Cohen -- Lu's mentor at Harvard University and a think tank senior researcher -- as well as with government officials and members of the DPU, the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, and a group of Taipei-based Japanese journalists.

Lu added that 15 years ago, she might have met the Japanese video reporter, Kenji Nagai, who was recently shot to death by a soldier in Myanmar as he was filming a bloody military clamp down on anti-government protests staged by local civilians and monks.

Lu recalled that in 1992, she planned to lead a group of courageous Taiwanese people to attend the National Day ceremony in Beijing to test how communist China would react to those who came from a democracy.

She said that at an international press conference called in Tokyo, one day prior to her planned trip to Beijing, she met the Japanese reporter who told her that he was a supporter of Aung San Suu Kyi, a pro-democracy activist and also the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner who has been under a house arrest over the past decade.
The reporter told Lu that he helped Suu Kyi several times, noting that Lu is very much like Suu Kyi, according to Lu.
The reporter later gave his camera, which he described as a "lucky camera, " to Lu as a lucky charm for her safety in China, Lu went on.
Lu said that she failed to enter China, but has cherished the gift ever since.
Hailing the reporter as a "hero, " Lu said that Nagai sacrificed his life for covering the event and standing up against unjust and arbitrary military government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grand justice roster becomes younger

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices has become younger with the addition of four new members to its roster Monday.

The council now has 11 grand justices, including Judicial Yuan President Lai In- jaw and his deputy Hsieh Tsay-chuan, both of whom were originally grand justices and assumed their new posts in a ceremony held earlier in the day.
According to the existing constitutional provisions, the Judicial Yuan president and vice president concurrently serve as grand justices.
The average age of the new Council of Grand Justices is approximately 57 years. Eight of the previous grand justices were older than 60.

The four new grand justices -- Lin Hsi-yao, Tsai Ching-you, Che Chi-ming and Lee Chen-shan -- are all from academic or judicial communities. As all of them are familiar with administrative and criminal laws, their recruitment will help upgrade the Council of Grand Justices' competence in interpreting constitutional provisions and safeguarding the dignity of the country's Constitution, judicial sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow TimesGOther Russia's Candidate is Kasparov
The Other Russia on Sunday chose Garry Kasparov as its unity candidate for the March presidential vote while confirming a party list of 450 candidates for the Dec. 2 State Duma elections, in which the party is not eligible to run. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman insists on quitting

TEXT.P: Outgoing ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun issued a statement late Monday, in which he reiterated his determination to step down from the party's chairmanship.

Yu asked the party's heavyweights not to try to retain him because he has no intention to stay at all. He urged them to start the process of selecting a successor to take over the party's helm as soon as possible.
Despite his departure from the top party post, Yu said he will continue working for the party's cause and help ensure the party's victory in the 2008 presidential and legislative elections.
Yu also called for all party workers and pro-independence civic groups to throw their support behind the party's presidential ticket and legislative candidates.

After he was indicted on graft charges over misuse of special allowance funds set aside for his discretionary use during his tenures as Presiential Office secretary-general and premier, Yu decided to quit after the party's Sept. 30 national congress. But he later decided to step down earlier after his proposal to add a more radical clause to the "normal country resoultion" to underscore the party's commitment to change the country's name to Taiwan and write a new constitution was rejected by the party's other bigwigs. He didn't attended Sunday's paty congress.

Party sources said Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan, who concurrently serves as top manager of presidential candidate Frank Hsieh's campaign office is likely to serve as DPP acting chairwoman if Yu rejects to return.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 1, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on Taiwan's participation in Frankfurt Book Fair Date and Time: 02:00 p.m., Tuesday, Oct. 2, 2007 Place: 561, Zhungxiao E. Road, Sec. 4, Taipei City
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sues ISO over incorrect reference

TEXT.P: Taiwan has filed a lawsuit against the International Organization for Standardization, widely known as ISO, over its reference to the country as "Taiwan Province, China" instead of "Republic of China (Taiwan)," an official said Monday.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, the government filed the suit with a court in Geneva July 20 after the ISO failed to respond positively to its repeated requests to rectify Taiwan's designation in the ISO 3166 country codes list.
Wang said the lawsuit was filed in the name of the government of the Republic of China (Taiwan).

Claiming that the ISO is in violation of Taiwan's name rights by using the "Taiwan Province, China" designation in its country codes list, the lawsuit demands the ISO stop using such a derogative reference and instead refer to Taiwan with its correct formal name "Republic of China (Taiwan)."
Wang further said that using the title "Republic of China (Taiwan) " not only complies with legal provisions and political reality but also meets the demands of various domestic political camps.

It marked the first time that Taiwan has taken a legal action against a major international organization over the name issue. The Geneva court has accepted the suit and the development of the issue will hinge on the court's judgment.

Over the past two years, Wang said, the country's representative office in Geneva has negotiated with the ISO authorities on many occasions and expressed the government's solemn stance on the issue by retaining lawyers to send letters of protest to the ISO headquarters.

Regrettably, Wang said, all such efforts have not received any goodwill response from the ISO. As the ISO 3166 list has been widely used in the international community, cases of international organizations and multinational business groups referring to the country as "Taiwan Province, China" have become increasingly prevalent.
"Such a development has not only invited misunderstanding and confusion for Taiwan but has also undermined Taiwan's national status and interests," Wang lamented.

Up until now, Wang said, the MOFA and the country's representative offices abroad have dealt with the issue on a case-by-case basis, asking each international organization or private corporation that refers to the country as "Taiwan Province, China" to correct the mistake.

However, such an approach cannot possibly resolve the issue once and for all, Wang said, adding that the government has thus decided to file a lawsuit against the ISO with a view to requiring it to revise its 3166 country codes list.

The Geneva-based ISO is an international standard-setting body composed of representatives from various national standards organizations. Founded on Feb. 23, 1947, the organization promulgates world-wide industrial and commercial standards. It is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.

While ISO defines itself as a non-governmental organization, its ability to set standards that often become law, either through treaties or national standards, makes it more powerful than most NGOs. In practice, ISO acts as a consortium with strong links to governments.
ISO officials once said that the 3166 list was formulated in 1974 in line with the United Nations practice of referring to Taiwan as "Taiwan Province, China."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice presidential candidate embarks on visit to U.S., Canada

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) vice presidential candidate departed Monday for a 12-day visit to the United States and Canada in a bid to help strengthen Taiwan's relations with the two countries.

Speaking prior to his departure from the Taoyuan International Airport, Vincent Siew said that the major purpose of his trip is to help re-build mutual trust and mend bilateral relations with the United States, which he claimed have sunk to a low ebb under the Democratic Progressive Party administration.
Siew, a former premier, stressed that he is not carrying out the mission for the KMT, but rather called it a task undertaken for the sake of the whole country.
"At a time when great diplomatic difficulties face the nation, any capable individual, regardless of his or her political affiliation, should act for the government," he said.

Siew was accompanied by John C. T. Feng, a former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, and Chan Chi-shean, a well-known doctor who once served as president of the Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center, among others on the tour.

While in the United States, Siew will visit officials at the State Department, the Department of Defense and those in charge of trade and finance affairs. He is also slated to meet secretarial staffs in charge of diplomatic affairs for the presidential candidates of both the Republican Party and the Democratic Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25% of college students depressed: poll

TEXT.P: Approximately one in four university students who responded to a recent poll are constantly depressed, according to the results of the poll released by a local charitable organization Monday.

The John Tung Foundation, which devotes itself to the promotion of anti-smoking and public health in Taiwan, conducted the poll of students at 58 local universities and colleges in May and June. A total of 6,198 valid replies were collected.
The poll found that 25.7 percent of the respondents, up 1.4 percent from last year, suffer serious depression.
When in a bad mood, those surveyed said that they often deal by turning to their classmates or friends for help, or sleep or exercise, said Vivian Yeh, the foundation's mental health section chief.

In addition, the poll said that 5.5 percent of the respondents noted that they often relieved their depression by talking to their online friends. The ratio is higher than the 1.9 percent of those responding to the poll who said they would talk to school counselors about their depression, the poll went on.
According to the poll, women suffer higher levels of depression than their male counterparts. The poll also found that more first-year students than seniors are emotionally troubled.

Foundation Chairman Huang Chen-tai urged school counselors to take the initiative in caring for their students, adding that it is also necessary to help those who are depressed realize that it is not difficult to seek assistance.
Lai Tung-ming, chairman of the Good Neighborhood Foundation, for his part, noted that the foundation has designed a questionnaire to help the public determine whether they are troubled by depression.
Copies of the questionnaire have been made available at 4,000 7-eleven convenience stores around the country over the past seven years, Lai continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA rebuts Chinese FM's remarks at U.N. meeting

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) rebutted as "wrong claims" Monday Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi's recent remarks at a United Nations session in which he called Taiwan an inseparable part of China and criticized Taiwan's planned referendum on its U.N. bid as a move toward de jure independence.
Yang made the remarks in a speech delivered at a U.N. General Assembly session Sept. 28.

The MOFA rebutted Yang's allegations in a news release, pointing out that Taiwan and China have been unrelated since 1949, with no one subordinate to the other, for China has never had sovereignty over Taiwan nor has it had right to levy tax on the Taiwanese people. Taiwan is by no means a part of China, the press statement said.
It also stated that the U.N. Resolution 2758 only decided China's representation in the world body, but did not define Taiwan's relations with China, nor Taiwan's representation in the U.N.

Regretting that China and its allies have repeatedly cited the resolution to bar Taiwan from taking part in the United Nations, the statement said they have distorted the true meaning of Resolution 2758.

Moreover, the MOFA statement said China, not Taiwan, should be held responsible for causing tension across the Taiwan Strait. China's saber-rattling, missile threat and diplomatic suppression have made the two sides further apart and lack mutual trust, it added.
Popular support for holding a referendum on the U.N. bid proves that the people of Taiwan refuse to tolerate China's threats and unreasonable treatment any longer, the statement said.

It also defended Taiwan's diplomatic allies who have spoken up at the ongoing U.N. sessions for Taiwan's U.N. bid, saying that they would not stand to see the international community continually ignore Taiwan's right to joining the United Nations simply because of China's obstruction. China should not smeared Taiwan's diplomatic allies due to their support for Taiwan's cause, the MOFA statement added.
