DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 2, or the 22nd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2001: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime.
2004: Iraqi insurgents shoot down a U.S. military helicopter near Baghdad, killing 36 soldiers and crewmen aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more allies back Taiwan's bid at U.N. General Assembly
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/02/07 13:28:03 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Two more of Taiwan's diplomatic allies expressed their support for the country's bid to join the United Nations Monday at the ongoing annual session of the U.N. General Assembly.

Raising the issue during the general debate of the session, Tuvaluan Deputy Prime Minister Tavau Teii expressed his country's disappointment at the fact that the world body has refused even to put the issue of Taiwan's membership bid on the agenda of the session.

Teii urged the United Nations to urgently address the issue of the Taiwan people's right to join the United Nations, stressing that Taiwan has the ability to fulfil its obligations as a full member of the world body as required under the U.N. Charter.
"The United Nations cannot be said to be universal, nor can global peace and security be assured until the issue of membership for Taiwan in the organization is properly resolved," Teii said.

Meanwhile, Patteson Oti, minister of foreign affairs, external trade and immigration of the Solomon Islands, attributed the "indignity" suffered by Taiwan to what he called "organized international hypocrisy" by "a powerful constellation of states interested only in the protection of trade and investment rather than any humanitarian concerns."

Oti said Solomon Islanders have a native empathy for all people who are struggling to reclaim what is rightfully due to them under international law, adding that his country's preference is to recognize both China and Taiwan "on a realistic rather than an imaginary politico-juridical footing."

Oti urged the General Assembly to implore China to pledge to use peaceful means to settle its sovereignty dispute with Taiwan and proposed that the Security Council launch an investigation into the cross-Taiwan Strait situation to determine whether it is likely to endanger international peace and security.

Also Monday, the U.N. representative of Malawi wrote letters to U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon; Srgjan Kerim, president of the 62nd session of the General Assembly; and Leslie Christian, Ghana's permanent representative to the United Nations who is serving as the president of the Security Council for the month of October, urging the world body to deal with Taiwan's membership application "properly and seriously."

While Taiwan has tried without success to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993, this year marks the first time the country has applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan.

However, following the return of Taiwan's application by the U.N. Secretariat first in July and again in August, an item endorsed by 16 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the United Nations to address Taiwan's membership application has also been excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Krosa likely to affect Taiwan this weekend: CWB

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Krosa, which formed Tuesday morning in waters east of the Philippines, is likely to affect Taiwan in four to five days, Central Weather Bureau forecasters said.
As of Tuesday morning, the storm was centered 1,200 km east-southeast of Oluanpi -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan, packing maximum sustained winds of 75 kph, the forecasters said.
They said that the storm has shown signs of lingering in its present position and that no major changes in its movement are expected over the next couple of days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MND to review control mechanism for handling confidential papers

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu said Tuesday the military needs to review its current mechanism for handling confidential papers in order to plug information leaks.

Lee made the remarks after the Apple Daily reported that an orderly at Chief of General Staff Hou Shou-yeh's office had not rigorously followed the standard procedures of destroying shredded confidential papers and had instead sold them to a private recycling operator for profit.
A reporter for the local daily was able to buy two bags of

the shredded confidential papers for NT$40 (US$1.2) and to piece them together to obtain information concerning the movement of China's air and sea forces, Taiwan's military drills, and the movement of U.S. armed forces, according to the report.

Lee, while communicating with the opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus on next year's central government budget, said that he was indignant upon learning of the news and that Gen. Hou was also very upset.
Lee said that the ministry's paper shredding machines are very old and do not shred documents into small enough strips, which he added is a problem that the ministry needs to address.
On possible information leaks, Lee said that he has instructed related personnel to deal with the matter according to regulations.
The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said in a press release Tuesday that the orderly's actions represented a dereliction of duty.

The MND stressed that the military has established rigorous procedures for the handling and destroying of confidential papers and that the ministry will step up educating of military personnel about secret keeping.
The ministry said it will also review the control mechanism within the military thoroughly to avoid a repeat of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices soar on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 134.75 points to close at 9,623.25.
The bourse opened at 9,597.96 and fluctuated between 9,642.95 and 9,582.7 during trading. A total of 6.7 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$206.39 billion (US$6.34 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 3.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 2.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent.
Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.5 percent, and textile stocks at 0.9 percent.
Construction issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to, 857, with 231 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 168 points to close at 9,669, with 38,781 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November increased 163 points to finish at 9,675, with 428 contracts traded, while December futures increased 190 points to end at 9,680, with 64 contract transactions. March futures moved up 169 points to close at 9,680, with five contract transactions, while June futures increased 188 points to end at 9,670, with 10 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,501 for October, 9,512 for November, 9,490 for December, 9,511 for March and 9,482 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

October TE futures increased 5.8 points to close at 399.3, with 3,161 contracts traded, while November TE futures increased 5.45 points to finish at 398.8, with 41 contract transactions. December TE futures rose 1.5 points to finish at 395.2, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures gained 40 points to close at 1,076.8, with 5,722 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 43 points to finish at 1,076, with 56 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. remains most popular destination for overseas study

TEXT.P: The United States remains the most popular destination for Taiwan students to pursue tertiary education overseas, followed by the United Kingdom, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Ministry of Education.

The statistics show that a total of 34,811 Taiwan students went abroad to pursue tertiary education last year, including 16,451 to the United States, 9,653 to the United Kingdom, 2,862 to Australia, 2,108 to Japan and 1,997 to Canada.
Among all international students in the United States, students from Taiwan formed the sixth largest group, behind only those from India, China, South Korea, Japan and Canada, in that order.

Overseas education consultants said the tallies indicate that most Taiwan students prefer to pursue tertiary education in English-speaking countries, although the study destination choices of Taiwan students have become more diversified in recent years.
The consultants advised students interested in pursuing tertiary education overseas to visit the various education fairs scheduled to begin this month to obtain the information they need.

The Australian education fair will be held in Taichung on Tuesday and in Kaohsiung on Wednesday, while the Canadian education fair is slated to be held in Kaohsiung Oct. 5 and in Taipei Oct. 6-7, and the the American education fair will be held in Taipei Oct. 13-14, in Taichung Oct. 16 and Kaohsiung Oct. 15.

The European education fair is scheduled to be held in Taipei Nov. 3-4, and the British education fair is slated to be held in Taipei Nov. 3-4, Kaohsiung Nov. 6, Taichung Nov. 7 and Hsinchu Nov. 8, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA explains President's October trip to Marshall Islands

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will take a direct flight to the Marshall Islands in October for a meeting with his counterparts from Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Yu Teh-sheng, deputy director general of the MOFA Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, indicated at the MOFA's routine press conference that President Chen is scheduled to attend the second summit of heads of state between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies Oct. 12-13.
According to the announced plan, Chen will take off Oct. 11, and return to Taipei Oct. 14. The president will not fly to other allied nations during the four-day journey, Yu said.
Taiwan maintains diplomatic relations with Palau, Tuvalu, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati and Nauru in the South Pacific region.
Yu said presidents of those countries will join the 2007 summit, except President of Kiribati Anote Tong who has informed Taiwan that his vice president will participate in the meeting on his behalf.
Tong is occupied by his re-election campaign, Yu added.
Meanwhile, sources at the MOFA revealed that an aircraft with a capacity of 200 people will be commissioned to fly President Chen and a large group of his entourage directly to the Marshall Islands.

At the press conference, Yu also addressed the high-profile meeting between South Korean President Roh Moo-hyun and his North Korean counterpart Kim Jong- il, which began in Pyongyang, North Korea earlier the day.
Yu said the MOFA has been paying close attention to the regional situation and interactions between the Korean leaders.

Speaking of the possibility that the United State might strike North Korea from its list of countries that support terrorism and set up a liaison office in Pyongyang after the communist country promised to give up its nuclear facility in September, Yu said Taiwan will also begin efforts to forge goodwill between Taiwan and North Korea, and explore private channels in search of opportunities for bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.005 to close at NT$32.573.
A total of US$1.249 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.547 and fluctuated between NT$32.521 and NT$32.599.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 NTSO music festival to launch Oct. 6

TEXT.P: The 2007 International Music Festival organized by National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra (NTSO) will begin Oct. 6 in Taichung City in central Taiwan, an NTSO spokesman said Tuesday.

The NTSO has designed 10 different series for the festival that will include a total of 17 concerts and last about two months. Venues for the festival include the Chung Hsing Hall in Taichung City, Wufeng Concert Hall in Taichung County, National Concert Hall in Taipei City, and eastern Taiwan.
A variety of music forms such as symphony, chamber music, and solo recitals will be featured in the festival, the spokesman said.
The organizer has invited the Malaysian Philharmonic Orchestra and the Singapore Symphony Orchestra, both new and outstanding Asian philharmonic ensembles, to perform.

World-renowned chamber music groups like the Berliner Barock Solisten will present Baroque music, featuring flutist Emmanuel Pahud, the spokesman said, adding that soloists like oboe master Hansjorg Shellenberger and pianist Gergely Boganyi will also perform at the invitation of the NTSO.

Wong Chin-chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, said the festival will not only bring prolific musicians to the Taiwanese people but will also make the international community aware of Taiwan's music scene.
The NTSO will also open master classes in which Boganyi and violinist Ernst Kovacic will give lessons, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President outlines qualifications of ideal DPP chairman

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has to be a top campaign manager so as to help DPP candidates win the upcoming legislative and presidential elections.

The president was responding to questions on whom will succeed Yu Shyi-kun who recently resigned when he and Vice President Annette Lu attended the 30th anniversary of the Taichung Youth Industrial Park in central Taiwan.

The president said that he hopes the next DPP chairman will serve as the party's volunteer and handyman. The chairman should also serve as a coordinator so as to promote party cohesion and forge a broad-based party consensus, Chen said.

Last but not the least, the chairman should be able to stump successfully for DPP legislative candidates and the presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang as well as help Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations.
Asked who would be the ideal candidate to serve as party chairman, the president said "Vice President Lu standing beside me would be the best candidate."

Despite calls for President Chen to again serve concurrently as the party chairman and president, a local newspaper reported Tuesday that Yeh Chu-lan, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, has been tapped to become the acting DPP chairwoman.
Chen concurrently served as the party chairman 2002-2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outgoing DPP chairman supports president as successor

TEXT.P: Outgoing ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun expressed his support Tuesday for a proposal urging President Chen Shui-bian to succeed him as party chairman.

Noting that it is consistent with the DPP's system for the president to serve concurrently as party chairman, Yu said such an arrangement will facilitate the implementation of party policies and focus attention on the party's election campaigns.
Chen, who last held the position of DPP chairman in 2002, resigned in December 2004 to assume responsibility for the party's failure to win a majority in the 2004 legislative elections.

Yu originally decided to step down after the party's Sept. 30 national congress, in the wake of his indictment Sept. 21 on corruption and forgery charges for alleged misuse of his "special allowance funds" during his tenures as the president's chief of staff from 2000-2002 and 2005-2006 and as premier from 2002-2005.

However, Yu immediately expressed his intention to resign Sept. 27, after his proposal to add a more radical clause to the "normal country resolution" to underscore the party's commitment to change the country's name to Taiwan and write a new constitution was rejected by other party leaders.
With his resignation offer yet to be approved by the party, Yu Monday reiterated his determination to step down and asked the party's heavyweights not to try to retain him any more.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wholesalers arrested for selling counterfeit fashion goods

TEXT.P: Three wholesalers in the southern port city of Kaohsiung have been arrested on suspicion of distributing counterfeit fashion goods to local retailers, police sources said Tuesday.

Members of a police squad formed to protect intellectual property rights and crack down on commercial piracy found more than 4,000 fake brand-name fashion items during a raid Monday on storehouses owned by the wholesalers in the city's Yencheng district and Sanmin district, the sources said.
A large number of boutique handbags and personal adornments carrying various fake brand-name labels, including Hello Kitty, Meloday and Innamoroll, were seized in the raid, according to the sources.
The wholesalers claimed that all those items were imported from China and South Korea, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI, Hwa-chuang signed pact to develop driver safety sensor system

TEXT.P: A memorandum of understanding to develop a new driver safety sensor system has been signed by the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and Hwa-chuang Automobile Technical Center Co., sources at both sides disclosed Tuesday.

In the first stage, the system will be capable of monitoring the driver's heartbeat and breathing to determine his physical status and to warn him in case of falling asleep or losing consciousness, they noted.

Duann Jia-ruey, general director of ITRI's Center for Measurement Standards (CMS), said that as long as the driver is within a one meter radius of the system, the system, based on ultra wideband sensing technology, is able to detect the driver's biological functions remotely.
Duann added that the same technology can also be applied to remote medical care monitoring system, that will be especially helpful with such patients as children or the elderly.

Liu Yi-cheng, general manager of Hwa-chuang Co., predicted that in the following stages of research and development, several other key features will be integrated into the system, including a drunken driving sensor and an active safety system capable of detecting the vehicle's parameters for potential hazards.

Blackwater security contractors in Iraq have been involved in at least 195 "escalation of force" incidents since early 2005, including several previously unreported killings of Iraqi civilians, according to a new congressional account of State Department and company documents.

The Senate yesterday overwhelmingly approved a $648 billion defense authorization bill that faces a veto by President Bush over a provision that protects homosexuals under federal hate-crime laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien reports 89 enterovirus cases among schoolchildren

TEXT.P: Hualien County in eastern Taiwan has reported 89 cases of enterovirus among schoolchildren in the first nine months of this year, resulting in the temporary closure of eight kindergartens and nurseries, the Department of Health under the Hualien County government said Tuesday.
Health officials reminded parents to teach their children good hygienic habits as the second wave of the disease usually strikes between September and October.

They also urged the parents to heed early symptoms of infection, which include drowsiness, fever, stiff neck and numb limbs, twitching as well as shortness of breath, and urged parents to seek treatment as soon as possible if they detect such symptoms.

Enteroviruses are spread from person to person through contact with the nasal secretions, saliva or stool of an infected person, or by contact with surfaces contaminated with bodily secretions from an infected person.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Report Says Firm Sought to Cover Iraq Shootings
Employees of Blackwater USA have engaged in nearly 200 shootings in Iraq since 2005, in a vast majority of cases firing their weapons from moving vehicles without stopping to count the dead or assist the wounded, according to a new report from Congress.
The Wall Street Journal: Dow Hits Record Despite Losses At Big Banks
Stocks soared to a new all-time high even as two of the world's biggest banks reported billions of dollars in losses connected to bad mortgages, suggesting that investors already are shrugging off the problems that rocked global financial markets only weeks ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Judicial Yuan head vows to defend judicial independence

TEXT.P: New Judicial Yuan President Lai In-jaw has vowed to defend judicial independence from political interference, which he set as one of his key goals upon assuming his new position.

Lai made the remarks at his inauguration ceremony Monday, during which he and Hsieh Tsay-chuan were sworn in as the Judicial Yuan's President and Vice President. Lai replaced retiring Weng Yueh-sheng.

Lai expressed hope that the Judicial Yuan will make all-out efforts to defend judicial independence, which he identified as an important principle enshrined in the Constitution, and a crucial support of good social order.

Lai pointed out that Weng, who devoted more than 35 years to the country's judicial work, promoted many reforms of court organization, the litigation system, judicial personnel recruitment, and judicial administration during his tenure as Judicial Yuan president.
Weng's efforts have borne fruitful results, Lai said, adding that he will continue the nation's judicial reforms by enacting pragmatic measures.

Future judicial tasks will include efforts to acquire additional judicial personnel and resources in order to improve trial efficiency, and will also enhance judicial ethics, and the cultivation of ahumanitarian spirit through education to better trial quality, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Int'l Flower Exhibition to open at end of October

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition will be held Oct. 31-Nov. 4 at the Taipei World Trade Center, with local growers and counterparts from six other countries -- the Netherlands, Australia, Japan, Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia -- invited to showcase their special flora, a spokesman for the event organizer, the Council of Agriculture (COA), said Tuesday.
Chen Wen-teh, director general of the COA International Cooperation Department, said it has been 12 years since the last flower exhibition of this kind was held in 1995.

In that year, the value of Taiwan's flower production was a mere NT$9 billion (US$276.24 million), with exports worth US$9.7 million. National output has since grown to NT$12.5 billion, while exports surged to US$78 million in 2006, Chen noted.

Taiwan's flower exports have also seen changes in flora strains over the 12-year period, Chen went on, indicating that chrysanthemum was the major export in 1995, but that this flower has been gradually replaced by other flowers, including dancing lady and butterfly orchids, as well as Eustoma.
Over the years, Taiwan's flower output has greatly improved in terms of quality and variety thanks to local farmers' dedication to developing new strains and seeking new markets, Chen said.

The long-awaited show will be only open to foreign buyers on the first day of the event, with representatives of 500 businesses from 30 countries accredited to visit the venue, according to the organizer.
Public visits are welcome Nov. 1-4, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Tax cuts - first shots in the battle for votes
Plans for an autumn general election were being stepped up last night after proposals to exclude all but millionaires from paying inheritance tax electrified the Tory conference. Tax was thrown into the centre of the election battleground as Labour claimed that the Tories could not afford George Osbornes proposal to raise the inheritance tax threshold from G300,000 to G1 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Rep. to U.S. denies meddling with KMT candidate's trip
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/07 19:23:50 (Jorge Liu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the United States Tuesday dismissed as "groundless" a report from Taipei that he was going out of his way to interfere with a visit to the United States by Taiwan opposition Kuomintang's vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew.
Joseph Wu said he wouldn't do any such thing, nor would the U.S. government allow him to interfere.

He made the comment after claims were published in a Taipei-based newspaper that he is trying to spoil Siew's visit by preventing, as far as possible, the opposition candidate from meeting U.S. senior officials.

Wu said U.S. officials had told him before the July visit of Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, that they would extend the same treatment to Hsieh's opposition counterpart, adding that there is no way for his office to sway the host country on this regard.

Contrary to the report in the Taipei-based paper, the leading Taiwan official in the United States said his office would do its best to help Siew arrange his itinerary in the United States, although he has not yet received any information on Siew's trip thus far.

His remarks were supported by the KMT's representative to Washington, Jason Yuan, who claimed that he had seen nothing to indicate that Taipei's officials in Washington are trying to frustrate Siew's visit until he read the report on paper.

Yuan said he didn't believe that there was any truth to the report as Siew will prod Washington to conclude a free trade agreement with his country during his meetings with U.S. officials, which benefit Taiwan and is consistent with efforts made by Wu's office.
Siew will arrive in Washington later in the day for a four day visit. He will then travel to California, where he will fly from San Francisco to Canada for a six day visit to that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Bartenders Association meeting to be held in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: More than 600 bartenders and guests from 56 countries will attend the International Bartenders Association (IBA) meeting in Kaohsiung next month, the Bartenders Association of Taiwan (BAT) announced Tuesday.
Announcing the news at a press conference, BAT officials said the IBA meeting, as well as the International Cocktail and Flairtending Competition, will be held in the southern port city Nov. 24-25.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan, who spoke at the press conference, expressed hope that Taiwanese bartenders can keep the championship of the competition in Taiwan.
Yeh is credited with promoting bartending during her tenure as acting Kaohsiung mayor 2005-2006.
She also lauded Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

She said that Hsieh, during his tenure as Kaohsiung mayor 1998-2005, used some of the "special allowance fund" set aside for his discretionary use to train young bartenders and encourage them to excel in the job.
Yeh said Taiwanese bartenders have made their mark during major competitions in recent years and that they often note that they "come from Taiwan" during award ceremonies.
She expressed the hope that those who enter the competition this year will be spokespeople of Taiwan so as to raise the country's profile in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Pride parade to showcase `rainbow power'

TEXT.P: An annual parade of the gay, bisexual and transgender (GBT) communities will be held Oct. 13 in downtown Taipei to showcase the "rainbow power" of these communities whose members are often discriminated against, parade organizers said Tuesday.

The parade, which is entering its fifth year and is expected to draw over 10,000 participants, will make its way down Zhongxiao East Road and end in the square behind Taipei City Hall, where a stage will be set up for music performances, said Wang Ping, chief convener of the parade.

Taiwan's GBT communities ask for anti-discrimination, equality, diversity and respect with the parade, which can also be seen as a platform for them to directly dialogue with other citizens, Wang said.

From a humble beginning of only 1,000 participants in the inaugural 2003 parade to more than 10,000 participants last year, the parade has established itself as the biggest of its kind in Asia, said the president of the Taiwan Tongzhi Hotline Association, who uses the alias Gofyy.

"It's true that the movement in Taiwan still has a long way to go, but we are very proud at the same time to say that it plays a leading example compared to other Asian countries, such as Japan and Thailand, " said Gofyy.
To boost the visibility of the event, popular local singer A-Mei has been named the rainbow ambassador of the parade, Gofyy said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nail polish found to contain excessive lead concentrations

TEXT.P: One nail polish product of 46 samples examined by the Consumers' Foundation (CF) was found to contain lead in excess of 1,000 ppm, far beyond the 20 ppm limit, CF Chairman Cheng Jen-hung said Tuesday.
The substandard product is in the brand of "BICHUN," Cheng said.

The 46 samples were collected during March at 10-dolar shops, night markets, grocery stores, and department stores in Taipei, Taichung, Nantou, Changhua, Tainan, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung areas, Cheng said. All of the samples were colored red, Cheng added.

Cheng said lead can be absorbed through the skin, mouth or nose. People who have long-term contact with lead are susceptible to lead intoxication, which can cause anemia, renal failure, and pathological changes of the cranial nerves.
He suggested consumers avoid nail biting while wearing nail polish, and avoid using nail polish too frequently.
Moreover, Cheng pointed out that some 67 percent, or 31 of the 46 examined samples, were improperly labeled.

According to Cheng, the sixth article of the Cosmetics Sanitary Control Act stipulates that a list detailing the composition, purpose, usage, weight, quantity, factory address, approval number and date at which the product leaves the factory, should all be included on product labels.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 Asian countries take part in Asia Trade Promotion Forum

TEXT.P: Representatives from 15 member countries of the Asia Trade Promotion Forum (ATPF) are participating in an event to promote its Capacity Building Initiative Program (CBIP) which opened Monday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

The CBIP, part of an ATPF exchange program now in its fifth year, was organized by the quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and will run through Wednesday, a TAITRA official said Tuesday.

The official noted that this is the first time that Taiwan has won the right to host a CBIP meeting. It is hoped that the series of activities will allow Taiwan to demonstrate its economic power and help bolster its international profile, he added.

According to the official, ATPF was initiated by the Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO) to promote multilateral exchanges among more than 20 ATPF member countries. The JETRO now acts as secretariat of the forum. The official said the member countries take turns hosting its annual meeting.

This year, nearly 30 trade promotion organizations from 15 countries have sent representatives to attend the program in Taiwan, including Japan, South Korea, Australia, China, Hong Kong, Macau, Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, Nepal, India, Sri Lanka and Mongolia.

The official said the program serves as a platform for members to exchange experiences in international trade promotion in order to upgrade the service quality offered by their trade promotion organizations.

TAITRA will also organize a trip for program participants to visit a newly completed exhibition hall in the Nankang district of Taipei City, and arrange for them to embark on the Taiwan High Speed Railway and take a cultural tour of central Taiwan to learn more about the development of local cultural and recreation industries and experience the beauty of the central island landscape.

DOC.HEADLINE: GBT communities expect more than words from local politicians

TEXT.P: Election candidates are welcome to do more than speak up for gay rights so they can secure votes from members of the gay, bisexual and transgender (GBT) communities, representatives from these communities said Tuesday.

"Taiwan society has been more open for the awareness of gay rights, and many election candidates want votes from this specific group. However, they have to submit their `beef' rather than just offering lip service, " said the president of the Taiwan Tongzhi Hotline Association (TTHA), who goes by the alias Gofyy.

The U.S.-based Kinsey Institute estimates that 10 percent of the human population are gay, bisexual or transgender, he said, adding that this fact makes such communities a focus group politicians cannot afford to ignore.
More often than not, however, Gofyy said, politicians and candidates say they support gay rights but fail to come up with substantial opinions and policies.

"GBT communities welcome any support, but these people are not fools either. They know very well who are for real and who are not. Candidates cannot expect to win votes by simply participating in gay pride parades and offering vocal support, " he said.
The annual "Taiwan Pride Parade, " organized by TTHA and more than a dozen GBT groups, is set for Oct. 13 in downtown Taipei to raise gay rights awareness.
GBT communities in Taiwan have been establishing "observation groups" in past elections to examine candidates' opinions and positions on gay rights, Gofyy said.

"Some candidates who have shown support for GBT groups during their campaigns never did anything after being elected. Some did push for new legislation or amendments but in the end they were stuck in the Legislative Yuan due to opposition from conservative legislators, " he said.
Two major elections are coming up in Taiwan, while legislative elections scheduled to be held at the end of 2007 and the presidential election set for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Yat-sen University's Performing Arts Season opens

TEXT.P: The Siwan Performing Arts Season organized by National Sun Yat-sen University opened Tuesday and will continue for more than three months until Jan. 6, 2008.
The season began with an exhibition of paintings by Li Meige, who specializes in traditional Chinese thick color painting. The exhibition will run until Oct. 14.
On Oct. 6, a student troupe and an orchestra from Tunghai University in Taichung will stage a classical opera.

Tseng Dau-hsiong, who is an opera conductor, baritone and musical educator, will give a lecture on Mozart's opera seria, Idomeneo, Re di Crete Oct. 20, while Chinese opera singer Wang Hey-ling will speak on "Famous Opera Singers and Their Fans" Oct. 31.

Kimbo Hu, the Taiwan aboriginal singer who has earned himself the title of "Father of Folksongs" in Taiwan, will stage a concert titled "Sing the Songs of My Own," together with Taiwan folk group Wild Fire Nov. 2.

A cello ensemble from Sun Yat-sen University will present "From Song of the Birds to the Swinging Cello" Oct. 12, while the Baroque Camerata, also from the university, will give a concert titled "Rethinking Bach" Nov. 9.
The Baroque Camerata, together with the Kaohsiung Chamber Choir, will give another concert Dec. 11.
The acclaimed Polish composer Zygmunt Krauze will give a piano recital, "The Night of Poland," at the Sun Yat-sen Hall Nov. 19.
On Nov. 24, renowned vocalist Chang Pao-lang will give a recital titled "Unforgettable Folk Rhyme" featuring Taiwanese folk songs.
The renowned Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera Co. will stage a play, "Red Gate Light Breeze," Dec. 2.
Other performances will include cosplay by Gin-Ing-Ger Puppet Troupe and dance by the Dance Forum Taipei troupe.

A second art exhibition will take place Oct. 23 through Nov. 25 featuring works by faculty members of Sun Yat-sen University and their families, while another exhibition by Taiwanese artist Liang Yifen will run from Nov. 29 to Jan. 6 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Xiamen tourist group visits Penghu via 'mini links'

TEXT.P: A tourist group from Xiamen in China's Fujian province arrived in Taiwan's Penghu Island Tuesday for a four-day visit via the "mini-three links" between Taiwan-held Kinmen Island and Fujian Province.

The group, consisting of more than 280 tourists from Xiamen, is the first tourist group from Xiamen to visit Penghu via the direct ferry service, commonly known as the mini-three links, since Fujian authorities allowed their citizens to sightsee in Penghu.
The tourists traveled from Xiamen on board various ferries sailing between the two sides to Kinmen, from where they took charter flights to Penghu.

A Xiamen-based tour agency operator said that Penghu would be able to attract more Xiamen tourists if regular flights were established between Kinmen and Penghu islands to shorten travel time and lower costs.
On Sept. 28, a tourist group from Fujian's Quanzhou City also arrived in Penghu via the "mini three links" for sightseeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local airline launches Taichung-Ho Chi Minh City charter flights

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Uni Airways launched its first charter flight from Taichung Airport in central Taiwan to Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam Tuesday.
The service will offer three charter flights per week on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. The three flights boosts another seven per week run by another local carrier, Mandarin Airlines.

Uni Air Chairman Tony Su said Uni Air will operate another charter flight service between Taichung and Hong Kong from Oct. 24. The new route will have 11 flights per week, along with another 12 flights run by Mandarin Airlines.

Uni Air started charter flights between Taichung and Japan in February, Su went on, adding that the airline sees good business potential for Taichung Airport and plans to make it an important center for international aviation service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor disappointed over sports lottery bidding

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu expressed strong disappointment Tuesday over a Ministry of Finance (MOF) formal announcement of the winning bank of the country's first sports lottery to be launched next year.

Chen urged the ministry not to make the public lose faith in the sports lottery issuer and pushed prosecution authorities to finish an investigation into the role of the bid winner, Taipei Fubon Bank, in an insider trading scandal as soon as possible.
Chen made the remarks at a city government meeting in the southern port city one day after the MOF announced Taipei Fubon Bank as the winner of the sports lottery license.
The ministry had delayed the announcement since Sept. 3 when an MOF screening committee selected Taipei Fubon Bank over two other bidders -- the Bank of Kaohsiung and Chinatrust Commercial Bank.

The delay was the result of widespread concern about Fubon Financial Holding Co. Chief Investment Officer Daniel Chiang, who was detained for questioning by prosecutors in August over his alleged role in Standard Chartered Bank's acquisition of Hsinchu International Bank and was recently released on bail pending further probes.
Taipei Fubon Bank is a division of Fubon Financial Holding Co., the second- biggest financial services provider in Taiwan.
Chen described the Kaohsiung city government, which partially owns the Bank of Kaohsiung, as "highly disappointed" over the MOF announcement.

Chen said the Bank of Kaohsiung filed a complaint with the MOF over the bidding process last month and had yet to receive the response. The ministry's decision to make the announcement at this point will prompt the public to question the propriety of the bidding process and lose confidence in the sports lottery, she claimed.

However, Vice Minister of Finance Liu Teng-cheng defended the announcement, saying that the ministry had asked the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) whether Taipei Fubon Bank is involved in the scandal and whether the bank will be punished.
Quoting the FSC, Liu said Taipei Fubon Bank has received no punishment for violating any financial regulations since one year before the bank filed its application for the sports lottery bid.
There is also no substantial evidence to suggest that the bank is involved in the Hsinchu bank acquisition scandal, Liu noted.

In addition, Taipei Fubon Bank promised last week that it will unconditionally give up its rights to run the sports lottery if punished by the FSC in the future due to its involvement in the insider trading case, Liu added.

Speaking of the possibility that the delayed announcement will lead to a postponement of the planned date for the official launch of the sports lottery, Liu said that in principle, Taipei Fubon Bank will still launch the lottery April 15 as scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICDF to help promote local tourism development

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) will hold an activity in the northern city of Hsinchu to share Taiwan's success in local community and tourism development with Taiwan's African diplomatic allies, an official said Tuesday.
Chang Nan-chang, head of the ICDF's International Human Resources Development Department, made the remarks at a press conference at the Hsinchu City Hall.

Also present at the press conference were officials from Hsinchu City, Hsinchu County and Miaoli County in northern Taiwan, as well as officials from the Gambia and Burkina Faso, two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Africa.

The activity, to take place Oct. 5 at a coastal park in Hsinchu City, is part of the ICDF's collaboration with the three local governments to increase foreign officials' understanding of Taiwan's achievements, Chang said.

The foundation will also hold additional activities Oct. 4 in the city and counties to offer the foreign officials an opportunity to interact with local residents, Chang said, adding that the hands-on experience will help the officials understand local people's responses to government policies.
The officials will also be taken on a tour of local tourist attractions and traditional industries, Chang went on.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs-run ICDF is tasked with coordinating Taiwan's overseas aid projects for developing countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will be `reborn:' VP

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be "reborn" within six months as the country is set to start a new phase of judicial reform now that the Judicial Yuan has got a new president, Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday.

Lu made the remarks in a local development seminar in Chiayi City in southern Taiwan sponsored by Taiwan Heart -- a non-profit group initiated by the vice president to carry out various social welfare programs.

According to Lu, the country will embark on a new stage of judicial reform from now until the inauguration of the next president May 20, 2008 after Lai In-jaw took over the post as Judicial Yuan president from Weng Yueh-sheng Oct. 1, and because the Control Yuan will also rekindle its routine operations next year after a hiatus of more than two years.

Taiwan Heart is committed to joining forces with the nation's judicial reformers in the coming months as the legislative and presidential elections approach, she said, adding that group members will assist government authorities in wiping out vote buying and other irregularities in the run-up to the two major elections.

Apart from political issues, Lu said, the group will also do its best to recruit more professionals, such as lawyers and doctors, to further advocate social benevolence projects. She expressed the hope that Taiwan Heart will have more than 70,000 members by the end of this year to help advance social welfare programs.
Lu said Taiwan Heart will continue promoting meaningful projects in society even though she has to step down from the vice presidency next May.

Commenting on the country's failure to obtain U.N. membership under the name Taiwan this year, Lu said the government at least has done something and the move has helped increase Taiwan's visibility in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Boycott of Taiwan U.N. Day proposal `unacceptable': spokesman

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers' boycott of a Cabinet proposal to designate Oct. 24 as "Taiwan United Nations Day" is "unacceptable," Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.

Shieh, who concurrently serves as Government Information Office (GIO) minister, made the remarks after lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) blocked the proposal earlier in the day from being placed on the agenda for discussion at Friday's legislative plenary session.

Shieh said the boycott of the proposal demonstrates that the KMT opposes the country's U.N.-membership bid, even though the party initiated a campaign for a referendum on pushing for the country's return to the U.N. under the country's official name "Republic of China."

Describing President Chen Shui-bian's campaign to join the U.N. under the name Taiwan as the "common aspiration" of the Taiwanese people, Shieh said the Cabinet will submit the "U.N. Day" proposal to the legislature again.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu vaccine safe: pediatricians

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Pediatric Association (TPA) Tuesday urged people considered to be at high risk of influenza to take advantage of free vaccinations offered by the government, saying that the mercury-containing vaccine is safe.

Amid public concern about the mercury content in flu vaccine, TPA President Lin Tzou-yien and Assistant Secretary-General Lee Ping-ing released a joint statement to claim the safety of the vaccine which contains thimerosal -- an organomercury compound that has been commonly used as an antiseptic and antifungal agent in some vaccines since the 1930s.
In the statement, the pediatricians claimed that the organomercury "cannot cause illness" and that it is discharged from the human body soon after the injection of the thimerosal-containing vaccine.

The statement quoted results of a joint research by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, Harvard University and Stanford University targeting 1,074 children aged between seven and 10 through a comprehensive neurophysiologic evaluation.
The research, which was published on the influential New England Journal of Medicine in September, concluded that mercury-containing vaccines have caused no side effect on childrens' nervous systems.

A comment in the popular weekly general medical journal also says that the issue of mercury-containing vaccines has been magnified in an irrational manner in the U.S. to a political and judiciary problem, the TPA said, urging the Taiwan people to be "rational."

Earlier, Legislator Sun Ta-chien of the opposition Kuomintang brought up the public concerns over the safety of flu vaccines during a question-and-answering session at the Legislative Yuan, following the government's implementation of a free flu vaccination program for high-risk groups of people Monday.

The government's 2007 free flu vaccination program covers all first- and second- grade elementary school students around the country after an analysis by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) on reported flu cases between 2000 and 2006 in Taiwan found that the incidence of flu turning into serious disease among children under 12 years is four or five times the number among people over 65, while the mortality rate is also three or four times that of the elderly, far higher than other age groups.
According to CDC experts, the best way to prevent flu is to get flu shots.
Taiwan usually enters flu season around the end of November, with cases reaching a peak around Christmas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Party members hope president will assume chairmanship: lawmaker

TEXT.P: Members of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have reached a consensus on President Chen Shui-bian assuming the party's chairmanship after Yu Shyi-kun insisted on stepping down from the post, DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh claimed Tuesday.
Wang, who is also a DPP legislative caucus whip, made the comments while answering questions from reporters at the Legislative Yuan.

The issue of the DPP chairmanship has been under the spotlight since Yu offered to resign from the party's top post late last month following his indictment for embezzlement by Taipei prosecutors over allegedly misusing special allowance funds during his tenures as premier and as Presidential Office secretary- general.

According to Wang, it is the common desire of most DPP members that Chen concurrently assume the chairmanship to lead the party to victory in the coming legislative and presidential elections. Chen concurrently served as DPP chairman from 2002-2004.

Turning to a media report that Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan may serve as DPP acting chairwoman if Yu insists on quitting, Wang said that he has never heard of such discussions within the party.
DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin said that it would be good for President Chen to serve as party chairman to help forge unity.

Meanwhile, Yeh Chu-lan said that she will fully respect the party's decision to handle the chairmanship issue through party mechanisms -- something which the Central Standing Committee (CSC) will discuss in its weekly meeting Wednesday.

Party sources said Chen is likely to assume DPP chairmanship if Yu insists on stepping down. But they also predicted that Yeh Chu-lan may serve as acting party chairwoman should Chen be loath to take over the post.
Commenting on the same issue, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said earlier the same day that Yu's offer to depart has to be considered by the CSC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers blast China for visa denial

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers said Tuesday that their failure to attend the opening ceremony of the 2007 Special Olympics World Summer Games being held in Shanghai Oct. 2-11 is the result of political obstruction by the Chinese government.
DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni said China should not refuse to allow her to attend the ceremony, adding that she is also a consultant of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC).

DPP legislators Lan Mei-ching, also a CTOC consultant who was also denied a visa to attend the Shanghai ceremony, said sports should transcend political boundaries and that she is supporting the Taiwanese athletes competing in the Special Olympics.
She said she wanted to encourage the athletes at the event and expressed regret that China does not allow her to travel to Shanghai.
Despite the two lawmakers' inability to attend in the event, two other DPP legislators -- Hsu Jung-shu and Wang Jung-chang -- were given visas to attend the opening ceremony.

Special Olympics is an international nonprofit organization established to help people with intellectual disabilities to develop self-confidence, social skills and a sense of personal accomplishment through sports training and competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three ractopamine suppliers prosecuted in Changhua County

TEXT.P: The Public Prosecutors Office in Changhua indicted three men Tuesday for supplying the illegal veterinary drug ractopamine and the banned antibiotic chloramphenicol to pig farms in Changhua County.

Prosecutors are seeking one year in prison for Ho Po-yen, owner of a trading company in Taipei, an eight-month sentence for Huang Shih-hui, owner of a company in Kaohsiung, and a six-month sentence for Lin Chieh-sheng, owner of a firm in Changhua County.
The prosecutors are also asking for a fine of NT$10,000 each for the companies of Ho and Huang.

According to the prosecutors, Ho bought large amounts of ractopamine from China and sold it to hog raisers in Changhua County. He also supplied the drug to Huang for distribution among pig farmers in Kaohsiung.

The prosecutors, supported by police and a central Taiwan mobile unit organized by the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice, raided a warehouse in Taipei July 31 and another warehouse in Kaohsiung Aug. 2, and seized 28 metric tons of ractopamine and 150 kilograms of material for making chloramphenicol.

Ractopamine is a drug used as a feed additive to increase protein and decrease fat in pigs. Taiwan has zero tolerance for ractopamine residue in pigs, although it is legal to use the drug in more than 20 countries, including the United States.
Taiwan has also banned chloramphenicol as a feed additive since 2002, with offenders liable to fines of NT$6,000 to NT$30,000 under the Veterinary Drugs Control Act.
The use of ractopamine to produce more lean meat in hogs became a issue of contention in Taiwan in July after two shipments of pork from the United States were found to contain ractopamine residue.

To allay fears of the public about the drug's harmful effects on their health, the Department of Health assured that the ban on the use of ractopamine in pigs will remain in place and that imports of pork containing residue of the drug will not be permitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cause of CAL plane fracture remains mystery

TEXT.P: The cause of a 77-cm fracture in the fuselage of a China Airlines (CAL) Boeing 737-800 that was found after the plane landed in Japan Sept. 20 remains unknown, aviation sources said Tuesday.
According to data and information provided by CAL, the sources said, the fracture is suspected to be a symptom of corrosion, but the cause of the corrosion remains a mystery.

CAL maintenance workers discovered the hairline crack near the tail of the jet during a routine post-flight inspection Sept. 20 afternoon at Saga Airport on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu. No anomalies were detected during the plane's flight from Taipei.

The fracture was found about 30 minutes before the plane's scheduled departure for a return trip to Taipei. The airline sent another plane from Taipei to pick up the flight's 49 passengers, who left Saga Airport nearly 5 1/2-hours behind schedule.

CAL, Taiwan's largest carrier, sent 10 maintenance technicians to Saga Sept. 21, but the sources said repair work had not yet been started because Boeing Co. has not yet come up with any repair or maintenance instructions.
Noting that Boeing exercises great caution in dealing with the issue, the sources said Boeing has sent technical staff to Saga to assist in investigating the cause of the fracture.

With the cause undetermined, the plane has been stuck at Saga for nearly two weeks as the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is reluctant to issue a certificate of air worthiness for the aircraft to fly back to Taipei.

CAA officials originally supposed that the fracture was caused by scratching from a ground service vehicle after the plane landed, but that possibility has been ruled out after an extensive investigation, the sources said.

CAL planes are subject to two rounds of thorough checks before any flight. If the fracture existed before its flight from Taipei to Saga, it should have been found. As a result, the fracture could have occurred in mid-air, the sources said.
On Aug. 20, a China Airlines Boeing 737-800 that landed at Okinawa's Naha airport exploded in a fireball at a gate seconds after all 157 passengers and eight crew safely evacuated.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to continue volunteer work after stepping down

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he will continue with the volunteerism he has championed throughout his presidency after he steps down next May.
Chen made the pledge while meeting with winners of this year's Golden Camel Award in honor of outstanding volunteers.

Noting that he has designated May 20 as Taiwan Volunteer Day since he assumed presidency May 20, 2000, Chen said he has consistently marked the anniversary of his inauguration with volunteer work over the past seven years.
"After ending my second presidential term May 20, 2008, I'll continue to learn from all of you in doing volunteer work," Chen assured his guests.
Pointing out that Taiwan is the world's second country that has passed an act on volunteer work, Chen said the number of volunteers has grown rapidly since the law was promulgated in 2001.
Quoting government tallies, Chen said Taiwan now has 101,605 registered volunteers, with the total volunteer working time reaching 8.56 million hours annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 3, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on the launch of commercial on the campaign against election bribery ahead of the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections Date and Time: 11:00 a.m., Wednesday, Oct. 3, 2007 Place: Pao-An Temple, 61, Hami Street, Taipei City Host and/or main speakers: Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin and Cabient Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun Press Contact: Tel.3356-6500 3. DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers blast China for visa denial

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers said Tuesday that their failure to attend the opening ceremony of the 2007 Special Olympics World Summer Games being held in Shanghai Oct. 2-11 is the result of political obstruction by the Chinese government.
DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni said China should not refuse to allow her to attend the ceremony, adding that she is also a consultant of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC).

DPP legislators Lan Mei-ching, also a CTOC consultant who was also denied a visa to attend the Shanghai ceremony, said sports should transcend political boundaries and that she is supporting the Taiwanese athletes competing in the Special Olympics.
She said she wanted to encourage the athletes at the event and expressed regret that China does not allow her to travel to Shanghai.
Despite the two lawmakers' inability to attend in the event, two other DPP legislators -- Hsu Jung-shu and Wang Jung-chang -- were given visas to attend the opening ceremony.

Special Olympics is an international nonprofit organization established to help people with intellectual disabilities to develop self-confidence, social skills and a sense of personal accomplishment through sports training and competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three ractopamine suppliers prosecuted in Changhua County

TEXT.P: The Public Prosecutors Office in Changhua indicted three men Tuesday for supplying the illegal veterinary drug ractopamine and the banned antibiotic chloramphenicol to pig farms in Changhua County.

Prosecutors are seeking one year in prison for Ho Po-yen, owner of a trading company in Taipei, an eight-month sentence for Huang Shih-hui, owner of a company in Kaohsiung, and a six-month sentence for Lin Chieh-sheng, owner of a firm in Changhua County.
The prosecutors are also asking for a fine of NT$10,000 each for the companies of Ho and Huang.

According to the prosecutors, Ho bought large amounts of ractopamine from China and sold it to hog raisers in Changhua County. He also supplied the drug to Huang for distribution among pig farmers in Kaohsiung.

The prosecutors, supported by police and a central Taiwan mobile unit organized by the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice, raided a warehouse in Taipei July 31 and another warehouse in Kaohsiung Aug. 2, and seized 28 metric tons of ractopamine and 150 kilograms of material for making chloramphenicol.

Ractopamine is a drug used as a feed additive to increase protein and decrease fat in pigs. Taiwan has zero tolerance for ractopamine residue in pigs, although it is legal to use the drug in more than 20 countries, including the United States.
Taiwan has also banned chloramphenicol as a feed additive since 2002, with offenders liable to fines of NT$6,000 to NT$30,000 under the Veterinary Drugs Control Act.
The use of ractopamine to produce more lean meat in hogs became a issue of contention in Taiwan in July after two shipments of pork from the United States were found to contain ractopamine residue.

To allay fears of the public about the drug's harmful effects on their health, the Department of Health assured that the ban on the use of ractopamine in pigs will remain in place and that imports of pork containing residue of the drug will not be permitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cause of CAL plane fracture remains mystery

TEXT.P: The cause of a 77-cm fracture in the fuselage of a China Airlines (CAL) Boeing 737-800 that was found after the plane landed in Japan Sept. 20 remains unknown, aviation sources said Tuesday.
According to data and information provided by CAL, the sources said, the fracture is suspected to be a symptom of corrosion, but the cause of the corrosion remains a mystery.

CAL maintenance workers discovered the hairline crack near the tail of the jet during a routine post-flight inspection Sept. 20 afternoon at Saga Airport on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu. No anomalies were detected during the plane's flight from Taipei.

The fracture was found about 30 minutes before the plane's scheduled departure for a return trip to Taipei. The airline sent another plane from Taipei to pick up the flight's 49 passengers, who left Saga Airport nearly 5 1/2-hours behind schedule.

CAL, Taiwan's largest carrier, sent 10 maintenance technicians to Saga Sept. 21, but the sources said repair work had not yet been started because Boeing Co. has not yet come up with any repair or maintenance instructions.
Noting that Boeing exercises great caution in dealing with the issue, the sources said Boeing has sent technical staff to Saga to assist in investigating the cause of the fracture.

With the cause undetermined, the plane has been stuck at Saga for nearly two weeks as the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is reluctant to issue a certificate of air worthiness for the aircraft to fly back to Taipei.

CAA officials originally supposed that the fracture was caused by scratching from a ground service vehicle after the plane landed, but that possibility has been ruled out after an extensive investigation, the sources said.

CAL planes are subject to two rounds of thorough checks before any flight. If the fracture existed before its flight from Taipei to Saga, it should have been found. As a result, the fracture could have occurred in mid-air, the sources said.
On Aug. 20, a China Airlines Boeing 737-800 that landed at Okinawa's Naha airport exploded in a fireball at a gate seconds after all 157 passengers and eight crew safely evacuated.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to continue volunteer work after stepping down

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he will continue with the volunteerism he has championed throughout his presidency after he steps down next May.
Chen made the pledge while meeting with winners of this year's Golden Camel Award in honor of outstanding volunteers.

Noting that he has designated May 20 as Taiwan Volunteer Day since he assumed presidency May 20, 2000, Chen said he has consistently marked the anniversary of his inauguration with volunteer work over the past seven years.
"After ending my second presidential term May 20, 2008, I'll continue to learn from all of you in doing volunteer work," Chen assured his guests.
Pointing out that Taiwan is the world's second country that has passed an act on volunteer work, Chen said the number of volunteers has grown rapidly since the law was promulgated in 2001.
Quoting government tallies, Chen said Taiwan now has 101,605 registered volunteers, with the total volunteer working time reaching 8.56 million hours annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 3, or the 23rd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet- level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."
