DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Krosa expected to affect Taiwan from Saturday: CWB

TEXT.P: Typhoon Krosa, which was upgraded from a tropical storm Wednesday morning, is expected to affect Taiwan from this Saturday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Wednesday.
As of 8 a.m. Wednesday, Typhoon Krosa was centered 1,060 km south-southeast of the Japanese island of Okinawa, moving northwesterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 10-14 kph., CWB meteorologists said.

Packing maximum sustained winds of 155 kph, Typhoon Krosa -- the 15th reported in the West Pacific region this year -- had a radius of 200 kilometers as of 8 a.m., the meteorologists said, adding that the radius expected to increase as the typhoon moves toward Taiwan.

Krosa is expected to bring sporadic showers to northern and eastern Taiwan over the next two days, while cloudy skies are forecast for central and southern Taiwan, and temperatures are expected to be high for the western part of the island, the forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four more allies plead Taiwan's case at U.N. General Assembly
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/03/07 12:56:41 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Four more of Taiwan's diplomatic allies voiced support for the country's bid to join the United Nations Tuesday during the ongoing session of the U.N. General Assembly, bringing to 17 the total number of allies which spoke for Taiwan at the annual meeting.
Raising the issue during the general debate were the representatives of Saint Kitts and Nevis, Burkina Faso, Belize, and Kiribati.

In his statement, Timothy Harris, minister of foreign affairs of Saint Kitts and Nevis, said Taiwan should be admitted to the United Nations according to the principle of universality followed by the world body.

Addressing China's accusation that Taiwan's bid is a separatist move amied at achieving independence, Harris pointed out that U.N. membership is not a "deterrent to unification" as seen in the example of the former East Germany and West Germany, nor is it "the panacea to fragmentation" as seen in the deconstruction of the former Soviet Union.
"What has always been clear is that the United Nations has extended a warm welcome to all states and respected the equality of all states," Harris said.
Noting that Taiwan has shown that it can be "a true partner in development, " Harris said that the international community has been deprived of the gift of that partnership by rejecting Taiwan.

Djibrill Yipene Bassole, minister of foreign affairs of Burkina Faso, claimed that by denying membership to Taiwan -- a democratic and modernized country with 23 million people, the United Nations has given up its pursuit of modernization and the principle of universality.

Belizean Minister of Foreign Affairs Lisa Shoman said that his country remains steadfast in its support of Taiwan's membership bid and that it will continue to advocate representation for Taiwan in the world body.

Meanwhile, Natanaera Kirata, minister of public works and utilities of Kiribati, expressed his regret that once again, the issue of U.N. representation for Taiwan was not given a fair opportunity to be discussed by the General Assembly this year.

Kirata said Taiwan and its 23 million people deserve to be treated justly by the United Nations, given the country's upholding of the principles of democracy, mutual respect and understanding as stipulated in the U.N. Charter.

Taiwan has not been represented in the United Nations since 1971, when the Republic of China's U.N. seat was given to the People's Republic of China. While the country has tried without success to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993, this year marks the first time the country has applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan.

However, following the return of Taiwan's application by the U.N. Secretariat first in July and again in August, an item endorsed by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the United Nations to address Taiwan's membership application has also been excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.
Of the total of 24 diplomatic allies of Taiwan, only seven did not plead Taiwan's case during the week-long general debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait peace will be built on talks on equal footing: DPP

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait peace will be built on negotiations between Taiwan and China on an equal footing, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh made the remarks after South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il in Pyongyang Tuesday on the first day of three days of talks between the two leaders, marking the second meeting between the heads of state of the two Koreas since the Korean Peninsula was divided 60 years ago.
Wang said the meeting is significant in that the two Koreas are engaging in talks on an equal footing based on mutual respect.

He lamented that China has yet to view Taiwan as a sovereign, independent state, saying that cross-strait peace should be built on mutual respect so that negotiations between the two sides based on an equal footing will be possible.
He said that both Koreas are members of the United Nations. In comparison, China has continued to obstruct Taiwan's bid to join the world body.
He urged China to "take a cue" from the Roh-Kim meeting, acknowledge that Taiwan is a sovereign, independent country and help Taiwan join the United Nations.
China should also remove the 900 missiles deployed along its southeastern coast to end the military threat against Taiwan and contribute to peace in Asia and the rest of the world.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher accused Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang, of being unwilling to face the fact that the relationship between Taiwan and China is a "state-to-state" one.

He urged Ma to learn from the meeting between the two Korean heads of state, saying that talks on direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should also be conducted on an equal footing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Tax deductions for salaries, educational expenses to be raised

TEXT.P: The Cabinet finalized a draft amendment to the Income Tax Law Wednesday that would allow taxpayers to claim higher deductions for salaries and educational expenses.

According to the bill, which requires final approval by the Legislative Yuan, the deductions for salaries and for the physically or mentally challenged would be increased from NT$78,000 (US$2,393) and NT$77,000, respectively, to NT$82,000.
In addition, taxpayers would be able to claim a deduction of up to NT$25,000 for each dependent studying in college or university, as opposed to up to NT$25,000 per household at present.
In a measure aimed at preventing taxpayers from using donations to avoid paying taxes, the bill stipulates that only donations made in cash would be eligible for deductions.
Sheu Yu-jer, director-general of the Ministry of Finance's Taxation Agency, estimated that the changes would reduce the government's revenues by NT$200 million per year.

While the change in the deductions for donations would increase the government's revenues by NT$3.5 billion per year, the changes in the deductions for salaries, the physically or mentally challenged, and educational expenses would decrease its revenues by NT$1.7 billion, NT$200 million and NT$1.8 billion, respectively, according to Sheu.
He said the proposed amendment would lessen the tax liability of members of the middle class, prevent tax evasion and lower operational costs of businesses.
The changes would also benefit disadvantaged groups and middle-to-low income families, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen 'best choice' to serve as DPP chairman: lawmaker

TEXT.P: Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian is the best choice to serve as the new DPP chairman.

The issue of the DPP chairmanship has been in the spotlight since Yu Shyi-kun offered to resign from the party's top post late last month following his indictment on forgery and corruption charges by Taipei prosecutors for allegedly misusing special allowance funds during his tenures as premier and as Presidential Office secretary-general.

Yu had originally planned to step down from the post after the party's national congress held Sept. 30. However, he left the post Sept. 27 after other DPP bigwigs came to a decision Sept. 26 to only change the wording of the party's "normal country resolution" instead of adopting his proposal to add a clause call for the changing of the country's name to "Taiwan".
On the question of who should succeed Yu, Legislator Chai said that it would be suitable for President Chen to serve concurrently as the head of the DPP.
Chen served as DPP chairman from July 2002 to December 2004 when he resigned to assume responsibility for the party's failure to win a majority in the legislative elections that year.
Chai said that if President Chen is unwilling to assume the DPP chairmanship again, then Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan would be the "second best choice."

Meanwhile, another DPP legislator, Huang Wei-cher, expressed the hope that President Chen will assume the post as soon as possible to help allay DPP supporters' concerns that the party seems divided while the opposition camp has consolidated itself ahead of the presidential election slated for March next year.

DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday that the succession issue is expected to be discussed at a DPP Central Executive Committee meeting next Tuesday and that hopefully a final decision will be made by then.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged to deal with problem of students' lack of sleep

TEXT.P: Lawmakers urged the Ministry of Education (MOE) Wednesday to come up with substantial measures within one month to address the issue of students not getting enough sleep due to heavy school workloads.
Legislator Lee Ching-an of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said the ministry should take responsibility for this problem.
Her colleague Chiang Yi-hsiung said that a study should be conducted to determine whether insufficient sleep affects the mental development of students.
Deputy Education Minister Lu Mu-ling said Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng has instructed related agencies in the ministry to deal with the matter.

Pan Wen-chung, director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, urged parents to pay more attention to their children's daily schedules to make sure that they get at least eight hours of sleep per night, noting that many children spend too much time watching TV or surfing the Internet.
In addition, he urged students to get more exercise, saying that doing so will ensure good sleep quality and benefit their physical and mental development.
He also asked parents to assess the condition of their children and not to push them to engage in too many extracurricular activities so that their school work will not be negatively affected.

The two lawmakers' expressed their concern on the issue after the results of a survey released earlier the same day showed that Taiwan teenagers sleep half an hour less than their counterparts in other countries.

Huang Yi-shu, a child psychiatrist at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital who conducted the survey, said that Taiwan's teenagers get 7.5 hours of sleep per night on average, less than the 7.9 hours enjoyed by their counterparts in the neighboring countries of Japan, South Korea, and China, where the importance of education is stressed as strongly as in Taiwan.

She said that not getting enough sleep will affect the development of teenagers, adding they could display such symptoms as hyperactivity, irritation or anxiety if the problem persists over an extended period of time.

She suggested that elementary school students get more than nine hours of sleep per night and go to bed before 10 p.m., while junior and senior high school students should go to bed before 11 p.m. and get eight hours of sleep.
Huang conducted the survey on more than 2,000 students between Grade Six in elementary school and the second year of senior high school between June 2005 and June 2006.
She found that the sixth-graders get an average of 7.9 hours of sleep per night, junior high school students get 7.5 hours, and senior high school students get 6.8 hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier urges China to serve regional peace, stability

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Wednesday urged China to use its influence on Myanmar to persuade the ruling junta to conduct dialogue with local democracy activists for the sake of Myanmarese people's happiness.

Chang made the call after he heard a report at the Executive Yuan by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on the Myanmarese military junta's recent brutal crackdown on a peaceful democratic movement.
Chang expressed hope that China can understand the values of freedom, democracy and human rights and serve as a key power helping maintain international and regional peace and stability.

Using any form of brute force, violence or non-peaceful means for an internal crackdown or external intimidation is intolerable in a civilized society, Chang said, condemning Myanmarese troops for opening fire on unarmed Buddhist monks and civilian demonstrators over the past few days.
It was violence against democracy, human rights and humanity, the premier said.
He also advised Taiwanese people to refrain from traveling to Myanmar for the time being, while instructing the MOFA to pay close attention to any possible changes in the political situation there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 76.82 points to close at 9,700.07.
The bourse opened at 9,650.03 and fluctuated between 9,783.75 and 9,618.14 during trading. A total of 6.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$215.15 billion (US$6.61 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.7 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 3 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.21 percent, textile stocks at 1.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.4 percent, and foodstuff issues at 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,095 to 778, with 228 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH will take responsibility if flu vaccines harmful

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday that all the influenza vaccines imported and offered by the government are safe and that it will take full responsibility if any of the doses are found to cause harm to people.

Shih Wen-yi, a deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control (CDC), said that so far, there is no scientific evidence to prove that mercury-containing flu vaccines are unsafe, adding that since there is no way to prove they are unsafe, the center cannot exclude the products from its order list.
Shih said the CDC will not consider importing only mercury-free flu vaccines, since these products are scarce and imports would be insufficient to meet domestic demand.
The Consumers' Foundation voiced opposition Wednesday to the availability of mercury-containing flu vaccines, saying that the government should guarantee the safety of the vaccines.

A foundation spokesman said it does not exclude the possibility of filing a lawsuit against the DOH for providing "health-impairing" mercury-containing flu vaccines and demanding national compensation.
Responding to the accusation, Shih said the CDC guarantees the safety of mercury-containing flu vaccines and is willing to take full responsibility.

He also challenged the Consumers' Foundation by asking whether the foundation will take responsibility if people stop receiving flu vaccinations because of what he claimed were "unfounded allegations" made by the foundation.

The Taiwan Pediatric Association (TPA) urged people considered to be at high risk of influenza to take advantage of free vaccinations offered by the government, claiming that the mercury-containing vaccine is safe.

Amid public concern about the mercury content in the free flu vaccine, TPA President Lin Tzou-yien and Assistant Secretary-General Lee Ping-ing released a joint statement to claim the safety of the vaccine, which contains thimerosal -- an organomercury compound that has been commonly used as an antiseptic and antifungal agent in some vaccines since the 1930s.
In the statement, the pediatricians claimed that the organomercury "cannot cause illness" and that it is discharged from the human body soon after the injection of the thimerosal-containing vaccine.

The statement quoted results of a joint research by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, Harvard University and Stanford University targeting 1,074 children aged between seven and 10 through a comprehensive neurophysiologic evaluation.
The research, which was published in the influential New England Journal of Medicine in September, concluded that mercury-containing vaccines have caused no side effect on childrens' nervous systems.

A comment in the popular weekly general medical journal also says that the issue of mercury-containing vaccines has been magnified in an irrational manner in the U.S. to a political and judiciary problem, the TPA said, urging the Taiwan people to be "rational."

Legislator Sun Ta-chien of the opposition Kuomintang brought up the public concerns over the safety of flu vaccines during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan the day before, following the government's implementation of a free flu vaccination program for high-risk groups of people Monday.
The government's 3 million-dose free flu vaccination program for 2007 covers persons over 65 years of age or children aged between six months and two years.

The free flu shots are also available to first-line medical professionals, hospital volunteer workers, community pharmacists, medical lab workers, school nurses, crew of international airlines, quarantine workers, poultry farmers and bird raisers, nursing home residents, people suffering from severe injuries or diseases, as well as first-year and second-year primary school students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 102 points to close at 9,771, with 51,611 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November rose 100 points to finish at 9,775, with 872 contracts traded, while December futures gained 90 points to close at 9,770, with 64 contract transactions. March futures moved up 74 points to close at 9,742, with 12 contract transactions, while June futures increased 32 points to finish at 9,702, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 9,669 for October, 9,675 for November, 9,680 for December, 9,668 for March and 9,670 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

October TE futures rose 2.7 points to close at 402, with 3,942 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 2.8 points to finish at 401.6, with 34 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures gained 22.6 points to close at 1,099.4, with 7,001 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 23.8 points to finish at 1,099.8, with 119 contracts traded. March TF futures increased nine points to close at 1,097, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to establish `Taiwan exchanges holding company'

TEXT.P: The Cabinet finalized Wednesday a plan to establish a holding company to integrate the country's stock and futures exchanges and related agencies.

After its formation, the holding company will cover four subsidiaries -- the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp., the Taiwan Futures Exchange, the Taiwan Depository and Clearing Corp. and the GreTai Securities Market, according to the plan.
In the second stage of the plan, the Cabinet will push for the listing of the company's stock and set up an independent unit in charge of market supervision and regulation.

Wu Tang-chieh, director-general of the Securities and Futures Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission, said the plan will involve an amendment to the Securities Transaction Act and that if the proposed amendment is passed by the Legislative Yuan within this legislative session, the holding company can be established next year.
According to Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, the plan to establish such a holding company is consistent with the trends in other countries, such as Germany, Italy, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Chang said he hopes the plan will help integrate existing resources, enhance the performance of the exchanges and help investors lower trading costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science industrial parks' Jan.-Aug. turnover grows 11.6 percent

TEXT.P: The combined turnover of three science industrial parks affiliated to the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) reached NT$1.2 trillion (US$36.85 billion) during the January-August period, posting an 11.6 percent growth compared with the level of the same period of 2006, according to an NSC report released Wednesday.

The report assessed that the combined turnover of the Hsinchu Science Park, the Central Taiwan Science Park (CTSP) in Taichung County, and the Southern Taiwan Science Park (STSP) in Tainan County is expected to increase to have increased to NT$2.1 trillion by the end of the year, contributing to an annual growth of 14.8 percent.

NSC Vice Chairman Huang Wen-hsiung said the opto-electronics industry was the largest among six major sectors in the science parks, with a turnover of NT$634.57 billion during the eight-month period, or 51.8 percent of the total.
Sales of flat-screen monitors accounted for the bulk of the opto-electronics sector's turnover thanks to an increasing demand beginning in the second quarter, Huang said.

Integrated circuit manufacturing was the second-largest industry in the parks, with a turnover of NT$474.2 billion in the eight-month period, or 38.7 percent, followed by the computer and peripheral sector with NT$63.67 billion.
The other major industries in the parks cover the fields of communications, precision machinery and biotechnology.
According to Huang, the number of businesses operating in those science parks has reached 600, of which 408 are located in the Hsinchu park, 89 in the CTSP, and 108 in the STSP.
Over 190,000 people are now working in the facilities, he added.

Los Angeles TimesG Bulls bet they have weathered the worst.
Wall Street surged Monday, lifting the Dow index to a record high, as big investors bet that the worst of the global credit cruch had passed -- and with it the threat of recession. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 191.92 points, or 1.4%, to 14,087.55 topping the previous record close of 14,000.41 set July 19. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

The Japan Times: Okinawa may defeat textbook censorship
Education Minister Kisaburo Tokai indicated Tuesday his ministry may let history textbook publishers continue saying the army forced civilians to commit mass suicide during the 1945 Battle of Okinawa.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Released Red Brigader arrested for bank heist.
A former commander of the Italian leftist urban guerrilla group Red Brigades, who was released from jail for good conduct, was arrested Monday for a bank heist in the central Italian city of Siena. Cristoforo Piancone, 57, was serving a life sentence for six murders and two attempted murders.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: From Errand to Fatal Shot to Hail of Fire to 17 Deaths
It started out as a family errand: Ahmed Haithem Ahmed was driving his mother, Mohassin, to pick up his father from the hospital where he worked as a pathologist. As they approached Nisour Square at midday on Sept. 16, they did not know that a bomb had gone off nearby or that a convoy of four armored vehicles carrying Blackwater guards armed with automatic rifles was approaching.
The Wall Street Journal: Wal-Mart Era Wanes Amid Big Shifts in Retail
The Wal-Mart Era, the retailer's time of overwhelming business and social influence in America, is drawing to a close.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Clinton Widens Lead In Poll
Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton has consolidated her place as the front-runner in the contest for the Democratic presidential nomination, outpacing her main rivals in fundraising in the most recent quarter and widening her lead in a new Washington Post-ABC News poll.
The Washington Times: War foe: Block Iraq funding or levy surtax
Rep. David R. Obey, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, yesterday threatened unilaterally to block President Bush's $189 billion emergency war- funding bill to force a U. S. pullout from Iraq and called for levying a surtax to cover the war's costs.

: The Straits Times: Normal stream students to get more choices, help.
Normal stream students aspiring for ploytechnic places will get more help, including teaching staff who understand their learning styles.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Normal courses upgrade comprehensive.
Education of Ministry will offer more manpower and financial resources for Normal course students to enhance teachers' skill, and to increase the opportunities for Normal course students to enter a higher school like Institute of Technical Education (ITE).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, closing at NT$32.573.
A total of US$1.345 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.548 and fluctuated between NT$32.538 and NT$32.614.

DOC.HEADLINE: More information service firms invited to join IDB's BEST program

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has invited three more information technology service companies to join its "Best E-Services export of Taiwan" (BEST) Flagship Program, in which the MOEA will help firms in this sphere boost their exports and elevate their competitiveness.

According to Lin Chun-hsiu, a section chief of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) , the three companies are InfoChamp Systems Corp., Advanced Control and Systems Inc. and Wistron Corp., which mainly offer information technology information services in the steel and chemical sectors.

With the joining of the three companies, the BEST Flagship Program, which began in 2005, will cover information technology service firms for almost every sphere in Taiwan, including manufacturing, finance, e-government and information security, Lin added.
Since 2006, seven projects involving 46 information technology service companies under the program have increased revenue of NT$3 billion (US$92,880), with NT$1.7 billion going for exports.
Lin went on that the program originally was to have been closed next year. However, the IDB has been still evaluating new projects due to the good results produced from the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors seek 22 years for Chiayi speaker over graft

TEXT.P: The speaker of the county council of Chiayi in southern Taiwan was indicted Wednesday on charges of corruption and prosecutors demanded a 22-year sentence for him.

According to Chiayi prosecutors, County Council Speaker Yu Cheng-tah received at least NT$3 million (US$90,909) in bribe, via his aides, from private businessmen in January this year when the county government was organizing a lantern festival.
Yu was indicted on charges of receiving bribes and extortion, the prosecutors said.

Another seven people, including two of Yu's aides and two Chiayi county government officials, were also indicted on corruption charges. Three businessmen were indicted in the same case on charges of bribery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local publishers to attend 2007 Frankfurt book fair

TEXT.P: Some 64 local publishers will take part in the upcoming 2007 Frankfurt Book Fair in Germany that starts Oct. 10, presenting 677 books in 10 categories to show the vitality of Taiwan's publishing industry and seek chances for international copyright trade.
This year's Taiwan booth is organized by the Taipei Book Fair Foundation (TBFF) with authorization from the Government Information Office, said TBFF Chairman Lin Tzai-chuei.
A category named "Window on Chinese-language Publishing" will recommend 32 literary works by seven Chinese writers who have won international recognition, he said.

The seven writers are Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, Li Ang, who gained international recognition for her book titled The Butcher's Wife, poet Yang Mu, literary critic Wang Der-wei, Yu Kuo-fan, whose translation of Journey to the West has brought him world renown, and historians Yu Ying-shih and Ray Huang.

This year's theme is "Taiwan -- the Paradise of Chinese -language Publishing, " Lin said, adding that the variety of books to be exhibited exemplify that Taiwan is a favorable place for writers and publishers for its cultural openness.

A special section of this year's Taiwan booth will display Chinese-language literary works banned in some other countries. Works of exiled Chinese dissident writers including Gao, Kang Zhengguo and Jingfuzi will be included, Lin said.
The booth will also showcase comic books by local illustrators like Jimmy Liao, Lin Ching-huei and Chang Sheng.
Lin added that Horlemann, a German publisher, will launch a German translation of Li Ang's "The Visible Ghosts, " and hold a series of activities to promote her book during the book fair.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Fresh Tory tax cuts for family and companies
Personal and business tax cuts will be unveiled by the Conservatives in any autumn general election campaign, The Times was told yesterday, as poll fever began to run out of control.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japanese high schools strengthen cultural exchanges

TEXT.P: Taipei Municipal Zhong Shan Girls' High School received Wednesday a group of visiting Japanese Taiwan from Sumiyoshi Senior High School in Osaka.

The 300 students and teachers from Sumiyoshi Senior High School, headed by Principal Etuji Nakano, will visit major tourist spots, including scenic Hualien County, Taipei's night markets and the Taipei 101 building. Some of the Japanese children will stay at the homes of their Taipei counterparts.

Zhong Shan Girls' High School Principal Huang Yu-yi said it is the first time in 50 years that the school has received such a big delegation from a foreign country, adding that it took almost one year to arrange the visit.

In order to give the visitors a good impression of Taiwan, Zhong Shan Girls' High School arranged music and dance performances to celebrate their arrival and has mobilized almost all the students familiar with the Japanese language, including ethnic Japanese students studying at Zhong Shan, although most of the students of the two schools generally communicate with each other using English.
Nakano said their visit will help strengthen mutual understanding of each other's history and culture, as well as consolidate friendship, and expressed hope that such visits will continue.
According to Huang, students from Zhong Shan Girls' High School will visit Osaka in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 defendants in Rebar group scandal to remain in custody

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ruled Wednesday that 10 defendants connected with the Rebar Asia Pacific Group scandal will remain in custody for two more months despite their plea for release after their current custody term expires.

The court noted that the defendants, including several family members of Wang You-theng, the fugitive founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, have embezzled from various subsidiaries under the Rebar group and that they have played major roles in the scandal.
The evidence is against them, said Liu Shou-sung, spokesman of the Taipei District Court.
Their embezzlement from the corporations has not only affected the economy, but has had widespread ramifications in the whole of society, according to Liu.
Liu said that to facilitate the trial of the case, the court will hold them in custody until Dec. 8.
Also, because they have committed felonies, there will be no limits on the number of times their custody period can be extended -- usually it is extended only once or twice.

The 10 defendants include Wang Shih-chan, younger brother of Wang You-tseng, and three of Wang You-tseng's children -- China Rebar Vice Chairman Wang Lin-tai, Asia Pacific broadband Telecom President Wang Lin-yi and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. Chairman Wang Lin-chiao, as well as top executives working for Wang in various companies.

In an indictment in March, the prosecution said the Wang family obtained illegal benefits by setting up numerous dummy corporations through which they engaged in fraud, insider trading and embezzlement on a massive scale.

The scandal came to light in early January when two of its member companies -- Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Co. and China Rebar Co. -- filed for bankruptcy restructuring with the Taipei District Court. The move sparked a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar subsidiary that has since been taken over by the state-run Central Deposit Insurance Corp.
Wang You-tseng and his wife Wang Chin She-ying fled to China and later to the United States last year before the group's financial woes became public. They remain on the nation's most-wanted list.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals drop

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan during China's Oct. 1-7 national holiday is estimated to grow 18 percent as compared with the same period of last year, despite a drop in Chinese tourist arrivals in the first nine months, an official said Wednesday.

Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Ho Nuan-hsuan said 56,122 Chinese tourists traveled from Hong Kong, Macau or other countries to Taiwan during the nine-month period, a drop of 23 percent compared with the same period of last year.

The ministry attributed the decline to Beijing's reinforced move to crack down on illegal Taiwan visits by Chinese people living in China via other countries, and its reluctance to formally allow Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Taiwan has opened its doors for Chinese citizens living abroad to make sightseeing trips to the island. Chinese citizens living in China are also allowed to visit for sightseeing via a third country.
It has been assessed that 1,840 Chinese tourists will visit Taiwan during China's so-called "golden week" National Day holiday in China, according to the MOTC.
In general, the number of foreign tourists to Taiwan totaled over 2.4 million in the January-August period, representing an increase of 4.52 percent year-on- year, according to MOTC statistics.
During the eight-month period, local people made 6.14 million overseas visits, registering a 3.54 percent year-on-year growth, the tallies show.

In terms of domestic tourism, the number of visits to the 295 major tourist attractions around the country reached 96.37 million in the first seven months of the year, according to the MOTC statistics.

The most popular privately operated tourist attraction was the Taipei 101 Observatory, the MOTC said, noting that the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung City, central Taiwan attracted more tourists than other entry-fee government-run tourist attractions in the seven-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 high-tech labs inaugurated at Chengkung University

TEXT.P: The National Applied Research Laboratories (NARL) opened satellite labs focusing on nanotechnology and chip design at National Chengkung University (NCU) in southern Taiwan Wednesday.

NCU Principal Lai Ming-chao and NARL President Chuan Che-nan presided over the name plate unveiling ceremony for the National Nano Device Laboratories and the National Chip Implementation Center to mark the beginning of cooperation between the two organizations.

According to an NCU spokesman, the NARL, which is under the supervision of National Science Council, signed an agreement earlier this year with the university to further their cooperation in nanotechnology, advanced solar cell and chip design research.

The establishment of the two laboratories in the Tainan City university aims at establishing a high-tech research and development base in southern Taiwan to balance the country's high-tech development in northern and southern regions, the spokesman added.
Chuan said five of the NARL's eight offices have been located in southern Taiwan with an aim of boosting industry in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Room for growth in Taiwanese-British trade: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that there is still ample room for development between Taiwan and Britain in bilateral trade exchanges.
Chen made the remarks when he received a British parliamentary group at the Presidential Office.
He said bilateral trade between the two countries reached more than US$4 billion last year, with Britain being Taiwan's third-largest trading partner in Europe.
He noted that since the two countries signed an agreement to avoid double taxation and tax evasion in 2002, it has contributed a great deal to promoting investment in each other's country.
As of the end of last year, Taiwan had invested in 150 projects in Britain totaling US$1 billion, accounting for half of the island's investment in Europe, he said.

Just as Britain is the top choice of Taiwanese businessmen in Europe, British manufacturers have also invested in over 400 projects amounting to US$4 billion, the fifth-largest source of investment in Taiwan.

Chen also praised Lord Faulkner, co-chairman of a pro-Taiwan parliamentary group, for his contribution to the enhancement of substantial relations between the two countries. Faulkner led a delegation that attended Chen's inauguration ceremony for his second term as president in 2004.
Chen noted that the pro-Taiwan group had only 17 members when it was inaugurated in May 2005, a number that has since grown three-fold to 51 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Day fireworks show to be held at Dapeng Bay in Pingtung

TEXT.P: A fireworks show prepared by the central government to celebrate the 2007 Double Ten National Day will be held in the Taiwan Strait 400 m off the coast of the Dapeng Bay in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, organizers said Wednesday.

It will mark the first National Day fireworks display held on the seas, Pingtung County officials said, noting that the annual show slated for Oct. 10 will draw an estimated 100,000 visitors to the county.

The fireworks show is scheduled to take place at 7: 00 p.m.- 8:00 p.m., according to the county government, which revealed that it has also planned many activities, including street arts performance and a community fair, as part of National Day celebrations.
In 2006, the Double Ten National Day fireworks display took place in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu vaccination going well in Kaohsiung City

TEXT.P: Flu vaccination is progressing well in Kaohsiung City, in southern Taiwan, with 3,031 citizens already receiving flu shots on the first day of free vaccination service, an official of the Kaohsiung city government's Department of Health said Wednesday.

Concerns over the vaccine, which contains traces of mercury in the form of the preservative thimerosal, seems to have had no impact on Kaohsiung citizen's acceptance of the service, the official said.

The Kaohsiung city government bought 116,921 vaccines for the use of people in high-risk groups this year. Some 69,053 target senior citizens over the age of 65, while 15,292 are for kids aged between six months and two years.

Other 32,576 are for the first-and second-grade elementary students, who are included in the free vaccination service this year, the official said, adding that the department will send medical teams to administer vaccination to eligible students in schools.
The free influenza vaccination service for people in high-risk categories will last until Nov. 30, and the remaining flu shots will be open to the general public from Dec. 1, the official said.

The official said influenza vaccination is safe, and seldom causes side effects. However, he still suggested that people who had adverse reaction from getting flu shots or kids under six months, should avoid vaccination.
People who are in fever or have acute disease should put off vaccination time for safety, he added.
He called on people to receive flu shots earlier to arm themselves against flu that usually enters its season around the end of November in Taiwan, with cases reaching a peak around Christmas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP torchbearer resigns from party

TEXT.P: Former Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung, once an influential figure in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), renounced his party membership Wednesday.
Shen told reporters that he has posted his party membership certificate to the DPP office in Taipei. The DPP's head office confirmed that the office has received Shen's certificate.
The DPP office also said that Shen sent a statement accompanying his certificate, declaring that from now on he will have nothing to do with any DPP policies and decisions.
Shen said he had remained in the DPP long enough, mainly because his presence would make the "bad boys in the party" uncomfortable.
"Now that they seem to have become numb, there is no point for me to remain in the DPP," he said.

Shen, 68, served as legislator for four terms from 1993 to 2005. An eloquent man, he never hesitated to criticize his own party and has been considered by the opposition as the "conscience" of the DPP.
Once a torch-bearer for the pro-independence movement, Shen lost the legislative election in 2004 when he was considered by DPP members as a divisive figure within the party.
During the past three years, he has become a virtual loner in the DPP and has been listed as one of the "11 nemeses" within the party who dared to criticize the DPP and call for reform.

Some DPP members disliked his close association with pro-opposition figures, including Sisy Chen, a former independent legislator who left the DPP, and Jaw Shaw-kong, chairman of UFO Radio and supporter of the pan-blue opposition alliance of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

A main reason leading to Shen's isolation in the DPP was his failure to back up President Chen Shui-bian's denial that first lady Wu Shu-jen ever accepted unlawful campaign contributions from Chen Yu-hao, a business tycoon.
During his 2004 re-election campaign, President Chen ordered Chen Yu-hao, former chairman of the Tuntex Group and a fugitive exiled abroad, to be placed on Taiwan's "most wanted list."

A furious Chen Yu-hao revealed in the week before the election that he gave NT$3 million (US$91,900) in cash to help Chen Shui-bian's campaign for Taipei mayor in 1994, and another NT$3 million in 1998 to fund his campaign for a second mayoral term.

Chen Yu-hao said that on both occasions, Shen, who was a legislator at the time and served as Chen Shui-bian's campaign manager, accompanied him to the residence of the president on Minsheng East Road in Taipei and witnessed the handovers of the cash to the first lady.

Chen Yu-hao claimed that he had received thank-you phone calls from Chen Shui- bian on both accounts. Although President Chen denied that his wife ever met with Chen Yu-hao, the allegations cast serious doubt over his integrity and caused a fall in his support rating.

Despite being held in high esteem as a man who always told the truth, Shen neither confirmed nor denied Chen Yu-hao's allegations. As a result, he pleased neither side and drew criticism from within the DPP for not backing up the president. However, he eventually confirmed in June 2006 that he had accompanied Chen You-hao to the president's residence twice to meet with the first lady.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Science Park hopes IC design can become world's No. 1

TEXT.P: Hsinchu Science Park Administration Director-General Huang De-ruei expressed his hope Wednesday that the production value of integrated circuit design, or IC design, will grow to take a 40 percent share of the global market in two or three years, thereby establishing it as No. 1 in the world.

Huang made the remarks as he and his counterparts from the Central and Southern Taiwan Science Park reported on the revenues of the three parks in the first eight months of this year at the invitation of the National Science Council.
Huang said that the revenues of Hsinchu Science park in the January-August period totaled NT$737.3 billion (US$22.34 billion), amodest growth of 3.36 percent from the same period last year.

Of those revenues, the production value of the IC design sector totaled NT$160.5 billion, up 24.85 percent over the same period last year, with a global market share of 20 percent, to rank second in the world.

Among the six major sectors in the Hsinchu Science Park, the IC sector accounted for 72 percent of revenues, the largest, at NT$533.1 billion, up 4.27 percent from the same period last year. The opto-electronics sector is the second largest with revenues of NT$105.5 billion, up 11.42 percent year-on-year.
Huang also reported that exports to Malaysia recorded the greatest growth at 88 percent in the first eight months, which he said is a good thing in terms of market diversification.
Exports to Vietnam also registered an increase, showing that exports to Vietnam will grow rapidly, Huang added.

Yang Wen-ke, director-general of Central Taiwan Science Park, said that although the park is only four years old, it reported revenues of NT$156.48 billion in the first eight months of the year, up 54.66 percent from the same period last year, and the revenues at the end of the year should reach NT$240 billion.

He predicted that the park's revenue next year will reach NT$360 billion with the number of manufacturers stationed in the park reaching 110. He envisioned revenues reaching NT$1 trillion, and the number of manufacturers stationed in the park reaching 150 within a decade.

Southern Taiwan Science Park Director-General Chen Chun-wei said that park revenues reached NT$331.3 billion in the first eight months, up 16.86 percent from the same period last year after strong demands for TFT-LCD due to falling costs and price reductions for flat panel displays.

He predicted production values this year will reach around NT$520 billion, and reach NT$1 trillion within five years thanks to strong demands for high-end communications, digital and consumer electronics products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier defends government's economic records

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has defended the Cabinet's major economy-boosting plans over the years, saying that it would be a distortion of the facts to say that the plans have made a "negative contribution" to the country's economic growth.

Chang made the remarks Tuesday while fielding questions from Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lin Te-fu at a question-and-answer session of the Legislative Yuan about an assessment recently released by the legislature's Budgetary Research Center on next year's total government budget.

The assessment report said that over the past seven years, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration initiated the "8100 Get Taiwan Moving" project, the "Ten New Major Construction Projects" (investing NT$500 billion over five years), and "Mega Investment, Mega Warmth" project.
The claimed that all those economic development projects have failed to boost the country's economy.

Chang questioned the center's evaluation criteria, saying that the country's economic growth rates in recent years have surpassed 4 percent and that the Cabinet has slashed next year's budget for personnel expenses as requested by the legislature.

Meanwhile, in a response to the lawmaker's question about low wage levels in Taiwan compared to those in South Korea, Hsu Chang-yao, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , said that the comparison did not take into account fluctuations of the two countries' currency exchange rates.
In recent years, South Korea's exchange rate has risen by 25 percent, while that of Taiwan has remained quite stable, Hsu went on.

In addition, consumer price levels in South Korea have also increased, Hsu said, adding that these factors contribute to the impression that South Koreans' salaries are higher than those of their Taiwanese counterparts.
Yet, if calculated in terms of global purchasing power, actual wage levels are higher in Taiwan than in South Korea, Hsu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to become mobile technology island: official

TEXT.P: The "Mobile-Taiwan" project will help the country realize its goal of transforming itself into a mobile technology hot spot, an economic official said Wednesday.

The project is part of the government's new 10 major infrastructure projects initiated in 2003, said Shen Rong-jin, deputy director of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Shen made the remarks at a press conference held by Far EasTone Telecommunications Co. to announce a plan to equip the company's 24 shuttle buses traveling between Taipei and the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport with wireless services to be available next month.
The plan is the result of the telecommunications company's participation in the government's "M-Taiwan" project, a company spokesman said.
Bus passengers will be able to check airline schedules, to receive traffic updates, and to surf the Internet wirelessly while vehicles are running at high speeds, the spokesman noted.
The "M-Taiwan" project refers to the construction of broadband pipelines and the promotion of related applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County chief in Hokkaido to learn from its dairy industry

TEXT.P: Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan is currently on a visit to Hokkaido, Japan in an effort to boost trade and learn from the Japanese prefecture's dairy industry.

According to a press release issued by the county government of Changhua in central Taiwan, Cho met with the mayor of Otaru City, a port city of Hokkaido, Tuesday to exchange views on possible bilateral cooperative programs.

Heading a delegation composed of Changhua County Council Speaker Pai Hung-sen and several high-ranking county government officials, Cho visited Hokkaido's Tokai University Wednesday to get a better understanding of park golf, a new form of sport developed in Hokkaido. As the sport requires no special techniques or physical strength, this sport has been popular in Hokkaido among people of all ages as a family sport.
According to Tokai University, golf courses in Hokkaido are closed from November through April due to the icy winter weather.

A Tokai University spokesman suggested that Taiwanese enterprises construct more golf courses to lure more Japanese park golf lovers to spend their vacations in Taiwan, taking advantage of the direct flights between Taiwan and Hokkaido.
Furthermore, if Changhua County can develop more golf courses and hot springs, it could attract 10,000 to 20,000 Japanese tourists to spend the winter there, the spokesman added.

Noting that Hokkaido boasts one of the best dairy industries in the world, Cho said his county government will strengthen communications with this Japanese prefecture to learn from its development in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taisugar chairman resigns to concentrate on election campaign

TEXT.P: Yu Cheng-hsien, chairman of the state-owned enterprise Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar), said Wednesday that he had tendered his resignation two weeks ago to Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen, so that he could concentrate on his campaign for a legislative seat.
Yu, told reporters that he is now on leave, waiting for his successor to take over the chairmanship.

He said that with the election only 100 days away, he has to devote himself full-time to the election campaign and let voters in his constituency -- the Kangshan township in Kaohsiung County -- come to understand the new "single- member constituency, two-vote" system through vigorous publicity.

Yu, 48, was legislator from 1987 to 1993 and served as minister of the interior from 2002 to 2004. He resigned the ministerial post in April 2004 to take responsibility for the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the 2004 presidential election. He was appointed Taisugar chairman in 2005.

The "319 shooting" occurred while Chen and Lu were campaigning in a jeep in Tainan, southern Taiwan. The opposition believes the incident generated sympathy votes for Chen and Lu, helping them to win the election by a mere 29,500 votes. The opposition parties also suspect that the incident was staged, but their efforts to form a commission to investigate the shooting have met resistance from the DPP and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma vows not to double as KMT chairman if elected president

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou vowed Wednesday that he will not double as party chairman if elected president in the March 22, 2008 election.
Ma made the remarks to reporters during a visit to Miaoli County in northern Taiwan.
Ma asserted that if he wins the presidential election, he will not serve double- duty, no matter what the situation, so as to fully dedicate himself to state affairs.

However, Ma declined to comment on whether President Chen Shui-bian should concurrently serve as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman, saying he is not in a position to comment on the DPP's internal affairs.

The DPP chairmanship issue has been under the spotlight since Yu Shyi-kun offered to step down from the post late last month following his indictment by Taipei prosecutors over alleged misuse of special allowance funds during his tenures as premier and as Presidential Office secretary-general.
It has been widely speculated that President Chen may take over the DPP's chairmanship following Yu's resignation.

The DPP's Central Standing Committee (CSC) agreed to accept Yu's offer to resign during its weekly meeting Wednesday and approved a proposal to invite Chen to concurrently take over the party's helm. Chen concurrently served as DPP chairman from 2002-2004 after winning the 2000 presidential election.
It was also agreed in the CSC weekly meeting that the party's Central Executive Committee (CEC) should come to a final decision concerning the DPP chairmanship issue in its Oct. 5 meeting.

Speaking after the CSC weekly meeting, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said that President Chen is "certainly" the best one to take over the party's helm, and that the CEC will make a formal announcement following the Friday meeting so as to help forge party unity in the run-up to the legislative and presidential polls.
A DPP legislative caucus whip said Tuesday that it is the common desire of most party members that President Chen assumes chairmanship and lead the party to win the two coming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice Ministry unveils anti-vote buying film

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice made public Wednesday a short anti-vote buying commercial as part of its efforts to raise public awareness of irregularities in the run-up to the Jan. 12 legislative polls.

The commercial was screened at a news conference presided over by Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin at the Baoan Temple in Taipei's Talungtung district. Hundreds of Talung Elementary School pupils and residents in the nearby region were invited to take part in the event. Schoolchildren chanted anti-vote buying slogans to add fanfare and momentum to the activity.

Shih told the audience that his ministry has started a campaign to fend off vote buying and wipe out irregularities as the legislative and presidential elections approach, and reiterated that cash rewards for successful tips could be as much as NT$10 million.
The Ministry of Justice has to date paid over NT$400 million (US$12.3 million) in cash awards to informants, he noted.

According to Shih, the Justice Ministry has tracked 27 and 1,624 vote-buying cases related to the coming presidential and legislative elections, respectively. Anyone caught buying votes could be jailed for three to 10 years, he said, adding that the ministry is closely watching some 1,665 individuals who might engage in vote-buying ahead of the two key elections.

National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih said in a meeting called later the same day at the agency that police authorities across the country will step up crackdown on gangsters and illegal weapon possession to maintain public order and protect candidates' personal safety prior to the legislative and presidential elections.
In addition, Hou said, police will also go all out to eradicate vote-buying or other activities that might upset the holding of free and fair elections and their results.

Competition among candidates in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative election is expected to be intense due to the adoption of a new "single-member constituency, two-vote system" that will see the current number of legislative seats halved from 225 to 113 in the new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Six universities in Hsinchu to hold joint art season

TEXT.P: The six universities in Hsinchu have reached an agreement on jointly organizing an art season in the northern Taiwan city in 2008, the top cultural affairs official in the city government said Wednesday.
Lin Sung, director of the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Hsinchu city government, told reporters that the art season has been tentatively scheduled for January through April next year.
Terming the six universities an "important asset" of Hsinchu, Lin commended the universities for their active participation in the city's public affairs.
He added that the art season is intended to increase exchanges among the universities and allow students to demonstrate their creative talent through various cultural activities.

The six universities are: National Chiao Tung University, National Tsing Hua University, Chung Hua University, Hsuan Chuang University, Yuanpei Institute of Science and Technology and National Hsinchu University of Education.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP sets up first election command center in Tainan City

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday set up its first election command center in Tainan City in the run-up to next year's legislative and presidential polls, according to a DPP official.

Lee Ying-yuan, former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs who quit that post to serve as general manager for the campaign of DPP candidate Frank Hsieh in the March 22 presidential election, made the announcement at the party's branch in the southern Taiwan city, where the election command center -- the first of its kind in the DPP -- is located.

Almost all DPP heavyweights from the Tainan area attended the center's inauguration at the party's local branch, including Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tian- tsair and City Council Deputy Speaker Kuo Hsing-liang and several councilors, among others.
Lee hailed Hsieh as a charismatic leader capable of overcoming great pressure in times of astounding difficulties -- an outstanding characteristic of Hsieh.

Lee also praised Hsu's achievements in Tainan City since he began serving as mayor from 2001 and expressed hope that Hsu's contributions will help Hsieh win greater voter support in the coming presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate's 'Wild Cursive' receives full-house welcome in N.Y.

TEXT.P: The Cloud Gate Dance Theatre of Taiwan once again impressed audiences in New York Tuesday evening with choreographer Lin Hwai-min's Chinese calligraphy inspired production "Wild Cursive." The opening performance of the 25th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) received a full-house welcome.
"Wild Cursive" is the final chapter of Lin's trilogy. Inspired after studying Chinese calligraphy masterpieces, Lin created the first installment of "Cursive" in 2001.

Lin told media in New York the process in producing the trilogy has much to do with the development of the dancers. He said that training in martial arts, tai chi tao yin, modern dance, ballet, meditation, and Chinese opera movements enables the dancers to turn themselves into bodily brushes.

In 2003, Cloud Gate opened the Melbourne International Arts Festival with "Cursive II", winning both the Age Critics' Award and the Patrons' Award. In 2006, "Cursive: A Trilogy" was chosen as the best dance choreography of the year as a result of critics' poll by Ballettanz and Theaterheute.

Cloud Gate made its BAM Next Wave debut in 1995 with "Nine Songs". In 2000, the dance theater brought Hermann Hesse's "Siddhartha" inspired "Songs of the Wanderers" to the Next Wave, and again in 2003 was invited to present the internationally-acclaimed "Moon Water" at the festival.
Five performances of "Wild Cursive" at the BAM Howard Gilman Opera House are scheduled on Oct. 2, and Oct. 4-7.

A co-sponsor of the event, the Asia Society in New York, invited Lin Hwai-min to speak on Cloud Gate and to give his views on choreography on Oct. 3. BAM has also arranged "a dialogue with Lin Hwai-min" moderated by art critic Anna Kisselgoff at the academy on Oct. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: UK official promotes European directives on producer responsibility

TEXT.P: A visiting Britain official is promoting European directives, which set targets on the collection, recycling and recovery of all types of electrical goods, to Taiwanese companies and government agencies.

The directives apply to all electrical products in the European market and focus on producer responsibility, extending the "polluter pays" principle, said Steven Andrews, an official who came from U.K.'s Department of Business Enterprise and Regulatory Reform (BERR).

Andrews is promoting the WEEE (Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment) and RoHS (Restriction of Hazardous Substances) directives, both of which were adopted by the European Union in 2003 to regulate the production of electrical products, in this, his first visit to Taiwan.

Taiwan is a must-go stop because of its leading position in the electrical and information communication technology (ICT) industries, said Andrews, who had visited Japan and North America to promote the regulations.

WEEE directive asked all EEE producers who sell their products in Europe to finance the collection and treatment of WEEE. The RoHS directive also seeks to reduce the environmental impact of EEE by restricting the use of six hazardous substances during manufacture, Andrews summed up.

According to statistics provided by the Industrial Development Bureau of Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, he said, more than 90 percent of Taiwan products are in compliance with the RoHS directive.

Implementing the directives means short-term production cost increases for companies, which must re-design products to meet the requirement, he said. In the long term, he noted, prices for ICT products will invariably go down with time, and by using fewer resources, the industry will see its costs drop.

Several countries, including Japan and the United State, have described the directives as "a European way of excluding other countries' products in the EU market, " he said, adding that the U.S. also claims that it is a breach of World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations.
But Andrews stated, "It's not true, since the directives applied to all 27 EU member states as well. And the WTO has issued a clearance [of the directives]."

By launching the initiate, Europe is taking the lead to protect environment, reduce resources consumption and promote energy efficiency. And it's being recognized as the right thing to do, by the many countries copying the European initiate, he said.
Andrews is scheduled to speak at the 2007 Resource Recycling Forum, which is taking place in Taipei from Oct. 3-5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan issue becomes international one: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the Taiwan issue has become an international one, as more than 140 countries discussed the country's U.N. membership bid for four hours at the General Assembly for the first time this year.

The development shows that the government has adopted the right strategy in launching its U.N. bid under the name Taiwan rather than the official title, Republic of China, as in its previous 14 annual bids, and therefore captured international attention, Chen added.

The president made the remarks during a meeting with members from Taiwan chapters of the Kiwanis International, the Rotary International, the Lions Clubs International, and Junior Chamber International at the Presidential Office.
Chen noted that the success of the U.N. bid cannot solely rely on the government or the president alone, but rather requires a collective effort from public and private sectors.

In addition, Chen said that while the world community harshly condemns the ruling military junta in Myanmar for bloody crackdowns on protests staged by Myanmese civilians and Buddhist monks demanding democracy, China regarded the crackdowns as the Southeast Asian country's "internal affairs" which it claimed "does not adversely affect the regional peace."
Chen expressed regret over China's remarks and said that it is hard to believe that "different countries could have different understandings of universal values, such as democracy and freedom."

Universal values should transcend national borders, race, politics, and political parties, Chen went on, adding that while many countries are imposing sanctions on the Myanmese junta government, China chooses to take side with violence.
He reiterated that the planned referendum on whether to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is not intended to change the country's official title.

Through the U.N. bid, the Taiwanese people wish to make their voices heard by the international community, Chen said, adding that the world community now increasingly understands the demands of local people.

Citing the results of a recent survey, Chen said that a mere 3 percent of the American people who responded to the survey have visited Taiwan, but up to 55 percent said that they support Taiwan becoming a U.N. member.

The ratio would increase to over 70 percent if Taiwan passes a referendum to back the U.N. bid next year, Chen continued. By then, U.S. lawmakers, the government, or even the president would need to follow the mainstream public opinion to throw support behind Taiwan's U.N. bid, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 4, or the 24th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: Six universities in Hsinchu to hold joint art season

TEXT.P: The six universities in Hsinchu have reached an agreement on jointly organizing an art season in the northern Taiwan city in 2008, the top cultural affairs official in the city government said Wednesday.
Lin Sung, director of the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Hsinchu city government, told reporters that the art season has been tentatively scheduled for January through April next year.
Terming the six universities an "important asset" of Hsinchu, Lin commended the universities for their active participation in the city's public affairs.
He added that the art season is intended to increase exchanges among the universities and allow students to demonstrate their creative talent through various cultural activities.

The six universities are: National Chiao Tung University, National Tsing Hua University, Chung Hua University, Hsuan Chuang University, Yuanpei Institute of Science and Technology and National Hsinchu University of Education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice Ministry unveils anti-vote buying film

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice made public Wednesday a short anti-vote buying commercial as part of its efforts to raise public awareness of irregularities in the run-up to the Jan. 12 legislative polls.

The commercial was screened at a news conference presided over by Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin at the Baoan Temple in Taipei's Talungtung district. Hundreds of Talung Elementary School pupils and residents in the nearby region were invited to take part in the event. Schoolchildren chanted anti-vote buying slogans to add fanfare and momentum to the activity.

Shih told the audience that his ministry has started a campaign to fend off vote buying and wipe out irregularities as the legislative and presidential elections approach, and reiterated that cash rewards for successful tips could be as much as NT$10 million.
The Ministry of Justice has to date paid over NT$400 million (US$12.3 million) in cash awards to informants, he noted.

According to Shih, the Justice Ministry has tracked 27 and 1,624 vote-buying cases related to the coming presidential and legislative elections, respectively. Anyone caught buying votes could be jailed for three to 10 years, he said, adding that the ministry is closely watching some 1,665 individuals who might engage in vote-buying ahead of the two key elections.

National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih said in a meeting called later the same day at the agency that police authorities across the country will step up crackdown on gangsters and illegal weapon possession to maintain public order and protect candidates' personal safety prior to the legislative and presidential elections.
In addition, Hou said, police will also go all out to eradicate vote-buying or other activities that might upset the holding of free and fair elections and their results.

Competition among candidates in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative election is expected to be intense due to the adoption of a new "single-member constituency, two-vote system" that will see the current number of legislative seats halved from 225 to 113 in the new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sea warning for Typhoon Krosa may be issued Thursday: CWB

TEXT.P: A sea warning for Typhoon Krosa may be issued later Thursday if the storm maintains its current speed and direction of movement, forecasters at the Central Weather Bureau said.

As of 8 a.m. Thursday, Krosa was centered 850 km east-southeast of Oluanpi -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving northwesterly at 15 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 165 kph, forecasters said, adding that the typhoon is likely to continue to increase in intensity.

They said further observation is required to determine how much of an impact the typhoon will have on Taiwan, adding that the weather will likely remain unstable over the next few days, especially over the weekend by which time the storm is expected to have come closer to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 72.68 points to close at 9,627.39.
The bourse opened at 9,663.53 and fluctuated between 9,676.35 and 9,574.01. A total of 5 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$162.75 billion (US$4.99 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 4.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 4.6 percent, textile stocks at 2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.4 percent, and construction issues at 1.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up 0.2 percent and machinery and electronics shares increasing 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 718, with 227 stocks remaining unchanged.

TAIEX Index futures for November decreased 94 points to finish at 9,681, with 614 contracts traded, while December futures decreased 85 points to end at 9,685, with 58 contract transactions.
