DOC.HEADLINE: President raps China for trying to bar intervention on Myanmar issue

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian condemned China Thursday for attempting to block international intervention on the issue of Myanmar after the recent violent crackdown on demonstrations against military rule in the Southeast Asian country by calling the incident an "internal affair" of Myanmar.

Chen said in the latest issue of his online newsletter that China's move to define the incident as an "internal affair" of Myanmar is aimed at influencing the international community's perception of the situation in Myanmar and exonerating the Beijing-backed military junta.
Most importantly, Beijing is trying to find a sound excuse to justify its "anti- democracy, anti-freedom and anti-human rights" despotic governance of the Chinese people, Chen said.

Based on this reason, Chen continued, China has repeatedly emphasized that "different countries" can adopt "different standards" for democracy, freedom and human rights in an attempt to eliminate the universality of these values so as to allow all dictators around the world to legitimize their despotism.

Pointing out that China has continued to suppress dissidents, Falun Gong followers and press freedom in the country, intimidate neighboring democracies, including Taiwan, and secretly support dictatorial regimes in the rest of the world, the president urged leading democracies in Europe and the Americas not to deliberately use a looser standard in judging China.
"We must again emphasize that there is only one standard for democracy, freedom and human rights," Chen said.

"Only if we courageously pinpoint the facts of China's violations against democracy, freedom and human rights, condemn the acts, and sanction China for them can we provide any protection to regional and international peace and stability," he added.

Noting that Western democracies' conniving at human rights abuses and suppression of freedom by the Nazi and Fascist regimes in Europe during the interwar years from 1921-1939 allowed these dictatorial regimes to become powerful at a great cost to humanity, Chen said that history has taught us that "paying no regard to the disadvantaged is tantamount to nurturing evil."
He said Taiwan, as an emerging democracy, is willing to contribute to regional and global peace and development based on the universal principles of democracy, freedom and human rights.
Also, Taiwan will closely monitor the developments in Myanmar and provide any humanitarian assistance whenever necessary, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 allies support Taiwan's bid at U.N. sessions: MOFA

TEXT.P: Eighteen of Taiwan's diplomatic allies voiced support for Taiwan's membership bid at the 62nd U.N. General Assembly session held Sept. 25 to Oct. 3, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Thursday.

Top leaders of 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies -- namely Honduras, Paraguay, El Salvador, Swaziland, Sao Tome and Principe, Nauru, Palau, Gambia, the Marshall Islands, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Lucia, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Tuvalu, the Solomon Islands, Burkina Faso, Belize, and Kiribati -- spoke in support of Taiwan's U.N. membership bid during the session, the officials said.

Speaking on the first day of the debate session on Sept.25, Panamanian President Martin Torrijos expressed concerns about the tension in the Taiwan Strait, urging countries in areas that face security threats to take steps to alleviate tensions and resolve disputes by peaceful means, according to the officials.

In their speeches delivered during the debate sessions, representatives of the 17 countries, including several heads of state, all pointed out that Taiwan, as an independent and peace-loving sovereign state, is qualified to become a U.N. member.
They cried foul at the United Nations' exclusion of Taiwan, saying such unfair treatment and discrimination should come to an end.

Moreover, they criticized U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon for failing to impartially handle Taiwan's membership application in line with the U.N. Charter and relevant meeting regulations. They also demanded that the United Nations respond to the 23 million Taiwan people's aspiration and embrace Taiwan as a new member.

The leaders of Gambia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Solomon Islands further urged the United Nations to take active steps to alleviate cross-strait tensions and help hammer out a peaceful solution to the disputes between the two sides.

Among Taiwan's 24 diplomatic allies, only five -- Haiti, Nicaragua, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic and Malawi -- didn't speak up for Taiwan at this year's U.N. General Assembly session. Taiwan's one other ally -- the Vatican -- is not a U.N. member.
The MOFA expressed its gratitude in a news release for the diplomatic allies' generosity in lending faithful support to Taiwan's national cause and U.N. membership bid.

The ministry also reaffirmed the government's stance on the U.N. membership issues, saying the quest for U.N. representation under the name Taiwan is an established policy and urging the international community to resist China's pressure and make a just and sensible response to Taiwan's appeal.

Meanwhile, the U.N. representative of Malawi wrote letters to U.N. Secretary- General Ban, Srgjan Kerim, president of the 62nd session of the General Assembly, and Leslie Christian, Ghana's permanent representative to the U.N. who is serving as the president of the U.N. Security Council this month, urging the world body to deal with Taiwan's membership application "properly and seriously."

DOC.HEADLINE: President to 'seriously consider' calls for him to serve as DPP head

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stopped short of saying Thursday that he would accept the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, but he did say he would "seriously consider" the matter.

President Chen made the remarks after a meeting with local dignitaries and a visit to a temple in Taipei County, one day after the DPP Central Standing Committee "reluctantly" accepted the resignation of DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and unanimously passed a resolution asking President Chen to assume the post. Chen served as the party chairman between 2002-2004.

Whether Chen will accept the post should become clear Friday when a provisional DPP Central Executive Committee meeting is slated to be held. The participants in the meeting are expected to unanimously urge Chen to take the party's helm.
The president said he "does not know if [he] is capable of shouldering the position of DPP chairmanship, " pointing out that it is "no easy job."

Chen said that as the president, he is already shouldering a burden of a "weight of 100 kg" and that if he is to concurrently serve as the DPP chairman, this would require him to shoulder "another 100 kg."
"If the party indeed expects me to shoulder the responsibility, I'll seriously consider the matter," he said.
He urged former Presidential Office Senior Advisor Koo Kuan-min to use his sway with Yu to try to persuade the latter to stay on as chairman.
Pointing out that he hopes Yu will stay on in the post, Chen said that if Yu is willing to do so, then the DPP Central Executive Committee can still keep him.

Meanwhile, Yeh Chu-lan, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Thursday that the president has heard the call of the DPP for him to take the helm of the party but "has to take various things into consideration."
"The president is now cautiously thinking about the matter, " Yeh said.

Yu announced his decision to resign late last month after being indicted on graft charges for his alleged misuse of a "special allowance fund" during his terms as premier and as Presidential Office secretary-general.

Despite calls for him to stay, he expressed that he was adamant about resigning after his more radical version of the "normal country resolution" was voted down at the party's national congress last Sunday.

The version, which included the words "changing the country's title to 'Taiwan' from the current Republic of China to declare to world that Taiwan is a sovereign independent country, " failed to receive the support of more than half of the congress delegates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan University to become first complete academy in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The National University of Tainan (NUTN) in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, is expected to become the first complete learning institution in Taiwan in 2009 when it begins to accept junior high school students, the university's chief said Thursday.

NUTN, established 109 years ago as a normal college during the Japanese colonial era, now operates a number of graduate institutes, colleges, a senior high school, an elementary school, a kindergarten and classes for supplementary education, receiving students aged from two-and-a-half to adults.

When the university begins to accept junior high school students, a student could receive his or her entire education and continue throughout his or her life without having to change schools, said Huang Hsiu-shuang, president of the university.

With an "extended family" of faculty and students, NUTN is scheduled to relocate its main campus and teaching buildings to a much bigger campus to be located in the Chiku rural township in Tainan County in seven years, Huang said.

NUTN is scheduled to celebrate its 110th founding anniversary in 2008, Huang said, adding that noted alumni including Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng are expected to return to the school for a series of celebratory activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP-backed referendum petition `could make world record'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) aims to collect 2 million signatures by the end of this month for the party's petition to hold a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid, "in the hope that the number can be recognized as a Guinness World Record," a DPP official said Thursday.

So far, 917,000 people have signed the petition for the referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, which is expected to be held alongside the March 2008 presidential election, according to DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung.
Lin said he has checked related documents and discovered that no referendum- related records are listed in the Guinness World Records.

Claiming that Taiwan has the world's highest threshold for the initiation of referendums, Lin said the DPP will apply to have the signature number listed in the annual reference book after the party achieves its goal of collecting 2 million signatures.
According to Lin, 60 percent of people responding to a recent DPP-organized opinion poll think the referendum is very important, compared with 30 percent who think the referendum is not important.

Also, the survey found that nearly 90 percent of the supporters of the "pan- green camp" of the DPP and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union are in favor of the referendum and will turn out for the 2008 presidential election, Lin said.

The petition is the second phase of a procedure in which the DPP is required to obtain the signatures of more than 5 percent of the number of eligible voters in the last presidential election -- more than 825,359 -- after obtaining more than 0.5 percent of the number in the first phase.

The DPP, which is determined to push for the referendum despite strong opposition by the United States, had originally set its target at 1 million signatures. However, the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee officially raised the target to 2 million Wednesday.

While Taiwan has tried without success to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993, this year marks the first time the country has applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan.

However, following the return of Taiwan's application by the U.N. Secretariat first in July and again in August, an item endorsed by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the United Nations to address Taiwan's membership application has also been excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2015 textile industry output projected at NT$580 billion

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has projected the annual output value of Taiwan's textile industry for 2015 at NT$580 billion (US$17.75 billion) and has suggested development directions such as innovation for the industry, according to Economic Minister Steve R.L. Chen.
Chen made the remarks Wednesday at the opening ceremony of the Textile International Forum and Exhibition 2007 in Taipei City.
He said textile products should focus on being innovative, functional, industrial and with high added value if they are to create more business opportunities.

The output value of the textile industry for 2006 reached NT$460 billion, with the textile trade surplus reaching US$9 billion, Chen said, adding that Taiwan's textile industry has made great contributions to the nation's economic development.
Taiwan should enforce its competitiveness through innovation and good market segmentation to counter the impact of cheap products from emerging countries, Chen said.

With a development history of nearly 60 years, Taiwan's textile industry has rich experience and strong ability for industry transformation, which will bring further improvement in business performance and Taiwan's economic outlook, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.026 to close at NT$32.599.
A total of US$772 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.573 and fluctuated between NT$32.543 and NT$32.628.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Development Fund to sponsor biotech, IC companies

TEXT.P: The National Development Fund under the Executive Yuan will appropriate some NT$70 million (about US$2.15 million) to two local companies by mid-October as part of its NT$10 billion funding project dubbed "investing in local small- and medium-sized enterprises," officials disclosed Thursday.

Sources at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) also reported that the ministry is evaluating another 91 candidate companies and that 18 of them will be selected by the end of this year to share another NT$330 million under the same project.

For the two companies to be funded, the MOEA' s Small and Medium Enterprise Administration Deputy Director-General Huang Wen-gu said one of them is an integrated circuit manufacturer specialized in touch panels and the other is a biotech company focused on disease prevention and biological detection.
The IC company will receive NT$30 million, while the biotech company will be injected with NT$40 million, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG David Cameron challenges Gordon Brown to an election
David Cameron laid out his programme for government yesterday, insisting that he had the personal qualities to lead Britain a nd issuing a direct challenge to Gordon Brown to call a general election.

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Visco saved by one vote.
The Senate rejected Wednesday a motion introduced by the opposition alliance "the Liberty House", which asked Vice Minister of Finance and Economics Vincenzo Visco to quit, by one single vote of difference: 157 against 156.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Villar, JdV laud decision on ZTE deal
Senate President Manuel B. Villar Jr. yesterday welcomed the cancellation of the $ 329-million national broadband network (NBN) deal with China's ZTE Corp., saying President Arroyo heeded calls for her to "walk the talk" on government's anti-corruption drive.
The Philippine Daily InquirerG NBN deal probe in limbo
MANILA, Philippines -- The Senate probe of the $329-million contract for the National Broadband Network (NBN) project is in limbo amid allegations that Malacanang and a "powerful businessman" have allegedly "co-opted" the blue ribbon committee chaired by Sen. Alan Peter Cayetano.
The Philippine StarG Broadband project still on, says Palace
The government is determined to set up a national broadband network despite its scrapping of a $329-million NBN deal with ZTE Corp. of China amid allegations of bribery and corruption that led to the resignation of elections chief Benjamin Abalos.
The Manila TimesG Senate to push on with ZTE hearings
The Senate blue-ribbon committee will continue investigating the National Broadband Network deal with ZTE Corp. despite the President's decision to cancel it, Sen. Alan Peter Cayetano said Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news

The Moscow TimesGGazprom Says Deal Reached With Kiev
Gazprom said Wednesday that it had reached a deal with Ukraine over a large gas debt after threatening to reduce supplies, but Kiev denied that it owed as much as the $1.3 billion cited by the company. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: Visiting foreign officials learn about community development

TEXT.P: Foreign officials from 23 countries have come to Taiwan to attend a camp in which they can share Taiwan's experience in community development, a government foundation said Thursday.
The International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) said the camp on community and tourism development has been one of the most popular camps sponsored by the ICDF.
This year's two-week camp opened Oct. 3 and will last through Oct. 16, the officials said.

This year, the ICDF will also cooperate with Hsinchu City, Hsinchu County and Miaoli County to demonstrate on how to work with the public to push for community regeneration and push for local tourism through policy implementation.
The officials taking part in the camp include tourism officials from The Gambia and Chile, Venezuelan parliamentarians and Indonesian agricultural officials, the officials said.

In addition to the regular classes, the ICDF has also invited the participants to take part in a forum with officials from Hsinchu City, Hsinchu County and Miaoli County, an "international night" party and a Hakka culture and food party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traffic controls for Double Ten National Day

TEXT.P: Traffic controls will be enforced in the area surrounding the Presidential Office Oct. 9-10 when the country will be celebrating Double Ten National Day, the Taipei Municipal Police Department announced Thursday.

When the traffic controls are enforced in two stages between 10 p.m. Oct. 9 and 1 p.m. Oct. 10 -- National Day -- vehicles and pedestrians will be prevented from using certain roads leading to Ketagalan Boulevard near the Presidential Plaza, the police said.

A National Day rally is scheduled to be held on the Presidential Plaza in the morning of Oct. 10, with the armed forces expected to display their latest weaponry systems and combat skills, along with performances by private groups and students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inspection agency to check Chinese toys after U.S. recall

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection will step up safety checks on one brand of Chinese-made toy handbells for children after U.S. retailing giant Target announced a voluntary recall of 80,000 of the toys due to safety concerns, a bureau spokesman announced Thursday.

According to an Oct. 2 statement issued by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, a Taichung-based company is in charge of distributing the toys, which are shaped like baseballs, soccer balls and basketballs, the spokesman said.

The statement indicated that although no injuries related to the toys have been reported so far, the toys contain small parts that can cause choking or suffocation if young children try to swallow them.

Over the next six month, the bureau will conduct inspections on the toys on a batch-by-batch basis to prevent the toys from reaching the local market, the spokesman said, adding that all toys, whether domestically made or imported, are required to pass inspections before entering the local market.

The bureau will also closely monitor the domestic toy market to keep out dangerous toys, the spokesman said. He added that consumers are encouraged to inform the agency if they are aware of the sale of substandard toys.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau issues sea warning for Typhoon Krosa

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for Typhoon Krosa at 5: 30 p.m. Thursday.
The weather bureau warned ships operating in the Bashi Channel and seas off Taiwan's northern and southeastern coasts to be on the alert for strong winds and high waves.

As of 5 p.m., Krosa was centered 690 km east-southeast of Oluanpi -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan -- moving northwest at 15 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 173 kph, CWB meteorologists said, adding that the typhoon is likely to continue to increase in intensity.

According to the course of the typhoon's movement, the outer rim of Typhoon Krosa -- with a radius of 250 km -- is expected to cover the entire island Saturday, further closing with its eye moving across northern Taiwan by Sunday, when its impact on the island will be the greatest, they forecast.
The weather will be unstable for the entire island from Friday, with sporadic rain forecast for northern and northeastern Taiwan, the forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Secret U.S. Endorsement of Severe Interrogations
In February 2005, the Justice Department issued an opinion that provided explicit authorization to barrage terror suspects with a combination of painful physical and psychological tactics, according to officials.
The Wall Street Journal: REPUBLICAN VOTERS BELIEVE free trade is bad for the U.S. economy, a shift in opinion that mirrors Democratic views, a new WSJ/NBC poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30% of Taiwan expatriates in U.S., Australia, Canada want to return

TEXT.P: Thirty percent of Taiwanese expatriates living in the United States, Australia and Canada are considering returning to Taiwan, according to the results of a survey conducted by the Chinese Compatriot Affairs Commission.
Commission officials provided the figure when they were invited to attend a seminar sponsored by the Taoyuan Real Estate Development Association.

The survey results show that 33 percent of Taiwanese expatriates in the United States are considering returning to Taiwan, compared with 31 percent who said they are uncertain and 34 percent who said they are not considering the idea.

Fifty-six percent of those who said they want to return said it was mainly because of a desire to return to their roots, followed by medical care considerations (14 percent) and employment opportunities (13 percent).

In the survey on Taiwan expatriates in Australia, 33 percent said they are considering returning to Taiwan, compared with 47 percent who said they are not certain and 20 percent who ruled out such a possibility.
The main reason for return is employment opportunities (39 percent), followed by a return to their roots (28 percent) and starting their own business (18 percent).
For those who do not want to return to Taiwan, over half of them said they have become used to Australia.

Thirty-three precent of Taiwan expatriates in Canada said they are considering a return to Taiwan, compared with 20 percent who said they are not certain and 29 percent who said they are not considering such a possibility.

For those considering a return, 22 percent cited the reason of seeking work, followed by a return to their roots, 21 percent, and for various other reasons such as wanting to start their own business, cheaper and comprehensive medical care, as well as taking care of elderly family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Iraqis to Pay China $100M for Weapons
News of major arms deal comes as a top U.S. commander tells Post he expects U.S. troops to stay in Iraq for "at least three to five more years."
The Washington Times:21st century comes to Tibet
Tibet, for centuries a Himalayan kingdom lost in time, is lost no longer. China's shift to a market economy and its relentless drive for development have brought the region storming to the cusp of the 21st century, and in some places over the edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Kaohsiung Film Festival to open Oct. 26

TEXT.P: The 2007 Kaohsiung Film Festival, sponsored by the Kaohsiung city government, is scheduled to open Oct. 26 for a 10-day run to screen 52 domestic and foreign films.

According to the city government's Department of Information, altogether, there will be 97 film screenings at two locations in the southern Taiwan city: Oscar Digital Theaters and Kaohsiung Municipal Film Archive.

Among other domestic films to be shown will be the Most Distant Course, directed by Lin Jing-jie, which won the International Film Critics' Week Award for best film at the International Venice Film Festival last month.

The film is about how a psychiatrist on the verge of a nervous break down, a sound technician dumped by his girlfriend, and an office girl whose boyfriend takes another lover, manage to overcome the emotional stress and change their lives.

Also to be screened will be the newly released Summer's Tail, by Taiwanese director Cheng Wen-tang, about how two high school dropouts, together with a gifted student and a Japanese exchange student, savor their freedom and the joy of youth at a secret hideout.
Two acclaimed Japanese films will have their Taiwan premieres at the festival: Maiko Haaaan!!!, by director Nobuo Mizuta, and Turtles Are Surprisingly Fast Swimmers, by director Satoshi Miki.

The former is a saga about a Japanese salaryman and his single-minded quest to live as an apprentice geisha, while the latter is a comedy about how an ordinary Japanese housewife applies for a job working as spy for a foreign organization.

According to the organizers, the films to be screened at the festival focus on five main themes: futuristic films, spectacular debuts, documentaries for ordinary people, prospective directors offering new Taiwanese experiences, and new waves and subcultures.
In addition to the film screenings, film directors and actors will attend to various seminars to share their views and experiences with the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wanted ex-investigator expatriated from Malaysia

TEXT.P: A former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MOJIB) officer who fled the country in June this year was repatriated from Malaysia Thursday.

Ou Tsung-jung, formerly an investigator with the MOJIB Taipei Office, was indicted by Taipei District Prosecutors' Office on charges of corruption, embezzlement and theft in late 2001 after he was discovered to have stolen 34 antiques or artifacts owned by former Kuomintang Legislator Wu Tse-yuan.
Wu was indicted in 1996 on charges of corruption related to two graft cases involving the building of two waste water processing plants in Taipei County.

At the time, Ou was one of the MOJIB investigators responsible for Wu's cases. In November 1996, the investigators searched Wu's residence and removed 77 antiques, bronzes, ivory carvings and other artifacts as evidence.
In March 2001 after his indictment, Wu demanded the return of all his property. The MOJIB Taipei Office checked the items and found that 34 were missing.
Ou's colleagues than searched Ou's residence and discovered the missing items, along with checks and IOUs that Ou embezzled from other cases he had handled.
After he was given a prison term of five years and four months for graft, embezzlement and theft in late 2001, Ou appealed. Judges from the Supreme Court upheld the sentence.
Ou again appealed, and in June this year, the National Police Agency was informed that Ou had fled the country, together with his family, for Malaysia using passports from Belize.
The National Police Agency then informed the Malaysian police, who in turn apprehended Ou Oct. 1 on an expired visa.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice presidential candidate visits U.S. Congress
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/04/07 21:15:34 (By Chiehyu Lin and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's vice presidential candidate, Vincent Siew, visited the U.S. Congress on the first day of his visit to America, with an aim of strengthening bilateral relations, the party's representative in Washington, D.C. said Wednesday.

Jason Yuan said Siew met with 18 senators, including Chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee Carl Levin, Chairman of the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Joe Lieberman, and Sen. Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader.
The senators stated that they expect Taiwan will act as a peacemaker in the Asia-Pacific area and take pragmatic measures to maintain regional peace across the Taiwan Strait, Yuan said.
Siew replied that the KMT understands their concerns and will act responsibly instead of acting as a "troublemaker, " if victorious in the upcoming elections.

The House Committee on Foreign Affairs held a welcome party for Siew the same day, which was attended by 24 House members, including the committee's Chairman Tom Lantos, Co-Chairman of the House Congressional Taiwan Caucus Steve Chabot, and senior Republican Congresswoman Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, as well as House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer.
They all praised Taiwan's freedom and democracy, and agreed that the Taiwanese people have the right to decide their future.

Siew introduced the KMT's political vision to the senators, congressmen and congresswomen, and said that the KMT supports Taiwan's purchase of F-16 C/D jet fighters from America. He added that both Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties hope the U.S. government would consent to the deal.

Lantos and Ros-Lehtinen both mentioned that the House of Representatives unanimously passed Resolution 676 the day before, declaring that the United States, consistent with the Taiwan Relations Act, will make available to Taiwan articles and services necessary to maintaining a self-sufficient defense capacity.

Siew told reporters that the warm welcome he received in America is indicative of the good friendship between Taiwan and America, and has also indicated that the United States pays great attention to bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. experience 'undesirable' for Taiwan: Envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/04/07 21:33:27 (By Michelle Tsai and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong experience provides an undesirable and unacceptable model for Taiwan given that Hong Kong's records on human rights, freedom, and democracy have worsened since its handover to China in 1997, Taiwan's representative to the United States Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

Wu was responding to a question from the audience after delivering a speech at the Leadership Institute, a Virginia-based organization which provides seminars and workshops to conservatives in the U.S.
Wu said that the Chinese government has been touting the "one country, two systems" model of Hong Kong to Taiwan in its campaign to make the island accept unification with China.
He noted that the Taiwanese people are resisting China for two reasons -- the wealth gap between the two sides, as well as China's totalitarian political system.
Wu said he believes that if China turns itself into another U.S. or the United Kingdom, it would encounter less resistance from the people of Taiwan.
Meanwhile, he said if China is to become a democracy like the U.S., it will need to learn to respect the will of the Taiwanese people.
In addition, Wu said that Taiwan is a de facto independent country, even though the U.S. does not recognize the country's statehood.
As Taiwan enjoys a vigorous democracy and a brisk economy, people in the country think that they are entitled to be a member of the international organizations, Wu said.
However, Taiwan has been barred from joining the United Nations and the World Health Organization, which he said is "unfair to Taiwan."
Wu blasted China for relentlessly oppressing Taiwan and for claiming that Taiwan is a part of China, which he said threatens Taiwan's participation in the world community.

Noting that China has continued to provide assistance to dictatorships, including North Korea, Myanmar, and Iran, Wu said that China does not simply pose a threat to Taiwan but also creates problems for other democratic countries.
As China is expanding its military clout, and thus escalates tensions in East Asia, enhanced cooperation between Taiwan, Japan, and the U.S. is needed to ensure security in the region, Wu went on.
Saying that there are frequent exchanges between Taiwan and the U.S., Wu noted that Taiwanese people share a similar mentality with their American counterparts.
However, Wu noted that recently the U.S. government's image has not been very good in Taiwan as it opposes the Taiwan government's push for the country's bid to enter the U.N. under the name Taiwan.

Citing the results of a recent survey, he said that 16.8 percent of the survey respondents consider the U.S. government to be "friendly," indicating that the ratio saw a drop from last year's 32.2 percent.

Wu said that the U.S. government could improve its image in Taiwan by granting visa-free access to Taiwanese people, allowing the use of Taiwanese driving licenses in the U.S., signing a free tree agreement with Taiwan, selling more defensive weapons to Taiwan, and strongly supporting Taiwan's participation in the international community.

Although Taiwan maintains a good relationship with the U.S., there are some limits for Taiwan, Wu noted, giving an example that on his own name card, he is not called "Taiwan's Representative" but "Representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO)."
As a result, he is sometimes regarded as a company's sales representative and has even been asked what product he sells, according to Wu.
We said that there are also many restrictions on the broadcasting of Taiwan's national anthem and the display of the country's national flag in the U.S., and "that hurts sometimes," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen not to address Double Ten National Day rally

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that President Chen Shui- bian will not address the National Day rally in front of the Presidential Office this year.

Wang, the chief organizer of the National Day celebration ceremony, said that the Presidential Office has given notice that the president will not address the rally and that the message he wants to deliver to the nation will be expressed in a meeting held within the Presidential Office prior to the rally.
The practice of the president addressing the National Day rally has been observed for years.

However, last year, as the president was addressing the rally, opposition legislators sitting on the two sides of the grandstands unfurled red banners and flashed 'thumbs down" signs to show their support for an ongoing campaign to depose the president over a spate of corruption allegations against his family members and close aides, their actions prompted the president to suggest that the rally be scrapped in 2007.
Wang said that he will address the rally and then enter the Presidential Office to invite the president to join rally participants and observe the performances.

Wang also said that in respect to the rally's host -- the Presidential Office -- a publicity board bearing the slogan on Taiwan's bid to U.N. membership in front of the Presidential Office will not be removed.

Noting that last year protesters from the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign disrupted National Day celebration activities, he expressed hope that they will observe order and not disturb the progression of celebration activities this year.
The "National Defense Show" arranged by the Ministry of the National Defense (MND) is expected to be the main attraction of the rally, which will be run from 9 a.m. till noon.

The MND has mobilized 2,300 military personnel, 71 fighter planes and various armored vehicles for the show, although the long-range Hsiungfeng missiles, which reportedly could hit targets in China, will not be on display.

The planes will pass the Presidential Office in flying formation to kick off this part of the show. Marching bands will then lead military personnel to display various kinds of weaponry and equipment, culminating with elite parachutists gliding down Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug contaminated crabs from India ordered destroyed

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) ordered Thursday that a batch of live crabs imported from India be destroyed after it was discovered that they contained residue of the forbidden antibiotic nitrofurans, a DOH official said that same day.

Officials from the DOH Bureau of Food Safety said that 384 kgs of live crabs, imported from India by a company in Taipei County, had been found to contain nitrofuran metabolites -- substances that indicate use of the drug.

The concentration of nitrofuran metabolites detected in the Indian crabs stood at 5.4 ppb, in contravention of Taiwan's regulations, which allow no nitrofuran metabolites in any seafood produce, regardless of whether it is imported or locally-produced.
The officials said that consumers can be at ease as none of this batch of live crabs from India had been distributed on the domestic market.
In the wake of this finding, the DOH has increased the inspection rate of India- imported live crabs from 5 to 20 percent, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peace the most important aspect of German unification: academia

TEXT.P: The most important aspect that the experience of German unification might offer Taiwan is that there was not a single incident of bloodshed, a visiting German professor said Thursday in Taipei.

"There was not a drop of blood shed during the process of German unification. I think it's the most important part of the experience," said Rudolph Wagner, a professor at Germany's Heidelberg University and one of the most respected sinologists in Europe, during a roundtable with press.

Wagner is scheduled to deliver a speech, titled "German Unification: Popular Culture, Maoist Students, and the Socialist Disneyland, " Saturday in an international lecture series organized by Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation.

The background to and process of German unification was unique, as is the Taiwan Strait issue, which is why the experience cannot be duplicated, he said, adding that it's not suitable to compare these two cases.

Most West German citizens neither talked about unification, nor saw it coming six weeks before the 1989 unification. In fact, it was East German citizens who pushed for unification. And the German unification essentially defied post-Cold War common sense, which postulated that continued separation, rather than unification, was more likely he pointed out.
Wagner described German unification as an "accident" of history amid the unpredictable and rapid changing international situation of the late 1980s.
"Wait for the historical moment, then something will happen, " he said in a comment on the future of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

With a Ph.D. from the University of Munich, Wagner has done extensive research on Buddhism, Taoist philosophy, and contemporary Chinese politics and the media. In 1992, he was awarded the Leibniz Prize, Europe's most prestigious prize in the humanities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to work with BSI on occupational disaster reduction system

TEXT.P: The British Standards Institution (BSI) will assist the Cabinet-level council of Labor Affairs (CLA) in developing a new mechanism aimed at reducing occupational accidents and disasters at local factories or workplaces, a CLA official said Thursday.

CLA Chairman Lu Tien-lin, BSI Taiwan Branch General Manager Gao Yi-min, and Director-General of Bureau of Standards, Metrology, and Inspection Chen Chieh- shan signed a declaration on cooperation in the relevant field earlier in the day, the official said.
The official said Taiwan's occupational disaster rate has registered a 50.6 percent decrease since the CLA launched an occupational safety promotional program in 2001.
However, he said Taiwan needs to make greater efforts in occupational safety management systems in order to meet the standards of more advanced countries and further lower occupational accidents.
He added that Britain has the lowest occupational disaster rate in the world, and thus it is worthwhile learning from its experience with occupational safety management systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate furious over failure to visit airport

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), was visibly furious Thursday when he and his entourage were barred from visiting Taoyuan International Airport's second terminal because of what he termed "pressure" from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government.

Ma, former KMT chairman, was to tour the terminal before announcing his new aviation policy but had to change his schedule after being told by airport authorities that he was not allowed to engage in political activities in the terminal.

"Let everyone see the ugly face the DPP government. The ruling party is using such acts against an opposition candidate. They will get what they deserve, and we will see about that," he told reporters.
"They can prevent me entering the airport, but they cannot stop me from pushing for reform," he added.

Accompanied by Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun, Ma proceeded to visit a free trade zone managed by the Farglory Group and hear a briefing on its plan to attract international companies to set up offices in the zone.

When told that according to international surveys the Taoyuan International Airport now ranks 85th among the world's 136 major airports and 20th among 27 airports in Asia, Ma appeared saddened, saying, "It makes me so angry that I feel like crying."
He deplored that the Taoyuan airport, which used to be Taiwan's pride, has now become a symbol of backwardness.

"Simply by changing the airport's name from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to Taoyuan International Airport will not bring better luck," he said, adding, "Only by pushing reform and replacing the ruling party will the nation see better luck."

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism promotion association opens branch in Kuala Lumpur
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 4 (CNA) 10/04/07 22:16:36 (By Flor Wang and Charles Kang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) -- a non-profit group dedicated to advancing Taiwan's tourism -- opened an office in Kuala Lumpur Tuesday to help court a larger number of Malaysian tourists to visit Taiwan.

Chang Fu-an, director of TVA's Kuala Lumpur office, informed the CNA of the opening of the office Thursday. Scores of tourism officials and industry representatives of the two countries took part in the activity, he said.

According to Chang, his office hopes to help attract at least 160,000 visits by Malaysian tourists to Taiwan next year, based on an annual 10 percent growth rate in Malaysian tourist arrivals and enhanced tourism cooperation between the two countries.
The office is poised to implement further promotional activities and present more appealing tour packages with comprehensive services to court Malaysian visitors.
Chang expressed hope that the number of tourists arriving from Malaysia would exceed 150,000 in 2007, and 160,000 in 2008.

Victory Y. Tseng, Taiwan's representative to Malaysia, was quoted by Chang as saying that the opening of TVA's Kuala Lumper branch will effectively further galvanize tourism-related exchanges between the two states.
According to Tseng, Taiwanese tourists paid around 160,000 visits to Malaysia in 2006, while Malaysian tourists made some 110,000 visits to Taiwan in the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office sponsors writing contest on Taiwan sovereignty

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office kicked off an online writing contest Wednesday in an effort to encourage the public to explore issues related to the country's sovereignty.
The contest will run through Nov. 15, with the length of each entry capped at 5,000 Chinese characters, according to a press release from the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs.
The writing contest is being held in line with the government's promotion of the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan this year, the press release said.
Contestants should register and send their articles on the Web site of the Presidential Office, the press release noted.

A panel of experts will serve as judges to select 10 winners, who will have the opportunity to meet Vice President Annette Lu and receive cash prizes ranging from NT$20,000 (US$612) to NT$5,000, the press release concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: German nationalism history something for Taiwan, China to consider

TEXT.P: Germany's tragic experience of nationalism spanning from 1930s to 1940s offers something for Taiwan and China to consider as a responsible government should be more rational than its citizens, a visiting German professor said Thursday.

Germans abandoned their "nationalism dream" after the nightmare of the Nazi era and World War II, which provide them with a better reading of nationalism, said Rudolph Wagner, a professor at Germany's Heidelberg University.

Responding to a reporter's question about the development of nationalism on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, especially in China, Wagner said that the Chinese government is very much aware of the dangers of whipping up nationalistic fever.

China has used nationalism as a political tactic against other countries, such as Japan, but always knows when to stop and pull people out of the streets because it is a two-sided blade which might very well turn against the Communist government itself, he said.
"Neither China nor Taiwan has anything to gain [from whipping up nationalism], " he claimed.

Wagner said he didn't want to elaborate on Taiwan's situation since he is not an expert, and the future of any country is difficult to predict. However, he noted that there are many things happening simultaneously in Taiwan right now, including Taiwan's huge investment in China and the call to normalize Taiwan's status as an independent country.
"A responsible government has to be more rational than its citizens, " he said, adding that a responsible government will not tolerate age-long political or military standoff.

Wagner is scheduled to deliver a speech, titled "German Unification: Popular Culture, Maoist Students, and the Socialist Disneyland, " Saturday in an international lecture series organized by Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation.

With a Ph.D. from the University of Munich, Wagner has done extensive research on Buddhism, Taoist philosophy, and contemporary Chinese politics and the media. In 1992, he was awarded the Leibniz Prize, the most prestigious European prize in the humanities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate reveals plan for Taoyuan aviation city

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that if elected president in 2008, he will develop Taoyuan International Airport and its peripheral areas into an "aviation city."

Ma Ying-jeou told reporters that his plan would incorporate 6,150 hectares of adjacent land with the airport and encourage transportation, trade and entertainment operators to form a "Taoyuan Aviation City."

The former KMT chairman stressed that to implement the plan, Taiwan will have to allow direct transportation links with China -- a policy which he said is unlikely under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, no matter who in the DPP becomes president.

Ma said that if he wins the 2008 election, he will allow direct flights between China and four airports in Taiwan: Taoyuan International Airport, Taipei Sungshan Airport, Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung, Kaohsiung Hsiaokang International Airport.
His plan will also see a third terminal at the Taoyuan airport completed in 2018 to meet increased passenger and cargo volumes.
In addition, he added, Keelung Port, Taichung Port and Chiayi County's Putai Port will open for direct shipping to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration officers indicted on corruption charges

TEXT.P: Two National Immigration Agency (NIA) officers have been indicted by the Chiayi Prosecutors Office on corruption charges for allegedly collaborating with human trafficking rings and illegal foreign labor brokers, the office announced Thursday.

According to an indictment filed by the office, Lin Shun-tang, 43, a division chief at the NIA's Chiayi branch, has been taken into custody after being investigated in July for allegedly collaborating with the foreign wife of a local citizen and manpower brokers to hide runaway or illegal alien workers in mountainous areas around Chiayi County in southern Taiwan.

Lin is accused of leaking information of upcoming raids by law enforcement agents to local human traffickers and bosses who had hired illegal alien workers in order to help illegal and absconding foreign workers escape law enforcement officers.

Another immigration officer, Lee Chang-lin, 44, was also prosecuted on corruption and fraud charges over allegedly helping Lin fabricate statements regarding the "false arrests" of those absconding foreign workers in order to apply for special monetary rewards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Marine National Park Headquarters opens in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: The government opened a marine national park office in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Thursday to signify its determination to protect the oceans and their marine inhabitants.

Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang and Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu jointly presided over a nameplate unveiling ceremony for the Marine National Park Headquarters (MNPH) , located in Metropolitan Park in downtown Kaohsiung.
Initially, Lee said, the MNPH will administer the country's first marine national park, namely the Dongsha Atoll National Park in the South China Sea.

In the future, Lee said, the ministry's Construction and Planning Agency will evaluate the feasibility of designating several scenic outlying islands, such as Green Island, Penghu Islands and three islets off northern Taiwan coast, as marine national parks to better manage and conserve marine resources in those areas.

Noting that the establishment of the Marine National Park Headquarters signifies the government's determination to upgrade the protection extended to the oceans and marine life to levels on par with world standards, Lee said the new office will focus on conducting marine resources survey, research, conservation, management as well as manpower cultivation, eco-tourism development and raising public awareness of marine life conservation.

The Dongsha Atoll National Park, covering the Dongsha Island along with two coral reefs completely submerged at high tide -- the Beiwei Bank (also known as the North Vereker Bank) and the Nanwei Bank (or South Vereker Bank) -- is located 240 nautical miles southwest of Kaohsiung.
The government constructed a national monument on the island June 30, 1989 and an adjacent structure to protect the monument May 18, 1993, to assert its sovereignty over the archipelago.

The establishment of a marine national park administration has become urgent because the marine resources and natural ecology in the area have been gravely damaged over the past decade due to rampant poaching by fishermen using destructive fishing methods such as poison and explosives, an Interior Ministry official said.
According to government data, the Dongsha islands cover an area of 350,000 hectares, with atolls accounting for 80,000 hectares.
Noting that the islands cover an area three times that of Taipei City, the official said the archipelago boasts the largest and most unspoiled group of atolls in the West Pacific.

With their unique maritime eco-system, the official said, the coral reefs surrounding the islands are the best in Taiwan's territorial waters. Dongsha's coastal waters are also known for their biodiversity, with 489 fish species and about 200 coral strains documented, as well as numerous other marine species.

Against this backdrop, the official went on, it has become urgently necessary for the government to set up a marine national park administration to better protect and conserve the natural ecology of the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU lawmakers call for 'pan-green' integration

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the "pan-green" camp, urged President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to help integrate the two parties ahead of two key elections should he decide to assume the DPP chairmanship.

TSU legislative caucus whip Lo Chih-ming and party lawmakers, including Ho Ming- hao, Tseng Tsahn-deng and Lin Chih-chia, issued the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference to display their support for DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh.

Yu Shyi-kun offered to resign from the DPP's top post late last month after his indictment over alleged misuse of special allowance funds set aside for his discretionary use during his tenures as premier and as Presidential Office secretary-general.
Yu insisted on stepping down from the DPP chairmanship despite Chen's efforts to persuade him to stay on the post, and reiterated that he fully backs Chen to concurrently serve as DPP chairman.

The DPP's Central Standing Committee (CSC) agreed to Yu's resignation and approved a proposal to invite Chen to assume party chairmanship at its weekly meeting Wednesday. According to CSC members, the party's Central Executive Committee will formally announce Chen's chairmanship in a Friday meeting.

As President Chen is almost certain to assume DPP chairmanship, Lo urged Chen to swiftly resolve fractional disputes within the DPP and mend its differences with the TSU so as to score a "pan-green" victory in the coming legislative and presidential elections.

Lo asserted that the TSU will firmly back Hsieh in the March 22 presidential election and urged Chen to take concrete action to step up DPP-TSU cooperation in order not to upset the "pan-green" camp's overall chances.

According to Tseng, "pan-green" grassroots backers are deeply concerned that DPP's internal strife might affect the pan-greens' chances in the coming two elections. He called on Chen to quickly coordinate and arrange mutual cooperation to secure "pan-green" electoral victory after he assumes DPP chairmanship.
Chen's takeover of the DPP chairmanship would provide a new opportunity for the two parties to re-unite and maintain the DPP's grip on power, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office sponsors writing contest on Taiwan sovereignty

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office kicked off an online writing contest Wednesday in an effort to encourage the public to explore issues related to the country's sovereignty.
The contest will run through Nov. 15, with the length of each entry capped at 5,000 Chinese characters, according to a press release from the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs.
The writing contest is being held in line with the government's promotion of the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan this year, the press release said.
Contestants should register and send their articles on the Web site of the Presidential Office, the press release noted.

A panel of experts will serve as judges to select 10 winners, who will have the opportunity to meet Vice President Annette Lu and receive cash prizes ranging from NT$20,000 (US$612) to NT$5,000, the press release concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: German nationalism history something for Taiwan, China to consider

TEXT.P: Germany's tragic experience of nationalism spanning from 1930s to 1940s offers something for Taiwan and China to consider as a responsible government should be more rational than its citizens, a visiting German professor said Thursday.

Germans abandoned their "nationalism dream" after the nightmare of the Nazi era and World War II, which provide them with a better reading of nationalism, said Rudolph Wagner, a professor at Germany's Heidelberg University.

Responding to a reporter's question about the development of nationalism on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, especially in China, Wagner said that the Chinese government is very much aware of the dangers of whipping up nationalistic fever.

China has used nationalism as a political tactic against other countries, such as Japan, but always knows when to stop and pull people out of the streets because it is a two-sided blade which might very well turn against the Communist government itself, he said.
"Neither China nor Taiwan has anything to gain [from whipping up nationalism], " he claimed.

Wagner said he didn't want to elaborate on Taiwan's situation since he is not an expert, and the future of any country is difficult to predict. However, he noted that there are many things happening simultaneously in Taiwan right now, including Taiwan's huge investment in China and the call to normalize Taiwan's status as an independent country.
"A responsible government has to be more rational than its citizens, " he said, adding that a responsible government will not tolerate age-long political or military standoff.

Wagner is scheduled to deliver a speech, titled "German Unification: Popular Culture, Maoist Students, and the Socialist Disneyland, " Saturday in an international lecture series organized by Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation.

With a Ph.D. from the University of Munich, Wagner has done extensive research on Buddhism, Taoist philosophy, and contemporary Chinese politics and the media. In 1992, he was awarded the Leibniz Prize, the most prestigious European prize in the humanities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate reveals plan for Taoyuan aviation city

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that if elected president in 2008, he will develop Taoyuan International Airport and its peripheral areas into an "aviation city."

Ma Ying-jeou told reporters that his plan would incorporate 6,150 hectares of adjacent land with the airport and encourage transportation, trade and entertainment operators to form a "Taoyuan Aviation City."

The former KMT chairman stressed that to implement the plan, Taiwan will have to allow direct transportation links with China -- a policy which he said is unlikely under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, no matter who in the DPP becomes president.

Ma said that if he wins the 2008 election, he will allow direct flights between China and four airports in Taiwan: Taoyuan International Airport, Taipei Sungshan Airport, Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung, Kaohsiung Hsiaokang International Airport.
His plan will also see a third terminal at the Taoyuan airport completed in 2018 to meet increased passenger and cargo volumes.
In addition, he added, Keelung Port, Taichung Port and Chiayi County's Putai Port will open for direct shipping to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 5, or the 25th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
2001: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, shows his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian receives visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow, exchanging views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Land warning issued for Typhoon Krosa

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Typhoon Krosa Friday as the storm continued on its forecast course toward Taiwan.

Areas expected to be affected by the storm within the next 24 hours include Ilan, Hualien, Taitung, Orchid Island, Green Island, Hengchun Peninsula, Hsinchu, Taoyuan, Taipei and Keelung, according to CWB forecasters.
The forecasters also urged ships operating in waters off Taiwan's northeast and southeast coasts, the Bashih Channel, and the Taiwan Strait to be on alert.

At 8 a.m. Friday, Krosa was centered 470 km east-southeast of Oluanpi -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving northwesterly at 14 kph toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.

Affected by the outer edge of the typhoon, most of Taiwan is expected to experience showers Friday, with the chance of rain registering 90-100 percent in the northern and northeastern regions, 40-60 percent in the central and southern regions, and 70 percent in the southeastern region, according to the CWB.

The CWB predicted that the rainfall brought about by Typhoon Krosa in mountainous areas over the next few days is likely to reach 800-1,100 mm in the northern and northeastern regions, 200-400 mm in Taitung, 600-800 mm in the central region, 300-500 mm in Tainan, and 200-400 mm in Kaohsiung and Pingtung.
In low lying areas, rainfall is expected to amount to 300-500 mm in the northern region, 400-600 mm in the northeastern region, 200-300 mm in central Taiwan, and 80-150 mm in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Ministry activates typhoon response operations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense activated emergency response operations Friday to deal with Typhoon Krosa which has continued on its forecast course toward Taiwan and is expected to increase in intensity to become a "super typhoon" by the weekend.

A military spokesman said that the Defense Ministry announced the activation at 5: 30 a.m., ordering all command, combat and offshore units to set up their own typhoon response centers to prepare for possible rescue and relief operations.
Meanwhile, the spokesman said that a scheduled rehearsal Friday for a flyby to be staged during the Double Ten National Day rally has been canceled because of Typhoon Krosa.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Typhoon Krosa Friday morning as the storm continued to move toward Taiwan.
At 11 a.m., Krosa was centered 450 km east-southeast of Oluanpi -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan -- moving northwesterly at 14 kph toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.

The outer rim of Typhoon Krosa -- with a radius of 300 km -- is expected to cover the entire island Saturday, with the eye of the storm forecast to move across northern Taiwan on Sunday, the CWB reported.

Areas expected to be affected by the storm within the next 24 hours include Ilan, Hualien, Taitung, Orchid Island, Green Island, Hengchun Peninsula, Hsinchu, Taoyuan, Miaoli, Taipei and Keelung, according to CWB forecasters.
The forecasters also urged ships operating in waters off Taiwan's northern, eastern and southeastern coasts, the Bashih Channel, and the Taiwan Strait to be on alert.

Meanwhile, the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture announced Friday that an emergency response mechanism to deal with possible mudslides triggered by the typhoon has been activated.
