DOC.HEADLINE: People urged to wash hands often to avoid pinkeye amid outbreak

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health urged people Friday to wash their hands regularly to avoid being infected with conjunctivitis, commonly known as pinkeye.

Responding to newspaper reports Friday that pinkeye has spread rapidly islandwide in recent days, particularly in the northern city of Keelung and the southern county of Yunlin, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said that to avoid being infected, people should wash their hands often and avoid rubbing their eyes.

Shih said that since the conjunctivitis outbreak has not been declared an epidemic, the CDC is unable to determine exactly how many people in the country have been infected. However, he added that the center has been told by hospitals that the number of pinkeye patients has increased rapidly over the past several days.

Shih further said that the center has already contacted the Ministry of Education and epidemiologists to work out measures to cope with the situation and informed hospitals under the direct jurisdiction of the Department of Health to take measures to prevent a further spread of the disease.

Noting that the last time that a pinkeye outbreak occurred in Taiwan was in the 1970s and that it was the result of enterovirus type S70, Shih said that this time around, the outbreak also seems to have been caused by enterovirus.

Lu Tah-wen, director of the the Ophthalmology Department of Tri-Service General Hospital, said that pinkeye is a highly contagious epidemic disease which can be caused by infections (such as bacteria and viruses), allergies, or substances that irritate the eyes, but that judging from recent cases he has treated, he believes that the current pinkeye outbreak is related mainly to enterovirus.

Meanwhile, Chiu Hsiao-wen, deputy director of Yunlin County's Bureau of Education, discounted a China Times report Friday that over 1,000 people in Yunlin have been infected, saying that as of Friday morning, the bureau had not been notified by any school in the county of an outbreak of the disease.

Kao Kun-yu, an official with the Yunlin County Bureau of Health, also said Friday that as of noon, his bureau had not received any requests from any schools or the Yunlin Bureau of Education for help regarding a pinkeye outbreak.

Kao called for students, particularly young kids, and all members of the public to seek medical aid if they are infected with pinkeye -- an inflammation of the conjunctiva, the clear membrane that covers the white part of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids.

To avoid being infected, Kao said, kids should be taught to wash their hands often with water and soap. They also should not share eye droppers, tissues, wash cloths, towels, or pillowcases with other people, Kao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outstanding debt of all governments reaches NT$4.19 trillion

TEXT.P: The outstanding debt of over one year of all the governments at all levels in Taiwan had reached NT$4.19 trillion (US$126.96 billion) as of the end of last year, the nation's top auditing official said Friday.

Auditor-General Lin Ching-long made the remarks while giving an auditing report on the central government's revenue and expenditures as well as on a special fund for the expansion of investment in infrastructure projects in 2006.

Lin said that the central government's revenue in 2006 totaled NT$1.54 trillion, or NT$161.7 billion higher than the original estimate, while expenditures amounted to NT$1.52 trillion, or NT$41.8 billion less than the original estimate.
He noted that the government has been unable to balance its budget in recent years and has had to rely on issuing government bonds and borrowing to tide over its financial difficulties.
Lin noted that the central government has appropriated funds to repay its debt every year over the past five years but has not been able to repay the total amount owed each year.

Adding to the central government's financial woes has been the high level of tax evasion, the slow progress in privatization of state-owned enterprises, as well as the worsening financial situation of the nation's health insurance system, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to probe use of bovine bone-based material in dental treatment

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) pledged Friday to step up its inspections concerning the illegal use of bovine bone-based material in dental implant surgery, amid fears that such material may have been imported from mad cow disease-affected areas.

Liu Li-ling, deputy chief of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, pointed out that medical devices made from bovine bone are currently forbidden in the country unless they are sent to the DOH for inspection in advance and obtain a permit from the department.
As no permits have been issued by the department so far, it is safe to say that any bovine bone-based medical devices currently available on the market are illegal, Liu said.

Liu made the remarks in response to a claim by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chu Chun-hsiao that approximately 30 percent of dental clinics in the country use bone graft material made of bovine bone from mad cow disease-affected countries, such as the United States, a practice which the legislator said exposes patients to the risk of being infected with the deadly disease.

In some cases, bone grafting is required in dental implant treatment, and bovine bone is one of the options for bone expletive substances in the process that is aimed at regenerating lost bone and tissue to create a better quality bone site for the implantation.
According to Liu, anyone who is caught manufacturing, importing, selling or supplying unlicensed medical devices will be subject to imprisonment of up to three years and a maximum fine of NT$100,000.
Lu said that members of the general public can call the DOH's hot line at 0800-625748 to report any such activities.

Peng Ming-hsing, a section chief at the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine's Animal Quarantine Division, said that although there has not been any evidence showing that using bone material from animals infected with mad cow disease in bone grafting will transmit the disease to the receivers, the government should still deal with the issue carefully to minimize the possibility of infection among the country's citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Underground firearms factory busted

TEXT.P: The police in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan busted an underground firearm factory in the county Thursday, nabbing the factory owner and a batch of guns and tools.

Taitung police said at a news conference that after months of investigation and surveillance, the police raided the garage owned and run by Lai Chien-chuan, Thursday night, arresting Lai on the spot and confiscating a batch of firearms, including converted gas rifles, pistols, semi-finished converted Beretta guns, ammunition and tools for weapon modification.
Lai, 33, claimed that he is "addicted" to firearms of all kinds and purchased these weapons online to satisfy his personal hobby, according to the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to leave for Marshall Islands Oct. 11 to attend summit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will depart for the Marshall Islands Oct. 11 to attend the second Taiwan-South Pacific leaders' summit scheduled to take place the following day, Chen Chi-mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Friday.

Chen Chi-mai said after the summit, President Chen and leaders of the six Pacific allies -- the Solomon Islands, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Palau, Tuvalu and Nauru -- will sign the "Majuro declaration" in which the leaders of the allies will express their support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations. Majuro is the capital of the Marshall Islands.

The summit meeting will review various cooperation projects in the "Palau Declaration" signed during the first summit to strengthen their friendship through long-term cooperation in the areas of economic development, capacity building, society and culture, Chen Chi-mai said.
The summit also is aimed at countering China's efforts to woo Taiwan's allies in the region, Chen Chi-mai said.
The president is scheduled to depart 10: 35 p.m. Oct. 11 aboard a special plane on a direct flight to the Marshall Islands.

On Oct. 12, President Chen and his counterparts among the allies will not only review the results of the "Palau Declaration" but also discuss issues of health care and environmental protection before signing the "Majuro declaration."

The next day, Oct. 13, President Chen will hold bilateral talks with heads of state of the allies, as well as meet with Marshall Islands and Japanese media. The president will also host a dinner for Taiwan expatriates, embassy personnel, Taiwan's technical missions, volunteers and college graduates taking alternative national service.
President Chen and his entourage will attend a fishing competition and a barbecue before returning to Taiwan Oct. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 10.13 points to close at 9,617.26.
The bourse opened at 9,645.63 and fluctuated between 9,670.13 and 9,565. A total of 4.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$158.04 billion (US$4.85 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 4.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.9 percent, textile stocks at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down 1.3 percent and machinery and electronics shares dropping 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 770, with 221 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICDF trained volunteers to begin overseas service

TEXT.P: A group of 40 well-trained volunteers gathered under the Taiwan-based International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) will soon depart for overseas services, an ICDF spokesman said Friday.

They have received six-month training in languages, cultural adaptation, self- defence and professional knowledge in different aspects to help them adjust to overseas volunteer life, the spokesman said.
The ICDF, a government-run organization in charge of official aid to poor countries, is entering its 11th year of sending service volunteers overseas, the spokesman said.

The organization's efforts in operating the program has attracted the attention and interest of many Taiwanese, the spokesman said, adding that over 300 people applied to participate in the program this year.
Both the number of people enrolled and selection of volunteers this year hit record highs, the spokesman said.
The 40 selected volunteers, including school graduates, workers, retiring overseas school principals, and even senior ICDF volunteers, will head to 13 different developing countries.
They will provide assistance in many aspects, such as Mandarin instruction, medical care, computer information training, counseling on agricultural technology and business, and physical education.

Three volunteers last year joined an aid program to Costa Rica in Central America last year, but ceased their services when the country broke off diplomatic relations with Taiwan in June this year. They have retuned to the volunteer service force again, and will head to Paraguay in South America and the Marshall Islands in western Pacific, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Krosa approaching Taiwan at declining speed: CWB

TEXT.P: Typhoon Krosa has been declining in speed as it moves toward Taiwan, a meteorologist for the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Friday, attributing this to the effects of a weak Pacific high pressure system.

Tsai Fu-tien, an official responsible for weather forecasts at the CWB, said that as Krosa approaches Taiwan, it will decrease in speed. He predicted that when the strong typhoon gets close to the island, it will turn north and drop further in speed, describing the situation as a moving car which slows down as it enters a curve.

Now, the challenge in predicting the typhoon's impact on Taiwan is to calculate how weak the Pacific high pressure is -- the key factor that influences a typhoon's direction of movement, according to Tsai. He added that the typhoon may either pass across the northern part of Taiwan or make landfall in the eastern region.

How the typhoon will affect Taiwan depends on where it lands, the meteorologist said, noting that the CWB meteorologists will not be able to determine how much of an effect the typhoon will have on the island until it gets closer.

Krosa was upgraded to a typhoon from a tropical storm on Tuesday, and since then, it has been moving northwest at 16 kph. On Thursday night, the typhoon's speed had decreased to 10 kph, according to the CWB.

At 2 p.m. Friday, Krosa was centered 430 km east-southeast of Oluanpi -- the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving northwesterly at 14 kph toward the island and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.

Affected by the outer edge of the typhoon, most of Taiwan is expected to experience showers Friday, with the chance of rain registering 90-100 percent in the northern and northeastern regions, 40-60 percent in the central and southern regions, and 7 percent in the southeastern region, according to the CWB.

The CWB predicted that the rainfall brought about by Typhoon Krosa in mountainous areas over the next few days is likely to reach 800-1,100 mm in the northern and northeastern regions, 200-400 mm in Taitung, 600-800 mm in the central region, 300-500 mm in Tainan, and 200-400 mm in Kaohsiung and Pingtung.
In low lying areas, rainfall is expected to amount to 300-500 mm in the northern region, 400-600 mm in the northeastern region, 200-300 mm in central Taiwan, and 80-150 mm in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malaysian Philharmonic Orchestra performs in Taipei City

TEXT.P: The Malaysian Philharmonic Orchestra performed at the National Concert Hall in Taipei City Thursday under the baton of conductor Matthias Bamert as part of a first-ever performance tour of Taiwan.
The orchestra, in collaboration with noted French pianist Alain Lefevre, will also perform at Chunghsing Hall in the central city of Taichung Saturday.

During the Taipei concert, Lefevre performed the Harold in Italy Overtures by French composer Hector Berlioz (1813-1869) and Piano Concerto No. 1 by Polish composer Frederick Chopin, while the orchestra performed Carmen Suite by French composer Georges Bizet (1838-1875) and Daphniset Chloe Suite by French composer Maurice Ravel (1875-1937).
Formed in 1998, the orchestra, which is made up of 105 musicians from 25 countries, is dedicated to the promotion of musical cultural exchanges in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.002 to close at NT$32.597.
A total of US$556 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.568 and closed at the day's high of NT$32.618.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps offering free medicare in RP
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/07 17:22:19 (By Emerson Lim and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 27-member mission of the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps arrived in Manila Friday, prepared to offer four days of free medical services to the locals living in remote and poor communities around the Philippines.

The mission, led by Dr. Liu Chi-chun, head of the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps, is made up with four physicians, three dentists, three pharmacists, two medical technologists, 12 nurses and three volunteer workers.

The mission plans to travel some 3,000 kilometers around the Philippines to give four rounds of philanthropically medical services to residents in Davao of the Mindanao Island, Subic Bay in the Island of Luzon, and ghettos of Manila.
Some 2,000 Philippine citizens are expected to benefit from the free Taiwan medical services.

The Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps, established in Taiwan in 1996, has been active over the past decade in offering free medical services to people living in remote or backwater areas in Taiwan and abroad.
The group is scheduled to return to Taiwan Oct. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate opens campaign Website to woo young voters

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate, has launched an official campaign Website in an effort to attract young voters via the audio and video platform and strengthen his online interactions with them.

Hsieh's top campaign manager, Yeh Chu-lan, hosted a launch ceremony Thursday at Hsieh's campaign office in Taipei to unveil the Website, which was also attended by National Youth Commission Chairwoman Cheng Li-chun, and cartoonist Yufu.
During the ceremony, Yeh led the supporters in shouting slogans such as "Hsieh get elected" and "Viva Taiwan". According to Yeh, Viva means "beautiful long life" in Italian.
Yeh said the Website not only highlights Hsieh's energy and vitality, but also presents various aspects of Taiwan with the goal of helping promote the beauty and spirit of Taiwan to the world.

She added the Website covers a number of images ranging from tourist attractions with local characteristics-- such as Chijin beach scenery in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and Chiku wetland in the southern county of Tainan--to a famous documentary film depicting the daily life of three elderly rice farmers in Tainan County.

Noting that two of Hsieh's campaign advertisements and other video and audio entries have also been posted online, Yeh invited Website users to go to the Website: http: //www.vivataiwan.tw to vote online to express their opinions.
In addition to the Website, Hsieh maintains several blogs and the campaign Website is linking to the personal Website of Hsieh's running mate Su Cheng- tseng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court rejects president's bid to reclaim evidence

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court Friday turned down a request by President Chen Shui- bian to reclaim materials held by prosecutors as evidence in his "state affairs fund" case, which were recently proclaimed by the president to be "absolute secrets."
The court ruled that the process in which the materials were proclaimed as "absolute secrets" involved "serious, obvious flaws" and should be regarded as invalid.
According to current law, President Chen is eligible to appeal against the district court ruling.

On Sept. 6, Chen petitioned the court to return invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic missions that are used by prosecutors as evidence in the case, on the grounds that the materials have been proclaimed as "absolute secrets."

The president made the move after the Council of Grand Justices confirmed June 15 the president's constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose such information.

However, the court determined Friday that Chen lacks any reason or legal basis to ask for the return of the materials because the president's privilege to refuse to give testimony and produce evidence should be exercised before, not after, the testimony is given and the evidence submitted.
On Chen's claim that the materials were seized by the prosecutors without a warrant, the court noted that the seizure was carried out based on a warrant issued by the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office.

Further rebutting Chen's claim that the materials were held without his consent, the court said the invoices and vouchers were taken away with the consent of the head of the Presidential Office's accounting department, because the department, not Chen, was the keeper of the invoices and vouchers.
Also, the data regarding the six secret diplomatic missions was submitted to the prosecutors by presidential aide Lin Te-hsun after obtaining Chen's approval, the court said.

Pointing out that Chen did not insist that the withheld materials were state secrets when receiving questioning by prosecutors last year, the court claimed that the president's move to proclaim the materials as "absolute secrets" only during the final stage of the trial was "aimed merely at covering up the administrative negligence and even irregularities" of the defendants.
The court added that the move, which was not intended to protect national security or national interests, violates the State Secrets Protection Act and should be considered unlawful.

According to the court, the president's "state secrets privilege" is part of executive power and should be exercised in accordance with the State Secrets Protection Act and subject to scrutiny by the judiciary.

The prosecution named Chen as a "joint perpetrator" while indicting first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of corruption and forgery Nov. 3, 2006, after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen stressed that none of the money went into his own pocket, claiming it was necessary to use receipts from different individuals to muster the funds to engage in secret diplomatic missions in certain countries because of the confusing and inconsistent accounting system governing expenditures by the Presidential Office.

However, the Taipei District Court ruled Jan. 19 that the six diplomatic missions cited by the president as having drawn on the state affairs fund were not secret as the president claimed, and should be disclosed in court proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA thanks U.S. House for supporting sufficient arm supplies

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed gratitude Friday to the U.S. House of Representatives for passing unanimously a resolution urging the executive branch to supply Taiwan with sufficient defensive weapons and services.

The U.S. House passed Resolution 676 Wednesday, declaring that the United States, conforming to the Taiwan Relations Act, should make available to Taiwan articles and services necessary to maintaining a self-sufficient defense capacity.
MOFA deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-bi said Friday that the resolution shows the U.S. House's solid support for Taiwan's determination to upgrade its self- defense ability.

It also indicated that the U.S. Congress is paying close attention on the growing military imbalance across the Taiwan Strait caused by China's military expansion and deployment of nearly 1,000 missiles aimed at Taiwan, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP underlines 'essence' of National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: The Double Ten National Day is the best time for the country to demonstrate its determination in bidding for U.N. membership, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday.

Legislator Wang Tuoh made the remarks at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan while explaining why no placards carrying words of "celebration for the Republic of China National Day" were erected on the tower building of the Presidential Office this year, as is usually the case.
It's the first time since the seat of the ROC government was relocated to the island in 1949 that the tower building will not be decorated with festive placards of this kind.
Wang said it is more important to reflect the "essential problem" of Taiwan's absence in the United Nations in the celebration of the country's National Day than to highlight the festivity.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the chief organizer of the official National Day celebration ceremony, said Thursday that President Chen Shui-bian will not address the National Day rally in front of the Presidential Office this year, and that the Taiwan U.N. bid banners hung on the front of the office will not be replaced by those traditionally hung for the ROC National Day celebration, respecting request of the Presidential Office -- the rally's host.

Wang said that the message President Chen wants to deliver to the nation will be expressed in a meeting held within the Presidential Office prior to the rally, despite long observance of the practice of the president addressing the National Day rally.

Regarding the name "ROC", which was replaced by the slogan of "Taiwan joins the U.N." in National Day decorations on the Presidential Office, Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said that concealing the country's formal designation on the National Day is "obviously not respectful of the country."
Ma also said that he will not take part in the National Day rally in front of the President Office because he did not receive an invitation from the host.
Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung revealed his intention of "no show" at the rally due to the controversial banner decorating the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI increases set two-year high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for September was 107.3, up 3.08 percent from the same month last year, the highest year-on-year growth rate since October 2005, according to the figures released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Friday.

The wholesale price index (WPI) was 126.67 for September, representing an annual increase of 4.63 percent, and the growth rate for the first nine months of the year reached 6.08 percent, DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Veltroni in support for reducing number of ministers.
Rome Mayor Walter Veltroni, who is a leading candidate for the leadership of the Democratic Party in formation, expressed his support for a reduction of the number of central government's ministers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments urged to be careful with event spending

TEXT.P: Related government agencies should carefully assess the effect of large-scale activities sponsored by the local governments, Auditor-General Lin Ching-long said Friday.

Lin made the remarks as he delivered an auditing report to the Legislative Yuan on the budget use of the central government, and the use of special funds for the expansion of investment in infrastructure projects in 2006.

Legislator Tsai Sheng-chai of the opposition People First Party said local governments have often spent lavishly sponsoring tourism and other festivals under the pretext of boosting the local economy and community development.
Tsai questioned if the Ministry of Audit has checked carefully the effect and efficiency of those activities.

Lin stated that more and more local governments are sponsoring ever larger-scale activities, save for the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu which have yet to spend more than NT$4 million (US$121,210) sponsoring large-scale tourism activities.
Lin said the government must ensure that local governments are following appropriation regulations for each event and assess the benefit of such large- scale activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: New alliance to promote travel medicine

TEXT.P: A new business alliance grouping a noted hotel, a travel agency and a local medicine association announced a joint program Friday to promote Taiwan's travel medicine.

It is the first time that the three industries have joined together to work to promote travel medicine, the market for which, according to estimates by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, could be worth NT$7 billion (US$220 million) per year.

Under the program, Grand Hotel and the Taipei-based Asia-Pacific Society of Travel Medicine (ASTM) will cooperate in promoting travel medicine packages to attract foreign visitors for both pleasure and medical purposes.

The cost of a specially designed four-day medicinal tour being programmed is estimated to be worth NT$30,000 - NT$60,000, and it includes a three-hour health checkup. An anti-oxidation treatment course, skin care and a magnetic wave face lift session will also be available.
Customers will be accommodated in the Grand Hotel in Taipei and spend their leisure time visiting local tourists spots, such as Taipei 101 Tower and the National Palace Museum.
ASTM Director Shieh Ying-hua said at a news conference that Taiwan's medical services rank among the best in Asia, with relatively low costs.
Citing Thailand as an example, Shieh said, foreign nationals paid some 730,000 travel medicine visits to the Southeast Asian country in 2003, and the number further grew by 16 percent in 2005.

Although Thailand, Singapore, South Korea and India have engaged in travel medicine for years, Shieh said he believes that Taiwan stands a good chance of attracting a considerable number of foreign visitors for travel medicine thanks to the superior medical care and treatment available.
Visitors from Japan and Middle Eastern countries are potential customers, he added.
Chiu Wen-ta, president of the Taiwan Hospital Association, said that Singapore lures some 500,000 travel medicine patients each year and Thailand, double that number.

The critical point now facing Taiwan is that the country must effectively improve the standard of its services if it hopes to catch up with Thailand or Singapore in the travel medicine field, he pointed out.

According to Dragon Tours General Manager Yang Chung-lin, Taiwan has a great potential to develop travel medicine, even it just starts to embark on that course. "Taiwan's medical level is quite competitive compared with those of neighboring countries," he said confidently.

DOC.HEADLINE: No balloon release during Double Ten National Day rally: NSB

TEXT.P: The National Security Bureau (NSB) will not allow the release of large balloons during Double Ten National Day celebration next week lest they threaten the security of the participants.

NSB officials said the balloons could pose a threat to air force fighters that will pass over the Presidential Office in formation, and to the elite parachutists who will glide down Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
The officials said that to avoid disruptions during the rally, the bureau has worked with the organizing committee to communicate with civic groups in advance of the event.
Having received information showing that a few people may try to release balloons to publicize their political advocacy, officials warned them not to attempt to do so.
They stressed that they will ensure the safety of the participants, their equipment and the smooth progression of the rally, and that any challenge to government authority will not be tolerated.

Last year, supporters of a campaign against President Chen Shui-bian over a series of corruption surrounding his family members and close aides had used the Double Ten day to highlight their cause, prompting the authorities to step up security this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu City to set up information center for foreigners

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu city government will set up Taiwan's first regional information center for foreigners providing accommodation information, assistance, and counseling in a variety of aspects, a local official said Friday.

The center will be located on the first floor of the Industrial Development and Investment Promotion Committee building, which is on the city's Chungyang Road. The center is located in downtown Hsinchu City and close to many big hotels and public facilities, such as the train station and city hall.
The committee and the city government's Bureau of Tourism will provide information for reference by foreigners, with students from six colleges and universities working as volunteers at the center.
The center will provide information in housing, lodging, restaurants, shopping, medical treatment, sightseeing, transportation, and assistance in communications and counseling to foreigners.

Wu Sung-lin, director-general of the Department of Regional Affairs under the Cabinet-leve Research, Development and Evaluation Commission has agreed to provide a subsidy of NT$5 million (US$152, 905) for the center's establishment, the official said.
The operations of the center are aimed at building a more friendly environment for foreigners in an effort to attract more foreign investors and visitors, the official said.

Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer said the city has many foreign visitors and professional workers thanks to international cooperation projects at the Hsinchu Science Park and local universities, and the information center will further help improve the city's services to foreigners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's contribution to APEC appreciated: APEC Secretariat

TEXT.P: Taiwan's contribution to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum is very much appreciated and Taiwan is encouraged to keep up its engagement in APEC activities, APEC Secretariat Executive Director Colin Haseltine said Friday.

Taiwan has submitted initiatives and participated in various APEC projects over the years, said Haseltine, the 15th executive director of the APEC Secretariat for the 2007 APEC Year hosted by Australia.

"My suggestion for Chinese Taipei would be keep doing what you're doing, " he said in a round table discussion organized by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and attended by local government officials and academics.

The Australian diplomat talked about APEC's present achievements and future prospects. What APEC has done, especially at the working group and ministerial level, has been underpublicized, underestimated and underappreciated, he said.

The leadership meeting of the heads of 21 member economies has always been the public focus, but it is lower-level meetings and projects that have made differences and promoted what APEC sets out to do -- promote fair and open trade, Haseltine said.
In the future, APEC plans to keep promoting regional economic integration and a free trade area in the Asia-Pacific region, although the latter will be difficult to accomplish, he said.

The organization will undertake internal reform to improve its efficiency and push for domestic economic structure reform among member economies as well, he said, noting that better domestic economic structures serve the interest of all APEC members.
Haseltine formerly served as head of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei from 1992-1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Alistair Darling admits Britains economy is slowing as house prices start to fall
The first monthly fall in house prices this year was reported yesterday, fuelling fears that a looming downturn in the property market will hit the economy hard next year. In the latest sign that the housing market is now rapidly losing steam, Halifax, Britains biggest mortgage lender, said its regular survey showed that average national house prices fell by 0.6 per cent in September, marking their first monthly fall since December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate vows to create jobs for university graduates

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou vowed Friday to create jobs for university graduates if he wins the March 22, 2008 presidential election.
Ma made the pledge while giving a speech during a visit to Ching Yun University in Taoyuan County. He was warmly greeted by hundreds of students and teaching faculty.

Stressing that it is the government's responsibility to build a good environment and create a platform for the youth to cultivate an international vision, Ma said that it is sad to learn that the average monthly salary of South Korean university graduates is triple that for their Taiwan counterparts.

If elected president, Ma promised that his administration would offer young men and women loans to start their own business and provide scholarships for 100,000 gifted students to pursue advanced knowledge abroad. His administration would encourage the youth to explore broader horizons and help them feed back their learning to the country, he said.

Ma also reiterated his intention to allow the entry of 3,000 Chinese tourists per day in the initial stages of an open-door tourism program. That would help create at least NT$60 billion (US$1.85 billion) worth of business each year in the home market, he said.
To reinvigorate Taiwan's economy and improve the people's livelihoods, a series of economic stimulus, urbanization and farmland reform programs will be put forward, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police crack down on gangsters before National Day

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) has apprehended more than 700 gangsters in northern and central Taiwan for violations of the Organized Crime Prevention Act, CIB officials announced Friday.

The bureau launched the latest wave of a crackdown on local gangsters as part of its efforts to prevent them from engaging in illegal activities as police prepare for the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations, the officials said.
The police busted several rings involving a total of 221 gangsters in Taipei allegedly involved in blackmail, illegal debt-collecting and various other crimes, the officials said.

In addition, police in central Taiwan busted a ring led by a suspect who used violence to gradually gain ownership of a funeral service company, the officials said, adding that the lucrative funeral service industry often attracts the attention of local gangsters.
During the one-day crackdown, the police also referred to prosecution authorities 42 gangsters who have allegedly committed serious illegal acts, the officials went on.

An additional 573 gangsters were also nabbed for allegedly using violence to collect debts, blackmailing construction companies and recruiting young people to join criminal rings, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget for U.N. bid activities being examined: Auditor-General

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Audit has not stopped overseeing government spending on organizing activities to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid, Auditor-General Lin Chin- lung said Friday.

Lin said the ministry has mailed a letter to the Sports Affairs Council (SAC), requesting an explanation of whether or not it earmarked a budget this year for activities targeting Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations, or whether it spent money based on government regulations in organizing a nationwide torch relay Oct. 24 to win public support for the U.N. bid.
Lin made the remarks in response to a question by Legislator Lin Teh-fu of the opposition Kuomintang during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

At the session, the lawmaker questioned the legality of the SAC's allegedly spending tens of millions of taxpayer dollars to organize the torch relay, which will pass through all 25 of Taiwan's counties and cities.
Lin Teh-fu claimed that the SAC did not write a budget for any such activities this year and questioned how it plans to finance the torch relay.

The auditor-general said he had also asked both the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Government Information Office (GIO) to explain and make public their spending on advertising Taiwan's U.N. bid.
The MOFA said it spent more than NT$47 million (US$1.4 million) on U.N. advertising this year, while the GIO spent NT$16 million to publicize Taiwan's strong desire to be part of the United Nations.

Although both said they used money from their budgets to seek Taiwan's presence in international activities to conduct the publicity, Lin Chin-lung said his office was not satisfied with the answers and has requested a further explanation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panama 1st lady expresses gratitude for Taiwan's donations
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/05/07 21:17:12 (By Ramon Huang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Panama's first lady Vivian Fernandez de Torrijos expressed gratitude on behalf of Panamanian President Martin Torrijos at a donation ceremony Thursday for Taiwan's donations and assistance in building bamboo houses, schools and providing medical aid to the Central American country.

Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Hou Ping-fu noted that the ROC government built 30 bamboo houses last year in Panama's Ngobe Bugle area with the aim of improving the life quality of Panama's indigenous people.

The bamboo houses turned out to be popular and so Taiwan has scheduled to build an additional 300 this year and another 300 next year for the Panamanian people, who also plan to grow bamboo by themselves for the use of construction, Hou said.
Hou said Taiwan will help build 90 schools in rural villages in Panama and will also help restore the country's dilapidated gyms, baseball and soccer fields.
Hou emphasized that Taiwan's foreign aid projects now focus on providing assistance to poor people in remote rural areas in diplomatic allies and have totally transparent management.
He said Taiwan also donated vehicles, motorbikes and communication devices to Panama's police force to help improve the country's social order.

Taiwan will also present free air tickets to members of Panama's national baseball team so they can take part in the World Cup baseball championship to be held in Taipei and Taichung cities in November, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: House's Iraq Bill Applies U.S. Laws to Contractors
With the armed security force Blackwater USA and other private contractors in Iraq facing tighter scrutiny, the House of Representatives on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a bill that would bring all United States government contractors in the Iraq war zone under the jurisdiction of American criminal law. The measure would require the F.B. I. to investigate any allegations of wrongdoing.
The Wall Street Journal: M&A Milestone: $101 Billion Deal For ABN Amro; Group Set to Dismember 183-Year-Old Bank; Will Buyers Regret It?
The biggest banking deal ever is likely to conclude today, resulting in the dismemberment of one of Europe's largest banks.
The significance of the deal goes beyond its $101 billion price tag and the demise of 183-year- old ABN Amro Holding NV of the Netherlands. Depending on how the buyers fare, it could become either a symbol of the overexuberance seen in the recent mergers-and-acquisitions boom, or -- as some investment bankers hope -- a precedent for tackling breakups of big companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sits on world's fourth-largest forex reserves

TEXT.P: Taiwan sits on the world's fourth-largest foreign exchange reserves, worth US$262.94 billion as of the end of September, the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) announced Friday.

According to CBC officials, the figure represents an increase of US$1.56 billion over the previous month's level and it puts Taiwan in the world's fourth spot behind China with US$1.33 trillion (as of late June) , Japan with US$922.5 billion (as of late September) and Russia with US$298.5 billion (as of late August.)
Although Taiwan marked a slight growth in forex holdings in the August-September period, it registered a decline compared to late last year when it had US$266.15 billion in forex holdings.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said that the decrease is within a reasonable range, while CBC officials attributed the phenomenon to Taiwan's continued capital outflow and a depreciating local currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: University students share international volunteering experience

TEXT.P: Students from National Tsing Hua University (NTHU) who took part in an international volunteer program said Friday that it expanded their visions, changed their perspectives on the world and helped them cherish what they had back home even more.

The program, launched by NTHU this summer for the first time, sent 32 students to five countries -- Indonesia, Malaysia, China, Nepal and Poland -- to do social and educational work from July to September.

"Now I know that even electricity and clean water are blessings, "said Tseng Chia-hsing, one of 15 students who helped teach basic medical knowledge, hold an English summer camp and a garden party in the remote village of Jugedi, Nepal during a 45-day stay.

Kerwin Cheng, a material science and engineering graduate student, taught computer operation in eight training camps in Medan and Aceh, Indonesia, which were hit by a tsunami in 2004 and are still recovering. Cheng said he was inspired by the bright and passionate spirit of the Indonesians, who lost almost everything in the disaster but never gave up.

Liao Ching-yi spent more than two months in Poland living with drug addicts under treatment. The program was a collaboration with the Monar Association, one of the largest non-government organizations (NGOs) in Poland and Europe.
The other two groups went to Qinghai, China and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia to teach high school students.

The program is a variation of the school's mandatory course on labor services, which in the past usually required students to help clean the campus, said Hocheng Hong, dean of student affairs. Judging from the results, the program is a good learning experience for students, he said.
NTHU will collaborate with organizations in Haiti, Nigeria and China next year, Hocheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Congress Seeks Secret Memos On Interrogation
Democratic lawmakers assailed the Justice Department yesterday for issuing secret memos that authorized harsh CIA interrogation techniques, demanding that the Bush administration turn over the documents. But officials refused and said the tactics did not violate anti-torture laws.
The Washington Times: A modern, traditional Tibet
Gyagetubba squats with a cell phone to his ear near the entrance of his yak-hair tent, perhaps making a business deal or arranging to purchase supplies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC urges Beijing to address dialogue mechanism

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged Beijing Friday to pay heed to the existing communication channels between Taiwan and China in the face of the lack of formal negotiation mechanisms between the two sides.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun issued the call at a routine news conference in response to reporters' questions about a summit between North and South Korean leaders, who exchanged joint declaration documents Thursday in Pyongyang, North Korea, with commitments to forging peace and creating economic prosperity between the two Koreas.

Commenting on the meaning of the Korean summit to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Liu said the event indicates that "it is necessary for the governments on the two sides of the strait to enhance communications and step up contacts through relevant channels so as to explore more positive relations."

Liu urged China to pay heed to the importance of continuing two-way dialogue and communications now that Taiwan and China have for some time been negotiating technical matters at the working level concerning setting up direct cross-strait charter flight services and regarding Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists.

Although bilateral negotiations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , have "temporarily" been halted for some 10 years, Liu said, communication channels between the two semi-official organizations still exist and should not be overlooked.
SEF and ARATS were set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of government-to- government contacts across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nicaraguan foreign minister to attend ROC National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos will arrive in Taiwan Oct. 7 to attend the Double Ten National Day celebrations, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Friday.

It will be Santos' first visit to Taiwan since he assumed office early this year, the officials said, adding that Santos will be accompanied by his deputy, Valdrack Jeantschke, and other Nicaraguan officials.

Santos had promised to visit Taiwan during the first quarter of this year amid speculation about a possible breakdown in relations between Taiwan and its Central American diplomatic ally since the Sandinista regime returned to power in January.

President Chen Shui-bian led a delegation that attended his Nicaraguan counterpart Daniel Ortega's inauguration ceremony in January and visited the country again in August to take part in a leadership summit between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in the region as part of the government's efforts to solidify relations.

During his five-day visit, Santos will call on Chen, Foreign Minister James Huang, Economic Minister Steve R.L. Chen and Council of Agriculture Minister Su Jia-chyuan, among other government officials, the officials noted.
Santos will be taken on a tour of the Taipei World Trade Center and the Taipei 101 building, they went on.

Santos will also take the high-speed train to visit Taiwan Sugar Corp. and Tseng-Wen Reservoir in southern Taiwan, according to the officials, who add that Santos is scheduled to leave the country Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier instructs tightened prevention measures for Typhoon Krosa

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung instructed central and local government officials Friday to step up their efforts to guard against damage from torrential rain, mudslides and flooding brought by approaching Typhoon Krosa.
Chang made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Central Disaster Response Center in Taipei.
Chang ordered the Coast Guard Administration and the National Police Agency to forbid the public from going to coastal areas, as well as certain riversides and mountainous areas.

He also asked the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction and the Council of Agriculture to increase prevention efforts to monitor mudslide-prone areas and minimize possible damage.
Chang also instructed local government officials to check on flood prevention water gates and water pumps.
As of 8 p.m., one person in Taipei City had been reportedly lightly injured by a window shattered by strong wind.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to appeal against court ruling on evidence reclaim bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will appeal against a Taipei District Court ruling that turned down his request to reclaim materials held by prosecutors as evidence in his "state affairs fund" misuse case, the Presidential Office said Friday.

The Presidential Office made the announcement in a news release after the District Court ruled earlier in the day that Chen lacks legal basis to ask for the return of the materials because the president's privilege to refuse to give testimony and produce evidence should be exercised before, not after, the testimony is given and the evidence submitted.

On Sept. 6, Chen petitioned the court to return invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony and data related to six secret diplomatic missions that are being used by prosecutors as evidence in the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case, on the grounds that the materials have been proclaimed "absolute secrets."

The president made the move after the Council of Grand Justices confirmed June 15 the president's constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose such information.

In terms of the constitutional principle of division of power, the Presidential Office press statement said, the court should respect other government organs' legitimate powers, including the president's "state secret privilege."

Against this backdrop, the statement said, the District Court should not have denied the president's right to proclaim the withheld materials as "absolute secrets;" otherwise, the constitutional provisions safeguarding the president's special status would be rendered void.

Even if the court is entitled to scrutinize the propriety of the president's exercise of his "state secret privilege, " the statement said, the scrutiny should be conducted by another more suitable judicial agency, not by a court that is trying the "state affairs fund" case and has withheld the evidence materials in question.

Since the District Court ruled that the president's proclaiming the materials as "absolute secret" is an administrative decree, the statement said, the propriety or legality of such a move would be determined by an administrative court in accordance with the existing law. Consequently, the statement said, the District Court has apparently violated the law in making such a ruling.

Noting that the District Court seems to have readily quoted prosecutorial indictment to incriminate the defendants in the "state affairs fund" case, the statement said such a premature judgment is in obvious violation of the Criminal Procedural Law that demand all suspects be considered innocent before a final ruling is handed down.

The statement also rebutted as "false allegations" the District Court's claim that the president's move to proclaim the materials as "absolute secrets" only during the final stage of the trial was "aimed merely at covering up the administrative negligence and even irregularities" of the defendants.

As the country's constitution has not explicitly prescribed a "state secret privilege" system, the statement said the president has to seek a constitutional interpretation and wait until after the Council of Grand Justices meted out a ruling to proclaim those evidence materials as "absolute secret."

Stressing that Chen has on many previous occasions declared those materials as "sate secrets, " the statement said the District Court has deliberately ignored Chen's previous announcement. The District Court's allegations against Chen were "putting the cart before the horse," the statement said.

Since both the District Court has a vested interest in the outcome of the ruling, the statement said, the court is not in a position to make a ruling on whether the withheld materials should be returned to the Presidential Office.

The prosecution named Chen as a "joint perpetrator" while indicting first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of corruption and forgery Nov. 3, 2006, after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen stressed that none of the money went into his own pocket, claiming it was necessary to use receipts from different individuals to muster the funds to engage in secret diplomatic missions in certain countries because of the confusing and inconsistent accounting system governing expenditures by the Presidential Office.

However, the District Court ruled Jan. 19 that the six diplomatic missions cited by the president as having drawn on the state affairs fund were not secret as the president claimed, and should be disclosed in court proceedings.
After the Council of Grand Justices confirmed the president's "state secret privilege" in a constitutionality ruling in June, the court has made all court proceedings behind closed doors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Satuiday, Oct. 6, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
44 Taiwan companies on top-1,000 list of R&D investors outside Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/06/07 13:34:02 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Forty-four Taiwan companies were ranked among the world's top 1,000 non-EU companies investing the largest sums in research and development in 2006, according to a report released recently by the European Commission's Joint Research Center.
The 2007 EU Industrial R&D Investment Scoreboard, published in early October, shows that the largest number of companies on the list were from the United States and Japan.

The 44 Taiwan companies on the list covered the areas of semiconductors, electronic equipment, computer hardware, electrical components and equipment, personal goods, fixed line telecommunications, automobiles and parts, electricity, leisure goods, industrial metals, computer services, and industrial machinery.

They included Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., which ranked 120th for investing 374.15 million euro (US$528.75 million) in R&D in 2006; BenQ Corp., which ranked 132nd for investing 349.55 million euro; and Hon Hai Precision Industry, which ranked 176th for investing 248 million euro.
The annual report indicates that corporate R&D grew by 10 percent for 2006, with EU-based companies increasing their R&D investment by 7.4 percent.

Total R&D investment by the top 1,000 EU-based companies and the top 1,000 non-EU companies amounted to 372 billion euro, accounting for more than 85 percent of the world's total, according to the report.
Worldwide, the U.S.-based pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. was the largest R&D investor in 2006, spending 5.76 billion euro in this regard.
Among EU countries, the Germany-based automobile manufacturer DaimlerChrysler took top spot for spending 5.23 billion euro on R&D in 2006.
By sector, pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies invested the most in R&D in 2006, overtaking equipment sector and technology hardware companies.
Meanwhile, the report shows that EU companies continued to increase their R&D investment at a lower rate than companies in the rest of the world last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 47 rivers at high risk of mudflows

TEXT.P: Forty-seven rivers are at high risk of experiencing mudflows owing to heavy rain caused by Typhoon Krosa, officials at the Council of Agriculture's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau warned Saturday.
The affected areas include 21 villages in five townships located in Taipei County, Yilan County and Hsinchu County, where residents have been evacuated to safer places, the officials said.

Another 831 rivers are listed as at moderate risk, affecting 80 townships in Yilan County, Taipei County, Taipei City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Miaoli County, Taichung County, Taichung City, Nantou County and Chiayi County, they said adding that residents in these areas have been advised to prepare for evacuation.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), Typhoon Krosa was centered 100 km east-southeast of Yilan in northeastern Taiwan at Saturday noon, packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph, with the radius of the storm covering the whole of Taiwan proper.

While rain and wind in the northern and northeastern regions have been intensifying, some areas have seen heavy rainfall of more than 50 mm per hour, particularly in the mountainous areas in the northern and northeastern regions, CWB forecasters said.

CWB tallies show that between early Friday until 11 a.m. Saturday, accumulated rainfall registered 786 mm on Yilan County's Taiping Mountain, 584 mm on Hsinchu County's Niaotsui Mountain, 495 mm in Taoyuan County's Fuhsing township, 424 mm in Miaoli County's Taian township, 419 mm in Taipei County's Wulai township, 397 mm in Taichung County's Hoping township.

Forecasters said the typhoon has shown signs of decreasing in intensity and is expected to decrease in speed -- from 15 kph to 11 kph, meaning that the storm will likely not depart Taiwan until Sunday afternoon at the earliest.
They advised the public to avoid any trips to the mountainous areas or riversides, which are prone to landslides, falling rocks, mudflows and floods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three injured in typhoon

TEXT.P: Three people have been injured in accidents caused by Typhoon Krosa as of noon Saturday, according to tallies released by the Cabinet's emergency response center.

They include a 66-year-old woman in Taipei City who suffered cuts to her head, arms and legs when window glass at her residence broke in the storm, and a 50 -year-old woman, also in Taipei City, who injured her elbow when she was knocked to the ground by heavy winds while riding her motorcycle.
Also injured was a 62-year-old man on Orchid Island, who fractured his leg by the seaside while watching the high waves triggered by Krosa.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, the typhoon was centered 20 km southeast of Yilan, northeastern Taiwan at 3 p.m. Saturday, moving in a northward direction at 12 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.
With the storm's 300 km-radius covering the whole of Taiwan proper, wind and rain in the northern and northeastern regions have been intensifying, CWB forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to appeal court ruling on returning evidence

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will appeal as soon as possible a Taipei District Court ruling turning down his request to reclaim materials held by the prosecution as evidence in his "state affairs fund" misuse case, a Presidential Office official said Saturday.

David Lee, director of the Department of Public Affairs, said that when the Presidential Office receives formal notification from the Taipei District Court, expected next Monday, it will file an appeal with the Taiwan High Court within five days.

Lee's remarks came one day after Taipei District Court rejected President Chen's request on Sept. 6 that the court return invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals, and data related to six secret diplomatic missions being used by prosecutors as evidence in the case.

The president said he made the request on the grounds that the materials had been re-labeled as "strictly confidential" materials that should be kept secret permanently after the Council of Grand Justices confirmed June 15 the president's constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose such information.

Taipei District Court ruled Friday that the process in which the materials were labeled as "strictly confidential" involved "gross flaws" and should be considered invalid. The related documents and data should not be listed as "state secrets" under the State Secret Act but instead as evidence that prosecutors can use against the defendants, the court further said.
The Presidential Office said in a news release issued late Friday that the District Court is not in a position to deny the president's "state secret privilege."

The news release said that as the Taipei District Court has a vested interest in ruling on whether to return the withheld materials, it is not suitable to deal with the case which it said should be conducted by another more suitable judicial agency.

The prosecution named Chen as a "joint perpetrator" while indicting first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of corruption and forgery Nov. 3, 2006, after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen stressed that none of the money went into his own pockets, claiming it was necessary to use receipts from different individuals to muster the funds to engage in secret diplomatic missions in certain countries because of the confusing and inconsistent accounting system governing expenditures by the Presidential Office.

However, the Taipei District Court ruled Jan. 19 that the six diplomatic missions cited by the president as having drawn on the state affairs fund were not secret as the president claimed, and should be disclosed in court proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 600,000 households suffer power outages due to Typhoon Krosa

TEXT.P: More than 600,000 households have experienced power outages as a result of Typhoon Krosa as of 3: 00 p.m. Saturday, according to Taiwan Power Co. officials said.
Power supply has been restored to 340,000 of the households , the officials added.
They said the northeastern region has been hit the hardest, with 84,000 households in Keelung and 52,000 households in Yilan experiencing power outages.
In Taipei, 35,000 households in the northern district and 17,000 households in the western district were affected, they said.
Also affected were 15,000 households in Taoyuan, 8,000 in Hsinchu, 22,000 in Nantou, 19,000 in Miaoli and 24,000 in Taichung, they said.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, Typhoon Krosa was centered 30 km north- northeast of Hualien, eastern Taiwan at 4 p.m. Saturday, moving in a northward direction at 12 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of 184 kph.
Forecasters at the bureau said Krosa has shown signs of lingering in its present position, with the storm's 300 km-radius covering the whole of Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local civic groups rally to support democracy movement in Myanmar

TEXT.P: Several Taiwan civic groups held a parade in downtown Taipei City Saturday amid heavy rains and strong winds triggered by Typhoon Krosa to show their support for the democracy movement in Myanmar on the Global Day of Action for Myanmar.

Myanmarese in Taiwan and members of several Taiwan civic, religious and human rights groups gathered to express their support for Myanmar's "Saffron Revolution" and to urge the military junta to stop oppressing demonstrators and the democracy movement.

Participants in the rally called for the international community to keep pressuring the junta and to take necessary diplomatic steps to negotiate with the Myanmar government on the release of Myanmar dissidents. It also urged people to support protests of any form to help Myanmar become a democratic country.

The Taiwan Aung San Suu Kyi Network, the main organizer of the parade, also voiced support for the pro-democracy activist and 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner who has been under house arrest for the past decade, said Sun Yo-lien, the network's spokesman.

"We also urge China and Russia, which are among Myanmar's few allies, to stop associating with and assisting the junta. We do not rule out pushing for a boycott of the 2008 Beijing Olympics if China fails to respond, " Sun said.

About 200 people took part in the parade. Similar parades were held in many countries the same day, including Canada, France, Japan, South Korea, New Zealand, Australia, India, United Kingdom and the United States, Sun said.
The civic groups also paid tribute to Kenji Nagai, a Japanese photojournalist who was shot dead by Myanmar soldiers in the anti-government demonstration Sept. 27.

"I'm glad there are many young people among us. Their presence today shows that the younger generation in Taiwan does care about what is happening in other parts of the world, " said Huang Wen-hsiung, a senior protester.

DOC.HEADLINE: Initial estimate puts agricultural losses at NT$4.53 million

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Krosa which has battered Taiwan with strong winds and heavy rains had reached NT$4.53 million (US$137,270) as of 2 p.m. Saturday, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported.
Taichung County in central Taiwan reported the biggest losses at NT$2.87 million, while neighboring Nantou County reported losses of NT$1.66 million, COA officials said.
The officials said that the affected crop areas totaled 107 hectares, and that 14 percent of the crops, mainly oranges and bananas, in these areas were damaged.

They also reported that vegetables sold at Taipei City wholesale markets totaled 1,540 tons Saturday, up 382 tons from Friday. The selling price averaged NT$38.6 per kilogram, down NT$0.6 from NT$39.2 Friday.

They said that major agricultural groups have stockpiled around 2,852 tons of frozen vegetables and that the groups will release them daily to meet the needs of consumers after assessing the market situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scale of economic crime in recent years "a catastrophe": academic

TEXT.P: Economic crime has become a serious problem in Taiwan in recent years, an academic said Saturday, noting that since 2000, over 450 individuals and corporations have been indicted for embezzling a total of more than NT$276.7 billion (US$8. 38 billion) in public or corporate funds.
Speaking at a seminar on the issue, Soochow University Professor Hsieh Yi-hung said that this wave of economic crime has been tantamount to "a catastrophe."
He noted that over the past eight years, 92 corporations and 367 individuals have been involved in embezzlement scandals.

Although the Ministry of Justice has mapped out standard procedures for preventing major economic criminals from fleeing to other countries, Hsieh lamented that several notorious tycoons remain at large, namely Rebar Pacific Group Chairman Wang You-tseng, who allegedly embezzled NT$70 billion from various listed companies under his group, Chen Yu-hao of Tuntex Group, who is accused of embezzling NT$60 billion, and Wang Yu-yun of Chung Hsing Bank, who is believed to have embezzled NT$30 billion from the company.
What is worse, Hsieh said, is that these fugitive tycoons have continued living lavish lifestyles and even started new businesses overseas.

Hsieh attributed the rampant corporate crime in recent years to the fact that the line between government and business has become blurred to such an extent that it has undermined the government's supervisory role.
The best way to restore public confidence in the government is to have those indicted for economic crimes repatriated back to Taiwan and to retrieve the embezzled money, he said.
