DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor urges criminalization of lax oversight by officials

TEXT.P: Financial officials who have failed to actively fulfill their duties of overseeing banking, capital market and corporate operations should be subject to strict criminal penalties to ward off major economic and financial crimes, a prosecutor said Saturday.

Hsu Yung-chin, a head prosecutor with the Shihlin Prosecutor's Office in Taipei City, made the appeal in a speech delivered at a seminar on updating the country's financial supervisory mechanism to cope with emerging economic and high-tech crime.

Hsu, the country's first prosecutor ever to be posted at a financial supervisory agency, said that during his stint as a proscutor stationed at the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), he came to find that many financial officials were passive in policing stock market operations and corporate accounting practices.

Hsu, who has investigated many high-profile financial scandals, including a Taiwan Development Corp. stock insider trading case involving Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, said economic crime, financial crime, and crime involving the rich and the famous could simply stem from weak corporate oversight.

However, these criminal activities might also involve legal, economic, social and political problems, Hsu said. For instance, a corporate financial scandal usually originates from "greed, " but ruptures or negligence in the internal monitoring mechanism could also be a cause, he noted, adding that accounting and administrative overseeing units should reflect on whether they have fulfilled their duties of timely and effective supervision.

In the past, Hsu said, stock market price rigging and insider trading tended to be different in style. But nowadays, he said, the two criminal activities have often been interwined. Worse still, big-time players now often simultaneously manipulate prices of many stocks, making it even more difficult for prosecutors to investigate.
If supervisory organs fail to actively cooperate with investigative and prosecutorial agencies, Hsu said, probes into such cases can be a tall order.

Against this backdrop, Hsu said, financial supervisors who have been lax or passive in carrying out their watchdog duties should be prosecuted and given harsh prison sentences to prevent corporate scandals and financial irregularities.

DOC.HEADLINE: President inspects typhoon disaster response center

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of the Central Disaster Response Center in Taipei Saturday as Typhoon Krosa lashed Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rainfall.

Chen was briefed on the latest typhoon situation and its impact on public infrastructure. As the storm has cut power supplies to many homes, caused flooding and disrupted traffic services in some areas, Chen directed relevant central government agencies to assist local governments in rehabilitation work.
"All levels of government units should step up repair of damaged public facilities so that our people can resume normal daily life, " Chen said during the inspection tour.
Chen was accompanied by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai during the inspection tour.

According to Chang, torrential rains brought by the storm have damaged 27 major roads leading to several aboriginal communities in mountainous regions around the country. Chang said he has directed the Ministry of Transportation and the Council of Indigenous Peoples to take contingency measures to prevent those communities from losing contact with outside world or being left isolated.

As of 4 p.m. (0800 GMT), Krosa, the Cambodia word for crane, was centered at sea about 30 kilometers southeast of Yilan in northeastern Taiwan, with sustained winds of 184 kph, the Central Weather Bureau said.
The northern port city of Keelung bore the typhoon's brunt as a massive power cut blacked out 400,000 households, officials said.

The island's capital, Taipei, was eerily quiet with shops and offices closed and residents staying home. City officials said strong winds uprooted more than 200 trees in the city, while knee-deep water flooded a residential area in suburban Beitou.
About 2,000 households suffered power outages in northern Miaoli County, where a raging river destroyed a village bridge, officials said.
Cathay Pacific Airways canceled flights from Taipei to Hong Kong, Japan and South Korea. Dragon Airlines also canceled flights between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Ferry services were halted between Taiwan, Green Island and the island of Lanyu, and several domestic flights were canceled, officials said.

According to tallies released by the Central Disaster Response Center, 17 people had been injured amid gusty winds and torrential downpours as of 3: 30 p.m., but no casualties have so far been reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: President still mulling whether to take over DPP's helm

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he is still pondering whether he is competent enough to concurrently serve as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen made the remarks during a grassroots community outreach visit in the central county of Changhua.

On Friday, the DPP's Central Executive Committee (CEC) held an extraordinary meeting during which it formalized a call by the party's Central Standing Committee for Chen to take over the DPP chairmanship after Yu Shyi-kun formally quit the post Monday.

Speaking at the CEC meeting, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged Chen to ignore criticism from some "deep-green" or hardline pro-independence advocates and take over the party's helm to lead the party to victory in next year's legislative and presidential elections.
Responding to press inquiries about the possibility of his return to the DPP chairmanship, Chen said he is listening attentively to pros and cons of the arrangement.

"I'll consult with other party heavyweights and those concerned about the DPP chairmanship issues to get a better understanding of their opinions," Chen said, adding that he will refer to their advice in making his final decision.

Several noted pro-independence diehards, including former senior presidential adviser Koo Kwan-min and talk show host Wang Ben-hu, have voiced strong opposition to the proposal of Chen doubling as party chairman again. They said Yu should stay on to avoid putting yet another burden on Chen's shoulders.

As a matter of fact, Chen said he is seeking reasons to politely reject DPP members' call for him to take over the party chairmanship as he is already shouldering a heavy duty as the country's head of state.
Nevertheless, he added that if the party indeed expects him to take up the responsibility, he will give the proposal a serious thought.

Asked about his view on the Taipei District Court's rejection of his request for return of classified documents seized in the high-profile "state affair fund" embezzlement case, Chen said the ruling didn't come as a surprise to him.
While expressing his respect for judicial authorities, Chen said he will defend his legitimate rights by appealing the ruling to the Taiwan High Court.

On Sept. 6, President Chen requested that the District Court return invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals, and data related to six secret diplomatic missions being used by prosecutors as evidence in the case. All those materials are now kept by the District Court.

The president said he made the request on the grounds that the materials had been re-labeled as "strictly confidential" materials that should be kept secret permanently after the Council of Grand Justices confirmed June 15 the president's constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose such information, also known as "state secret privilege."

But the District Court rejected Chen's request in a ruling issued Friday, saying that the exercise of the president's "state secret privilege" should still be made in line with the constitutional principle of balance of power and should be subject to scrutiny.

In a press statement issued late Friday, the Presidential Office said that since the documents are now in the District Court's possession, the District Court is not a suitable judicial organ to decide whether they should be returned to the Presidential Office or not.
Against this backdrop, the statement said it will appeal to the High Court within five days after it formally receives the ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 7, 2007

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 die, 17 injured as typhoon slams into Taiwan

TEXT.P: Two local citizens were killed and 17 others injured as Typhoon Krosa lashed Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rainfall Saturday, according to statistics released by the Central Disaster Response Center.
One of the dead was a man identified as Chiu Wen-hung, who was killed when his home on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei was buried by massive mudslides.
A 60-year-old man, identified as Chiu Cheng-chi who was staying in the same house when the cave-in occurred, is listed missing as search and rescue efforts are still ongoing as of press time.
One family member has been hospitalized for treatment of injuries sustained in the cave-in, while five others have been rescued and sent to a safe place, city officials said.
The other casualty was a 79-year-old man living in the northern city of Hsinchu who fell to his death while checking ruptures on his home's rooftop, according to the disaster response center.

In capital Taipei, a total of eight people were injured amid gusty winds and heavy downpours brought by Typhoon Krosa. Power supply to 24,000-plus households in the city was cut at one point, but the supply has restored by evening. Nearly 600 trees were uprooted around the city and 40 cave-ins were reported in the city's hillside regions.

As of 6:40 p.m., more than 2 million households, mostly in Yilan County, Keelung City, Taipei City and Taipei County, were blacked out because of power cut, but power supply had restored to 80 percent of those households by evening.
According to Taiwan Power Co. data, Typhoon Krosa -- the Cambodian word for crane -- caused the largest scale of blackout since Typhoon Herb battered Taiwan in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 7, or the 27th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

President Bush on Friday defended the CIA's harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects, saying its methods do not constitute torture and are necessary to protect America from attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: Krosa pounds Taiwan, leaving five dead, two missing, 52 injured

TEXT.P: Typhoon Krosa wreaked havoc on Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rainfall Saturday, leaving at least five local citizens dead and 52 others injured, the Central Disaster Response Center reported Sunday.
According to statistics released by the center, as of 10 a.m. Sunday, five people were confirmed to have been killed in typhoon mishaps, two were reportedly missing, and 52 others injured islandwide.
The typhoon has also knocked out power to hundreds of thousands of homes and, as of 10 a.m. Sunday, some 145,000 households were still without power, according to the center.

A father and son, identified as Chiu Cheng-chi, 60 and Chiu Wen-hung, 43, were killed after their home on Yangming Mountain in Taipei City's northern suburb was buried under a massive mudslide Saturday.
A 79-year-old man, identified as Chou Chin-fu who lived in the northern city of Hsinchu, fell to his death while checking ruptures in his home's rooftop during the onslaught of the typhoon Saturday.

A 50-year-old woman in the southern county of Tainan, identified as Huang Ching- chu, was killed on the road when her motorbike slammed into the concrete pole of a roadside light, according to the disaster response center.

The fifth casualty was a 40-year-old farmer in the northeastern county of Yilan, identified as Lo Kuei-fa, who was confirmed to have been washed away by flood in the Lanyang Brook Saturday. His body was found Sunday morning.

Meanwhile, a 56-year-old chef with a hotspring hostel in Chienshih rural township in the northern county of Hsinchu was reported missing after his dorm room was buried by mudslides. As of press time, the Hsinchu police and fire fighters were still searching for the man.
Two residents in the southern county of Pingtung fell into separate sewage ditches, and were listed as missing as of 10 a.m. Sunday, according to the disaster response center.

As of 6:40 p.m. Saturday, more than 2 million households, mostly in Yilan County, Keelung City, Taipei City and Taipei County, were blacked out due to power failures, but the power supply was restored to 80 percent of those households by evening.
According to Taiwan Power Co. figure, Typhoon Krosa -- the 15th typhoon reported in the West Pacific area this year -- caused the largest scale blackout since Typhoon Herb battered Taiwan in 1996.
The typhoon, downgraded to a tropical storm Sunday after making landfall in the northeastern county of Yilan Saturday afternoon, is expected to completely leave Taiwan proper by nightfall Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 264 areas on 'red alert' for mudslides

TEXT.P: The Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture issued "red alerts" given the threat of rock and mudslides in 264 locations in Taipei City and nine other counties islandwide Sunday.

Typhoon Krosa -- which swept across northern Taiwan Saturday -- bringing torrential rains to the island, triggered slides in locations in north and northeastern Taiwan and still threatens to cause additional mudslides in central and southern counties.
The Soil and Water Conservation Bureau issued "red alerts" Sunday against potential rock and mudslides at 264 sites in 119 villages in nine counties around the island and Taipei City.
In Yangming Mountain in Taipei City's northern suburb, two men -- father and son -- were confirmed to have been killed early Sunday morning after their home was buried by a mudslide Saturday.

Bureau officials urged the public to remain on high alert against the possibility of rock and mudslides and called for local governments to evacuate people if the situation warrants preventative measures.

The 264 risky areas are scattered throughout the eastern county of Yilan, the northern counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli and the central counties of Taichung and Nantou, the southern counties of Yunlin and Chiayi, as well as the capital, Taipei City.

Officials warned that mountainous areas are now extremely vulnerable to landslides because the soil in these areas is water saturated due to Typhoon Krosa, which is expected to continue bringing torrential rains to the island over the next two days.
They said that after a "red alert" is issued, the local government is responsible for warning locals and implementing evacuation procedures if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$350 billion private-sector funds sunk into public works

TEXT.P: More thane NT$350 billion (US$10.7 billion) private-sector funds had been funneled into 552 public work projects by the government between 2002 and the end of September this year, according to the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC).

Additional private-sector investments worth NT$17.5 billion are expected to be channeled into another 15 new projects in the coming months, PCC officials said, adding that most of the new projects are related to sewage and tourism-related facilities as well as transportation, cultural and commercial establishments.

According to PCC officials, these public construction projects, which include investments from the private sector, are estimated to have increased government revenues by some NT$330 billion, and will help create more than 80,000 jobs after they start operations.

Officials said that government agencies and local administrations are now intent on attracting greater investment from the private sector to take part in public construction projects which will help the government reduce its financial burdens, create employment and boost the country's economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice presidential candidate arrives in San Francisco
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/07/07 17:33:47 (By Chou Shih-huei and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew arrived in San Francisco Saturday from Washington D. C -- ending the first leg of his 12-day tour to North America.
Siew was greeted at the airport by Mark W. P. Liao, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, and hundreds of Taiwan expatriates.

Describing his just-concluded three-day visit to the U.S. capital as "satisfactory, " Siew told reporters that he can tell that the United States has great expectations of Taiwan and keenly hopes to maintain traditionally cordial ties between the two countries.
Siew said he strongly believes that friendly Taiwan-U.S. relations can be restored and further improved if the KMT retakes power in March 22, 2008 presidential election.
While in Washington D.C., Siew visited the U.S. Congress and met with 18 senators and 24 House representatives to exchange views on political philosophy.
According to Siew, his visit to Washington D. C. should help improve the impression that the United States has of the KMT.

Siew is slated to stay in San Francisco for three days, where he will attend a flag raising ceremony to observe the Oct. 10 National Day of the Republic of China with ROC nationals, and call on hi-tech companies and local Chinese communities to exchange views on and explore means of reinvigorating and expanding Taiwan's economy.
Siew will then proceed to Canada after wrapping up his visit to the United States.
He is accompanied by John C. T. Feng, a former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, and several well-known figures on his current North American tour.

Siew and former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou have paired up on a ticket to contest the coming presidential poll with the rival ticket of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, composed of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang, both of whom previously served as premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: President seeks esprit de corps among DPP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for members and supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday to set aside their differences and reunite in an esprit de corps so as to help facilitate his decision on taking up the helm of the DPP once again.

Chen said he is still pondering whether he is competent enough to concurrently serve as DPP chairman, but he "would not shun the duty if assured by an obvious demonstration of unity by party members and supporters."

He called for everybody to pitch in, saying that he is not capable of taking on all the responsibilities single-handedly, and it would be meaningful for him to assume the DPP chairmanship only if all others do their part and take up a share of overall responsibility.
Chen made the remarks during a grassroots community outreach lunch in the Zhongshan District, Taipei City.

He said he has told DPP members that there are 100 reasons for him to politely reject the party chairmanship as he is already shouldering a heavy duty as the country's head of state, but "DPP members have demonstrated great goodwill in asking me to take the party helm again."
Chen served as DPP chairman from July 2002 to December 2004 when he resigned to assume responsibility for the party's failure to win a majority in the legislative elections that year.

On Friday, the DPP's Central Executive Committee (CEC) held an extraordinary meeting during which it formalized a call by the party's Central Standing Committee for Chen to take over the DPP chairmanship after Yu Shyi-kun stepped down Sept. 27.

Yu announced his decision to resign late last month after being indicted on graft charges for his alleged misuse of a "special allowance fund" during his terms as premier and as Presidential Office secretary-general.
Despite calls for him to stay, Yu said that he was adamant about resigning after his more radical version of the "normal country resolution" was rejected by party leaders Sept. 26.

The version, which included the words "changing the country's title to 'Taiwan' from the current Republic of China to declare to world that Taiwan is a sovereign independent country, " failed to receive the support of party leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Europe-based young Taiwanese scholars meet in Belgium
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/07/07 18:12:08 (By P.C. Tang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Europe-based young Taiwanese scholars specializing in the humanities and social sciences convened their first annual assembly in Leuven City, Belgium Saturday for the purpose of promoting academic exchanges, an event organizer said Sunday.

The one-and-half day conference was organized by Taiwanese doctoral students at Leiden University in the Netherlands and sponsored by Taiwanese students at University of Leuven in the hope of providing a platform at which young Taiwanese scholars studying in Europe might present their diversified academic achievements and generate greater academic interchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and Europe Union, according to the organizer.

A number of young Taiwanese scholars currently pursuing their doctoral degrees from universities in Belgium, Netherlands, British, France and Germany and Sweden participated in the conference during which they presented the results of their studies and engaged in discussions.
A formal launch ceremony for an association composed of the scholars is slated to take place and a chairman will be elected ahead of the conclusion of the conference, according to the organizer.

Taiwan's Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen was also present at the convention on behalf of the government to show support for, and recognize the importance of, the establishment of the academic group and conference.

During the convention, Yao also expressed hope that young scholars who have a better understanding of Europe will serve as bridges between the two polities, thereby increasing mutual understanding between Taiwan and Europe, according to the organizer.

Chiu Hei-yuan, a research fellow at the Institute of Sociology of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top academic institution, and Joseph Hsu, director of the Science Division in the Taipei Representative Office in the EU and Belgium, will deliver keynote speeches during the meeting as well, the organizer added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Symantec launches emoticon look-alike photo contest

TEXT.P: The Symantec Corp., a global leader in Internet security software, is holding a global photo competition running through until Oct. 15 to find the best photos of facial expressions imitating emoticons, with a variety of prizes including US$10,000 in cash on offer, an event organizer said Sunday.

The contest, dubbed "the Norton 360 emoticon look-alike competition, " invites Internet users to click a photo of the best impression of emoticon which can be an angry, winking, smiling, or panicked face, or one with its tongue sticking out, and upload it to http//photocontest.symantec.com. An emoticon is a visual representation of an emotion or attitude, according to the organizer.

Participants are allowed to upload more than one pictures, and the photos may be of themselves or someone they know. Once contestants upload their pictures, they will be entered in the prize draw, with a chance to win the grand prize of US$10,000 or one of five first place prizes of $1,000 in various categories.
Submissions will be judged on the following criteria: authenticity, creativity and best representation of themes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maintaining status quo in best interests of Taiwan people: candidate

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate said Sunday that maintaining the status quo of the Republic of China reflects the common wish of the majority of the people in Taiwan and is in the best interests of the country.

Ma Ying-jeou traveled to Lungtan in the northern county of Taoyuan Sunday to pay a courtesy visit to 82-year-old Hakka novelist Chung Chao-cheng at his home, where the writer questioned Ma about his theory of "an ultimate unification across the Taiwan Strait."

Ma answered Chung by clarifying his stance that presently it is not an opportune time for Taiwan to talk about independence or unification with China and "maintaining the ROC's status quo" remains the common wish of the majority of the Taiwan people.
He added that currently, economic issues, public order and education are all much more pressing than the independence vs unification question.

Chung, who is regarded as one of the founding fathers of Taiwan's "native literature, " seemed to be satisfied with Ma's explanation, saying that he found Ma's discourse based on democracy and the people's will acceptable.

Ma talked with Chung for 40 minutes until they were forced to end their meeting earlier than expected because members of the public, interested in the Ma-Chung meeting, had swamped the road in front of Chung's residence, causing a traffic jam.

When asked by a reporter whether he paid the visit to Chung in hopes of winning over more voters, Ma said it is not the first time for him to visit the writer, adding that he has read Chung's books since he was a child, and visited Chung while serving as Taipei's mayor. "It would not be right not to include Chung on my Taoyuan itinerary," Ma said.

For his part, Chung said that some people had dissuaded him from meeting with Ma, but he met the candidate anyway, out of consideration that he might have an chance to learn the KMT presidential candidate's thoughts on the question of independence vs unification.
Chung said he asked Ma to remain consistent in his stance on that issue during the campaign and after the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSE chief calls for clearer regulations governing insider trading

TEXT.P: Wu Rong-i, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSE), Saturday urged the government, in collaboration with law experts, to review existing rules regulating insider trading cases and come up with clearer and more feasible regulations.
Wu made the call while delivering a speech on the differences between theory and practice in dealing with insider trading.
Wu said that the TSE has handed over more than 100 suspected insider trading cases to prosecution for probes in recent years, but the accused in most of the cases were cleared of any wrongdoing.

Noting that as regulations governing the nature and scope of "material, non- public information" for insider trading and the definition of when the information becomes material are not clear, many business representatives have expressed concerns that they could be inadvertently caught up in insider trading.
Wu said since assuming the TSE chairmanship, he has found that there is ample room for discussions exploring the implications of the lawfulness of some commercial activities.
He said that the key point for judicial agencies to decide whether the accused is guilty or not lies on the definition of the point at which information becoming material.

According to existing insider trade regulations, insiders -- including a company's directors, supervisors, managers and their close relatives -- are banned from buying or selling stocks of their company within 12 hours of the release of important information likely to affect the company's stock price, but the problem is determining at what point information should be judged as being in the public domain, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan Science Park in need of workers

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park in Taichung County will have to recruit at least 1,700 workers in 2008 due to its rapid business expansion, according to an investigation by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

Chung Chin-chi, director of the CLA's service center in charge of Taichung, Changhua and Nantou counties, said that enterprises based in the compound are expected to experience great manpower demands next year -- with 55 percent of some 1,700 jobs available for factory workers and 32 percent targeting computer hardware engineers.

According to Chung, a total of 89 companies have been approved to open shop in the science park in central Taiwan. Thirty-four enterprises have already kicked off operations in the compound, with approved investments of over NT$1.7 trillion and 16,000 employees, he said.

The Central Taiwan Science Park will have a demand for as many as 90,000 workers in the coming years -- a figure which may climb to 140,000 if job opportunities released by nearby industrial zones are also included, Chung said.
Thanks to its rapid growth, the park is expected to create even more jobs and to become the prime employment hub for job seekers in Taiwan's central regions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: High Court prepares for president's appeal to reclaim evidence

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court has selected eight senior chief judges in preparation for an imminent appeal by President Chen Shui-bian to reclaim evidence held by a lower court in probes of his "state affairs fund" case, court sources said Sunday.

According to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Ruling No. 627 issued June 15, the High Court is obliged to form a special tribunal to deal with a dispute between the president and the prosecution or a district court over the exercise of the president's "state secrets privilege."
The CGJ ruling also stipulates that such a special tribunal should be led by a senior chief judge and include another four judges.
Eight of the 16 chief judges at the High Court meet the seniority requirement to head the special tribunal, as each of them has been in on the bench for more than 10 years, the court sources said.
Meanwhile, the sources said, the High Court is scheduled to unveil the roster of each five-member tribunal Monday.
When the High Court receives President Chen's appeal, it will determine by drawing lots which tribunal will handle the case.

Chen is expected to appeal the Taipei District Court's Friday ruling that rejected his request for the return of a collection of documents and articles held by the court as evidence in the probes into his alleged misuse of the "state affairs fund".
According to CGJ Ruling No. 627, Chen can appeal the District Court ruling to the High Court within five days after receiving the notification.

The District Court obtained the evidence collection from a prosecutorial team that indicted the first lady Wu Shu-jen and three former and incumbent presidential aides last November on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund, " a special allowance fund set aside for the president's discretionary use for state affairs.
The collection consists of invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic projects from 2002 to last December.

Chen asked for the return of the collection Sept. 6 on the grounds that the collection were "strictly confidential" information under the protection of the Classified National Security Information Protection Act and should be kept secret permanently.

The president said in his petition that the collection was labeled "strictly confidential" in line with CGJ Ruling No. 627, which confirms the president's constitutional right to decide what constitutes a state secret and his right to refuse disclosure, also known as "state secrets privilege."

However, the District Court ruled illegal the president's declaration that the collection was top secret, claiming that while the June 15 CGJ constitutional interpretation states that the president has the right to keep classified information secret, the exercise of the right should still observe the constitutional principle of balance of power and be subject to scrutiny.

In a news release issued late Friday, the Presidential Office said the District Court has no power to deny the president's right to proclaim that the court-held collection of documents are "strictly confidential" since the grand justices have already confirmed the president's "state secrets privilege."

Even if the exercise of the "state secrets privilege" should be subject to judicial scrutiny, the news release said it should be conducted by a more suitable judicial organ rather than the District Court.

Regretting that the District Court made many biased allegations and judgments in its ruling about the pending "state affairs fund" case, the press statement said the District Court is by no means an appropriate agency to decide whether the collection of documents in question should be returned to the Presidential Office.

The Presidential Office further said that as the District Court has a vested interest in the outcome of the ruling on the "ownership" of the collection, it should not be permitted to issue a ruling on the case given the potential conflict of interest.

The Presidential Office also rebutted the District Court's "false allegations" that the president's move to proclaim the collection secret was merely aimed at covering up the defendants' wrongdoings. Making such a premature judgment is in obvious violation of the Criminal Procedure Law, which stipulates that all defendants be considered innocent before a final ruling is handed down.

DOC.HEADLINE: Land warning for Typhoon Krosa lifted on Taiwan proper

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted the land warning for Typhoon Krosa on Taiwan proper Sunday at 5: 30 p.m. after Krosa skirted Taiwan's northeast regions the previous day.

According to the CWB, it lifted the typhoon's land warning for all of Taiwan proper because the strong typhoon had lost steam and weakened to a tropical storm as it moved on towards China at a speed of 14 kilometers per hour.
However, meteorologists warned residents in mountainous areas from Hsinchu County to Pingtung County of heavy rains yet to come, brought by the remnants of the typhoon.

Meanwhile, agricultural losses around the country climbed further Sunday noon, with ravaged crops in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan reaching NT$200 million in losses. Chiayi and Taitung counties in southern and southeastern Taiwan sustained agricultural damages of more than NT$80 million and NT$50 million, respectively, while Nantou County in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung County in the south suffered losses of over NT$47 million.

Vegetable prices in Taipei's wholesales market have skyrocketed to an average of NT$40.7 (US$1.25) per kilogram Sunday morning, up from Saturday's NT$38.6, as supplies shrank to 642 metric tons, down from 1,538 metric tons a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: President expected to accept DPP leadership before Thursday

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian might agree to assume the leadership of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party before Thursday, a DPP lawmaker said Sunday.

Ker Chien-ming, whip of the DPP Legislative Caucus, said Chen is expected to answer the party's call before Thursday, when he is slated to depart for the Marshall Islands for a summit with Taiwan's South Pacific allies.
The call was made by the party's Central Standing Committee on Oct. 3, and by the Central Executive Committee on Oct. 5 after Yu Shyi-kun stepped down from the chairmanship Sept. 27.
Many party officers appointed by Yu followed Yu's suit by tenderring their resignations, and their successors must be appointed by the new chairman, Ker said.
The President, who had served as DPP chairman from July 2002 to December 2004, said earlier Sunday that he would accept the mandate only if party members promise to rally behind him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Krosa takes heavy toll on agriculture

TEXT.P: Typhoon Krosa took a toll worth NT$748.67 million (US$22.96 million) on agriculture, according to tallies released Sunday by the Council of Agriculture.
That amount includes NT$567 million in damage to about 20 percent of crops on 13,283 hectares, which is tantamount to the complete loss of crops on 2630 hectares.
The hardest hit crops include bananas, rice, persimmons, guavas, papayas, and grapes.

Livestock and poultry damage comes to NT$190,000. Fishery damage amounts to NT$1.16 million, with 13.2 hectare of fish ponds flooded. Forestry damage stands at NT$2.22 million caused mainly by damage to 15 hectares of woodland.
Damage to agricultural facilities amounts to NT$26.75 million, while damage to fishery facilities, particularly the set nets installed around the coast of the island, stands at NT$150 million.
Among the 16 counties on the island, Nantou, Hualien and Tainan bear the brunt of the hit, suffering a damage of NT$157 million, NT$ 150 million and NT$111 million respectively.
Typhoon Krosa also knocked out power to 2.32 million households during its onslaught against Taiwan, according to the Taiwan Power Co.

Thanks to its repairing crew and contractors, power supply has been restored to 2.25 million households, or 97 percent of them by Sunday afternoon, and most of the remaining households were inaccessible because of damage to roads linked to them, according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 8, or the 28th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsiung Feng-2E missile not to be displayed on National Day

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu said Monday that the Hsiung Feng-2E cruise missile -- the latest version of Taiwan's domestically-developed missiles -- will not be showcased during the military display scheduled for the Double Ten National Day Wednesday.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said that the land-attack cruise missile will not be displayed at the event because it is still in the development stage.

However, Lee said that other domestically-developed advanced missiles, including the supersonic anti-ship Hsiung Feng-3 missile and the anti-tactical ballistic missile Tien Kung-3, as well as several unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) will be displayed.

Lee made the remarks in response to a question raised by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang about whether Washington had suggested that Taiwan not showcase the Hsiung Feng-2E for fear that doing so could be provocative to China.
The defense minister said that the United States has respected Taiwan's decision to develop defensive weapon systems, adding that "we will handle the matter with great vigilance."
According to the Ministry of National Defense (MND), a variety of advanced military hardware will be showcased at this year's National Day military display, the first to be held since 1991.

MND officials said that the flyby to be staged by the Air Force during the National Day event will showcase many aircraft purchased in the years after the last gathering, including the AH-1W attack helicopter, the OH-58D combat search helicopter, the S-70C chopper, and several fixed-wing aircraft, such as the F-16 and Mirage 2000 jetfighters.

Other advanced military hardware to be showcased at the event include two eight- wheel-drive CM-32 Clouded Leopard vehicles, an Avenger air defense missile system armed with Stinger missiles and a 50-caliber machine gun, as well as armored Humvees equipped with TOW armor-piercing missiles, the officials said.
An Assault Amphibian Vehicle AAVP7, purchased from the United States in 2001, will also featured, they added.
Mobile Army and Marine radar, fire fighting vehicles of the chemical corps, and a pontoon bridge of the engineering corps will also be included in the display.

Members of several military units, including the Marine Corps Amphibious Reconnaissance and Patrol Unit and the Army Special Forces, as well as a skydiving team will perform as part of the display, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguay, Taiwan's staunchest supporter: President Duarte

TEXT.P: Paraguay is one of Taiwan's staunchest supporters and cannot be "bought" in any way, visiting Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos said Monday.
Duarte expressed his sincere wish that Taiwan can achieve its goal of finding its identity in the international community as soon as possible.
President Chen Shui-bian met with Duarte and his wife at the Presidential Office for a talk Monday after a red-carpet welcome ceremony for the Paraguayan couple outside the Presidential Office.
President Duarte and his wife are among many foreign dignitaries who have come to Taipei to attend the Republic of China Double Ten National Day celebrations slated for Wednesday.

President Chen said that although Paraguay is the furthest from Taiwan geographically among all the country's diplomatic allies, the close ties and strong friendship between the two sides has erased that distance.

Noting that Paraguay has spoken out in support of Taiwan's U.N. membership bid at every General Assembly gathering since Duarte assumed the presidency in 2003, Chen said that Paraguay is one of the most important forces assisting Taiwan's bid to join the world body.
"President Duarte's clear and powerful speech in support of Taiwan's bid delivered at this year's U.N. General Assembly gathering moved many people in Taiwan and was greatly appreciated," Chen said.

Chen further said that President Duarte's current visit to Taiwan is particularly significant as the two countries are celebrating the 50th anniversary of the establishment of formal diplomatic relations this year.
Chen also expressed his congratulations to Duarte on the occasion of his birthday, which happens to coincide with Taiwan's National Day on Oct. 10.

For his part, Duarte told Chen that he always feels at home when he visits Taiwan and that he will spare no efforts to further cement ties between Taiwan and Paraguay as the two countries share common goals and ideals.
Duarte and his wife last visited Taiwan in May 2004 to attend President Chen's inauguration for a second term.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 122 points to close at 9,739, with 27,168 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November gained 127 points to finish at 9,747, with 630 contracts traded, while December futures rose 124 points to close at 9,750, with 18 contract transactions. March futures moved up 112 points to finish at 9,750, with five contract transactions, while June futures increased 109 points to close at 9,750, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 9,617 for October, 9,620 for November, 9,626 for December, 9,638 for March and 9,641 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

October TE futures rose 4.45 points to close at 400.85, with 2,310 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 3.4 points to finish at 400.75, with 27 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures moved up 20.8 points to close at 1,102.2, with 3,895 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures increased 23.2 points to finish at 1,103.8, with 128 contracts traded.
