DOC.HEADLINE: 'Lust, Caution' breaks box office record in Taipei City

TEXT.P: Oscar-winning director Ang Lee's latest film "Lust, Caution" set a box office record in Taipei City over the last three days during the onslaught of Typhoon Krosa, a Buena Vista Film Co. Ltd. spokesman said Monday.

According to the spokesman, "Lust, Caution, " which recently won the Golden Lion Award at the 2007 Venice Film Festival, earned NT$11.19 million (US$345.370) at the box office in Taipei City from Friday through Sunday, during which time most theaters were forced to close early because of the typhoon.

In its first two weeks after being released Sept. 24, the film earned NT$72 million in Taipei City, breaking the previous record of NT$60.97 million held by Lee's Oscar-winning film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, " the spokesman said. He added that the film earned NT$150 million around the island for the same period.
The many sex scenes in the latest film by Lee, whose movies usually do not have many such scenes, have attracted even more curious people who are not regular moviegoers, the spokesman said.
In addition, many of the topics raised in "Lust, Caution" continue to be hot topics of conversation on the Internet and on television programs, he said.

"Lust, Caution, " which is based on a novel by the late Chinese writer Eileen Chang, tells the story of a group of patriotic students who plan to assassinate the intelligence chief in the Japanese-backed Chinese government during World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget appropriation for inauguration `based on professionalism'

TEXT.P: The appropriation of NT$99.5 million (US$3.01 million) for the presidential inauguration next year is based "on the principle of professionalism, " Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan said Monday.

Yeh, who concurrently serves as the campaign manager of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, made the statement during a legislative committee reviewing the revenues and expenditures of the Presidential Office as part of its review of the central government budget for 2008.

Legislator Joanna Lei of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) questioned what she claimed are the "high expenses" of the inauguration while the public "live in misery, " with KMT Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang parroting her opinion.

Yeh said she is sure Hsieh will win the presidential election, but claimed that the appropriation of the inauguration budget is not aimed at favoring Hsieh, but is based on the principles of "neutrality, professionalism and needs."

Feng Juei-lin, chief accountant of the Presidential Office, said the budget appropriated for the 2000 presidential inauguration ceremony was NT$38 million, while the actual expenses were NT$72 million. The budget appropriated for the 2004 inauguration ceremony was NT$84 million, while the actual expenses were NT$69.58 million.

Liu Hsi-chuan, a bureau chief of the Presidential Office, said the 2008 inauguration ceremony will be held in the square in front of the Presidential Office if the weather is clement but will be moved to the Taipei Arena, an indoor stadium in downtown Taipei, in case of rain.
Liu claimed that if the ceremony is held outdoors, NT$10 million could be saved.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices surge

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, apparently boosted by a big rise in stock markets in the United States, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 99.91 points to close at 9,717.17.
The bourse opened at 9,736.93 and fluctuated between 9,744.97 and 9,683.14 during trading. A total of 5.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$152.36 billion (US$4.7 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.9 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent, with plastics and chemical shares, machinery and electronics stocks, and paper and pulp issues all at 0.7 percent.
Construction stocks moved down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by textile shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 662, with 219 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Krosa exceed NT$1.16 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses resulting from Typhoon Krosa had increased to NT$1.168 billion (US$35.71 million) as of Monday, according to statistics released by the Council of Agriculture (COA) later that day.

The COA estimated that crop damage amounted to NT$969 million, with a total of 22,940 hectares of cropland affected. Bananas and rice paddies were the worst- affected crops, with persimmons also taking a heavy hit.

Meanwhile, damage to stock and poultry facilities amounted to NT$1.37 million, damage to the fishing and aquaculture sectors reached NT$1.16 million and damage to forestry production amounted to NT$2.22 million, COA officials said.

The officials said Nantou and Hualien counties were the hardest-hit areas, qualifying farmers to apply for relief aid and low-interest loans, while farmers in Yilan, Miaoli, Changhua and Tainan counties are qualified to apply for low- interest loans.
Typhoon Krosa swept through northern and northeastern Taiwan Saturday, battering most of the country with strong winds and torrential rain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic growth to top 4.58 percent this year: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung estimated Monday that the country's domestic economy will grow by at least 4.58 percent this year, given steady growth in the industrial sector and thriving performances on the local bourse.

Chang made the estimate during a speech delivered at a ceremony to mark the inauguration of four new products by the Taiwan Futures Exchange -- GreTai securities market stock index futures, GreTai Securities market stock index options, non-electronics, non-finance sub-index futures and non-electronics, non-finance sub-index options.

Chang offered his congratulations to the Taiwan Futures Exchange for the inauguration of the new products, which he said will help complete the exchange's product lines and in turn benefit traders and investors in terms of their fund hedge efforts.

Noting that futures transactions in Taiwan topped 100 million contracts last year to rank the 18th-largest in the world, Chang said the listing of a Taiwan Exchanges Holding Company, which will happen in the near future, will help strengthen the performances of Taiwan's stock and futures markets even further.

He added that Taiwan's overall economic growth could top at least 4.58 percent this year with the aid of the domestic stock market, which has continued to attract foreign funds that have reached a seven-year high so far this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to open Web page in support of democracy in Myanmar

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is preparing to add a new page to its official Web site in the next few days stating Taiwan's support for democratic activities in Myanmar, a MOFA spokeswoman said Monday.

Yeh Fei-bi, vice director-general of the MOFA Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, said the ministry has never stopped caring about the democracy movement in that country, which was hit with a bloody crackdown by the military junta in Yangon last month.

The MOFA hopes it can connect with international friends via the Web page in a drive to unify support from around the world for Myanmar's democratization, Yeh said in response to criticism from Sun You-lien, the spokesman for a Taiwanese support network for Myanmar's pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel peace laureate who has been under house arrest for many years.

Sun said earlier at a conference on the Myanmar issue held by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD), a non-profit think tank, that he felt it is "unbelievable" that the MOFA said in a report to the Cabinet Oct. 3 that it cannot do anything about the Myanmar junta's crackdown on civilian protesters as Taiwan maintains no diplomatic ties with either the Southeast Asian country or its main ally -- China.
Yeh denied that the MOFA said in the report that it "can't do anything about" the Myanmarese democracy movement.

Although Taiwan cannot talk with China and Myanmar through diplomatic channels, it can still contact Taiwanese businessmen operating in Myanmar, non-government organizations and civic groups that support the democracy movement in Myanmar in voicing its support, Yeh said, adding the TFD conference focusing on the Myanmar issue was sponsored by the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to release frozen vegetable stocks to meet post-typhoon demand

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will act to release frozen vegetable stocks to meet market demand in the wake of severe damage done to the country's agricultural sector during this weekend's Typhoon Krosa, COA officials said Monday.
Those agricultural losses have surpassed NT$1 billion, officials said, noting that 22,940 hectares of cropland was damaged by the storm.
While vegetable and fruit wholesale markets around the island were not open for Monday, it is currently unclear how much of an impact agricultural losses will have on the market, the COA said.

According to COA statistics, the stock of frozen vegetables maintained by major farmers' groups around the island now stands at 2,666 tons, including 1,823 tons of root and rhizome vegetables, and 756 tons of leafy vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP chairman will attend Double Ten National Day rally

TEXT.P: An anti-corruption campaign spokesman said Monday that Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who initiated the campaign, will attend the Double Ten National Day rally.

Jerry Fan, spokesman of the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign, made the remarks after he and other key officials of the campaign called on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the chief organizer of the National Day rally, earlier in the day to communicate with him on the behavior of those attending the rally.

Fan noted that the nation's security authorities, as well as a pro-government TV station, have in recent days continued to claim that the "red-clad" anti- President Chen Shui-bian protesters will attempt to disrupt the Double Ten National Day celebrations like they did last year.
The media also reported that Chen has said that "if the protesters dare to make any move on National Day, they will be arrested," Fan said.

Fan said the campaign will only mobilize Shih and added that a poster of Shih in his fugitive days when he was wanted by the then-Kuomintang administration will be displayed with the caption " Chen Shui-bian, are you going to arrest me one more time."
The appearance of Shih, who was put behind bars for a quarter of a century for preaching democratic ideals, will be "enough to represent the spirit of the red- clad army," according to Fan.

Fan said Shih will wear a red shirt and will "show up somewhere" on the periphery of the rally. He will follow the regulations of the organizing committee by not carrying any dangerous weapons and will not shout slogans or unfurl banners.

The campaign, initiated by Shih to despose Chen in August 2006 in the wake of a series of scandals surrounding Chen's family members and close aides, created a phenomenon in which several large-scale rallies culminated with the encircling of the Presidential Office and Chen's official residence on National Day last year. The campaign only petered out toward the end of last year.

Legislators of the opposition and the ruling parties scuffled briefly on the grandstand while Chen was delivering a speech on National Day as opposition legislators flashed the "thumbs down" gesture to lend support to the protesters. The move caused great embarrassment for Chen and prompted him to say that the rally should be scrapped.
Chen has decided not to address the National Day rally this year, in a departure from past precedent.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes Taiwan and Dominican Republic will sign FTA soon

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Monday that Taiwan and the Dominican Republic will sign a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) as soon as possible to benefit enterprises in both countries.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting with visiting Dominican Republic Vice President Rafael Alburquerque, who was in Taipei to participate in celebrations of Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day.

Noting that Taiwan and the Dominican Republic have concluded the first-round of FTA negotiations, Chen expressed hope that such talks might continue so as to strengthen bilateral trade and economic ties.
Until now, countries in Central America signing FTAs with Taiwan -- including Panama, Guatemala, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Honduras -- have been those with which Taiwan maintains diplomatic ties.

Chen also extended gratitude to the Dominican Republic government for its support to Taiwan's participation in world organizations and activities, although it has not publicly spoken in favor of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations as the Caribbean country is applying to be a non-permanent member of the U.N. Security Council and would rather not express publicly its support to Taiwan's entry to U.N. so as to not incur China's veto over its U.N. Security Council bid.
The Republic of China has tried in vain to re-enter the United Nations since 1993, and this year changed tactics by applying for a seat under the name Taiwan, although that too failed.
Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu has said that there will be a trade conference held Tuesday in Taipei to help attract Taiwanese enterprises to invest in the Dominican Republic.

Lu added that she will also accompany Alburquerque on visits to several trade establishments in Taiwan Tuesday, and host a banquet in honor of the Dominican Republic delegation, which more than 100 local high-tech business executives in Taiwan will attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fund to sponsor poor children in northern Vietnam

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Fund for Children and Families said Monday that it has decided to sponsor 1,000 children in an impoverish village of northern Vietnam.

Fund officials said the village, Quang Phong, in the Na Ri region about 240 km north of Hanoi, capital of Vietnam, has a population of around 30,000, composed mainly of five minority tribes: the Tay, Nung, Dao, Hmong and Kinh.

The officials said that because the village is in a remote mountainous area with little access to the outside world, it has been listed as one of the country's most impoverished areas by the Vietnamese government.

This is why the fund has decided to help the children in the village, noting that when the fund recently sent officials to visit the village, they found the backwards and impoverished situation very similar to that of Taiwan four decades ago.
The fund called for Taiwan's people to extend a helping hand so as to improve the medical care, living conditions and education in the village.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic growth target for 2008 will be no less than 4.5%: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government's economic growth target for next year will be no less than 4.5 percent, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Ho Mei- yueh said Monday.

At a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economics and Energy Committee, Ho said Taiwan's economic growth in the first half year was adjusted upward to 4.62 percent thanks to better-than-expected private investment, with the economic growth for the whole year forecast to be 4.58 percent thanks to prosperous foreign trade and stable private consumption.
The CEPD originally set the goal for Taiwan economic growth for this year at 4.6 percent, according to Ho.

Noting that although the crisis caused by sub-prime loan problems in the United States has also caused tremendous losses in Asia's financial markets, Ho said the crisis will have a limited impact on the world as many countries have abundant foreign exchange reserves and have committed to financial reforms that will enhance the stability of banks. Ho predicted that China and India will maintain their rapid economic growth in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan diabolo dance troupe popular in New Jersey
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/08/07 21:07:31 (By Lillian Lin and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Diabolo Dance Theatre of Taiwan won the hearts of its audience in New Jersey this weekend over the course of its 90-minute performance of a dance drama, titled "Heart of the Ocean" which features a combination of diabolo stunts, dances, music, drama and stage special effects.
The performance is part of the troupe's one-month tour in the United States and Canada.
At the invitation of the Cabinet-level Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission, the troupe will stage 13 performances in the two countries between late September and late October.

It is the third time that the commission has invited the troupe to perform overseas, a commission official said, adding that the troupe was also successful in its tours in Africa and Asia in February this year and in 2006, respectively.
Founded in 1986, the troupe consists of performers aged between 8-24, who dress as little mermaids, bubble spirits, clown fish, and sharks in their performances.
During the past decade, the troupe's performances have won acclaim from people all over Taiwan, as well as New York, Singapore, South Korea, Russia, Middle East and Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIA Asia Derivatives Conference to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2007 FIA Asia Derivatives Conference will take place in Taipei Oct. 10-12, with more than 250 representatives from financial exchanges and futures industries of nearly 20 countries expected to attend, a spokesman for the Taiwan Futures Exchange (TFE) said Monday.

It will be the largest international event of its kind held in Taiwan since the TFE was established in 1997, the spokesman said, adding that the event will help boost Taiwan's profile on the world stage.

The event will provide opportunities for domestic futures companies to learn from the international market experiences of the Korea Exchange (KRX) , the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) , the European Exchange (EUREX), the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) and the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE) , among others, the TFE noted.
The event will also be beneficial to the fostering of cooperation between financial exchanges in the Asia Pacific region and their counterparts in other parts of the world, the TFE spokesman went on.

Since becoming a member of the Futures Industry Association (FIA) in 2001, the TFE has taken an active role in the association's annual meetings in an effort to enhance its relationships with other members, the spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, the TFE won the right to organize the conference in March as part of efforts to raise its global profile and highlight Taiwan's significant role in the derivatives markets in the Asia Pacific region.

The conference will feature more than 20 keynote speeches and seminars on information exchanges between financial exchanges, business opportunities for investing in Taiwan's futures market, the new role of market participants, and introductions to Asian markets, the spokesman said.
The conference will also provide an overview of Chinese and Indian markets to help participants understand the latest developments of derivatives products in Asia, the spokesman went on.
In addition, a total of 23 local and foreign futures companies will join the event to increase participants' understanding of the derivatives markets in various countries, he added.

Noting that the formation of collaborative and strategic alliances has become a global trend among the world's financial exchanges aiming to expand their market shares amid fierce competition, the spokesman said that Asian financial exchanges should seriously consider how to respond.

Against this backdrop, Bill Brodsky, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE), will be invited to share ideas and experiences on mergers between financial exchanges, the spokesman said.

Brodsky is expected to touch upon the merger between the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange earlier this year, which created the world's largest and most diverse financial exchange.

The Washington D.C.-based FIA, the world's largest institution for futures trading, established the FIA Asia last year to help promote derivative products in the Asia Pacific region amid the brisk development of Asian derivative products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team departs for Solomon Islands for medical aid services

TEXT.P: A medical team organized by the government-run Hsinchu General Hospital (HSGH) took a flight Monday for the Solomon Islands, where it is to remain for 15 months for medical aid services.

The medical team is part of the government's efforts to boost diplomatic relations with Taiwan's South Pacific allies. It was brought together around the theme, "Strengthening Oceanic Democratic Alliances and Realizing Comprehensive Partnerships, " at the first Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit last September, said HSGH President Chang Ching-nan.

Chang noted that the medical team, made up of HSGH physicians including Chang Hsiu-wei, an expert in cardiovascular surgery, will offer medical care and treatment as well as training in techniques dealing with medical research, hospital management, and constructing modern medical care and treatment facilities.

On the Solomon Islands, many local patients suffer from chronic diseases such as hypertensive cardiovascular disease and diabetes. In infectious disease control, the country is seen with high rates of malaria and tuberculosis, according to Chang.
Given those local challenges, Chang said that the medical team will also help the South Pacific country develop efficient public healthcare policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to do more to support Myanmar democracy

TEXT.P: Taiwan should do more to help democratic development in Myanmar and thereby demonstrate its unyielding support for universal human rights and advance its democracy-promoting diplomatic policy, participants of a forum said Monday.

"For example, Taiwan should pass the Refugee Act as soon as possible and help establish a Myanmar refugee settlement regime here to show our support of democracy in Myanmar, " said Lai I-chung, Director of ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Department of International Affairs, in a forum focused on the latest political developments in Myanmar following the recent massive protests.

More than 100,000 persons of Myanmarese descent currently living in Taiwan are also welcome to voice their opinions to the international community on the democratic development in their home country, said Joyce Lin, a professor at Tamkang University.
Taiwan should also seize this opportunity to increase its exchanges with Myanmar, the only Southeast Asian nation that does not trade with Taiwan, Lin said.

Discussants of the forum, which was organized by Taiwan Thinktank, agreed that the effect of global condemnation of Myanmar's ruling junta will be limited since the regime enjoys the support of China and Russia in the United Nations' Security Council. However, Taiwan should keep sending strong messages that it sides with the people.

"We don't want people to get the impression that whenever Taiwan speaks or makes the international headlines, we only do so out of concern with our own problem, which is the Taiwan Strait issue. We should keep communicating to let people know that, as a member of the international community, we do care about what happens elsewhere, " Liu noted.

There are so many things Taiwan can do with the Tibet and Myanmar issues to act as a "guardian of democracy" in the Asia-Pacific region, Lai said, adding that Hong Kong relinquished that role after the 1997 handover to China.
Political parties, non-government organizations (NGOs) and the legislature can all act to show Taiwan's support of the people of Myanmar, Lai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sets new trade surplus record in first nine months

TEXT.P: Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$17.44 billion in the first nine months of this year, setting a new high, an official of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Monday.

Lee Li-hsueh, director-general of MOF's Department of Statistics said that exports totaled US$178.74 billion, while imports totaled NT$161.3 billion in the Jan.-Sept. period. The trade surplus of US$17.44 billion represents an increase of 28.1 percent over the same period last year.
Lee noted that trade surpluses in the Jan.-Sept. periods from 2001 to 2006 were US$11.7 billion, US$15.3 billion, US$16.5 billion, US$11.8 billion, US$7.7 billion and US$13.6 billion, respectively.

Exports in September alone totaled US$22.22 billion, up 10.6 percent from the same month last year, while imports totaled US$19.07 billion, up 10.5 percent from the same month last year: the second highest total for a single month.
Lee said that the trade surplus in September totaled US$3.15 billion, or the 19th consecutive month in which a trade surplus has been registered since March 2006.

She attributed the increase in exports to increased trade with Hong Kong, China and six Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries -- Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia, which she said grew by over 19 percent when compared with the same month last year. Exports to Europe also increased by 10.8 percent.

Meanwhile, imports from the United States and China increased by 25.9 percent and 12.8 percent, respectively. Imports from Japan, Europe and the six ASEAN countries increased by 7.7 percent, 7.4 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively.
Lee said that generally speaking, exports in the fourth quarter are stronger than those in the third quarter, with the exception of last year.

Particularly noteworthy is that Taiwan's exports to China accounted for 44.1 percent of the total exports, breaking the 40 percent level for the first time, while exports to the United States declined for the third consecutive month, and exports to Japan declined for the fifth straight month.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC expatriates celebrate National Day in Baltimore
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/07 21:48:37 (By Jorge Liu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Approximately 300 Taiwanese expatriates living in the United States have attended an evening party at a hotel in Baltimore Saturday to jointly celebrate the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day in advance.
Also present at the party were Joseph Wu, Taiwan's representative to the United States, and his wife, as well as U.S. lawmakers.
Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley also sent a representative to the party to express his gratitude for the contributions made by ROC expatriates to the development of Maryland.

During his address to the party, Wu lauded the efforts and patriotism of Sue L. Wang, president of the Taiwanese American Diversity Association in Greater Baltimore, who organizes such National Day celebrations annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to put opening of casino industry on hold

TEXT.P: The government will not open up the casino industry for the moment due to the absence of relevant legal framework and a lack of public consensus, Ho Mei-yueh, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Monday.
Ho was responding to a question from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Yi-hsiung during a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.
Ho noted that other countries do not separately promote the casino industry, but integrate it into the comprehensive development of the leisure industry.
The opening of the gambling industry requires a sound legal environment and a special institution to oversee the industry, Ho said.
She added that further discussions on how to minimize the possible adverse impact of the casino industry opening will be held among relevant government agencies in the future.
Ho said that the government will first launch a sports lottery, then seek more public input on the casino industry issue when local people are more familiar with foreign sporting events.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice candidate clarifies party split rumor
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/07 21:59:53 (By Chou Shih-huei and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, vice presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), clarified Sunday a rumor that the KMT might split while stressing the KMT ticket's resolve to win the March 22, 2008 presidential poll.

Siew made the remarks to reporters on his second-day visit to San Francisco prior to a welcome party hosted by more than 600 "pan-blue" supporters of the KMT ticket pairing Siew with former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
Reiterating that Ma and he himself are determined to win the next presidential election, Siew said that the KMT is also committed to acting as a peacemaker for Taiwan in the international community.

Siew expressed his strong belief that the Taiwan people will pass a correct judgment on the competing tickets, and that the KMT will eventually prove itself to be an indigenous regime by obtaining their approval.
He also rebutted speculation that the KMT might split due to "rifts" among the party's central committee, the Ma-Siew ticket, Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.
"It is to be expected that there will be different viewpoints within a democratic party, " he noted, while describing the rumors as an attempt by ill- intentioned elements to divide the party.

In terms of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Siew made it clear that the KMT stands firm on maintaining the status-quo between Taiwan and China by safeguarding its principles of "no unification, no independence, no military confrontation."

According to Siew, a "strong ROC" must possess a sufficiently strong deterrent capability, be supported by allies like the United States, refrain from preaching Taiwan independence and be committed to democratic values.

Earlier the same day, Siew took part in a national flag raising ceremony in front of the Santa Clara County Government building to mark the 96th Oct. 10 National Day of the Republic of China organized by local ethnic Chinese communities.

Hundreds of ROC expatriates, local U.S. politicians and ROC officials stationed here, including Mark W. P. Liao, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, also took part in the activity.

Siew addressed the occasion and stressed the KMT's determination to safeguard the ROC and the national flag. He encouraged overseas ROC nationals to return to Taiwan and vote for the KMT ticket in the coming presidential poll.
Siew arrived in San Francisco Saturday from Washington D. C. after concluding a three-day visit to the U. S. capital, where he met U.S. congressmen and think tank members.
Siew is slated to stay in San Francisco for three days and will proceed to Canada before wrapping up his 12-day tour to North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military budget to hit 3 percent of GDP next year: minister

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu said Monday that the country's defense budget will hit 3 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) next year, compared to this year's 2.69 percent of GDP.

Lee made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan defense committee meeting in response to queries by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Hong Chi-chang, who concurrently serves as chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, which is responsible for Taiwan's dealings with China in the absence of direct government-to-government contacts.
According to Hong, many military strategic research has shown that the military balance across the Taiwan Strait is increasingly tilted in China's favor.

Amid persistent and continuously growing saber-rattling from China, Taiwan must maintain a strong defense force, Hong said, questioning how the Ministry of National Defense would build a strong deterrent force to tackle ongoing military threats from China, particularly in the coming years which will be critical to Taiwan's future.

Echoing Hong's viewpoint, Lee admitted that the cross-strait military build-up is tilting in favor of China and pointed out that his ministry has been working to build up a new generation of state-of-the-art weaponry to deal with contingencies across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Tightest squeeze on wallets in a decade
Gordon Brown is facing an economic downturn next year as he struggles to recover from the humiliation of being forced to call off an autumn general election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses due to typhoon increase to NT$2.67 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses due to Typhoon Krosa, which battered Taiwan Saturday with strong winds and heavy rains, were estimated at more than NT$2.67 billion (US$80.9 million) as of Monday, according to the latest figures released by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
COA Officials said that agricultural crop losses have been pegged at NT$2.37 billion, with bananas, rice, persimmons, grapes, papayas and star fruit suffering the worst damage.
Livestock and poultry losses were put at NT$1.75 million, mainly because of the deaths of 75 goats, 4,000 chickens and 14,000 ducks.

Losses to fishing facility were estimated at NT$150 million, and to damaged fish ponds at NT$1.16 million. Losses to farm land and facilities were pegged at NT$135.95 million, forestry at NT$4.48 million, while poultry facilities sustained losses of NT$2.52 million.

COA officials said that in line with relief measures for the agricultural sector in times of natural disasters, Miaoli, Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Hualien, Nantou and Tainan counties are eligible for cash subsidies and low-interest loans, while Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Pingtung, Taitung, Yilan counties are eligible for low-interest loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Map brings Britain artist to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Repeated claims that "Taiwan is a part of China", made by Chinese friends after seeing her creation of a China map without Taiwan, encouraged visiting artist Susan Stockwell to gain first-hand experience of the island.

That was what brought Stockwell, a British artist, to Taiwan last week for a three-month stay through the "Taiwan-U.K. International Fellowship Program," an artist-in-residence program run at the Taipei Artist Village.

Stockwell, who has been doing extensive international work, created a paper map of China during her last residency in Nanjing, China. The response from her friends were unexpected, she said, as almost all of them pointed out that she left out Taiwan, but never mentioned Macau and Hong Kong, neither of which were on the map.
Her friends repeated to Stockwell over and over again that Taiwan is a part of China, which made her very angry, she said.

The U.K. Royal College of Art graduate said she had learned a little about China-Taiwan relations before, but the incident dramatically boosted her curiosity. She jumped at the opportunity upon learning an opening at the artist exchange program.
"I think it was fate that brought me here, " she said.

Stockwell will stay in Taiwan until Dec. 22, after which she will present her work in an open exhibition. She plans on visiting old buildings, Taipei's MRT, and computer factories in Taiwan in the coming week as she seeks inspiration before coming up with artistic ideas.

The fellowship program, co-sponsored by the Council for Cultural Affairs and U.K's Visiting Arts and Arts Council England, is entering its third and last year. Seven Taiwanese artists went to United Kingdom while six U.K. artists have come to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Justice Minister Mastella warns of terrorism.
Italian Justice Minister Clemente Mastella warned Sunday that the nation's current political atmosphere would probably lead to the cultivation of a new terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Iraqis Pull Back From Key U.S. Goal
For much of this year, the U.S. military strategy in Iraq has sought to reduce violence so that politicians could bring about national reconciliation, but several top Iraqi leaders say they have lost faith in that broad goal.
The Washington Times: World comes to aid of Kashmir
Two years after a devastating earthquake, Pakistan-controlled Kashmir is on the road to recovery and the region's prime minister says his people owe a large debt of thanks to the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: U.S. Renews Bid to Destroy Opium Poppies in Afghanistan
After the biggest opium harvest in Afghanistanzs history, American officials have renewed efforts to persuade the government here to begin spraying herbicide on opium poppies, and they have found some supporters within President Hamid Karzaizs administration, officials of both countries said.
The Wall Street Journal: Some Warning Flags Fly As Stocks Continue to Soar
The major stock-market indexes set records last week, making up for their late- summer swoon. But other financial indicators are behaving quite differently than they did in July, when the market last peaked, which is fueling some analysts' concerns that the stock market is primed for a drop.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urges early influenza vaccination of high risk groups

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) Monday called for the elderly and children under two years of age to make use of the free influenza vaccine, noting that the number receiving the free shot in the first week of the month slipped by 30 percent compared with the same period last year.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH Centers for Disease Control, said that according to the center's estimate, only 360,000 of those over 65 years of age, or 14.6 percent of the elderly, received the free shots, compared with around 25 percent of 2.4 million elderly who got the free shots during the same period last year.

Of children aged between six months and two years, 19,000 had received flu shots. That figure represents approximately 9 percent of the children in that age group, down from 15 percent during the same period of the year before.
Shih attributed the overall 30 percent decrease of those receiving free shots to reports questioning the safety of the mercury-containing flu vaccines.

He stressed that research has shown that the vaccine, which contains minimal amounts of thimerosal -- an organomercury compound that has commonly been used as an antiseptic and antifungal agent in vaccines since the 1930s -- is not harmful and will be discharged from the human body.

He urged high risk groups -- the elderly and the young children -- to be vaccinated by the end of November to avoid being infected by more serious diseases such as pneumonia, or a complication of influenza.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pushing to raise Paraguayan beef import quota

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the government should consider raising the import quota for Paraguayan beef since it is highly popular on the local market.
Chen made the remarks while hosting a dinner party in honor of visiting Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte.
According to Chen, Paraguay's beef import quota of 440 tons for the year was already used up in April.

After learning that the last batch of Paraguayan beef was reserved for the Oct. 10 National Day reception, Chen said the Presidential Office had to negotiate with the reception's host ministry -- the Ministry of Foreign Affairs -- to get a portion of the beef to serve at Monday's welcoming party for Duarte, which was also held to wish Duarte many happy returns as Oct. 11 marks his birthday.
Chen said he will ask relevant government agencies to evaluate the feasibility of increasing import quota for Paraguayan beef in the future.

Noting that Paraguay is the best bridgehead for Taiwanese businesspeople to tap into the vast market in South America, Chen said the government will continue to encourage them to invest in Paraguay under a co-prosperity program.
To assist in Paraguay's talent cultivation efforts, Chen said the government will continue to offer scholarships for at least 100 Paraguayan students to study in Taiwan annually.

Chen also expressed his gratitude for Duarte's generous support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations. The Paraguayan president has consistently spoken up for Taiwan's U.N. bid in his speeches delivered at the U.N. General Assembly annual session in the past years.
For his part, Duarte stressed the firmness of friendship between Paraguay and Taiwan, saying that bilateral relationship will remain steadfast for good.
Duarte arrived in Taipei Sunday for a five-day state visit, during which he will attend the country's Double Ten National Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 9, or the 29th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: Map brings Britain artist to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Repeated claims that "Taiwan is a part of China", made by Chinese friends after seeing her creation of a China map without Taiwan, encouraged visiting artist Susan Stockwell to gain first-hand experience of the island.

That was what brought Stockwell, a British artist, to Taiwan last week for a three-month stay through the "Taiwan-U.K. International Fellowship Program," an artist-in-residence program run at the Taipei Artist Village.

Stockwell, who has been doing extensive international work, created a paper map of China during her last residency in Nanjing, China. The response from her friends were unexpected, she said, as almost all of them pointed out that she left out Taiwan, but never mentioned Macau and Hong Kong, neither of which were on the map.
Her friends repeated to Stockwell over and over again that Taiwan is a part of China, which made her very angry, she said.

The U.K. Royal College of Art graduate said she had learned a little about China-Taiwan relations before, but the incident dramatically boosted her curiosity. She jumped at the opportunity upon learning an opening at the artist exchange program.
"I think it was fate that brought me here, " she said.

Stockwell will stay in Taiwan until Dec. 22, after which she will present her work in an open exhibition. She plans on visiting old buildings, Taipei's MRT, and computer factories in Taiwan in the coming week as she seeks inspiration before coming up with artistic ideas.

The fellowship program, co-sponsored by the Council for Cultural Affairs and U.K's Visiting Arts and Arts Council England, is entering its third and last year. Seven Taiwanese artists went to United Kingdom while six U.K. artists have come to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military budget to hit 3 percent of GDP next year: minister

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu said Monday that the country's defense budget will hit 3 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) next year, compared to this year's 2.69 percent of GDP.

Lee made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan defense committee meeting in response to queries by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Hong Chi-chang, who concurrently serves as chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, which is responsible for Taiwan's dealings with China in the absence of direct government-to-government contacts.
According to Hong, many military strategic research has shown that the military balance across the Taiwan Strait is increasingly tilted in China's favor.

Amid persistent and continuously growing saber-rattling from China, Taiwan must maintain a strong defense force, Hong said, questioning how the Ministry of National Defense would build a strong deterrent force to tackle ongoing military threats from China, particularly in the coming years which will be critical to Taiwan's future.

Echoing Hong's viewpoint, Lee admitted that the cross-strait military build-up is tilting in favor of China and pointed out that his ministry has been working to build up a new generation of state-of-the-art weaponry to deal with contingencies across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses due to typhoon increase to NT$2.67 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses due to Typhoon Krosa, which battered Taiwan Saturday with strong winds and heavy rains, were estimated at more than NT$2.67 billion (US$80.9 million) as of Monday, according to the latest figures released by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
COA Officials said that agricultural crop losses have been pegged at NT$2.37 billion, with bananas, rice, persimmons, grapes, papayas and star fruit suffering the worst damage.
Livestock and poultry losses were put at NT$1.75 million, mainly because of the deaths of 75 goats, 4,000 chickens and 14,000 ducks.

Losses to fishing facility were estimated at NT$150 million, and to damaged fish ponds at NT$1.16 million. Losses to farm land and facilities were pegged at NT$135.95 million, forestry at NT$4.48 million, while poultry facilities sustained losses of NT$2.52 million.

COA officials said that in line with relief measures for the agricultural sector in times of natural disasters, Miaoli, Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Hualien, Nantou and Tainan counties are eligible for cash subsidies and low-interest loans, while Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Pingtung, Taitung, Yilan counties are eligible for low-interest loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urges early influenza vaccination of high risk groups

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) Monday called for the elderly and children under two years of age to make use of the free influenza vaccine, noting that the number receiving the free shot in the first week of the month slipped by 30 percent compared with the same period last year.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH Centers for Disease Control, said that according to the center's estimate, only 360,000 of those over 65 years of age, or 14.6 percent of the elderly, received the free shots, compared with around 25 percent of 2.4 million elderly who got the free shots during the same period last year.

Of children aged between six months and two years, 19,000 had received flu shots. That figure represents approximately 9 percent of the children in that age group, down from 15 percent during the same period of the year before.
Shih attributed the overall 30 percent decrease of those receiving free shots to reports questioning the safety of the mercury-containing flu vaccines.

He stressed that research has shown that the vaccine, which contains minimal amounts of thimerosal -- an organomercury compound that has commonly been used as an antiseptic and antifungal agent in vaccines since the 1930s -- is not harmful and will be discharged from the human body.
He urged high risk groups -- the elderly and the young children -- to be vaccinated by the end of November to avoid being infected by more serious diseases such as pneumonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pushing to raise Paraguayan beef import quota

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the government should consider raising the import quota for Paraguayan beef since it is highly popular on the local market.
Chen made the remarks while hosting a dinner party in honor of visiting Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos.
According to Chen, Paraguay's beef import quota of 440 tons for the year was already used up in April.

After learning that the last batch of Paraguayan beef was reserved for the Oct. 10 National Day reception, Chen said the Presidential Office had to negotiate with the reception's host ministry -- the Ministry of Foreign Affairs -- to get a portion of the beef to serve at Monday's welcoming party for Duarte, which was also held to wish Duarte many happy returns as Oct. 11 marks his birthday.
Chen said he will ask relevant government agencies to evaluate the feasibility of increasing import quota for Paraguayan beef in the future.

Noting that Paraguay is the best bridgehead for Taiwanese businesspeople to tap into the vast market in South America, Chen said the government will continue to encourage them to invest in Paraguay under a co-prosperity program.
To assist in Paraguay's talent cultivation efforts, Chen said the government will continue to offer scholarships for at least 100 Paraguayan students to study in Taiwan annually.

Chen also expressed his gratitude for Duarte's generous support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations. The Paraguayan president has consistently spoken up for Taiwan's U.N. bid in his speeches delivered at the U.N. General Assembly annual session in the past years.
For his part, Duarte stressed the firmness of friendship between Paraguay and Taiwan, saying that bilateral relationship will remain steadfast for good.
Duarte arrived in Taipei Sunday for a five-day state visit, during which he will attend the country's Double Ten National Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT's VP candidate rapped for 'disgracing' Taiwan's democracy

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew has 'disgraced' Taiwan's democracy by portraying the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led Taiwan as a troublemaker, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.

In a speech delivered at the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council in Washington, D.C. last weekend, Siew claimed that the DPP's incompetence has made more and more Taiwan people skeptical about whether democracy can resolve many of the social and political problems facing Taiwan, according to Shieh.

"Wasn't this kind of accusation echoing the Chinese leadership's rhetoric?" Shieh asked, adding that if Siew has any doubts about the value of democracy, he should bow out of next year's presidential election.

Shieh was even more critical of Siew's allegations that the DPP administration has made Taiwan be viewed as a "troublemaker" in the international community, calling it a "nasty and shameful accusation."
Siew departed Taipei last Monday for a 12-day visit to the United States and Canada as part of his barnstorming campaign tour.
His speech to the audience at the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, which groups American companies with business interests in Taiwan, was titled "Marching Toward a Strong, Steady and Positive Taiwan."
Shieh said Siew was not courageous by failing to state the country's official name, "the Republic of China, " in his speech on such a solemn occasion.
"The KMT has always proclaimed itself to be the faithful guardian of the Republic of China. So why didn't Siew refer to our country by its official title treasured by the KMT?" Shieh asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to go ahead with state-owned banks merger plan: spokesman

TEXT.P: The government will go ahead with its plan to merge three wholly state-owned banks into a holding company, despite a Legislative Yuan motion demanding a halt to the project, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.

Shieh made the remarks a day after the opposition-controlled legislature's Finance Committee passed a motion requiring the administration to suspend its plan to form the Taiwan Financial Holding Co. which will combine the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan and the Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China under one umbrella.
Noting that bank mergers and transformation are under the jurisdiction of the executive branch, Shieh said the legislature can only offer advice or recommendations.

"While the Executive Yuan respects the legislature's power to make suggestions, it will go ahead with the plan to merge and transform the three state-owned banks into a financial holding company," Shieh said.

The motion to put the brakes on the plan was initiated by opposition Kuomintang Legislators Lo Ming-tsai and Alex Fai, who claimed that the government, while working out the merger plan, had not taken bank staff's rights and interests into account. Moreover, they added that the terms of the contract between the new holding company and staff of its subsidiary banks remain unclear and undecided and that the "demise" of the Export-Import Bank will lead to an abrupt halt to export financing for small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs).

In response, Shieh said the lawmakers' concerns about the rights of the bank staff are unfounded. "Since all three banks are 100 percent state-owned, their staff's rights and interests will be fully guaranteed after the banks are transformed into a fully government-controlled financial holding company," he added.

As to concerns about export financing for SMEs after the merger, Shieh said trade financing and export insurance will be taken over by the Bank of Taiwan's relevant departments. Given the Bank of Taiwan's financial strength and experience in corporate banking and international financing, Shieh said, trade financing will be further expanded and become even more accessible to SMEs after the merger.

Shieh further said the statute governing the Export-Import Bank will not be scrapped for the time being. "The Executive Yuan will not seek an annulment of the statute until after the completion of the merger of the three banks," he added.
While screening the Bank of Taiwan's 2007 budget bill earlier this year, the legislature passed a resolution demanding that the Bank of Taiwan be transformed into a financial holding company.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung then announced in mid-August that he had instructed the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to draft an all-encompassing plan to form a Taiwan Financial Holding Co. grouping the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan and the Export-Import Bank of the ROC under one umbrella.
The premier set Dec. 31 as a deadline for the MOF to come up with the blueprint for the merger, which will be carried out in three phases.
According to MOF officials, the planned Taiwan Financial Holding Co., with US$158.8 billion in assets, will emerge as the country's most pre-eminent financial services provider.

The new company will also be the 89th largest financial services company in the world and the 18th largest in Asia, the officials said, adding that the new holding company will have the necessary economies of scale to enable it to boost productivity and broaden and deepen its reach into new markets.
Such expanded capabilities will also help reduce operational costs, maximize utilization of stockholder equity, and optimize risk management, the officials added.
