DOC.HEADLINE: China players condemned for insulting Taiwan players at cyber games

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) condemned China's players in the 2007 World Cyber Games (WCG) Tuesday for verbally insulting and attempting to physically assault Taiwan's participants upon the conclusion of the games in the U.S. city of Seattle over the weekend.

The Chinese contestants did so in protest after Taiwanese player Liu You-chen, who won a bronze medal in the competition, displayed the Republic of China flag while receiving the medal on stage at the presentation ceremony.

MOFA deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said the incident indicates that China's suppression of Taiwan has reached such an extent that Beijing is "almost insane and unselective in the methods it uses, " adding that the Chinese players actions at the cyber games event will only deepen the international community's and Taiwan's resentment against China.
Yeh urged citizens participating in international events to request the assistance of the country's representative offices overseas beforehand if they feel any threat to their personal safety.

In this latest case, officials at Taiwan's representative office in Settle arrived at the scene 15 minutes after the occurrence of the incident to lodge a protest with the organizer and help report the case to the U.S. police, Yeh said.
Also Tuesday, a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers demanded that Chinese President Hu Jintao apologize to the Taiwan people and to the world over the incident.
According to Legislator Wang Sing-nan, Beijing should not mistakenly believe that it will succeed in forcing the Taiwan people to surrender and agree to unification with China by using such means.
"Instead, Beijing should punish the participants to appease the angry Taiwan people," Wang said.

Legislator Wang Tuoh said Beijing has not only humiliated the Taiwan people but has also "disgraced Chinese civilization." He urged the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party to join the DPP in condemning China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 77.34 points to close at 9,639.83.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 9,743.61 and hit the day's low at 9,591.94. A total of 5.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$164.44 billion (US$5.04 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues and construction issues both at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 516, with 238 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 86 points to close at 9,654, with 38,168 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November dropped 91 points to finish at 9,656, with 913 contracts traded, while December futures decreased 77 points to close at 9,673, with 39 contract transactions. March futures moved down 150 points to close at 9,600, with eight contract transactions, while June futures lost 130 points to finish at 9,620, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,740 for October, 9,747 for November, 9,750 for December, 9,750 for March and 9,750 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

October TE futures dropped 1.65 points to close at 399.15, with 3,025 contracts traded, while November TE futures decreased 1.35 points to finish at 399.4, with 56 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures lost 16.6 points to close at 1,086, with 3,402 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 19.4 points to finish at 1,084.4, with 151 contracts traded. December TF futures decreased 11 points to close at 1,094.4, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wholesale vegetable prices drop by 5 percent in Taipei

TEXT.P: Wholesale vegetable prices dropped by 5 percent in Taipei fruit and vegetable wholesale market Tuesday -- the first trading day in the market since Typhoon Krosa swept through northern and northeastern Taiwan Saturday, a spokesman for the Council of Agriculture (COA) said.

The prices decreased from NT$40.76 (US$1.25) per kg last Friday to NT$38.7 on Tuesday, while the volume of vegetables shipped to the market grew to 931 tons Tuesday from Friday's 640 tons, according to COA statistics.
The reason for the price drop is that farmers had harvested crops prematurely ahead of Krosa's arrival out of fear that the storm would destroy their crops, the COA spokesman said.
Wholesale vegetable prices are expected to fluctuate over the next several days, he added.

Typhoon Krosa caused over NT$2.6 billion worth of losses in the agricultural sector, according to the COA, which revealed Monday that it will release frozen vegetable stocks to meet market demand if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate back on campaign trail

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh may have been "on retreat" for the last few days to deliberate on what to do next in his campaign and for the country.
Chang made the remarks after Hsieh delivered a speech by video posted on his campaign Web site Monday following his disappearance from public sight for ten days.

Rumors had been rampant in both the DPP and the opposition camps regarding Hsieh's "disappearance" during the period as it was considered quite unusual, especially during a peak period in campaigning. Many speculated that it might be one of Hsieh's new campaign tactics, while others said they believed that Hsieh was really "exhausted" by the political struggle within his party.

In the video speech, Hsieh said that he was recovering from a foot injury and at the same time pondering Taiwan's future. He said he will reveal his thoughts on important issues after "the political structure of the party is determined." The DPP chairmanship remains vacant since Yu Shyi-kun resigned from the post late last month.

Hsieh pointed out that although he was at home during the last 10 days, he kept up to date on events in Taiwan and the rest of the world by watching television and using the Internet. He said he expressed online his concern for three aboriginal young men who were sentenced to three months in jail Sept. 28 for making off with government-owned windfall timber.

Hsieh further said he also expressed concern for the victims of Typhoon Krosa and sent donations to them, adding that he now sees his good health as a gift from the God and will use it for the welfare of humanity.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.591.
A total of US$977 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.569 and hit a high of NT$32.635.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st Taiwan-developed performing humanoid robot unveiled

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first humanoid robot performer "Janet, " which is capable of speaking, singing and walking, debuted at a news conference on Monday to promote a robot design and manufacturing contest and made a splash.

"Janet" announced on the occasion that the 11th National University and Technical College Creative Robot Design and Manufacturing Contest organized by the Ministry of Education is slated to be held Oct. 19-21 at Cheng Shiu University in the southern county of Kaohsiung.

According to Lin Chi-yu, a professor at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (NTUST) , which developed the performing robot over two years, the university plans to create another robot of the same type named "Thomas" to facilitate interactive performances between the pair.
Lin added that the duo are expected to begin staging their performances for disadvantaged groups beginning next summer on a trial basis in preparation for their future international debut.

He said that although Japanese auto maker Honda created ASIMO, the world's most advanced humanoid robot featuring posture control technologies, it has no facial features or other performance-related functions.

While another robot HUBO, developed by professor Oh Jun-ho at the Korean Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, can display facial expressions, it lacks the capability to stage a show, Lin added.

From the very beginning, the biped walking robot "Janet" was designed and developed with a view to developing interactive and performing functions, Lin said, adding that the state-of-the-art performing technology was created through the concerted efforts of NTUSC and several Japanese robotics labs.

Noting that a total of seven teachers and scores of doctoral and master students at NTUSC are taking part in the development of "Janet, " Lin said that the hardware needed to build the robot has cost NT$10 million.

In addition to "Janet" and "Thomas", the research team will also develop two double-wheeled intelligent robots to join the shows, according to Lin, he added the team plans, in five years, to set up a "Taiwanese robotic theater" in major amusement parks around the world, such as Disneyland and Universal Studios in the United States, to help build Taiwan's high-tech image and boost the country's international profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: President thanks Swaziland for speaking up for Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed gratitude to the Kingdom of Swaziland, one of its African allies, for speaking up for Taiwan's application to join the United Nations at the world body's general assembly.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Swaziland Speaker of the House of Assembly, Prince Guduza Dlamini, who is currently in Taiwan at the head of a delegation for Taiwan's Double Ten National Day celebrations, at the Presidential Office Monday.
Chen also thanked Guduza for the support extended by Swaziland's King Mswati III to Taiwan's efforts to further participate in the international community.

Chen said a medical cooperation protocol between the two countries, signed when Mswati III visited Taiwan for the Taiwan-Africa leadership summit in September, will allow Taiwan to send a medical team at the beginning of next year to reside in Swaziland and provide medical aid on a long-term basis.
A new protocol dealing with cooperation between the countries over the next 10 years will soon take force, to the benefit of Taiwan's solid relations with this African ally, Chen said.

Chen told Guduza and his delegation, that the National Day celebrations of this year will be particularly spectacular as it will include a presentation of the country's military might for the first time since 1991.

Chen also invited Guduza to visit operations of Taiwan's high-tech and communications industries during his stay, hoping that Taiwan's experience in this field will help further Swaziland's economic development.

The Swaziland Congress has established the Taiwan-Swaziland Congress fellowship group, following steps taken by Taiwanese legislators who set up a similar group after visiting Swaziland in July this year, Guduza said, adding that Swaziland will continue to support Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 100 foreign guests to attend National Day celebration: MOFA

TEXT.P: More than 100 foreign friends of Taiwan have answered the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) invitation to take part in the country's celebration of its 2007 National Day, Oct. 10, a spokesman for the ministry said Tuesday.

According to Leo Lee, director general of the MOFA Department of North American Affairs, the VIPs include Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos, Dominican Vice President Rafael Alburquerque De Castro, and Nicaraguan Minister of Foreign Affairs Samuel Santos, all of whom have come to Taipei over the past few days.

In addition, seven political and academic groups from the United States have arrived for the Double Ten National Day celebrations, Lee said, noting that one of these is a delegation from the Republican National Committee.

The foreign guests have been invited to attend a grand military parade slated for Wednesday morning in front of the Presidential Office, and a cocktail party hosted by the government at 4: 00 p.m. that same day at the Taipei Guest House, according to MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon donates NT$200 million to animal project

TEXT.P: Business tycoon Terry Kuo donated NT$200 million (US$6.15 million) Tuesday to National Taiwan University (NTU) for a "love animal" benevolent project to be implemented jointly by the NTU and the Taipei County Government.

Kuo, Hong Hai Precision Industry Co. chairman and one of Taiwan's richest men, signed a memorandum of understanding with NTU President Lee Si-chen and Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei Tuesday morning.

In mid-May a Taipei high school teacher knelt in front of Kuo's company headquarters in Tucheng, Taipei County asking for assistance to help salvage a large number of captured stray dogs that were to be slaughtered by the Taipei County authorities.
According to Kuo, upon learning of the incident, he immediately called Chou while on board a plane and voiced his hope that the Taipei County could shelve the planned slaughter.

However, Kuo said he found it to be a complex matter that must be addressed through adequate legislation, professional evaluations and effective execution after discussing with Chou feasible means of tackling the stray animal problem.

Admitting that the donation was inspired by the teacher's plea, Kuo stressed that it is a positive development for all of society and concerned charity groups. He attributed the forging of the cooperative project to the NTU, the Taipei County and the medical team at the Yonglin Foundation, whose collective efforts have led to the three-way cooperative project.
Kuo also called for charitable organizations to help scrutinize the project and join forces in promoting the project in other cities and counties.

According to Lee, the project personnel plan to spend three years implementing the love animal project and will introduce international top-level training courses for staff and commit to raising public awareness, reducing the number of stray animals and setting up a medical care network for homeless animals.
It is estimated that the Taipei country will have to spend an additional NT$2.1 billion each year to care for stray animals, Chou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group to hold film festival to promote bid to end death penalty

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty will hold a film festival starting Oct. 12 to call public attention to the issue of abolishing capital punishment, officials said Tuesday.

The Murder by Numbers Film Festival, the second of its kind since 2004, will be held to mark the Oct. 10 World Day Against the Death Penalty and to underline the violent nature of the death penalty, according to alliance CEO Lin Hsin-yi.

The festival, scheduled for Oct. 12-14 in Taipei and Oct. 19-21 in Kaohsiung, will feature nine films from Taiwan, Italy, Sweden, France, Denmark, India and the United States, Lin said, adding that the alliance hope the films will help the public better understand the issue.

Liu Ching-yi, president of the Taiwan Association for Human Rights, noted that the issue of a moratorium on the death penalty has been included on the agenda of the ongoing 62nd session of the United Nations General Assembly and that the General Assembly is expected to adopt a resolution on the issue in November.
Liu suggested that Taiwan proactively adopt the human rights values and practices advocated by the United Nations if the country wishes to join the world body.

Wu Chih-kuang, deputy convener of the alliance, pointed out that although Taiwan remains one of the few countries where the death penalty has not been abolished, no executions have been carried out over the past two years, a situation which he said could be taken as the beginning of the end of the death penalty.

Noting that 28 criminals are still on the death row in the country, Judicial Reform Foundation CEO Lin Feng-cheng urged President Chen Shui-bian to officially declare a moratorium on the death penalty and grant amnesty or sentence commutations to criminals under sentences of death.
Lin also suggested that the Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin not sign any execution orders, but rather work to amend related laws to pave the way for the abolition of the death penalty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei wins bid to host World Design Congress 2011

TEXT.P: Taipei has won its bid to host the World Design Congress 2011, defeating the other final competitor, Melbourne, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Tuesday.
Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen is scheduled to call a news conference Tuesday night to officially announce the news, the officials said.

Taipei formally filed an application with the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design (ICSID) in January this year, competing with 19 other cities from 13 countries, for the right to host the 2011 congress.
After several rounds of votes, Taipei and Melbourne were short-listed as finalists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguayan president visits hospital in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accompanied visiting Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos on a visit to a hospital in southern Taiwan Tuesday.

Duarte, who arrived here Sunday to attend the Double Ten National Day celebrations, and his wife took the high speed train to Chiayi county to visit Buddhist Tzu Chi Hospital's Dalin branch, one of the hospitals set up by the Tzu Chi Foundation, the largest charity organization in Taiwan, founded by Master Cheng Yen.

In a briefing to the visitors, hospital superintendent Lin Chun-lung noted that Tzu Chi had its first contact with Paraguay in 1992 when Paraguay and Argentina suffered serious floods after days of heavy rains. Tzu Chi followers in Argentina went to Paraguay for flood relief and their good deeds so touched the hearts of the Chinese expatriates there that they set up a Tzu Chi liaison office in the South American country in 1996.
The volunteers in the liaison office have regularly visited orphanages, nursing homes and provided urgent assistance, as well as set up five elementary schools in impoverished villages, Lin said.
The Tzu Chi hospital in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, also donated a container of medical equipment to the Asuncion University Hospital in 2001.

Noting that Tzu Chi is dedicated to charity missions, medical aid, and the promotion of culture and education, Lin said that it has in recent years expanded its works to include international relief, bone marrow donation, environmental protection and community volunteer works.
After visiting the hospital, Duarte, his wife and their son went to the Janfushan Fancy World in Kukeng township, Yunlin County.
Duarte has spoken up for Taiwan in the United Nations General Assembly on the nation's bid to join the world body for the past five consecutive years since assuming the presidency in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Herbal medicine labels tend to exaggerate effects

TEXT.P: Seven out of 10 herbal medicine product packages examined by the Consumer Reports, a magazine published by Consumers' Foundation, Chinese Taipei (CFCT), exaggerated the medical effects on their labels, CFCT President Cheng Jen-hung announced Tuesday.
The samples were collected by the magazine at grocery stores and supermarkets in the Taipei area this May, Cheng said.

One of the seven exaggerated labels claimed to produce effects that would change one's physical condition and appearance. The other six products were implied to possess body shaping effects, and their labels made claims that the contents can change one's physical appearance, Cheng said.

Cheng asked authorities to inspect the seven products which he claimed to have violated regulations of the Food Sanitation and Management Act and should be fined between NT$30,000 (US$918) and NT$150,000, or have their business licenses suspended if violations are repeated, he added.

Cheng reminded consumers to keep an eye on exaggerated herbal medicine claims and to be careful when choosing products. Products claiming to be able to reduce weight usually contain purgatives such as plantain seed whose effects are only short-lived, and should not be taken without consulting a qualified doctor.

Consumers should consult doctors for directions and information on the effects and side effects of their active ingredients, particularly pregnant women, children, and breast-feeding mothers, Cheng said. He added that consumers should avoid taking western medicine and Chinese herbal medicine at the same time and should stop taking medicines if any adverse reactions arise.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan firms invited to invest in Dominican Republic

TEXT.P: Visiting Dominican Republic Vice President Rafael Alburquerque made an appeal Tuesday for more Taiwanese companies to invest in his country once the country's science park is completed.

Alburquerque, who was here to participate in celebrations of the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day, made the appeal during a visit, accompanied by his Taiwanese counterpart Annette Lu, to several science parks and a free trade zone located in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

Lu hailed the planning and the achievement of a semiconductor and optoelectronics science park constructed by Formosa Plastics Group, adding that it might serve as a model for the Dominican Republic in the planning of its own science park.

Noting that both Taiwan and the Dominican Republic are island countries and that both have maintained solid diplomatic ties for several decades, Lu said she believes that Taiwan's process of high-tech development can be taken as a lesson by the Dominican Republic.

Alburquerque mentioned that the Dominican Republic and Taiwan have been cooperating closely on several projects, and expressed hope that his country's science park will lure more Taiwanese enterprises to invest there.
Taiwan and the Caribbean country have recently concluded the first-round of Free Trade Agreement negotiations, and President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Monday that such talks will proceed rapidly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inbound passengers warned against brining in hairy crabs

TEXT.P: Custom officers have seized 274 kg of Chinese hairy crabs from inbound passengers since Sept. 8, Taipei Customs Office said Tuesday.
The office said in a press release that the crabs, much sought-after by local people, have yet to pass the safety inspection and they could pose danger to health.

If inbound passengers attempt to sneak them into the country, they will invariably be detected by custom officers or X-ray machines, the office said, adding that they detect the hairy crabs every day which end up being destroyed.

Taiwan adopted a stricter inspection criteria to deal with Chinese hairy crabs this year after imported crabs last year were tested and found to contain traces of the banned antibiotic nitrofuran, a cancer-causing substance.

China recently accused Taiwan of adopting too stringent criteria on its hairy crabs, and said that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot reach an agreement on inspection criteria, Taiwan people this year will not be able to enjoy Chinese crabs.
Local crab importers have yet to apply to import the delicacy this year, the Department of Health said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung health officials assist Tainan in combating dengue fever

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County government has sent health officials and quarantine experts to neighboring Tainan City to help halt an expanding outbreak of dengue fever in the run-up to the Oct. 20 opening of the 2007 National Athletic Games in the southern Taiwan city, a county official said Tuesday.
Huang Chih-chung, director of the Kaohsiung County Bureau of Health, made the announcement in his report to the county government during a routine meeting of senior officials.
Huang indicated that the number of indigenous dengue fever cases in Tainan City has reached 477 since the beginning of the year, while Kaohsiung City has recorded 64 cases and Tainan County 32.

Huang said there are five to 10 new cases of dengue fever reported in Tainan City everyday, while Kaohsiung has only reported three confirmed cases of the mosquito-borne disease since the past summer.

Given that dengue fever virus will remain rampant in October, the county official suggested that athletes coming for the upcoming Tainan City games take anti-dengue precautions, noting that a delegation from his bureau is now in Tainan City helping with works to control and prevent a wider outbreak.
The National Athletic Games is a major sports competition at which athletes will be chosen to compete in the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.
Dengue fever is a flu-like viral disease spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes, which often breed in stagnant water close to human dwellings.
The disease usually begins suddenly with a high fever, rash, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, muscles and joint pain, accompanied by nausea, vomiting and loss of appetite.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate to resume campaign soon

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, who has been out of public view for several days, will resume his election campaign schedule as soon as the DPP chairmanship is settled, Hsieh's campaign office spokesman Chao Tien-lin said Tuesday.
The DPP chairmanship has remained vacant since Yu Shyi-kun resigned from the post late last month.

Hsieh delivered a speech by video posted on his campaign Web site Monday in which he explained that he had been ill and needed rest, Chao said, adding that Hsieh has now fully recovered from a cold, although a foot injury described as "serious" will take more to heal.
Hsieh said in the video that he was waiting for a full recovery of his foot and at the same time making use of his convalescence to ponder the nation's future and the DPP's tangled party affairs.
Chao said Hsieh will also reveal the results of his deliberation on important national issues once the DPP chairmanship is decided.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Harbor may lose its volume handling ranking

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor is at risk of losing its No. 6 global ranking in terms of container handling volume after a period of slow growth, according to the latest tallies released Tuesday by the Department of Aviation and Navigation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Department officials said the harbor handled 7.58 million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) of containers in the first nine months this year, an increase of 4.41 percent compared with the same period of last year.

However, the pace of the increase has declined, the officials said, noting that in January and February, the handling volume increased by more than 10 percent, but then declined to less than 7 percent in the next two months, and slipped to less than 5 percent between May and September.
They said the handling volumes of Rotterdam in the Netherlands and Dubai in the United Arab Emirates are fast catching up and that Kaohsiung could be taken over by both of them.

The officials noted that many countries are pursuing harbor development. In comparison, Kaohsiung Harbor has good conditions but many shipping companies have to adjust their navigation routes because there is no direct transport link between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, which they said undermines Kaohsiung's competitive edge.

Kaohsiung Harbor retained third place after Singapore and Hong Kong in container handling volume for many years until slipping to fourth place in 2000. It dropped a further notch to fifth place in 2002 and has been in sixth place from 2003 to 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visiting Paraguayan president receives honorary doctorate

TEXT.P: Visiting Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos has received a honorary doctoral degree in political science from Chinese Cultural University for his long-term contributions to Taiwan-Paraguay diplomatic relations, a university spokesman said Tuesday.
The conferral of the degree was recommended by Foreign Minister James Huang and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai, the spokesman noted.
Since being elected president in 2003, Duarte has promoted economic and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and the South American country, the spokesman said.
Prior to this year's visit, Duarte attended the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations in Taiwan in 1985 as a reporter, the spokesman said.
Duarte also visited Taiwan in 2002 as a presidential candidate and attended President Chen Shui-bian's inaugural ceremony in 2004 as president, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien organic producers to seek Canadian market entry

TEXT.P: Hualien Magistrate Hsieh Shen-san will lead a delegation to Canada Oct. 14 to promote Hualien's organic produce, a county government official said Tuesday.

Tu Li-hua, director of the Hualien county government's Department of Agriculture, said this will be the first time a government agency has presided over a project to export agricultural produce to Canada.
Scenic Hualien County in eastern Taiwan began organic cultivation in 2004 and its products have gained a good reputation and growing popularity among domestic consumers.
According to Tu, Hualien's farmers have just received export orders from Canada for agricultural produce worth NT$10 million (US$308.640).

Tu said that although exports to Canada might not be as good as expected in the initial stage, it represents a good outlet for Hualien's high-quality organic agricultural products after passing Canada's strict produce testing and gaining popularity among Canadian consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei International Electronics Autumn Show opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Electronics Autumn Show opened Tuesday in Taipei, with 2,100 booths manned by more than 1,000 local and foreign companies showcasing energy-saving and eco-friendly electronic products with high quality designs, a spokesman for the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Tuesday.
The show has entered its 33rd year and will run through Oct. 13, said the spokesman.

The show consists of four theme halls aimed at increasing local and foreign buyers' understanding of global accreditation standards for electronic components, new applications of broadband communication technology, the latest trends in electronic security equipment, as well as the Industrial Technology Research Institute's research results in the field, the spokesman noted.

In addition, the show contains a special exhibition area highlighting Taiwan- made products that have won either the logo of "Taiwan Fine Products" or the iF design awards in the last two years, the spokesman said.
The iF award, which has been given annually by the German company International Forum Design GmbH since 1954, is one of the most sought-after prizes in the design industry.
The show also has an additional exhibition area displaying the distinct features of electronic products across the Taiwan Strait, the spokesman said.
He added that Taiwan's electrical and electronic industries have shifted their focus to digitalization, wireless applications, broadband networks, soft electronics and nanotechnology.

This year also marks the first joint collaboration between the show and the Taiwan International RFID Applications Show, as well as the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition, the spokesman said.

The Taipei International Electronics Autumn Show is being held at exhibition halls one and three of the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC), while the Taiwan International RFID Applications Show is also taking place at the TWTC's Exhibition Hall Three, and the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center Oct. 11-12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Syongfong 2e missiles not to be displayed in National Day parade

TEXT.P: The locally developed Syongfong 2e missiles will not be displayed in the military display in the Double Ten National Day celebration rally Wednesday, because it is an attack weapon that can reach Shanghai, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the rally's chief organizer, said Tuesday.

It could be "too sensitive" to display such a weapon of aggression in the military parade, Wang said during a meeting with representatives of Taiwanese expatriates living in New York who were invited to attend the Oct. 10 celebration.

However, the anti-ship Syongfong III missiles, as well as the Sky Bow and Patriot missiles, will be displayed, along with Mirage 2000 fighters, F-16 A/B jet fighters and Indigenous Defense Fighters, Wang noted.
Referring to a planned skydiver display, Wang said the weather conditions will govern whether or not that show can take place.

Speaking of the controversial issue concerning the decoration of the Presidential Office's central tower building, which was hung with a plaque carrying the slogan "Taiwan joins the U.N., " instead of the traditional "Republic of China National Day Celebration, " Wang said that this year is a "special" year and that the host of the official National Day celebration ceremony -- the Presidential Office -- has insisted on the U.N. message.
It is the first time since the seat of the ROC government was relocated to the island in 1949 that the tower building will not be decorated with the placard reading "ROC National Day celebration."
Wang also noted President Chen Shui-bian will not address the National Day rally in front of the Presidential Office.

The message the president wants to deliver to the nation will be expressed in a meeting held within the Presidential Office prior to the rally, despite long observance of the practice of the president addressing the National Day rally, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum petition solicits over 1 million signatures: DPP

TEXT.P: A total of 1,005,670 signatures were solicited during the second phase of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) petition campaign for holding a referendum on the government's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, according to a statement released Tuesday by the DPP.
The press statement said the number of signatures solicited is a big step toward the DPP's referendum threshold of 2 million signatures for the second phase.

The party raised the referendum petition target from the previous 1 million to 2 million people at a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting Oct. 3, in order to make the result better represent Taiwan's determination to hold the referendum and the strong public support.

The statement said the DPP will keep making efforts to reach the projected number of signatures by the end of October, with the aim of letting the public make the decision for Taiwan's future and create a position for Taiwan in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker calls for vote on gambling bill

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called Tuesday for a vote on the opening of casinos on Taiwan's outlying islands within the current session.

Wang made the comments following a meeting with Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa, County Council Speaker Chen Chao-ling, Legislator Lin Ping-kun and local township chiefs, who asked for Wang's support for quick passage of the bill. The Penghu group also paid a visit to the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) later in the day.

Wang said the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus should no longer use the DPP's objection as an excuse to block the bill's passage now that Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT's presidential candidate, has publicly expressed support for the establishment of a gambling industry on the offshore county of Penghu.

The issue has been deferred for too long and now is the time to swiftly deal with it through a vote, since some DPP and opposition Taiwan Solidarity Alliance lawmakers have said they might agree to vote in favor of the bill's passage.

Wang also criticized the DPP administration's intention of allowing the opening of casinos in three central and southern counties on Taiwan proper, calling it an indication of its deep lack of knowledge about the gambling industry.
He urged the DPP administration not to put off the bill any longer with the pretext of a lack of complementary measures.
Pointing to Las Vegas' and Singapore's development experience as examples, Wang said it is "obvious" that the gambling industry must be clustered in a specific area.

He questioned whether visitors would be willing to travel to outlying islands to gamble if the same entertainment were available on Taiwan proper, stripping the outlying islands of economic opportunities.

Admitting that some caucus members have objected to the idea of allowing the opening of casinos on outlying islands, DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien- ming said the party will gauge how to respond to the issue after the bill has been included on the legislative agenda by the Procedure Committee.
"It is too early to discuss the issue, " he said, "because the caucus will have to exchange views with relevant agencies to find common ground."

Later that same day, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that it is unaware of how the Legislative Yuan will deal with the gambling bill but that it will fully respect its authority in this regard.
According to the CEPD, the government will not start to promote the gambling industry until all complementary measures have been put in place.
CEPD Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh said during a legislative meeting the previous day that it is necessary for the government to first acquire social consensus before it begins to promote the industry.

It is extremely important to establish relevant laws and create a sound system before casinos are allowed to be set up, she said, noting that it is the case in other countries that casinos are authorized to open only when related legislation has been implemented and when a supervisory agency has been instituted to regulate the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Signals show that rows over social welfare policy in the ruling center-left coalition are on a positive way. Premier Romano Prodi said that it is very positive if the signals are those of a less agressive attitude.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Chancellor set to take on the 'super-rich' Alistair Darling is expected to take the first step today in a potential crackdown on private equity firms by outlining plans to change the tax relief enjoyed by the industry.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Will focus on economy &
jobsVGMA Faced with another impeachment attempt at the House of
Representatives, President Arroyo yesterday vowed to remain
focused on the economy and ignore the political noise.
The Philippine Inquirer: Stocks hit record high Philippine shares Monday soared to a record high amid a rally in US stocks, cuts in interest rates and the weakening of the dollar.
The Philippine Star: Stocks, peso hit new highs Stocks and the peso rose to record levels yesterday as a deluge of US dollars further buoyed the local bourse and underpinned an upbeat outlook for the economy.
The Manila Times: DepEd violated own rulesVCOA
If the Department of Education has problems addressing the classroom shortage, it's probably because the department prioritized constructing buildings in areas where the need was less acute.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Sprint Nextel's Chief Resigns
Sprint Nextel said yesterday that chairman and chief executive Gary D. Forsee will step down immediately, just two years after directing the $35 billion merger that created the nation's third-largest wireless company.
The Washington Times: GOP hits Hillary's 'baby bonds'
Republican strategists say Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton"s call for giving every newborn $5,000 for education is the first major mistake in her front-running campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Democrats Seem Ready to Extend Wiretap Powers
Two months after insisting that they would roll back broad eavesdropping powers won by the Bush administration, Democrats in Congress appear ready to make concessions that could extend some crucial powers given to the National Security Agency.
The Wall Street Journal: Zoellick Charts Inclusive Course At World Bank
The World Bank's new president, Robert Zoellick, has put an end to a staff insurrection at the bank by styling himself as the opposite of his predecessor, Paul Wolfowitz, a former Pentagon official. Three months on the job, he has become the un- Wolfowitz. Where Mr. Wolfowitz relied on a few recruits from the Bush administration, Mr. Zoellick hasn't hired a single one. While Mr. Wolfowitz froze out bank staff, Mr. Zoellick meets with the bank's 24 vice presidents every morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSE chair warns of Chinese economy's `transitional crisis'

TEXT.P: Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSE) Chairman Wu Rong-i said Tuesday that there is a "transitional crisis" for China's economy, which he claimed is "highly likely" to collapse.
In a speech at the Kaohsiung County Hall, Wu further urged local businessmen to invest in the United States and Europe, which he described as "truly profitable and safe" markets.
According to Wu, Taiwan relies too much on China in terms of investment and trade, which he described as highly risky.
No countries are like China, which allows its economy to develop freely and yet has a tight political control over it, according to Wu.

Describing China as Taiwan's "enemy" with an economy fraught with risk, Wu said Taiwanese businessmen should eye what he claimed are the "profitable and safe" markets in the U.S. and Europe rather than China.

In addition, Wu said the government should ease economic regulations and increase the modernization of laws and regulations to strengthen the country's competitiveness. He also particularly called for an improvement in the legislature's efficiency in reviewing bills.

Describing Taiwan's economy and foreign trade as competitive, Wu said Taiwan ranks 17th globally in terms of total foreign trade value, adding that the country has been "enjoying a trade surplus over the years."
Wu also noted that Taiwan's Gross National Product (GNP) ranks 20th in the world, while Taiwanese people's purchasing power is in 18th place globally.
He said the ratio of foreign stock holdings in Taiwan and that of foreign stock trade are also increasing annually, which indicates foreign investor confidence in the prospects for Taiwan's economy.
He said that as of late July, foreign investors owned 33.67 percent of Taiwan's stock market, which amounts to NT$7.8 trillion (US$239 billion).

Responding to Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing's observation that South Korea, whose national income is half of Taiwan's, now outperforms Taiwan economically, Wu expressed doubt about the reliability of South Korea's economic figures.
According to Wu, Taiwanese people's purchasing power is far ahead of that of the South Korean people, which he said demonstrates that Taiwan enjoys much more stable economic growth than South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for October 10, 2007

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in hisotry

TEXT.P: Today is Wednesday, Oct. 10, or the 30th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announced on Sept. 28 that Oct. 10 is henceforth to be observed as ROC National Day in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising, which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the presidency.
1919: The Chunghua Kemingtang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chungkuo Kuomintang (KMT), also known as the Nationalist Party.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National Government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The U.S. and U.K. governments announce their intention to relinquish extra-territoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National Government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1958: The ROC air force shoots down five mainland MiG-17 fighters and damages two more off the mainland coast, losing one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by U.S. President Richard Nixon to be vice president, resigns before appearing at a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1974: A mass rally of 250,000 celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the Republic of China.

1975: A military parade of 35,000 members of the ROC armed forces and reserves highlight the observance of the 64th National Day of the Republic of China, with more than 13,000 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries joining in the celebration.

1976: A quarter of a million people assemble in the Presidential Square for National Day ceremonies with more than 15,000 overseas Chinese from over 50 countries and areas taking part in events marking the 65th anniversary of the Republic of China.
1978: More than 12,000 members of the Chinese armed forces brave driving rains to stage the largest military parade in many years during National Day celebrations.

1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo accepts the people's gift of 18 F-5E jet fighters with a pledge to recover the mainland at a huge rally attended by 250,000 people to mark the Double Ten National Day.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.

1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person, promising that the ROC will accomplish his ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Pusan, in southern South Korea, killing 292.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.

1999: On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian urges his fellow citizens to strive fearlessly forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights.

2001: A Republic of China Double Ten National Day parade is held at Yokohama's Chinatown, with more than 300 pro-Republic of China overseas Chinese residents and friendly Japanese people participating.
2001: Steven Newman, the Guinness world record holder for the most number of countries traversed on foot completes his 27th conquest when he arrives at the southern-most tip of Taiwan.

2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says in his National Day message that the ROC government has not only strongly condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, but has also supported "all necessary United States actions to fight international terrorism."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man never upholds a man because of what he says, nor does he discard what a man says because of the speaker's character."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan online purchases to top NT$185 billion in 2007: III

TEXT.P: Taiwan's online shopping business is forecast to top NT$185.5 billion (US$5.66 billion) for 2007, the quasi-governmental Institute for Information Industry (III) reported Wednesday.
Taiwan's e-commerce market is estimated to expand to NT$253 billion for 2008, up by 36.4 percent from the 2007 level, said Chou Wen-ching, an analyst with the III's Market Intelligence Center (MIC).

The most popular product on online shopping networks is travel packages, expected to account for 58 percent of total online sales for 2007, Chou quoted the results of the latest MIC survey as indicating.

Computer and information technology products are the second most popular product category, at an estimated 11 percent of the total e-commerce market for 2007, followed by clothes and accessories, beauty and cosmetics products, air and train tickets, and books and m agazines, in that order, Chou said.
Among these categories, beauty and cosmetics products are expected to see the largest growth for the year, increasing 16 percent over the 2006 level, he added.

According to the survey, 53 percent of Taiwan-based online shopping businesses suffered an operating loss in 2005, with the figure declining to 42 percent in 2006. The figure is expected decrease further in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges to continue pushing Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Wednesday that Taiwan will continue its quest to join the United Nations despite its latest setback.

Chen reiterated in his 2007 National Day address that by applying for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan, the country has no intention of challenging Resolution 2758 adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1971, according to which the Republic of China's U.N. seat was given to the People's Republic of China.
He further said that Taiwan also has no intention of competing with the PRC for the right to represent China,
"Resolution 2758 neither defined Taiwan as a part of the PRC nor affirmed the proposition that the PRC has any right to sovereignty over Taiwan, " Chen noted.

Stressing that it is a historical fact and the status quo that Taiwan and the PRC are two sovereign, independent nations, Chen said the PRC has neither the right nor the ability to represent the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Though thwarted, the country's first membership application under the name Taiwan received unprecedented attention this year, with representatives of more than 140 U.N. member states participating in a debate on the issue during the annual session of the General Assembly and media reports on the bid numbering more than four times as many as in the previous year, Chen said.
"This all goes to show that this year's efforts to join the United Nations have been a diplomatic success and have greatly raised Taiwan's visibility in the international community," he said.

Citing the results of a recent opinion survey in which 70 percent of Americans said they would support U.N. membership for Taiwan if a referendum on the issue were passed in Taiwan, Chen said this shows whether the people of Taiwan are united is a factor crucial in whether the U.N. membership bid will succeed.

Meanwhile, Chen again urged the ruling and opposition parties to work together to amend the Referendum Act as soon as possible to address the "absurdity" and "unreasonableness" of the law, such as restrictions on the referendum topics, depriving administrative agencies of the right to initiate referendums, and excessively high thresholds for referendum petitions and passage of referendums.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which is pushing for a referendum on the U.N. bid alongside the March 2008 presidential election, aims to collect 2 million signatures by the end of this month for the party's petition, in the hope that the number can be recognized as a Guinness World Record.

While Taiwan has tried without success to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993, this year marks the first time the country has applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan.

However, following the return of Taiwan's application by the U.N. Secretariat first in July and again in August, an item endorsed by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the United Nations to address Taiwan's membership application was also excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Apparel Convention 2007 to open Oct. 24 in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 23nd annual meeting of the International Apparel Federation (IAF) is scheduled to take place Oct. 24-26 in Taipei, officials of the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) said Wednesday.

The IAF World Apparel Convention 2007 will focus on the theme "Asia - from a global production base to an emerging consumer market" and be held alongside the Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show, the TTF officials said.

Founded in 1972, the IAF is a global association open to entrepreneurs and executives from the apparel chain worldwide. Its membership includes national clothing associations and companies whose core business is sourcing, designing, development, manufacturing, distribution or retailing of apparel products.

The IAF's membership now includes apparel associations from 32 countries representing over 150,000 companies that provide products and services to the apparel industry - a membership that represents over 5 million employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has not lost its place as 'Asian tiger': President Chen

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, quoting domestic and international tallies, said Wednesday that Taiwan is no less impressive economically than South Korea and has not lost its place as one of the "four Asian tigers."

Speaking during his National Day address, Chen said that Taiwan is a success story and that the people of Taiwan should not underestimate or look down on themselves, stressing that Taiwan has never been marginalized or ceased to be one the "four Asian tigers."

In his address to government officials, lawmakers, foreign dignitaries and representatives from all walks of life delivered in the Presidential Office to mark the Double Ten National Day, Chen said that over the past seven years, some people have tried to disparage Taiwan for personal political gain.

Recently, Chen said, they have even repeatedly claimed that Taiwan has lost its place as one of the "four Asian tigers." "I would like to call upon my compatriots to realize that so long as we cherish Taiwan in our hearts, we certainly will not fail to note its presence as an economic power," Chen said.

He said that according to forecasts released by Taiwan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and by the Central Bank of Korea, each country's economy will grow by 4.6 percent for this year; Taiwan's consumer price index will post a rise of 1.5 percent, while South Korea's will rise by 2.5 percent; Taiwan's unemployment rate for the year will be about 3.8 percent, compared to South Korea's 3.3 percent; and the ratio of average incomes in the highest 20-percent and lowest 20-percent income brackets will be 6: 1 in Taiwan and about 8:1 in South Korea.
Quoting the 2007 World Competitiveness Report released by the International Institute for Management Development May 10, Chen said that Taiwan ranked 18th and South Korea 29th this year.

Meanwhile, he said, in the three major indices of the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2006-2007 released in September 2006 -- the Growth Competitiveness Index, the Global Competitiveness Index, and the Business Competitiveness Index -- Taiwan ranked 6th (first in Asia), 13th, and 21st in the world, respectively, while South Korea ranked 21st, 24th, and 25th.

As the aforementioned statistics and rankings demonstrate, Taiwan is no less impressive, economically speaking, than South Korea, Chen said, adding that both nations qualify as "Asian tigers" in terms of overall economic performance, government finances, domestic purchasing power parity, and various competitiveness rankings.
Currently, he said, Taiwan's production values in the important categories of large TFT-LCD flat panel manufacturing, contract IC chip-making, and IC packaging and testing rank first in the world.

As of the end of August, this year's business turnover at Taiwan's three major science parks -- Hsingchu Science Park, Central Taiwan Science Park and Southern Taiwan Science Park -- stood at NT$1.23 trillion (US$37.88 billion). The figure is expected to increase to a record high of NT$2 trillion by the end of the year, Chen continued.

In the future, he continued, this administration will work to accelerate development of and attract investment in the newly expanded facilities of each science park. The government will also work to promote precision machinery, communications electronics, and biotechnology to become Taiwan's third, fourth and fifth trillion-NT-dollar industries, following the semiconductor and flat panel industries.
It is hoped that this will help achieve the goal of balanced industrial and regional development within Taiwan, he said.

"As for the stock market, which reflects our economy's prospects, the Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted index has risen by about 25 percent from the beginning of the year, and the overall value of traded stocks has hit record highs," he said.

As can be seen, far from falling out of the ranks of the "four Asian tigers, " Taiwan has become a leader in numerous high-tech realms, he said, adding that Taiwan has expanded beyond Asia to achieve a global presence. "Given this shining record, I am confident that as long as we keep Taiwan in our hearts and have confidence in the country, it will certainly have high visibility in the world."

Noting that in the past few years, Taiwan-born stars, such as Ang Lee, Chien- ming Wang, Chen Shih-hsin, Chu Mu-yen, Kevin Lin, Chan Yung-jan and Chuang Chia- jung, have had stellar performances on the world stage and continued to bring honor to the nation, Chen said "it is hard to put into words the pride we feel for their outstanding achievements."

At the same time, however, he said, "we feel deep distress when people, for political reasons and in pursuit of power, disparage Taiwan. For in denying Taiwan, they deny all the sacrifices and contributions made by the 23 million people of Taiwan for their nation over the past half century and more."

DOC.HEADLINE: President promises to attend NPC's anniversary next year

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that it is his greatest honor to be invited to attend the 100th anniversary ceremony of the National Press Club (NPC) in the United States after he leaves office next year.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with Peter Hickman, vice chairman of the NPC Newsmaker Committee, at the Presidential Office.
Chen said that it is an invitation to the 23 million people of Taiwan and that he is willing to represent the Taiwan people to take part in the ceremony.
Meanwhile, Chen lauded Hickman's strong belief in democracy and press freedom, saying that three incidents can show that Hickman does not cave in to any pressure from China.
First of all, Chen said, the NPC did not remove Taiwan's national flag from among those of other countries displayed at the NPC's hall as China has repeatedly requested.
Secondly, Chen said that Hickman, facing even greater pressure from Beijing in May, invited him to speak to U.S. press members and academics via a NPC- organized videoconference.

Thirdly, despite mounting pressure from China, the NPC still invited Wang Wenyi, a Falun Gong member, to talk about how the Chinese government oppresses Falun Gong practitioners and particularly how China harvests organs from living Falun Gong members.

Touching upon Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations, Chen noted that there are still many countries that would not support or even explicitly oppose Taiwan's entry into the World Health Organization (WHO) or the United Nations for fear of offending China.

He stressed that the people of Taiwan undoubtedly have the freedom and the right to express their common aspiration for the country to become a member of international organizations and that they should not be deprived of this right.
Chen also said that the Taiwan people have been excluded from the U.N. for 36 years, which he described as "extremely unfair."
In response, Hickman said that China will not be able to achieve its aims by putting pressure on the NPC, adding that he hopes more people from Taiwan can give speeches at the NPC in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally developed next generation laptop unveiled

TEXT.P: A palm-sized laptop touted to be the next generation of notebook was unveiled Wednesday, with its local developers predicting that the device dubbed Micro Tube or MTube, will grab a 1 percent market share in global laptop sales by 2009.

Under the commission of the Executive Yuan's Science and the Technology Advisory Group (STAG) , researchers from the Industrial Technology Research Institute, the Institute for Information Industry, VIA Technologies, Taiwan Television and Accton Wireless Broadband collaborated on the MTube development project, spending nearly one year and some NT$40 million (about US$1.2 million) , STAG members disclosed.

Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching, who is the convener of STAG operations, said the components of MTube are all made in Taiwan, indicating Taiwan's integrated competence in information technology and its edge in the budding industry of micro-sized laptops.
MTube combines the functions of a conventional laptop, personal digital assistant, cellphone and WiMax platform to provide a comprehensive solution for mobile digital service, Lin noted.

After MTube enters mass production in 2009, they hope the annual production can reach 1 million units in the first year, approximately 1 percent of global market share, STAG members said, adding that the price will be less than NT$10,000.
