DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA sets budget at NT$31.56 billion for 2008

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has set its budget at NT$31.56 billion (US$956.36 million) for next year, marking a record high, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Yang Tzu-pao said Thursday.

The budget represents an increase of NT$2.7 billion, or an annual growth of 10 percent, over the NT$28.86 billion budget for this year, Yang said, adding that the increased funds will be mainly used for foreign aid to boost international cooperation. According to Yang, foreign aid will total NT$1.71 billion, or around 0.13 percent of gross national product.

He said the ratio is still lower than the 0.7 percent set as a target by the United Nations, adding that the ministry will continue to push for foreign aid programs taking into consideration the nation's financial situation and foreign diplomatic needs.
Yang made the remarks while delivering a report on the ministry's budget for 2008 at meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee.

He noted that the expenditures of NT$31.56 billion for 2008 will include an open budget of NT$25.78 billion, of which he said NT$11.94 billion will be used for international cooperation programs, marking an increase of NT$1.71 billion over the level for this year.
As for the portion of the budget that will remain confidential, which will total NT$5.78 billion, the funds will chiefly be used to cement Taiwan's ties with its diplomatic allies, he said.
Taiwan currently maintains formal diplomatic relations with 24 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: President set to head to Marshall Islands for leadership summit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is set to depart late Thursday night for the Marshall Islands to attend the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific diplomatic allies.

Accompanied by an entourage comprised of approximately 120 Cabinet members, lawmakers and media representatives, Chen is scheduled to arrive in Majuro Friday morning, after which the president will hold talks with Marshall Islands President Kessai Note and preside over the opening ceremony of an international convention center there, according to the itinerary released by the Presidential Office.

Taking place Friday afternoon will be the leadership summit, where ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will brief participants on the results of the implementation of the Palau Declaration signed during the first summit.

Medical and health cooperation and environmental protection will be two major issues on the agenda of this year's summit, and the participating leaders are expected to sign the Majuro Declaration upon the conclusion of the event.

In addition to Chen and Note, other leaders who are scheduled to attend this year's summit are Kiribati Vice President Teima Onorio, Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr., Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia.

On Saturday, Chen will hold separate talks with Remengesau, Onorio, Scotty, Ielemia and Sogavare, accept interviews by Marshall Islands media and Japan's Fuji Television, have an informal gathering with Taiwan media representatives, meet with Taiwanese expatriates, and receive members of Taiwan's technical corps in the Marshall Islands.
On Sunday, Chen will join Note on a fishing cruise and attend a barbecue before wrapping up his Marshall Islands visit. The president is scheduled to arrive in Taipei that evening.
Taiwan has since 1986 maintained diplomatic relations with the Marshall Islands, a nation with an area of 181 square kilometers and a population of nearly 60,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 57.84 points to close at 9,697.67.
The bourse opened at 9,707.93 and fluctuated between 9,729.47 and 9,661.23 during trading. A total of 5.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$156.88 billion (US$4.82 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 5.9 percent, followed by textile stocks at 3.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.1 percent, construction issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 979 to 880, with 284 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 96 points to close at 9,749, with 32,222 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November increased 100 points to finish at 9,754, with 1,591 contracts traded, while December futures increased 77 points to end at 9,750, with 68 contract transactions. March futures moved up 65 points to close at 9,749, with three contract transactions, while June futures increased 72 points to end at 9,750, with eight contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 9,653 for October, 9,654 for November, 9,673 for December, 9,684 for March and 9,678 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

October TE futures increased 1.45 points to close at 400.6, with 3,447 contracts traded, while November TE futures increased 1.15 points to finish at 400.55, with 126 contract transactions. March TE futures rose 8.6 points to finish at 399.8, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December and June.

October TF futures gained 16 points to close at 1,100.8, with 3,544 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 15.2 points to finish at 1,099.6, with 283 contracts traded. December TF futures increased 3.6 points to finish at 1,098, with eight contracts trading hands. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fair Trade Commission to probe CPC's crude oil purchase costs

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission (FTC) said Thursday that it will conduct an investigation into the crude oil purchase costs of the state-owned CPC Corp. Taiwan.

Commission officials said that they will report on the results of the investigation to the Legislative Yuan in December. Whether the level of recent petroleum price hikes is reasonable will be known by then, they added.

The officials made the remarks at meeting of the Economics and Energy Committee of the Legislative Yuan during which the commission reviewed the budget of the FTC and passed a resolution requesting that the commission
immediately conduct a probe into the CPC's oil purchase costs.

Legislator Wang Tu-fa of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the CPC has raised petroleum prices repeatedly over the past year based on the company's calculations that its crude oil purchase costs have accounted for 80 percent of its operating costs.

Wang claimed that the ratio should only be a little more than 60 percent judging from the CPC's financial statements. If the costs of phasing out old equipment are factored in, then the ratio is less than 60 percent, he said.
Noting that excessive price hikes go against the public's interests, Wang urged the commission to look into the discrepancy between his calculations and those of the CPC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi constructing secondary school in northern Thailand

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation is currently constructing a secondary school in northern Thailand as part of its ongoing efforts to help people in the region, a foundation spokesman said Thursday.
The school is slated to be inaugurated in two years, according to the spokesman for the charitable organization, which is headquartered in the eastern county of Hualien.
The volunteer-based humanitarian foundation launched an aid program aimed at helping the people of the region in 1994, the spokesman said.
Under the program, the foundation has built four Tsu Chi villages to offer agricultural know-how to locals and to take care of those who are unable to make a living, the spokesman noted.

Furthermore, the foundation has provided scholarships to local disadvantaged children, the spokesman said, adding that it also opened a primary school in the region in May, 2005. The school currently has 275 students, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA buying damaged rice to reduce farmers' losses

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has started buying unhusked rice damaged by Typhoon Krosa to help ease rice farmers' financial losses, a COA official said Thursday.

Agricultural losses resulting from Krosa, which swept through northern and northeastern Taiwan Saturday bringing strong wind and torrential rain, have exceeded NT$3.85 billion (US$117.68 million) , the official said, citing the latest statistics released by the COA.

Rice paddies, along with bananas, were the two worst-hit crops. Other crops such as grapes, persimmons, ponkan mandarin oranges, guavas, bell fruit and papayas also suffered serious damage, the official said.
The typhoon also caused losses to forestry production, damage to fishery and aquaculture facilities, and numerous stock and poultry deaths.

Farmers in 11 counties, including Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaoshiung, Hualien, Taitung and Yilan are qualified to apply for government relief aid and low interest loans, while farmers in Hsinchu and Pingtung counties are eligible to apply for low interest loans, the official said.
He added that the COA is continuing to release frozen vegetables and has asked farmers' associations to help farmers with harvests to meet post-typhoon market demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-affected rare seabird set free

TEXT.P: An adult brown booby (sula leucogaster) -- a large seabird of the gannet family -- which was probably affected by Typhoon Krosa and had drifted from eastern Taiwan to the west where it was captured, was released into the wild Thursday.

According to the Society for Wildlife and Nature (SWAN) of Taiwan, the bird was sighted Oct. 8 resting on the deck of a freighter that was anchored in Taichung Harbor on the west coast of central Taiwan.
The harbor authorities notified SWAN about the unprecedented sighting of the rare bird that same day, and specialists from the organization went to the harbor to capture it.
After examining and feeding the brown booby, SWAN specialists found that the bird was exhausted but had suffered no physical injuries. They decided to let it rest for two days before setting it free.
The booby is a rare seabird and there are only nine species worldwide, only one of which appears near Taiwan's east coast.
An adult brown booby reaches about 76 cm in length, with a wingspan of 145 cm. Its head and upper body are dark brown, with the remainder white.
While these birds are typically silent, bird watchers have reported them making occasional sounds similar to grunting or quacking.
The species breeds on islands and coasts in pantropical areas of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans. They also frequent the islands in the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea.
Brown booby pairs may remain together over several seasons. They perform elaborate greeting rituals.

They are spectacular divers, plunging into the ocean at high speed. They mainly eat small fish or squid that they catch near the surface and they can also catch leaping fish while skimming the surface.

Although brown boobies are powerful and agile fliers, they are particularly clumsy in takeoffs and landings -- often an adult bird needs a run-up of 10 meters before it can build up enough speed to take off.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should discard `guise' of Republic of China: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan should stop taking the "guise" of the Republic of China, as the country's sovereign territory covers only Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu but not China.

Chen urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to stop "deceiving" the people of Taiwan and recognize "the fact that the name Republic of China is totally unacceptable in the international community, " noting that the name has been rejected in almost all international organizations, including the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization.
"Don't do things that not even you (the KMT) believe in. Having been cheating for decades, are you going to go on cheating? " Chen asked.

Chen made the remarks during a news conference held ahead of his planned visit to the Marshall Islands, during which he also announced his acceptance of the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

A day earlier, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou accused the DPP of "colluding with the Chinese communists to eradicate the ROC, " after Chen avoided the term ROC in his National Day Address and substituted it with Taiwan.
In defense, Chen said Ma should not have said things that were "inconsistent with history, " claiming that the ROC was toppled by the Communist Party of China rather than by the DPP.

Even the late ROC President and KMT Chairman Chiang Kai-shek, who resumed office in Taipei in 1950 after fleeing from China to Taiwan, admitted that the loss of China to the communists meant the downfall of the ROC, according to Chen.

Chen further challenged Ma to clarify if the ROC he referred to was the one that co-founded the United Nations in 1945, while calling Ma's attention to the facts that Taiwan was a Japanese colony when the ROC was established in 1912 in Nanjing, China and that the ROC Constitution did not include Taiwan when it was drafted in 1946.
"It was the existence of Taiwan that enabled Chiang Kai-shek to continue his regime here under the guise of the ROC. Let bygones be bygones, but we must be very clear as to what we are," Chen said.

Pointing out that as many as 85 percent of the people in Taiwan think the country's sovereignty covers only Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu but not China or Outer Mongolia, Chen called on the KMT to admit the "factual status quo" that "Taiwan is Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Getting referendum on U.N. bid passed `only focus': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that getting a planned referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan passed will be his "only focus" after taking the helm of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The president made the remarks at a news conference during which he announced that he will concurrently serve as DPP chairman.

Chen expressed hope that the DPP-initiated U.N. bid referendum proposal will solicit 2 million signatures, more than twice the required 850,000 signatures, in a show of the will and determination of the public in the quest for U.N. seat. The proposed referendum will take place alongside the March 22 presidential election next year.
He also expressed hope that the proposal will be passed by receiving more than 8 million "yes" votes.

Chen noted that a constitutional reform proposal will have a much higher threshold to be considered passed, as it will require "yes" votes from half of the eligible voters. A referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid will only need half of the voters to turn out and half of them to give approval to be considered passed.

The president said that constitutional reforms, amendments or a new constitution will first require a proposal by three-quarters of the legislators before the proposal can be put to a referendum, which will be considered passed if half of the eligible voters cast "yes" ballots.
As there are no constitutional reform or new constitution proposals in the legislature, it is "out of the question" that there will be any constitutional reform before March 2008, he added.
Chen also described the Referendum Law as "flawed," which he said has hampered the public's rights and freedom to exercise a referendum, adding that the problem needs to be redressed.

But he said redressing the Referendum Law will not affect the DPP-initiated planned referendums on retrieving the ill-gotten assets amassed by the main opposition Kuomintang during its five decades of rule, as well as on Taiwan's membership of the United Nations.
Chen pledged in his 2004 inauguration address that by the time he completes his presidency in 2008, he would hand the people of Taiwan a new constitution that is "timely, relevant and viable."

DOC.HEADLINE: Winners of Da Dun Fine Arts Exhibition to be announced

TEXT.P: The final results of the 12th Da Dun Fine Arts Exhibition, organized by the Taichung city government, will be announced at an award ceremony to be held in the central city this weekend, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday.

Hu said that unlike many other local governments that gave up organizing such art events years ago, the Taichung city government has continued to hold the event and has attracted an increasing number of entries from home and abroad over the years.

Hu said that this year, the exhibition organizer has received a record of 101 foreign art works -- from the United States, Germany, Austria, South Korea, China, India, Singapore, Malaysia, Israel, Paraguay, Honduras, Gambia, Peru and South Africa.
Hu said he will personally announce the top five winners, each of whom will receive a cash prize of NT$200,000 (US$6,116).

DOC.HEADLINE: Local entrepreneurs donate NT$900 million to NTU Hsinchu campus

TEXT.P: Four entrepreneurs have donated a total of NT$900 million (about US$27.6 million) to National Taiwan University (NTU) to fund a project to foster its Hsinchu campus and make it the centerpiece of the nation's biomedical research, university sources said Thursday.

Of the total, NT$150 million came from Etron Technology, a chip-design company; NT$50 million was provided by Health Banks, a company specialized in umbilical cord blood-related technology; NT$350 million was donated by Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. (PSC) ; and the other NT$350 million was offered by an NTU alumnus who refused to reveal his name.
Memoranda of understanding were signed by NTU and three of the four donors on the same day at a press conference in Taipei.
According to NTU, the Hsinchu campus will be established in three stages, with seven complexes to be built in the coming years on its 38 hectare compound.
Meanwhile, the funding provided by PSC and the NTU alumnus will be used to construct two of the seven complexes, NTU officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3,000 attend ROC National Day party in Washington
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 10 (CNA) 10/11/07 17:58:45 (By Lin Chiehyu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Approximately 3,000 people attended a party organized by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington, D.C. Wednesday to celebrate the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day.

ROC Representative to the United States Joseph Wu delivered remarks at the party while standing on stage with several U.S. lawmakers, making it the first time an ROC representative has spoken on such an occasion.
Nine U.S. congressmen, including Republican presidential candidate Tom Tancredo, attended the party and many of them voiced support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.
Tancredo said he hopes President Chen Shui-bian, who gave congratulatory remarks in a pre-recorded video message, could personally attend such parties in the future.

In his video address, Chen lauded Taiwan's economy, culture and democracy, while urging other countries to resist pressure from China and support Taiwan becoming a member of the U.N. and the World Health Organization.

Wu, for his part, described Taiwan as the U.S.'s ninth-largest trading partner, the fifth-largest importer of U.S. farm produce, and the world's 16th-largest economy and said Taiwan should be given the same opportunity as other countries to sign a free trade agreement with the U.S.

Also present at the party were U.S. defense officials, the Washington-based military attaches of El Salvador, Italy and Belgium, as well as American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Managing Director Barbara Schrage and many former AIT officials.
A number of renowned academics from Taiwan and the U.S. also attended.

In Taipei, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs organized a National Day cocktail party that was attended by Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos, Swaziland House of Assembly Speaker Prince Guduza Dlamini and Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos, among 1,000 guests.
Speaking at the gathering, Foreign Minister James Huang thanked the country's friends around the world for backing Taiwan in various forms.
He also said Taiwan is willing to make a greater contribution to world peace and prosperity.
A parade and an evening celebration was also held in the southern county of Yunlin.

More than 30 groups from the Yunlin county government, the local business sector and schools took part in a parade led by Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey, who sang a rap song to promote Taiwan's U.N. membership bid.
It was the first time the southern county had hosted such a large-scale National Day evening party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Think-tank revises economic growth upward to 4.61 percent

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Polaris Research Institute revised upward Thursday its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 from 4.58 percent to 4.61 percent.

The economy is expected to pick up steam slightly this year, benefiting from steadily growing economies in the rest of the world, said Liang Kuo-yuan, president of the research think-tank, at a press briefing.

The rosy prospects have prompted the institute to revise its forecast for the country's economic growth for 2007 upward to 4.61 percent from the 2006 level, slightly higher than the 4.58 percent forecast earlier by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), Liang said.

Polaris predicted that Taiwan's economic growth will reach 4.59 percent for the third quarter and 4.62 percent for the fourth quarter, with the growth for the whole year registering 4.61 percent, Liang added.

Although the country's exports to the United States and Japan have slowed, its exports to China, Europe and Southeast Asia have continued to expand, Liang said, adding that Taiwan's export trade is expected to grow at a rate of 5.87 percent this year, with Q3 and Q4 growth topping 4.69 percent and 7.87 percent, respectively.

On the inflation rate, Polaris predicted that the consumer price index (CPI) will rise by 1.3 percent this year over the 2006 level, mainly as a result of several typhoons that drove up grocery prices, and rising prices of crude oil, commodities and other raw materials on the international market.

Meanwhile, Liang said, the Taipei-based Central Bank of China is forecast to continue to raise domestic interest rates in Q4 in an effort to get rid of the deficit suffered by the financial service sector in Q1 and Q2.

Lower interest rates, in turn, have attracted inflow of foreign funds, shoring up the value of the new Taiwan dollar, Liang said, adding that the currency is forecast to reach a rate of NT$32.5 to US$1 in Q4.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, EVA Airways considering offering flights to Prague

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways -- the country's two largest carriers -- expressed interests Thursday in offering flights to Prague, capital of the Czech Republic, after Taiwan and the Central European country signed an aviation agreement earlier in the day.

Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Billy Chang and his Czech counterpart Jindrich Ploch signed the agreement and CAA officials said that although CAL currently operates cargo flights between Taipei and Prague, it has to apply separately for each individual flight.
With the signing of the formal agreement, the two sides agree to 14 passenger flights per week, with no limit on the number of cargo flights.

There will also be fifth freedom for both passenger and cargo flight services, meaning the right to take on passengers, mail and cargo destined for the territory of another agreeing nation and to put down passengers, mail and cargo coming from any such territory.
CAL is considering cooperating with a Czech air carrier in co-sharing flights in the initial stages and if there are enough passengers, it might open a Taipei- Prague route via Bangkok.
EVA Airways, lured by the extended traffic right, also said it is considering flying the Taipei-Prague route.

EVA Airways announced late last month that it had decided to cancel its Taipei- Paris passenger flight services from Nov. 23 due to increasing operational costs, and to begin cargo-only service on the route in January 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taishang voting army' expected for 2008 presidential election
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 11 (CNA) 10/11/07 19:42:50 (By Chang Ming-kun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Some 220,000 Taiwanese citizens operating businesses in China, known in Taiwan as taishang, are expected to return to Taiwan in March 2008 to cast their votes in the next presidential election, a Taiwanese business leader in Beijing said Thursday.

Chang Han-wen, president of the Association of Taiwan Investment Enterprises on the Chinese Mainland, said his association is planning to help at least 220,000 Taiwanese citizens, including taishang, their Taiwanese staff and dependents, return to Taiwan in the period 10 days before the March 22 presidential election.
The effort is aimed at demonstrating the voting strength of taishang, as only by voting can they make sure their wishes and hopes are valued by the administration in Taiwan, Chang noted.
Chang said he had already contacted airline companies and had been told that 220,000 seats will be available in March 2008 for taishang and their dependents wishing to return to Taiwan to vote.
If more than this number want to vote, Chang said, his association will help make arrangements for additional flights or larger airplanes to satisfy demand.

Asked to speculate on whether most of the taishang will vote for opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, Chang said the taishang are politically pragmatic and that "they will vote for whoever they consider beneficial to them, regardless of the candidate's political persuasion."

DOC.HEADLINE: Police will not conduct household visits with firearms: NPA

TEXT.P: Police officers will not be required to carry firearms while visiting private homes, an official with the National Police Agency's (NPA's) census division said Thursday.

The official was responding to a local newspaper report that policemen will be allowed to carry firearms while conducting what the newspaper claimed are "census visits" to the homes of parolees, known suspects and known criminals under newly revised regulations governing police work.

Quoting unidentified low-ranking police officers, the Taipei-based China Times said that as police officers tend to conduct the so-called "census visits" during their daily patrols -- during which they are obliged to be armed -- the amended police regulations could lead to the scenario in which police officers enter private homes carrying firearms for census surveys.

In response to the newspaper's claims, the NPA spokesman pointed out that the agency has never demanded police officers carry firearms when conducting census visits. In fact, since 1992, the official noted, the police have not even been involved with population registration affairs.
With the evolution of Taiwan's democratic development, the official went on, the police have not needed to conduct census surveys.

As a result, the amended police work rules have enshrined a new mechanism for "selected household visits" to the homes of parolees, prisoners released on commuted sentences and those deemed prone to criminal activity. The legislature passed the amendments June 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sightseeing creates business for Changhua Coastal Industrial Park

TEXT.P: A business model connecting production and sightseeing has created opportunities for enterprises stationed in the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park in central Taiwan, an economic official said Thursday.

According to the official of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the park's annual business turnover for 2006 reached NT$117.8 billion (US$360.24 million).
A combination of production and sightseeing helped to improve the enterprises profiles and images and thus contributed to business performance, the official said.

Two successful examples of the business model are the Taiwan Glass Exhibition Hall operated by Taiwan Mirror Glass Enterprise, and Brand's Health Museum operated by the makers of the popular brand of nutrition preparations. The former has attracted 600,000 visitors since its inauguration two years ago, while the latter draws nearly 50,000 visitors every year, the official said.

Moreover, an up-and-coming human body museum operated by Show Chwan Memorial Hospital in collaboration with the National Museum of Natural Science is believed to have potential for creating more business opportunities for the park.

The park had investments by a total of 306 enterprises as of September this year, up from the 155 in 2002, with total rental land reported as 133.8 hectares. The government's favorable rental policies initiated in 2002 have contributed to the increasing number of companies in the park, the official said.

The MOEA expects the park's business turnover to achieve new highs in the future, with the potential of the sightseeing sector, more production, and the establishment of other facilities such as a glass processing zone and wind power plants, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: British design exhibition shows creativity, commercial success

TEXT.P: A collection of 20 outstanding British designs from various fields are being displayed at Taipei 101 to showcase the United Kingdom's creative industries and highlight their combination of creativity and commercial success.

The exhibition, titled "Love and Money, " features 20 projects and designers that balance business ambition and commercial success with the invention and experimentation for which Britain's creative industries are internationally renowned, said Michael Reilly, Director of British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei.

From Oct. 11-21, design projects of well-known architect Zaha Hadid, the first female architect to win the prestigious Pritzker Architecture Prize, Tom Dixon, Jamie Hewlett, and other design companies and studios will try to showcase the U.K's very best in a number of categories, said curator Christine Losecaat in the opening ceremony.

"British design still values money, which means investment and returns, before emotion, " Hanif Kara, who founded the structural engineering firm Adams Kara Taylor (ATK) , stated matter-of-factly. However, he added, the degree of creativity and quality of production are what differentiates good designs from "just designs."

A series of events will also be held during the exhibition, including an architectural design symposium, a design forum, and a "Pecha Kucha Night" at which invited designers will get together to present and exchange ideas in a casual setting.

The exhibition, which is jointly organized by UK Trade and Investment and the British Council, has been held in Japan, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, and following its visit to Taipei will travel to its last stop Seoul, South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: International symposium discusses `glocalization' developments

TEXT.P: If Taiwan is serious about connecting with the international community, it needs to pay attention to education, the media and the general mentality, foreign representatives said in an international symposium Thursday.

Representatives from Japan, Singapore and South Korea and foreign representatives stationed in Taiwan participated in the two-day symposium organized by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) of the Executive Yuan to discuss "glocalization, " an invented term used to describe the tempering effects of local conditions on global pressures.
As globalization integrates economies and societies around the world, the process has been affected by each country with its own special character, said RDEC Minister Shih Nun-jeh.
Because of this, the government and people should "think internationally, act both internationally and locally" and create an English-friendly environment, Shih added.

Richard Vuylsteke, Executive Director of the American Chamber of Commerce, encouraged Taiwan to welcome immigrants rather than marginalize them. Taiwan's traditional teaching methods should be revised and the media should stop focusing on Taiwan alone, Vuylsteke also suggested in his presentation.

Singapore's approach to glocalization can be summed up with a simple "three pro's" -- pro-growth, pro-talent and pro-harmony -- said Raymond Tan, International Manpower Division Assistant Director of Singapore's Ministry of Manpower.
The keys are to create an investment-friendly environment, attract international talent and maintain cultural diversity and social harmony, Tan explained.

Promoting multiculturalism, which enhances "connectedness, " is essential in the development of glocalization as well as public education, because resistance to immigrants and other cultures can be expected, said Ron McIntyre, executive director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG How hospitals failed to stop spread of superbug that killed 90 in two years
At least 90 patients died and more than 1,100 became infected as hospital managers failed to control the worst outbreaks ever recorded of the super-bug clostridium difficile, a report states today.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Army Offers Big Cash To Keep Key Officers
The Army is offering cash bonuses of up to $35,000 to retain young officers serving in key specialties -- including military intelligence, infantry and aviation -- in an unprecedented bid to forestall a critical shortage of officer ranks that have been hit hard by frequent deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan.
The Washington Times: Visit to N. Korea urged
The South Korean government urged Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice yesterday to visit Pyongyang as a "political boosting measure" to an international deal requiring North Korea to disable its main nuclear facilities by year"s end.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP legislative caucus endorses president assuming chairmanship

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) voiced his support Thursday for President Chen Shui-bian's assuming the role of party chairman, saying that could help secure victory in two key elections early next year.

DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Tuoh and lawmakers, Huang Wei-cher and Hsieh Hsin-ni, called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to display their backing after Chen formally announced his acceptance of the DPP chairmanship earlier the same day.

Chen promised to lead the party to victory in the Jan. 12 legislative election, and pledged to secure victory for the DPP presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang in the March 22 presidential poll so as to maintain the DPP's grip of power.

Wang and the two lawmakers said that they strongly believe that Chen fully weighed how to consolidate different forces within the DPP before deciding to take over chairmanship and that such a move could help forge greater unity between DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and the party central ahead of the legislative and presidential polls.
Chen's return to the party helm will help coordinate and better arrange party affairs and provide an optimal opportunity for Hsieh to closely collaborate with Chen in a critical moment, Wang said.
According to Huang, Chen will definitely do his best to campaign for Hsieh and the party will put forward its best lineup to serve in the election campaign.
Chen first concurrently served as president and DPP chairman from 2002-2004 after coming to power in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate outlines plan to boost employment

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou outlined Thursday a plan to boost employment, pledging to create new jobs and increase income levels for the general public if elected president in the March 22, 2008 presidential poll.

Ma unveiled the economic and employment stimulus program while giving a speech to unveil his vision to reinvigorate Taiwan's economy during an investment forum sponsored by Citigroup Global Markets Ltd.

Ma stated that he is resolved to turn the financial, tourism and health care sectors into the three engines responsible for driving up Taiwan's economy, with average economic growth rates of at least 6 percent per year, an average per- capita income of US$20,000 by 2011 and a jobless rate under 3 percent by 2012.

Complaining that Taiwan's economy and the people's livelihoods have markedly dwindled under the rule of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the past seven years, Ma stressed that he will first act to reform and stimulate Taiwan's financial system with an aim of creating 30,000 jobs in four years and contributing NT$1.3 trillion (US$40 billion) to the gross domestic product.
Secondly, Ma said, he will open Taiwan to Chinese tourists, starting with a daily limit of 3,000 people in the first year, gradually increasing to 10,000 per day in the fourth year.
The entry of Chinese tourists is expected to generate NT$200 billion in tourism revenues by the fourth year of his administration and to create an additional 100,000 fresh jobs within four years.
Thirdly, Ma said Taiwan should quickly jockey for position in the global travel medicine market, which might be worth as much as US$26 billion in 2007.

According to Ma, lifting unreasonable restrictions on service businesses will help sharpen the three engines of Taiwan's economic expansion, the first step in his efforts to develop Taiwan into a dual business operations center, namely, a global business operations hub for Taiwan companies and regional business operations headquarters for foreign concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Childhood myopia on alarming rise

TEXT.P: One-fifth of Taiwan's children suffer from vision problems before they reach 6 years of age, an eye doctor said Thursday.

In a news conference organized by the Bureau of Health under the Department of Health, Lin Lung-kuang, an ophthalmologist with National Taiwan University Hospital, quoted a recently conducted islandwide eyesight survey as finding that 20 percent of first graders in the country are myopic (nearsighted) and 61.8 percent of sixth graders suffer from myopia.
Among the sixth graders who suffer from myopia, 2.51 percent have severe myopia of over 600 degrees, Lin said.

Also speaking at the news conference, Yang Meng-ling, an eye doctor with Taipei Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, said television is the No. 1 culprit responsible for damaging the eyesight of preschool-age children.

Noting that Taiwan has the world's highest per capita number of people with eyeglasses, Yang urged parents not to allow their children to be glued to the TV or use computers for long periods, and to prevent children under the age of 3 from using computers.
Many children are now suffering from shortsightedness by the age of 3 or 4, and the myopic condition increases by 100 degrees a year, Yang added.
Wu Pei-chang, an eye doctor with Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, attributed childhood myopia mainly to the long periods of time that preschool children stay indoors at home.
Wu suggested that parents take their children outdoors more often so that the youngsters will watch less TV and play computer games less often.

He said it is wrong to believe that nearsightedness is a problem that can be tackled by wearing glasses, pointing out that severe myopia can result in a detached retina or glaucoma, as well as eye neural lesions: problems that will damage one's eyesight for a lifetime.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan photovoltaic industry output to hit NT$50 b. by 2009

TEXT.P: The annual output Taiwan's solar energy-related industry will top NT$50 billion (US$1.53 billion) in 2009, rising from a mere NT$7 billion in 2005, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen said Thursday.
Chen made the remarks at the opening ceremony for the 2007 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition, which will last for two days at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Following its successful debut in 2006, the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition has this year expanded in terms of exhibits and number of attendants, with 74 domestic and overseas companies invited and 110 booths set up.

Chen also noted that the linkage between the industry's up- and down-stream has rapidly developed in recent years, with several leading enterprises, including Taiwan CPC Corp., investing heavily in silicon material production and other companies expanding production capacity for photovoltaic components.
On regulatory renewal, Chen said that the government has enforced several key statutes, including the one on promoting renewable energy, to encourage and facilitate the industry's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU urges government to tackle low-end tea imports

TEXT.P: Lawmakers and officials of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the government Thursday to tackle substandard tea imports from China and Vietnam, which they said have seriously affected the livelihoods of Taiwan's growers.
TSU Secretary-General Chien Cheng-shan and Legislator Lai Hsing-yuan issued the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference.

Chien and Lai asked the government to apply additional emergency measures, such as "imposing temporary duty increase on the importation" to deal with the situation, as rampant cheap tea imports from the two countries have dealt a heavy blow to local farmers. The Council of Agriculture (COA) has applied to the Ministry of Economic Affairs for importation relief for local tea growers, they noted.
While the COA has promised to grant monetary handouts worth NT$400 million (US$12.27 million) to local tea farmers, Chien asked when the money will be delivered to them.

According to Lai, it will be Taiwan's first case concerning "temporary importation relief tariff, " and will take only three months for relevant government agencies to implement the measure -- a time much shorter than an eight-month period required for a regular importation relief case.

A "temporary importation relief tariff" can be immediately implemented as long as preliminary documents are available to prove that large amounts of foreign imports have hobbled local industry or business, Lai said.
In response to Chien's query, COA Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching made it clear that local tea farmers will receive the financial aid by the end of this year.

According to Lu Su-wen, a COA's section chief, the Ministry of Finance has been considering whether to impose anti-dumping tax on foreign tea imports, but will probably target only goods from Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Nicaragua to implement FTA next year

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Nicaragua exchanged instruments of rectification Thursday of a bilateral Free Trade Agreement (FTA) signed last year to pave the way for its implementation Jan. 1, 2008.

Taiwan's Economic Affairs Minister Steve R.L. Chen and visiting Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos Lopez exchanged the instruments of rectification in a ceremony held at the Ministry of Economic Affairs in Taipei.
Taiwan and its Central American ally started negotiations on the FTA in August 2004, and signed the pact June 16, 2006, after four rounds of talks.
Chen and Santos exchanged the notes of rectification after both countries' parliaments approved the accord.

After the FTA takes force next year, Nicaragua will allow tariff free entry of 3,374 Taiwanese products, which is about 51.1 percent of Taiwanese exports to Nicaragua, and Taiwan will also lift tariffs on the entry of 5,797 Nicaraguan products, or about 65.6 percent of Nicaraguan exports, including beef and coffee.
The FTA will also pave the way for the free entry of 97.3 percent of Nicaraguan products to Taiwan, and 95.1 percent of Taiwanese products to the Nicaraguan market 10 years after implementation.

The FTA will be beneficial in boosting bilateral trade and investment, technical exchanges and cooperation, Santos said, adding that Nicaragua's location at the center of Central America is convenient for Taiwanese investors looking to expand their investments to other American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enterovirus A 24 confirmed as culprit in pinkeye outbreak

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health confirmed Thursday that an enterovirus is the culprit responsible for the current outbreak of conjunctivitis, commonly known as pinkeye, among elementary students.

CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi confirmed that the enterovirus, known as Coxackievirus type 24, is the culprit in the the current outbreak of pinkeye among elementary students in the northern city of Keelung.

Shih said Coxackieviruses type 24 has been discovered in all samples taken from five of the young pinkeye patients from Keelung, proving that the pinkeye outbreak was related to enteroviral infection.
Shih urged people, particularly children, to wash their hands regularly to avoid being infected with enteroviruses, which can cause pinkeye.
He said that although the pinkeye outbreak has significantly subsided in Keelung, it has not completely run its course, so people should remain alert.
Shih said that since the conjunctivitis outbreak has not been declared an epidemic, the CDC is unable to determine exactly how many people in the country have been infected.
Coxackieviruses previously struck Taiwan in 1985, 1986, 1988 and 1989, but this year's outbreak is the first after a hiatus of 18 years, Shih said.
He added that Taiwan's last outbreak of pinkeye was in the 1970s, and that it was a result of enterovirus type S70.
Pinkeye is a highly contagious disease which can be caused by infections (such as bacteria and viruses), allergies, substances that irritate the eyes, or enteroviral infection.

Shih called for students, particularly young children, and all members of the public to seek medical aid if they are infected with pinkeye -- an inflammation of the conjunctiva, the clear membrane that covers the white part of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids.

To avoid infection, Shih said, kids should be taught to wash their hands often with soap and water. Also, they should not share eye droppers, tissues, wash cloths, towels, or pillowcases with others, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President will nominate independents for grand justice seats: whip

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will nominate competent individuals with no evident political affiliations to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) seats, a legisaltive whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Ker Chien-ming, the top convener of the DPP legislative caucus, made the remarks after Chen said at a news conference earlier in the day that he will refer a new list of four grand justice nominees to the Legislative Yuan for confirmation.
Chen proposed eight nominees for CGJ seats earlier this year, but the opposition-controlled legislature approved only four, vetoing four others in a confirmation vote held late last month.
Noting that he is authorized by the country's Constitution to nominate grand justices, Chen said he will faithfully fulfill that duty.

"With this duty in mind, I'll propose new nominees to fill the four remaining vacancies on the 15-seat Council of Grand Justices, " Chen said at the news conference in which he also announced his acceptance of the DPP chairmanship.

Regretting that opposition lawmakers failed to screen his previous nominees fairly and impartially, Chen said he hopes the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party will drop their bias in the next round of confirmation voting.

Chen, who headed for the Marshall Islands late Thursday to attend a leadership summit with his counterparts from the country's South Pacific diplomatic allies, is expected to refer a new nomination list to the legislature after returning from his overseas trip this Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: President sets off on 4-day visit to Marshall Islands

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian set off late Thursday on a four-day visit to the Marshall Islands to attend the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific diplomatic allies.

In addition to underlining Taiwan's independent sovereign status, Chen said prior to his departure that his South Pacific journey will also show the world of Taiwan's commitment and resolve to help promote stability, prosperity and democracy in the Asia-Pacific region.

Noting that the Marshall Islands visit followed his attendance to various Double Ten National Day celebration activities a day earlier and his announcement of acceptance of the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party earlier in the day, Chen said his hectic work schedule signifies his determination to expand Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers with a can-do spirit.

Medical and health cooperation and environmental protection will be two major issues on the agenda of this year's summit, and the participating leaders are expected to sign the Majuro Declaration upon the conclusion of the event, Chen said.
Accompanied by an entourage comprised of approximately 120 Cabinet members, lawmakers and media representatives, Chen is scheduled to arrive in Majuro Friday morning.

Shortly after his arrival, Chen will hold talks with his Marshall Islands counterpart, Kessai Note, and preside over the opening ceremony of an international convention center in that country, according to the itinerary released by the Presidential Office.

Taking place Friday afternoon will be the leadership summit, where ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will brief participants on the results of the implementation of the Palau Declaration signed during the first summit held in Palau last year.

In addition to Chen and Note, other leaders who are scheduled to attend this year's summit are Kiribati Vice President Teima Onorio, Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr., Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia.

Chen will hold separate talks with Remengesau, Onorio, Scotty, Ielemia and Sogavare Saturday, in addition to accepting interviews by Marshall Islands media and Japan's Fuji Television, having an informal gathering with Taiwan media representatives, meeting with Taiwanese expatriates, and receiving members of Taiwan's technical mission posted in the Marshall Islands.
On Sunday, Chen will join Note on a fishing cruise and attend a barbecue before wrapping up his Marshall Islands visit. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Sunday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 12, 2007

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Nicaragua to implement FTA next year

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Nicaragua exchanged instruments of rectification Thursday of a bilateral Free Trade Agreement (FTA) signed last year to pave the way for its implementation Jan. 1, 2008.

Taiwan's Economic Affairs Minister Steve R.L. Chen and visiting Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos Lopez exchanged the instruments of rectification in a ceremony held at the Ministry of Economic Affairs in Taipei.
Taiwan and its Central American ally started negotiations on the FTA in August 2004, and signed the pact June 16, 2006, after four rounds of talks.
Chen and Santos exchanged the notes of rectification after both countries' parliaments approved the accord.

After the FTA takes force next year, Nicaragua will allow tariff free entry of 3,374 Taiwanese products, which is about 51.1 percent of Taiwanese exports to Nicaragua, and Taiwan will also lift tariffs on the entry of 5,797 Nicaraguan products, or about 65.6 percent of Nicaraguan exports, including beef and coffee.
The FTA will also pave the way for the free entry of 97.3 percent of Nicaraguan products to Taiwan, and 95.1 percent of Taiwanese products to the Nicaraguan market 10 years after implementation.

The FTA will be beneficial in boosting bilateral trade and investment, technical exchanges and cooperation, Santos said, adding that Nicaragua's location at the center of Central America is convenient for Taiwanese investors looking to expand their investments to other American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 12, or the 21st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn today.
1822: Brazil becomes independent from Portugal.
1866: Ramsey McDonald, Scottish statesman and first Labour prime minister of Britain, is born.
1870: Robert E. Lee, Confederate general in the US Civil War, dies in Lexington at the age of 63. He won victories at Bull Run (1862), Fredericksburg (1863), and Chancellorsville (1863), before surrendering to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox in 1865.
1899: The Boer states respond to Britain's despatch of troops to South Africa by issuing a declaration of war, and the British military garrison at Mafeking, under Colonel Robert Baden-Powell, is under siege by Boer forces.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Price for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had profound influence on the development of symbolic ligic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1935: Adolf Hitler bans American jazz from German radio, calling it decadent.
1949: The ROC government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1949: Euginie Anderson is appointed US ambassador to Denmark, becoming the first female US envoy.
1951: Florence Chadwick, US swimmer, breaks the cross-English Channel record with a time of just 13 hours 33 minutes.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a frienship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent after 190 years of Spanish rule.
1968: Omar Torrijos Herrera, a military officer, takes control of Panama and bigins to rule as a dictator.
1971: Dean Acheson, US politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban governdment, deliver a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more UN aid for third world countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilataral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1986: A summit meeting between US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev ends in Reykjavik without any agreement on arms control being reached.
1986: During a display of ROC military power in the "Kuokuang Maneuvers," a combat skills exercise is held at a southern naval base.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: Strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobstrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen arrives in Marshall Islands
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/07 12:08:07 (By Wu Su-jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in the Marshall Islands Friday morning for a three-day visit.
Chen was greeted at the Majuro International Airport by Marshall Islands President Kessai Note and a group of Taiwanese expatriates.
Chen later paid a formal visit to Note at his office, before presiding over the inauguration ceremony for an international convention center in the South Pacific nation.
Set to take place Friday afternoon will be the centerpiece of Chen's current visit -- the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies.

Medical and health cooperation and environmental protection will be two major issues on the agenda of this year's summit, and the participating leaders are expected to sign the Majuro Declaration upon the conclusion of the event.

At the summit, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang is expected to brief participants on the results of the implementation of the Palau Declaration signed during the first summit held in Palau last year.

In addition to Chen and Note, other leaders who are scheduled to attend this year's summit are Kiribatian Vice President Teima Onorio, Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr., Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia.
Chen will hold separate talks with Remengesau, Onorio, Scotty, Ielemia and Sogavare Saturday, before wrapping up his visit and heading home Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Taipei mayor's corruption trial at high court opens

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High court opened Friday the corruption trial of former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who was indicted in February for allegedly embezzling public funds but later acquitted by the Taipei District Court.
Before entering the courtroom Friday morning, Ma reiterated that he is innocent and that he expects the high court to handle the case based on the principles of justice and fairness.

Ma, who is the opposition Kuomintang's candidate for next year's presidential election, was indicted by Taipei prosecutors Feb. 13 for allegedly embezzling NT$11 million (US$335,365) from his special mayoral allowance during his time in office between 1998-2006.

However, the Taipei District Court acquitted him on Aug. 14, accepting that it was a matter of convention that officials enjoyed considerable flexibility in dealing with their special allowance funds. The court ruled that Ma had no intention of embezzling any public funds.
The Taipei District Prosecutors' Office decided Aug. 17 to appeal the ruling.
On several DPP heavyweights, including Vice President Annette Lu and former DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, also being indicted Sept. 21 on similar charges, Ma said his heart goes out to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern science park's sales hit record high for July-Aug.

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park posted NT$100.39 billion (US$3.08 billion) in sales for July and August, the highest level ever recorded by the park for a single two-month period, according to tallies released Friday by the park.
The amount marked an increase of 13.26 percent over May and June and a rise of 40.33 percent over the same two-month period last year, Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration officials said.
For the first eight months of this year, the park's turnover topped NT$330 billion, or 63.71 percent of the target set by the park for 2007, the officials said.
They attributed the park's brilliant performance in July and August to the strong growth momentum of the semiconductor and photonics industries.

Owing to the robust market demand for thin film-transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) products, the photonics manufacturers in the park posted sales of NT$72.77 billion for July and August, up 52.11 percent year-on-year and accounting for 72.49 percent of the park's total turnover for the period, the officials said.
For the eight months to August, the photonics manufacturers in the park posted sales of NT$239.25 billion, up 19.98 percent year-on-year, the officials said.

Meanwhile, seasonal demand in the contract chip making market boosted the total sales of the semiconductor manufacturers in the park to NT$22.99 billion for July and August, up 11.01 percent year-on-year and accounting for 22.91 percent of the park's total turnover, they said.
For the first eight months of the year, the semiconductor manufacturers in the park posted sales of NT$76.16 billion, marking an increase of 3.5 percent year- on-year, the officials said.

Precision machinery manufacturers in the park registered sales of NT$3.44 billion for July and August, up 68.04 percent year-on-year, and of NT$11.89 billion for the first eight months of the year, up 66.77 percent, marking the largest increase in sales among all manufacturers in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate challenges KMT rival to debate on U.N. bid issue

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh invited his opposition Kuomintang rival, Ma Ying-jeou, Friday to take part in a debate against him on the issue of holding a nationwide referendum on the country's bid to enter the United Nations.

Hsieh, who appeared in public for the first time in 14 days on Friday, said at a news conference that he challenges Ma to a debate in order to find out whether Taiwan's bid to "enter" the United Nations under the name Taiwan -- as promoted by President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling DPP -- would be more realistic or whether Ma's idea of pushing for the Republic of China's "re-entry" into the world body would be more feasible.
DPP Legislator Lai Ching-teh welcomed Hsieh's challenge to Ma, saying that such a debate could help the country arrive at a consensus on the U.N.-bid referendum issue.

Lai said the Hsieh-Ma debate would also help members of the general public understand more about the two candidates' differing stances on the issue and also help them make the right decision when they cast a ballot in such a referendum.
Lai, however, expressed concerns that Ma might not have "the guts" to face Hsieh in a debate on the issue.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Kao Chien-chih said that the issue of whether the country should apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan or apply to re-enter the organization under the name "Republic of China" is an important issue but that he thinks Ma is pushing for the U.N.-bid referendum simply for the sake of winning votes in the upcoming presidential election.
Claiming that "in Ma's campaign, China is the manager," Kao said the Taiwan people have the right to demand that Ma clarify his stance on the issue in a debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
NTU to engage in student exchanges with Oxford, Cambridge: sources

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) could begin a student exchange program with the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge in September next year, NTU sources said Friday.

The sources said that NTU President Lee Su-chen, NTU Office of International Affairs Director Sheng Tung, as well as the deans of NTU's Colleges of Liberal Arts, Science, Social Science, Medicine and Engineering visited eight prestigious universities in Britain and France early this month in a bid to promote cooperative relations.
During the visit, NTU reached an initial agreement with the two British universities on student exchanges from next September.

It has been learned that the University of Oxford proposed research cooperation with the NTU on the subject of "Austronesian culture" while the University of Cambridge is keen on research cooperation on the subjects of Taiwan and China.

The sources also said that if the NTU can send students to the two British universities, it will be significant, noting that the University of Cambridge has so far only had a student exchange program with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wholesale vegetable prices surge in Taipei market

TEXT.P: Wholesale vegetable prices rose to NT$44.52 (US$1.37) per kg Friday from NT$41.82 the previous day in the Taipei market, for an increase of 6.46 percent, according to the Taipei Agricultural Products Market Corp. (TAPMC)

Anticipation among vegetable traders of a declining supply in the wake of Typhoon Krosa's devastation in early October was blamed for the price hike, TAPMC officials said, noting that wholesale vegetable prices broke the record high set after Typhoon Sepat hit the island in mid-August.
It might take a long time for the vegetable producing areas to recover for the devastation brought by Typhoon Krosa, the officials said.
The TAPMC reported that 831 tons of vegetables were shipped to the greater Taipei area Friday, and that leafy vegetable prices saw the largest increase.

The wholesale price of spring onions rose to NT$390 per kg and that of bok choys increased to NT$100 per kg, according to the TAPMC report. It also revealed that prices of zucchini, bitter gourds, tomatoes and sweet peppers are higher than usual at this time of year when the production season for these types of vegetables is coming to an end.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 201.2 points to close at 9,496.47.
The bourse opened at 9,677.33 and fluctuated between 9,731.16 and 9,490.01 during trading. A total of 5.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$153.32 billion (US$4.7 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 2.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.3 percent, textile stocks at 2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent, and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 386, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 297 points to close at 9,450, with 55,618 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November dropped 285 points to finish at 9,466, with 5,184 contracts traded, while December futures decreased 269 points to close at 9,481, with 91 contract transactions. March futures moved down 269 points to close at 9,480, with 19 contract transactions, while June futures lost 250 points to finish at 9,500, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 9,747 for October, 9,751 for November, 9,750 for December, 9,749 for March and 9,750 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

October TE futures moved down 12.5 points to close at 388.05, with 3,823 contracts traded, while November TE futures dropped 12.7 points to finish at 387.85, with 321 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures lost 49 points to close at 1,050.8, with 5,415 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 50.6 points to finish at 1,049, with 684 contracts traded. December TF futures dropped 42.8 points to close at 1,055.2, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chen solicits support for his WEO advocacy
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/07 16:08:43 (By Wu Su-jou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian solicited support from Taiwan's South Pacific allies Friday in his campaign for the establishment of a World Environment Organization (WEO) under a United Nations framework.

Chen, who arrived in the Marshall Islands Friday morning for a three-day state visit, called for presidents of the Marshall Islands, Palau, Kiribati, Nauru, the Solomon Islands and Tuvalu to write U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon and other U.N. member countries to jointly push for the establishment of the WEO to ensure our species' sustainable development and survival.

Addressing the opening of the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies, Chen said that the adverse impact of civilization on the environment has reached an immeasurable level, and that the impact will grow still more severe in the future.

In the past, he said, militarily powerful nations conducted nuclear tests in the South Pacific; now, industrially advanced countries discharge excessive amounts of CO2 into the atmosphere, causing global warming, climate change, and as a result the sea levels to continue to rise, threatening low-lying Pacific islands.

The consequences of such environmental abuse not only pose developmental dilemmas for South Pacific nations, including the six maintaining formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, but also pose a severe threat to these countries' sustainable existence, Chen said.

He reiterated that the world now needs a global organization capable of realizing the ideals of environmental protection, of integrating the powers of various countries, and of uniting every nation, without exception, to solve these problems.

Noting that he first launched his campaign in May this year calling for the establishment of a WEO, Chen said he would like to take the opportunity of the leadership summit to once again push for advocacy of the program, which he said would also be a reflection of the spirit and goals championed by Palauan President Tommy Remengesau in his "Micronesian Challenges" published in 2005.

Consequently, Chen said, he keenly looks forward to the presidents of Taiwan's South Pacific allies writing to Ban and leaders of all U.N. member countries to push for the establishment of a WEO to benefit the sustainable development and continued survival of the world's people.

DOC.HEADLINE: No punishment for handing out U.N. bid promotional items: official

TEXT.P: There will be no punishment of military police officers who handed out promotional items concerning Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations during the official National Day ceremony held earlier this week, a Presidential Office spokesman said Friday.

According to Chang Kung-han, deputy director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, the military police officers "did nothing wrong" and should not be blamed for their actions because seeking membership in the United Nations is one of the government's main policies.
However, the Presidential Office respects the decision by the National Day ceremony's organizing committee to recall the items, Chang said.

During the National Day ceremony held Wednesday in front of the Presidential Office, some military police officers in charge of maintaining order were found to be handing out to participants items such as U.N. bid fliers and inflatable thunder sticks printed with the "U.N. for Taiwan" logo.

Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who chaired the ceremony's organizing committee, ordered a recall of the items immediately after being informed of the situation, on the grounds that the items belong to a list of seven kinds of articles forbidden at the ceremony, namely large backpacks, sticks and clubs, knives, loud speakers, balloons, umbrellas and long-lens cameras.
Some opposition legislators have demanded that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) investigate the matter and punish the responsible military police commander.

Asked to comment on the issue Friday, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the items promoting the U.N. bid should not be treated as ordinary promotional items because joining the United Nations is official government policy.

However, in light of the attention that the incident received, the Cabinet will have the authorities concerned look into it, the premier said, adding that he has no idea if it was the Presidential Office which ordered that the promotional items be handed out.
Meanwhile, Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu said there is no need to mete out punishment if the military police commander is without fault.

Asked whether the one who gave the order, or the one who carried it out should be held responsible, Lee said it is "hard to reach a conclusion" because the scene where the incident took place was not directly under the control of the MND.

DOC.HEADLINE: China invited to East Asian Special Olympics tournament in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, China, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/07 17:17:10 (By Kuo Mei-lan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Special Olympics Chinese Taipei (SOCT) will invite athletes from East Asian countries and areas to take part in a table tennis tournament to be held in Taipei next year, SOCT Chairman Pai Hsiu-hsiung announced Friday.

Pai, a former deputy mayor of Taipei City, made the announcement in Shanghai ahead of his departure for home at the end of his trip to Shanghai, during which he attended the 2007 Special Olympics World Summer Games Oct. 2-11 in his capacity as the leader of the Chinese Taipei team.
Pai said table tennis aces from East Asian countries and areas, including China, Macau, South Korea, Japan and Singapore, are welcome to take part in the Special Olympics tournament.
Pai told CNA that the Chinese Taipei team won 33 gold medals in the competitions, which he pointed to as a praiseworthy achievement.
Special Olympics are sports events for athletes with intellectual disabilities.
The Chinese Taipei team took two separate flights to return to Taiwan Friday. The first group of athletes and trainers scheduled to arrive at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at 8:30 p.m.
