DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-funded convention center in Marshall Islands inaugurated
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/07 17:54:56 (By Wu Su-jou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian cut the ribbon at the inauguration ceremony for a Taiwan-funded international convention center in the Marshall Islands Friday.

Chen said that Taiwan, as a staunch partner of the Marshall Islands, will do its best to help the South Pacific nation develop, saying that "a true friend is one who stands by you when you most need help."

Linhu Jung-ta, the ROC ambassador to the Marshall Islands, said that after two years of planning, construction began on the convention center in March, which was completed with a total cost of US$5 million.
Chen, who arrived in the South Pacific nation Friday morning, paid a formal visit to Marshall Islands President Kessai Note to exchange views on a wide range of issues of mutual concern.
Sources said that Note reaffirmed the importance of his nation's diplomatic relations with Taiwan, saying he welcomed Taiwan's continued investment in the nation.

Note was appreciative of Taiwan's assistance in medical care, outlying island transportation and agricultural technology, and expressed hope that more Taiwanese businessmen will take part in the nation's development projects, especially in the tourism sector.
He also said that his nation supports Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

After the bilateral meeting, the two presidents joined Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr., Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia and Kiribatian Vice President Teima Onorio in walking to the convention center.
Chen presented a larger-than-life key to the building to President Note, symbolizing the ROC's donation to the Marshall Islands.

Chen congratulated the government and people of the Marshall Islands on the multi-functional convention center, saying that it was appropriate that it serve as the venue for the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies, which will take place in Friday afternoon.
The leaders then toured the Taiwan and Marshall Islands product exhibitions in the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel laureate feels honored to be member of Pontifical Academy

TEXT.P: Lee Yuan-tseh, former president of Academia Sinica, said Friday via his secretary that he felt honored to be appointed by Pope Benedict XVI as an academician of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences, one of Europe's most prestigious academies.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, asked his secretary to transmit the message while en route to the United States from Japan.

Also named as member of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences by the Pope Thursday was German physicist Klaus von Klitzing. The academy now has 80 academicians, with more than 20 of them Nobel laureates.

Lee, born in Hsinchu, Taiwan, in 1936, has gained world renown for his research on the crossed molecular beam technique. Lee is the fourth ethnic Chinese academic to receive the honor of being appointed to the Pontifical Academy of Sciences, following Lee Tsung-dao and Yang Chen-ning, both are Nobel laureates in physics, and rice expert Chang Te-tzu.
After graduating from National Taiwan University in 1959, Lee entered the University of California at Berkeley as a graduate student in 1962.
After receiving his Ph. D in Chemistry from UC Berkeley, Lee was invited to work as professor for the university.
Lee returned to Taiwan in 1994 to serve as president of Academia Sinica. He retired from the academy in 2006.

According to Lee's secretary, Lee has been dedicated to international affairs and the promotion of scientific education in Asia and the Middle East during the last few years. Lee said he will continue his efforts in this regard in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Average of 30 workers die in rooftop falls each year in Taiwan

TEXT.P: An average of 30 workers die in falls from roof tops every year in Taiwan, according to tallies released Friday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
Incidents in which workers fell to their deaths after accidentally crashing through the roofs accounted for the greatest number of fatalities at 72 percent, CLA officials said.

Thirty-five workers have lost their lives in such accidents so far this year, including recent cases in which workers fell to their deaths while repairing roofs damaged by typhoons, the officials said.
They attributed the increase in such accidents to the popular use of light materials such as asbestos and plastics in roofing, and urged construction workers to take proper precautions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improving English proficiency an uphill battle for Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan's education system is facing enormous challenges in improving the English proficiency of Taiwanese students, and it takes a lot more for the government, schools, teachers and students themselves to achieve the goal, panelists said in a symposium Friday.

While the craze to learn English in Taiwan continues to grow, Taiwan's education system has to work to improve overall proficiency from a wide range of angles, from college and university to preschool, said Vincent Chang, a professor at National Taiwan Normal University.

The fashion for getting an early start in English learning has caused Taiwanese parents anxiety and set high expectations, Chang said. However, an insufficiency of qualified English teachers, the "One nation, different practices" phenomenon, and variety of textbooks have all hindered efforts to improve English proficiency, he said.

The bi-polarity phenomenon was even more alarming, Chang claimed, as the results of the Basic Competence Test (BCT) showed two distinct groups of students, one performing exceedingly well while the other shows little or no English ability.
This phenomenon reflects the gap between urban and remote areas in terms of the availability of resources and English-teaching staff, Chang said.

Taiwan was not alone as South Korean government had been also making efforts to improve South Koreans' overall English proficiency and launched a program of reforms in recent years, said Park Jun-eon, a professor at Soongsil University.

The measures taken in those reforms include intensive re-training of in-service English teachers, upgrading the recruiting standard and strengthening communicative English education, Park said, adding that the Korean government established 'English experience areas', as well as Web sites and television channels dedicated to English-learning.

"Language is a process. It's not something you learn instantly, " said Doris Brougham, founder and chief executive officer of Overseas Radio and Television, whose English-teaching career spans 55 years in Taiwan. Brougham is also the publisher of several popular English-learning magazines in Taiwan.
It takes motivation for anyone to learn and improve English, and the best motivation is need, Brougham said.
The symposium, which focused on the theme of globalization, was organized by the Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic issues should be debated first: KMT candidate

TEXT.P: Responding to ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh's challenge to a policy debate, opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said if a debate indeed takes place, economic issues should be the first issue discussed.
Ma, who was in a Taipei courtroom Friday answering the questions of Taiwan High Court judges, responded to Hsieh's challenge in a statement announced by his aides.

Hsieh, who appeared in public for the first time in 14 days on Friday, said in a news conference earlier in the day that he challenged Ma to a debate in order to learn which would be more feasible: Taiwan's bid to "enter" the United Nations under the name Taiwan -- as promoted by President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling DPP -- or Ma's idea of pushing for the Republic of China's "re-entry" into the world body.

In reply, Ma said he is quite disappointed with what Hsieh had said in his news conference. According to Hsieh's logic, Ma said, what the country's name should be is more important than issues regarding the people's livelihood and welfare.

According to Hsieh's logic, the country's name is more important than reviving the sagging domestic economy, spiraling unemployment, the deepening government budget deficit and education, Ma noted in the statement.

Ma said that during Hsieh's "14-days in solitude, " he might not have become aware that the ranking of the container handling capacity of Kaohsiung Harbor has dropped to sixth in the world from third, a position it held before the DPP took power in 2000, and that the Standard & Poor's Rating Service local and regional government rating for the Asia-Pacific in 2007 named Taiwan and Fuji as the only two of 22 regional sovereign entities to receive negative scores.

Quoting former U.S. President Bill Clinton from his successful 1992 presidential campaign against George H.W. Bush, that "It's the economy, stupid, " Ma asked Hsieh to focus his attention on the economy and people's livelihood.

Ma said that after visiting local communities around the island over the past several months, he has become aware of the people's plight, which is entirely derivative of the poor economic situation, adding, "the people could care less about whether the country should be called the 'Republic of Taiwan.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar on UK architecture held in Taipei

TEXT.P: Taiwan is eager to learn from the British experience with regards to balancing creativity, the public interest and commercial success in architectural design, a Taiwan official said Friday in a U.K. Architecture Design seminar.

The seminar -- a part of the "Love and Money" exhibition featuring 20 projects of Britain's best design and promoting the U.K. creative industries -- has gathered architects and designers from Taiwan and the U.K. to discuss future trends in architectural design.

"The title of 'Love and Money' is intriguing because, traditionally, people tended to think that it's very difficult for creativity, culture, sustainable development and public interests to co-exist with financial and commercial success, " said Charles Lin, Director of Taiwan's Construction and Planning Agency.

A budget of more than NT$420 billion has been in the plans for Taiwan's infrastructure for the next five years, said Michael Reilly, Director of the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO). Reilly said he hopes that the experience of British designers will be beneficial to their Taiwanese counterparts.

British architects and designers are sharing with seminar attendees their approaches to engineering and strategies on how to design with a difference. Speakers included Hanif Kara, an engineer who founded the Adams Taylor Kara structural engineering company, and architects Benjamin Warner and Simon Blore.
The Love and Money exhibition is being held in Taipei Oct. 11-21.

DOC.HEADLINE: One imported malaria case confirmed in Kaohsiung City

TEXT.P: A mechanic working in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, is confirmed to have contracted malaria, according to a news release issued by the Kaohsiung City Bureau of Health Friday.
The news release said that the man caught the disease during a business trip to Guinea in West Africa in the period between late-August and Oct. 2.

The patient sought medical treatment at a hospital in the city's Nantzu district Oct. 8, after falling ill with a fever, frequently breaking out in a sweat, and suffering headache, stomach ache, vomiting and diarrhea. Laboratory tests confirmed Wednesday that the illness was malaria, according to the news release.

The patient, now in a stable condition, is being treated at the hospital, said bureau officials, adding that no family members or other people close to the patient have so far shown any sign of infection.

Officials indicated that the patient fell ill after being infected by mosquito bites. In Taiwan, there are mosquitoes of the kind that bit the man in Africa, however, officials said those mosquitoes live in mountainous areas and usually do not appear on the flats, and urged the public to remain calm because there is little chance of being infected by the vector-born disease on the island.

Taiwan was certified by the World Health Organization in 1965 as a malaria-free area. Nevertheless, the island reports around 30 imported cases of malaria annually from other countries in Southeast Asia, Africa and Oceania, according to the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health.

Malaria causes symptoms, including anemia, fever, chills, nausea, flu-like illness, and in severe cases, coma and death. Malaria transmission can be reduced by preventing mosquito bites through the use of mosquito nets and insect repellents, or by mosquito control measures such as spraying insecticides inside houses and draining standing water where mosquitoes lay their eggs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA solicits investment from third-largest polysilicon producer

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has promised to fully assist Renewable Energy Corp. (REC) , the world's third largest polysilicon producer, if it decides to invest in Taiwan, according to MOEA Minister Steve R.L. Chen.
Chen made the remarks Thursday during a meeting in Taipei with Erik Thorsen, president and chief executive officer of the Norway-based supplier of silicon and components to the solar energy industry.
Thorsen was invited to deliver a keynote speech at the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum that opened Thursday.

REC is planning to build a factory in East Asia due to the inconvenience of transporting raw polysilicon materials to the region, Chen said, adding that the company is also optimistic about the prospect of the optoelectronics industry in the region.
REC will dispatch a special task force to Taiwan, South Korea, China, Singapore, Malaysia, and other countries in the region next week to determine the best location to build the factory, Chen noted.
It will take the company three to four months to make the final decision, Chen went on.

During the meeting with Thorsen, Chen gave a briefing on the current state of development of Taiwan's optoelectronics industry, saying that if REC invests in Taiwan, it will benefit from Taiwan's prosperous information technology (IT) industry.

During the meeting, Chen also said that the government is determined to boost the local optoelectronics industry and that it has provided many incentives in an effort to attract foreign polysilicon manufacturers to Taiwan.

Taiwan also has complete optoelectronics industry clusters, which would help REC cut its costs, according to Chen, who also added during the meeting that Taiwan's local colleges and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) have produced an abundance of human resources.
At present, Chen said, the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau has already established a one-stop window to help REC better understand Taiwan's situation in the field.
He also said that the CPC Corp, Taiwan (CPC) , a state-run oil company, and Formosa Plastics Group (FPC) have expressed their intentions to develop a joint venture with REC.

FPC Chairman Lee Chih-tsuen confirmed Thursday that FPC did hold talks with REC over the possible collaboration and that REC once sent staff members to visit FPC's factory site in Mailiao in the southern county of Yulin.

However, Lee said that FPC insists on using a new technology to produce solar- grade silicon wafers, which he claimed is much faster than traditional methods and results in an output that is 10 times higher than normal.
Such a cooperative venture, if realized, would make REC the first polysilicon producer in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to extend compulsory education by 2011

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that compulsory education will be extended to cover children aged 5 by 2011.

Chang said the government has already begun work to carry out the policy in three stages. He made the announcement at a legislative interpellation session in response to an inquiry by Legislator Huang Shih-cho of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Huang said Taiwan is faced with a population crisis, with a decline in the number of children per family. Taking Taipei City as an example, he said the number of children enrolled in elementary schools totaled 170,000 in 2006, a drop from 190,000 in 2001.

The Taipei city government has assessed that the number of first-grade students will further drop by 37 percent in six years in the city, Huang said, warning that if the trend cannot be reversed, at least 20 elementary schools around the country will not be able to recruit any students within six years.
Extending compulsory education to cover kindergarten-age children has been proposed as a strategy to help resolve the plight of school facilities left idled or unused.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recalled infant cold medicines not imported into Taiwan: DOH

TEXT.P: Fourteen infant non-prescription cold medicines recently recalled in the United States have not been imported into Taiwan, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Friday.
Liao Chi-chou, director of the DOH Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, made the remarks after several U.S. drug manufacturers announced the recalls.

According to the results of a report issued by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention early this year, at least 1,500 children under the age of 2 suffered from complications after taking non-prescription cough and cold drugs.

In addition, U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) statistics show that at least 54 reported cases of child death involved the use of decongestant and another 69 cases involved the use of antihistamine. Both medicines can be used to relieve runny or stuffy nose associated with a cold.
According to Liao, there are no problems with the medicines per se, adding that the problem stems from overdosing.
Liao noted that in the U.S., there are non-prescription medicines that can be easily purchased by the public at supermarkets.
As a result, American infants aged under 2 are often found to have been given excessive amounts of such drugs, Liao went on.

In Taiwan, Liao went on, the DOH has not approved the sale of any cold medicine for children under the age of 3 and he suggested that children under the age of 3 be taken to hospital if they catch a cold.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's South Pacific allies support its U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 12 (CNA) 10/12/07 21:16:28 (By Wu Su-jou and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The heads of state of Taiwan and its six South Pacific allies issued a joint declaration Friday in which they expressed their support for Taiwan's right to join major world organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO).

President Chen Shui-bian and leaders of the Marshall Islands -- the host of the summit -- Palau, Kiribati, Nauru, the Solomon Islands and Tuvalu, signed the declaration after attending the second Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit held in Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands.

In the joint declaration, the leaders recognized Taiwan's achievements in democratization and economic development, and Taiwan as a sovereign country whose right to participate in international organizations should not be deprived.

The leaders hailed Chen's idea of promoting the Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit and expressed gratitude to the Taiwan government in implementing cooperation projects announced at the first such summit held in Palau last year, which were designed to promote the sustainable development of Taiwan's allies in the South Pacific.

Taiwan has sent 16 mobile medical teams to its Pacific allies during the past year, helping 15,000 residents in the region, the declaration said, adding that Taiwan has promised to station permanent medical missions in the region and will study the idea of setting up a "long-distance health care assistance and consulting system" with its Pacific allies.

As climate change has had a harsh impact on the environment and threatens the lives of people of island nations, the leaders agreed to push for the establishment of the World Environment Organization (WEO) , a brainchild of Chen, to combine international efforts in tackling environmental problems.

Taiwan also promised to help its Pacific allies train law enforcement personnel, including environmental protection personnel, assist them reduce the digital divide, send volunteers there to teach children in need, and help Pacific ally students pursue advanced studies in Taiwan, according to the declaration.

In consideration of the cultural similarity between Taiwan's aboriginal people and the people of Pacific countries, the leaders support the establishment of a headquarters of Austronesian culture in Palau to promote the research and preservation of the culture, the declaration said.

The third Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit will be held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, in 2008, as the original organizer -- Solomon Islands -- said it did not have enough time to organize the summit, according to Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Chang Siao-yue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Confirmed dengue fever cases in Tainan city break 500 mark

TEXT.P: The Tainan city government reported Friday that the number of confirmed cases of dengue fever has broken the 500 mark and now stands at 511, making it the city's worst ever outbreak of the disease.

City government officials said they discovered clusters of infection dengue fever infection in individual households in both northern and eastern parts of the city and urged the public to be on guard.

With the National Athletic Meet due to open in the southern city next week, the Tainan city government has pulled out all the stops to eradicate the mosquitos and ensure the safety of participating athletes.
Health officials also urged the public to remove any containers of standing waters that could serve as breeding grounds for the disease-bearing mosquitoes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon-caused agricultural losses hit NT$4.3 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses resulting from Typhoon Krosa have reached NT$4.3 billion (US$131.6 million) , with 12 counties and cities entitled to financial aid and low-interest loans offered by the central government, according to statistics released Friday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
Krosa swept through Taiwan Oct. 6, bringing strong wind and torrential rain.
Rice paddies were the worst-hit crops. Other crops such as bananas, grapes, persimmons, ponkan mandarin oranges, guavas, bell fruit and papayas also suffered serious damage, according to the COA.

The COA statistics also show that losses in fishery production have amounted to NT$42.14 million, with NT$10.8 million-worth of damage to forestry. Damage to fields and agricultural facilities have exceeded NT$163 million, while that of fishery facilities have reached NT$195 million, according to the tallies.

Farmers in Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Hualien, Taitung, Pingtung and Yilan are qualified to apply for government relief aid and low interest loans, while farmers in Hsinchu County and Tainan City are eligible to apply for low interest loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA collaborating with Japan to fight eel fry smuggling

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) is collaborating with Japanese law enforcement authorities to fight eel fry smuggling, CGA Minister Wang Jinn-wang said Thursday.

Wang said during a legislative session that as the smuggling of eel fry is expected to reach a peak before the high season for eel fry begins from the end of October to next February, the CGA and the Maritime Safety Agency of Japan (MSAJ) are stepping up joint efforts to stop the practice.

He said that with acute shortages of eel fry in China due to overfishing and poaching, fry smuggled from Japan is especially popular in Taiwan's aquaculture industry, prompting the CGA to apply stricter measures to deter smuggling.

He added that the collaboration is in addition to the "An Kong" operation, a campaign to step up a crackdown on the smuggling of farm produce and fishery products launched Nov. 1 last year by the CGA and 10 other agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior.

The CGA has always maintained close cooperative relations with the MSAJ in information exchange, Wang said, citing a successful raid in April in which a Taiwanese fishing boat was detained by the MSAJ on suspicion of smuggling eel fry in waters off Ishigaki island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture.

The two agencies also apprehended a Taiwanese fishing boat allegedly carrying amphetamines near Miyako island in Okinawa, Wang said, adding that with the same cooperation, law enforcement officials in Myanmar and Malaysia have seized a large haul of contraband drugs in two trafficking cases.

The CGA is also working with police authorities in the United States, Thailand and Hong Kong to control the growing problem of drug trafficking and drug- related crime and strengthen information exchanges and cooperation, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT presidential candidates urged to debate on major issues

TEXT.P: A parliamentary watchdog urged the presidential candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday to debate on major policy issues immediately in response to public expectations.

The Taipei Society, which is mainly composed of academics, made the appeal after DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh invited his KMT rival, Ma Ying-jeou, to debate the planned referendums on Taiwan's U.N. bid.

Hsieh noted that the DPP wants to hold a referendum on the nation's U.N. bid under the name Taiwan, while the KMT wants to hold a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. membership under its official name, the Republic of China, or any other "pragmatic name." Hsieh challenged Ma to debate on which referendum initiative is more feasible and to let public opinion decide the result of the debate, with the loser retracting his proposal.
Ma, in response, said the real problem lies with the economy and that if Hsieh wants a debate, then economic issues should be given priority.

The Taipei Society said in a statement that the 2008 presidential election will be a race between Hsieh and Ma, but the society claimed that for months, the media has been centered on the vice presidential candidates, the lawsuit against Ma over his alleged misuse of his "special allowance fund," and the probe into irregularities in Kaohsiung's MRT system allegedly involving Hsieh during his tenure as Kaohsiung mayor.
The society said these issues do not incite the
passion of the voters and that there are many major issues in the 2008 presidential election that need to be addressed.

The presidential candidates should debate such issues as whether the country should pursue eventual unification with China or independence; the checks and balances against the president, the premier and the legislature; and how to break through China's obstruction and establish diplomatic relations with more countries, as well as how to join international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor to help Malawi athletes attend 2009 World Games

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu pledged Friday to help Malawi athletes attend the World Games, slated to take place in the southern port city in 2009.
Chen made the promise during a meeting with Esther Mcheka Chilenje Nkhoma, the first deputy speaker of Malawi's National Assembly, and three female Malawi lawmakers.
Saying that she will give money to allow Malawi athletes and Chilenje to attend the games, Chen expressed appreciation to Malawi for strongly supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.
Meanwhile, Chen noted that Kaohsiung has attached great importance to ecology and environmental protection during its transformation from a heavy-industry city to a trade-and-tourism city.
She said she hopes Kaohsiung can have "a clean and natural environment like Africa."
Chen said that in Taiwan, women have equal opportunities to men to participate in politics, pointing out that the vice president and one-quarter of the Cabinet are women.

In response, Chilenje said that there are limited opportunities for Malawi women to take part in politics. However, she said she believes female lawmakers often pay more attention to social problems related to children, women and minority groups.
Chilenje expressed a wish to establish collaboration with Kaohsiung to learn more about the city's experience in developing heavy industry.
Chilenje also thanked Taiwan for offering aid to Malawi and reiterated the country's staunch backing for Taiwan's U.N. membership bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: New alliance to be formed to campaign for Myanmar democracy: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Friday that a new alliance will be formed Saturday to campaign on behalf of pro-democracy forces in Myanmar.
Lu made the remarks while attending a human rights concert on Green Island off the coast of the eastern county of Taitung.
Also present at the concert were political victims who were imprisoned on the island by the previous Kuomintang (KMT) government during its 55 years of authoritarian rule.

Lu said more than 30 social groups have expressed willingness to join the alliance, adding that in the future, a "democratic development study program" will be established, with foreign youths doing study in Taiwan, particularly the 3,000-plus Myanmarese students in Taiwan, as main targets.

Speaking to reporters, Lu showed a camera she said was a gift from the Japanese video reporter Kenji Nagai, who was recently shot dead by a soldier in Myanmar while filming a bloody military clampdown on anti-government protests staged by civilians and Buddhist monks.

Lu said she received the gift at an international conference she called in Japan in 1992 to announce a trip she had been planning to make to China. She planned to lead a group of Taiwanese people to attend a National Day ceremony in Beijing to see if China would treat them with goodwill.

At the news conference, Lu went on, Nagai gave her the camera as a lucky charm for her safety in China and said he had used it to take many photos of Aung San Suu Kyi, a pro-democracy activist and 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner who has been under house arrest over the past decade after winning a popular election.
Lu said she failed to enter China and was sent back to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Friendly ties with China critical to Taiwan's U.N. bid: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that if Taiwan hopes to achieve success in its bid to join the United Nations, it must spare no efforts to develop friendly relations with China.
Wang made the remarks in a speech at Shih Hsin University in suburban Taipei.

Taiwan should boost its ties and exchanges with China to achieve normality in the hope that the two sides might offer reciprocal assistance in various fields and pave the way for the elimination of long-term misunderstandings and hostility between the two sides, Wang said.

If Taiwan fails to improve its relations with China, its future U.N. membership applications -- which China has successfully blocked from inclusion on the agenda of the annual U.N. General Assembly session since 1993 -- will be certainly thwarted again by China.
This is certain, as China is a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, which is tasked with processing membership applications, Wang noted.

He also urged the government to seek more support from Taiwan's diplomatic allies and encourage them to speak up for Taiwan in future sessions of the U.N. General Assembly, saying that Taiwan should also seek support from other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, including the United States, France, the United Kingdom and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: National pension system to be implemented Oct. 1, 2008: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that a much-anticipated national pension system will be put into practice Oct. 1, 2008, creating a social security mechanism for disadvantaged people who currently lack any pension benefits.
Chang made the remarks in a speech delivered at an evening party marking the 42nd founding anniversary of the Christian Tribune News, a local newspaper.

Noting that the national pension system will cover some 3.5 million people who currently lack any pension benefits, Chang said the new mechanism, coupled with the national health insurance program that has long been in place, will contribute to the establishment of a fair and just society.

The Legislative Yuan passed the National Pension Act in July, making it possible for people aged 25 to 65 who are not covered by military, civil service, teachers or labor insurance programs, as well as farmers under the age of 65, to join the program.

They will be required to pay a monthly contribution based on a percentage of the national minimum wage. Contributions will be calculated on a graded scale ranging from 6.5 percent to 12 percent of minimum wage.

After retirement at the age of 65, contributors would receive a pension of up to NT$8,986 per month for the rest of their life, a figure that will be adjusted in line with changes in the consumer price index.

Given the current minimum wage of NT$17,280, a monthly contribution of 6.5 percent of the minimum wage would amount to NT$1,123, of which a citizen will pay 60 percent, or NT$674, per month, while the government will cover the remaining 40 percent.
After 40 years, the total amount contributed by the citizen would be NT$515,082, while the payout would amount to NT$1.83 million over 17 years, calculated on an average lifespan of 82 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 13, 2007

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 13, or the third day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son from a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India, to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 B.C.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, becomes one of the three co- winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian hails the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature to self-exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
2001: The rampancy of counterfeit bank notes in circulation in Taiwan prompts the Central Bank of China (CBC) to add two items on its Web site's home page to teach the public the different ways to distinguish fake bills from real ones.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Genocide bill spurs Turkish envoy's recall.
Turkey recalled its ambassador to Washington on Thursday and denounced as "unacceptable" a congressional panel's vote declaring theearly 20th century slaughter of Armenians by Ottoman Turks a genocide. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times U.N. climate body, Gore awarded Nobel
Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore and the U.N.'s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) won the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for their efforts to build up and disseminate knowledge about man-made climate change and to lay the foundations for fighting it.

Lu said more than 30 social groups have expressed willingness to join the alliance, adding that in the future, a "democratic development study program" will be established, with foreign youths doing study in Taiwan, particularly the 3,000-plus Myanmarese students in Taiwan, as main targets.

Speaking to reporters, Lu showed a camera she said was a gift from the Japanese video reporter Kenji Nagai, who was recently shot dead by a soldier in Myanmar while filming a bloody military clampdown on anti-government protests staged by civilians and Buddhist monks.

Lu said she received the gift at an international conference she called in Japan in 1992 to announce a trip she had been planning to make to China. She planned to lead a group of Taiwanese people to attend a National Day ceremony in Beijing to see if China would treat them with goodwill.

At the news conference, Lu went on, Nagai gave her the camera as a lucky charm for her safety in China and said he had used it to take many photos of Aung San Suu Kyi, a pro-democracy activist and 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner who has been under house arrest over the past decade after winning a popular election.
Lu said she failed to enter China and was sent back to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Friendly ties with China critical to Taiwan's U.N. bid: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that if Taiwan hopes to achieve success in its bid to join the United Nations, it must spare no efforts to develop friendly relations with China.
Wang made the remarks in a speech at Shih Hsin University in suburban Taipei.

Taiwan should boost its ties and exchanges with China to achieve normality in the hope that the two sides might offer reciprocal assistance in various fields and pave the way for the elimination of long-term misunderstandings and hostility between the two sides, Wang said.

If Taiwan fails to improve its relations with China, its future U.N. membership applications -- which China has successfully blocked from inclusion on the agenda of the annual U.N. General Assembly session since 1993 -- will be certainly thwarted again by China.
This is certain, as China is a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, which is tasked with processing membership applications, Wang noted.

He also urged the government to seek more support from Taiwan's diplomatic allies and encourage them to speak up for Taiwan in future sessions of the U.N. General Assembly, saying that Taiwan should also seek support from other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, including the United States, France, the United Kingdom and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: National pension system to be implemented Oct. 1, 2008: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that a much-anticipated national pension system will be put into practice Oct. 1, 2008, creating a social security mechanism for disadvantaged people who currently lack any pension benefits.
Chang made the remarks in a speech delivered at an evening party marking the 42nd founding anniversary of the Christian Tribune News, a local newspaper.

Noting that the national pension system will cover some 3.5 million people who currently lack any pension benefits, Chang said the new mechanism, coupled with the national health insurance program that has long been in place, will contribute to the establishment of a fair and just society.

The Legislative Yuan passed the National Pension Act in July, making it possible for people aged 25 to 65 who are not covered by military, civil service, teachers or labor insurance programs, as well as farmers under the age of 65, to join the program.

They will be required to pay a monthly contribution based on a percentage of the national minimum wage. Contributions will be calculated on a graded scale ranging from 6.5 percent to 12 percent of minimum wage.

After retirement at the age of 65, contributors would receive a pension of up to NT$8,986 per month for the rest of their life, a figure that will be adjusted in line with changes in the consumer price index.

Given the current minimum wage of NT$17,280, a monthly contribution of 6.5 percent of the minimum wage would amount to NT$1,123, of which a citizen will pay 60 percent, or NT$674, per month, while the government will cover the remaining 40 percent.
After 40 years, the total amount contributed by the citizen would be NT$515,082, while the payout would amount to NT$1.83 million over 17 years, calculated on an average lifespan of 82 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President urges Kiribati to set up embassy in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/07 12:09:05 (By Wu Su-jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Saturday that the Kiribati government led by President Anote Tong will establish an embassy in Taiwan soon.

Raising the issue during talks with Kiribati Vice President Teima Onorio in the Marshall Islands, Chen said he is confident Tong will win his Oct. 17 re- election bid in light of Tong's popularity among his people and the overwhelming victory of Tong's Pillars of Truth party in an August parliamentary election.
Chen asked Onorio to help relay an invitation to Tong to visit Taiwan at some point between late 2007 and early 2008.

According to Chen, Kiribati was the first country to forge diplomatic relations with Taiwan during his presidency, and he said he cherishes very much the ties between the two countries and his personal friendship with Tong.

Noting that Kiribati is the place on which the first daylight falls each day, Chen said he had decided to use a picture of him watching the sunrise in Kiribati that was taken during his last visit to the Pacific nation in 2005 on his 2008 New Year greeting cards.
Chen said the use of the picture will be a show of his hopes for Taiwan, adding that he hopes the move will also be helpful to boosting Kiribati's tourism industry.

Onorio expressed her gratitude to Taiwan for its assistance in promoting Kiribati's development and pledged to continue to support Taiwan's bids to join international organizations, including the United Nations.
Onorio also said she is deeply impressed that Chen has overcome numerous challenges with courage and determination during his presidency.
The talks were held on the sidelines of the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its Pacific allies that was held Friday in the Marshall Islands capital of Majuro.

In addition to Onorio, Chen was also scheduled to hold talks with Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr., Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Philippine Inquirer:
"I go down, You go down", says house speaker JDV of President Arroyo
They have decided to keep the ruling coalition intact, if only to avert what one of their political allies earlier warned of -- the possibility of "mutually assured destruction."
The Philippine Stsr: Rizal landfill re-opened
Averting a possible garbage crisis, Rodriguez Mayor Pedro Cuerpo yesterday ordered the reopening of the 14-hectare Montalban sanitary landfill.
The Manila Times: House adds P30B to social services
The House of Representatives added P30 billion to social services, when it passed on second reading the proposed P1.227-trillion national budget for 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Stowaway on SIA flight from KL hides in nose wheel well.
Changi Airport had an unexpected passenger drop in on it on Thursday night - he fell out of the nose wheel well of a Singapore Airlines aircraft that had just landed.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Enhance economic connection between China and S'pore by common culture base: Wong Kan Seng.
The first Singapore Season in China kicked off on Friday evening in Beijing to extend beyond arts and culture. Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng said Chinese enterprises could use Singapore as a springboard for their global business strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid will help Taiwan emerge from China's shadow: president
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/07 14:37:41 (By Wu Su-jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that Taiwan is a sovereign state independent of China and that trying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan will help the country emerge from China's shadow.
Chen made the remarks during an informal gathering with Taiwanese media during a visit to the Marshall Islands to attend the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its Pacific allies.

According to Chen, the Pacific leaders taking part in the summit have expressed their approval for Taiwan's move to use the name Taiwan to apply for U.N. membership, because they generally agree that the strategy will help bypass the obstruction set by Beijing's "one China" policy.

Chen claimed the situation has proven wrong a notion held by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that the country must use the name Republic of China, but not the name Taiwan, to rejoin the United Nations, in order to secure the country's relations with its diplomatic allies.

"Don't cheat our people any more. If we continue using the name Republic of China, we cannot be sure how long our ties with our diplomatic allies can last. Instead, using the name Taiwan will help us find a way out," Chen said.

Chen recalled that in 2005, he held talks with Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty in the Marshall Islands that were crucial in that they paved the way for the restoration of Taiwan-Nauru diplomatic ties -- which were cut in 2002 soon after he assumed the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Chen said it was China's aggressive move to woo away Nauru with the purpose of embarrassing him and Taiwan that prompted him to publicly declare Aug. 3 that year that Taiwan and China are two separate countries on each side of the Taiwan Strait.
He said Taiwan must not continue downgrading itself by clinging to a "one China" policy that agrees Taiwan is part of China or claiming Taiwan and China belong to one country awaiting unification.
"Taiwan is Taiwan and China is China. Taiwan is definitely a sovereign state, not part of China," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's future more important than economic issue: president
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/07 15:16:39 (By Wu Su-jou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that Taiwan's future and its orientation are "absolutely more important" than the issue of the nation's economy.
The president made the remarks to reporters in Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, where he attended the second leadership summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies the previous day.

The president dismissed the idea of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) using the economy as the focus of the 2008 presidential election, noting that opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has made the issue the centerpiece of his election campaign.

Ma cited former U.S. President Bill Clinton's successful 1992 campaign catchphrase "it's the economy, stupid! " when he was challenged by DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh to debate planned referendums on Taiwan's U.N. bid Friday.
Chen said the KMT used the economy during its 2004 presidential campaign and said "there is nothing new in its repetition."
Chen said that Taiwan people know the 2008 presidential election is crucial to Taiwan's future.
"Ma should not think Taiwan people as `so stupid' as to believe that economic issues are more important than national sovereignty and Taiwan's future," Chen said.
He claimed that Ma has continued to preach eventual unification with China and that the KMT's charter still advocates eventual unification.
The KMT, or the Chinese Nationalist Party, still has "China" at the front of its name, Chen continued.
Ma says Taiwan is the Republic of China, but dare not say the Republic of China is Taiwan, Chen claimed, adding that Ma shuns the question and only wants to talk about the economy.
If one wants to talk about the economy only, then it just turns Taiwan into Hong Kong and becomes "another special administrative region," Chen claimed.
Ma needs to be unequivocal about whether he wants "only to focus on the economy and earning money, " Chen said, asking if that "is in line with the public's wishes."

DOC.HEADLINE: President promises to step down as DPP chairman next May
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/07 15:28:49 (By Wu Su-jou and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he will step down as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the same time he concludes his presidential tenure May 20, 2008.

Chen made the promise during a an informal gathering with Taiwanese reporters covering his visit to the Marshall Islands. Chen arrived in Majuro, the Marshall Islands capital, Friday for a three-day visit to meet with heads of state of Taiwan's six allies in the South Pacific.

In response to inquiries focusing on an announcement prior to his trip that he had decided to re-assume office as DPP chairman, the president said that he "won't definitely dominate the state with party guidelines" after taking over the chairmanship and that he will "absolutely withdraw from the DPP chairmanship when he leaves the presidency next year."

"There is no doubt that Frank Hsieh will double as DPP chairman" if he wins the presidential election next year, Chen said, implying that he will not interfere in his successor's administration after leaving power.
"One country cannot have two presidents simultaneously, " he said, quoting former U.S. President Bill Clinton, who made the comment during a meeting with Chen in Taipei in February 2005.

Speaking of the 2008 presidential election, Chen said the ruling party is faced with an entirely different set of challenges than it encountered in 2000 and 2004. In those years, he explained, "the DPP was a strongly consolidated political party."

At that time, the enemies were all from the outside, but today, he went on, "none of our enemies are on the outside but are inside ourselves, " referring to the party's internal conflicts and factionalism.
Chen served as DPP chairman 2002-2004. In December 2004, he resigned to shoulder responsibility for the DPP's failure to win a legislative majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lead in cosmetics within permissible levels: DOH

TEXT.P: The lead content of cosmetics and skin care products on the Taiwan market ranges within permissible levels and should not cause panic among consumers, Department of Health (DOH) officials said Saturday.

The officials made the remarks in response to the results of tests on 33 brand- name lipsticks released recently by the U.S.-based Campaign for Safe Cosmetics, which found that 61 percent contained lead levels of 0.03-0.65 parts per million (ppm).
According to Liao Chi-chou, head of the DOH Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, many cosmetics and skin care products such as lipsticks and toner contain very small amounts of lead -- less than 20 ppm.

As the lead content in the lipsticks falls within this permissible level set by Taiwan's regulations for cosmetic and pharmaceutical safety, the DOH will not order a recall of the products from the local market, Liao said.
DOH officials said consumers should not overreact to the test results, especially when people usually only apply lipsticks to their skin rather than consuming them.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to invite Pacific leaders to his home
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/07 16:51:56 (By Wu Su-jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he will invite leaders of the country's Pacific allies to his new home in Kaohsiung when the third Taiwan- Pacific leadership summit is held in the southern Taiwan city next year.

Chen said the decision to hold the third summit in Kaohsiung was made during the second summit held Friday in the Marshall Islands capital of Majuro, following a proposal by one of the participating Pacific leaders that the next summit be held in Taiwan.

Aware that Chen is planning to move to Kaohsiung after completing his presidential term next year, another Pacific leader even suggested that the next summit be held at his new home, according to Chen.
However, Chen said that as his new home will be too small to host the summit, he promised the Pacific leaders that they will be invited to his home for dinner during next year's summit.
The date for the third summit has yet to be decided. Chen will conclude his presidential term May 20, 2008 and is constitutionally banned from seeking a third term.
Chen said he has chosen an apartment in Kaohsiung but has yet to purchase it, adding that he "definitely will buy it."
Asked if he has any plans to sell his Taipei apartment, the president said the apartment will be sold if he does not have enough cash to pay for his new home.

Chen, who is on a three-day visit to the Marshall Islands, made the remarks during an informal gathering with Taiwanese media. The president is scheduled to wrap up his visit and return to Taiwan Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to step up care for the elderly: interior minister

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Saturday that stepping up care of the elderly has become a major responsibility of the government.
Lee made the remarks at the opening ceremony of a care for the elderly exhibition in Banciao, Taipei County prior to Senior Citizen's Day, which falls on Oct. 19.
Lee noted that the elderly account for 10 percent of the total population and that this number is expected to will reach 20 percent, or one in every five people, by 2026.
For this reason, finding ways to let the elderly live happy and healthy lives has become a major responsibility, he said.
Lee noted that the Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Senior Citizen's Welfare Law in January, and the National Pension Act in July.

He said the national pension system will provide a security net for disadvantaged people who currently lack pension benefits, adding that people aged 25 to 65 who are not covered by military, civil service, teachers or labor insurance programs, as well as farmers under the age of 65, can join the program.

They will be required to pay a monthly contribution based on a percentage of the national minimum wage. Contributions will be calculated on a graded scale ranging from 6.5 percent to 12 percent of the minimum wage.

After retirement at the age of 65, contributors will receive a pension of up to NT$8,986 per month for the rest of their lives, a figure that will be adjusted in line with changes in the consumer price index, Lee said.

In addition, the government also passed a long-term care program this year, investing NT$81.73 billion (US$2.47 billion) over 10 years to take care of the elderly in anticipation of the graying society, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Council for Science to hold committee meeting in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Paris-headquartered International Council for Science (ICSU) is scheduled to hold the third meeting of its Committee on Freedom and Responsibility in the Conduct of Science (CFRS) at Academic Sinica Oct. 15-17, according to a Saturday news release from the prestigious institution.

Academic Sinica was commissioned to host the CFSR meeting for the first time since the committee was established to deal with issues concerning the rights and responsibilities of scientists. Ovid Tzeng, an academician and former vice president of Academia Sinica, is one of the committee's members.

The ICSU, founded in 1931, is the world's oldest non-governmental scientific organization committed to international cooperation for the benefit of humanity. It is made up of 29 international scientific unions and 112 national academies of science or research councils. In 1937, Academia Sinica joined the ICSU.

The CFRS meeting slated for Oct. 15-16 will be a closed meeting of 12 committee members from 10 countries, while the Global Health Workshop Oct. 17 will only be open to professionals for discussions focusing on the rights and responsibilities of scientists during outbreaks of infectious diseases such as SARS, avian flu and dengue fever in Asia, according to the news release.

Keynote speakers at the event will include 2002 Nobel laureate in medicine John E. Sulston; George Fu Gao, director of the Chinese Academy of Science's Institute of Microbiology; Professor Sai Kit Lam of medical microbiology from the University of Malaya; Lai Ming-chiao, president of the Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University; Chen Chien-jen, head of the Cabinet-level National Science Council; and Ellson Y. Chen, president and CEO of Taiwan- based Vita Genomics, Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large output forecast for Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park

TEXT.P: The output of the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park is expected to reach at least NT$18 billion (US$545.45 million) within 10 years, the Construction and Planning Administration (CPA) under the Interior Ministry reported Saturday.
CPA officials said the first-stage of construction work of the park has been completed and they estimated that 20 manufacturers will be stationed in the park by the end of the year.
Within six years, 120 manufacturers will have entered the park, providing 8,000 jobs and boosting the southern Taiwan job market, they said.
The construction of amenities such as banks, a post office, telecommunications, eateries and supermarkets will be completed in May 2008, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Gore awarded Nobel Peace Prize.
Former U.S. vice president Al Gore was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize Friday for his contribution to increasing people's awareness of the global warming. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change of the United Nations was named co- winner with Gore.

DOC.HEADLINE: `I'm running for Taiwan's presidency': DPP candidate

TEXT.P: "I'm running for the presidency of Taiwan, whose official title is the Republic of China as enshrined in the country's Constitution," Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate, said Saturday.

Hsieh made the remarks in a speech to an audience at the Rotary International's Tatung club in Taipei a day after his opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rival Ma Ying- jeou said Hsieh should answer the question of "for which country's presidency is he running?" before proposing any debate between them.

Ma posed the question after Hsieh challenged his KMT rival to a debate on the nation's title and the two parties' separate referendum initiatives on the country's U.N. membership bid. Ma also said that if a debate indeed takes place, economic issues should be the first subject addressed.

In response, Hsieh said Ma's question was nonsense. "I have on numerous occasions said that as our Constitution has not yet been amended, the Republic of China remains our country's title; but as Taiwan is actually independent, it's plausible to say that I'm running for the presidency of Taiwan," Hsieh argued.

By posing such a question, Hsieh said, Ma was exploiting the abnormality in Taiwan's national status to play a "war of words." In his view, Hsieh went on, the real issues to be tackled today are what Taiwan's national title should be and how the nation can secure its place in the international community.

While inviting Ma to debate on the KMT-initiated referendum proposal that would ask whether the government should apply for a return to the United Nations in the name of the ROC, Hsieh said he asked Ma to first answer two questions -- "whether his definitions of the ROC today and the ROC before 1971 are the same, and whether Ma sees the referendum as part of efforts to join the U.N. or just a campaign tactic."
Hsieh said he feels regret that Ma had so far not yet responded to either of his questions. "Ma's non-reaction proves the plausibility of my inquisition," he claimed.

Describing Taiwan's U.N. bid as an "international gambling game," Hsieh said it is not just Taiwan's internal issue, but rather an issue of global concern. Against this backdrop, Hsieh said, there are critical differences between the implication of applying for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan and that of applying for a return to the U.N. in the name of the ROC.
"In the quest for a decent place on the international stage, it is imperative to decide what our designation should be," Hsieh said.
Consequently, he went on, the DPP-initiated referendum proposal to ask whether the government should apply to join the U.N. under the name Taiwan is crucial.

"If the DPP-proposed referendum succeeds by securing the required number of votes in line with our Referendum Law provisions, the world will come to learn that the people of Taiwan overwhelmingly aspire to be represented in the U.N.," Hsieh said.

As the United Nations admits only sovereign states, Hsieh said Taiwan's statehood would be self-evident by seeking to enter the body. The issue remaining to be sorted out or debated would only be its title or designation.
"We should seek a national consensus on this issue; otherwise, foreign countries will be confused and thus become reluctant to lend their support," he added.

Taiwan has unsuccessfully sought U.N. representation since 1993 when the KMT was in power. Fourteen of the bids were filed under the title ROC and this year marked the first time the application was presented under the name Taiwan.

"Even though we failed again this year, we have drawn much more attention and support this time around. Many foreign news outlets, opinion leaders and parliamentarians have thrown support behind our bid," Hsieh noted.

Through these latest efforts, Hsieh said, the world has come to understand that the People's Republic of China does not represent Taiwan, which he said is a stance shared by both Taiwan and the United States -- Taiwan's most important political ally.

Hsieh further said it is imperative for Taiwan to unequivocally spell out its separate identity from China right now. "If we fail to continue seeking U.N. representation, the world could be misled into accepting China's sovereignty claim over Taiwan as shown in U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon's earlier statement about the issue, " he cautioned.
By inviting Ma to debate on the U.N. bid issue, Hsieh continued, he is delivering on his promise to cooperate with any individuals regardless of their political stripe or preference.

As both the DPP and the KMT have been collecting signatures in support of their respective U.N. bid referendum initiatives to be held alongside the next presidential election slated for March 22, 2008, Hsieh said he has called for an open debate with Ma to let the public hear the reasoning behind each proposal and to gauge public opinion on them.
If a Hsieh-Ma debate on the issue takes place, Hsieh suggested, a public opinion poll should be taken and the referendum initiative receiving less support should be withdrawn.

Hsieh said he firmly believes that if 10 million Taiwan voters give "yes" votes to the planned U.N. bid referendum, it would have enormous clout for Taiwan's quest for a U.N. seat. "It would lead the world society to reflect upon why Taiwan cannot join the U.N., " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan image should be remodeled: legislative speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng claimed Saturday that southern Taiwan is the "most important area of the island" and suggested that the image of that region be reformed to "truly reflect the strategic importance" to the country's development.
Wang said it is the southern area that houses the country's heavy industry, which he described as the "fundamental infrastructure" that supports Taiwan's economic development.

Southern Taiwan is also the country's logistic, agricultural and fishery center, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) heavyweight further said, noting that those are the resources that should be taken advantage of in efforts to develop the region.
Wang made the remarks in a lecture in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, to a young leadership camp organized by the Pingtung New Youth Service Association.
Wang also revealed a plan to write a book featuring his ideas and proposals concerning what he described as "homeland replanning."

He also claimed that it was "Taiwan's loss" that former KMT Chairman Lien Chan was never elected to serve as president, referring to Lien's plan to construct "six operational centers" in Taiwan. The proposal was brought up during Lien's failed campaign for the presidency in 2000.

Lien had proposed to build an international airport and a center of warehouses in Kaohsiung, Wang said, claiming that if Lien had had the chance to realize his economic ideas, Taiwan's economic development would have been "astonishing."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urges early flu vaccination

TEXT.P: A government offer of free influenza vaccine is safe and the elderly and young children should get vaccinated as soon as possible, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Saturday.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH Centers for Disease Control, said there is no scientific evidence to prove that a minimal level of mercury in the flu vaccine poses a health threat.

Shih's words came amid reports that the mercury contained in the vaccines have affected the willingness of people to take the shots. In the first week of the free shot program that started Oct. 1, the ratio of two priority groups -- people over 65 years of age and those between two months and two years old -- dropped by 30 percent when compared with the same period of last year, according to the reports.

After pledges of safety by the DOH as well as experts, the ratio of young children taking shots gradually rebounded in the past week, although the ratio for the elderly taking shots had yet to recover.

Shih said that free shots for the elderly have not risen, but have shown a gradual decline in recent years and speculated that this might because the public has let down its guard because there have been no major outbreaks in recent years.

Shih said the World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the three different strains, including the Solomon Islands strain of H1N1, the Wisconsin strain of H3N2 and the strain B/Malaysia could result in influenza outbreaks in the Northern Hemisphere, which prompted the DOH to purchase 2.69 million vaccines.

But he said the WHO has recently warned that there may be other mutant strains, adding the when mutant stains strike, the elderly and the young will be mostly affected. Experience in the United States has shown that for the elderly and the young who have been vaccinated, the symptoms are milder than those who have not been vaccinated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan encouraged to open up linguistically, culturally

TEXT.P: Taiwan society can achieve higher goals by opening up linguistically and culturally, and it's time for Taiwan and China to "start talking to each other", one of the most respected Sinologist in Europe said Saturday.

Taiwan has achieved amazing things, including the peaceful democratic transformation, but its society will be able to do much more if it opens up linguistically and culturally, and understand what happens in the world today, said Rudolph Wagner, a professor at Germany's Heidelberg University, in his speech.

The speech, titled "German Unification: Popular Culture, Maoist Students, and the Socialist Disneyland, " was scheduled for last Saturday but was postponed because of Typhoon Krosa. The speech was one of an international lecture series organized by Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation.

Focusing on German unification in his speech, Wagner was asked about the Taiwan- China situation in the question and answer session. He said Taiwan and China should start talking to each other for a civilized communication rather than political rhetorics of nationalism.

Commenting on the "dignity" factor in Taiwan independence movement, Wagner said that the sense of dignity does not neccessarily have to bundle with sovereignty because Taiwan has won its dignity in its bloodless democratic transition and economic growth.
As for the Taiwan identity, he said that "the world just doesn't respect that very much."
Wagner said the Chinese government has been amazingly successful in managing its economic development in recent years and has actually showed substantial amount of restraint in the Taiwan issue.

He also believed that China had pushed for hosting the 2008 Summer Olympics to repress the internal hawkish military force which has been anxious to take Taiwan by force. China knew very well that, in order to maintain the current economic growth, peace in the next 15-20 years was a priority, Wagner claimed.

With a Ph.D. from the University of Munich, Wagner has done extensive research on Buddhism, Taoist philosophy, and contemporary Chinese politics and the media. In 1992, he was awarded the Leibniz Prize, Europe's most prestigious prize in the humanities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president calls for end to `polarized bi-party system'

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday that Taiwan's party politics have been "deformed" in a situation in which politics is dominated by just two parties -- the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the pro-unification Kuomintang (KMT).

Such a "polarized bi-party system" poses a great threat to Taiwan's security and future development, Lee warned while addressing a seminar on challenges and obstacles to Taiwan's drive to become a normal country.

According to Lee, the polarized "independence vs. unification" bi-party political situation has allowed the DPP and the KMT to easily "manipulate" elections into a bitter duel between pro-independence and pro-unification forces.

"Such practices have not only hindered rational debate on issues critical to people's livelihoods and national development but have also deepened internal division over national identity, " Lee lamented, adding that the scenario would also provide a hotbed for China to drive wedges and exploit any gaps in local society.
So long as this "polarized bi-party system" exists, Lee said Taiwan will face the perils of annexation by China.
In the run-up to Taiwan's 2008 presidential election, Lee said, the candidate favored by the Beijing leadership is already very clear.

"If Beijing's 'favorite son' wins the election, they would get the chance of cultivating an irreversible situation favorable for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, " Lee warned, adding: "Should that be the case, Taiwan will have a hard time escaping a "unification scheme" drafted by them.

After the people of Taiwan were allowed to elect their head of state directly in 1996, Lee said China consistently racked on its brains to help its "favorite sons" in Taiwan's previous three presidential elections. Thanks to growth in Taiwan-centric consciousness, China's past schemes didn't succeed.

Lee said he is worried that the current DPP administration's incompetence, internal rifts over basic policy lines and other factors could lead to its defeat in next year's presidential election, which would put Taiwan's future at high risk.
Against this backdrop, Lee said seeking a way out of Taiwan's current "polarized independence vs. unification bi-party" politics has become desperately urgent.

In his view, Lee argued that Taiwan should strive to turn the existing polarized bi-party system into a healthy bi-party system dominated by the two indigenous parties -- the DPP and its "pan-green" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Lee, who has been known as the TSU's spiritual leader, said he looks forward to see the pro-unification KMT gradually peter out and fade away. At the same time, he said, the TSU should gradually grows into a strong "Taiwan-centric third force" that can compete with the DPP.

Noting that the TSU adopts a social democratic policy line and is dedicated to pursuing social justice, Lee said he hopes local voters can support the TSU in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections in which a new "single-member constituency and two ballots" electoral system will be implemented.

"By so doing, Taiwan-centric consciousness will become mainstream and pro- independence voters will have a new choice other than the DPP," Lee said, adding that a healthy bi-party system will be able to gradually take roots under such circumstances.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president calls for end to 'polarized bi-party system'

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday that Taiwan's party politics have been "deformed" in a situation in which politics is dominated by just two parties -- the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the pro-unification Kuomintang (KMT).

Such a "polarized bi-party system" poses a great threat to Taiwan's security and future development, Lee warned while addressing a seminar on challenges and obstacles to Taiwan's drive to become a normal country.

According to Lee, the polarized "independence vs. unification" bi-party political situation has allowed the DPP and the KMT to easily "manipulate" elections into a bitter duel between pro-independence and pro-unification forces.

"Such practices have not only hindered rational debate on issues critical to people's livelihoods and national development but have also deepened internal division over national identity, " Lee lamented, adding that the scenario would also provide a hotbed for China to drive wedges and exploit any gaps in local society.
So long as this "polarized bi-party system" exists, Lee said Taiwan will face the perils of annexation by China.
In the run-up to Taiwan's 2008 presidential election, Lee said, the candidate favored by the Beijing leadership is already very clear.

"If Beijing's 'favorite son' wins the election, they would get the chance of cultivating an irreversible situation favorable for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, " Lee warned, adding: "Should that be the case, Taiwan will have a hard time escaping a "unification scheme" drafted by them.

After the people of Taiwan were allowed to elect their head of state directly in 1996, Lee said China consistently racked on its brains to help its "favorite sons" in Taiwan's previous three presidential elections. Thanks to growth in Taiwan-centric consciousness, China's past schemes didn't succeed.

Lee said he is worried that the current DPP administration's incompetence, internal rifts over basic policy lines and other factors could lead to its defeat in next year's presidential election, which would put Taiwan's future at high risk.
Against this backdrop, Lee said seeking a way out of Taiwan's current "polarized independence vs. unification bi-party" politics has become desperately urgent.

In his view, Lee argued that Taiwan should strive to turn the existing polarized bi-party system into a healthy bi-party system dominated by the two indigenous parties -- the DPP and its "pan-green" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Lee, who has been known as the TSU's spiritual leader, said he looks forward to see the pro-unification KMT gradually peter out and fade away. At the same time, he said, the TSU should gradually grows into a strong "Taiwan-centric third force" that can compete with the DPP.

Noting that the TSU adopts a social democratic policy line and is dedicated to pursuing social justice, Lee said he hopes local voters can support the TSU in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections in which a new "single-member constituency and two ballots" electoral system will be implemented.

"By so doing, Taiwan-centric consciousness will become mainstream and pro- independence voters will have a new choice other than the DPP," Lee said, adding that a healthy bi-party system will be able to gradually take roots under such circumstances.
