DOC.HEADLINE: Chen goes sea fishing in the Marshall Islands
DOC.DATELINE: Majuro, Marshall Islands, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/07 15:31:53 (By Wu Su-jou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian had a good time sea fishing in the Marshall Islands with his South Pacific counterparts Sunday.

Paired with Marshall Islands President Kessai H. Note, Chen boarded a boat Sunday morning to go fishing around a coral reef islet, where the two presidents jointly caught fish weighing 14 kg during the two-hour outing.

It turned out that the Chen-Note team beat the rival team of Palauan President Tommy Remengesau and Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty in the two-way sea fishing championship between the heads of states. Remengesau and Scotty jointly caught 9.1 kg of fish.

Chen then joined Note, Remengesau, Scotty, Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia and other ranking officials from the houst country for a barbecue lunch.
At the barbecue, Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey performed a rap -- including the lyrics "UN UN for Taiwan, Taiwan No. 1..." -- and won a big round of applause.

Chen and his entourage arrived in the Marshall Islands Friday for a three-day state visit. They will depart from the capital city, Majuro, at 3 p.m. Sunday and are scheduled to arrive home in Taipei around 6:40 p.m. the same day.

Over the past three days, Chen met with his counterparts from the Marshall Islands, Palau, Kiribati, Nauru, the Solomon Islands and Tuvalu for the Second Leadership Summit between Taiwan and Its Pacific Allies. He also officiated at a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Marshall Islands International Conference Center, which was built with Taiwan aid.

Upon the conclusion of the summit meeting, the seven heads of states jointly announced a Majuro Declaration, in which the six presidents of South Pacific nations vowed to staunchly support Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
During the meeting, Chen solicited support from these allies in his campaign for the establishment of a World Environment Organization (WEO) under a United Nations framework.

Chen called on the leaders of these six nations to write U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon and other U.N. member countries to jointly push for the establishment of the WEO to ensure our species' sustainable development and survival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to ask for a deadline for flu vaccination BOO cooperation

TEXT.P: Taiwan has decided to ask that a deadline be set for the signing of a contract on a build, own, operate (BOO) project for the production of flu vaccines in Taiwan with Dutch Pharmaceutical company Akzo Nobel, a Department of Health (DOH) source said Sunday.

The DOH Centers for Disease Control (CDC) chose Akzo Nobel in July 2006 as a possible partner for talks on a BOO project, under which Akzo Nobel -- the largest pharmaceutical company in the Netherlands -- would help Taiwan produce flu vaccines domestically.

Although such talks are nearly complete, a final contract has not been signed between the two sides. According to the agreement as it stands, Akzo Nobel will help Taiwan build a flu vaccine manufacturing plant in a biomedical industrial park located in Chupei, northern Taiwan.

Nevertheless, in March this year, Schering-Plough -- a worldwide, research-based pharmaceutical company -- signed an agreement with Akzo Nobel to buy Organon Biosciences, which is an Akzo Nobel department responsible for vaccine research and development.

As the acquisition deal has not yet been closed and related talks, particularly on regulatory clearance procedures, are not expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of this year, an Organon official told the CNA recently that neither Organon, nor Akzo Nobel will be able to make any solid decision on the BOO project with Taiwan at the moment.

The Organon official said that Akzo Nobel and the CDC are still in discussions, in particular about the financial terms and conditions of the BOO project, but at the moment the Dutch company cannot give Taiwan a timetable for the signing of any contract regarding the vaccine cooperation BOO project.
"The BOO project will require approval by Schering-Plough, " he pointed out.
On this latest development, CDC officials said Taiwan cannot wait indefinitely and may, as a result, opt to pursue a "Plan B."

The options for a "Plan B" have not yet be set, but could include signing contracts with another foreign vaccine maker to initiate a new BOO project; helping Taiwan's local companies to develop flu vaccines; and striking advance procurement agreements (APA) with foreign pharmaceutical companies to secure sufficient quantities of flu vaccines, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment in Southern Taiwan Science Park picks up steam

TEXT.P: Investment in the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County has continued to pick up steam with the number of companies operating there and business turnovers completed continuing to expand, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Sunday.
As of Sept. 30 this year, the number of companies operating in the Southern Taiwan Science Park has increased to 102 from less then 30 in 2002 when the park was inaugurated, MOEA officials said.
Business turnover registered in the science park reached NT$100 billion (US$3.06 billion) in the first nine months of this year, compared to NT$6.4 billion posted in 2002, the officials said.
They added that for the entire year of 2007, business turnover in the park is expected to top NT$120 billion.

As of Sept. 30 this year the park has created 12,000 job opportunities, they said, adding that it is expected that after a comprehensive building is completed in 2009, the park will provide at least 15,000 job openings.

Construction of the 7-story building -- which is planned to house a conference and exhibition hall, bank, post office, convenience stores and several restaurants -- is scheduled to begin later this month, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Navy officials punished for handling classified documents recklessly

TEXT.P: Three Navy officials, including a rear admiral were punished for inappropriately handling classified documents, according to a statement issued by the Ministry of National Defense Sunday.

The statement confirmed a report carried by Sunday's United Daily News that Commander Shen Jao-chun, a staff member of the Navy Command Headquarters in Taipei, was reprimanded and removed from his current post for downloading classified documents and processing them on his personal computer at home.
His direct superior, Captain Hsiang Ching-tsung, was also reprimanded and removed for failing to learn of the matter and correct it.
Rear Admiral Chu Tsung-rung, chief of the department at which the two officers worked was spared a reprimand, but has been removed from his post as a consequence.

The terse statement quoted a report from the Navy Command Headquarters as saying that the Navy, which bans accessing official documents on personal computers, is taking the incident seriously and tightening up security procedures to prevent a repetition of it.

The United Daily News said the incident was detected "recently" by a "friendly military unit" which found Shen processed classified military documents on his personal computer against military regulations.

Shen downloaded military documents without permit onto a USB disk and then handled them on his personal computer. These documents were thereby stolen by hackers who successfully broke into Shen's personal computer as he surfed the Internet, said the United Daily News.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid vs. livelihood debate becomes presidential campaign issue

TEXT.P: The debate over whether Taiwan's U.N. bid or the country's economy should take center stage in the 2008 presidential election became a hot topic between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Sunday.

One day after DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh claimed that the U.N. bid should take precedence over the economy because the people are not livestock and need dignity more than they need to be further stuffed with food, DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh urged KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou Sunday to take up Hsieh's challenge to debate the U.N. bid, which the lawmaker claims needs to be addressed more urgently than the economy.

Like the country's economy, the bid for U.N. membership is an issue no presidential candidate can avoid, Wang said, adding that as both the DPP and KMT have initiated their own proposals for a referendum to be held alongside the presidential election in March, 2008, the two party's candidates should debate the pros and cons of their particular proposals in public to avoid a failure of both of them in the referendum due to a division between their supporters.

Wang was referring to the DPP's proposal for the country to bid for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan in keeping with the party's push to establish Taiwan's permanent independence, and the KMT's proposal to join the U.N. under the name of the country's official title of the Republic of China, in line with its advocacy of maintaining the political status quo.
Noting that defense, diplomacy and ties with China will be the major challenges facing the next president, Wang said the economy should be put on the back burner for the time being.
The KMT, in response, criticized Hsieh for likening people who desire for a better life to livestock Sunday.

"Mark my words, " KMT Spokesman Su Chun-ping cautioned Hsieh, "people are not livestock, they deserve to prosper. Government leaders who failed to provide the people with a better life should apologize and step down.

He claimed that under the DPP's seven-year rule the country has lost NT$12 trillion due to economic decline, NT$6 trillion to high-profile economic crimes involving senior government officials, and NT$900 billion to government sales of state-owned assets at a loss, not to mention the losses caused by DPP administration's pocketbook diplomacy and numerous grand but useless public projects.

Citing statistics to support his claims regarding the people's misery, Su said that one person committed suicide every two hours in Taiwan in 2006; Kaohsiung Harbor's worldwide ranking in terms of the volume of containers it handled is set to declined to 8th this year, down from third in 2002; the starting salary of college graduates now averages at NT$26,000 (US$797.9), lower than what it was eight years ago; and accumulated government debt has risen to NT$530,000 (US$16,265) per capita.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen returns from Marshall Islands

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian returned to Taipei Sunday evening after a three-day visit to the Marshall Islands, calling his trip a success.

On his arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the president told journalists that his summit with leaders of Taiwan's six Pacific allies in Majuro, the capital of the Marshall Islands on Oct. 12, have cemented the country's strategic partnership with countries in that region.
Noting that even mice could roar as lions, the president said the six Pacific allies are vociferous in their support of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations despite their small sizes.

That summit which resulted in the Majuro Declaration, as well as as similar summits he had with leaders of the Taiwan's Central America allies in Tugucigapa, Honduras in August and with leaders of Taiwan's African allies in Taipei in September have anchored Taiwan firmly in the international community in defiance of Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan.

On the sidelines of the Majuro summit, Chen said he also had bilateral talks with leaders of the six allies, namely the host country's President Kessai Note, Kiribati Vice President Teima Onorio, Nauruan President Ludwig Scotty, Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr., Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to appeal district court ruling on classified materials

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will appeal a recent decision by the Taipei District Court to reject his request for the return of classified documents seized in a high profile "state affairs fund" embezzlement case, the Presidential Office announced Monday.

Chen's lawyers -- Chen Chuan-yueh and Hung Kuei-tsan -- are expected to announce at a news conference at 5 p.m. the president's decision to appeal the decision to the Taiwan High Court in order "to defend his legitimate rights," Presidential Office officials said.

On Sept. 6, Chen petitioned the district court to return invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals, and data related to six secret diplomatic missions being used by prosecutors as evidence in the case. All the materials are now being held by the district court.

The president made the request on the grounds that the materials had been re- labeled as "strictly confidential" materials that should be kept secret permanently after the Council of Grand Justices confirmed June 15 the president's constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose such information, also known as "state secret privilege, " the officials said.

Nevertheless, the district court rejected Chen's request in a ruling issued Oct. 5, saying that the exercise of the president's "state secret privilege" should still be made in line with the constitutional principle of balance of power and should be subject to scrutiny.
The court ruled that the process in which the materials were proclaimed as "absolute secrets" involved "serious, obvious flaws" and should be regarded as invalid.

The court determined that Chen lacks any reason or legal basis to ask for the return of the materials because the president's privilege to refuse to give testimony and produce evidence should be exercised before, not after, the testimony is given and the evidence submitted.
On Chen's claim that the materials were seized by the prosecutors without a warrant, the court noted that the seizure was carried out based on a warrant issued by the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office.

Further rebutting Chen's claim that the materials were being held without his consent, the court said the invoices and vouchers were taken away with the consent of the head of the Presidential Office's accounting department, because the department, not Chen, was the keeper of the invoices and vouchers.
Also, the data regarding the six secret diplomatic missions was submitted to the prosecutors by presidential aide Lin Te-hsun after obtaining Chen's approval, the court said.

Pointing out that Chen did not insist that the withheld materials were state secrets when undergoing questioning by prosecutors last year, the court claimed that the president's move to proclaim the materials as "absolute secrets" only during the final stage of the trial was "aimed merely at covering up the administrative negligence and even irregularities" of the defendants.
The court added that the move, which was not intended to protect national security or national interests, violates the State Secrets Protection Act and should be considered unlawful.

The prosecution named Chen as a "joint perpetrator" when it indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen on corruption and forgery charges Nov. 3, 2006 after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen stressed that none of the money went into his own pocket, claiming it was necessary to use receipts from different individuals to muster the funds to engage in secret diplomatic missions in certain countries because of the confusing and inconsistent accounting system governing expenditures by the Presidential Office.

However, the district court ruled Jan. 19 that the six diplomatic missions cited by the president as having drawn on the state affairs fund were not secret as the president claimed, and should be disclosed in court proceedings.

In a press statement issued late Oct. 5, the Presidential Office said that since the documents are now in the district court's possession, the district court is not a suitable judicial organ to decide whether or not they should be returned to the Presidential Office.
According to current law, Chen, his wife Wu Shu-jen, and the president's aides Ma Yung-cheng, Lin Te-hsun and Chen Chen-hui can appeal the district court ruling.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

October TE futures increased 2.85 points to close at 390.8, with 2,579 contracts traded, while November TE futures increased 2.4 points to finish at 390.25, with 1,123 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures gained 14.2 points to close at 1,064.4, with 2,829 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 16.6 points to finish at 1,065.6, with 1,171 contracts traded. December TF futures increased 4.8 points to finish at 1,060, with four contracts trading hands. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 21.98 points to close at 9,518.45.
The bourse opened at 9,565.36 and fluctuated between 9,577.04 and 9,431.66 during trading. A total of 4.41 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$121.26 billion (US$3.72 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

The three other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 4.8 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 614, with 242 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science, technology budget to be increased 4.6 percent: MOEA

TEXT.P: The government's budget for the Department of Industrial Technology (DOIT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs for next year is expected to top NT$18.94 billion (US$580.83 million) , up 4.6 percent over the 2007 level, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang said Monday.

Most of the budget will be used to help upgrade the industrial structures of industries in central and southern Taiwan, small and medium enterprises, as well as traditional industries, Shih said during a Legislative Yuan Science, Technology and Information Committee session.
According to Shih, Taiwan's research and development budget in 2005 was 2.46 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for that year, ranking 10th in the world.

Shieh said that of the DOIT's 2008 budget, which has been screened by the National Science Council, NT$8.44 billion, or 45 percent, will be allocated to the non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute; 19 percent will be allocated to finance special research projects conducted by private companies; 25 percent will go toward financing special research projects conducted by non- profit institutes; 5 percent will be allocated to research projects conducted by the academic sector; and 6 percent will go toward financial management of science and technology related affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Target for international tourist arrivals for 2008 adjusted downward

TEXT.P: The government adjusted its target Monday for the number of foreign tourist arrivals in Taiwan for 2008 to some 4 million, down from 5 million as envisaged in 2002.

Reporting at the Legislative Yuan, Lai Se-chen, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said that Taiwan would have had difficulty reaching the 5 million target next year, mainly due to the fact that China has not yet allowed its citizens to make tourism trips to Taiwan.
Lai said that to cope with this situation, the Tourism Bureau has mapped out new plans and goals for the coming three years in terms of foreign tourist arrivals.
Under these plans and goals, Lai said, arrivals in 2007 are set at 3.75 million, a slight decline from the previously estimated level; 4 million for 2008; and 4.25 million for 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government urged to build bicycle path network

TEXT.P: Three Taipei city councilors called Monday for the establishment of a comprehensive network of bicycle paths in the capital city, out of concern for the safety and benefits of cyclists.

Councilors Wang Chih-ping, Dai Hsi-chin and Chen Yu-mei of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , made the call after they examined bike traffic around several Mass Rapid Transport stations earlier in the day.
After the city government began Sept. 1 to fine cyclists who illegally ride on fast traffic lanes or on the sidewalk, they found that bike commuters have since become the most vulnerable road users.

On many road sections in the metropolis, Dai said, it is common to see cars jostling motorbikes for road space, forcing the motorbikes to crowd bicycles off the road. To protect themselves, cyclists often have to risk being fined by riding on the sidewalk, he noted.

According to traffic police statistics, Wang indicated that since the beginning of September, the police have so far ticketed 383 cyclists for running red lights, 116 for riding in the fast lanes, 71 for riding on pedestrian crossings, and 132 for riding against the traffic flow.
On average, 24 tickets are issued per day, Wang said, indicating that the high rate could mean the city has not had set aside enough road space for cyclists.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Crash severs a vital state artery. Fiery I-5 pileup kills three.
The fiery Interstate 5 truck crash that killed at least three people south of Santa Clarita has severed the state's main north-south transportation artery for an indefinite period, authorities said Saturday. Officials guessed that southbound lanes could reopen as early as Tuesday but were unwilling to speculate about the northbound lanes. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Democratic party is born, Veltroni wins.
Rome mayor Walter Veltroni won the election of the secretary general of the Democratic Party which was formally established Sunday. Veltroni obtained some 76 percent of votes cast by some 3.3 million Italian citizens and legal foreign residents around the nation.

DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Tioman ferry fire: Passengers 'jumped after crew left them'.
Passengers on a holiday ferry that burst into flames on Saturday, killing four, claim they had to jump into the sea with their children after the crew abandoned them.
The Lianhe Zaobao: We need to maintain Singapore's competitive ability with perfect legal system: MM Lee.
The rule of law has given Singapore the advantage in the center of South-east Asia as leader knew. But Singapore still need to maintain Singapore's competitive ability with perfect legal system.

The Moscow TimesGLate U.S. Offer Follows Chilly Talks
Weekend visit by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert Gates failed to resolve tensions between Washington and Moscow, lowering hopes that relations will be mended before Presidents Vladimir Putin and George W. Bush leave office. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

The Manila Bulletin: Mass measles vaccination starts
The department of Health (DOH) in partnership with local government units (LGUs) will mobilize some 10,000 vaccination teams nationwide starting today for the month-long mass measles immunization campaign targeting at least nine million Filipino children.
The Philippine Inquirer: 2 governors: 'Yes, we received money'
Two more governors -- both from southern Luzon -- Sunday owned up to receiving P500,000 each from Malacanang last week at the height of a controversy over moves to impeach President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.
The Philippine Stsr: Contractor to expose P900-M landfill stink
In another twist to what looked like a quagmire of filth that saturates the Montalban landfill ruckus, the operator of the newly opened 19-hectare landfill in Rodriguez, Rizal is seeking a Senate inquiry to expose the alleged misuse by the local government of the P900 million it generated from the six-year operation of its adjacent 14-hectare landfill.
The Manila Times: Govt eyes peace talks
The government will study the possibility of resuming talks with the National Democratic Front (NDF) after the leftist group showed willingness to restart the stalled negotiations, a Palace official said.

The New York Times: Interim Heads Increasingly Run Federal Agencies
For now, the most powerful law enforcement official in the federal government is a 47-year- old lawyer little known outside Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.017 to close at NT$32.598.
A total of US$645 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.553 and fluctuated between NT$32.515 and NT$32.603.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Army Corps commander indicted on corruption charges

TEXT.P: A former commander of the 6th Army Corps in northern Taiwan has been indicted on charges of corruption, Vice Minister of National Defense Ko Cheng-en confirmed Monday.

Questioned by reporters about a front-page report on the indictment carried by the local daily the China Times, Ko said the Ministry of National Defense respects the military prosecutors' decision to ask the Military High Court to impose a 16-year sentence on Lt. Gen. Cheng Shih-yu for embezzling NT$1.34 million in public funds.

The sentence being sought for Cheng is the harshest ever for any ranking military official in Taiwan charged with corruption. Cheng is also the highest- ranking military officer to be indicted in recent years.
Ko urged the public not to allow an "isolated case" to offset the contributions made by the great majority of the armed forces' personnel.
He also denied speculation that Cheng's prosecution might have something to do with a power struggle among the top military brass.

Cheng has been in custody since July 20 pending the completion of an investigation into charges that he embezzled NT$1.34 million (US$41,090) of his administrative funds between late 2006 and July this year while he served as commander of the 6th Army Corps.

According to the China Times report, the military prosecutors asked for a 16-year sentence rather than the minimum seven years in prison because he did not confess to the crime and remained "unrepentant."
Previous reports by other news media said that Cheng remitted NT$150,000 of his administrative fund every month to a 39-year-old mistress while he served as commander of the 6th Army Corps.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has not executed anyone for two years: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that no death row convict has been executed in Taiwan for nearly two years and that he has always wanted the death penalty being phased out completely from the country.

Talking to Mario Marazziti, the famous movie director and founder of the anti- death penalty group the Community of Sant'Egidio, at the Presidential Office, Chen said that due to barriers posed by divided public opinion, capital punishment has not been abolished in Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Chen said, he has made sure that the Ministry of Justice has exercised great prudence in executing death row inmates and hopes to first achieve a "zero execution record" before capital punishment is abolished once and for all.

As a result, he went on, no death row convict has been executed in Taiwan since January 2006, adding that this can be seen as a positive response to the anti- death penalty movement launched by groups around the world.

He said it would be a great triumph for the world's anti-death penalty movement if a motion -- initiated by the European Council to have capital punishment abolished from the world completely -- is passed and adopted by the United Nations General Assembly.
The president said that so far, over 130 nations, or two-thirds of all U.N. member countries, have ceased executing death row convicts or have abolished capital punishment.

Chen recalled that 20 years ago when he was a legislative aide, he had begun to push for an abolition of the death penalty in Taiwan "because at that time, I had already become aware that abolishing capital punishment was a global trend, with one country on average ceasing executing death row convicts or abolishing capital punishment each year."

Ever since he was elected president in 2000, Chen said, he has stressed the imperative of abolishing the death penalty and as a result, then-Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan proposed a draft for basic human rights, which included a clause calling for the abolition of capital punishment.

Chen quoted the results of a public opinion poll indicating that 80 percent of adults in Taiwan oppose the abolition of the death penalty, although 40 percent would support it as long as complementary and preventive policies are worked out as additional measures.

For his part, Marazziti said that although Taiwan is not a U.N. member, its government's pushing for an abolition of the death penalty is tremendously significant and will earn recognition and support from the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Comic book on Taiwan's outstanding people to be published

TEXT.P: Cartoonist Tsai Chih-chung said Monday that he has decided to publish a comic book introducing Taiwan's successful and distinguished individuals in an effort to promote good values in society.
Stan Shih, founder of the Acer Group and also chairman of the union of winners of an annual award for outstanding young persons, encouraged Tsai to promote good values through his comics, Tsai said.

According to Tsai, his comic strips introducing nearly 80 outstanding individuals will first be published in newspapers or on the Internet, and will then collect the strips and publish them in book form.
The author of the well-known and best-selling comic books "The Words of Chuangtzu" and "The Words of Laotzu, " Tsai is also highly regarded in the cultural and creative industries.

Emphasizing the importance of the development of Taiwan's cultural and creative industries, Tsai pointed out that although about 70 percent of the world's animation production is made in Taiwan, personnel in this field do not receive further training for their future development.

In order to nurture talent in the field, Tsai also lectures in a graduate program on digital content at National Taiwan Normal University and at the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology. He expressed hope that this provide a better future in the field for talented people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese president urged to respect Taiwan's sovereignty

TEXT.P: A legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Chinese President Hu Jintao Monday to respect Taiwan's sovereign status.

Legislator Wang Tuoh made the call at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan in response to remarks by Hu concerning the Taiwan issue in his report at the opening of the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Beijing earlier in the day.
Hu, who concurrently heads the CPC, said that Beijing will never waver on its "one China" principles, nor will it give up efforts to seek peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
In his report, Hu also reaffirmed no change in Beijing's principle of "entrusting hope to the Taiwanese people" for the goal of unification and no compromise on Taiwan's separation movements.
Hu also called for talks to end cross-strait hostility under the "one China" policy.

In response, Wang said the DPP respects Hu's "one China" overture since there is indeed only one China in the world. Nevertheless, Wang went on, the DPP looks forward to China's reciprocal respect for Taiwan's sovereign status.
Stressing that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state, Wang said Taiwan has never belonged to the People's Republic of China nor been part of it.

It is worthy of respect that China has begun to take the idea of "peace" as a means of resolving disputes, Wang said, but cautioned that it is not acceptable to take the ideas of "unification" or "one China" as a prerequisite for efforts to hold cross-strait talks on resolving bilateral disputes.

If China wants to "entrust its hope to Taiwanese people, " Wang suggested, it should first withdraw the hundreds of missiles it has deployed targeting Taiwan and help Taiwan obtain access to international organizations.
Meanwhile, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Taiwan will not talk about "unification" with the Chinese Communist regime.

"We will never talk about unification or other things with a regime that suppresses Tibet, kills its own people and supports the military junta of Myanmar, " Shieh said, describing the attitude as "our insistence upon adopting democracy and human rights."

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC urges overseas nationals to vote in presidential election

TEXT.P: Overseas Compatriots Affairs Commission (OCAC) Vice Chairman Cheng Tung-hsing urged overseas nationals Monday to return home and cast their ballots in the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

According to Cheng, the OCAC did not earmark any budget to encourage compatriots living abroad to take part in presidential elections at home, and it is difficult to make a precise calculation in advance of the number that would return.

In the 2000 and 2004 presidential polls, some 8,600 and 11,300 overseas nationals, respectively, registered with the Central Election Commission (CEC) demonstrating their desire to return and vote, but the actual numbers to do so were only around 5,000 and 9,400, CEC tallies showed.

But OCAC officials predicted that number for next year's presidential election may exceed the 2004 and 2000 figures, as many overseas expatriates have recently inquired about the relevant details of coming home and voting in the presidential poll.

To serve all compatriots around the world intent on voting in the presidential election at home, the OCAC has produced a question-and-answer booklet which is available at its overseas outposts and posted related information on its Website to make them freely available, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 402 students in Chiayi infected by acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis

TEXT.P: At least 402 students in Chiayi City's elementary and middle schools have been infected by acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, health officials at the city government said Monday.
The officials at the Public Health Bureau under the city government said the highly contagious enteroviral eye infection is most likely caused by coxsackievirus type A24, a variant of enterovirus.

They warned that the disease could easily develop into an epidemic but urged the public not to panic, because the eye infection can be prevented by frequent hand washing and avoiding the use of shared towels.
Those people who feel the urge to rub their eyes should do so with a cotton swab or a Q-tip, instead of using their hands, they added.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is characterized by sudden onset of painful, swollen, red eyes, with conjunctival hemorrhaging and excessive tearing. The disease has been noted throughout the tropical regions.
According to medical doctors, no effective treatment is available for the disease, and patients can only wait for the disease to run its course after 7 days while receiving treatment for symptoms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City steps up breast cancer prevention campaign

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's Department of Health held a news conference Monday to promote breast cancer prevention and cure as part of a series of activities in October to promote awareness of the disease.

Health officials from the department offered tips on health education, as well as free breast ultrasounds, cervical smears and bone density checks to participants at the news conference held at Taipei 101 building.

Citing statistics compiled by the Executive Yuan's Department of Health, a city official said at the occasion that breast cancer is a major threat. It is now the most common form of cancer and the third most common cause of cancer death among Taiwanese women, he added.

To further increase public awareness of the disease, the department will also hold an aerobics performance Oct. 20 to introduce the importance of good general health and fitness in the prevention of breast cancer, the official added.

A total of 4,423 Taipei City citizens died from cancer in 2006, which was about 30 percent of the city's total death toll and an increase of 133 people over the previous year, the official said, adding that early discovery and treatment are crucial to reducing the cancer mortality rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local school to assist in Saudi aquaculture development

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan City in southern Taiwan will sign a contract with an American venture Tuesday to assist in developing aquaculture off Saudi Arabia's Red Sea coast, a spokesman for the school said Monday.
The signing ceremony for the project, Taiwan's first cross-border cooperation between industry and the academy, will be held at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel in Taipei City, the spokesman said.
Under the contract, the NCKU will provide a biomedical product developed by the school to the DevCorp International, an American venture operating in the Arabian Gulf area, the spokesman said.

The fish farming project has received much attention from the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, the spokesman said, adding that the contract will not involve revealing any crucial technology know how.

The school will also hold a news conference after the signing ceremony to introduce the public to the product which has been used for about one year in Taiwan, and the leading technology involved in its production, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City schools required to report new pinkeye cases daily

TEXT.P: Starting Monday, all schools in Taipei City are required to report new cases of conjunctivitis, commonly known as pinkeye, each day for three weeks as part of the efforts of the city's Department of Education to keep track of the outbreak, an education official said that day.
According to statistics released by the education department, 3,208 teachers, students, and school staff contracted the eye disease Oct. 8-15, Department of Education Director Wu Ching-chi noted.
In an effort to contain the highly contagious disease, the education department has suggested that pinkeye patients stay at home until fully recovered, Wu said.

On Monday, Wu said that vocational and senior high schools reported 139 new cases, junior high schools reported 325 cases, and primary schools reported 491 cases. He added that schools in the Neihu District reported the greatest increase in the number of cases with 247.

Meanwhile, Yen Mu-yong, an official with the city's Department of Health, said that the pinkeye outbreak is currently occurring mainly in the area close to the northern county of Taipei and the northern city of Keelung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's future in hands of its people: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's future must be determined by its people and Beijing's "one China" principle is the prime barrier to cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, the Cabinet- level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said is a news release issued Monday.

The MAC issued the press release after Chinese President Hu Jintao called for a peace agreement based on the one-China principle earlier the same day during the opening session of the Communist Party of China's 17th five-yearly Congress.

Hu was quoted by AFP in a report from Beijing as saying, "On the basis of the one-China principle, let us discuss a formal end to the state of hostility between the two sides, reach a peace agreement, construct a framework for peaceful development of cross-strait relations and thus usher in a new phase of peaceful development."
According to the MAC, Hu's insistence on using the "one China" principle to develop peaceful cross-strait dealings is reflective of ignorance as to the existing situation between Taiwan and China.

If Beijing chooses to believe that Taiwan's people would accept its "one country, two systems" unification scheme, China must be entirely ignorant as to mainstream opinion in Taiwan, the MAC said, adding that Beijing is seeking to create a justification for its anti-secession law against Taiwan by presenting Taiwan's democratization efforts as moves toward "de jure independence."
For Taiwan, China's institution of a democratic system is the cornerstone to building peaceful relations and developing two-way exchanges between the two sides, the MAC said.

If China truly intends to contribute to the well-being of Taiwan's people, it should swiftly remove all political barriers and artificial barriers to wrapping up negotiations on the opening of direct cross-strait passenger and cargo charter flight service and on allowing Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan, the MAC stated.

If China fails to remove its many politically charged barriers to concluding technical talks with Taiwan, it will be impossible for the two sides to move on to negotiations over the establishment of full direct transport links and construct a peaceful framework, the MAC statement noted.

While expressing hope that China would embark on a democratic course as soon as possible to catch up with worldwide moves toward democracy, freedom and human rights, the MAC called on Beijing to forswear its "one China" framework, scrap its anti-secession law, stop its bullying of Taiwan in the international community and remove all of its missiles aimed at Taiwan.

To end the state of hostility and build a genuine peace across the strait, China should begin formal negotiations with Taiwan's popularly elected government without any preconditions, the MAC sttement concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: President sets tone for cooperation with DPP presidential candidate

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Monday described Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate for the March 22, 2008 presidential election, as the "leading actor" in the electoral campaign, and stressed that he is only playing an auxiliar role to help Hsieh on to victory.

Chen made the comments during an inspection tour of the DPP headquarters -- the first after the president accepted the party's chairmanship last Thursday prior to his departure for the Marshall Islands later that same day for a visit. Chen returned home Sunday evening from the Marshall Islands, where he took part in the second summit between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies.

Brushing aside rampant speculation that the president would guide Hsieh on how to campaign and ask Hsieh to follow his policies once he took over as DPP chairman, Chen said that Hsieh-Chen collaboration, rather than Chen-Hsieh cooperation, remains the key to the DPP's electoral campaign in the few months remaining before the Jan. 12 legislative and March 22 presidential elections.

Chen asserted that there is a deep mutual understanding between Hsieh and himself based on past long-term cooperation, and labeled Hsieh as the "protagonist" in their pairing. "I am playing only a supporting role and looking after the house for the party, " he explained.

Chen stressed that his assuming the DPP chairmanship is intended to mend differences and forge unity within the party as the party also seeks to garner public approval on two referendums concerning Taiwan's U.N. membership and retrieve the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) ill-gotten party assets, besides securing victory in the upcoming elections.

Chen announced that Yu Shyi-kun, his predecessor who stepped down from the DPP's chairmanship last month, would serve as the party's "top advisor," and Su Tseng- chang, vice presidential candidate, as its "top honorary advisor."

Commenting on the DPP's partnership with the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the run-up to the legislative election, Chen said that he has learned of the TSU's preliminary stance and admitted that it too is a critical issue with which the party must deal.

Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general at the Presidential Office who has been appointed to replace Lin Chia-lung as DPP secretary general, said that steps will be taken through party mechanisms to make arrangements with the TSU and that a possible settlement might be made public within a week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-graft leader wants Assembly and Parade Law abolished

TEXT.P: The leader of an anti-graft campaign told a trial court Monday that the Assembly and Parade Law should be abolished because it infringes on the constitutional rights of the people of Taiwan.

Shih Ming-teh, leader of tens of thousands of red-clad protesters who tried to depose scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian late last year, made the remarks while defending himself and 15 other anti-graft leaders on the first day of a trial at the Taipei District Court.

The 16 defendants, who pleaded not guilty, were indicted on charges of violating the Assembly and Parade Law on the Oct. 10 National Day last year when they led tens of thousands of supporters to besiege the Presidential Palace in an attempt to force the president to step down.

Shih expressed strong disagreement with the prosecution's charge that he had committed a crime by leading the protestors in a street parade. He contended that it is the people's constitutional right to oppose corruption -- a right recognized in the 2003 United Nations Convention Against Corruption.
He said the protest parade ended peacefully and should be seen as having set a "textbook example" of the proper conduct of mass demonstrations.

Shih, who served as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party between 1994 and 1996 before quitting the party in 2000, said that if found guilty by the lower court, he will not appeal, but will serve his term in prison.

Saying that he has fought for freedom, human rights and justice for the Taiwanese people all his life, Shih expressed confidence that even if he is found guilty, history and the Taiwan people will do him justice one day.
Shih was imprisoned twice between 1962 and 1989 for a total of 25 years under the Kuomintang's previous authoritarian regime. He has been described by supporters as "Taiwan's Mandela."

He initiated the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign in September last year after a public prosecutor indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of corruption and forgery and named President Chen as a "joint perpetrator."

Although the president is protected by the Constitution from being tried while he is in office, the trial of his wife and five other defendants, including two former senior presidential aides and two Presidential Office officials, has continued at the Taiwan District Court since Dec. 15 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President appeal to reclaim documents of 'state affairs fund' case

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's lawyer filed an appeal with the Taipei District Court Monday for reclamation of a collection of documents and articles held by the court in the probes of a "state affairs fund" misuse case, in which first lady Wu Shu-jen is a defendant.

Chen Chuan-yueh filed the appeal on behalf of President Chen after the district court handed down a ruling Oct. 5 that rejected the president's request for the return of the collection on the grounds that the president's labeling of the collection as "strictly confidential" as illegal.

According to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Ruling No. 627 issued June 15, the Taiwan High Court is obliged to form a special tribunal to deal with a dispute between the president and the prosecution or a district court over the exercise of the president's "state secrets privilege."

A court official said the District Court will hand over the appeal to the High Court as soon as possible to seek a solution to the dispute. In accordance with the CGJ constitutionality ruling, the district court has temporarily suspended trial of the "state affairs fund" case pending a ruling by the High Court on whether the collection of documents should be returned to the Presidential Office.
In preparation for the president's appeal, the High Court already unveiled last Monday the rosters of eight special tribunals qualified to handle the case.

The High Court will decide by drawing lots which special tribunal will be authorized to mete out a ruling on the appeal. In line with the CGJ stipulations, each tribunal is composed of five judges, one of whom must have served as chief judge for at least 10 years.
Speaking at a news conference, the president's lawyer outlined several key reasons for filing the appeal against the District Court ruling:

-- In terms of the CGJ constitutionality rulings No. 328 and 419, the president's "state secrets privilege" is beyond the scrutiny of the judicial branch because its exercise involves military, diplomacy and national security affairs.

-- The CGJ ruling No. 627 handed down June 15 that confirms the president's "state secrets privilege" does not empower a general court to examine the president's proclamation of a document or a diplomatic mission as confidential that should be kept secret. The practices or precedents set forth in the U.S. Watergate case could not be employed in President Chen's case as the Watergate case didn't involve any national security, diplomatic or defense interests.

-- The CGJ No. 627 ruling clearly states that the president should be given the opportunity to explain or give supplementary explanations whether national security and interests are at stake in disclosure of the collection of documents in question.
-- Any dispute between the president and the judicial branch over exercise of their respective powers should be dealt with by the CGJ, not the district court.
-- The exercise of president's "state secrets privilege" does not restrict to those prescribed in the Classified National Security Information Protection Act.

The District Court obtained the collection of documents and articles from a prosecutorial team that indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen and three former and incumbent presidential aides last November on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund, " a special allowance fund set aside for the president's discretionary use for state affairs.
The collection consists of invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic projects from 2002 to last December.

Chen asked for the return of the collection Sept. 6 on the grounds that the collection were "strictly confidential" information under the protection of the Classified National Security Information Protection Act and should be kept secret permanently.

The president said in his petition that the collection was labeled "strictly confidential" in line with CGJ Ruling No. 627, which confirms the president's constitutional right to decide what constitutes a state secret and his right to refuse disclosure, also known as "state secrets privilege."

In a news release issued Oct. 5, the Presidential Office said the District Court has no power to deny the president's right to proclaim that the court-held collection of documents are "strictly confidential" since the grand justices have already confirmed the president's "state secrets privilege."

Even if the exercise of the "state secrets privilege" should be subject to judicial scrutiny, the news release said it should be conducted by a more suitable judicial organ rather than the District Court.

Regretting that the District Court made many biased allegation and judgments in its ruling about the pending "state affairs fund" case, the press statement said the District Court is by no means an appropriate agency to decide whether the collection of documents in question should be returned to the Presidential Office.

The Presidential Office further said that as the District Court has a vested interest in the outcome of the ruling on the "ownership" of the collection, it should not be permitted to issue a ruling on the case given the potential conflict of interest.

The Presidential Office also rebutted the District Court's "false allegations" that the president's move to proclaim the collection secret was merely aimed at covering up the defendants' wrongdoings. Making such a premature judgment is in obvious violation of the Criminal Procedure Law, which stipulates that all defendants be considered innocent before a final ruling is handed down.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pinkeye outbreak reveals personal hygiene issues

TEXT.P: The outbreak of pinkeye syndrome reveals that the personal hygiene habits of Taiwanese people are not up to the standards of advanced countries like America and Japan, Steve Kuo, director-general of Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health said Monday.
The outbreak also implies that Taiwan should make greater efforts to prepare to counter "more terrible" viruses than the one involved in this particular disease, Kuo said.

Kuo made the remarks at a news conference held by opposition Kuomintang legislators Kuo Su-chun and Hsieh Kuo-liang at the Legislative Yuan. Hsieh complained that the Department of Health has not been able to control the spread of pink-eye syndrome--a form of acute conjunctivitis--in real time.

Hsieh pointed out that the syndrome started spreading throughout southern Taiwan and Keelung City in northern Taiwan Oct. 4, but the CDC procrastinated its sample collection and inspection activities until Oct. 8, and thus delayed its confirmation of the presence of Coxsackie A24 virus--the culprit responsible for of the disease--until Oct. 11.
Kuo replied that including pink-eye syndrome in the infectious disease system would help improve the efficiency of epidemic disease prevention and cure.

He estimated that it takes about three months to control the disease and at least one month to cool down its spreading situation. He also added that over 10 thousand people have been infected with the disease.

Kuo said the Ministry of Education will work together with DOH to prevent the spread of the disease. Schools will enhance their efforts to educate students about the disease, and teach students good hygiene habits.

He called on the public to avoid sharing towels, hand-to-eye contact, and eye medicine, and to wash their hands thoroughly before and after contact with their eyes. He also reminded people to reduce the amount of time spent in public places to reduce the odds of infection, and suggested that students infected with the virus should temporarily stop going to schools to avoid contributing to new infection clusters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government lowers targeted number of foreign visitors by 1 million

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has revised downward next year's targeted number of foreign visits to Taiwan by one million as the number of Japanese visitors to Taiwan is not increasing at the anticipated rate, a bureau official announced Monday.

Despite the reduced growth, the number of Japanese travelers to Taiwan still grew by 2.23 percent so far this year, while that of Japanese visitors to South Korea and Singapore showed negative growth, Bureau Director General Janice Lai said.

However, Lai admitted that it is difficult to reach this year's goal of 3.75 million foreign visits to Taiwan, particularly due to the lower than expected number of Japanese tourists coming to Taiwan.
Japanese travelers to Taiwan make up one third of the country's total foreign visitors, Lai said.

According to Lai, as of September, the total number of foreign visits to Taiwan has reached 2.7 million, up from the same period of last year. To reach this year's target, the bureau needs additional 1.05 million foreign visits in the remaining three months.
The bureau has revised its plan aimed at boosting the development of local tourism industry between 2007 and 2009, and now aims to realize annual growth of seven percent, Lai noted.

Under the revised plan, the bureau hopes to increase the number of foreign visits to Taiwan to four million by 2008, and 4.25 million by 2009, Lai said, adding that the plan does not include Chinese tourists who are currently not allowed to travel directly to Taiwan from China.
The plan is part of a tourism-boosting project launched by the Executive Yuan in 2002 with the aim of doubling foreign visits to Taiwan to 5 million by 2008.

During the first eight months of this year, foreign visits to Taiwan from Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore, and Malaysia all reported an increase, while the number of U.S. visitors to Taiwan fell, Lai said, attributing the increase to many years of governmental efforts.

The bureau's figures show that in recent years, the number of foreign visitors arriving in Taiwan on a tourist visa has increased by 73 percent from 870,000 in 2000 to 1.51 million in 2006, Lai went on.
Lai forecast that the number of visitors will further rise to 1.75 million next year.

However, in recent years, the number of foreign tourists with a business visa has dropped, Lai said, pointing out that during the period between January- September of this year, the number of foreigners making business trips to Taiwan posted a year-on-year decline of 2.38 percent.

Lai also said she hopes that the Legislative Yuan will approve the bureau's proposal to increase its budget next year by NT$1.1 billion (US$36 million) . She added that NT$600 million of that would be used to enhance the international profile of tourism in Taiwan.
Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the Travel Agents Association of R.O.C., Taiwan, for his part, urged the government to lift a ban on Chinese tourists to Taiwan as soon as possible.
Meanwhile, Hsu also called for an increase to the government's budget for international marketing, which he claims could generate high returns.

In addition, Hsu suggested the government grant visa-free access to visitors from Thailand, train Korean-speaking tour guides, and increase the bi- directional passenger rate of local charter flights to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 16, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospects of further executions by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the Israeli state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: Republic of China government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy of moving carefully and steadily in a step-by-step fashion.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty some two weeks earlier of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat and politician, dies at the age of 78. As U.S. secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program, often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti- revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six- Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a U.S. military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Prize winner for literature, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blacking out London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC navy's destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after 31 years of service.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh says that he feels no remorse for having thrown his weight behind President Chen Shui-bian in the later stages of the presidential campaign in March of the same year.
2001: Taiwan atmospheric scientists successfully obtains vital typhoon data by flying two remote-control aircraft close to the depression's eyewall, a world first for any flying object collecting meteorological information.
2001: A Taipei delegation leaves for Indonesia to attend the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival in Jakarta.
2001: Taiwan's Picvue Electronics, Ltd. invests US$12 million to engage in research and development of crystal display plates with two Scottish manufacturers.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-graft leader wants Assembly and Parade Law abolished

TEXT.P: The leader of an anti-graft campaign told a trial court Monday that the Assembly and Parade Law should be abolished because it infringes on the constitutional rights of the people of Taiwan.

Shih Ming-teh, leader of tens of thousands of red-clad protesters who tried to depose scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian late last year, made the remarks while defending himself and 15 other anti-graft leaders on the first day of a trial at the Taipei District Court.

The 16 defendants, who pleaded not guilty, were indicted on charges of violating the Assembly and Parade Law on the Oct. 10 National Day last year when they led tens of thousands of supporters to besiege the Presidential Palace in an attempt to force the president to step down.

Shih expressed strong disagreement with the prosecution's charge that he had committed a crime by leading the protestors in a street parade. He contended that it is the people's constitutional right to oppose corruption -- a right recognized in the 2003 United Nations Convention Against Corruption.
He said the protest parade ended peacefully and should be seen as having set a "textbook example" of the proper conduct of mass demonstrations.

Shih, who served as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party between 1994 and 1996 before quitting the party in 2000, said that if found guilty by the lower court, he will not appeal, but will serve his term in prison.

Saying that he has fought for freedom, human rights and justice for the Taiwanese people all his life, Shih expressed confidence that even if he is found guilty, history and the Taiwan people will do him justice one day.
Shih was imprisoned twice between 1962 and 1989 for a total of 25 years under the Kuomintang's previous authoritarian regime. He has been described by supporters as "Taiwan's Mandela."

He initiated the "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign in September last year after a public prosecutor indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of corruption and forgery and named President Chen as a "joint perpetrator."

Although the president is protected by the Constitution from being tried while he is in office, the trial of his wife and five other defendants, including two former senior presidential aides and two Presidential Office officials, has continued at the Taiwan District Court since Dec. 15 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President appeal to reclaim documents of 'state affairs fund' case

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's lawyer filed an appeal with the Taipei District Court Monday for reclamation of a collection of documents and articles held by the court in the probes of a "state affairs fund" misuse case, in which first lady Wu Shu-jen is a defendant.

Chen Chuan-yueh filed the appeal on behalf of President Chen after the district court handed down a ruling Oct. 5 that rejected the president's request for the return of the collection on the grounds that the president's labeling of the collection as "strictly confidential" as illegal.

According to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Ruling No. 627 issued June 15, the Taiwan High Court is obliged to form a special tribunal to deal with a dispute between the president and the prosecution or a district court over the exercise of the president's "state secrets privilege."

A court official said the District Court will hand over the appeal to the High Court as soon as possible to seek a solution to the dispute. In accordance with the CGJ constitutionality ruling, the district court has temporarily suspended trial of the "state affairs fund" case pending a ruling by the High Court on whether the collection of documents should be returned to the Presidential Office.
In preparation for the president's appeal, the High Court already unveiled last Monday the rosters of eight special tribunals qualified to handle the case.

The High Court will decide by drawing lots which special tribunal will be authorized to mete out a ruling on the appeal. In line with the CGJ stipulations, each tribunal is composed of five judges, one of whom must have served as chief judge for at least 10 years.
Speaking at a news conference, the president's lawyer outlined several key reasons for filing the appeal against the District Court ruling:

-- In terms of the CGJ constitutionality rulings No. 328 and 419, the president's "state secrets privilege" is beyond the scrutiny of the judicial branch because its exercise involves military, diplomacy and national security affairs.

-- The CGJ ruling No. 627 handed down June 15 that confirms the president's "state secrets privilege" does not empower a general court to examine the president's proclamation of a document or a diplomatic mission as confidential that should be kept secret. The practices or precedents set forth in the U.S. Watergate case could not be employed in President Chen's case as the Watergate case didn't involve any national security, diplomatic or defense interests.

-- The CGJ No. 627 ruling clearly states that the president should be given the opportunity to explain or give supplementary explanations whether national security and interests are at stake in disclosure of the collection of documents in question.
-- Any dispute between the president and the judicial branch over exercise of their respective powers should be dealt with by the CGJ, not the district court.
-- The exercise of president's "state secrets privilege" does not restrict to those prescribed in the Classified National Security Information Protection Act.

The District Court obtained the collection of documents and articles from a prosecutorial team that indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen and three former and incumbent presidential aides last November on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund, " a special allowance fund set aside for the president's discretionary use for state affairs.
The collection consists of invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic projects from 2002 to last December.

Chen asked for the return of the collection Sept. 6 on the grounds that the collection were "strictly confidential" information under the protection of the Classified National Security Information Protection Act and should be kept secret permanently.

The president said in his petition that the collection was labeled "strictly confidential" in line with CGJ Ruling No. 627, which confirms the president's constitutional right to decide what constitutes a state secret and his right to refuse disclosure, also known as "state secrets privilege."

DOC.HEADLINE: Torch relay open to all parties: GIO

TEXT.P: The upcoming round-the-nation torch relay to promote the country's bid to join the United Nations is open to all political parties, ethnic groups and people of all ages, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.
Opposition parties, including the Kuomintang, are welcome to participate in the 11-day event, Shieh said.
The relay will kick off at 7 a.m. Oct. 24 in front of the Presidential Office on Ketagalan Boulevard in downtown Taipei, with President Chen Shui-bian leading the pack, Shieh said.

Noting that Oct. 24 is of historic significance as the U.N. Charter entered into force Oct. 24, 1945, Shieh said the GIO has picked the day to launch the torch relay to send the world a clear message that the people of Taiwan want representation in the world body.

"We would also like to use the occasion to voice our protest against the U.N. snub to our membership application, " Shieh said, adding that its denial of Taiwan's access has violated its principle of membership universality and its promise of safeguarding basic human rights.

Shieh, Sports Affairs Council Chairman Yang Chung-ho and several outstanding athletes jointly lighted a symbolic torch at a news conference Monday to promote the event and invite people from all walks of life to attend.
Yang said 17 athletes and celebrities will carry the torch through 25 counties and cities around the country, including the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.

Besides pushing for the country's U.N. membership bid, Yang said the 11-day torch relay is also aimed at encouraging people to take more exercise. The 1,200-km torch relay is expected to attract at least 100,000 participants, Yang said, adding that those interested in the vent are welcome to take part in the relay in the cities or townships at their convenience.
Meanwhile, Shieh said the GIO will put up advertisements or commercials before Oct. 24 to invite local citizens to organize teams to join the road run.
The event is scheduled to conclude at 6: 30 p.m. Nov. 3 when the torch will return to the Presidential Office plaza.

Responding to press inquiries about the government's stance toward Chinese President Hu Jintao's call for an end to cross-strait enmity and for the signing of a peace agreement under its "one China" principle, Shieh said Taiwan will not negotiate with a regime that kills its own people, suppresses Tibet and backs Myanmar's military junta.

Stressing that human rights and democracy are the foundation of the country, Shieh said if the Beijing leadership really wants to entrust its hopes on the people of Taiwan, it should listen to them and realize what price Taiwan people have paid for human rights and democracy.

While Taiwanese and Chinese people can stand together for democracy and human rights, Shieh reiterated that Taiwan's government will never discuss peace, unification or other issues with a regime that bullies and oppresses Tibet, kills its own people and supports the military junta in Myanmar.
