DOC.HEADLINE: DPP announces new department chiefs

TEXT.P: Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will serve as the new director of the party's Culture and Information Department, while another DPP lawmaker, Hsiao Bi-khim, will head the party's International Affairs Department, according to the DPP's new secretary-general, Cho Jung-tai.

Cho made the announcement at a news conference Monday morning after accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on an inspection tour of the DPP headquarters. It was Chen's first visit to the party's headquarters since he agreed to assume the party chairmanship last Thursday.

Cho said Legislator Wang Tuoh will serve as the executive director of the DPP's Policy Research and Coordinating Committee, Legislator Huang Sue-ying will be director of the Women's Development Department, and Legislator Cheng Kuo-chung will head the party's democracy school.
Meanwhile, Cho said that former DPP Taipei City Councilor Ko Ching-sheng will head the DPP Secretariat and former party lawmaker Hsiao Yu-chen will lead the Social Development Department.

The incumbent chiefs of the Youth Development Department, the Ethnic Affairs Department, the Organizational Development Department, the Financial Management Committee, and the Information Survey Center are likely to stay on their posts, but a final decision is still pending, Cho said.
He added that a changeover ceremony will be held Wednesday when the party's Central Standing Committee holds its regular weekly meeting.

On Monday, Cho also announced that Liu Chien-sin, a former vice minister of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, and former Taipei City Councilor Lan Shi-tsung will be the party's deputy secretaries-general in charge of publicity and organizational affairs, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier urges communication on policy to stamp U.N. bid logo on mail

TEXT.P: Relevant authorities need to increase communication with the public on a recently implemented controversial policy of stamping mail with a logo promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

Chang said the authorities should try to make the public understand that the government has opted to use the method to promote the bid because Taiwan has had no access to international organizations and that it is very important for Taiwan to be included in these organizations.
Since the start of this month, Taiwan Post Co. has stamped the "U.N. for Taiwan" logo on some domestic mail and international mail at random each day.

However, the United Daily News reported Tuesday that an American teaching English in Taiwan protested what he called the "dictatorial practice" of using private mail as a promotional item of the ruling party after he discovered that a letter he recently mailed to his fiancee in the United States was stamped with the logo.

In response, Chang said he thinks it is "very appropriate" for the authorities to use the logo on mail since joining the United Nations is the mainstream opinion among Taiwan's citizens and is also an official policy of the government.
Chang said he believes the authorities will evaluate public reaction to the measure in deciding whether to carry on with it.
Also Tuesday, at the request of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Taiwan Post Co. President Wu Min-you promised that the company will review the policy and produce a report within a week.
According to Wu, the policy of stamping the logo on mail, which is scheduled to continue until Dec. 31, was made by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the company.

Wu argued that there is nothing inappropriate about the policy as a majority of the people in Taiwan support the U.N. bid, adding that the company has in the past stamped other promotional logos on mail, such as the one promoting the fight against the SARS outbreak in 2003 and the one promoting a campaign against vote buying in 2004.

Disagreeing with Wu, KMT Legislator Kuo Su-chun claimed the drive to apply for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan is one initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to boost the party's 2008 presidential campaign, which she said has nothing to do with the government's policy.

Meanwhile KMT Legislators Shuai Hua-min and Wu Yu-shen said that Taiwan Post Co. has no right to express any political positions on behalf of the people and that the company's policy has violated the people's freedom of speech.

The DPP has been pushing for a referendum to be held alongside the next presidential election on whether to use the name Taiwan to join the United Nations, while the KMT has been pushing for a referendum on the Republic of China applying to return to the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan financial supervisor to attend IAIS annual conference

TEXT.P: Susan Chang, vice chairwoman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), will lead a Taiwan insurance business delegation to attend the 14th annual conference of the International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) to be held in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Oct. 16-19.
Chang arrived in New York Sunday evening. She visited the FSC New York office Monday.

Chang said that more than 500 delegates of financial supervisors from 90 countries will attend the IAIS annual conference this year. In addition, 160 representatives of insurance companies and international organizations will attend as observers.

The IAIS holds three meetings and a conference every year. At the 2006 conference, members of the association passed a resolution stating that the FSC will host the three meetings slated for 2010 in Taipei.
Chang said that the FSC has been active in international activities. In July 2008, the FSC will host the annual meeting of the International insurance Society for the first time.

Established in 1994, the IAIS represents insurance regulators and supervisors in some 180 jurisdictions. The IAIS issues global insurance principles, standards and guidance papers, provides training and support on issues related to insurance supervision, and organizes meetings and seminars for insurance supervisors.

The agenda of the 44th annual conference will feature international accounting standards, education project for insurance supervisors, creating supervisory and regulatory capacity in emerging markets, reinsurance, globalization, principle- based supervision, cross-sectoral risk transfer and securitization, and balancing insurance needs of urban and rural populations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier pledges to react responsibly to possible sanctions by China

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung pledged Tuesday that the government will react responsibly to any possible economic sanctions by China.

However, Chang said he cannot reveal any more details in public because the issue is one that concerns national security, stressing that no matter how China suppresses Taiwan, relevant authorities in the government will make their utmost efforts to protect the interests of the country's citizens.

The premier made the remarks during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan when he was asked whether the ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration is properly prepared for a possible escalation in cross-Taiwan Strait tensions and for possible moves by China to impose economic sanctions against Taiwan.

On the issue, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen said that in the event of China imposing economic sanctions, Taiwan should be able to find other markets to replace China in light of the island's strong export momentum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 60 points to close at 9,563, with 40,989 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November rose 62 points to finish at 9,577, with 21,501 contracts traded, while December futures increased 59 points to close at 9,578, with 72 contract transactions. March futures moved up 100 points to finish at 9,609, with eight contract transactions, while June futures gained 60 points to close at 9,599, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,503 for October, 9,515 for November, 9,519 for December, 9,509 for March and 9,539 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

October TE futures rose 2.9 points to close at 393.55, with 4,244 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 2.9 points to finish at 393.1, with 2,645 contract transactions. December TE futures dropped 0.25 points to close at 393, with three contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 2.65 points to finish at 392.55, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

October TF futures gained 1.6 points to close at 1,066.6, with 3,630 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 2.6 points to finish at 1,067.6, with 2,587 contracts traded. December TF futures dropped two points to close at 1,058, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Veltroni: Premier Prodi for full five-year term of legislature.
Secretary general-elect of the newly established Democratic Party Walter Veltroni said that his party would fully support Premier Romano Prodi's government to complete the five-year term of the current legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. study center to be set up

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will set up a center to study the United Nations Oct. 21 to help push for Taiwan's entry to the world organization, director of MOFA's Department of International Organizations Lin Yung-lo said Tuesday.

According to Lin, the Taiwan New Century Foundation will be responsible for planning the U.N. Study Center, which follows the establishment of the Asia- Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Study Center and the World Health Organization (WHO) Study Center set up also by MOFA.

There will be a seminar held at the inauguration ceremony for the U.N. Study Center to discuss means of combining the efforts of the people of Taiwan in pushing for the country's early entry to the United Nations, Lin added.

Regarding Taiwan's achievements in promoting its entry to the U.N. under the name Taiwan for the first time this year, Lin said the fact that the United States did not speak unfavorably of Taiwan's U.N. bid at the just concluded U.N. General Assembly boded well for Taiwan, while Taiwan's media campaign and the support shown by its allies produced results close to the targets originally set by the government, Lin said.

As for next year's plans, Lin went on to say that the MOFA will pay special attention to the attitudes of the United States, Japan and the European Union toward Taiwan's WHO bid next year, and work to make them understand that applying for U.N. or WHO membership under the name Taiwan is reflective of the will of the majority of Taiwan's people.

The Republic of China failed to re-enter the United Nations in all of its attempts since 1993 due to opposition from China, and this year it changed tactics by applying for a seat under the name Taiwan, although that too failed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA asks Beijing ease international squeeze on Taiwan

TEXT.P: Beijing should quit trying to squeeze Taiwan out of the international community if it truly wishes to display goodwill toward Taiwan, Wang Chien-yeh, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Wang made the comments in a MOFA news conference following Chinese President Hu Jintao's call for a cross-Taiwan Strait peace accord the day earlier during the opening of the Communist Party of China's 17th Congress in Beijing.

AFP quoted Hu as saying: "On the basis of the one-China principle, let us discuss a formal end to the state of hostility between the two sides, reach a peace agreement, construct a framework for the peaceful development of cross- strait relations and thus usher in a new phase of peaceful development."
The White House hailed Hu's remarks as a step forward in the resumption of cross-strait negotiations.

Although Hu's remarks sound softer this time around and are supposed to help build positive ties between Taiwan and China, Wang rebutted that Beijing must not make its "one-China" principle a precondition to the resumption of cross- strait negotiations because Taiwan is an independent and sovereign democracy, and its future must be determined by Taiwan's people.

If Beijing is really willing to show good faith to Taiwan, it should leave greater diplomatic room for Taiwan in the international community instead of applying a "zero-sum" rule and thereby upsetting cross-strait exchanges, Wang said.

The United States has long been supportive of reopening cross-strait negotiations and hopes that Beijing will hold talks with Taiwan's popularly elected government rather than opposition party leaders, he noted.

Whether or not Taiwan and China are able to rekindle bilateral negotiations will depend on China's ensuing actions, and the MOFA will continue closely watching its follow-up moves after the close of the Chinese communists' 17th Congress, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Male victims of domestic violence on the rise

TEXT.P: The number of male victims of domestic violence is on the rise, with 7,000 incidents against men reported in the first half of the year, representing 21 percent of the total, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Interior (MOI) Tuesday.

The figures show that a total of 10,294 men fell victim to domestic violence in 2005, representing 17 percent of the total. In 2006, the number of male victims soared to 11,763, comprising 18.5 percent of the total.
Although these figures exhibit an increasing tendency for men to be victimized, the vast majority -- 80 percent -- of domestic violence victims are women.

MOI statistics also show that there has been a substantial increase in the number of young boys suffering domestic abuse, with 4,300 cases reported against male children in 2005, and 5,500 in 2006: an increase of 28 percent year-on- year.

According to National Taiwan University Professor Wang Li-jung, who was commissioned by the MOI to study the issue, male victims were mostly often subject to some form of mental and emotional maltreatment rather than physical abuse.

An MOI spokesman said that since the government promulgated the Domestic Violence Prevention Act in June, 1998, the ministry has also stepped up its publicity efforts to encourage victims of domestic violence to seek professional assistance.

The spokesman added that the MOI has launched the round-the-clock 113 hotline and helped local governments around the country establish domestic violence prevention centers to provide assistance to victims in a timely manner.
He encouraged male victims of domestic violence not to be embarrassed to admit being victimized, and not to be shy about asking for help from every possible source.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices opened low but closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 74.02 points to close at 9,592.47.
The bourse opened at 9,468.88 and fluctuated between 9,618.03 and 9,461.27 during trading. A total of 5.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$157.34 billion (US$4.82 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.9 percent, textile stocks at 1.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 2.7 percnet, followed by construction issues at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 833, with 256 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Newly-discovered planet named after Chiayi

TEXT.P: A minor planet newly discovered by the Lulin Observatory of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County, has been formally named Chiayi--the name of the southern Taiwan county that houses the observatory, NCU President Lee Lou-chuang said Tuesday.

The observatory officially adopted the name Monday, after the International Astronomical Union's Committee on Small Body Nomenclature approved an application from the observatory to name the planet after Chiayi Sept. 26, Lee said.
Lee said the planet was so named in order to express gratitude to local aboriginal people for their assistance to the observatory during the early stages of its establishment.

The planet, about 2.4 kilometers in diameter, was spotted between Mars and Jupiter by Lulin Observatory Director Lin Hung-chin Oct. 25 in 2006, with great assistance from Yie Chuan-chih, a student at the Sun Yet-sen University in Guangzhou City in China.

Lin said planet Chiayi's orbit brings it within 280 million kilometers of the Sun and as far as 420 million kilometers distant. It takes 3.62 years for the planet to complete its path around the Sun, Lin added.

NCU Vice President Ip Wing-huen said the observatory started its "Lulin Sky Survey" (LUSS), a systematic sky scouting project in March in 2006, and that more than 450 minor planets have been discovered so far. For an observatory using a telescope of one meter in diameter, that performance is rather excellent, according to Ip.

Ip said NCU's Graduate Institute of Astronomy joins an international research project, Pan-STARR, which is aimed at finding new small planets or comets in order to establish the world's most thorough observatory system of astronomical phenomena.

The project was organized by University of Hawaii with authorization of the U.S. Department of State, Ip said, adding that Taiwan is the only Asian team in the project, which has also been joined by university teams from America, Germany, and Britain.

The NCU will spend about NT$130 million (US$3.98 million) to purchase a new two- meter telescope, which will be completed and installed in 2010 when the planet will be best viewed from the observatory. The new telescope will be available for public use, to view the planet and other astronomical phenomena, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally developed oral vaccine for fish to be used in Saudi Arabia

TEXT.P: A new type of oral vaccine developed by National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in the southern city of Tainan to protect fish against various viral infections will be used in Red Sea waters off the coast of Saudi Arabia, a spokesman of the university said Tuesday.
The announcement came after NCKU President Michael M. C. Lai signed a cooperation agreement with DevCorp Chairman James Greenberg at a hotel in Taipei earlier in the day.
Lai predicted that the agreement will generate a production value of approximately NT$60 billion (US$1.8 billion).

According to test results, the world-leading vaccine technology developed by the university's biotechnology team can effectively lower the death rate of fish fries and in turn reduce the use of antibiotics, Lai noted.
The vaccine has also been successfully applied to production systems for developing highly disease-resistant fish fries, Lai said, adding that the success rate could surpass 80 percent.
The vaccine has resolved the long-term bottleneck in the local fish aquaculture industry and greatly enhanced the development of the industry, Lai continued.
In the past, oral vaccines were often mixed with artificial feed for fish, which according to members of the research team neither produced satisfactory results nor could be used on fish fries.
DevCorp, the founder and the operator of Saudi Arabia's Venture Development Fund, has been actively promoting collaboration projects between Asia and the Middle East recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: Live-fire exercise in Matsu open to public view

TEXT.P: The Matsu Defense Command will stage a live-fire sea exercise near Nangan, one of five major islands of the outlying Matsu island chain, on Oct. 30, a spokesman for the command announced Tuesday.
The spokesman said tourists and local residents are welcome to view the hour- long live-fire "Wanping Exercise," from 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. Oct. 30 from a playground of Matsu Senior High School.
Weapons to be used will include 120mm caliber heavy mortars, 20mm machine guns, the M2HB-QCB.50 caliber heavy machine gun, and the M249 squad automatic weapon.
An exhibition of the weapons used by the command will take place simultaneously at the high school.

The spokesman said the command has set two periods -- from 6:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Oct. 26 and Oct. 29 -- for rehearsals, and that operators of fishing boats and aircraft are warned not to approach the restricted area.
He added that officers from the defense command will give a detailed explanation of the exercise and the rehearsals at Matsu Senior High School on Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.001 to close at NT$32.597.
A total of US$1.35 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.518 and hit a high of NT$32.695.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen urges China to abandon 'one China' principle

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that Beijing has to give up its "one China" principle prior to seeking to sign a peace agreement with Taiwan.
In addition, China must also abandon its "anti-secession law" and dismantle its deployment of more than 900 missiles targeting Taiwan, Chen stressed.

Chen put forth the conditions for signing of the cross-Taiwan Strait peace agreement during his visit to Keelung, northern Taiwan, earlier in the day in response to Chinese President Hu Jintao's call Monday for the formation of a framework for peaceful development of cross-strait relations "on the basis of the one China principle."
If Taiwan accepts Hu's call, the result will not be peace but Taiwan's surrender, Chen claimed.
The president also underlined: "Taiwanese are not Chinese and vice versa."
Meanwhile, regarding Hu's call for talks to end cross-strait hostilities, Vice President Annette Lu said she hopes the two sides can deal with each other "on a cooperative and complementary basis."
Lu made the remarks in response to media inquiries in Nantou southern Taiwan.
Lu said she had not yet thoroughly read the Hu's call, but it sounded "gentler" than she had expected.

In the current international state, no one will tolerate acts that damage world order, therefore she suggested the two sides begin to seek to create "healthy and normal" cross-strait relations based on the the principles of "goodwill, mutual equality and mutual benefit."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi fares in Taipei, Keelung to go up in November

TEXT.P: Taxi fares in Taipei City will be hiked beginning Nov. 1, officials of the Taipei city government's Department of Transportation said Tuesday.
Cab fares in neighboring Taipei County and Keelung City are also expected to rise as taxi drivers in the two areas have traditionally followed the rates adopted in Taipei City.
The announcement came after the Taipei city government approved a proposal to raise the city's cab fares at a meeting earlier in the day. The last adjustment was made seven years ago.
After the adjustment, the current night-time fare will apply around the clock, while an additional NT$20 will be charged between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m., the officials said.

Furthermore, during the day-time period of Chinese New Year holidays, an additional NT$20 will be added to the new regular fare per ride while during the night-time period, an additional NT$40 will be charged, the officials explained.

The adjustment does not involve changing fare meters and allows for the starting fare to be raised to NT$70 for the first 1.25 kilometers, after which an additional NT$5 will be required for every following 250 meters, the officials went on.
An additional NT$5 will also be required for every 1 minute and 40 seconds of waiting time, according to the officials.
In addition, the transportation department decided to cancel a NT$10 surcharge for opening the taxi trunk and for telephone booking, the officials noted.
Noting that there are around 60,000 taxies in Taipei and Keelung, the officials said that stickers will be put on the taxies as part of the efforts to inform the public of the price hike.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait financial seminar opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 13th cross-strait financial seminar opened in Taipei Tuesday, with the number and level of participating Chinese financial officials among the highest in years.
The two-day symposium was jointly sponsored by Taipei-based Taipei Foundation of Finance, Chung-Hwa Institute for Economic Research and Beijing-based Banking Society of China.
Ko Chen-en, chairman of the Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research, urged the participants to share with each other the problems and challenges faced in their respective financial markets.

Yi Kang, assistant governor of the People's Bank of China and head of the Chinese delegation, noted that between 1978 and 2006, China's gross domestic product averaged growth of around 9.7 percent, which was considered a miracle by other countries.
The Chinese currency, the yuan, was pegged to the U.S. dollar between 1996 and 2005, but since July 21, 2005, has appreciated against the greenback by around 11 percent, Yi said.

On the major problems faced by Chinese economy, Yi pointed to the sharp increase in investment, the huge trade surplus, the high consumption of resources, and serious pollution, all of which the Chinese government needs to address.

Yi's 20-odd delegation included ranking officials of the People's Bank of China, Import and Export Bank of China Vice President Su Zhong, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Vice President Li Xiaopeng as well as chiefs of other financial institutes.
Zhu Yunlai, a son of former Chinese Premier Zhu Ronggi, also came in his capacity of the CEO of China International Financial Corp.
Topics discussed Tuesday included Taiwan's current monetary policy, the central bank's management strategy, and the currency policy options for China given the current influx of capital.

The Taipei Foundation of Finance said the seminar will also discuss issues related to the reasons for the accumulation of foreign exchange reserves, financing for the small- and medium-sized enterprises, corporate governance of commercial banks, solicitation of private equity funds, the capital market and the underwriting business as well as insurance operators facing an aging society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
After the seminar, the Chinese delegation is expected to call on Taiwan's major financial institutions, including banking, securities, insurance operators, before leaving Taiwan Oct. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'One China' prerequisite key barrier to peace accord: premier

TEXT.P: Beijing's "one China" principle is the key barrier to forging a peace accord across the Taiwan Strait, and Taiwan cannot accept political obstructions to open bilateral negotiations on such an accord, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.
Chang made the remarks in response to a question by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Tseng Tsahn-deng during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Chinese President Hu Jintao called for a one China-oriented peace accord between Taiwan and China, a formal end to the state of hostility between Taiwan and China and the construction of a framework for the peaceful development of cross- strait relations a day earlier at the opening of the Communist Party of China's 17th Congress in Beijing.

Taiwan's future is in the hands of its people and Beijing's "one China" prerequisite goes against the so-called Taiwan-centric notion among the people, Chang asserted to reporters outside the Legislative Yuan following the legislative session.

The premier lamented Beijing's insistence on the "one China" policy and argued that taking such a politically charged position marks no departure from Beijing's past stance and is not helpful to the improvement in cross-strait ties.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Cheng Ming-tong read a press release to reporters stating that "Beijing's adhesion to the 'one China' condition has created an astounding political barrier to peace negotiations between the two sides."

"If Hu is really intent on forging peace across the strait, he must recognize the historical and existential fact that Taiwan and China are separately ruled and do not belong to one another, " Chen went on.

He urged Beijing to forswear its "one China" precondition, scrap the anti- secession law, stop bullying Taiwan in international society and remove all its military units targeting Taiwan so as to begin formal negotiations with Taiwan's popularly elected government on making peace across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker urges permission for banks to invest in China

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called Tuesday for governmental permission for Taiwan's financial sector to invest in China.
Wang issued the call while giving a speech titled "The New Legislative Yuan and Taiwan's Future" during a seminar sponsored by the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei.

As it would be easier for Taiwan-based banks to break into the Chinese market than into the Japanese or European markets, the government should allow local banks and peripheral businesses to invest in China as part of their globalization efforts, Wang said, voicing his belief that the issue could be resolved in a piecemeal fashion by starting with signing memorandums of understanding with Chinese counterparts.
According to Wang, Taiwan is facing a crunch as it has increasingly been pushed aside amid fierce competition from neighboring countries and hit hard by a worsening economy at home.

Taiwan ranked last among Asia's four little dragons in 2006 and 2007 in terms of per-capita income, with Singapore's average income now double that of Taiwan, he pointed out. In a further sign of bad news, the central and local governments have collectively incurred financial debts of more than NT$4 trillion (US$123 billion) , he added.

The government should devote greater energy to improving Taiwan's economy instead of wasting time on politics, he said, suggesting the government lift restrictions on China-bound investment and allow Chinese capital to invest in the home market and open regular direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, among others.

Asked by reporters following the seminar when he would pay a visit to China, Wang replied that it might be better to do so after the March 22, 2008 presidential election and that he would like to talk over the above-mentioned issues with relevant Chinese officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for participation in U.N. bid torch relay

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged politicians across party lines Tuesday to take part in an upcoming nationwide torch relay promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations, which is set to begin Oct. 24 from Taipei.

Describing the bid as a policy with support across party lines, and an aspiration of the country's citizens, Chen said he hopes that all people will participate in the event regardless of political affiliation.
"There is only one Taiwan, and there is only one goal. I hope every one will work together to achieve something big," he said.
Chen made the remarks in response to reports that some local government chiefs from the Kuomintang have refused to take part in the event.

According to the relay route and itinerary released Monday by the Sports Affairs Council, Chen will lead the first leg from Taipei City to Taipei County, after the torch is ignited at 7 a.m. Oct. 24 on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
The 1,200-km relay, which will cover all 25 counties and cities around the country, is expected to take 11 days to complete.
Local government chiefs and people's representatives have also been invited to participate in the event.

Taiwan has tried without success since 1993 to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation. It suffered a fresh setback in its quest for representation in the world body last month as an item endorsed by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the world body to address Taiwan's membership application was excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

With promotion of the U.N. bid being a main policy plank of the Democratic Progressive Party administration, the Cabinet has decided to designate Oct. 24 -- the anniversary of the coming into force of the Charter of the United Nations which is celebrated internationally as United Nations Day -- as "Taiwan United Nations Day" and is pushing for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration Agency vows to safeguard human rights amid scandal

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) has vowed to protect the human rights of illegal foreign immigrants detained at the agency's centers around the country Tuesday amid reports that one of its officers was probed for abusing foreign laborers in his charge.
An agency spokesman said that the immigrants should and will be treated fairly.

Describing the scandal as an isolated case, the NIA spokesman said that there is no problem with the quality of the agency's staff and pledged that its staff members will face judicial charges for any misconduct.
The remarks came after Ma Yun-chie, an officer at the agency's detention center in the central city of Taichung, allegedly abused his power and mistreated two female foreign laborers.
The scandal broke out after the victims filed a complaint.

Upon learning of the incident, NIA Director Wu Chen-chi instructed his officials to collect relevant evidence, the spokesman said. However, Ma refused to cooperate and threatened to commit suicide, he went on.
The agency later asked prosecutors in Taichung to investigate the scandal, the spokesman noted, adding that Ma was detained after prosecutors questioned him.
The spokesman said that the agency has already relieved Ma of his position and will investigate whether his supervisors fulfilled their responsibilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung dance troupe's new show `Pet' to premiere Oct. 19

TEXT.P: The central Taiwan-based Acme Physical Dance Theater will celebrate its 10th founding anniversary by performing the premiere of its new show "Pet" in Taichung this week.
Two performances will be staged at 7:30 p.m. Oct. 19 and 20 at Taichung City's Chunashan Hall.

Troupe founder and artistic director Shih Gee-tze told reporters that in the show, the definition of "pet" has been expanded to cover many favored things in life for different people, including rag dolls for little girls, motorbikes for men obsessed with speed, name-brand clothing for rich women and drinking in a bar after work.

Shih said the show combines dance with music and drama, allowing the dancers, singers and actors to interact with dogs, cats and other "pets" and to use their body language to reflect various aspects of life for different people in a humorous way.

Acme Physical Dance Theater was established in June 1997 as the the first professional modern dance troupe based in Taichung. Since 2000, the group has been invited to perform in Malaysia, the United States, Australia, Russia and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas visits are necessary for president: official

TEXT.P: Overseas visits are necessary for the president to strengthen ties with other countries, and therefore so too are the costs of charter flights for such visits, an official of Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

The official made the remarks in response to questions from opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lien Chiang-fu over the high cost of chartering planes for President Chen Shui-bian's overseas trips and the effectiveness of Chen's visits to foreign countries since his inauguration in 2000.

According to Chiang, Chen has made 14 overseas visits, at a cost of NT$600 million (US$18.5 million) for charter flights during the last seven years. Chiang blasted Chen for draining the government's coffers for nothing.

The official explained that the government sets aside a budget each year for international conferences and exchanges, and NT$160 million is included to cover the costs of overseas visits by president, vice president, chiefs of five government branches, and special presidential envoys.

President Chen's chartering of planes for his overseas visits is in keeping with standard government practice, the official went on, citing the example of ex- premier Sun Yun-suan, who chartered a Boeing 747 to visit Central America in the 1980s, and former President Lee Teng-hui, who visited several countries using charter planes.

In consideration of Taiwan's increasingly limited development space in the international community due to China's pressure tactics, overseas visits by Taiwan's heads of states are imperative, especially given the number of foreign visits made by Chinese leaders, the official stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate proposes cross-strait talks based on '1992 Consensus'

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, suggested Monday that the two sides of Taiwan Strait begin talks on the basis of the "one China, respective interpretations" consensus reached in 1992.

The so-called "1992 Consensus" refers to an understanding the KMT claims to have reached in Hong Kong that there's only one China but that both sides are free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" actually means.
"What we think of the 'one China' means the Republic of China, " Mai said.

Ma suggested the two sides seek to end the state of hostility between them on the basis of the consensus. However, he noted that is only an agreement on maintaining peace across the strait, and "the future of Taiwan still has to be decided by Taiwanese people."

Ma made the remarks in Taitung, southern Taiwan, in response to media inquiries on Chinese President Hu Jintao's Monday proposal for a peace agreement between the two sides on the basis of the "one China" principle.

The former KMT Chairman said it has, for some time, been his idea that the two side should sign a peace agreement to end the state of hostility between them, and that the idea has been adopted by the KMT as a part of its party platform.

Asked whether he regarded Hu's report as a gesture of goodwill, Ma said that compared with Beijing's conducts in the past, he thinks the call for a peaceful development of cross-strait relations is an "improvement."

DOC.HEADLINE: Long-term unemployment rate drops significantly: CLA

TEXT.P: The long-term unemployment rate has dropped significantly, although the labor participation rates for the middle-aged and elderly need to be increased, a Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Tuesday.

The official made the remarks after the CLA compared employment statistics in 2006 released by 20 countries, including Japan, South Korea, Singapore, the United States, Canada, Mexico and major European Union countries.
The comparison is part of the council's efforts to further understand the differences between Taiwan's labor situation and that of other countries, the official noted.
The ratio of job seekers who had not been employed for over one year in Taiwan's total unemployment rate fell greatly from 17.3 percent in 2005 to 13.6 percent in 2006, the official said.
The ratio is lower than that of 13 out of the 20 nations, including Germany (57.2 percent) , Italy (52.9 percent) and Portugal (51.8 percent), the official went on.
The labor participation rate for people aged between 55 and 64 was 41.5 percent in Taiwan which, the official said, needs to be addressed although it is much better than Italy's 33.4 percent.
In the 1996-2006 period, Taiwan's labor force posted an average annual growth rate of 1.2 percent, which is on a par with the rates of South Korea and the United States, the official noted.
The official added that the rate is much higher than that of Japan, which reported negative growth, but far lower than that of Singapore (2.7 percent).

Taiwan's unemployment rate in 2006 recorded 3.9 percent, the third-lowest among the 20 countries, the official said, noting that in the same year, South Korea's unemployment rate was 3.4 percent, Japan's was 4.1 percent, Singapore's was 4.8 percent and that of the U.S. was 4.6 percent.
According to the statistics, the male labor participation rate of the 20 nations was roughly the same at around 70 percent, the official said.
Italy and France reported low male labor participation rates of 60.6 percent and 62.7 percent, respectively, the official went on.

Saying that there is an obvious difference in the female labor participation forces of the 20 countries, the official noted that the lowest rates were recorded in Italy and Mexico, with 37.9 percent and 40.7 percent, respectively.

Taiwan's female labor participation force amounted to 48.7 percent, which, according to the official, is higher than Japan's 48.5 percent but lower than the South Korea's 50.3 percent and Singapore's 54.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opt-out offer for U.N. bid slogan on mail: Taiwan Post

TEXT.P: Taiwan Post Co. officials said Tuesday that those who do not wish their mail to be stamped with a slogan promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations can mark their envelopes as such and that their wishes will be respected.
The officials said after a meeting that it will urgently request the Executive Yuan to offer instructions as to whether to stop stamping the words "U.N. for Taiwan" on mail.
Until the Executive Yuan gives a clear instruction, members of the public who refuse to allow their mail to be stamped with the slogan can mark their envelopes to indicate this, the officials said.
They added that the Post Office was following government policy and noted that as a state-owned enterprise, they could not do otherwise.
Since the start of this month, Taiwan Post Co. has stamped the "U.N. for Taiwan" slogan on some domestic mail and international mail at random each day.

Taiwan Post Co. President Wu Min-you said earlier Tuesday that the policy, which is scheduled to continue until Dec. 31, was drawn up by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the company.

Wu argued that there is nothing inappropriate about the policy, claiming that a majority of the people in Taiwan support the U.N. bid and adding that the company has in the past stamped other promotional slogans on mail, such as one promoting the fight against SARS during the outbreak of 2003 and another promoting a campaign against vote buying in 2004.

However, the United Daily News reported Tuesday that an American teacher of English in Taiwan had protested what he described as the "dictatorial practice" of using private mail as a promotional item for the ruling party after he discovered that a letter he recently mailed to his fiancee in the United States had been stamped with the slogan.
The teacher, surnamed Talovich, said the slogan fails to represent his position on the issue and that stamping his mail without his consent "infringed upon his freedom of speech."

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been pushing for a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid to be held alongside the presidential election next year, and the slogan "U.N. for Taiwan, Peace Forever" has been omnipresent recently on most government buildings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan people will not accept China's `two-faced' tactics: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister James Huang said Tuesday that the public will not accept China's "two-faced" tactics of offering peace overtures while squeezing Taiwan's space in the international community.

Huang made the remarks in response to Chinese President Hu Jintao's statement at the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China a day earlier that China will seek talks with Taiwan under the "one China" policy in the hope of ending the hostility and signing a peace agreement between the two sides.
Noting that although Hu made the remarks in a soft tone of voice full of goodwill, Huang said he needed to remind the Taiwan people of what he described as "Hu's real intention."
When Hu proposed peace talks, he remained silent about the severe diplomatic war between the two sides in the international community during the last several decades, Huang went on.

According to Huang, Hu said in his statement that China will "pin hope on the Taiwanese people" for the goal of unification. Huang questioned whether Beijing will continue its repression of Taiwan and its deprivation of the rights of the Taiwan people to gain a reasonable position in the international community while offering its peace overture.

He cited the example of the recent world cyber games held in Seattle, in which Chinese participants insulted a Taiwanese competitor who unfurled a Republic of China national flag on the winners podium after winning an award at the games.
Huang said that although he has noted Hu's softer tone toward Taiwan during the recent years, Beijing's repression of Taiwan has never been lightened.

He said that only when Beijing abandons its "one China" principle, abrogates its anti-secession law and dismantles the hundreds of missiles it has aimed at Taiwan will there be peaceful talks and real peace between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vote recount margin might be set at within 0.3 percent

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition lawmakers tentatively agreed Tuesday that if ballots collected by the winner and the closest rival in future elections have a margin of within 0.3 percent, a vote recount mechanism will be automatically activated.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng made the remarks after he convened a coordination meeting on a draft amendment on the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

He noted that the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus thinks the existing vote recount mechanism, which is activated by the Central Election Commission, is not objective and that the 1 percent margin between the rivals is too high.
The lawmakers finally agreed to lower the gap to within 0.3 percent, Wang said.

Laborious vote recounts have been conducted twice in recent years. In the 2004 presidential election, the KMT's Lien Chan filed two separate lawsuits in an attempt to annual the election and the election result after he lost to President Chen Shui-bian by 29,518 votes out of around 13 million ballots cast. Lien collected 6,442,450 votes against Chen's 6,471,770. A lengthy vote recount reduced the margin between the two to around 25,000 votes.

The KMT's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, Huang Chun-yin, also filed lawsuits against his rival, Chen Chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, after losing the mayoral election Dec. 9, 2006 by a margin of 1,114 votes. Chen still had the most ballots even after the recount.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kuishan Island hot spring enzyme able to produce biomass energy

TEXT.P: A research team with National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) in Keelung City has discovered an enzyme present at undersea hydrothermal vents near outlying Kuishan Island in Yilan County, which can be used in the production of biomass energy, Tzou Wen-hsiung, a professor of the school said Tuesday.

Tzou, a professor at the NTOU's Institute of Bioscience and Biotechnology, said at a news conference in Taipei City that the enzyme's function was discovered by research staff of NTOU's Center for Marine Bioscience and Biotechnology: an inter-disciplinary team responsible for integrating the school's resources and teaching faculty to conduct research.
Liu Hsiou-mei, professor of the school's Institute of Marine Biology, is among discoverers of the enzyme, Tzou said.

The enzyme, derived from Thermoanaerobacterium sp. NTOU2, can be used to decompose agricultural crops to produce biomass energy in the form of alcohol, Tzou said, adding that the school is applying for patent rights for the application of their research to industrial processes involving the enzyme.
He estimated that it will take about one year for the center to confirm the enzyme's chemical activity before it embarks on cooperative projects with industry.

Tzou said the center, which targeted its research to the application of enzymes to the production of biomass energy, found that Kuishan Island has a rare ecological system and enjoys unlimited marine resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI launches new energy-saving vehicle

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has officially launched its newly developed energy saving vehicle, dubbed the Ecooter, designed to create a driving trend in urban societies, an ITRI executive said Tuesday.

Wang Han-ying, chief of the Intelligent Vehicle Section under the ITRI's Mechanical and Systems Research Laboratories, said the design of the Ecooter is an integrated representation of advanced card making and information technologies developed by the ITRI.
Wang said the most notable design aspect of the Ecooter is its diamond-shaped four-wheel chasis system that allows the vehicle to make a 360-degree turn in a radius of just 1.2 meters.

A special self-leaning system prevents it from overturning when negotiating curves, making it very nimble in confined city areas, Wang said, adding that the small size of the vehicle -- it is designed to carry only the driver -- helps increase its ease of parking.
Moreover, Wang went on, the energy-saving vehicle uses electric power and is non-polluting, while its energy consumption is only one-third that of traditional vehicles.

The ITRI will continue to develop automotive electric motors and energy- intensive battery systems to be installed in the vehicle's wheels, in an effort to simplify its construction, and will keep creating variant designs to capitalize on its distinctive looks, Wang said.

The ITRI plans to debut the Ecooter at the International Motorcycle Exhibition to be held in Milan, Italy, in November, in order to seek cooperative projects with international vehicle manufacturers, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Yingge International Ceramics Festival reaches climax

TEXT.P: The 2007 Yingge International Ceramics Festival reached its climax Tuesday, with two world-renowned ceramics masters from abroad completing massive works in a ceramics park for public view.

French sculptor Jacques Kaufmann and American ceramics artist Doug Casebeer both used bricks for their creations, which shared a common theme of "family." Kaufmann's work is titled "Sweet Home," while Casebeer's piece is called "Safe."

Yingge township is well-known in Taiwan for its ceramics technology and production. The annual festival is intended by the Yingge Ceramics Museum to put Yingge on the world map as a town that produces high-grade ceramics.
The festival was originally scheduled to open Oct. 5, but the opening had to be postponed to Oct. 13 because of Typhoon Krosa. The event will continue until Oct. 21.

Organizers said they set "Wind and Water Brings Good Luck" as the theme for the 2007 festival, but did not expect such a huge wind along with five days of torrential rain, which they believe will bring luck to the town.
They added that the series of activities planned for the festival is ideal for the whole family and that the township government will provide free shuttle bus services for visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks 32nd in world in terms of press freedom

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 32nd in the world in terms of press freedom, up from the 43rd place it held last year, according to
the Worldwide Press Freedom Index 2007 released Tuesday by the Paris-based Reporters without Borders on its Web site.
Taiwan's ranking is better than Japan's, which was in 37th place, and the United States, which stood at 48th. China, meanwhile, came in at 163rd among the 169 countries measured in the index.
Iceland led the pack in first place, followed by Norway and Estonia, with Turkmenistan, North Korea and Eritrea bringing up the rear at the bottom of the list.

Of the 20 countries at the bottom of the index measruing the level of press freedom in 169 countries , seven are Asian ( Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Laos, Vietnam, China, Burma, and North Korea), five are African (Ethiopia, Equatorial Guinea, Libya, Somalia and Eritrea), four are in the Middle East (Syria, Iraq, Palestinian Territories and Iran) , three are former Soviet republics (Belarus, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan) and one is in the Americas (Cuba).
It is the sixth index published by the Reporters Without Borders in as many years.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Menzies Campbell out in brutal but bloodless coup Sir Menzies Campbell resigned suddenly as the Liberal Democrat leader last night in yet another convulsion for British politics. Vince Cable, the Treasury spokesman and deputy leader, has taken over as acting leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Big U.S. Banks Try to Restore Confidence in Credit Markets
The biggest banks in the United States, with active encouragement from the Treasury Department, unveiled a plan yesterday to keep the housing-related debt crisis from worsening.
The Wall Street Journal: Bernanke Spots Relief in Markets
Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke signaled satisfaction that the central bank's recent actions have cushioned the economy from market turmoil, but he offered no clear signal on whether officials are inclined to cut rates again at their next policy meeting in two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Verizon Says It Turned Over Data Without Court Orders
Verizon Communications, the nation's second- largest telecom company, told congressional investigators that it has provided customers' telephone records to federal authorities in emergency cases without court orders hundreds of times since 2005.
The Washington Times: Bush urged to block merger
House Republicans have introduced legislation calling for the Bush administration to block the merger of a U.S. computer-security equipment company and a Chinese firm with close ties to Beijing's military and a history of illicit exports and industrial espionage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 17, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
2001: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum begins in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.
2001: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opens with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's FDI inflows hit record high for 2006
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/17/07 13:16:34 (By Y.C. Jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's inward foreign direct investment (FDI) amounted to a record high of US$7.42 billion for 2006, ranking sixth in South, East and Southeast Asia, according to the World Investment Report 2007 released Tuesday.

Taiwan ranked behind only China, Hong Kong, Singapore, India and Thailand in the region in terms of inward forward direct investment, according to the annual report, which was published by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).

Taiwan's inward foreign direct investment for 2006 marked an increase of 356 percent over the figure of US$1.62 billion for 2005 and an increase of 291 percent over the figure of US$1.89 billion for 2004.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's outward foreign direct investment totalled US$7.39 billion for 2006, ranking the country fifth in the region behind Hong Kong, China, India and Singapore. The amount marked an increase of 22.74 percent over the figure of US$6.02 billion for 2005 and a rise of 3.56 percent over the figure of US$7.14 billion for 2004.
For 2006, the total FDI inflows to South, East and Southeast Asia amounted to a record high of US$200 billion, marking an increase of 19 percent over the previous year's level.

The report shows that Taiwan ranked 119th in the world in terms of the Inward FDI Performance Index for 2006, while the country ranked 20th in terms of its Inward FDI Potential Index for 2005 -- the most recent year for which data is available.
Based on these results, Taiwan was placed in the category of "below potential" countries, which are defined as having high FDI potential but low FDI performance.
The Inward FDI Performance Index ranks countries according to the ratio of a country's share of global FDI inflows to its share of global gross domestic product (GDP).
The Inward FDI Potential Index is an average of the values of 12 variables expected to affect an economy's attractiveness to foreign investors.
A senior economist at the UNCTAD told the Central News Agency that "below potential" countries tend to be less dependent on FDI inflows in pursuing their development goals.

For example, the United States saw its Inward FDI Performance Index ranking somewhere around 120th for three consecutive years to 2006, although it maintained its top position in terms of its Inward FDI Potential Index for 2004 and 2005, the economist said.

He noted that Taiwan's Outward FDI Performance Index ranked 27th, 27th and 26th, respectively, for the three years between 2004 to 2006, which may indicate that Taiwan and its businesses tend to rely on outward FDI to enhance their international competitiveness.

Similarly, France ranked 87th, 78th and 74th, respectively, for the three years between 2004 and 2006, while the country's Outward FDI Performance Index ranked 19th, 16th and 17th for the same three years, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to keep striving to improve press freedom: Cabinet spokesman

TEXT.P: Commenting on Taiwan's continuously improving ranking in terms of press freedom among countries in the world, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday night that the administration will strive further to improve press freedom in the country.

Taiwan ranks first in Asian and 32nd in the world in terms of press freedom for 2007, according to the Worldwide Press Freedom Index 2007 released Tuesday by the Paris-based Reporters without Borders.
Taiwan ranked 43rd in the world in 2006 and 51st in 2005 in terms of press freedom, according to the Reporters without Borders.
Taiwan placed ahead of Japan, which ranked 37th in the world, and the United States, which ranked 48th, in the 2007 report. China, meanwhile, ranked 163rd overall in terms of press freedom.

Welcoming Taiwan's higher ranking, Shieh, who also serves as the minister of the Government Information Office, said this reflects the results of democratization in Taiwan, where human rights, freedom of speech and press freedom have been fully respected and protected.
"Taiwan's ranking of 32nd in the world in terms of press freedom represents the pride of all Chinese communities in the world," Shieh claimed.

He added, however, that there is still ample room for Taiwan to improve in this regard and that the administration will not become complacent about progress in Taiwan's world ranking in press freedom.

He added that the government will work to continue to improve press freedom while hoping that the international community will better perceive the progress that Taiwan has made in the areas of democratization, freedom and human rights.

In the Worldwide Press Freedom Index 2007, Iceland led the pack, followed by Norway, Estonia, Slovakia, Belgium, Finland, Sweden, Denmark, Ireland and Portugal, in that order. Turkmenistan, North Korea and Eritrea placed at the bottom of the list.

Of the 20 countries ranked lowest among the 169 countries surveyed, seven are located in Asia (Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Laos, Vietnam, China, Burma, and North Korea) , five are in Africa (Ethiopia, Equatorial Guinea, Libya, Somalia and Eritrea), four are in the Middle East (Syria, Iraq, Palestinian Territories and Iran), three are former Soviet republics (Belarus, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan) , and one is in the Americas (Cuba), according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier asks for review on treatment of detained foreign laborers

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that he has asked for a complete review of the way in which detained foreign laborers are treated following reports that an officer of the National Immigration Agency (NIA) abused foreign laborers in a detention center recently.

According to the reports, Ma Yun-chie, an officer at the agency's detention center in the central city of Taichung, allegedly abused his power and mistreated several female foreign laborers earlier in the month.

"The incident should not be taken lightly, nor should it be viewed as an isolated case," the premier said, adding that "regardless of whether those who are detained are victims of human smuggling rings or labor exploitation, they should not be subject to inhumane treatment."

He said the pursuit of human rights protection has been one of the major goals of his administration, stressing that "the protection of the basic rights of foreign laborers will be the same as that of citizens of the country."

The premier said that he has asked the Ministry of the Interior, which oversees the NIA, to get to the bottom of the alleged abuse incident and come up with measures to prevent the same thing from happening again.
The premier made the remarks in an Executive Yuan meeting during which he listened to a report by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on the protection of foreign laborers.

He asked the CLA to accelerate its efforts to push for implementation of its proposed measures of forming a direct hiring joint service center, improving the mechanism for foreign laborers switching to new employers, establishing a data base of foreign laborers changing employers, monitoring and punishing rogue employers, and setting up a mechanism for assessing foreign laborer brokerage agencies.
He said that the Executive Yuan approved late last year a comprehensive action plan that covers all forms of human trafficking and that it has asked relevant government agencies to execute the plan.

He urged the Ministry of the Interior to map out a draft bill on the prevention of human trafficking so as to flesh out an overall strategy for preventing such trafficking and for prosecuting traffickers in order to upgrade Taiwan's international image.

He noted that Taiwan's efforts to combat human trafficking have been recognized in the U.S. State Department's 2007 Trafficking in Persons report which was released in June, adding, however, that there is still room for improvement.

Taiwan has been reinstated on the list of "Tier 2" countries in the report because while the island's trafficking problems remain daunting, Taiwan authorities showed clear progress in addressing trafficking for both sexual and labor exploitation over the past year.
Taiwan was placed on the list of "Tier 1" countries in the 2003 and 2004 reports but was downgraded to "Tier 2" in the 2005 report.
In the 2006 report, Taiwan was placed on the "Tier 2 Watch List" for not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking.

While governments that fully comply with the minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking are placed in "Tier 1, " governments that are making significant efforts to meet the minimum standards are placed in "Tier 2."
Governments that do not fully comply with the minimum standards and are not making significant efforts to do so are placed in "Tier 3" and may be subject to certain sanctions.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate urged to stop pushing for U.N.-bid referendum

TEXT.P: A civic group urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, Wednesday to stop pushing for a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

The Action Alliance Against U.N.-Bid Referendum called for Hsieh to instead come up with a campaign platform which would include policies on reviving the sagging domestic economy and improving the people's livelihood.
Members of the alliance called for the DPP administration to put the funds that would be used for holding a U.N.-bid referendum toward programs aimed at improving the people's livelihood.

Responding to Hsieh's remarks made recently that the U.N. bid should take precedence over the economy "because the people are not animals and need dignity more than they need to be further stuffed with food, " Wu Jung-yuan, a convener of the alliance, asked Hsieh whether he is a human being or not. "Doesn't he need to eat?"

Wu said he believes that Hsieh made such a remark because he cannot handle or refuses to face the fact that the DPP administration has caused Taiwan's economic slump through its ineptitude and inefficiency.

Wu asked Hsieh to stop using rhetoric and political slogans and to instead offer an apology for making such an insulting remark to the Taiwan public, saying that most of the Taiwan people are dignified, hardworking and diligent citizens who do not deserve to be subjected to such verbal humiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down six points to close at 9,556, with 22,558 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November dropped nine points to finish at 9,570, with 40,671 contracts traded, while December futures moved down eight points to close at 9,570, with 52 contract transactions. March futures decreased 76 points to close at 9,533, with four contract transactions, while June futures rose 46 points to finish at 9,645, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 9,562 for October, 9,579 for November, 9,578 for December, 9,609 for March and 9,599 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

October TE futures gained 1.6 points to close at 395.1, with 3,116 contracts traded, while November TE futures rose 2.7 points to finish at 395.7, with 3,578 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 2.2 points to close at 395.2, with eight contract transactions, while March TE futures increased 0.45 points to finish at 393, with one contract traded. June TE futures rose 4.1 points to close at 393, with one contract traded.

October TF futures dropped 7.4 points to close at 1,058.8, with 2,509 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 10.8 points to finish at 1,056, with 3,577 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Homes for veterans to accept non-veterans: Cabinet official

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) will open its homes for veterans to the general public, sharing the resources with all needy senior citizens around the country, VAC Minister Hu Chen-pu said Wednesday.

Hu also revealed that the VAC is scheduled to open the facilities around the island from Friday, when Taiwan will celebrate the Double Ninth Festival which falls on the ninth day of the ninth month of the Chinese lunar calendar.
The festival has been celebrated in Chinese society since ancient time as a way of showing respect to the elderly.
Hu made the announcement in his report concerning the opening of the VAC-run nursing and health-care shelters exclusively for retired military personnel at a meeting of the Executive Yuan.
The new measure, Hu noted, is part of the "Mega Warmth" welfare program that former Premier Su Tseng-chang initiated last October.

At a press conference following the meeting, Hu indicated that there are 18 homes for veterans around the country, which can accommodate 11,306 people in all. At present, there are a total of 1,400 vacancies at those homes.
Hu said it costs around NT$7,000 (US$214) per person per month to stay at the veterans home.
Hu speculated that the number of vacancies is expected to continue increasing as the average age of the current inmates is between 81 and 82.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's forex investment firm banned from investing in Taiwan: MAC

TEXT.P: China Investment Co. Ltd. -- China's state-controlled foreign exchange investment company -- is not allowed to invest in Taiwan's stock market, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Wednesday.
Chen noted that the capital held by the company is basically in the form of sovereign wealth funds and that most countries around the world are cautious about accepting such investment.

He made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Home and Nations Committee while commenting on statement made a day earlier in Beijing by China Investment Chairman Lou Jiwei that the company's investment targets cover all overseas markets, including Taiwan and Hong Kong.

The company was established directly under China's State Council, or Cabinet, last month to make use of the country's huge foreign exchange reserves, which topped US$1.4 trillion as of the end of September. The capital managed by the company is estimated at US$200 billion.
According to Chen, Lou's statement could be a "means of gaining publicity" and could also have "political motives."

Pointing out that Chinese capital is currently forbidden from being invested in Taiwan according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, MAC officials said that no matter the form of the investment, no capital from the company is permitted in Taiwan under the existing circumstances.

Meanwhile, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Investment Commission said that even if the company files an application with the commission to invest in Taiwan, the commission lacks any legal basis by which it could accept it.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to help DPP win at least 50 legislative seats

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, who assumed the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday, vowed at a handover ceremony that he will strive to help the ruling party win at least 50 seats in next January's legislative elections.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chen said that as DPP chairman, he will not shun his three major responsibilities: To help the DPP take at least 50 seats in the legislative elections and give the DPP-led "pan-green camp" a legislative majority; to help the DPP presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang get elected as the next president and vice president; and to enable the referendum on the retrieval of the opposition Kuomintang's ill-gotten assets and the referendum on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan to be held successfully.

The seventh legislature will be elected Jan. 12 in accordance with a new "single-member constituency, two-vote" electoral system, replacing the "multi- member constituency" system of the past. The number of seats will also be cut from 225 to 113, which will consist of 73 regional seats from 73 constituencies, six seats for aborigines and 34 seats for legislators at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.008 to close at NT$32.605.
A total of US$1.18 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.572 and hit a high of NT$32.674.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien community wins Presidential Cultural Award

TEXT.P: A community in the eastern country of Hualien won the prestigious Presidential Cultural Award Wednesday for its perseverance in efforts to seek the sustainable development of communities.

Starting with four couples and their families in 1996 who organized a classical poem and essay recitation class for children and a reading club for adults, the community in the Fengtien area of Shoufeng township in Hualien has made itself a role model in terms of community development over the past 11 years.

Members of the community -- who call themselves the Ox Plough Working Group -- have made business development, welfare and medicare, public order of the community, humanities and education, environmental protection and landscape building their six major duties necessary for securing sustainable development for their community.

The Ox Plough Working Group began to promote an "in-depth tour of Fengtien" program in 1998, which not only earns at least NT$1 million (US$30,675) per year for the community, but has also introduced the area to people from the rest of Taiwan.

In 2006, the community was selected by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs as one of the communities in the country entitled to government subsidies and guidance for the building of model communities.

Members of the community follow tacit rules that they do not talk about politics, religion or matters concerning personal interests while engaging in community activities. They also do not receive salaries for any work they do related to community activities.
