DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 30.31 points to close at 9,562.16.
The bourse opened at 9,582.19 and fluctuated between 9,616.26 and 9,492.89 during trading. A total of 4.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$143.84 billion (US$4.41 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile issues moving down the most at 2.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares at 1.4 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent, banking and financial issues and cement stocks both at 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 736, with 312 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taiwan Aboriginal Tribes Expo to take place in November

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taiwan Aboriginal Tribes Expo is scheduled to take place in Taipei Nov. 17-24, the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples announced Wednesday.
Council officials said the venue for the event is the Xinyi Public Assembly Hall, a civic space and exhibition area recently transformed from a former military dependents' village.
According to the officials, the exhibition, sponsored by the council, is intended to promote the cultures of the aboriginal tribes, their ways of life and the marketing of their products.

The exposition will have different areas for theme pavilions, stalls for the exhibition and sale of products made by aboriginal people, stands serving a wide range of aboriginal delicacies, and stage performances.
The officials said those interested in operating a stall or a stand should apply to the Council of Indigenous People before Oct. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 presidential race choice between Taiwan, China: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the 2008 presidential election will be a choice between "Taiwan consciousness" and "the Great China mentality."

According to Chen, the race will be a duel between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang, who follow a Taiwan-centric line, and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) ticket of Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew, who abide by a one-China policy.
Chen claimed that the election will also be a competition between a combination of a "five-star" former mayor and a "five-star" magistrate and a team featuring only one "four-star" former mayor.

"The DPP enjoys much better qualifications and more advantages than our rival. I'm confident we will win the election as long as we fight in unity and unselfishly for the goal, " Chen said while addressing the DPP's Central Standing Committee immediately after he was inaugurated as the party's chairman.

Chen outlined three major missions that he aims to achieve during his chairmanship, which include helping the DPP win at least 50 legislative seats in next year's legislative elections, helping the Hsieh-Su ticket win the 2008 presidential race, and ensuring the passage of the referendums on reclaiming the KMT's ill-gotten assets and on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Chen said that although the DPP has collected 1.2 million signatures for its referendum petition on the U.N. bid -- a number more than enough to make the petition valid, the party hopes to continue the drive to obtain 2 million signatures by the end of October.

He claimed that the referendum, which is expected to be held alongside the presidential election, is "definitely not intended" to boost the DPP's presidential campaign but to "protect the country's sovereignty and the well- being of its people."

As Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, it is excluded from international organizations such as the World Health Organization, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and is also not allowed to sign international treaties such as the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, Chen noted.

"As long as Taiwan is barred from the United Nations, Taiwan will continue to be treated as a non-existent country, and Taiwan's people will remain second-class citizens in the international community," he said.
Pointing out that China is the main obstacle in Taiwan's bid to join the world body, Chen said the most important meaning of the referendum will be to "say no" to China's bullying.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to open direct employment service center for foreign workers

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will open a direct employment joint services center Jan. 1 next year as part of efforts to improve services for foreign laborers and prevent their exploitation, CLA Minister Lu Tien-lin said Wednesday.
Lu said the planned facility is the result of a CLA review of its foreign labor force employment system.

Lu made the announcement at a press conference following an Executive Yuan meeting earlier in the day in which he said he drew up the strategy to protect foreign workers from exploitation by human traffickers.

Lu said that in the early stage of the employment center's operations, household caregivers will be the first group of foreign laborers in Taiwan to make use of the services on offer, which will include allowing them to renew their three- year employment contracts with the same family without having to involve a labor broker.

The existing restrictions on foreign caregivers, including a ban on them changing employers three times in two months and changing their workplace to a different district, will also be relaxed in accordance with the opening of the new services center.

In the near future, Lu explained that under certain conditions and with the agreement of old and new employers, foreign caregivers will be able to switch employers directly, again without having to pay an exploitative labor broker.
The new measures are expected to be implemented by the end of this year, Lu noted.

To prevent foreign laborers absconding to evade broker fees or exploitation, Lu said the CLA will offer NT$100,000 (US$3,064) as reward for turning on runaway workers, while imposing stricter punishments upon those who employ foreign workers illegally, with maximum fines of NT$750,000 and a deduction of five persons from the foreign laborer quota of the offending employer.

According to the CLA, the planned joint services center will be equipped with five branch offices, including the one in the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, whose mission will focus on offering consultancy services related to foreign workers entering and leaving the country.

In addition to improving services for foreign workers, the CLA will also reinforce the existing screening system targeting labor brokerage companies, in a drive to expose unscrupulous brokers, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRTC to install additional double-decker bike racks

TEXT.P: The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) is to install additional double-decker bicycle parking racks outside the Yuanshan Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) Station to provide more parking space for Taipei City cyclists, a TRTC spokesman said Wednesday.
The TRTC already provides a total of more than 9,800 bike parking spaces outside several of the system's MRT stations, the spokesman said.
The TRTC installed the first double-decker bike racks outside Beitou MRT station in 2004, followed by Jiantan, Fuzhong and Gongguang stations, providing nearly 1,100 parking spaces.

According to the spokesman, the racks at Beitou station were made in Japan and cost more than NT$14,000 (US$428) each, while the double-decker racks later installed outside other stations were made in Taiwan and cost NT$8,000 each.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei county chief blasted for rise in special allowance fund

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei came under attack Wednesday for a steep increase in his special allowance fund following the county's upgrading to the status of quasi-special municipality.

Quoting the 2008 budget plan presented by the Taipei county government, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Shu-fen noted at a news conference that Chou's special allowance fund will increase to NT$200,000 (US$6,134.03) per month next year from the current NT$88,000.
The new amount will be higher than that granted to many other senior government officials, despite the fact that Chou's approval ratings are among the lowest in the country, Lin said.
Lin claimed that most of the extra funds allocated to the Taipei county government following the county's status upgrade Oct. 1 will go straight into Chou's pockets.

Citing a recent Taipei District Court ruling in former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying- jeou's corruption case that special allowance funds for public officials are considered subsidies in nature, Lin said the increase in Chou's special allowance fund is tantamount to the Taipei magistrate giving himself a salary raise of 227 percent.

Ma was indicted in early February for allegedly embezzling NT$11.17 million from his special mayoral allowance during his time in office between 1998-2006. He was acquitted by the Taipei District Court Aug. 14.

Lin noted that the Taipei magistrate's monthly special allowance of NT$200,000 is even higher than those of the vice president and the heads of the Legislative, Executive, Control and Examination yuans, as well as those of the heads of central government ministries.

"Has the Taipei county government invested enough resources in education and policing?" Lin asked, pointing out that many schools in the county have deteriorating facilities. "If not, then why has the magistrate decided to first increase his own special allowance fund?" she asked.

In response to Lin's criticism, Chou pointed out at a news conference held later the same day that the amount of his special allowance is prescribed by law and in line with those of the mayors of Taiwan's two other special municipalities, Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteers to help fight smoking in Taichung's schools

TEXT.P: Eighty-eight volunteer workers who completed their training in tobacco hazards prevention and control and received accreditation Wednesday will help fight juvenile smoking in Taichung City's schools.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu awarded the certificates to the volunteers at a ceremony on behalf of the city government's Public Health Bureau. All of the volunteers are mothers of teenage students.
Speaking at the ceremony, Hu cited statistics as saying that 4.38 percent of the students aged 13 to 15 in Taichung are smokers.

He said most of these youngsters had their first puff in Grade Five or Six or during the first two years in junior middle schools, and that these young people could get hooked on smoking for the rest of their lives.

The mayor urged the volunteers to help lower the prevalence of smoking among schoolchildren by making them understand the harmful effects of tobacco at an early age so that they will firmly say "no" to smoking.
Hu also asked the Public Health Bureau to conduct a survey every year to monitor the results of anti-smoking program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hospital signs MOU with Philippine medical center
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, the Philippines, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/17/07 20:04:37 (By Emerson Lim and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Chiayi Christian Hospital in the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on medical exchanges with a Philippine medical institution Tuesday as part of its efforts to expand bilateral medical exchanges.

Chen Cheng-jen, the superintendent of the Taiwanese hospital who is currently leading a 19-member medical team on a visit to Manila, signed the MOU with Rosalinda F. Rarndia, head of the Rizal Medical Center.
The Rizal Medical Center is the second hospital in the Philippines to set up exchange relations with the Chiayi Christian Hospital.
On behalf of the hospital, Chen presented a heart monitor worth over NT$224,000 (US$6,850) to the Philippine medical center.
Rarndia expressed appreciation to the hospital for offering health care for tens of thousands of Philippine workers in southern Taiwan.
She also thanked the hospital for sending medical teams to the Philippines to give medical treatment to local poor people in recent years.
Soon after arriving in Manila Oct. 10, the delegation began providing free medical services and hygiene education to over 1,300 people in several parts of the country.

Chen for his part said his hospital hopes its efforts will increase the friendship between the people of the Philippines and of Taiwan as well as raise the diplomatic profile of Taiwan in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese university delegation visits Taiwan for cultural exchanges

TEXT.P: A 24-member delegation from China's Northeast Normal University is visiting Taiwan for a cultural exchange program with five local universities, a spokesman for National Chiayi University in southern Taiwan said Wednesday.
The delegation concluded a three-day visit to National Chiayi University Wednesday.
During their stay in Chiayi, the Chinese students and teachers visited several tourist spots in Chiayi County, including Alishan, in addition to various university facilities.

Members of the delegation also attended a seminar held Wednesday at Chiayi University, with students of both sides exchanging views on the cultural and tourist differences between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
Prior to its visit to Chiayi University, the delegation had visited National Taiwan Normal University in Taipei, as well as Feng Chia University and National Taichung University in central Taiwan.
The Chinese students, who arrived in Taiwan Oct. 9, were scheduled to proceed to National Kaohsiung Normal University in southern Taiwan and to leave Taiwan Oct. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippines can serve as Taiwan's gateway to ASEAN market: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan is facing the prospect of a block of high tariffs in the AFTA (ASEAN Free Trade Area), but the Philippines could serve as its gateway to the Southeast Asian market given further bilateral economic cooperation, officials from Taiwan and Philippines said Wednesday.

Taiwanese products will be put at a disadvantage in the AFTA market as tariffs on all products within the 10 ASEAN member countries are to be completely eliminated by the year 2015, said Berton Chiu, Director General of Taiwan's Department of Investment Services, in a Philippines investment seminar.
If Taiwanese businesses intend to make a breakthrough, setting up production bases in Southeast Asian countries will be a must, and the Philippines is a good place for investment, Chiu said.

Having established a Taiwan-Philippines economic corridor linked by three economic and export processing zones, Taiwan's closest neighbor in the South is hoping to attract more investment from Taiwan. With that goal in mind, a delegation of officials from Philippines Economic Zone Authority (PEZA) , Calabarzon Regional Development Council and Philippines Ecozone Association (PHILEA) are visiting Taiwan.

The Philippine government has been encouraging private sector businesses to invest in its economic zones by offering incentives and assistance. Currently, there are 132 special economic zones operating in the country, said Lilia de Lima, Director General and chief executive of PEZA.

"As of now, there are 40-50 Taiwanese businesses operating in ecozones in the Philippines, including 18 in the Calabarzone, which comprised of five Luzon provinces...Among Taiwanese companies, 14 are in the apparel sector, seven in electronics sector while six are in textiles, " she said.

Taiwanese companies, especially those in the food industry, are encouraged to establish production bases in the Philippines and take advantage of the Philippines' high-quality pool of labor, Lima added.

The Philippines' infrastructure is probably not be as developed as others, but it provides businesses, especially the electronics industry, with a better turnaround time due to its proximity to Taiwan and strategic position in the Asia Pacific region, she said.
To strengthen bilateral economic cooperation, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Minister Chen Ruey-long will be leading a delegation to Manila for a ministerial level meeting in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to help local enterprises enter Russian market

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will invite Russian buyers to two seminars in Taiwan to analyze the trading practices of Russian enterprises in the hope of helping local firms enter that market, a TAITRA official said Wednesday.

The official noted that in Russia -- one of the promising BRIC countries comprising Brazil, Russia, India and China -- English usage is low, making it hard for Taiwanese companies to exploit the market there.

In consideration of this obstacle, TAITRA will invite representatives of several Russian enterprises, including eHouse -- one of Russia's largest e-commerce ventures -- and several major jewelers to explain to local firms how Russia, which depends heavily on foreign imports, searches for suitable suppliers around the world.

TAITRA will invite these Russian buyers to a seminar to be held at its Hsinchu office Oct. 23, and another at the Taipei International Invention Center Oct. 24, which will be broadcast simultaneously by video conference to TAITRA's offices in Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elite parachutists to stage performance next month: defense minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is scheduled to arrange for elite parachutists to land in front of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall next month, Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu said Wednesday.
But Lee said the exact date and the form of the performance has yet to be fleshed out.

Lee said the public anticipated watching the elite parachutists landing in the square in front of the Presidential Office during the Double Ten National Day celebrations, and were disappointed that those plans were aborted due to inclement weather.
"The MND has heeded the wishes of the public, and will arrange a performance to deliver on its promise," Lee said.

The MND wants to choose a landing place that will minimally interfere with the public and has tentatively chosen the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly named Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, located near the Presidential Office.
But the square in front of memorial hall is not available until next month, so the most likely date for the event will be some time in November, Lee said.

Lee said that November will be very suitable for a parachute jump, but whether the event will be held Nov. 3, when an islandwide torch relay to promote the nation's membership bid in the United Nations is expected to conclude in Taipei, he did not know. Lee only said that if that date is available, it will be held at that time as it is a weekend.
Asked whether the performance will be staged in conjunction with Taiwan's U.N. bid campaign, Lee only said that "everyone should watch and see."

Asked whether the parachutists will come down with the ROC's national flag or whether they will carry the banner emblazoned with the nation's slogan for U.N. bid, "U.N. for Taiwan, " Lee said that currently, the MND is planning to have them jump with the national flag.

Meanwhile, the MND said that the elite parachutists prepared for the National Day celebration performance for some time, and that they were disappointed that they were unable to strut their stuff due to weather conditions.
The MND has planned a performance "in line with the public wishes," a spokesman said, which he said has "nothing to do with the ongoing U.N. bid campaign."
The MND protested a report by the United Daily News, which said that the ministry has pushed for a parachutist performance to accommodate the torch relay activities.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party is backing the torch relay, which will start in Taipei Oct. 24, the day when the U.N. Charter was brought into effect 62 years ago. President Chen
Shui-bian will run the first leg of the torch relay and the torch
will then tour around the country to drum up support for the
nation's bid to join the world body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elite parachutists to perform in mid-November: MND

TEXT.P: A performance by elite parachutists will be staged at the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in mid-November, a spokesman of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed Wednesday.
The spokesman said that the elite parachutists were unable to perform during the Double Ten National Day celebrations last week because of poor weather conditions, disappointing many.
The newly announced performance has been planned to make up for the earlier cancellation, the spokesman added.
He said that in addition to the parachutist performance, there will also be a military marching band performance and combat skill performance by the army, marines and special forces.

The spokesman said that the performance, part of the MND campaign to raise the public awareness of national defense, will take place days after the conclusion of several politically-charged activities, such as the torch relay and bicycle tour around the island to drum up support for the country's U.N. bid, which will end Nov. 3.
The spokesman reaffirmed that the military will remain neutral and will steer clear of political activities, and urged the media not to engage in inappropriate speculation.

His remarks came after reports by the United Daily News, a local newspaper, earlier the day that the MND wants the parachutists to perform Nov. 3 in conjunction with the conclusion of the torch relay tour initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese-version 'Leben in Deutschland' published in Taipei

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Soochow University's Department of German Language and Culture published the Chinese version of the German-language book "Leben in Deutschland, " meaning "Life in Germany" in English, Wednesday, after it was translated by 26 students and teachers in the department.

Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey, who had served as director of the department and head of Soochow University's School of Foreign Languages and Cultures before joining government service, offered his congratulations during his visit to the university for the book's launch.
Introducing the 400-page book authored by Theo Sommer, Shieh said the book offers first-hand information of Germany's history, culture and current social situation.

The translation was part of the Ministry of Education's 2006 excellence in teaching recognition project, which offers financial subsidies to colleges and universities seeking to improve the quality of instruction.

The book "Leben in Deutschland" focuses on modern life and culture in Germany. It is composed by 30 separate reports on topics including the lives of children, intimate relations, marriage relations, work, education, human interactions, religion, leisure sports, and the lives of the elderly.
The topics were discussed in a series reports in the German influential weekly journal "Die Zeit" before being brought together in book form in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dwindling tourism may hit resort real estate

TEXT.P: A dwindling number of foreign visitors to Taiwan might hit the local resort real estate sector, business sources predicted Wednesday.
According to the sources, the sector could experience a noticeable slump in business next year if the entry of Chinese tourists fails to be realized by that time.

As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not yet come to terms on the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, the Tourism Bureau has adjusted the number of expected foreign tourist arrivals for 2008 to 4million, down from its original target of 5 million.

The situation may deal a heavy blow to the resort real estate sector, which has embarked on a tourism hotel construction boom in anticipation of hosting large numbers of Chinese tourists, the sources said.

By the end of 2008, there will be 32 newly completed tourist hotels, with an 8,435 room capacity, across the country, marking a 36 percent and 40 percent growth rate, respectively, according to Tourism Bureau statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower to build 20 more wind turbines

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) awarded a contract Wednesday for the construction of 20 more wind turbines in the third stage of its wind energy project.

Star Energy Corp., a subsidiary of Taiwan Cogeneration Corp., won the contract with a bid of NT$3.2 billion (US$98.05 million). It will build 14 wind turbines for Taipower in Szuhu township of Yunlin County and another six in Taipei County's Linkou township by June 2010.
According to Taipower, each windmill will have the capacity to generate 2,000 watts of electricity per hour.
Taipower officials said the company will put out to tender additional contracts for the remaining 54 wind turbines of the third-stage project.

Taipower, the sole electricity supplier in Taiwan, began to harness wind energy in 2002 and mapped out a plan to build up to 200 wind turbines in Taiwan and Penghu by 2010. Seventy-seven of these windmills with a total capacity of 121,760 kilowatts are already in operation, while 35 units are currently under construction.

The Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has set the target of generating enough renewable energy to meet 10 percent of Taiwan's electricity needs by 2010, with wind power making up 80 percent of the renewable energy.

Experts say that Taiwan's coastal areas are ideal for the development of wind power because they have strong northwesterly winds six months each year, with an average wind speed of five to six meters per second.

Taipower's long-term wind power development plant will build an additional 546 wind turbines between 2010 and 2020 in shallow waters off Taiwan's west coast and Penghu, with a total capacity of 1,980 megawatts at an estimated cost of NT$200 million each.
Of the 546 windmills in total, 176 will be built off Penghu, and the electricity generated by these units will be transmitted to Taiwan through a 40-km undersea cable.
The other 370 units will be established 10 to 15 km off the coast of Changhua and Yunlin counties, according to Taipower.

DOC.HEADLINE: President thanks Denmark party leader for backing Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his appreciation to Pia Kjaersgaard, leader of the Danish People's Party, Wednesday for firmly supporting Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO) over the years.
During a meeting with Kjaersgaard at the Presidential Office, Chen said that the Danish political leader has spoken up for Taiwan's cause on many occasions.
Chen noted that Kjaersgaard has also urged the Denmark government to recognize Taiwan and to invite him to visit Denmark.

Lauding Kjaersgaard's leadership, Chen said that the Danish People's Party had pushed the European Union policy spokesman to question Denmark's foreign minister and health minister six times over Taiwan's WHO membership issues, which later brought the Denmark government to agree to support Taiwan's meaningful participation in the world body.

In April 2004, recalled Chen, Jens Hald Madsen, chairman of the Danish Parliament's Foreign Policy Committee, organized a videoconference on Taiwan- related issues, in which Chen was invited to deliver a speech.
Lawmakers and academics from Sweden, Norway, Finland, and Iceland were also present at the videoconference.
At the end of the videoconference, Madsen announced the establishment of the Danish Parliamentarians Taiwan Association, Chen went on.
Chen said that he would like to take the occasion to thank association members for their long-time support for Taiwan. Kjaersgaard is a board member of the association.
Kjaersgaard, for her part, said that during her previous four visits to Taiwan, she noticed that Taiwan has been making progress in various areas, and called Taiwan a successful, model democracy.

Kjaersgaard pledged that she will again speak for Taiwan if she has the opportunity to participate in U.N. meetings. Three times in the past, Kjaersgaard served as Denmark's representative to the U.N., and each time she voiced support for Taiwan's U.N.-membership bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP in gear to campaign for U.N. membership bid

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has designated Oct. 28 as a "national endorsement day, " during which party heavyweights will hit the streets to encourage the public to sign a petition indicating their support for its campaign for a referendum on the country's U.N. membership bid, party officials said Wednesday.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lan Shih-tsung made the announcement at a news conference following a weekly meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee.

According to Lan, the DPP has collected more than 1.17 million signatures to date in the first phase of the campaign. The party hopes to garner an additional 1 million signatures over the next 10 days as the second phase of the campaign.

The DPP's local branches will set up 156 booths around the country to highlight the importance of the second phase of the campaign, in hopes of gathering 2 million signatures by the end of this month so as to allow for the holding of a referendum on the country's U.N. cause along with the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

President Chen Shui-bian and Frank Hsieh, the party's presidential candidate, will both take part in the signature campaign. But Chen is not expected to attend promotional activities to be staged at a night market in Taipei on the Oct. 28 "national endorsement day," party sources said.
The DPP is slated to sponsor a string of activities towards the end of this month to put the Taiwan U.N. cause issue under spotlight, including a round-the- nation torch relay Oct. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: Funds for U.N. bid campaign mainly come from MOFA, GIO: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The funds for a publicity campaign for the country's bid to join the United Nations mainly came from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Government Information Office (GIO), the Cabinet's budget chief said Wednesday.
Hsu Chang-yao, minister of the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan budget screening meeting.

During the meeting, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers accused some government agencies of illegally using their budgets to help the GIO carry out a publicity drive in line with the ruling party concerning Taiwan's U.N. membership bid.

According to a local media report, the GIO had demanded various government agencies each supply funds worth NT$2 million to help finance a "U.N. membership for Taiwan" campaign in conjunction with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -initiated U.N. bid referendum proposal.

The DPP has been engaged in a campaign calling for a referendum, to be held along with the March 22, 2008 presidential election, to gauge public opinion on whether the country should seek U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan.

In response, Hsu said the media report was not correct, insisting that the funds provided by various government agencies were mainly alloted to help the GIO better promote various government policies as a whole.
As to the U.N. bid publicity campaign, Hsu said the funds were primarily provided by the MOFA and the GIO.

KMT lawmaker Wong Chung-chun said at the legislative meeting that agencies providing such funds have violated the Budget Law and questioned how the GIO could use the budgets of other agencies to finance the U.N. bid publicity drive.

According to KMT lawmaker Chen Chieh, officials at the Department of Industrial Technology under the Ministry of Economic Affairs did not deny that the GIO had issued a notification asking for NT$2 million in monetary handouts during an earlier intepellation session.

Chen suspected that other agencies must have encountered the same situation and said it appeared to breach the Budget Law. He argued that such cases must be directly handed over to prosecutors to probe whether any laws were broken.

Chang Hsieh-yao, a lawmaker of the opposition People First Party (PFP) and the director of the party's policy center, claimed that agencies, including the Sports Affairs Council, Taiwan Power Company and Taiwan Post (formerly known as Chunghwa Post), could be punished in accordance with the Referendum Law and Public Officials Election and Recall Law for using state resources to help the DPP.
Chang made the comments during a PFP-sponsored public hearing in which officials from the various agencies and institutes were also invited to elaborate on the issue.
Government agencies must maintain neutrality regarding a possible referendum topic and they must not handle matters related to the topic as it is not yet an established government policy, Chang said.

He also recommended that the public ask for compensation from Taiwan Post in compliance with the Civil Code, if their personal letters are stamped by the company with a seal showing "U.N. for Taiwan."
According to Taiwan Post Deputy General Manager Huang Shu-chien, the company was only acting in the service of the government.

Chinese citizens, including Hong Kong and Macau residents, formed the second largest national group, making more than with 467,000 visits to Taiwan during the period and accounting for 20 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 18, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty- three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
2001: "President A-bian's Electronic Paper, " an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office is formally launched.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterats the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he receives visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
2001: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathers in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

President thanks Denmark party leader for backing Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his appreciation to Pia Kjaersgaard, leader of the Danish People's Party, Wednesday for firmly supporting Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO) over the years.
During a meeting with Kjaersgaard at the Presidential Office, Chen said that the Danish political leader has spoken up for Taiwan's cause on many occasions.
Chen noted that Kjaersgaard has also urged the Denmark government to recognize Taiwan and to invite him to visit Denmark.

Lauding Kjaersgaard's leadership, Chen said that the Danish People's Party had pushed the European Union policy spokesman to question Denmark's foreign minister and health minister six times over Taiwan's WHO membership issues, which later brought the Denmark government to agree to support Taiwan's meaningful participation in the world body.

In April 2004, recalled Chen, Jens Hald Madsen, chairman of the Danish Parliament's Foreign Policy Committee, organized a videoconference on Taiwan- related issues, in which Chen was invited to deliver a speech.
Lawmakers and academics from Sweden, Norway, Finland, and Iceland were also present at the videoconference.
At the end of the videoconference, Madsen announced the establishment of the Danish Parliamentarians Taiwan Association, Chen went on.
Chen said that he would like to take the occasion to thank association members for their long-time support for Taiwan. Kjaersgaard is a board member of the association.
Kjaersgaard, for her part, said that during her previous four visits to Taiwan, she noticed that Taiwan has been making progress in various areas, and called Taiwan a successful, model democracy.

Kjaersgaard pledged that she will again speak for Taiwan if she has the opportunity to participate in U.N. meetings. Three times in the past, Kjaersgaard served as Denmark's representative to the U.N., and each time she voiced support for Taiwan's U.N.-membership bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower to build 20 more wind turbines

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) awarded a contract Wednesday for the construction of 20 more wind turbines in the third stage of its wind energy project.

Star Energy Corp., a subsidiary of Taiwan Cogeneration Corp., won the contract with a bid of NT$3.2 billion (US$98.05 million). It will build 14 wind turbines for Taipower in Szuhu township of Yunlin County and another six in Taipei County's Linkou township by June 2010.
According to Taipower, each windmill will have the capacity to generate 2,000 watts of electricity per hour.
Taipower officials said the company will put out to tender additional contracts for the remaining 54 wind turbines of the third-stage project.

Taipower, the sole electricity supplier in Taiwan, began to harness wind energy in 2002 and mapped out a plan to build up to 200 wind turbines in Taiwan and Penghu by 2010. Seventy-seven of these windmills with a total capacity of 121,760 kilowatts are already in operation, while 35 units are currently under construction.

The Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has set the target of generating enough renewable energy to meet 10 percent of Taiwan's electricity needs by 2010, with wind power making up 80 percent of the renewable energy.

Experts say that Taiwan's coastal areas are ideal for the development of wind power because they have strong northwesterly winds six months each year, with an average wind speed of five to six meters per second.

Taipower's long-term wind power development plant will build an additional 546 wind turbines between 2010 and 2020 in shallow waters off Taiwan's west coast and Penghu, with a total capacity of 1,980 megawatts at an estimated cost of NT$200 million each.
Of the 546 windmills in total, 176 will be built off Penghu, and the electricity generated by these units will be transmitted to Taiwan through a 40-km undersea cable.
The other 370 units will be established 10 to 15 km off the coast of Changhua and Yunlin counties, according to Taipower.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bid to boost women's labor participation bearing fruit: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday the increasing labor force participation rate among Taiwan women indicates that the government's efforts to encourage women's entrepreneurship and employment are bearing fruit.

Chen made the remarks in the latest issue of his online newsletter, referring to a recent media report which mentioned the labor force participation rate of Taiwan women rose to a 10-year-high of 58.61 percent in August this year.

Chen noted that back in 1996, there was a wide gap between the labor force participation rates of men and women -- 71 percent versus 45 percent, mainly because the country's overall employment and entrepreneurial environment was very unfriendly to women.

To address the problem, Chen said, his administration pushed through several pieces of important legislation after his inauguration in 2000, including the Gender Equality in Employment Act of 2002 and the Sexual Harassment Prevention Act of 2006.

In addition, the government cooperated with private businesses to provide pre- vocational training for women between 2003 and 2006 and amended the Employment Insurance Act to introduce an allowance for parents on unpaid leave to take care of their children and a subsidy aimed at encouraging employers to establish daycare facilities for their workers, Chen pointed out.
The government has also been working to amend the Labor Insurance Statute to increase maternity payment from two months of an employee's salary to three months, he added.

On women's entrepreneurship, Chen noted that many women had difficulties obtaining business startup mortgage loans from financial institutions in the past because real estate was usually registered under the name of men.

To improve the situation, the government has persuaded financial institutions to accept the government as the guarantor of woman applicants for business startup loans, launching a micro business startup loan program in 2003 and a small loan program for female business starters in 2007, Chen said.
Since their launch in 2000, courses guiding women's enterpreneurship have drawn more than 17,000 participants, he added.

The president said all these measures have helped boost women's labor force participation, with the number of women in the work force increasing at an average annual rate of 2.05 percent over the past decade, compared with an average rate of 0.67 percent per year among men.
Meanwhile, women's labor force participation rate has seen a rise of 2.92 percentage points over the past 10 years, whereas that of men has decreased by 3.78 percentage points, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Culture chief calls for reinforced cultural education

TEXT.P: Taiwan should strengthen its cultural education in order to deepen national identity and Taiwan-centric consciousness, according to Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Minister Wong Chin-chu.

Wong made the remarks Wednesday at a ceremony held in Taichung City, central Taiwan, to mark Taiwan's Cultural Day, which coincides with the establishment of the Taiwan Cultural Association, which was founded by Taiwan's democratic movement vanguard Chiang Wei-shui in 1921.

Wong said the establishment of the Taiwan Cultural Association by the cultural elite of Taiwan 86 years ago, defying the repression by the Japanese colonial government, has inspired Taiwan's democratic and cultural movement.
In addition to paying tribute to those cultural precursors, Taiwan's new generation should continue their efforts in seeking a Taiwan identity, Wong stressed.

During a series of celebrations at the time, members of Taiwan's cultural sector issued a Taiwan New Culture Declaration, stressing the importance of a unique Taiwanese culture independent from that of China.

Noting that only an independent Taiwanese culture will make Taiwan really independent in diverse aspects, the cultural elite urged Taiwan's people to strengthen their unique culture and earn respect for it in the international community.
