DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan suspends French apple imports

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) imposed a temporary ban on apple imports from France Thursday in the wake of the discovery of codling moth larvae in a recent shipment.

According to officials at the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, the codling moth larvae were found Tuesday in a shipment containing 1,029 crates of Gala apples. The bureau has ordered that the shipment be destroyed or returned to the exporting country.

The officials said the bureau has notified the French authorities to suspend apple exports to Taiwan until the authorities identify the cause of the infestation and take measures to improve the situation.

As to the shipments that are on their way to Taiwan, the bureau will conduct a comprehensive inspection on them after their arrival to ensure the safety of the country's agricultural production environment, the officials said.
The incident marked the first time that codling moth larvae have been discovered in apple imports from Europe, they said.
In 2006, Taiwan imported 586 metric tons of apples from France, accounting for only 0.5 percent of the country's total apple imports, according to the COA.
Taiwan consumes around 115,000 metric tons of apples annually, relying on imports to meet more than 90 percent of demand.
The codling moth is considered a major pest affecting apple, pear, quince and walnut producing regions in Europe, Asia and North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC to decide Oct. 26 on ballot format for legislative elections

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will meet next week to discuss the way in which to hand out ballots in next year's legislative elections, CEC Secretary- General Teng Tien-yu said Thursday.

Teng noted that as a referendum on two proposals will be held in conjunction with the Jan. 12 legislative elections, the CEC will discuss whether to hand out the two ballots -- one for the legislative elections and the other for the two referendum proposals -- simultaneously or separately.

He was referring to the referendum proposal initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to retrieve what it calls the "ill-gotten" assets amassed by the Kuomintang (KMT) during its five decades of rule, and the proposal initiated by the KMT against corruption.

If the two ballots are handed out separately, the voters will first receive the ballot for the legislative elections and then receive the referendum ballot only after casting the first ballot. This method was used in the 2004 presidential election in which a referendum was simultaneously held.
If the two ballots are handed out at the same time, the voters will cast the ballots in separate boxes.

In response to reports Thursday by the Taipei-based United Daily News that the CEC will discuss at the Oct. 26 meeting whether to use the format of handing out two ballots simultaneously in next year's presidential election, Teng said that the commission will mainly discuss whether to use the format in the legislative elections.

"The format decided upon in the meeting will not necessarily be applied to the March 22 presidential election in 2008," Teng said, noting that two separate referendum proposals -- one initiated by the DPP on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan and the other initiated by the KMT on the country applying to return to the world body under its official name, the Republic of China -- are also expected to be held alongside the presidential election.

According to the United Daily News reports, if the CEC decides to hand out two ballots simultaneously in the presidential election, this will help boost the turnout rate and the chances of the U.N. bid proposal by the DPP being passed. The proposal will also help galvanize support for the ruling party in the presidential election, according to the reports.

Under the current Referendum Law, a proposal will be considered passed if the referendum turnout rate exceeds half of all eligible voters and if 50 percent of those who cast ballots vote in favor of the proposal.

In the 2004 presidential election, two proposals initiated by President Chen and put to a referendum -- one on purchasing more missiles to counter the military threat from China, and the other on engaging in dialogue with China -- failed to pass partly because not all eligible voters turned out to vote and partly because many of those who voted in the election refused to claim referendum ballots and walked out the polls directly. Although 90 percent of those who cast ballots in the referendum voted in favor of the proposals, the referendum turnout rate was only 45 percent of all eligible voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mega yacht orders for 2015 set to rank among top 4 countries

TEXT.P: The government is working on crafting policies to better promote the yacht building industry, aiming to make Taiwan rank among the world's top four mega yacht making countries, an official said Thursday.

The government projects that the output value of yacht building will be NT$19.5 billion (US$596.33) by 2015, and will also strive to help at least one local firm rank among the world's four leading firms by then, the official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development said.

Citing a report released in January by ShowBoats International, a yacht publication, the official said the world's mega yacht market will continue growing. He added that many of Taiwan's 31 yacht making firms have already shifted from building traditional yachts to super yachts to seize further business opportunities.

According to the official, the output value of Taiwan's yacht building industry for 2006 was NT$7.48 billion, up 4.8 percent from 2005's figure of NT$7.14 billion. That number was 16.5 percent of general shipping industry' output value at NT$43.52 billion for 2006, which marked a 10.3 percent growth from the previous year's NT$39.46 billion.
The official said the worldwide yacht market is worth about US$40 billion per year, with America enjoying 49 percent of the market.
The official pointed out that Taiwan ranked seventh in yacht building in the world, and first in Asia in 2006, in terms of yacht building orders.

Plans under consideration include improving infrastructure for industry clusters, developing related industries, training yacht design personnel, building laboratories to test ship functions, and holding international yacht exhibitions.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications will also make amendments to current legal regulations, integrate inspection bureaus, and simplify inspection processes to provide a smoother operating legal environment for the industry, the official went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 107 points to close at 9,677, with 44,777 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December gained 110 points to finish at 9,680, with 165 contracts traded, while March futures rose 52 points to close at 9,664, with three contract transactions. June futures moved up 22 points to finish at 9,601, with four contract transactions, while September futures increased 14 points to close at 9,501, with 49 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 9,570 for November, 9,570 for December, 9,612 for March, 9,579 for June, and 9,487 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

November TE futures gained 7.95 points to close at 403.6, with 4,227 contracts traded, while December TE futures rose 8.8 points to finish at 404, with 20 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 8.65 points to close at 401.65, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

November TF futures moved up 7.8 points to close at 1,063.8, with 3,530 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures rose 6.2 points to finish at 1,062.2, with 31 contracts traded. September TF futures increased 10.8 points to close at 1,065.6, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veterans homes to double as day-care centers: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Thursday that 18 veterans homes and 10 veterans medical institutions will be opened to provide day-care services for the elderly.
Chang said the move is aimed at helping the underprivileged elderly to get appropriate service and medical care, moving Taiwan toward the goal of becoming a "just" society.

The premier made the remarks when he presided over the inauguration of a day- care center at a veteran's home at Banchiao, Taipei County. Also present were Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun, Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) Chairman Hu Cheng-pu and legislators from across the party spectrum.
Chang said the VAC's sharing of its resources with the public will help the underprivileged and boost employment, which he said will let "more people feel the warmth of society."

Hu said the commission has been working with a "mega-warmth" program implemented by the Executive Yuan, using the currently available medical resources to take care of the elderly at the community level.
"The veterans homes will move toward the goal of becoming a multi-functional welfare institution for the elderly," Hu said.

Local newspaper China Times has reported that the 18 veterans homes will be able to provide nearly 1,500 beds for the day-care service. The monthly expenses for daily transportation and three meals per day will cost around NT$7,000 (US$212) a month, the reports said.

The reports also said that elderly people of middle- or low incomes, as well as mentally or physically challenged elderly people, will be given priority, with services available to the general population of the elderly depending on the number of remaining vacancies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to export lychees to New Zealand

TEXT.P: New Zealand has agreed to allow imports of Taiwanese lychees, in a breakthrough in agricultural issues reached at the 14th Taiwan-New Zealand economic consultation meeting, an economic official said Thursday.
The meeting closed Monday in New Zealand, said Vice Economic Affairs Minister Fadah Hsieh, who led aTaiwan delegation that attended the meeting.
Hsieh said Taiwanese lychees will be exported to New Zealand after the country settled its legal regulations in this regard.
He said the two countries also reached consensus in other aspects, including bilateral exchanges and cooperation in technology, digital content, biotechnology industry and venture capital investment.
According to Hsieh, Taiwan is still waiting for New Zealand's reply to a Taiwanese proposal at the meeting on holding regular bilateral education meetings and cooperation on controlled drugs.

As to New Zealand's concerns on Taiwan's quota and tariff regulations on imports of deer velvet, dairy products and mutton, Hsieh said Taiwan insisted on leaving the discussion until the World Trade Organization's new round of talks.
Citing statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Hsieh said two- way trade between Taiwan and New Zealand amounted to US$886 million for 2006.

Of that figure, Taiwan's imports from New Zealand were worth US$502 million, down 1 percent from 2005, while exports to New Zealand were US$384 million, a decrease of 17 percent from the year-earlier level.

However, he also pointed out that Taiwan's imports from New Zealand during January and September this year reached US$444 million, up 14 percent from the same period of 2006, while exports to New Zealand were worth US$353 million, an increase of 19 percent over last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF to sponsor training workshop for cross-strait negotiation

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is planning to sponsor a training workshop for people interested in taking part in cross-Taiwan Strait negotiation, SEF sources said Thursday.

The SEF -- founded in 1990 as an intermediary body authorized by the government to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait to meet rising demand since Taiwan began allowing its people to travel to mainland China in 1987 to visit relatives -- will sponsor the three-day workshop Nov. 30-Dec. 2 at a location on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei during which lectures and lessons will be given about negotiation skills and theory, said SEF officials.

Over the past 16 years, the SEF has engaged in 26 rounds of negotiations and talks with its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), culminating with two high-profile meetings in 1993 and 1998 between then-SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan. Both Koo and Wang had passed away.
The SEF has also managed to sign four pacts with ARATS, including an agreement on the norms of SEF-ARATS interactions and meetings.
SEF officials said that although official cross-strait meetings, or SEF-ARATS meetings, were suspended in recent years due to political factors, members of the foundation have not been sitting idle.

Lecturers at the first SEF workshop are expected to include You Ying-lung, SEF vice chairman and secretary-general; Shi Huei-yow, director of the National Security Bureau; and Chang Jung-feng, vice president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to pray for U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to pray this weekend in the southern city of Tainan for success in promoting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials said Thursday.
The prayers are being organized by the Presbyterian Church of Taiwan.
In a speech, the president will share his expectations for and the meaning of a DPP-initiated referendum on applying for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan, the officials said.

In addition to praying for the success of the U.N. bid, participants will also pray for smooth presidential and legislative elections next year and for clean campaigns during the run-up to the elections, the officials said.

Taiwan has tried without success since 1993 to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation. It suffered a fresh setback in its quest for representation in the world body last month as an item endorsed by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies asking the world body to address Taiwan's membership application was excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

With promotion of the U.N. bid the main policy plank of the DPP administration, the Cabinet has designated Oct. 24 -- the anniversary of the coming into force of the Charter of the United Nations which is celebrated internationally as United Nations Day -- as "Taiwan United Nations Day" and will kickstart a 11-day nationwide torch relay on that day to promote the bid.
The DPP is also pushing for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, which is expected to be held alongside the March 2008 presidential election.
The party aims to collect 2 million signatures by the end of this month for the referendum petition, in the hope that the number can be recognized as a Guinness World Record.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Senate, Bush Reach Consensus on Spying
Legislation grants legal immunity to telecom companies that assisted in past eavesdropping while restoring court oversight of surveillance.
The Washington Times: Mexican crisscrossed border with TB
A Mexican national infected with a highly contagious form of tuberculosis crossed the U. S. border 76 times and took multiple domestic flights in the past year, according to Customs and Border Protection interviews and documents obtained by The Washington Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan International Cultural and Creative Industries Show opens

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan International Cultural and Creative Industries Exhibition opened Thursday in Taipei, with more than 200 companies from around the world participating, according to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which is organizing the event.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, noted that the world's daily production of cultural and creative industries reached US$22 billion.
With its global average growth exceeding that of manufacturing and service industries during the past 10 years, Huang said the cultural and creative industries are full of commercial potencial.
The three-day exhibition is being held at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) together with the Autumn Taipei International Gift and Stationary Show.

The cultural and creative exhibition was originally included in the Taipei International Gift and Stationary Show in the past, but this is the first time the creative exhibition has been conducted separately from the stationary show due to its fast development and despite the fact that many local manufacturers have relocated to China and Hong Kong and are no longer interested in participating in the show.
The exhibition is divided into international brand names and products with local characteristics, including visual arts, crafts, publications, and commercial and industrial design.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Plan Would Ease F.C. C. Restriction on Media Owners
The plan would relax decades-old media ownership rules, including repealing a rule that forbids a company to own both a newspaper and a television station in the same city.
The Wall Street Journal: INVESTIGATORS ARE SCRUTINIZING the role of an indicted Houston businessman in a probe of possible fraud involving contracts for supplying food to troops in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: President recognizes presidential cultural award winners

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised the winners of the fourth Presidential Cultural Awards at an award presentation ceremony Wednesday for their great contributions to raising the value of Taiwan's culture.

Likening the winners to "cultural farmers who sowed and planted seeds of culture in the fields of Taiwan, " Chen lauded their efforts to promote the sustainable development of culture in communities around the country.

Chen said the winners are worthy of pride as they have being striving to make Taiwan a place with a wide variety of cultural elements and have inspired more and more people to work for a more diversified and splendid culture.
He added that the awards, now in their eighth year, have become prestigious and have so far been handed out to a total of 21 groups or individuals.

This year, the winning groups include the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, the Hualien County's Niouli Community Interchange Association, the International Headquarters Search and Rescue, and the Homemaker's Union and Foundation. The two individual winners are Chiang Shu-shen, a scholar specialized in Taiwanese history, and Lim Chang-tzuo, lead singer of Taiwanese band Chthonic.

Also presented at the ceremony were Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, National Cultural Association Secretary-General Tchen Yu-chiou and Chen Chi- mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
According to Tchen, the winners were selected for their contributions in the fields of social service, international peace, environmental protection, artistic creation and cultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.01 to close at NT$32.595.
A total of US$1.01 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.576 and hit a high of NT$32.636.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fire on Kinmen's Kuningtou coast dying down

TEXT.P: The National Airborne Service Corps under the Ministry of Interior called off a fire-fighting operation on the outlying island of Kinmen using helicopters Thursday, as the fire was dying down and being kept under control by local firemen.

The fire broke out around 2 p.m. Wednesday near the coast at Kuningtou, a battlefield in October 1949, and quickly spread to grassland and windbreak trees nearby under the force of northeasterly winds.
The cause of the fire was unknown, but there was speculation that it might have been caused by farmers burning out weeds or by a discarded cigarette butt.
Firemen were advised by military authorities not to enter the area to fight the flames because it is seeded with an estimated 1,000 landmines.
Local people said the heat of the fire had set off more than 10 landmines. The explosions could be heard kilometers away from Chincheng township, seat of the Kinmen county government.
According to the Kinmen County Fire Department, by late Wednesday night, the fire had destroyed at least seven hectares of grassland and three hectares of woodland.
Kinmen Defense Command officers said the minefield affected by fire was originally scheduled for demining next year, but the fire has apparently made it necessary to speed up the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's inbound investment exceeds US$10 billion in first 9 months

TEXT.P: Approved inbound investment by overseas companies exceeded US$10 billion for the first nine months of this year, an increase of 6 percent over the same period of last year, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Thursday.

An official from the MOEA's Investment Commission noted that Taiwan's inbound investments have shown brilliant performance during the past few years, with that of last year reaching a record high of US$13.96 billion.

According to the World Investment Report 2007 published by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) , Asia surpassed the rest of the world in terms of attracting foreign investment during the previous year.
The report shows that Taiwan's inward foreign direct investment (FDI) registered a record high of US$7.42 billion for 2006, ranking 31st among the 218 countries surveyed.
Taiwan's FDI last year also represented a 356 percent growth over the US$1.62 billion registered in 2005, according to the report.

In addition to several big investment projects launched by multinational companies in Taiwan, the American biotechnology and pharmaceutical giant MediVas and Intrinsyc Software International Inc. of Canada have decided to put their Asian bases in Taiwan because of its favorable investment environment, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB rules out possibility of joining Chinese delegation

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has ruled out the possibility of joining a Chinese delegation to attend an international weather meeting, a CWB official said Thursday.

CWB Director-General Hsin Chiang-lin made the remarks after his Chinese counterpart, Zheng Guoguang, mentioned during a recent interview with a Hong Kong daily that he once proposed to Taiwan that CWB officials join Chinese delegations for participation in international weather symposiums.
Zheng also suggested that Hsin could serve as deputy leader of Chinese delegations.
However, Hsin noted that previous exchanges between Taiwanese and Chinese weather officials have only focused on technical problems and have not involved political issues.
According to Hsin, Taiwanese and Chinese meteorological institutions take turns organizing seminars and invite weather officials from both sides to exchange ideas at the seminars as consultants.
Hsin said he took part in a seminar organized in China last year but canceled his trip to attend the event again this year due to a typhoon.

Hsin Tsai-chin, deputy director-general of the CWB who also participates in many seminars held in China, noted that experts on both side of the Taiwan Strait specialize in different areas of weather forecasting.

As a result, it is necessary to have exchanges between Taiwanese and Chinese experts, he said, giving the example that during the northeasterly monsoon season, Taiwan needs weather data from China, while during typhoon season, China needs data from Taiwan.

In terms of earthquake information, Hsin Tsai-chin said Taiwan can learn from China's earthquake forecasts, which have been developed over three decades, while China can learn from Taiwan's earthquake prevention measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRDC develops new nano-silver vacuum coating technology

TEXT.P: A new vacuum coating technology for nano-silver particles has been developed by the Kaohsiung-based Metal Industries Research and Development Center (MIRDC), enabling a 99.99 percent bacteriostatic effect on coated tableware and cookware, center researchers said Thursday.

They noted that the center started its research and development project on the nano-silver vacuum coating process in 2003 and that after four years, finally came up with a new solution that is able to equally plate the surface with high hardness coating and nano-silver particles.

After testing, the nano-silver coating proved effective in reducing the number of bacteria it comes in contact with, giving a 99.99 percent kill rate for escherichia coli and staphylococcus aureus -- two common pathogens, they added.
According to MIRDC, the technology can be applied to various products such as tableware, cookware, bathroom accessories and household appliances.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rule on indigenous residents' rights to traditional areas gazetted

TEXT.P: The picking up by indigenous people of fallen trees and waste wood in forests where indigenous people have their traditional homelands is legally acceptable, officials from the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) said Thursday.

The CIP, in association with the Council of Agriculture (COA) , gazetted the administration rule Thursday at a news conference concerning the legitimacy of the rights to their traditional areas by the Atayal tribespeople living in two mountainous villages in Chienshih township of the northern county of Hsinchu.

With the publication of the rule, it is now legal for Atayal people living in Chienshih township's Yufeng village and Hsiuluan village to pick up and keep fallen trunks, waste wood and all other crops or produce from the forests in their neighborhood, an area of about 37,000 hectares, said CIP Minister Icyang Parod.

It is not only significant in terms of returning native areas to the indigenous people, it is partly an effort realizing President Chen Shui-bian's ideal and promise to the aborigines to develop a "partnership" between the Democratic Progressive Party administration and the country's indigenous people, Parod said.

He said Yufeng and Hsiuluan villages were first selected as locations to implement the "return traditional areas to the indigenous people" program because as recently as six months ago, an Atayal resident in Smangus -- the most remote and deep-mountain Atayal area on the border of Hsinchu County and eastern Yilan County -- was charged and convicted of theft for picking up a fallen trunk in the forest near his home.

Also speaking at the news conference, COA Vice Minister Lee Chien-chuan expressed hope that related regulations will be hammered out soon so that all indigenous people in the country can be protected by the regulations and enjoy legal access to natural products in their neighborhoods.

Chienshi rural township head Tseng Hsiao-chung, Yufeng village chief Chen Jung- kuang, Hsiuluan village chief You You-lien and several dozen village people traveled from the mountains to Taipei to witness the publication of the rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chair urges Beijing to scrap `one China' framework

TEXT.P: Taiwan will welcome negotiations with China so long as Beijing forswears its "one China" framework and sets no preconditions to any talks, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

MAC Chairman Chen Ming-tong made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in response to Chinese President Hu Jintao's call for a peace agreement based on the "one China" principle two days earlier during the opening session of the Communist Party of China's ongoing annual national congress.
Chen said it is impossible for the Taiwan government to ink any agreement under the "one China" framework, which he described as "an act of surrender."

Soon after Hu was sworn in as China's president, President Chen Shui-bian proposed the idea of establishing such a framework for peaceful development of cross-strait relations in January 2003, Chen Ming-tong noted.
However, there was no response from Beijing, he said, adding that five years passed before Hu's recent call and still he insists that Taiwan accept the "one China" framework.

To show sincerity, Beijing should scrap the "one China" framework, abolish its anti-secession law, stop squeezing Taiwan out of the international community, and remove missiles deployed along its southeastern coast targeting Taiwan, he went on.

Meanwhile, MAC officials described the "one China" principle as the greatest barrier to the development of cross-strait relations, not the political basis on which peaceful development of cross-strait relations can be built, as Hu claimed in his address.
Beijing should change its rigid mentality with regard to its policies towards Taiwan and face the fact that Taiwan is not a part of China, the officials continued.
If China is sincere in its claim that it wants to benefit the people of Taiwan, it should rule out unrealistic political barriers, the officials said.

China should collaborate with Taiwan to complete negotiations on the cross- strait cargo and passenger charter flights issue and on allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan based on the existing consensus reached between both sides, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung needs to make more effort to attract tourists: councilor

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey of foreign tourists to Kaohsiung City show that the municipal government needs to do more to promote the city's special characteristics to attract more visitors from abroad, City Councilor Lien Li- chien said Thursday.
Lien made the remarks while revealing the results of the survey conducted by National University of Kaohsiung on foreign visitors to the southern port city between October and December last year.

A total of 303 foreigners were surveyed, including 28 percent from Japan, 20 percent from Hong Kong, Macau or China, and 26 percent from Western countries. In the survey, 73 percent of the respondents answered "no" when asked whether they had a favorite scenic spot or attraction in Kaohsiung City.

Pointing out that this finding illustrates that the city has failed to make a lasting impression on most foreign visitors, Lin called for the municipal government to work harder to "package and sell" its special attractions.

Among the 27 percent percent of respondents who said they had a favorite tourist attraction in the city, 32.4 percent mentioned Liouho Night Market, 31.1 percent mentioned Ruey Fong Night Market, 15.5 percent cited the coastal Chijin district, and 9 percent mentioned Lotus Lake.

As to activities engaged in during their stay in Kaohsiung City, 44.8 percent of the respondents mentioned shopping, 32.8 percent mentioned visiting night markets, and 26.9 percent mentioned visiting historical sites or places of cultural interest.
Lin expressed the hope that the municipal government will work harder to promote the city's top attractions and unique qualities and take steps to cater more to foreign tourists' needs.
"Only by taking such steps to boost tourism can Kaohsiung City increase its visibility in the international community," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No export permit for ships of ex-presidential adviser: official

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration will stick to its guns and will not issue export permits to two fishing vessels belonging to Koo Kuan-min, a former senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, administration Director Hsieh Ta-wen said Thursday.

Hsieh made the remarks after Taipei-based the China Times daily cited Wang Pai- chi, a former head of the Taiwan Expatriate Association in the Marshall Islands, as saying that the pro-independence tycoon had sold two of his old vessels to a Chinese fishing company.

Wang said that Koo, who runs Koo Fishing Co. in the South Pacific Nation, had possessed seven licenses for large purse seiners but sold the two ships along with the licenses to the Chinese company and built two new ones, thinking that he could use his political clout in Taiwan to apply for new licenses.

But as the Solomon Islands-based Forum Fisheries Agency, an organization set up to provide fisheries management and development advice and services to member countries, will not consent to the issuance of a new licence, the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture will not issue an export permit. Koo has appealed the decision to the Executive Yuan three times, the reports said.
"The Fisheries Administration will explain to the Appeals Review Committee under the Executive Yuan that its decision is based on legitimacy reasons," Hsieh said.

He noted that the administration published guidelines on construction permits and licence issuance for fishing vessels June 29, 2005, which state that the ships already under construction should be completed, while those yet to be built will be bound to the new regulations.

The Fisheries Administration instructed all shipyards to report their ongoing construction at that time and the administration sent officials to double-check six months after that date, at which point Koo's ships were not being constructed.

In addition, the international community has imposed stricter regulations on fishing, especially for migratory fish, and major fishery organizations have regulated the number of fishing vessels, requiring that the construction of new vessels must get a green light from regional fishery organizations in advance.

Hsieh said Koo appealed to the Executive Yuan in October last year and again in May this year, and was told to "turn the case over to the relevant authorities, who will deal with the matter according to the law."
Noting that Koo ignored the advice and appealed a third time this August, Hsieh said the administration is determined to uphold its stance.

Meanwhile, Koo called a news conference Thursday in an attempt to defend himself after the China Times report cited Wang as saying that Koo had not only sold the two ships to the Chinese company but had also acted as a broker, allowing the company to buy a tuna cannery in the Marshall Islands, which is scheduled to open next month.
The plant is expected to provide 500 jobs to the island nation of 50,000 people, which will have a major impact on Taiwan's diplomatic front, the reports also quoted Wang as saying.

Koo admitted that he did sell ships to the Chinese company, which he described as an act of business that has nothing to do with his loyalty to Taiwan. He denied categorically that he brokered the tuna cannery deal.
He said he "will sell vessels and sell fish, but will by no means sell out Taiwan."
He also expressed anger that his new ships -- two 1,200-ton deep-sea purse seiners built at a cost of around NT$600 million (US$18.18 million) -- had been denied export permits.
The two ships were completed a year ago, and applications were made to export them to the Marshall Islands and have them registered there. However, they are still stranded in Kaohsiung Harbor.
He said that a few days before the Fisheries Administration unveiled its guidelines he had already signed the contract to build the ships, and claimed that the guidelines should not apply to him.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Cabinet appproves new draft bill on welfare.
The Cabinet approved Wednesday a new draft bill on welfare based on an agreement achieved by trade unions and employers associations.

DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG UK house market is heading for crash
The property boom of the past ten years has left the British housing market in danger of following the slump in American house prices, the International Monetary Fund said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to stop investing, offer support to Myanmar democracy

TEXT.P: The democratic movement will be successful in its push to overthrow the 43-year- old tyranny in Myanmar, and Taiwan can show its support by reviewing its investments in the country, a visiting Myanmarese opposition representative said Thursday.

Unless Asian countries, including Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore, stop investing in Myanmar, U.S. economic sanctions on Myanmar's military junta will not work because Myanmar economy remains stable, said Nyo Ohn Myint, the Global Burma Campaign coordinator of the National League for Democracy (NLD), the main opposition in Myanmar.

Myint made the appeal at a Taipei conference, titled "Beyond Rangoon: Burma's yesterday, today and tomorrow, " which was co-sponsored by Taiwang's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Thinktank.

Myint, who prefers to refer to his homeland as Burma rather than Myanmar -- the name coined by the military junta -- said foreign investment in the country has not been helping the people. Myanmar does not have an open market economy as most of the companies were controlled by junta generals, he said, which means that most of the money goes to their pockets instead of to the people.

Taiwan can do more to support democracy in Myanmar, he said. Taiwan, especially the DPP which brought an end to the Kuomintang's (KMT's) long-time authoritative regime, can offer the benefits of its experience in democratic transition to the NLD, which Myint believed "will collapse within two years even if it wins the power tomorrow" due to a lack of democratic experience.

"We will win pretty soon. This is the final push, " said Bangkok-based Myint, whose older brother was declared missing during recent demonstration in Yangoon. The college professor-turned-activist said the most encouraging sign for Myanmar's democratic movement is the participation of the younger generation.

"Before, these young men only heard about the 1988 demonstration and crackdown. But now they have experienced what it was like, " he said of the junta's recent crackdown and killing of unarmed demonstrators and monks.

Myint pointed out that the "China factor" has played an important role in the military junta's hardline stance because the junta received financial, military and political support from China, which also has a veto as a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council.

Local professors also called on the Taiwanese government to do more to support Myanmar democracy. Once the Refugee Act is passed in the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan will be able to offer political asylum to Myanmarese dissidents, said Shih Cheng-feng, a professor at Tamkang University.

However, Soochow University professor Wu Chih-chung questioned the actual impact of reducing foreign investment in Myanmar on the junta because it will probably just "bring the junta closer to China."

DOC.HEADLINE: Corporate governance in Taiwan improved: foreign analyst

TEXT.P: Corporate governance in Taiwan has progressed due to improvements in accounting, financial reporting and the courts' handling of insider trading, an analyst of CLSA Ltd., a leading independent equity broker in Asia, said Thursday.

Peter Sutton, head of the research section of CLSA, made the remarks in a speech delivered at the invitation of U.S. Chamber of Commerce about corporate governance in Taiwan and other Asian countries.

According to the 2007 report recently released by the Asian Corporate Governance Association, Hong Kong has replaced Singapore as the best area in Asia in terms of corporate governance due to its efforts to protect shareholders' rights, an issue on which Singapore has taken less action, while Taiwan advanced from fifth place in 2005 to fourth, thanks to improved regulations and enforcement.

Sutton noted that although Taiwan made some progress in corporate governance, there is still much room for local companies to improve, including in the protection of shareholders, the publication of employees' dividends, the independence of governing authorities and the allocation of corporate bonds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan encouraged to plug into international carbon trading scheme

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government should be encouraged to address the issue of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by plugging into the international carbon trading scheme and leveraging its status as a non-Kyoto Protocol signatory, a visiting Britain energy consultant said in an interview with the CNA.

"Your government can decide how far and how fast you want to go [in dealing with GHG emissions]. Taiwan can take part in the international trading instruments, trade for allowances of carbon dioxide and manage those on its own, " said Liz Bossley, chief executive of Consilience Energy Advisory Group (CEAG) , a U.K. consultancy specializing in oil, gas, power, coal, weather and emissions trading issues.

Taiwan is not a signatory of the Kyoto Protocol, a United Nations framework setting mandatory emission limitations for the reduction of atmospheric greenhouse gases because participation is limited to U.N. signatories. In some ways, that framework has isolated Taiwan's efforts from the global effort, Bossley said, but it has also provided Taiwan with an opportunity to "observe and avoid errors."
Taiwan will be able to take the best of both world, said Bossley, who was invited to visit Taiwan by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Emissions trading, she said, is an administrative approach to controlling pollution by providing economic incentives to achieve reductions in the emission of pollutants. The market reached 30 billion Euros this year alone, she said.
Under current directives of the U.N. and European Union (EU) , Taiwan, as a third party, is allowed to trade emission allowances with anyone, Bossley said.

Bossley, a former emissions allowance trader, said Taiwan's government is encouraged to first educate the people on the impact of climate change and explain to citizens what the problem is before measuring the sources of GHG emissions.
"Since your industry is very concentrated, that will not be difficult to do. And finally your policy can be formulated and implemented, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International conference on magnetic resonance held in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The 16th Triennial Conference for the International Society of Magnetic Resonance (ISMAR) is being held in Kenting in southern Taiwan, the first time the event has been held in Asia since its inauguration 37 years ago, event conveners said Thursday.

ISMAR Conference 2007, sponsored by the National Science Council, Academia Sinica and the Taiwan Magnetic Resonance Society, has gathered 500 specialists from 30 countries, including Kurt Wuethrich -- winner of the 2002 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Adriaan Bax -- the President of International Society of Magnetic Resonance, and prominent scientists in related fields.

Huang Tai-huang, president of Taiwan Magnetic Resonance Society and the Chairman of ISMAR Conference 2007 explained that magnetic resonance is a sophisticated technique for detecting the spin of electrons and nucleons, and that the technique has already been applied to magnetic resonance imaging or MRI, protein structure determination, material and polymer characterization, and new drug development.

Huang also explained that ISMAR is an organization dedicated to the advancement of magnetic resonance research and applications, and that ISMAR Conference is one of the largest symposiums for magnetic resonance study in the world.

Huang noted that the right to host the conference from October 14-19 is taken as recognition of Taiwan's rapid advancement in the field, including the establishment of the High-field Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Center and Functional and Micro-Magnetic Resonance Imaging Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chen calls for media restraint in reporting mafia head's passing

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the media to exercise restraint in covering the news of a Taiwanese mafia leader who died abroad but whose body was returned to Taiwan for burial Thursday.

Chen said it would not provide a good example for the younger generation if domestic television channels incessantly report on the funeral of Chen Chi-li, the former leader of Taiwan's notorious "Bamboo Union" underworld syndicate, how his followers worshipped him, and the scale of the procession in which the ringleader's body was escorted from the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, upon the arrival of his coffin from Hong Kong, to Neihu, Taipei City for a funeral.
The president said that TV stations covered the return of the body of Chen Chi- li, with SNGs and repeated live broadcasts, as though the late "Bamboo Union" ringleader were a head of state.
Meanwhile, Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials also called for Taiwan's media outlets not to cover Chen Chi-li as if he was a folk hero.

The body of Chen Chi-li -- who was first cast into the international spotlight in 1985 when he was hired by a military intelligence head to kill a dissident ethnic Chinese writer in California -- will temporarily rest at a location in Neihu until a formal funeral slated for early November.
A Taiwanese judge gave Chen Chi-li six years' imprisonment for his involvement in that crime. He later fled to Cambodia in the early 90s after being charged for further organized crime activities.

The gang leader then took up residence in Phnom Penh and became an active player among Taiwan businessmen operating in Cambodia. Although Taipei authorities had tried to have him extradited to Taiwan, their efforts were frustrated by the lack of an extradition treaty between Taiwan and Cambodia.
He died recently at a hospital in Hong Kong.

CIB officials urged "Bamboo Union" members and funeral organizers to stick to their promises to the police that during the funeral period, no members of the "Bamboo Union" or any other underworld rings would converge to challenge law enforcement authorities, that no teenagers or children should take part in funeral affairs, and that no type of uniform would be worn.
Meanwhile, CIB officials said that more than 600 policemen and policewomen were mobilized Thursday to collect evidence to be used later in the arrest of any gang members appearing on wanted lists.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to promote long-term care insurance

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew said Thursday that his party will promote long-term care insurance for elderly persons once it wins 2008 presidential elections.
Siew made the remarks during a ceremony held in Taipei to mark this year's Senior Citizens Day, in which Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng also attended.
Wang claimed that many elderly persons have felt insecure during the last seven years under the governance of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Noting that Taiwan has entered an era which will witness the aging of society, Siew said the KMT will promote long-term care insurance for the whole population, with elderly persons initially being covered, while it will continue to promote the pension system.

According to KMT's planning, the insurance will eventually be aimed at covering the whole population, including physically or mentally disabled persons, with the insured, the employers and the government sharing the cost of insurance premiums.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Museum of Taiwan History to be inaugurated

TEXT.P: The National Museum of Taiwan History located in Tainan City in southern Taiwan will be inaugurated Oct. 20, after eight years of planning and construction, a museum spokesman said at a news conference Thursday.
The spokesman said President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the museum's nameplate unveiling ceremony.

Positioning itself as an institute providing a thorough array of resources for research into Taiwanese history, the museum has made great efforts to gather historical materials from public museums, private collectors, overseas holdings, and firsthand surveys.
The museum will focus on the research, collection, exhibition, and education of Taiwanese history, the spokesman said.
Written materials relating to Taiwanese history and its relations with countries, including Netherlands, Spain, Japan, China, America, and Britain, are among the key collections of the museum.

The museum has compiled over 40,000 objects or materials related to Taiwanese history, including an atlas of Taiwan in the 16th and 17th centuries, agricultural tools, fishing equipment, and old photos and films made during Japanese ruling period.

The museum has over 20,000 books in its collections and will display the "Compendium of Materials on Taiwanese History" representing years of material collection and publication efforts at its inauguration ceremony. The compendium is the result of the largest yet research project on Taiwanese history, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to host final night of Miss Young International 2007

TEXT.P: The final competition of the Miss Young International 2007 beauty pageant will take place in Kaohsiung Oct. 27, with 35 contestants from around the world vying for the crown.
The gala night will be held in the student hall of National Sun Yat-sen University.

Taiwan is represented by Lee Yan-jin, 22, a runner-up of two beauty pageants in 2005, while China is represented by Liu Xiao-ou, 21, currently a visiting student in Canada. This will be the first time that contestants from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan will compete in a beauty pageant on the same stage.

Other contestants are from more than 30 countries, including Australia, Brazil, Canada, Denmark, Germany, Japan, Korea, Russia, the United Kingdom, the United States, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam and countries in East Europe and Central and South America.
Contestants began arriving in Taiwan Oct. 9. They toured Taichung in central Taiwan Oct. 14-16 and participated in a fashion show in the southern city of Tainan Oct. 17.

They will travel further south to join various activities in scenic areas of Pingtung County Oct. 20-23 before arriving in Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan, on Oct. 24 to prepare for the gala night.
The Miss Young International beauty pageant began 37 years ago. Its aim is to seek representatives to increase young people's awareness of sensitive social issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Media watchdog groups call for improvement in local news quality

TEXT.P: The quality of local news and journalists' rights to cover events irrespective of the political leanings of their employers should be improved, even though progress has been made in terms of Taiwan's press freedom, executives of several media watchdog organizations said Thursday.

The groups made the call after the Paris-based Reporters Without Borders released its global survey on press freedom for 2007 two days earlier in which Taiwan ranked first in Asia and 32nd in the world, up 11 places from last year.
Lu Shih-hsiang, director of the Foundation for the Advancement of Media Excellence, said the survey covered the period between the second half of 2006 and the first half of 2007.

During that period, Taiwan media focused their reports on corruption scandals involving President Chen Shui-bian, his family and his aides, which led Reporters Without Borders to conclude that media coverage in Taiwan is becoming more diverse.

However, Lu noted that an anti-corruption campaign began in Taiwan Sept. 16 last year during which a CtiTV reporter was harassed by "red-clad" demonstrators demanding that Chen step down for his alleged involvement in several scandals.
"The harassment incident indicates that Taiwan's political tension was obstructing local reporters," Lu said.

Lu noted that Taiwan has been making progress in the annual press freedom survey, moving from 61st place in 2003 to this year's 32nd place. However, he added, news quality in the country needs to be greatly improved.
Lu further said that local media need to work particularly hard to win the public's trust.

Describing Taiwan media as having a serious ideology problem, obviously favoring certain political parties in their news reports and being too commercialized, Lu urged local news media to strive to meet professional standards.
Connie Lin, chairwoman of the Broadcasting Development Fund (BFD), said Taiwan's journalists enjoy so much freedom that they "do not even know the boundaries of freedom."
Noting that the content of local news stories is often superficial, Lin said Taiwanese news media completely fail to objectively analyze current events and fulfill their "gatekeeper" role.
"As a result, Taiwan's high ranking in the press freedom index is not something that should be celebrated," she said.
Lin urged local media to engage in self-reflection to see whether Taiwan's high ranking can be translated into higher professional standards."
Meanwhile, she went on, "local reporters should also ask themselves if what they are doing now is what they wanted to do as journalists before they entered the profession."

Lin attributed Taiwan's high ranking to the fact that no reporters are imprisoned in the country and that government agencies seldom launch raids on the offices of local media outlets. Still, the high ranking does not represent the whole picture of Taiwan's media, she said.
Chen Hsiao-yi, president of the Association of Taiwan Journalists, for her part, said that the news environment in Taiwan is comparatively free compared with that of some other countries.

However, she pointed out that there is still room for improvement in Taiwanese reporters' rights to cover events, which she said can be illustrated by Yu Shyi- kun's announcement of a boycott of reporters at the China Times at the end of last year when he was chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Chen also cited the recent example of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) refusing to allow a Liberty Times reporter to enter a screening meeting to cover the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-democracy activist hopes Taiwan will shelter Myanmar refugees

TEXT.P: A visiting Myanmese pro-democracy activist based in Thailand expressed hope Thursday that Taiwan's government will shelter Myanmar refugees.
Nyo Ohn Myint, head of the foreign affairs department of the National League for Democracy led by Nobel prize winner Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, made the appeal during a call on Vice President Annette Lu.
Myint said that since the military crackdown on pro-democracy protesters many people have sought assistance, and that the refugees are moving toward the neighboring countries.

He hoped that the Taiwan government will enact legislation to accept refugees facing political prosecution, saying that this will best illustrate Taiwan's cherished ideal that a nation is built upon human rights.

The vice president noted that more than 30 civic groups gathered recently to lend support to the democratic movement in the southeast Asian nation and set up a website through the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) founded by her.
Lu also said that an alliance founded by her in support of Myanmar's democratization will hold a seminar Dec. 8-9 to discuss ways to give more support to democratization in Myanmar.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA defends U.N. bid stamp

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang defended Thursday a "U.N. for Taiwan" seal stamped on outbound letters by Taiwan Post, saying that he does not think that doing so would taint Taiwan's international image.

The stamp, demonstrating Taiwan's desire to enter the United Nations, is part of established government policy to express why the country wants to take part in the world body and to bring the issue into the international spotlight.
However, Huang said that he would respect everyone's feelings and expressed his belief that Taiwan Post would make adjustments if any customer feels annoyed with its "U.N. bid for Taiwan" stamp.

An English teacher from the United States complained Monday that his personal letter, destined to the United States, was stamped with the seal, arguing that Taiwan Post is not entitled to so mark his personal correspondence.

DOC.HEADLINE: European Taiwan group meets FAPA delegates in Brussels

TEXT.P: Members of the European Federation of Taiwanese Associations (EFTA) met their counterparts from the Formosan Association of Public Affairs (FAPA) in the United States Thursday in Brussels for talks on cementing ties in the cause of Taiwan.

FAPA President Chen Wen-yen is leading a number of FAPA advisers, including June Teufel Dreyer, professor of political science at the University of Miami at Coral Gables, and Stephen Yates, an adviser to Republican presidential candidate Rudy Giuliani, to a two-day meeting with EFTA executives and members.

EFTA executives said that they are pleased to meet with Chen and the FAPA advisers and hope that the EFTA will learn from FAPA's experiences during the two-day meeting, thereby helping them serve Taiwan's cause in Europe more efficiently.
The meeting may become the first of a series of regular gatherings to take place between the two Taiwanese organizations in years to come, EFTA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group calls for stricter surveillance of sex offenders

TEXT.P: Lawmakers and civic group representatives paid a visit Thursday to Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin and called for stepped up surveillance and reformatory treatment of sexual assault criminals.
Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Yang Lee-huan and Taiwan Coalition Against Violence representative Chang Chin-li made the request to Shih to better protect women's and children's safety.
According to Yang and Chang, the Justice Ministry has fallen short of working out a comprehensive oversight and reformatory program for this kind of criminals who are prone to reoffend.

Chang blamed relevant government agencies, including the Justice Ministry, for failing to earmark more funds to serve that end and questioned why the ministry is not more intent on pursuing the matter.

Shih rebutted Chang's accusation and argued that his ministry has always attached a great importance to the issue, pointing out that relevant agencies and establishments -- such as medical and aftercare facilities -- must also collaborate in the effort.

According to Shih, the Ministry of Justice contributes some 29 percent of its annual budget to nationwide reformatory programs per year, a level which is well ahead of those appropriated for prosecution.
Shih, however, promised to staff 450 reformatory positions in three years to better deal with complications arising from a manpower squeeze in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmaker sues premier over U.N. bid signature drive

TEXT.P: Kuo Su-chun, a legislative caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), sued Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, several ranking officials and seven local government chiefs Thursday for what she called their illegal push for a signature drive led by the ruling party in pursuit of Taiwan's U.N. cause.

Kuo filed the lawsuit on behalf of the caucus with the Taipei Prosecutors Office against Chang, Deputy Finance Minister Lee Ruey-tsang and Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-feng, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chi, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tian-tsair, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu and Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung on charges of document forgery and hindrance of freedom.

In a written statement, Kuo accused Chang of using his position as the nation's top administrative chief to ask several agencies under the Executive Yuan to transfer some of their budgetary funds to help the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) with its signature drive for a U.N. membership bid referendum.

The KMT legislative caucus demanded that prosecutors look into whether Chang has broken relevant laws by asking that local government chiefs and official agencies fall in line with the DPP's campaign.
Lee was charged with unlawfully demanding that subordinate departments cooperate in the DPP's signature drive and that their staffers sign their names to the U.N. bid petition.

In addition, Sports Affairs Council Chairman Yang Chung-ho is being sued for breach of trust and embezzlement for allegedly allocating NT$100 million (US$3.07 million) from the council's budget to fund a planned DPP torch relay, slated for Oct. 24, to bolster Taiwan's U.N. cause.

The seven local government chiefs, all DPP members, were accused of forging documents and hindering freedom by requiring that township delegates secretly use the personal seals of elderly villagers to stamp the DPP's U.N. bid referendum petitions when making cash gifts to them on the occassion of an annual festival in honor of senior citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTC starts investigation into vegetable price gouging

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) has started an investigation into cases of vegetable price gouging recently reported in the news in Yunlin County in southern Taiwan, an FTC official said Thursday.

According to the official, the FTC has activated its emergency response system in order to deal with problematic vegetable price hikes and the exploitation of farmers in the wake of damages done by Typhoon Krosa, which hit Taiwan earlier this month.

The FTC has already sent a team to the fruit and vegetable wholesale market in Yunlin County's Hsiluo township to learn whether the reported cases of exploitation are factual, the official said, adding that local police and governemnt authorities will also enhance evidence gathering methods to help with the FTC investigation.
The FTC also sent another team to Yilan County's Sanhsing township in northeastern Taiwan, where the popular Sanhsing green onion is grown, to inquire into the bidding up of green onion prices.

The official said the FTC has not found evidence proving news reports that green onion prices have tripled. He explained that the reports might be a result of comparing the prices of green onions from different production areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two national universities in Taipei to merge in 2010

TEXT.P: The National Taipei University of Education (NTUE) is expected to be incorporated into National Taiwan University (NTU) in 2010, the heads of the two universities told lawmakers Thursday.

Answering questions from legislators in the Legislative Yuan, NTU President Lee Si-chen and his NTUE counterpart Chuang Chi-min said preparations for the merger are under way, and that the two universities expect to merge in 2010.

The plan to combine the two universities was proposed by the Ministry of Education more than 10 years ago, and the executives of the two schools have been working together to thrash out differences ever since.

Lee pointed out that the plan will be carried out in three stages, with the first stage allowing students of both universities to share the use of their libraries and to select each other's courses of study.

According to Lee, in the second stage, NTUE professors will be invited to teach courses at NTU, while NTU faculty members will join in the screening process to hire teachers for NTUE. After the differences between the two universities are narrowed, the institutions will be prepared for the third stage, becoming a single institution.
The 110-year-old NTUE is the oldest academic institution in Taiwan, while the NTU, only blocks away, is widely considered the best and most prestigious university in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ace Taiwan go player becomes youngest female Honinbo title holder
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/18/07 23:44:35 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Xie Yimin, a Taiwan-born ace go player who won the coveted Japanese female Honinbo title a day earlier, said Thursday that she loves the subtle Oriental board game with her whole heart and that there is still ample room for her to perfect her proficiency.
Xie defeated the defending Honinbo title holder, Kumiko Yashuro, 3-0 Wednesday in a best-of-five final.

At the age of 17 years and 11 months, Xie became the youngest Honinbo title holder in the event's 26-year history, taking 5.8 million Japanese yen (US$50,150) in prize money. She was also the youngest member when she was admitted to the Nihon Ki-in, the Japanese professional go academy, three year ago.
Xie, born in the northern Taiwan county of Miaoli, came to Japan five years ago to pursue a career in the intellectually challenging board game known as "wei- chi" in Taiwan.
A third-dan go player, Xie said she has yet to reach the professional game's top tier. "I still have a long way to go hit the pinnacle of the career," she told CNA in an interview.

As a matter of fact, Xie said she was not satisfied with her performance in the Honinbo contest. "I look forward to improvement in a world go championship to be held in Beijing late this month, " she said modestly. Xie is scheduled to represent Taiwan in the 2010 Guangzhou Asian Games' go event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose up against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing Gen. George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kilograms, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kilograms of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was admired most by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British had closed it for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1979: Lord Killanin, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1981: San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros declares that the historic city in Texas will establish sisterhood ties with the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The decline is 22.6 percent, almost 10 percent greater than the stock market crash of 1929, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, leader of the USSR, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch the centrally planned Soviet economy to a market economy.
1999: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: The ROC's opposition Kuomintang expels Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin- yi from the party, chiding him for "severely opposing KMT policies and impeding the interests of the people."
2001: Vice President Annette Lu receives 1998 Nobel laureate in medicine, Dr. Ferid Murad, at the Presidential Office.
2001: U.S. President George W. Bush tells reporters that in a meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, he reiterated Washington's stance on the Taiwan issue, namely "one China" and "a resolution of differences through peaceful means."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: Think-tank adjusts 2007 economic growth forecast upward

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) raised its forecast Friday for Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 to 4.55 percent.
The CIER forecast in July that Taiwan's economic growth rate for the year would be 4.26 percent.
Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 4.52 percent in the fourth quarter, CIER researchers said.
They also forecast an economic growth rate of 4.41 percent for the nation for 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier denies financing referendum drive with government funds

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung denied Friday allegations by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that the Cabinet has misappropriated government funds to finance activities promoting a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -backed U.N. bid referendum petition.

Chang said the Cabinet has "not spent even a dime" on activities related to the referendum, although the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Government Information Office have drawn on their budgets to support activities designed to promote the government's policy of bidding to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
Calling the allegations "100 percent untrue, " Chang challenged the KMT to present substantive evidence to support their claims.

The legislative caucus of the KMT has recently sued Chang for breach of trust and corruption for allegedly instructing agencies under the Cabinet to appropriate funds from other parts of their budgets to sponsor activities promoting the DPP-initiated referendum petition.

The caucus has also filed a separate law suit against Chang and seven local government chiefs for forgery and obstruction of freedom, demanding that prosecutors investigate whether Chang had instructed the local government chiefs to take advantage of their positions to help collect signatures for the DPP's petition for the U.N. bid referendum.
The DPP wants the referendum to be held alongside the March 2008 presidential election and aims to collect 2 million signatures by the end of this month for the referendum petition.

With promotion of the U.N. bid being the main policy plank of the DPP administration, the Cabinet has organized various activities for the purpose, including designating Oct. 24 -- the anniversary of the coming into force of the U.N. Charter which is celebrated internationally as United Nations Day -- as "Taiwan United Nations Day" and kickstarting a 11-day nationwide torch relay on that day.
