DOC.HEADLINE: CEC remains open on ballot format

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will remain open on the ballot format issue concerning next year's legislative and presidential elections, CEC Chairman Masa J.S. Chang said Friday.
Chang said that the CEC members are scheduled to meet Oct. 26 to discuss the way in which ballots should be handed out in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

As a referendum on two proposals will be held in conjunction with the legislative elections, the CEC will discuss whether to hand out the two ballots -- one for the legislative elections and the other for the two referendum proposals -- simultaneously or separately, Chang noted.

Chang was referring to the referendum proposal initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to retrieve what it calls the "ill-gotten" assets amassed by the Kuomintang (KMT) during its five decades of rule, and the proposal initiated by the opposition KMT against corruption.

If the two ballots are handed out separately, the voters will first receive the ballot for the legislative elections and then receive the referendum ballot only after casting the first ballot. This method was used in the 2004 presidential election in which a referendum was simultaneously held.
If the two ballots are handed out at the same time, the voters will cast the ballots in separate boxes.
Chang said that after the Jan. 12 legislative elections are held, the CEC will use the elections as a reference in deciding which ballot format to adopt for the March 22 presidential election.

Two referendum proposals -- one initiated by the DPP on the nation's applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan and the other initiated by the KMT on the country applying to return to the world body under its official name, the Republic of China -- are also expected to be held in tandem with the presidential election.

Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said that if the CEC insists on adopting the "one shot" format of handing out two ballots simultaneously in next year's presidential election, the KMT will ask all counties and cities under the "pan-blue alliance, " namely the KMT, the People's First Party and the New Party, to boycott the ballot format.
Tseng said the "pan-blue alliance" favors the "two step" format of handing out the two ballots separately in the March 22 presidential election.

Kuo Su-chun, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, asked the CEC to first allay people's concerns about the "one shot" ballot format before making its final decision for the next presidential election.

Included among the concerns about the "one shot" ballot format are that people might smuggle ballots out of the polling stations, that the voting process might be too time-consuming and lead to long queues at polling stations, that voters might unwittingly cast both ballots into one box, which could affect the election results, and that counting the votes in the presidential election would take longer to complete.

According to a United Daily News report Thursday, if the CEC decides to hand out two ballots simultaneously in the presidential election, this will help boost the turnout rate and the chances of the U.N. bid proposal by the DPP being passed. The proposal will also help galvanize support for the ruling party in the presidential election, according to the report.

Under the current Referendum Law, a proposal will be considered passed if the referendum turnout rate exceeds half of all eligible voters and if 50 percent of those who cast ballots vote in favor of the proposal.

In the 2004 presidential election, two proposals initiated by President Chen and put to a referendum -- one on purchasing more missiles to counter the military threat from China, and the other on engaging in dialogue with China -- failed to pass because many of those who voted in the election refused to cast referendum ballots.
Although 90 percent of those who cast ballots in the referendum voted in favor of the proposals, the referendum turnout rate was only 45 percent of all eligible voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: No peace accord possible under 'one China' framework: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has again rejected Beijing's "one China" principle as the precondition for the establishment of a cross-Taiwan Strait peace accord, saying any agreements signed under such a principle would mean surrender for Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks during an interview with the New York Times, which took place Thursday in Taipei, during which he was asked to comment on a recent peace overture by Chinese President Hu Jintao.

During Monday's meeting of the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Hu called for the formation of a framework for peaceful development of cross-strait relations "on the basis of the one China principle, " which has been characterized as a proposal for a cross-strait peace agreement.

Chen told the paper that although Taiwan has always welcomed the idea of signing a peace accord with China, the country opposes any preconditions or framework being set and any conclusions being reached prior to discussing an agreement, according to the transcript of the interview released Friday by the Presidential Office.
"We are even more opposed to missile threats or the use of non-peaceful means or military force to coerce any party into signing a peace accord," Chen said.
Against this backdrop, Chen outlined the three conditions that would need to be met before the two sides could start any discussion on the proposed accord.

They are namely that China openly renounce the use of force against Taiwan, that China repeal its Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan, and that China give up the notion of the "one China" framework, Chen said.
Chen stressed that Taiwan is a country independent of China and that accepting the "one China" principle "would spell the end of Taiwan as an independent, sovereign country."

On the country's plan to hold a referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, which has met strong opposition from the United States, Chen reiterated that holding such a referendum does not involve changing the country's official name or violating his "four noes" pledges to the United States.

The president said that although the referendum will be of no help to Taiwan's bid to become a U.N. member, it remains the most direct and democratic way for the country's 23 million people to express to the world their strong aspiration for U.N. membership.

"The point is that we want our collective voice to be heard by the whole world. The 23 million people of Taiwan will not be silenced just because of China's military intimidation, its missiles pointed at use, its coercion and its threats," he said.

According to Chen, joining the United Nations would boost Taiwan's economy, because the country could then hold talks freely with countries around the world for the signing of free trade agreements and take part in all organizations under the U.N. umbrella, including the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 64 points to close at 9,613, with 30,317 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December lost 54 points to finish at 9,626, with 107 contracts traded, while March futures lost 37 points to close at 9,627, with one contract transaction. September futures decreased 51 points to close at 9,450, with 10 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 9,677 for November, 9,680 for December, 9,664 for March, 9,601 for June, and 9,501 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

November TE futures lost 3.25 points to close at 400.45, with 2,904 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 4.45 points to finish at 399.55, with 14 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures moved down 12.4 points to close at 1,051.2, with 2,229 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures lost 9.2 points to finish at 1,053, with seven contracts traded. March TF futures increased 2.2 points to close at 1,066, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP calls for support of democratic movement in Myanmar

TEXT.P: Two lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged relevant authorities Friday to act through diplomatic channels to press the ruling junta of Myanmar to release at once Nobel peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, whom it has held under house arrest for years.

Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, who commands the DPP's department of international affairs, and Legislator Huang Sue-ying made the call at a press conference they jointly held at the Legislative Yuan with Nyo Ohn Myint, a former spokesman for Aung San Suu Kyi.
Both Hsiao and Huang also called on the government to support the democratic movement in Myanmar, also known as Burma.

At the same time, Hsiao blasted China, a powerful ally of Myanmar in the Asia- Pacific region, for "holding the candle to the devil" by ignoring the junta's brutal repression of democratic activists and monks through armed crackdown, arbitrary detentions and killings.

Nyo Ohn Myint revealed that the military junta's recent crackdown on peaceful pro-democracy marches led by monks on the streets of Myanmar is believed to have resulted in the death of more than 200 monks, while another 5,000 have been arrested and 2,000 more are missing.

Although the bloody crackdown has brought scrutiny and concern from international society, the autocratic rulers of Myanmar continue to suppress human rights and murder pro-democracy activists and monks.

Without the international community's censure, the military junta would have killed and prosecuted even more peaceful democracy aspirants, Nyo Ohn Myint said. Calling for the Taiwanese people and their legislature to support the efforts of the people of Myanmar seeking democracy, he named Taiwan, a democratic country which has also suffered under autocratic rule in the past, as a model for his country in its fight for democracy.

Nyo Ohn Myint also mentioned that although there have been envoys dispatched by the United Nations to negotiate an end to the inhumane crackdown on the democratic movement in Myanmar, they have all failed to bring even a glimmer of peace to the country.

He was informed that Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the ongoing non-violent movement for democracy in Myanmar, has been very much saddened by the bloody military crackdown on peaceful demonstrators. The military continues to accuse the peace activist of seeking to "destroy the country's unity," Nyo Ohn Myint said.
Based in Thailand, Nyo Ohn Myint now serves as the Global Burma Campaign coordinator of the National League for Democracy (NLD), the main opposition in Myanmar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dialogue under 'one China' premise unacceptable: DPP

TEXT.P: China's seeking talks with Taiwan under the "one China" policy is unacceptable to Taiwan, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official in charge of international affairs said Friday.

Hsiao Bi-khim, a DPP legislator recently appointed by President Chen Shui-bian to head the party's International Affairs Department after Chen assumed the DPP chairmanship, said Taiwan has long supported both peaceful dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and the notion that the two sides should be free to seek their own separate development paths in peace.

Peaceful interaction, however, presupposes that cross-strait dialogue takes place under the principles of justice and dignity, Hsiao said, adding that Taiwan cannot accept a cross-strait dialogue under a "one China" principle.

Hsiao made the remarks in a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan in response to Chinese President Hu Jintao's statement at the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China Oct. 15 that China will seek talks with Taiwan under the "one China" principle in hopes of ending the hostilities between the two sides and signing a bilateral peace agreement.

Stressing that there can be no peace without justice, Hsiao said any cross- strait pact or agreement signed between the two sides should first be discussed under circumstances in which the dignity of the Taiwan people is fully respected and that Taiwan's identity is fully acknowledged.
She said the "one China" policy denies the rights of the Taiwan people to make the choice of their own free will.

Noting that some Taiwanese individuals and political parties have accepted the "one China" policy unconditionally, which she said made her feel extremely distressed, Hsiao called on China to forsake the military intimidation of Taiwan and to drop the "one China" policy as a prerequisite for resuming cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.023 to close at NT$32.572.
A total of US$1.11 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.541 and closed at the day's high of NT$32.608.

DOC.HEADLINE: New electoral system could squeeze female political participation: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed concern Friday that a new electoral system set to be implemented during the upcoming legislative elections could squeeze the political participation of Taiwanese women.
However, despite such concerns, the good news is that half of the at-large legislative seats will be reserved for women under the new system, Lu said.

Lu raised the issue during a conference on gender mainstreaming held in central Taichung County, referring to the single-member constituency, two-vote system that will be implemented for the first time during the January 2008 legislative elections.
Also starting in the next legislative elections, the number of seats to be up for grabs will be halved to 113 from the current 225.
Lu noted that currently, 268 members of city and county councils around Taiwan are women.

Meanwhile only 25 out of the total of 319 township and village chiefs are women, and two of 23 local government chiefs in Taiwan are women, Lu said, urging the authorities concerned to work to increase the representation of women in politics.
Despite the low rate of participation by women in politics, the high socioeconomic status of Taiwanese women has received much international recognition, Lu said.

Citing a global report on the issue, Lu said the socioeconomic status of Taiwan's women ranks 19th highest among 193 countries surveyed, with Norway's first, the United States' 12th, Japan's 44th and South Korea's 60th.
Over the past 30 years, Taiwanese women have become more and more financially independent, which shows that the era of gender equality has arrived in the country, according to Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 25.35 points to close at 9,611.72.
The bourse opened at 9,666.58 and fluctuated between 9,673.96 and 9,609.58. A total of 4.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$138.99 billion (US$4.27 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, textile stocks fell 0.6 percent, and paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 680, with 270 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER adjusts 2007 economic growth forecast upward

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) raised its forecast Friday for Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 to 4.55 percent, 0.29 percentage points higher than that forecast by the think tank in July.

The rosier growth forecast for 2007 is based on the expectation that the domestic economy will expand in the second half of the year at a rate on a par with that posted in the first half year, said Wang Li-jung, director of the CIER Forecast Center.

Wang said the growth posted in the first half year -- a benefit of the steady recovery of the world market and brisk economic performance at home -- was better than expected. In the first six months of this year, consumption in the private sector expanded 3.4 percent over the year-earlier level, while investment in the private business sector grew 4.46 percent, a growth rate much higher than that posted in the government and official sectors.

CIER researchers forecast that Taiwan's overall economic growth will top 4.52 percent in the fourth quarter, with consumption and investment in the private sector growing at a rate slightly slower than that posted in Q3, while two-way trade is expected to perform better in Q4, according to Wang.

Meanwhile, Peng Su-ling, a deputy researcher with the CIER Forecast Center, said the center chose to adjust upward the 2007 economic growth forecast to 4.55 percent mainly as a result of better-than-expected domestic investment in Q2.
In Q2, Peng said, local investment in capital goods soared by 20 percent, with investment in semiconductor and TFT-LCD flat panel manufacturing industries leading the list.
CIER researchers also forecast an economic growth rate of 4.41 percent for the nation in 2008, slightly lower than the 2007 level.

They forecast that private sector consumption in 2008 will advance 2.91 percent over the 2007 level and that domestic investment will grow 4.94 percent, but the export trade in 2008 will slow a bit compared to 2007, mainly as a result of lower demand in the world market, while the import trade will be better than in 2007, due to greater demands in the domestic market.
The researchers forecast that the consumer price index in Taiwan will rise 1.98 percent in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan investors in China facing labor shortage problems
DOC.DATELINE: Kunshan, Jiangsu province, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/07 18:49:47 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: China is no longer a cheap labor manufacturing base it used to be, Chiang Pin- kung, vice chairman of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday.

Speaking at the 2007 Forum on Cross-Strait Industrial Cooperation and Development held in Kunshan, Jiangsu province, Chiang said most Taiwanese investors in China's coastal areas are facing labor shortage problems.

Chiang noted that Beijing's economic development policy now places greater emphasis on China's central, western and northeastern areas and that authorities have become more selective in approving investments from Taiwan.
As a result, Taiwanese businessmen who plan to set up a labor-intensive manufactory in China's coastal areas are facing a higher investment threshold and limited maneuvering room, he said.
Chiang added that Taiwanese investors in China are also facing rising production costs and difficulties acquiring materials for their factories.
He pointed out that the labor shortage is coupled with the problem of rising wages, with the average monthly wage for a worker in a Taiwanese-invested factory now surpassing US$200.

According to Chiang, Taiwanese investors looking to survive in business are left with two alternatives: moving their production bases to China's inland areas or to the north, or transforming their businesses to technology-intensive or service industries.

The annual forum, organized by the Kunshan city government and the Association of Taiwan Businessmen in Kunshan, is in its seventh year. More than 300 people, including some 100 academics, industrialists and politicians from Taiwan, are taking part in two days of discussions.
The focus of this year's forum is on outsourcing services and the prospect of the optoelectronics industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N.-bid torch relay not legal in Taipei City: city official

TEXT.P: A planned torch relay scheduled to kick off in the capital city Oct. 24 is illegal under the Assembly and Parade Law, Taipei city government spokesman Yang Hsiao-tung said Friday.

Yang made the statement in response to a written request by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) -- the organizer of the round-the-nation torch relay aimed at promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations -- that executive city officials participate in the first leg of the relay from Taipei City to Taipei County.
The 1,200-km torch relay, which is planned to cover all 25 cities and counties around the country, is expected to take 11 days to complete, according to SAC.
In a letter to the Taipei city government, the SAC also asked for city police's assistance in maintaining traffic order during the run.

In response, Yang criticized the central government, the sponsor of the U.N.-bid torch relay, for having never put its plan to occupy Taipei road space to the city government for approval and for failing to apply for the right to hold a march in Taipei as required by law.

Without the city government's permission, the planned run will be "obviously an illegal activity, " Yang said. In this regard, he went on, it is not the obligation of city officials to take part in the relay, nor the duty of the city's law-enforcing authorities to police the "illegal activity."

If the central government insists on carrying out the torch relay in Taipei, the city government will charge it for violating the Assembly and Parade Law, the Statute for Road Traffic Management and Punishment and the Constitution, Yang said.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin of the opposition Kuomintang reiterated at the city council earlier in the day his support for Taiwan's U.N. bid, while he described joining the U.N. as a universal goal. However, he underlined that he supports seeking a U.N. seat under the name "Republic of China."

The "China" seat in the United Nations was taken over by the People's Republic of China at the expense of the Republic of China in 1971. Taiwan has tried without success since 1993 to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation.

With promotion of the U.N. bid being a main policy plank of the Democratic Progressive Party administration, the Cabinet decided to designated Oct. 24 -- the anniversary of the coming into force of the Charter of the United Nations, which is celebrated internationally as United Nations Day -- as "Taiwan United Nations Day" and is pushing for a referendum on whether to apply to join the world body under the name "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival to open in February

TEXT.P: The 2008 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival is scheduled to run from Feb. 16 through April 20 next year, according to a decision reached Friday at a preparatory meeting of the Hsinchu city government.
Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tser told reporters that the theme of the festival will be "Mermaids Touring the Glass Fairyland."
Lin said a "glass art street" in a former air force dependents' village near the Hsinchu Glass Art Museum in Hsinchu Park will remain open from Feb. 2 to May 1.
He added that in addition to exhibitions of works by renowned glass artists in Taiwan, there will be music and dance performances to entertain visitors.
Hsinchu, which has dubbed itself the "city of culture and science, "has organized the biennial event since 1995. The 2006 festival attracted more than 410,000 visitors

DOC.HEADLINE: Comprehensive project to care for the elderly unveiled

TEXT.P: The government has unveiled a comprehensive project to care for the elderly in view of the rapid graying of the population, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Friday, the nation's Senior Citizen's Day.
MOI officials noted that the ratio of the elderly accounted for 10 percent of the total population in 2006, which is why the government has mapped out the 10-year, long-term care project.

Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang recently said that the Executive Yuan has approved the project to invest more than NT$81.7 billion (US$2.47 billion) in the decade between 2007 and 2016 for the long-term care project.
The comprehensive project will see the integration of services for the elderly currently provided by a variety of government agencies, as well as the addition of new services.
MOI officials said that depending on the financial situation and the preparations of the cities and counties, various services under the project will kick off in November at the earliest.

The new services include family care services, meaning that incapacitated elders can be sent to qualified families for care, and the government will provide subsidies based on the degree of the incapacity.
The other services are in-home rehabilitation if the elders cannot be delivered to a medical institution, and transportation services for the seriously incapacitated.

Government subsidies will also be expanded to cover medium-income households in addition to low- and lower-income households, although the amount of the subsidies will vary based on the category to which the households belong.
The government will provide full subsidies to low-income families, 90 percent subsidies to lower-income families and 60 percent to medium-income families.
The government will also extend subsidies to medium-income families to improve the mobility of elders under their care, such as the purchase of wheelchairs.
But meal service will be confined to low- and lower-income families, with the maximum subsidy providing for one meal per person.

To ease the burden on family caregivers, the government will also launch a "take a break service, " but only for those who have cared for elders for more than a month are eligible to apply, and those who have already hired foreign caregiver will be ineligible for the subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Picture book, exhibition to help Taiwan children understand Europe

TEXT.P: Explaining what the European Union (EU) is to adults is difficult enough, let alone explaining it to children, but there is no better way to introduce the EU to children in Taiwan than with a picture book, an EU official in Taiwan said Friday.

Speaking to a group of kindergarten children at the Taipei Public Library, Guy Ledoux, head of the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) in Taiwan, described the EU as "a big family of 27 children with different habits, but they have to obey the same rules."

Ledoux and French Institute in Taiwan Director Jean-Claude Poimbeouf were among a group of European representatives who launched an exhibition featuring the children's picture book "Petits Europeens (Little Europeans)", by French illustrator Nicole Lambert.
In 60 boards with texts in Chinese, Taiwan citizens will be able to explore the work of Lambert, an illustrator best known for her devotion to children's picture books.

"I hope that many children from Taiwan will visit the exhibition and will learn more about Europe. I hope that when they grow up and become students, some will come and study in Europe and see for themselves the great diversity of European countries and enjoy the various landscape, food and tradition, " Ledoux said.

The book tried to introduce background information, stories and traditions of the 27 EU member states to children around the world. The educational effort is part of a series of events the EETO has organized to help the people of Taiwan understand more about Europe, and to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the EU.
The EETO will organize a European Film Festival in 12 universities later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Returning students with overseas arts training present results

TEXT.P: Students receiving overseas art training under a scholarship program offered by the Ministry of Education (MOE) met to share their experience and training results at a news conference at the MOE Friday.

The MOE selected 12 outstanding, talented art and design students to study abroad for one year at different art institutes under its Art and Design Elite Scholarship Program in 2006. These students were put in three groups: creative design, graphic design, and digital media design.

Chen Hung-chih, a creative design student, said he learned a lot about German design and logic during his stay at Germany's Hochschule Fur Gestaltung Offenbach. During the training period, he created 11 projects that brought him awards and prize money in both domestic and international design competitions.

A graphic design student, Chang Yao-chung, who stayed at the Pratt Institute of the Arts in the United States, received an official offer of admission from the school after producing an outstanding calendar recording nuanced changes in a girl's moods.

Another four digital media design students who stayed at the Savannah College of Arts and Design in America have worked together on aproject called "Dung Beetle" which explores an interesting interpretation of consumer behavior through the relationship between dung and the dung beetle.

An official said that the MOE selected students for training next year during a seminar in early September. The design projects of students who joined the camp were also exhibited at the news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor vows to make city most suitable place for elderly

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin vowed Friday to join hands with the private sector to make the city the most suitable place for elderly people to live.

Hau said Taipei has been rated as one of the most suitable cities for the elderly, noting that its transportation development, medical resources, welfare for the elderly and amenities have reached a high standard.
But faced with the rapid rise in the elderly population, Hau said the city will have to work with the private sector to integrate social resources and build up a seamless welfare network.
According to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and released in September 2006, the number of those aged over 65 had reached 2 million.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development estimates that the ratio of the elderly will account for 16.5 percent of the total population between 2010 and 2015, and will climb to 21.6 percent after 2036.
A total of 13.4 percent of the nation's elderly live in Taipei, the highest percentage of all cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA launches program to help graduates find jobs

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) launched a program Friday to help unemployed young people find jobs amid high unemployment rates among new graduates.

Many young people in Taiwan cannot find jobs after they graduate, CLA Chairman Lu Tien-lin noted, adding that the current youth unemployment rate is 11.6 percent, which is three times Taiwan's overall unemployment rate.
According to the results of a CLA survey, 60-70 percent of local young people who responded to the survey said that they had trouble finding their first job, Lu noted
The survey also found that up to 40 percent of local companies polled have shut out first-time job seekers, Lu went on.

In an effort to help local young people, Lu said that the CLA has allocated NT$250 million (US$7.6 million) for the job-training program, which will be implemented in three phases over the next 18 months.
People under the age of 29, with a bachelor's or master's degree, are qualified to file an application with local job service stations to receive three months of on-the-job training, Lu said.
Each participant in the program will receive a monthly subsidy of NT$12,096, according to Lu.

A total of local 112 enterprises -- including Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) -- have supported the CLA program by offering 1,409 job opportunities, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film festival organizers call for Taiwan to abolish death penalty

TEXT.P: Taiwan should follow the global trend and abolish the death penalty, human rights advocates said at a film festival screening death penalty-related movies from various countries.

"The government always said death penalties were imposed in the name of the people, which means each and every one of us played a role in the execution of death row inmates. But did we really authorize the government to do that for us? " said Kao Yong-cheng, a lawyer who represented Human Rights Protection Committee of the Taipei Bar Association on the sidelines of the second "Murder by Numbers" film festival.

The festival, which was organized by Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty (TAEDP) , screened nine documentary films from Italy, France, Sweden, Denmark, India and the U.S., which all focused on the issue of death penalty.

There is a global trend to abolish the death penalty, said Italian director Mario Marazziti, whose film "Thou Shall Not Kill" is being screened. He noted that the death penalty has been abolished in more than 90 countries, and that there are 43 countries where there has not been a single execution in the past 10 years.

One of the films, "Un Abolistionniste: Robert Badinter, " documents the life story of Badinter, a high-profile French criminal lawyer, university professor and politician known for his struggle against the death penalty. The death penalty was abolished when Badinter served as Minister of Justice in 1981.
It took France almost 200 years to abolish the death penalty, showing that how difficult it is to tackle the issue, said Jean-Claude Poimbeouf, director of French Institute in Taiwan.

The penalty has always been a political issue, which is why it will take political measures to deal with the issue, Poimbeouf said, adding that most Taiwanese political leaders have a background in the practice of law and that they should reconsider abolishing the ultimate punishment given their expertise in both politics and law.

Most people think that crime rates will increase once the penalty is abolished, but this idea is false, said Go Yu-ling, Secretary-General of Taiwan International Workers' Association. In fact, surveys in various countries showed that crime rates did not rise after the abolition of the death penalty.

The festival, which was previously held in 2004, has been relatively successful, having doubled its viewership, said TAEDP executive director Lin Hsin-yi. The films are being shown in Kaohsiung this week after having been first shown in Taipei last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to expand global reach of Taiwan's LED industry

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has launched a four-year program aimed at expanding the global reach of Taiwan's white light emitting diode (LED) industry, an IDB official said Friday.
Under the program the IDB will establish testing standards for the industry, help promote investment, increase international cooperation and provide training courses, the official noted.
Describing LED lights as eco-friendly and energy-saving, the official said that the new technology can be applied in a wide range of areas and its production value is continuing to grow.
According to the official, Taiwan's white LED industry has a complete supply chain and generates an annual output of US$1.4 billion, which accounts for 23 percent of the global market.

The bureau has commissioned the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) to implement the program, the official went on, adding that the ITRI will help local manufacturers develop core technologies in an effort to enhance the competitiveness of their products.
In addition, the bureau will help form an industrial alliance to promote the integration of industrial chains, which the official said will provide a boost to Taiwan's LED industry.
The industry has been granted a subsidy of over NT$150 million (US$4.6 million) from the MOEA, the official added.

Without the establishment of uniform testing standards and regulations at home, the official said that it is necessary to take part in relevant international events to understand global trends in this regard and to learn from other countries' experience.

The official pointed out that a number of Japanese companies have already set up factories in Taiwan, and their cooperation with local manufacturers is beneficial to enhancing the quality for Taiwan's LED products.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid torch relay national sports event: premier

TEXT.P: A planned round-the-country torch relay promoting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations is a "national sports event, " rather than a "political activity " as it is described by the Taipei city government, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday.

Chang said it is not up to the city government to decide whether or not the relay run scheduled to kick off in Taipei Oct. 24 is a political event and therefore regulated by the Assembly and Parade Law.
Activities cannot be defined as political simply because they draw the participation of politicians, according to Chang.

Chang made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in response to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hsu Shao-ping's questioning of the city government's defining of the U.N. bid torch relay earlier in the day as an "illegal activity" due to the organizer's failure to apply for the local government's approval.

Earlier, city government spokesman Yang Hsiao-tung said the city government has formally informed the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) , the organizer of the torch relay at the instruction of the Cabinet, that it will charge the central government for violating the laws if it insists on carrying out the run in the capital city.

In response to Hsu's question, SAC Minister Yang Chung-ho pointed out that over the past half-century, road runs have been regarded as sports events aimed at boosting the health of the people. Therefore, they are not governed by the Assembly and Parade Law, he said.

The national torch relay, part of the Cabinet's effort to promote the U.N. bid under the name Taiwan, is planned to pass through all 25 cities and counties around the country in 11 days, according to the SAC.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOF provides online self examination for osteoporosis

TEXT.P: The International Osteoporosis Foundation (IOF) provides an online checklist allowing the public to carry out quick self-examination on the risk of osteoporosis, Taiwan Osteoporosis Association President Sung Yung-kuei said Friday.
The list provides questions relating to 19 risk factors for osteoporosis, a disease characterized by low bone mass leading to increased susceptibility to fractures, Sung said.

Family history of osteoporosis, low body weight, old age, smoking, excess alcohol, menopause and personal clinical history including bone fractures and use of corticosteroide tablets, are all crucial factors for the disease, Sung said.
Sung suggested that people consult a doctor if they are in a high-risk group according to the check list.

Citing the results of a national health survey conducted by the Department of Health, Sung said women are three times more likely to develop the disease than men, though men can still suffer from osteoporosis.
More than 70 percent of women over 50 who received osteoporosis tests at three Taiwanese hospitals were found to be in the high-risk group for the disease, Sung said.

Taiwan Orthopedic Association President Chen Wen-cho, suggested that people under 30 take more exercise, get more exposure to the sun and have a balanced diet rich in calcium in order to defend against developing osteoporosis in later life.
The same efforts by people over 30 will only slow down the speed of loss of bone mass, he added.
Chen called on osteoporosis patients to keep taking prescribed medicine for at least two to three years.

Osteoporosis patients tend to quit medication sooner than that because it causes gastrointestinal discomfort, but the possibility of hip fractures increases if patients do not complete their course of treatment, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Buses to gain access to Hsuehshan Tunnel in mid-November

TEXT.P: Passenger buses are expected to gain access to Hsuehshan Tunnel, the centerpiece of the Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei and Yilan counties from Nov. 15, following Thursday's successful fire drill in the tunnel, a National Freeway Bureau official said Friday.

The drill was aimed at ensuring that people would be able to escape smoothly and that proper air ventilation would be maintained amid the heavy smoke expected to result from a fire triggered by a bus crash in the 12.9-km tunnel, the official said.

The bureau will submit the drill reports to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications next week for further evaluation, the official said, adding that if all goes well, tour buses will be allowed to use the tunnel from Nov. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news

Two bombs exploded Thursday just seconds apart and feet from a truck carrying the returning opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, narrowly missing her but killing scores of people and bloodying her triumphal homecoming after eight years in exile.
The Wall Street Journal: Bombings Mar Bhutto's Return to Pakistan
Hours after Pakistani opposition leader Benazir Bhutto landed here to mass celebrations, two explosions near her cavalcade killed up to 126 people in a reminder of the escalating violence in the South Asian nation and of the personal risk she faces after eight years abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top fishery official addresses grievance of Penghu fishermen

TEXT.P: Fisheries Administration Director Hsieh Ta-wen promised Friday that subsidies for fuel oil for set-net fishing vessels will be increased.

Hsieh made the remarks during a meeting in which he was invited by Legislator Lin Pin-kun of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union to talk with fishermen on the outlying Penghu islands to hear about the problems they have encountered in recent years.
The fishermen said the Fisheries Administration has instructed that their vessels be fitted with voyage data recorders (VDRs) to show their mileage as a basis for receiving subsidies for fuel oil.

However, a lot of the boats operating out of Penghu are set-net operations and cannot stop their engines while operating at a set spot, which means they consume more fuel oil than a simple VDR would indicate.
Hsieh agreed to raise the subsidy by 50 percent to address their grievance.

The fishermen also complained about a Fisheries Administration's plan for a set amount of flying fish roe catches next year, noting that the biggest flying fish roe producing place is in Penghu and saying they have been caught short by the sudden change.
In response, Hsieh agreed to allow flying fish roe catches next year but told the fishermen they will have to record their haul for the reference of the administration in formulating its policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 octogenarians team up for motorbike tour of Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu gave his blessing Friday to 20 octogenarians from the central city of Taichung who have teamed up for a motorbike tour of over 1,000 kilometers around Taiwan next month.
Hu met with the 20 elderly people, whose average age is 81, at a press conference, saying that he hopes they will keep up their high spirits and set a world record.

The tour is being organized by the Taichung-based Hondao Elderly Welfare Foundation. A spokesman for the foundation said the 20 participants were selected from among more than 100 applicants after a physical showed they are fit enough for the 13-day journey.
The spokesman explained that the foundation organized the tour to allow elderly people to fulfill dreams they failed to realize when they were young.
"It's never too late to realize one's dream," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bombs Hit Convoy as Bhutto Returns
Two powerful bombs detonated next to a truck carrying former prime minister Benazir Bhutto late Thursday, just hours after she returned from exile to a triumphal homecoming. More than 120 people were killed and hundreds were wounded in one of Pakistan's worst episodes of political violence.
The Washington Times: Congress orders probe of TB case
Capitol Hill lawmakers yesterday called for an investigation into why federal officials knowingly allowed a Mexican national infected with a highly contagious form of tuberculosis to repeatedly board planes and cross U.S. borders.

DOC.HEADLINE: President celebrates sixth anniversary of online newsletter

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian attended a
ceremony Thursday at the Presidential Office to mark the sixth anniversary of his weekly electronic newsletter.

During the ceremony, a series of online videos featuring the president that were posted on the Taiwan YouTube video hosting Web site to coincide with the launch of the site that same day were unveiled to promote the new video and audio features.
Chen said he felt honored to be Taiwan's first head of state to have launched an e-newsletter, which he said signifies Taiwan's competitive edge in the information technology industry.
The "A-bian" e-newsletter has published 314 issues since its inauguration in 2001 and has a total of 123,000 online subscribers.
Noting that the newsletter is published electronically every Thursday, Chen said he reads every item of every issue before the newsletter is released, no matter how busy he is.

He noted from the latest issue that a new item themed "Taiwan Profile" will be added, under which the government's achievements in infrastructure construction over the past seven years will be introduced, including the high speed railway, the Central Taiwan Science Park, the Yuanshantzu flood-diversion tunnel, the Hsuehshan Tunnel on the Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei and Yilan, and the completion of water quality improvement projects in Kaohsiung region.

According to a spokesman for the Presidential Office, in addition to the e-newsletter, Internet users can also watch Chen on Taiwan YouTube. He added that the office will also post a series of films on the president's life on the official Web site of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier denies development of nuclear weapons

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that Taiwan has no plans to and will absolutely not "develop, produce, or acquire" nuclear, biological or chemical weapons.
Chang made the remarks while fielding questions from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Su Chi at the Legislative Yuan.

Su quoted a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator whom he refused to name as having told two other DPP legislators that President Chen Shui-bian has recently ordered the Chung-shan Institute of Science and Technology under the Ministry of National Defense to develop nuclear weapons and nuclear warheads.
Su claimed that many high-ranking officials of the National Security Bureau have often suggested that Taiwan develop offensive weapons against China's military threat.
The National Security Council also once secretly invited a former defense minister and scientists from a country with nuclear weapons to Taiwan, Su went on.
In response, Chang said that despite the threat posed by hundreds of Chinese missiles aimed at Taiwan, the development of Taiwan's military weapons focuses on war prevention and self-defense.

The government has begun to push for the nationalization of the military since the transfer of power in 2000, Chang said, adding that the military is no longer controlled by any single political party or individual.
He said the government will strengthen its communications with the United States, Japan, Southeast Asian countries and European countries if they have suspicions about Taiwan's military development.
Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu also denied that there is any nuclear weapons development plan in Taiwan.
Sources from the Presidential Office later described Su's remarks as sheer speculation and nonsense.

During an interview with the Central News Agency later in the evening, Su admitted that he has no intelligence whatsoever to show that the government has plans to develop nuclear weapons and admitted that he made his allegation as a result of "inference."
He said that he made the inference based on information he has "accumulated over the years, as well as on his observations and understanding of the international situation."

Describing the DPP lawmaker's remarks as "the last straw, " which he said helped him reach his conclusion, Su said that what he claims is "the government's intention to develop nuclear weapons" is a "big change" and he feels it is necessary to "disclose the information."

DOC.HEADLINE: Torch relay in busy area affects citizens' rights: Taipei mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday that the government would undermine the rights of Taipei citizens by choosing a busy place and time to sponsor a torch relay aimed at touting the government's desire to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Hau's words came after the city government informed the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) that permission for its planned round-the-country torch relay has not been applied for as it should have been, according to the Assembly and Parade Law.
The torch relay is set to kick off Oct. 24, the day the U.N. charter came into force 62 years ago, in the square in front of the Presidential Office.

Hau displayed the SAC's letter dated Oct. 12 to the city government, which asks the city government to arrange for officials to attend the torch relay ceremony and accompany the torch on the run. It was followed with letters dated Oct. 17 and Oct. 18, saying the SAC will sponsor the torch relay and a cycling activity in the square in front of the Presidential Office, asking the city government not to approve the site for the use of other events and asking the city government to provide traffic control assistance.
Hau said the SAC only said it will sponsor activities but had not applied to stage the activities, which shows no respect to the local government.

Asked if the central government can apply under urgent circumstances -- since the deadline for making such an application has already passed -- Hau said only that "the city government will follow the law in dealing with the situation."
He also pointed out that the central government has chosen a busy weekday to stage the publicity stunt, which Hau said has no precedent and will affect the citizen's rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: China shows true colors by hijacking U.S. search engines: GIO

TEXT.P: China has exposed its true colors by hijacking three U.S.-based Internet search engines, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Friday.

Shieh was responding to foreign wire service reports that Chinese Internet users trying to search on Google, Yahoo and Microsoft Web sites have been directed to the Chinese-owned search engine Baidu since the U.S. Congress awarded Tibet's exiled spiritual leader the Dalai Lama with Congressional Gold Medal Wednesday.

According to the reports, the hijacking might be China's retaliation for Washington's awarding of the Dalai Lama and U.S. President George W. Bush's appearance in public with the respected Tibetan spiritual leader

While China has long been notorious for its totalitarian control of its people, Shieh said it is nevertheless unthinkable that the Beijing leadership has dared to so shamelessly, unequivocally and brazenly tampered with the free flow of information by redirecting all traffic from the three powerful search engines.

The move also exposes China's duplicity in its so-called "peace overture" delivered in Chinese President Hu Jintao's speech at the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China earlier this week that called for an end to cross-Taiwan Strait enmity and for the signing of a cross-strait peace agreement, Shieh said.

The search engine redirects and the recent blocking of such popular entertainment Web sites as YouTube and Live.com further explain why China is placed at the bottom seventh in the Worldwide Press Freedom Index 2007 released Tuesday by the Paris-based Reporters without Borders, Shieh added.
According to an AFP report, Google has confirmed the blocking of its Chinese search engine and Microsoft said it was looking into the matter.

"It seems like China is fed up with the US, so as a way to fight back, they redirected virtually all search traffic from Google, Yahoo and Microsoft to Baidu, the Chinese based search engine, " analysts Danny Sullivan and Barry Schwartz wrote at Search Engine Roundtable, a Web site focusing on Internet search.

The authors said it was not clear exactly how or why the searches were being redirected, but China is known for tightly controlling the Internet and using a variety of filters to screen out search results for issues relating to dissidents or the 72-year-old Tibetan spiritual leader.

"Some have accused Baidu of hijacking the traffic, but we think it's likely that China is upset with the US over the award it granted to the Dalai Lama and is retaliating by hurting US-based search engines," Sullivan and Schwartz said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 20, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino- Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

The Philippine Inquirer: Mall bomb blast kills 8
MANILA, Philippines -- The explosion that ripped through the Glorietta 2 Mall in Makati City early Friday afternoon, killing eight people and wounding more than a hundred others was caused by a "hard explosive," mostly likely TNT or the military ordnance C4, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to subsidize HPV vaccination against cervical cancer

TEXT.P: The private Health, Welfare and Environment Foundation urged the government Saturday to subsidize human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination to encourage local women to receive the immunization to protect themselves against cervical cancer.

Releasing the results of a survey conducted Oct. 2-4 on 935 adult women in the Taipei and Kaohisung areas, foundation officials pointed out that 88 percent of the respondents think the government should subsidize the cost of HPV inoculation and that 91 percent think the government should increase its budget for cervical cancer prevention and control.

If the inoculation is partially subsidized by the government, 58.9 percent of the respondents said they will have themselves and their daughters immunized, and if the inoculation is fully subsidized by government, 77.8 percent said they will do so, according to the survey results.
Asked to rate the government's performance on cervical cancer prevention and control on a 10-point scale, the respondents gave it an average score of 5.9.

On the respondents' perception on cervical cancer, the survey found that 41 percent were unaware of the seriousness of the disease, and 42 percent were not worried about becoming a victim of the disease.

Although approximately 80 percent of the respondents knew the government subsidizes Pap smear screening for cervical cancer, only 66 percent have received the tests over the past three years, the results show.

Yu Shan-lin, a research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center, pointed out that around 5,500 new cervical cancer cases are recorded in Taiwan each year, with the number of fatalities registering around 800 per year.

Although the HPV vaccines have been proven effective in preventing the cancer, the inoculation rate among local women has remained low since the vaccines hit the Taiwan market last year, mainly because of the high price, Yu said.
Under these circumstances, if the government subsidizes the cost of HPV inoculation, more women will be encouraged to receive the shots, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Torch relay snub shows mayor's 'pettiness': spokesman

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin's intolerance of a planned torch relay to underline the country's resolve to seek U.N. membership reveals his 'pettiness and lack of breadth of view,' Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Saturday.

Shieh made the remarks a day after Hau accused the central government of violating the Assembly and Parade Law by failing to apply for a permit for its U.N. bid torch relay set to kick off Oct. 24, which is observed worldwide as United Nations Day in commemoration of the entry into force of the U.N. Charter on that date in 1945.

Claiming that the torch relay is a political event, Hau, a stalwart of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said the city government will not allow the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led central government to ignore the municipal authority and skip the permit application procedures.
In response, Shieh said the upcoming round-the-nation torch relay is a sports event for which prior approval by local governments is not required under the Assembly and Parade Law.

Shieh reminded Hau that most of the DPP-controlled city and county governments didn't require that KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou apply for prior approval when he embarked on a round-the-Taiwan bicycle tour in May to drum up support for his electoral bid.

"Most of the DPP-controlled local governments regarded Ma's cycling tour as a sports event and exempted him from the permit requirement, " Shieh said, adding that all those city and county governments even actively provided assistance with traffic control along the roads that Ma passed along.

Comparing their treatment of Ma and the Taipei city government's refusal to offer any assistance with maintenance of traffic order on the grounds that the torch relay is illegal, Shieh said that "one can easily tell who is being petty."

According to the schedule unveiled by the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) , the relay will kick off at 7 a.m. Oct. 24 in front of the Presidential Office on Ketagalan Boulevard in downtown Taipei, with President Chen Shui-bian leading the pack.

Seventeen athletes and celebrities will carry the torch through 25 counties and cities around the country, including the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, Shieh said, adding that the 11-day event is also aimed at encouraging local people to get more exercise.
The 1,200-km relay is scheduled to conclude at 6: 30 p.m. Nov. 3 when the torch is slated to return to the Presidential Office plaza.

Taiwan was forced out of the United Nations in 1971 when Beijing took over the "China" seat at its expense. Since 1993, the country has tried without success to have the U.N. General Assembly consider the issue of its representation in the world body.

DOC.HEADLINE: President insists U.N. bid torch relay lawful

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian insisted Saturday that the nationwide torch relay set to begin next week to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid is "definitely lawful, " urging the public to actively take part in the event.
Chen said that joining the United Nations is a goal shared by Taiwan's 23 million people and that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should not try to block the relay.
The president made the remarks during a trip to the southern county of Tainan.

The 1,200-km relay organized by the Sports Affairs Council, which will cover all 25 counties and cities around the country and is expected to take 11 days to complete, is scheduled to begin Oct. 24 from Taipei City.
The president is expected to lead the first leg from Taipei City to Taipei County, after the torch is lit at 7 a.m. that day on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

However, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, a stalwart of the KMT, claimed Friday that the event is a "political activity" for which a public assembly permit from the city government is required. He said that holding the activity without a permit is unlawful.
In response, Chen said the KMT should not adopt a "double standard, " and he dared the city government "to come crack down on the event if it wants to."

Noting that KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou previously made a nationwide cycling tour to drum up support for his campaign and that the party itself is pushing for a referendum on the restoration of the country's U.N. membership, Chen said the KMT should not try to prevent others from holding a road running event or try to obstruct the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) drive for a referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Chen pointed out that Ma's cycling tour stopped in a number of counties and cities held by the DPP and that the governments of these localities did not insist that Ma apply for a permit, adding that they even actively helped out by dispatching police to maintain order and assist with traffic control at events held during the tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate touts 'cross-strait common market'

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate said Saturday that although a cross-Taiwan Strait common market is a "goal" that cannot be achieved at this point in time, such a market nevertheless represents a "protective shield for Taiwan's future."

Vincent Siew, who served as chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research before being nominated as the KMT's vice presidential candidate in June this year, made the remarks in a speech delivered in Taipei at a training camp for executive members of the National Women's League of the Republic of China.

In the speech, Siew defended his "cross-strait common market" idea which he has promoted for over half a decade. The idea of the cross-strait common market has been criticized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh who has said that such a "one China market" would threaten Taiwan's existence.
Siew said that amid the economic "globalization and regional integration" trends, all countries around the world, except Taiwan, want to grab a share of the immense China market.

Because of political considerations, Siew claimed, the DPP-led government has refused to seek business opportunities in China, which he described as a key resource for Taiwan to maintain its vitality.
"It is not only stupid but also suicidal behavior," he claimed.
"We need the Chinese market, " Siew said, arguing that Taiwan and China share a common interest in increased economic exchanges.
Siew also mentioned that when he initiated the cross-strait common market idea in 2001, he won then President Chen's support.

However, Siew continued, after he became the KMT vice presidential candidate for the 2008 election, both Chen and the DPP's presidential candidate began to "distort" the idea by referring to it as a "one China market."

According to Siew, Hsieh has even expressed that although he supports the proposal for the two sides to engage in economic cooperation, he opposes the formation of a "cross-strait common market" which he has said would lead to Taiwan being flooded with cheap Chinese laborers and agricultural products
Siew criticized Hsieh's argument, calling it "blind" and saying this line of reasoning is like "turning the right into wrong."

Siew said his common market idea was formed on the model of the European Union, and its antecedent, the European Common Market. Under his proposed cross-strait common market, the two sides would "exist equally, without either side's sovereignty being consumed," he noted, adding that he knows of no European country that has been "wiped away" after joining the EU.
"A common market means that everybody can share the benefits generated by increased economic activity," Siew stressed.

Eventually, he continued, after a common market is formed, there will be free exchanges of personnel, capital, technology and products, but such exchanges can only be achieved through constant negotiations and the construction of a "firewall" to protect the interests of each individual member of the common market.

Siew noted that although it is now still too early to form a cross-strait common market, it is an aspiration and long-term goal that can serve as a framework for peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
