DOC.HEADLINE: Police head discusses principles in addressing torch relay dispute

TEXT.P: The Taipei city police commissioner said Monday he will address the controversial round-the-nation torch relay related to Taiwan's U.N. bid in a "modest and proper" manner when the event kicks off Wednesday in the capital city.
Wang Cho-chun made the remarks in response to questions delivered by city councilors at the city council.

How Wang deals with the event, a source of tension between the central government and the city administration, has become an issue of speculation among the concerned parties because both the mayor of the city and director-general of the National Police Agency (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior are his superiors.

Wang said that he will respect the city government's decision to treat the upcoming relay run as a "political activity, " which was ruled "illegal" after the organizer, the central government, failed to apply for the city government's approval under the Assembly and Parade Law which governs such activities.
Wang indicated that NPA Director-General Hou Yu-ih had called and told him that the agency considers the upcoming relay run to be a "sporting event."

No matter whether the planned activity is a sporting event or a march regulated in the Assembly and Parade Law, Wang said that a traffic maintenance plan is required for every kind of public activity taking place on the roadways of the capital city to allow the traffic division to prepare for disruptions.
Regarding President Chen Shui-bian's decision to take part in the Wednesday relay run as the first torch holder, Wang said it's the duty of the police to protect the president in outdoor activities.

However, if any actions undertaken at the event are deemed to break the Assembly and Parade Law during the run through the city, Wang said the police will enforce the law and order the gathering to disband.

So far, the police commissioner added, his department has not yet outlined a complete traffic deployment plan for the U.N.-bid torch relay, which is due to set off 7: 00 a.m. Wednesday from the Presidential Office square in downtown Taipei and will include the participation of high ranking government officials, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, and his running-mate Su Tseng-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gears up development of WiMAX technology, network

TEXT.P: Taiwan is keen to leverage strong development in its information and communication technology (ICT) industry to turn the local WiMAX industry into one of the best in the world, said developers and officials at an international WiMAX conference Monday.

The M-Taiwan WiMAX Application Laboratory (MTWAL) recently became the first application lab to be selected by the WiMAX Forum, according to an announcement by forum president Ron Resnick at the 2007 WiMAX Forum Taipei Showcase and Conference.

The forum is being held in Taipei Oct. 22-23, with 76 companies from all over the world participating. The MTWAL was established at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) campus in Hsinshu.

MTWAL, established to provide an environment in which to create innovative WiMAX applications, was already in operation ahead of the announcement, with seven companies and universities testing their applications at the campus, including Korean company IntroMobile's "NetMirror", Israeli company NDS's "WiMAX TV" and Rock Mobile's "Mobility Karaoke".

WiMax, the Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, is a telecommunications technology designed to provide wireless data over long distances in a variety of ways. The WiMax Forum was formed in June 2001 to promote standardization and interoperability.

Taiwan's government has put in a great deal of effort establishing the WiMAX network over the last three years, investing over US$664 million (NT$21.8 billion) -- the second highest level of investment in the industry worldwide, Minister of Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Minister Chen Ruey-long said, adding that the MOEA estimates that the total output value of the industry will reach NT$128 billion.
In addition to the MTWAL, a WiMAX Forum Certification Laboratory will be established in Taiwan in November.

The establishment of the laboratories and showcase couldn't have come to Taiwan at a better time, said ITRI President Johnsee Lee, who claimed that "this is a historical opportunity to witness the rapid growth of the WiMAX technology and applications."

Lee said Taiwan, which has been recognized by the global WiMAX community as a leader in the WiMAX ecosystem, finds itself well positioned in the critical period from 2007-2008, when the industry is expected to take off.
The showcase features demonstrations by the latest WiMAX system and chipset vendors, and firsthand insights into emerging end-to-end solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition of creative glassworks opens in Changhua County

TEXT.P: A joint exhibition of creative glassworks by companies in Changhua Coastal Industrial Park opened Monday in the central Taiwan county.

Guests of honor invited to witness the opening of the month-long exhibition included Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and Yeh Yun-Lung, deputy director-general of the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Speaking at the ceremony, Cho pointed out that the glasswork industry is a major part of the economy in Changhua County, with many related companies located in the coastal industrial park.
Cho said the exhibition is being held with the aim of attracting public attention to the creative glassworks and helping Taiwan's glasswork industry carve out a niche in the world market.

He said the Industrial Development Bureau under the economics ministry will help set up a special zone covering three hectares in the coastal industrial park for the glass industry, and that 15 companies have already expressed a desire to set up shop in the zone.
Cho said that the Changhua County government's target is to increase productive capacity in the special zone to 35 percent of the total glass production in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor extend condolences over thief chaser's death

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu extended her condolences Monday to the family of a man who died two days ago of heart and lung failure after helping police officers chase down a pair of teenage thieves.
Chen presented NT$50,000 in cash to the family as a token of the Kaohsiung city government's appreciation for the man's heroic act that cost him his life.

Hsieh Ching-chuan, 57, and his son joined the chase for two young thieves in the wee hours of Oct. 20 upon hearing police sirens in their neighborhood. After pursuing the two youngsters for 20 minutes, he stopped, out of breath, while his son continued the chase.
About 10 minutes later, hearing his son shout that he and the police officers had caught the two thieves in an alley, Hsieh dashed 200 meters to join his son, only to collapse in front of him.
Hsieh was rushed to the Kaohsiung Municipal United Hospital, but upon arrival doctors declared him dead of heart and lung failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: High Court revokes ruling on 'state affairs fund' documents

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court revoked Monday a Taipei District Court ruling that rejected President Chen Shui-bian's request for reclamation of a collection of documents and articles held by the court in the probes of a "state affairs fund" misuse case.
The High Court demanded that the District Court re-examine its previous ruling and make a new judgment.
It further said President Chen can appeal again if he disagrees with the District Court's new ruling.

The lawyers of President Chen and four defendants in the case -- first lady Wu Shu-jen and three of Chen's former and incumbent aides -- appealed to the High Court Oct. 15 after the District Court turned down the presidential request for the return of the collection in a ruling issued Oct. 5.
The District Court based its rejection on the grounds that the president's proclamation of the collection fo documents as "strictly confidential" is illegal.

According to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Ruling No. 627 issued June 15, President Chen is entitled to appeal to the Taiwan High Court over disputes with the district court or prosecution concerning the exercise of his "state secrets privilege."

As the four defendants in the "state affairs fund" case do not have the right to appeal the District Court ruling on the ownership of the collection of documents, the High Court ruling said they should not appeal again over the case.

The District Court obtained the collection of documents and articles from a prosecutorial team that indicted the first lady and three other defendants last November on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund, " a special allowance fund set aside for the president's discretionary use for official purposes. Chen was named as a "joint perpetrator" in the case, but he was not indicted because of his immunity from prosecution as prescribed in the Constitution.
The collection consists of invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic projects from 2002 to last December.
In line with the CGJ stipulations, the High Court organized a special five- member tribunal led by a senior chief judge to deal with the president's appeal.
The president's lawyers have outlined several key reasons for filing the appeal against the District Court ruling:

-- In terms of the CGJ constitutionality rulings No. 328 and 419, the president's "state secrets privilege" is beyond the scrutiny of the judicial branch because its exercise involves military, diplomacy and national security affairs.

-- The CGJ ruling No. 627 handed down June 15 that confirms the president's "state secrets privilege" does not empower a regular court to examine the president's proclamation of a document or a diplomatic mission as confidential that should be kept secret. The practices or precedents set forth in the U.S. Watergate case could not be employed in President Chen's case as the Watergate case didn't involve any national security, diplomatic or defense interests.

-- The CGJ No. 627 ruling clearly states that the president should be given the opportunity to explain or give supplementary explanations whether national security and interests are at stake in disclosure of the collection of documents in question.
-- Any dispute between the president and the judicial branch over exercise of their respective powers should be dealt with by the CGJ, not the district court.
-- The exercise of president's "state secrets privilege" does not restrict to those prescribed in the Classified National Security Information Protection Act.

Chen asked for the return of the collection Sept. 6 on the grounds that the collection were "strictly confidential" information under the protection of the Classified National Security Information Protection Act and should be kept secret permanently.

The president said in his petition that the collection was labeled "strictly confidential" in line with CGJ Ruling No. 627, which confirms the president's constitutional right to decide what constitutes a state secret and his right to refuse disclosure, also known as "state secrets privilege."

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker blasts flood control policy

TEXT.P: Legislator Lai Shin-yuan of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) blasted the government's flood control policy Monday and proposed that the budgets of authorities responsible for water conservation and forestry affairs be withdrawn entirely.

Lai told a meeting of members of the legislative Committee on Economics and Energy Affairs that she believes the government has wasted tens of billions of New Taiwan dollars on "useless" flood control and water conservation projects over past several decades.

The rivers under the water regulation projects launched by the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau and the Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture (COA) over past decades have mostly worsened the situation regarding the preservation of water and soil, Lai claimed, saying the country remains under the threat of floods and landslides.

Citing statistics, the lawmaker said that around 340,000 hectares of original forest on the island -- an area equivalent to three Yushan national parks -- has been cleared for agricultural or economic development purposes.
The deforestation has destroyed local soil and water balances, causing further landslides where the so-called river regulation projects were carried out, Lai claimed.

The legislator suggested that the government focus on land restoration and review whether or not to allow farming in mountainous areas. She also suggested that this year's budgets, totalling NT$1.7 billion (US$52.11 million) , be eliminated for the two COA bureaus, thereby effectively bringing an end to water regulation and flood control measures, which she described as biologically detrimental.
In response, COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan said he agreed with Lai's opinions and that his council hopes to take further steps to reforest mountainous areas.

Regarding planned construction projects to regulate river flow, Su said that what has to be done, must be done, but the COA will review the plans and make necessary improvements in flood-control planning and operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jan.-Sept. labor participation rate highest in nearly 10 years

TEXT.P: Taiwan's average labor participation rate for the first nine months reached 58.24 percent, the highest level in nearly 10 years, while the average jobless rate hit an almost seven-year low of 3.92 percent for the same period, government tallies showed Monday.

According to statistics made public by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , Taiwan's average labor participation rate for the period of January - September this year showed a 0.39 percentage point growth over the previous year's level.
DGBAS officials attributed the rise to more women entering the workplace thanks to their higher educational levels.

An average 10.28 million workers were employed each month during the first nine months of this year, a jump of 195,000, or a 1.94 percent growth, compared to the year-earlier figure, DGBAS tallies indicated. The figures are taken as a reflection of steady recovery in Taiwan's job market, DGBAS officials said.
The country's unemployment rate in September stood at 3.99 percent -- the equivalent of 429,000 jobless workers -- down 13,000 positions, or 0.1 percentage points, from August.

But the September jobless rate for university graduates and those with higher academic diplomas climbed to 4.97 percent -- the highest level in nearly one year, according to DGBAS statistics. The ratios for senior high school graduates and those who have only a junior high school or elementary school certificate stand at 4.49 percent and 2.91 percent, respectively.

Last month, some 10.74 million workers were employed across the country, a decrease of 56,000 month to month, but a noticeable increase of 166,000 positions, or 1.57 percent, over the same month in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 counterfeit items of Calvin Klein underwear seized

TEXT.P: Police have seized 20,000 counterfeit items of Calvin Klein underwear from a warehouse in Tainan County, a police spokesman said Monday.

The spokesman said that officers from the Intellectual Property Rights Police Team raided the warehouse last week after taking into custody a man in Taipei, identified by the surname Chen, for selling counterfeit Calvin Klein underwear through the Internet.

Chen confessed that all the pirated items he sold online at discount prices came China, and that he bought the goods from a warehouse in Yungkang township in Tainan County. He has been referred to the Taipei Prosecutors' Office.

According to the spokesman, members of the IPR police team searched the warehouse and confiscated such a wide array of unopened boxes containing various sizes of the Chinese contraband that made the warehouse look like a distribution center.

The spokesman quoted experts in the retail underwear market as saying that if sold through the Internet, the 20,000 items of clothing would have resulted in NT$10 million (US$306,410) in losses to Calvin Klein Co.

An audacious cross-border ambush by Kurdish rebels based in northern Iraq killed at least 17 Turkish soldiers Sunday, ratcheting up pressure on the Turkish government to launch a military offensive into Iraq.

Authorities are considering emptying the massive U.N. headquarters building for at least three years to get a long-delayed renovation project back on track and on budget, according to people who have been briefed on the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. Internet pioneer talks on Web's future, challenges

TEXT.P: The Internet of the future will present as many opportunities as challenges, all of which will definitely go beyond anything he imagined in the 1970s, a U.S. Internet pioneer said in a keynote speech delivered during a conference in Taipei Monday.

In the future, one will be seeing a lot of Internet-enabled devices, one will be buying clothes for oneself in the virtual world with real world cash, and communicating with the Mars via Internet, said Vint Cerf, an American computer scientist regarded as one of the founding fathers of the Internet, in the speech titled "Tracking the Internet into the 21st Century".

At the same time, the vice president and chief Internet Evangelist of Google also told thousands of conference attendees that the development of the Internet faces enormous challenges, including intellectual rights, the semantic web -- also called Web 3.0 -- preserving interpretive programs, operating systems and hardware.

With the rapid development of communications technology, such as RFID (Radio- frequency identification), devices such as refrigerators, picture frames, telephones, automobiles and clothing will all be Internet-enabled and dramatically change one's life, he said.
"You could get e-mail or SMS (Short message service) from your refrigerator, " he said.

The best aspect of the future Internet is that it will involve the exploration of a completely different mode of advertising in which "everything is decided by the users -- whether they want to watch [the advertisement], what they want to watch. They will not be forced to watch them," he said.
InterPlanet (IPN), the interplanetary Internet, is Cerf's latest project.

DOC.HEADLINE: No major impact on local market if Chinese garments allowed in:MOEA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. C. Chen said Monday that local textile industry and related businesses will not sustain major impact if the government decides to allow Chinese garment imports.

Chen gave his assurances amid reports that the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will hold a cross-agency meeting Tuesday to weigh whether to permit 54 Chinese garment and low-end textile products, including men's suits, coats and ladies' dresses, to enter Taiwan.

Stressing that the government will not "create an opening for the sake of opening, " Chen said that the government's top concern when making a decision in this regard is whether such a move will affect the domestic industry and related businesses.
It has been reported that the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei and the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei are paying close attention to the matter as they have long expected such an opening.
BOFT Deputy Director-General Hsu Chun-fang said later the same day that the bureau must follow due process before deciding whether to open the domestic market to Chinese products.

An opening can only be made if no major negative impact is likely to happen, either with regards to national security or businesses at home, she explained, and gave assurance that the BOFT will grant its go-ahead only after it fully explores opinions within the local textile industry.
"The BOFT will not okay the opening unless local industry approves of the measure," she stressed.

As Taiwan's textile industry has increasingly shifted towards the manufacture of high-tech and high value-added products, the importation of low-end Chinese goods is not expected to deal a heavy blow to the domestic market, she opined, adding that if any damage is done in this regard, anti-dumping or other defensive mechanisms authorized under the World Trade Organization's framework can be applied to address the ensuing complications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Mayor pledges further donations of fire trucks to Manila

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin has pledged to continue donating fire trucks to the Philippine capital of Manila, which has for 41 years been a sister city with Taipei, a city official said Monday.
Hau made the promise during a meeting with Manila Mayor-elect Alfredo S. Lim at the Taipei City Hall earlier in the day, the official said.
In recent years, the Taipei city government has donated obsolete but useable fire trucks to the Philippines, the official noted.
During the meeting, Lim exchanged views with Hau on city affairs and expressed hope that Taipei would continue to donate fire trucks to Manila, the official went on.
Lim was later taken on a tour of several Taipei city construction projects. The official quoted Lim as saying that Taipei City has made rapid progress in its development.
Lim also spoke highly of Taipei 101 and the citys night view, according to the official.
This is Lim's second visit to Taipei. He expressed the hope that the two sides will further increase bilateral cooperation in economic, tourism, business and cultural fields, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local university inks cooperation deal with U.S. counterpart

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) has signed a cooperation agreement with the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) as part of its efforts to expand their current bilateral exchange program, a university spokesman said Monday.
It is the first time that the noted U.S. university has inked such an agreement with an overseas school, making this a historic step forward, the spokesman said.
The agreement will allow graduate students, doctoral students, and professors of the two universities to move between the institutions on exchange for as long as one year, the spokesman pointed out.

There has already been close collaboration on the exchange of undergraduate students between the two schools, the spokesman noted, adding that each semester, NCTU sends several students of its College of Electrical and Computer Engineering and College of Computer Science to UIUC as exchange students.
Currently, there are 15 NCTU students at UIUC, according to the spokesman, who added that an additional 14 students are scheduled to study at UIUC next year.
Under the new deal, NCTU will encourage senior doctoral students who have taken all the credits required for gradation and are writing their dissertations to head to UIUC, the spokesman said.
NCTU will also encourage young professors to conduct research at UIUC to expand their global perspective, the spokesman went on.
Under the agreement, professors of the two universities can jointly deliver a research paper or initiate joint international cooperation projects, the spokesman said.
In addition, both sides can file patent applications on the results of bilateral cooperation projects, the spokesman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia agree on numerous economic cooperation projects
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Australia, Oct.22 (CNA) 10/22/07 23:25:22 (By Derek Chen and T.C.Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Australia have forged a consensus on a number of economic and trade collaborative projects at an annual bilateral economics and trade consultative conference held Oct.18-19 in the Australian capital of Canberra.
The conference, now in its 12th year, is regarded as the most significant communications channel for economic and trade affairs between the two countries.
Fadah Hsieh, vice minister of economic affairs, led the Taiwanese delegation which included many Cabinet officials, to take part in the conference.
The next annual conference will be held in Taipei.

The conference was marked by the signing of an agreement to mutually recognize safety regulations governing information products, ease restrictions on the deposit business of Taiwanese banks in Australia, and the training of Taiwanese financial regulators.
In addition, both sides agreed to begin cooperation on the research and development of new drugs and clinical trials.
At the conference, Taiwanese representatives also invited their Australian counterparts to participate in a series of professional trade shows to take place in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 700 boxes of smuggled cigarettes seized in Tainan

TEXT.P: A task force composed of Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials and anti- contraband officials from the Tainan city government seized 700 boxes of smuggled cigarettes from a warehouse near Anping fishing harbor Monday.
A spokesman for the city government said that the task force discovered a 50-meter tunnel leading from the side of a wharf at Anping fishing harbor to the warehouse.
He said the tunnel's end at Anping harbor was not easily visible because it was hidden behind used car tires.
Members of the task force who discovered the secret tunnel followed it all the way into the warehouse, where they found 700 boxes of untaxed cigarettes, with a street value of NT$20 million.

The spokesman said the smuggling ring had used a conveyor belt to move the contraband from a fishing boat at the wharf to the warehouse in order to save time and reduce the risk of having their illegal operation exposed.
He added that the case has been referred to the Tainan Public Prosecutors' Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguay first lady thanks local charity

TEXT.P: Paraguay's first lady, Maria Gloria Penayo de Duarte, has personally expressed appreciation to the Taichung-based Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) for providing financial assistance to poor children in Paraguay, a charity spokesman said Monday.

The Paraguayan first lady visited a branch of the charitable organization in the northern county of Taipei Oct. 8 prior to her participation in the Double Ten National Day celebrations held Oct. 10 in Taipei City, the spokesman noted.
The charity has been offering monetary assistance to approximately 1,000 children of impoverished families in Paraguay, the spokesman said.
The TFCF is also helping improve the living standards of local communities in Paraguay, according to the spokesman.
The spokesman noted that the charity will continue to help improve the health and educational services available to Paraguayan children, and called on the Taiwanese public to donate to the children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 23, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

If Chen is not the suitable applicant, the High Court ruling said the District Court just needs to turn down the request and need not bother to check whether Chen is eligible to proclaim the documents as "strictly confidential" in terms of his "state secret privilege."
Against this backdrop, the High Court revoked the District Court's previous ruling and demanded the District court mete out a new judgment.

The lawyers of President Chen and four defendants in the case -- first lady Wu Shu-jen and three of Chen's former and incumbent aides -- appealed to the High Court Oct. 15 after the District Court turned down the presidential request for the return of the collection in a ruling issued Oct. 5.
The District Court based its rejection on the grounds that the president's proclamation of the collection fo documents as "strictly confidential" is illegal.

According to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Ruling No. 627 issued June 15, President Chen is entitled to appeal to the Taiwan High Court over disputes with the district court or prosecution concerning the exercise of his "state secrets privilege."

As the four defendants in the "state affairs fund" case do not have the right to appeal the District Court ruling on the ownership of the collection of documents, the High Court ruling said they should not appeal again over the case.

The District Court obtained the collection of documents and articles from a prosecutorial team that indicted the first lady and three other defendants last November on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund, " a special allowance fund set aside for the president's discretionary use for official purposes. Chen was named as a "joint perpetrator" in the case, but he was not indicted because of his immunity from prosecution as prescribed in the Constitution.
The collection consists of invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic projects from 2002 to last December.
In line with the CGJ stipulations, the High Court organized a special five- member tribunal led by a senior chief judge to deal with the president's appeal.
The president's lawyers have outlined several key reasons for filing the appeal against the District Court ruling:

-- In terms of the CGJ constitutionality rulings No. 328 and 419, the president's "state secrets privilege" is beyond the scrutiny of the judicial branch because its exercise involves military, diplomacy and national security affairs.

-- The CGJ ruling No. 627 handed down June 15 that confirms the president's "state secrets privilege" does not empower a regular court to examine the president's proclamation of a document or a diplomatic mission as confidential that should be kept secret. The practices or precedents set forth in the U.S. Watergate case could not be employed in President Chen's case as the Watergate case didn't involve any national security, diplomatic or defense interests.

-- The CGJ No. 627 ruling clearly states that the president should be given the opportunity to explain or give supplementary explanations whether national security and interests are at stake in disclosure of the collection of documents in question.
-- Any dispute between the president and the judicial branch over exercise of their respective powers should be dealt with by the CGJ, not the district court.
-- The exercise of president's "state secrets privilege" does not restrict to those prescribed in the Classified National Security Information Protection Act.

Chen asked for the return of the collection Sept. 6 on the grounds that the collection were "strictly confidential" information under the protection of the Classified National Security Information Protection Act and should be kept secret permanently.

The president said in his petition that the collection was labeled "strictly confidential" in line with CGJ Ruling No. 627, which confirms the president's constitutional right to decide what constitutes a state secret and his right to refuse disclosure, also known as "state secrets privilege."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei grants permit for U.N. bid torch relay

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has approved a parade and public assembly application by the organizers of a nationwide U.N. bid torch relay slated to kick off Oct. 24 in the city, officials said Tuesday.

The application was filed Monday afternoon by the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association (CTRRA) on behalf of the Sports Affairs Council (SAC), according to Huang Ching-fu, chief of the Taipei City Police Department's Peace Preservation Division.

Although it is usually required that such an application be filed at least six days beforehand, the department nevertheless gave favorable consideration to the case and granted the permit Monday night for the holding of the event, Huang said.

As the event will not include any rallies, the organizers are not required to apply for a right-of-way permit from the city government or put forth any traffic control plans, he said, adding that the department will dispatch police to maintain order and assist with traffic control along the way, he said.

Over the previous few days, the city government and the SAC had been engaged in a dispute over whether the torch relay -- intended to promote the country's bid to join the United Nations -- is a "political activity" or a "sports event."
The SAC, which considered the torch relay a "sports event, " only notified the city government of its plan to hold the activity without applying for any parade or public assembly permit.

However, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin insisted that the event is a "political activity" for which a permit from the city government is required. He said that holding the activity without a permit would be unlawful.

Also Tuesday, SAC Deputy Chairman Lee Kao-hsiang said that the council still defines the torch delay as a sports event and that it asked the CTRRA to help file the application in order to try to end the dispute.

Meanwhile, CTRRA Deputy Secretary-General Ho Li-chiung explained that the association is not a co-organizer of the torch relay but is only assisting the SAC with recruiting athletes to run in the activity.

According to Ho, the application for the parade and public assembly permit for the torch relay has set a precedent, because no permit has ever been required for any of the road running events that the association has held in the past.
The 1,200-km relay, which will cover all 25 counties and cities around the country, is expected to take 11 days to complete.
President Chen Shui-bian is expected to run the opening leg, after the torch is lit at 7 a.m. Oct. 24 on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Average regular wage for first 8 months up 1.75 percent year-on-year

TEXT.P: Local wage earners' regular average monthly wage stood at NT$36,650 (US$1,110) in the first eight months of this year, marking a 1.75 percent rise year-on- year, an official of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.
The increase was the highest in nearly seven years, the official said.
Regular wage refers to the base pay, including holiday pay, vacation pay and sick time pay, but excluding overtime pay and irregular bonus pay.

The official further said that The number of employees in the industrial and service sectors totaled 6.166 million in August, marking an increase of 10,000 over the level for the previous month and rise of 94,000 over the figure for the same month a year-earlier.
The number of employees in the first eight months averaged 6.161 million, marking a 96,000 rise year-on-year, or the fourth-highest level in nearly seven years, according to the official.

The average wage in August was NT$42,124, up 0.06 percent from the level for the previous month. The average wage in the first eight months stood at NT$46,646, up 1.84 percent year-on-year, the official went on.

The average number of working hours in August stood at 192.6, up 4.2 hours from the figure for the previous month but down 0.2 hours from the figure for the same month a year-earlier, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jobless rate among bachelor's degree hits 4.97%: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate in September among people with at least a bachelor's degree reached 4.97 percent, marking the highest level within the last year, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Monday.

A DGBAS official attributed the high increase over the past year to the fact that young people frequently change jobs, saying that 83 percent of the unemployed university degree holders are "voluntarily" unemployed who quit due to dissatisfaction with their jobs.
Despite an increase in the unemployment rate, the official said that it is not a structural unemployment problem and that the reason behind the increased unemployment rate is relatively simple.

The statistics also show that in the same month, the unemployment rate among people with a high school degree stood at 4.49 percent, while that among people with a junior high school degree or below was 2.91 percent, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor appreciates permit application for U.N. bid torch relay

TEXT.P: The Sports Affairs Council's (SAC's) decision to apply for a permit from the Taipei city government for an upcoming nationwide torch relay marks a win-win situation for the central and local governments, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.

Hau made the remarks one day after the city government approved a parade and public assembly application for the event, which was filed Monday by the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association (CTRRA) on behalf of the SAC to resolve a dispute with the city government over whether the event is a political or sports activity.

Hau said the position of the city government remains that any governmental or civic organizations intending to hold sports or political activities in the city must apply for a permit beforehand and that the holding of the torch relay without a permit would have been considered unlawful.
Referring to the SAC's move to ask the CTRRA to help apply for a parade and public assembly permit, Hau said he appreciates the step taken by the SAC to remedy its previous error.
Unlike the SAC, which considers the torch relay a "sports event," Hau has insisted that the event is a "political activity" for which a permit from the city government is required.

The 1,200-km relay, designed to promote the country's bid to join the United Nations, is scheduled to kick off Wednesday in Taipei City. The relay, which will cover all 25 counties and cities around the country, is expected to take 11 days to complete.
President Chen Shui-bian is expected to run the opening leg, after the torch is lit at 7 a.m. Oct. 24 on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
