DOC.HEADLINE: Pushing U.N. bid is national leader's responsibility: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that it would be a dereliction of duty on his part if he were to fail to push for the country's bid for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan.
The president made the remarks during an interview with Happy Radio based in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.
"The push for joining the world body is the mission and the responsibility of the nation's leader and a way to propel Taiwan onto the world stage," the president said.
"If I cannot take care of the name of the country," and let it be "replaced or changed," then "I should be held accountable," he said.
He also pointed out the difference between the referendum proposal initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the one initiated by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

In a nutshell, the DPP's proposal aims at securing a seat for Taiwan in the United Nations, while the KMT's proposal is for the nation to return to the world body under its official name, the Republic of China, which would mean unseating the People's Republic of China and Mongolia from the world body, Chen claimed.
The president said he is confident that a DPP-initiated proposal will be passed when it is put to a vote alongside the presidential election in March 22, 2008.
He estimated that over 8 million people will turn out and cast ballots in favor of the proposal, which he said will "mark the public consensus on the U.N. bid."

Under the current Referendum Law, a proposal will be considered passed if the referendum turnout rate exceeds half of all eligible voters and if 50 percent of those who cast ballots vote in favor of the proposal.

In the 2004 presidential election, two proposals initiated by President Chen were put to a referendum -- one on purchasing more missiles to counter the military threat from China, and the other on engaging in dialogue with China -- failed to pass. Although 90 percent of those who cast ballots in the referendum voted in favor of the proposals, the referendum turnout rate was only 45 percent of all eligible voters.

The president also talked about the campaign strategy for the coming presidential election, reiterating that his cooperation with Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate, will ensure victory for the party in the election. Chen assumed the chairmanship of the party last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to run opening leg of U.N.-bid torch relay

TEXT.P: A nationwide torch relay promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations is scheduled to begin Wednesday in Taipei City, with President Chen Shui-bian running the opening leg, Sports Affairs Council (SAC) officials said Tuesday.

After the torch is lit Wednesday morning, the president will run along the Ketagelan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to Jingfu Gate at the boulevard's cross section with Zhongshan South Road, according to SAC Deputy Chairman Lee Kao-hsiang.

Running behind Chen will be a team comprised of Vice President Annette Lu, athlete representatives who will run in the relay as well as Cabinet members and citizens who have volunteered to take part, Lee said.

Upon arrival at Jingfu Gate, the president will pass on the torch to several athletes who will carry on with the run along Zhongshan South Road, Zhongxiao East Road, Academia Road and Nankang Road to Hsichih, Taipei County, Lee said.

The 1,200 km relay, covering 25 counties and cities around the country, is set to be completed in 11 days, with the torch expected back in Taipei City Nov. 3, according to the itinerary released by the SAC.

Also Tuesday, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai urged the public to take an active part in the event regardless of their political, ethnic or religious backgrounds to show their support for the U.N. bid.
Senior executives and staff members of the party will also participate in the event, Cho said.

Meanwhile, DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, who only recently recovered from a leg injury, will join the opening run at a point located 200 meters in front of Jingfu Gate, according to Hsieh's campaign aides.
The torch relay is one of the largest-scale events organized by the DPP administration to promote its bid to apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Not wishing to let the DPP dominate the issue, the opposition Kuomintang will Wednesday launch a nationwide cycling tour to promote the party's drive calling for the restoration of the Republic of China's membership in the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices rise significantly

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose sharply Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 141.76 points to close at 9,502.39.
The bourse opened at 9,419.54 and fluctuated between 9,512.56 and 9,419.54 during trading. A total of 4.7 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$148.45 billion (US$.56 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 2.0 percent, followed by banking and financial issues at 1.6 percent, construction stocks at 1.0 percent, plastic and chemical shares at 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.24 percent.
Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile shares at 0.4 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,480 to 540, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO urged to resume direct contact with Taiwan

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) should resume direct engagement with Taiwan to prevent the appearance of any holes in the global epidemic control network, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged in a press release Tuesday.

The MOFA made the appeal after the WHO's International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) skipped Taiwan and instead asked China to inform Taiwan of the contamination of an outbound shipment of green corn from Thailand in September that resulted in a 10-day delay in Taiwan receiving the information.
It marked the first time that the WHO has failed to engage Taiwan directly.

"We protest the WHO's snub and urge the international community to face squarely the flaw of Taiwan's exclusion from the International Health Regulations (IHR) mechanism and hammer out a remedy by resuming direct contact with Taiwan, " the MOFA said in the press statement.
The ministry also condemned China for repeatedly putting pressure on the WHO to refrain from direct engagement with Taiwan.

Dismissing as a "sheer lie" China's claims that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China and that its IHR implementation covers Taiwan, the ministry said the Thai green corn case clearly indicates that China does not care about the Taiwan people's health at all.

The fact that China didn't inform Taiwan of the contamination of the Thai green corn until 10 days after it received the notice from the INFOSAN Sept. 12 is yet further proof of China's lack of concern for the health rights of the people of Taiwan, the ministry said.

Besides instructing Taiwan's representative office in Geneva to lodge a formal protest with the WHO over the incident, the ministry also called on the world health regulatory body to address the problems resulting from its failure to include Taiwan in its IHR disease and epidemic control mechanism simply because of China's opposition.
Under Beijing's pressure, the WHO secretly signed a memorandum of understanding with China in 2005 under which the WHO agrees to avoid direct engagement with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally grown vegetables to be available soon: Premier

TEXT.P: Massive quantities of locally grown vegetables will enter the market at the beginning of November to help ease weeks of high vegetable prices, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.
Vegetable prices in local market have risen due to crop damages caused by Typhoon Krosa which hit Taiwan earlier this month.

In order to minimize the typhoon's impact on vegetable prices, the government has continued releasing frozen, cold stored, and imported vegetable stocks to provide a stable supply and meet market demand, Chang said.
Chang suggested consumers buy root stocks instead of leafy vegetables before locally grown vegetables enter the market in early November.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Su Jia-chyuan said the COA will craft measures to lower vegetable wholesale prices to less than NT$50 (US$1.53) per kg within one week while it continues providing frozen and important vegetables to the market.
A spokesman of the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. said wholesale price in Taipei area for Tuesday was NT$50.91 per kg, which was cheaper than Monday's figure of NT$52.6.

Autumn is the harvest period for most vegetables, the spokesman said, adding that the wholesale market's vegetable quantity for Tuesday reached 1,052 tons, with the prices of some vegetables, such as water spinach, celery, okra, and loofah showing an obvious decline.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical professionals relocating to China should be 'managed': PM

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that there should be "effective management" of medical professionals relocating to China, saying that relevant laws and regulations should address the issue.

The premier made the remarks when fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan amid reports that Chang Kung Memorial Hospital, a national-level hospital, will open a branch in Xiamen in southeastern China's Fujian province next month.

Chang noted that the guiding principle will be safeguarding the health of the Taiwanese people, saying that the Department of Health (DOH) should learn more about how much medical equipment and how many professionals of Chang Kung hospital will be relocating to China.
The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the nation's China policy charting agency, should also map out a policy to help manage the issue, the premier said.
DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mou said that out of humanitarian concern, medical professionals need not to seek prior approval from the government to relocate to China.
But he said that the distribution of Taiwan's medical professionals and the habits of Taiwan people seeking medical treatment should not be affected.
"A massive relocation of medical professionals may impact medical quality, " he noted, adding that the DOH will discuss the matter with the MAC.
MAC Chairman Chen Ming-tong said that if Taiwan can produce an oversupply of medical doctors, then there will be no problem with a number of them going to China or anywhere else.
But if the supply falls short of demand, then the health of Taiwan people should be given a priority, Chen added.
He said that this is not about national security, but the health of Taiwan's people.

The question is how many medical professionals will relocate and whether there will be an impact on the quality of medical care, adding that "if there is no impact, then there will be no regulation. But if there is, of course, there will be regulation, " adding that this is the gist of the government's China policy of "effective management."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 presidential poll option between Taiwan, China: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the presidential poll early next year is extremely critical to Taiwan's future because it will present voters with an option between Taiwan and China.
Chen made the remarks in an exclusive interview with a Kaohsiung-based radio station.

Expressing his strong belief that a "Taiwan-centric" identity will trounce the "greater China" notion in the March 22 presidential election, Chen said that although Taiwan is small in size, it is capable of providing protection for the many Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China.

Chen accused Vincent Siew, vice presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on the party's ticket with former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, of forswearing a pro-Taiwan stance by promoting a cross-Taiwan Strait common market.

Such a one-China oriented common market would endanger Taiwan's economic lifeline, he said, arguing that the economic integration of Taiwan and China would lead to the political unification of the two sides.

The coming presidential election will present a choice between Taiwan and China, Chen said, urging the public to enthusiastically take part in the round-the- nation torch relay for Taiwan's U.N. membership bid that will kick off Wednesday and run through Nov. 3.

The president also elaborated on his doubling as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and described his role in the next presidential poll as that of an auxiliary helping Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate, to win the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 189 points to close at 9,513, with 37,835 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December gained 182 points to finish at 9,512, with 247 contracts traded, while March futures rose 110 points to close at 9,537, with seven contract transactions. June futures moved up 111 points to close at 9,490, with seven contract transactions, while September futures increased 190 points to close at 9,344, with 14 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,324 for November, 9,330 for December, 9,427 for March, 9,379 for June, and 9,154 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

November TE futures rose 10.45 points to close at 399.35, with 3,241 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 10.65 points to finish at 399.5, with 32 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 12.05 points to close at 400.3, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

November TF futures gained 22.6 points to close at 1,035.2, with 2,647 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 16.8 points to finish at 1,035.4, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: China criticized for delay in passing on information

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health Tuesday blasted Beijing's delay in informing Taiwan of an outbreak of food contamination involving Thailand-grown baby corn, calling such behavior "bullying."

CDC Deputy Director General Shih Wen-yi denounced China as a "bully" in response to media inquiries following news reports disclosing the delay. China said it was informed by the World Health Organization (WHO) Sept. 12 that the baby corn exported by Thailand's PDI Trading Co. were suspected of having been contaminated by Shigella bacteria, which can affect the human digestion system.

However, instead of informing Taiwan of the suspected outbreak directly, the WHO requested that China convey the intelligence to Taiwan. It has been revealed that Beijing did not do so until Sept. 21, when it sent afax to the CDC to inform them of the matter, according to the reports.

Under International Health Regulations passed in 2005 by the World Health Assembly, the WHO's decision-making body, Shih said that the global group is obliged to convey to its "focal points" messages concerning disease outbreaks, toxic chemical substances, and the shipment of toxic organic substances, such as bacteria-contaminated baby corn.
China is one of the WHO's focal points but Taiwan is not, because China claimed it is capable of caring for the health of the Taiwanese people.

Shih complained that this is the reason why the WHO failed to inform Taiwan directly of the alleged contamination immediately following initial reports, and that this delay placed the health of the Taiwanese people under threat.
Shih pointed to China's responses to periodic reports of cases of human H5N1 avian influenza infection as examples of its reluctance to pass on information to Taiwan.

Each time, an hour or two before Beijing held a press conference to announce a new outbreak of the deadly avian flu, the CDC would receive a written message from its Chinese counterpart, Shih said, noting that the content of the written messages did not differ from those Beijing provided to the media, and that these messages "didn't help the country's quarantine efforts at all."
"That is the way China takes care of the Taiwanese people, " Shih complained.
According to the CDC, it has proved that the problematic baby corn were not shipped to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passage of U.N.-bid referendum to strengthen allies' support: MOFA

TEXT.P: The passage of a referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan will encourage the country's diplomatic allies to provide stronger support for its U.N. bid, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Tuesday.

Huang said the government has opted to use the name Taiwan because the country's official name, the Republic of China, is acceptable only by its diplomatic allies, but not by international organizations and countries with no diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Noting that the government has been striving to expand the country's foreign relations, Huang said it is possible that the passage of the referendum could help the country establish formal ties with more countries.
Huang made the remarks during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, when asked if the passage of the referendum would scare off the country's diplomatic allies.

While the country has tried since 1993 to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation, this year for the first time it applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan. However, as on previous occasions, the issue of Taiwan's membership application was excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

Determined to continue the drive, the DPP is pushing for a referendum on whether to apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, which is expected to be held alongside the March 2008 presidential election.

The United States has expressed strong opposition to the planned referendum on the grounds that the apparent pursuit of a name change in the referendum makes it appear to be a step towards changing the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
Calling the referendum initiative a "needlessly provocative action, " U.S. officials have warned that such moves could scare away potential friends who might help Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.01 to close at NT$32.580.
A total of US$728 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.564 and hit a high of NT$32.595.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor vows to inaugurate MRT system at year's end

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Tuesday that the goal of inaugurating the mass rapid transit (MRT) system at the end of the year remains unchanged.
Chen made the remarks amid reports that the inauguration of the the MRT system may be delayed because a section of the 28.3 km Red Line is only about 80 percent completed.

Chen admitted that the section is indeed behind schedule, but said that the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) , which is in charge of the construction, is making all-out efforts to get back on schedule.
She said she was perplexed by reports of a possible delay, stressing that she is ready to meet the goal of inaugurating the line at the end of year, so long as safety is uncompromised.

Kaohsiung's MRT system is comprised of the Red Line and the Orange Line. The 14.4 km Orange Line, due to a collapsed tunnel near Station 7, and water seepage in Station 1, is not expected to open until the end of 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister pans China over blocking WHO from engaging Taiwan

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang condemned China Tuesday for its pressuring the World Health Organization (WHO) to refrain from engaging Taiwan directly.

Huang issued the condemnation after the WHO failed to inform Taiwan directly of the suspected contamination of an outbound shipment of green corn from Thailand last month and instead passed the message first to China, which resulted in a 10-day delay in Taiwan receiving the information.

Noting that China's delay in informing Taiwan of the possible contamination of the Thai green corn is further proof of its lack of concern of Taiwan people's health rights, Huang said the international community should face squarely to the flaw and injustice of Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO-sponsored International Health Regulation (IHR) mechanism.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, the WHO's International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) informed all of its member countries Sept. 12 of suspected bacteria contamination of a shipment of green corn exported by a Thai trading company.

Because of China's obstruction, Taiwan has been shut out of the WHO after it lost its U.N. seat in 1971. In the past, the WHO used to inform Taiwan of important global health and disease information via the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under its Cabinet-level Department of Health. But this time around, the WHO skipped such a direct communications channel and instead asked China's CDC to inform its Taiwanese counterpart. The Chinese authorities didn't inform Taiwan's CDC until Sept. 21.

"The WHO owes Taiwan an explanation why it didn't directly inform Taiwan of the suspected Thai green corn contamination, " Wang said, adding that the WHO's abrupt change in its communication mode has left a gap in its global disease and epidemic prevention and control network.

Lin Yung-lo, director of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said the ministry has directed the country's representative office in Geneva to lodge a protest with the WHO. However, he said, the WHO has so far not made any response to Taiwan's protest.

In addition, Lin said the MOFA has also informed Taiwan's diplomatic allies and other important countries around the world, including the United States, the European Union and Japan, of the latest development in the WHO handling of issues regarding Taiwan.

Lin said the MOFA has reminded major world powers that the WHO's arbitrary placement of its communication channel with Taiwan under its dialogue mechanism with China implies that "Taiwan is part of China", a claim that does not conform with their basic stance or policy toward Taiwan.

In the wake of this incident, Lin said the MOFA will continue monitoring developments in China's and WHO's dealing with Taiwan and will step up consultations with major world power on relevant issues.
Under China's pressure, the WHO secretly signed a memorandum of understanding with China in 2005 under which the WHO promises to refrain from direct engagement with Taiwan.

According to MOFA officials, the WHO's failure to engage Taiwan directly violates the spirit of the IHR which took effect June 15, 2007 to lay out a new framework to better manage its collective defenses against acute public health risks and contribute to enhancing national, regional and international public health security.

Although Taiwan is not a WHO member, it has voluntarily abided by all IHR requirements. Moreover, Lin said, major countries, such as the United States, Japan and many EU member states, have promised to offer Taiwan meaningful participation in IHR activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health Dept. urged to protest China's delay in passing on information

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) should write to the World Health Organization (WHO) to blast China's "covering up" an outbreak of food contamination involving Thailand-grown baby corn, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) caucus whip Lo Chih-ming said at a news conference Tuesday.

According to an earlier news report in the local Liberty Times newspaper, the WHO informed its member countries of a food contamination case involving Thailand-grown baby corn Sept. 12 and requested that China inform Taiwan, disregarding an unimpeded communication channel which Taiwan, though not a WHO member, had established with the international body.
However, the newspaper stated that China had delayed informing Taiwan for 10 days, and even then failed to provide complete information to Taiwan's health authorities.

Lo said China intentionally blocked the communication channel between Taiwan and the WHO and deliberately delayed relaying the information, providing obvious evidence that China is not trustworthy on health issues and possesses neither the right nor the capability to protect the health and safety of Taiwan's people.
The TSU might respond by initiating a campaign urging each Taiwanese citizen to write a letter to the WHO denouncing China's deception, Lo went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU opposes imports of China-made garments

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) threatened Tuesday to block the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) if it fails to swiftly apply the brakes to a plan to allow imports of garments made in China to enter the domestic market.
TSU legislative caucus whip Lo Chih-ming issued the warning at a Legislative Yuan news conference.

According to Lo, the TSU is firmly opposed to such an opening and will not rule out the possibility of mobilizing workers from the domestic textile industry to seal off and paralyze the MOEA, and to demand that Minister Steve R. L. Chen step down should the ministry refuse to scrap the plan.
The livelihoods of more than 100,000 local workers would be hit hard if the MOEA bows to foreign pressure and approves the opening, Lo said.
It has been reported that the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei and the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei are very concerned about the issue as they have long expected such an opening.
TSU lawmaker Liao Pen-yen urged the MOEA to rein in those expectations and argued that they would freeze the ministry's budget or take other actions to frustrate the opening.

According to TSU lawmaker Lin Chih-chia, Taiwan's textile industry would be extinguished if garments manufactured in China are allowed to enter the home market. "Taiwan's traditional industry has had enough, " he complained, pointing to the local shoe-making and toweling sectors which have been squeezed out of the business due to large amounts of Chinese imports in the home market.

Chen said a day earlier that his ministry would not rashly approve the opening before the opinions of local industry are fully vetted. The government's top concern in reaching a decision on an opening is whether or not it will negatively impact local industry, he said.

Echoing Chen's remarks, officials of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade said that the domestic textile sector is not expected to be majorly impacted as it has succeeded in shifting toward the manufacture of high-tech and value-added goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Loving hug' policy replaced by 'shaking hands': defense ministry

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defence (MND) has announced that it will ask boot camp squad leaders to welcome new recruits with a handshake rather than giving them a hug.

The announcement came Monday after several legislators questioned Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu about the military's "loving hug" policy during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee earlier in the day.
Lee first defended the policy as aimed at soothing the new soldiers' feelings of unease in the new environment, but later promised to scrap the policy.
According to a press release issued by the MND later in the day, the ministry said it had conducted a careful assessment before implementing the "loving hug" policy Oct. 1.
The press release said that most of the new recruits accepted the "loving hug", while only "a handful" were "not used to being hugged" or were "too shy for hugging" as some media reported.
As a result, the ministry has decided to replace the "loving hug" policy with a handshake starting Monday, the press release concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. recalls two Taiwan-made products over safety concerns

TEXT.P: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) has announced that two products manufactured in Taiwan, a bicycle and a children's gymnastic balance beam, should be recalled due to safety concerns, Taiwan's Consumer Protection Commission Council (CPCC) said Monday.

According to the CPCC, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission issued the notice to Taiwan's representative office in the U.S. Oct. 18, saying that some 2,400 "Kidnastics Balance Beams", manufactured in Taiwan, have been recalled due to its violation of lead paint standards, while 45 "Rocky Mountain-Solo Bicycles" fabricated in Taiwan have been recalled due to a possible fall hazard to consumers as its head tube can become detached from the rest of the frame.
The children's gymnastic balance beam, measuring 72-inches x 4- inches x 1/2-inch with a blue vinyl cover, has a yellow Kidnastics logo printed on its top.

According to CPSC, they have received two reports of shoulder and facial injuries with the Rocky Mountain-Solo Bicycles. The models included in this recall are: 2006 SOLO CR50, 2006 SOLO CR70, and 2007 SOLO CR LTD.

The CPSC urged the consumers to stop using these bicycles immediately, which are sold in the U.S., Canada and Taiwan, and to return the frame to place of purchase to receive a free replacement frame, a full refund, or credit.
For more information, the consumers can visit CPSC's Web site at: www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/prerel/prhtml08/0850.html.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis outbreak slowing in Chiayi

TEXT.P: The number of people suffering from acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis -- known locally as pink eye disease -- in the southern city of Chiayi, the area of Taiwan worst-hit by the outbreak, is declining, Chiayi City Director of Health Sun Shu-jung said Tuesday.

A total of 157 elementary and junior high school students in the city were reported to be infected as of Tuesday. The number marks a significant drop in comparison with the peak of the outbreak recorded Oct. 5 with 477 cases, Sun said.
Thanks to the drop in the number of new patients, Sun added, a Department of Health order to submit daily reports on the outbreak has been lifted from the city.
In addition to Chiayi City, other affected areas include Taipei city and county, as well as Yunlin and Chiayi counties.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is characterized by sudden onset of painful, swollen, red eyes, with conjunctival hemorrhaging and excessive tearing. The disease has been noted throughout tropical regions.
According to doctors, no effective treatment is available for the disease and patients can only wait for the disease to run its course after around seven days while receiving treatment for symptoms.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-organized 'return to U.N.' bike tour to kick off Wednesday

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will launch a round-the-nation bicycle tour Wednesday in downtown Taipei to solicit public support for its bid to have Taiwan return to the United Nations under the name "Republic of China, " a KMT spokeswoman said Tuesday.

Lai Su-ju, the director of the KMT's department of cultural and information affairs made the announcement at a press conference on the activity, which she noted will be held simultaneously with the National Sports Council-sponsored torch relay promoting the U.N. bid under the name "Taiwan, " and will follow a route similar to the government's event.

Lai said the KMT will try to avoid clashes with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party when the two separate runs are underway because the main goal of the bike tour is to publicize their belief that "people in the country are suffering economic hardship."

At the press conference the KMT unveiled the theme, "Fighting for People's Livelihood, " for its round-Taiwan bicycle tour by having a five-year-old girl riding on a bicycle appear at the press conference, spelling out the lines: "All prices have been hiked! I already carry debts before I can go to work."

KMT Culture and Communications Committee Chairman Yang Tu said he hopes the planned bike tour will awaken the ruling party from its dreams of a successful U.N. bid to the reality that people around island are suffering because the country's economy has worsened over the past seven years.

According to the KMT, the party's presidential candidate, former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, will lead the tour when it kicks off at the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly known as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, in Taipei.

Lai stressed the tour will take place on roads outlined by the police, and that the KMT will also advise the participants to refrain from coming into conflict with those joining the government's torch relay.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taiwan Coffee Festival being held in Yunlin County

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taiwan Coffee Festival is being held in Gukeng township, Yunlin County, with various coffee-related activities and entertainment programs.

The annual festival, now in its fifth year, opened Oct. 13 and will run for three weeks until Nov. 4. The event, sponsored by the Yunlin county government and organized by the Gukeng township administration, is intended to promote and market Gukeng's chief agricultural product -- coffee.
Farmers in Gukeng have been growing coffee for more than three centuries, but few people are aware of Taiwanese coffee, as most of the beans are exported.

In recent years, as a result of changing lifestyles, coffee drinking has become more popular in Taiwan, and in 2003, the Gukeng township head saw an opportunity to revive the local economy and launched the annual coffee festival.

Main events in the 2007 festival include an evaluation of locally produced coffee beans by international experts, a demonstration by baristi and culinary school students to produce their best free pour art, a coffee bean roasting contest and a weekend coffee bean market.
On weekends during the festival, visitors are entertained with live music performances while they sip a cup of genuine Taiwanese coffee in one of Gukeng's coffee shops.
There are also two exhibitions, allowing visitors to view and buy local agricultural products and handicrafts made by prison inmates.
A group wedding will take place along Gukeng's two-kilometer "green tunnel" Oct. 27 to wed 150 couples from Yunlin County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Torch relay to put U.N. bid under global spotlight

TEXT.P: A round-the-nation torch relay that will kick off Wednesday in front of the Presidential Office is aimed at making jogging a popular exercise and putting Taiwan's U.N. cause under global spotlight, Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Minister Yang Jong-her said Tuesday.

The government hopes to convey the desire and resolve of Taiwan's people to enter the United Nations to the rest of the world through the torch relay that will pass through 25 cities and counties, including the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, before the 1,200-km run wraps up Nov. 3, Yang said.

Yang called on people from all walks of life and all parts of the the country, regardless of their political affiliation, to take part in the activity, so as to make jogging more fashionable in Taiwan and transmit its people's aspiration to the international community through collective participation.

According to Taipei municipal police department chief Wang Cho-ching, more than 700 policemen will be deployed to maintain public and traffic order in Taipei's streets Wednesday, when the SAC-sponsored U.N. membership bid torch relay and a round-the-island bike tour organized by the main opposition Kuomintang kick off simultaneously in Taipei.

As the Taipei City Government has granted approval to the two events, the public will be permitted to take part in both activities, Wang said, adding that police authorities from around the country will maintain neutrality in the run-up to and process of the two events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier praises `no-name hero' volunteers for overseas service

TEXT.P: Long-term volunteers of Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) for overseas service are "no-name heroes" for expanding Taiwan's unofficial diplomatic relations, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

A total of 40 ICDF long-term volunteers for overseas service have just completed a six-week training program to help them adjust to their overseas lives and will soon depart for various developing countries to serve in a number of different fields.

The ICDF, a government-run organization in charge of official aid to impoverished countries, is entering its 11th year of sending volunteers overseas and has already sent 263 volunteers abroad, including both long-term and short- term workers.

Chang said that although the ICDF volunteers have made great contributions to the international community, Taiwan still needs to make more effort to catch up on the achievements of the U.S. Peace Corps and the Japan Overseas Cooperation Volunteers, both of which are world renowned volunteer organizations.

Chang expressed hope that ICDF volunteers' performance and passion will draw more people to dedicate themselves to overseas volunteer service and added that he plans to offer his services as a volunteer after he steps down as premier next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to combine electronics, solar energy exhibitions

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will integrate Taiwan's electronics, photovoltaic, solar energy and broadband communications shows into a single big exhibition next year to improve efficiency and boost the competitiveness of domestic firms.

A TAITRA official said the just-concluded Taipei International Electronics Autumn Show, the Taiwan International Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) Show and the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition which were staged simultaneously earlier this month attracted 70,000 visitors from home and abroad, an increase of 10 percent over last year.
The majority of the buyers came from Asia and the United States, while those from the Middle East, Eastern Europe, Southeast Asia and Latin America also registered an increase, the official said.
According to TAITRA statistics, the joint organization of these three shows produced on-the-spot trade opportunities worth US$2.2 billion.

Encouraged by the notable increase in the number of foreign buyers attending the joint shows, TAITRA decided to add a broadband communications show to next year's joint exhibition, for which many local and foreign firms have already booked exhibition booths, the official added.

According to the official, the Taipei International Electronics Autumn Show, the Taiwan International RFID Show and the Broadband Communications Show will be held simultaneously in October next year at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall, while the Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition will take place at the Taipei International Convention Center and the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall One, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier approves ministers' participation in U.N. bid torch relay

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Steve R.L. Chen's participation in a torch relay promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations shows Chen's support of the government's policies, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

Chen and Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin said at the Legislative Yuan that same day that they will take part in the government's round-the-nation U.N. bid torch relay scheduled to begin the following day in Taipei City.

Responding to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Chia-chin's questions on the justification of the two ministers' participation, Chang said the Executive Yuan has approved Cabinet members' participation in the activity as long as it is during their personal time.

Replying to Lee's challenge that Chen should spend more time improving Taiwan's economy instead of taking part in the torch relay, Chang claimed that the government's bid to join the United Nations is "closely related" to the economy.

He explained that the Republic of China's withdrawal from the U.N. in 1971 resulted in its dropping out of international financial organizations like the World Bank, thus losing many business opportunities.

Chen said that as a political appointed official, he feels obliged to support the government's policies and added that his participation in the activity will not impede the Ministry of Economic Affairs' efforts to improve the economy, while Ho pointed out that his citizenship guarantees him the right to take part in such activities in his own personal time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade officials postpone decision on imports of Chinese garments

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has decided to postpone a decision on whether to permit imports of 54 items of China-made garments, a trade official said Tuesday.
Wu Hsin-hua, deputy director of the bureau, said an inter-ministry meeting scheduled for that day to review the restrictions on imports of these garments had been canceled.
Wu said no decision on the issue will be taken until the various concerned sectors, not the least the apparel industry, have been fully consulted.

Wu said his bureau decided to cancel the meeting late Monday after the disclosure of the meeting's discussion had drawn strong protests from apparel associations and opposition lawmakers, who threatened to stage a demonstration if the government allows imports of Chinese garments.

As is usual with imports of any Chinese products, Wu said, the imports were requested by local businessmen and the issue was referred to the meeting, which is hosted by the Bureau of Foreign Trade every month to review and discuss the country's trade policy.

Of the 54 items of apparel, including coats, women's apparel, overcoats and shirts, most are made of cotton or wool, which are seldom produced in Taiwan, and their imports would serve the interests of consumers although it might have negative impact on a few local producers, Wu said.

Taiwan has thus far approved the imports of 309 items of Chinese-made textile products, among which 41 percent were approved without any conditions and 59 percent were approved on the condition that they are made with Taiwan-produced materials, Wu said, adding that the 54 items of clothing that were to have been discussed Tuesday fall into the latter category.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to invest US$3 billion in WiMAX by 2012: ITRI

TEXT.P: The government and the private sector are expected to invest approximately US$3 billion in developing WiMAX technology in Taiwan by 2012, an analyst from a local research institute said Tuesday.
The forecast came as the 2007 WiMAX Forum Taipei Showcase and Conference, the first of its kind in the world, was taking place in Taipei Oct. 22-23.
The event, organized by the WiMAX Forum and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), attracted 76 local and foreign firms.
Founded in June 2001, the Portland, Oregon-based WiMAX Forum has 460 members, most of which are operators, as well as component and equipment companies.
WiMAX, or Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, is a new wireless communication technology that allows users to surf the Internet even when they are moving at high speed.

According to research conducted by the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) of the government-funded Institute for Information Industry, the global WiMAX market is expected to generate a total production value of US$75.5 billion by 2012.

Under a "Mobile-Taiwan" project launched by the government in 2003, the research predicts, the total output value of the WiMAX Customer Premises Equipment (CPE) shipment volume will amount to US$159 million this year, up 604 percent from last year's US$22.6 million.
Chang Chi, a senior industry analyst at the MIC, estimated that the total amount of investment for establishing WiMAX networks in the world is likely to reach US$4.8 billion between 2007 and 2008.
In the next six years, Chang predicted, half of the world's 500 telecom operators will invest in the establishment of WiMAX base stations.

According to Chang, with the assistance of various government projects, Taiwanese telecom operators have already acquired a global competitive edge in the development of the WiMAX industry supply chain.

Although Taiwan is expected to become a hub for researching, developing and producing WiMAX equipment, product certification will remain one of the major costs for local telecom operators, Chang went on.

If a WiMAX testing and certification center could be set up in Taiwan, Chang said, it would greatly reduce Taiwanese operators' costs and the time it takes them to launch WiMAX products on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three hypermarkets to sell vegetables at special prices

TEXT.P: Three major supermarket chains revealed plans Tuesday to sell from the following day certain kinds of leafy vegetables at a discount, with prices ranging from between NT$9 and NT$19 per bunch.

The separate announcements come after a news report disclosed that the Council of Agriculture (COA) intends to cooperate with local supermarket chains to sell COA-released leafy vegetables at NT$5 per bunch in an effort to curb increasing vegetable prices.
Both Carrefour and RT-Mart denied that the COA had offered them cheap vegetable stocks, while Geant said it had received COA assistance in stocking cheap vegetables.
However, Geant executives said they will sell sweet potato leaves in their stores around the country at NT$9 per bag from Wednesday, which is expected to be the cheapest vegetable in the market.
Carrefour mangers indicated that although the COA had not informed them of its plan to promote low-priced vegetables, their stores will still sell discounted products.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 OEC Cup Taiwan Ladies Tennis Open to begin Oct. 29

TEXT.P: More than 100 female tennis players from around the world, including top professional players in Asia, will compete in the 2007 OEC Cup Taiwan Ladies Open from Oct. 29.
They will vie for cash prizes totaling US$50,000 offered by the OEC Group, a leading trans-Pacific freight company.
Among the contestants are four seeded players: Akiko Morigami from Japan, Tamarine Tanasugarn from Thailand, Taiwanese player Chan Yung-jan and Yuan Meng from China.
The competition will take place at Yang Guang Shan Lin Country Club in Taoyuan County's Yangmei township.
Nine other leading Taiwanese female tennis players in the competition will be using the event as an opportunity for them to earn points in order to qualify for the 2008 Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for October 24, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Cycling tour around Taiwan to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid. Date and Time: 7 a.m., Wednesday, Oct. 24, 2007. Place: 24, ZhongShang South Road, Taipei City, Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall. Host and/or main speakers: KMT Presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou. Organizers: Kuomintang. Press Contact: 8771-1234.

3. Event: Celebration for 2007 United Nations Day in Taiwan. Date and Time: 2:30, p.m., Wednesday, Oct. 24, 2007. Place: 30, XinSheng S.Rd. Sec.3, Taipei, Civil Service Development Institute. The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: President Giorgio Napolitano urged judicial officials to stop quarrels when spoke of lawsuits against each other by Justice Minister Clemente Mastella and prosecutor of Catanzaro for offfice abuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Four parents die trying to save children Three British parents drowned as they attempted to rescue their children when they became trapped in strong currents off a Portuguese beach yesterday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Attempts to Ease Turkey-Iraq Tensions
The United States has warned Iraqi leaders to take concrete steps to crack down on Kurdish rebels operating against Turkey from northern Iraq, as Turkey yesterday dispatched more troops and heavy weaponry toward the Iraqi border.
The Washington Times: Honor for a fallen hero
"Murph" was determined to deliver his message on a rugged mountaintop, and died doing it.
The nation showed its gratitude to the young officer yesterday. President Bush presented the first Medal of Honor for combat in Afghanistan to the family of Lt. Michael P. Murphy, a Navy SEAL who sacrificed his life trying to save his comrades two years ago. The four were outmanned and outgunned deep behind enemy lines, hemmed in on three sides by hostile fire and 10,000 feet up.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: 2 Reports Assail State Dept. Role in Iraq Security
A pair of new reports have delivered sharply critical judgments about the State Departmentzs performance in overseeing work done by the private companies that the government relies on increasingly in Iraq and Afghanistan to carry out delicate security work and other missions.
The Wall Street Journal: More Debtors Use Bankruptcy To Keep Homes; Chapter 13 Filings Gain In Popularity Because They Halt Foreclosures
With loan defaults rising along with many mortgage payments, fast-growing numbers of homeowners are gambling on bankruptcy filings to try to stay in their homes.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid torch relay kicks off

TEXT.P: A round-the-nation torch relay to drum up support for the country's bid to join the United Nation under the name Taiwan kicked off Wednesday, with President Chen Shui-bian leading the pack.

President Chen passed the torch to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh after completing the opening leg from the Presidential Office plaza to Jingfu Gate at the intersection of Ketagalan Boulevard and Zhongshan S. Road in downtown Taipei to symbolize passing on the mission and legacy.

In a speech delivered before the start of the road run, Chen said the tradition of lighting a torch came from the ancient Olympics in Greece. Noting that the flame symbolizes peace, rationality and continuity, Chen said the U.N. bid torch relay is aimed at showing the world the 23 million Taiwan people's aspiration to have their country represented in the United Nations in the name of Taiwan.

Road run participants began to gather in front of the Presidential Office at 6 a.m. Following a flag-raising ceremony, a dancer lit the torch on the main cauldron amid festive music and dancing at 6: 35 a.m.

President Chen arrived at 6: 48 a.m. and signed his name on a giant billboard bearing the Chinese characters expressing the country's quest for U.N. membership. He then lit the torch in his hand and the torches kept by other bearers were also lit in turn.

The road run kicked-start at 7 a.m. President Chen led the 450-meter leg from the Presidential Office plaza to Jingfu Gate and many senior officials, including Vice President Annette Lu, Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, many Cabinet members and DPP department chiefs, also join the road running event.

Chen passed the torch to Hsieh after arriving at Jingfu Gate. The large crowd of runners continued running along Zhongshan S. Road, Zhongxiao E. Road to Hsitzu Railway Station in Taipei County. The 1,200-km relay, which will cover all 25 counties and cities around the country, is expected to take 11 days to complete.

They will vie for cash prizes totaling US$50,000 offered by the OEC Group, a leading trans-Pacific freight company.
Among the contestants are four seeded players: Akiko Morigami from Japan, Tamarine Tanasugarn from Thailand, Taiwanese player Chan Yung-jan and Yuan Meng from China.
The competition will take place at Yang Guang Shan Lin Country Club in Taoyuan County's Yangmei township.
Nine other leading Taiwanese female tennis players in the competition will be using the event as an opportunity for them to earn points in order to qualify for the 2008 Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 24, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT launches cycling tour for `return to U.N.' bid

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) launched a nationwide cycling tour in Taipei City Wednesday to drum up support for its push for a referendum on the country's return to the United Nations under the name Republic of China.

The event coincided with a nationwide torch relay organized by the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) to promote the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's goal of having the country join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

The opening ride was headed by KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, who led a team of cyclists that set off from the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall along Xinyi Road to the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.
A similar activity led by Ma's running mate, Vincent Siew, was expected to take place in Hsichih, Taipei County, before another one scheduled for Keelung City later in the day.
The cycling tour is scheduled to visit the country's 25 counties and cities in 11 days, following a route similar to the SAC-organized torch relay.

KMT officials said the referendum on the country's return to the United Nations and the DPP-initiated referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan are two opposing referendums, with the KMT calling for the maintenance of the status quo and the DPP one calling for a declaration of Taiwan independence.

According to Ma, the KMT-initiated referendum provides a better and more flexible solution than the DPP's, because if the KMT-backed referendum is passed, the government will be authorized to adopt an appropriate method at an appropriate time to push for the country's return to the United Nations.

Predicting that the DPP-backed referendum will lead to a diplomatic setback for Taiwan, Ma claimed that the DPP hopes to take advantage of the situation to incite a "sad sentiment" among the party's supporters to boost the party's presidential campaign and divert the public's attention away from the incompetence and corruption of the DPP administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China, two nations on either side: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Wednesday that Taiwan and China are two separate nations located on either side of the Taiwan Strait and that Taiwan has never been a province of China.

Addressing the opening of a round-the-island torch relay aimed at drumming up support for the nation's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Chen claimed that the U.N. bid is the mainstream opinion of the Taiwan public and an aspiration to uphold Taiwan's sovereignty and status.
"Today's torch relay is also a move protesting against China's ceaseless suppression and merciless containment of Taiwan, particularly when it comes to the 2008 Olympic Games," Chen said.
The president said that while international support is an important force helping Taiwan enter the U.N., esprit de corps demonstrated by the Taiwan people themselves is even more vital.

He called for the public to "say out loud" their pursuit of peace, democracy and compassion, saying that the people's support and response to the bid is the greatest energy that can light up the fire of the "Taiwan U.N. bid."
He added that the torch relay is aimed at showing the world Taiwan's aspiration to be represented in the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Chen kicked off the torch relay by running the opening leg of the event from the Presidential Office plaza to the Jingfu Gate at the intersection of Ketagalan Boulevard and Zhongshan South Road in downtown Taipei. He than passed the torch to ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh.
The 1,200-km relay, which will cover all of the country's 25 counties and cities, is expected to take 11 days to complete.

DOC.HEADLINE: President leads torch relay to promote U.N. bid

TEXT.P: A round-the-nation torch relay to drum up support for the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan kicked off Wednesday with President Chen Shui-bian leading the pack.

Chen passed the torch to ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh after completing the opening leg, to symbolize passing on the mission and legacy to his would-be successor.

In a speech delivered before the start of the run, Chen said the tradition of lighting a torch comes from the ancient Olympics in Greece. Noting that the flame symbolizes peace, rationality and continuity, Chen said the U.N. bid torch relay is aimed at showing the world the Taiwan people's aspiration to have their country represented in the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
Road run participants began to gather in front of the Presidential Office at 6 a.m. Following a flag-raising ceremony, a dancer lit the main cauldron amid festive music and dancing.

Chen arrived a few minutes later and signed a giant billboard bearing the Chinese characters that translate as "All People's Torch Relay to Advance into the United Nations". He then lit his torch and torches held by other bearers were also lit.
Chen led the first 450-meter leg from the Presidential Office plaza to the Jingfu Gate at the intersection of Ketagalan Boulevard and Zhongshan South Road in downtown Taipei.
Many senior officials, including Vice President Annette Lu, Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, the entire Cabinet and DPP department chiefs also joined the first lap of the run.

Chen passed the torch to Hsieh after arriving at the Jingfu Gate where Hsieh's running mate Su Tseng-chang and an army of young DPP members, as well as a crowd of road run supporters, were waiting for the arrival of the torch.
Hsieh then led the pack from Jingfu Gate to the Chang Jung-fa Foundation Building, which formerly housed the main opposition Kuomintang's headquarters.

At the conclusion of the short second leg of the run, Hsieh, who has just recovered from an ankle sprain, said that despite continuing pain in his leg, his heart felt happy seeing so many people taking part in the event.

"Even though my leg injury has not yet fully recovered, I insisted on joining the run. Everybody has to do something for our country, including for our country's goal of securing U.N. membership, " Hsieh said.

Noting that the torch relay is an expression of Taiwan's national will to enter the international community under its own name, Hsieh said he, like many other people, was very happy to get up early in the morning to warm up for the road run.

Stressing that the run should not be just a brief episode and should instead be a national campaign, Hsieh said he looks forward to seeing people at home and abroad do their parts and contribute to the country's quest for U.N. representation.
"Although our road to the United Nations is bumpy and rugged and probably studded with potholes and pain, I'm convinced that our pursuit will definitely have a happy ending," Hsieh added.

Afterwards, the pack continued running along Zhongshan South Road and Zhongxiao East Road to the Hsitzu Railway Station in Taipei County. The 1,200-km relay, which will cover all 25 counties and cities around the country, is scheduled to take 11 days to complete.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to probe Chinese doctor soliciting organ transplants

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has instructed that a probe be conducted into reports of a Chinese doctor coming to Taiwan to solicit local patients seeking liver transplants in China, a DOH official said Wednesday.

Hsueh Jui-yuan, director of the DOH Bureau of Medical Affairs, was responding to reports by the Taipei-based Liberty Times that Zhu Zhijun, director of the organ transplant center of Tianjin First Central Hospital, came to Taiwan in March and conducted assessments in the company of two Taiwanese doctors on liver disease patients waiting to travel to China to get transplants. The Tianjin hospital is touted as the biggest liver transplant center in Asia.
Hsueh said the DOH has instructed the Taipei city government Department of Health to conduct a thorough probe into the matter.

If it is confirmed that Zhu came to Taiwan under the cover of medical exchanges but instead conducted assessments on liver disease patients, he could be subject to a prison term of between six months and five years if he ever decides to return to Taiwan because he did not inform the DOH about his intentions in advance and "lacks the qualifications of a doctor" as approved by the government.

Hsueh said that if Taiwanese doctors helped Zhu solicit patients and are found to have bought or sold organs, they could be disciplined for violation of medical ethics and have their licenses to practise revoked.
The organization that invited Zhu to come to Taiwan will be dealt with according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the people of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
Hsueh also said Zhu has visited Taiwan at least twice, and he asked Taipei DOH to learn more details.
According to Hsueh, the standards of Taiwan's organ transplants are on par with "those of the world, " and safer than those done in China.
More than 7,000 people in Taiwan are awaiting organ transplants, but he lamented that only around 100 people donate organs each year, creating a serious imbalance between supply and demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coast Guard beefs up forces in Matsu area

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) has recently dispatched its powerful second-generation coastal patrol ship the Pao Hsing to the outlying island of Matsu to flex the country's maritime muscles against illegal Chinese poachers.

Since its arrival at Matsu Oct. 18, the 600-ton vessel has demonstrated its determination to crack down on illegal Chinese fishermen who have repeatedly entered Republic of China territorial waters to poach in waters near Matsu with dynamite and resource-depleting iron-hulled boats.

Pao Hsing officers have stopped and searched three intruding Chinese fishing boats, all from Fujian Province, confiscating 200 baskets of fishing gear, according to Yao Chou-dien, chief of the CGA operations in the Matsu area.
Over the past week, the vessel has also driven 13 Chinese iron-hulled boats out of Matsu waters, Yao added.
Yao disclosed that the Pao Hsing will conduct sweeping operations in Matsu waters in an effort to safeguard Taiwan's maritime security as well as protect fishery resources in that area.
Matsu is located nearer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
KMT presidential candidate pledges financial liberalization

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou pledged Wednesday to push for financial liberalization if he is elected in the March 2008 election.

Making the remarks during a seminar with the National Federation of Bank Employee Unions, Ma claimed that financial reforms being promoted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration are unjust because mergers of financial institutions only benefit a small minority of business groups.
The DPP administration's closed-door policy has also restricted the overseas development of the financial sector and threatens the sector's survival, Ma claimed.

He alleged that under the DPP's leadership, government-owned banks have been forced to sponsor the publicity campaign for the bid to join the United Nations, while personnel appointments of the banks have become tools for political tradeoffs.

Ma promised that if he is elected, he will respect the market mechanism in pushing for mergers of financial institutions, work to normalize cross-Taiwan Strait trade and business activities, and promote cross-strait capital exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Targeted number of foreign visits does not include Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: The nation's top tourism official said Wednesday that the targeted number of foreign visits to Taiwan for next year is set at 4 million because Chinese tourists are not included.
Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, denied that the bureau is falling short of its targeted foreign visits.
Lai said that if Chinese tourists -- who are not allowed to travel directly to Taiwan from China -- were allowed to enter Taiwan, the number of visits would definitely increase.

She noted that when the Executive Yuan launched a tourism-boosting project in 2002 to double the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan to 5 million by 2008, it had Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan as the basis for the figure.
But she noted that the cross-Taiwan Strait issue cannot be unilaterally decided by Taiwan, so that the Tourism Bureau has "pragmatically revised" the number downward to 4 million for 2008.

She said the two sides of the strait have completed talks on the technical aspects of opening up Taiwan to Chinese tourists, but added that the problem lies with the political aspect, with Beijing insisting on the precondition that Taiwan must recognize its "one China" principle before it will allow its people to visit Taiwan.
If Chinese tourists are excluded from next year's projections, the Tourism Bureau is aiming at an average annual growth of 7 percent, or 4 million visits in 2008, and 4.25 million by 2009, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO urged to directly inform Taiwan of food safety information
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/07 15:39:34 (By Y.C. Jou and Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has urged the Geneva-based World Health Organization (WHO) to directly inform Taiwan of information on food safety rather than notifying Taiwan of the subject via China, Lyushun Shen, director of the Taipei Cultural and Economic Office in Geneva, said Wednesday.

Taiwan's call came in response to a delay by China, which was asked by the WHO Sept. 12 to alert Taiwan to a batch of Thailand-produced baby corn imports contaminated with shigella -- a bacterium that can cause an infectious foodborne disease. China did not pass on the information to Taiwan until Sept. 21, Shen said.
Fortunately, Taiwan customs officials found that the contaminated baby corn had not been imported to Taiwan, according to Shen.

The Taipei Cultural and Economic Office in Geneva, on behalf of the Taiwan government, wrote to the WHO to express displeasure over its decision to warn Taiwan of dangerous imports via China, Shen went on.

During the past two years, the WHO has directly informed Taiwan of food safety information instead of relying on China to inform Taiwan, Shen said, speculating that Beijing might have played a critical role in the change of the notification mode.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 59.77 points to close at 9,442.62.
The bourse opened at 9,593.2 and fluctuated between 9,640.49 and 9,442.62. A total of 4.68 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$159.36 billion (US$4.89 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 1.1 percent, and construction issues at 0.1 percent.
Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.8 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 570, with 245 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mutated mice laboratory under Academia Sinica open to public

TEXT.P: A mutant mice laboratory established under Academia Sinica, the country's most prestigious academic institution, has been opened to public to give an understanding of the links between genes and life, the head of the laboratory said Wednesday.

Dr. Kung Hsiang-chih, who presides over the Mouse Mutagenesis Program Core Facility (MMPCF) lab, noted that the MMPCF is aimed at developing mouse models for human disease and that the knowledge gained through the efforts of the MMPCF might lead to the development of novel strategies for disease treatment and prevention and enhance biomedical technology development.
Kung said the 23 human chromosomes -- the string like cellular structures that contain genes and other DNA sequences -- are made up of millions of chemical subunits called bases.

Chromosomes play a critical role in human health, Kung said, adding that some scientists have linked genetic chromosome mutations to more than 350 human diseases and that the structural alterations of chromosomes are believed to be factors that cause a variety of mental retardation syndromes.
The MMPCF, established in 2002 with funding from the National Science Council, is one of the major laboratories of this kind in the world.

Kung said the laboratory welcomes visits by groups of visitors, especially students, adding that students will see some real experimental mutant mice at the laboratory with explanations from professional lecturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wholesale vegetable prices to drop by weekend: COA

TEXT.P: Wholesale vegetable prices are expected to fall to NT$50 (US$1.53) per kilogram by the end of this week, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Su Jia-chyuan said Wednesday.

In response to inquires by lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan on increasing prices of necessities that has raised public outcry, Su said that post-typhoon farmland rehabilitation has been carried out for weeks and harvest time is approaching.
If prices do not drop this week, it will mean something has gone wrong with the rehabilitation, Su said, adding that the COA will try to resolve such problems if they occur.

Underlining that it is the COA's duty to stabilize the market by offering abundant supplies while caring for farmers interests, Su said that if the council fails in promoting farmland rehabilitation, he will shoulder the responsibility and accept that he is incompetent.

COA Director of Agriculture and Food Agency Huang Yu-tsai also said he is confident that vegetable prices will drop by the end of the week, attributing the wave of price hikes to typhoon damage over the past two months.

Huang said supplies of green leafy vegetables are growing but added that the market is still short of Chinese cabbage, white radish, tomatoes and sweet peppers because it takes longer to restore these crops.
According to the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co., the wholesale vegetable price in the Taipei area for Tuesday was NT$50.91 per kilo, cheaper than Monday's NT$52.6.

Meanwhile, major supermarket chains Carrefour, RT-Mart and Geant, introduced discount vegetables in their stores Wednesday to lure consumers, with prices for leafy products ranging from between NT$9 and NT$30 per bunch.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to launch domestically developed satellites by 2010: NSC head

TEXT.P: Taiwan looks forward to launching its own domestically developed satellites with locally made launch vehicles by 2010, the head of the National Science Council (NSC) said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, NSC Chairman Chen Chien-jen confirmed that the council has been striving to make progress in the research and development of satellite launch vehicles in the hope that Taiwan will be able to venture into space with its own satellites launched with its own launch vehicles in less than three years.
Chen also solicited vital support from the legislators for financial aid to facilitate a launch vehicle R&D project.

Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao expressed concern at the legislative session that Taiwan's weather satellite FORMOSAT-3 is having trouble functioning, while the revenue generated by FORMOSAT-2 is not cost- efficient.
Chen confirmed that one of the six micro-satellites of FORMOSAT-3 has lost contact and two micro-satellites appear to have lost function, but he added that "it's no big deal."

Meanwhile, Chen supported his argument by confirming that despite partial malfunction, FORMOSAT-3 has been working effectively in offering constant observation data on the stratospheric temperature gradient over Antarctica, providing valuable temperature and humidity information to the Central Weather Bureau and other agencies.

FORMOSAT-3 is supposed to collect information from 1,800 "points of observation, " Chen said, adding that due to the malfunctions, FORMOSAT-3 has been monitoring weather conditions by collecting information from 1,600 points, fulfilling 90 percent of its duties.
On concern that FORMOSA-2 is not cost-efficient, the NSC chief said FORMOSAT-2 is a scientific research satellite that is not designed to be a money-making venture.
Instead, he said, FORMOSAT-2, which also observes the global weather conditions through GPS signals, offers valuable information and pre-warnings about the potential of mudslides on Taiwan.
The FORMOSAT-2 warning system has significantly helped the government and the people prevent or lessen damage caused by mudslides, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exclusion from U.N. impedes Taiwan's development: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that the exclusion of Taiwan from the United Nations has denied Taiwan access to important international information and has seriously impeded the country's overall development.

Delivering a speech at Yuan Ze University in Taoyuan County, Lu noted that Taiwan cannot become a signatory of many international treaties because it is not a member of the United Nations, but said that the country is nevertheless required to abide by these treaties.
According to Lu, Taiwan cannot determine its own fate at many crossroads in history and the people of Taiwan are often victims of international treaties that they cannot participate in.

Lu divided the history of the Republic of China into four phases: the Republic of China in China, the Republic of China's move to Taiwan, the Republic of China on Taiwan, and the Republic of China as Taiwan.
Lu said the mistaken decision by the late President Chiang Kai-shek to have the ROC withdraw from the United Nations in 1971 was responsible for the predicament faced by Taiwan today.

While the country has tried since 1993 to get the United Nations to consider the issue of its representation, this year marks the first time it has applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan. However, as on previous occasions, the issue of Taiwan's membership application was excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.
