DOC.HEADLINE: CTSP offers round-the-clock customs clearance services

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park (CTSP) -- Taiwan's third major science-based industrial park -- now offers round-the-clock customs clearance services to further facilitate the park's global business and manufacturing operations, CTSP officials said Wednesday.

The CTSP administration has helped establish a logistics center at the park, where upstream and downstream supply chains can work efficiently with domestic manufacturers operating in the park, who in turn are able to speed up processing operations and delivery of finished goods for export, the officials said.

The CTSP logistics center is considered more efficient than traditional bonded warehouses, as companies in the park can not only enjoy 24-hour customs clearance services but can also operate bonded warehouse business, transshipment, distribution, goods repackaging and quick processing operations in the park prior to re-exporting, the officials went on.
The CTSP logistics center is the second of its kind in Taiwan following the establishment of one in the Southern Taiwan Science Park several years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: South-relocated fisheries agency to formally re-open Oct. 29

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture (COA) is scheduled to reopen Oct. 29 at its new headquarters in the southern port city of Kaohsiung after having completed its relocation from Taipei to the south two days ago, COA Vice Minister Lee Chien-chuan said Wednesday.

The agency is the first government unit to relocate to southern Taiwan from the north after the issue of the relocation of government agencies was brought up earlier this year as part of efforts to balance the development of the north and south of the country.

At a press conference following a routine Executive Yuan meeting, Lee said the new Fisheries Agency will be situated in the Ocean-Going Fisheries Development Center located in Kaohsiung's Chienchen Fishing Port complex.

To maintain services to fishery operators in the north of the country, Lee said, the agency will set up a northern Taiwan branch office in the near future, adding that the Executive Yuan has adopted a draft amendment to the agency's organic regulations approving the planned facility's establishment.

Under the draft bill, the Kaohsiung-based Taiwan Area Fishery Radio Station will be transformed into the agency's internal organ from an outpost unit, with its functions expanded to cover the integration of fishery communication systems around the country, the construction of a complete fishing boat monitoring mechanism, the implementation of dynamic management of the nation's fishery sector and the maintenance of the safety of fishing boats in operation, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hospital uses new technique to excise fibroids

TEXT.P: Taipei Medical University Hospital (TMUH) has successfully used new techniques to excise uterine fibroids during a cesarean section delivery, the director of the TMUH Obstetrics and Gynecology Department announced Wednesday.
The excised fibroid weighed 3.8 kg, making it bigger and heavier than the baby, who weighed only about 2.8 kg, said Liu Wei-min.
Liu said the patient was diagnosed in March with a uterine fibroid 30 cm long, which at first misled him to estimating the patient as being in her 25th week of pregnancy.

Liu said he first delivered the baby, ligated the uterine arteries to prevent massive hemorrhage, which is very likely to happen to a pregnant woman during the operation, and then removed the fibroid. The patient's womb was stitched back to its normal size at the end of the operation, Liu added.

Traditional treatment for pregnant women with uterine fibroids requires a wait for more than six months after the birth before surgery, in order to avoid massive hemorrhage and imperfect stitching, Liu said, adding that the traditional treatment not only wastes medical resources but also causes fatigue for the patient.
The new technique does not affect the patient's future pregnancies or deliveries and removes the necessity of doing a second operation, Liu said.
According to Liu, about one-third of women over 30 can have uterine fibroids, and about 0.05 percent to 5 precent of women might have fibroids during pregnancy.

A fibroid that poses no threat to the fetus can be taken care of after delivery, but one that is considered dangerous to the fetus or which causes anemia for the patient should be removed before pregnancy, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan moving ahead at high speed: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan is not dragging its feet but is "moving forward at a galloping speed of 300 kph."

The president was referring to the speed of the high speed train when he attended a ceremony sponsored by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), builder of the bullet train, to express appreciation for those who took part in planning and constructing the railway. The day was chosen because the northern and southern parts of the original rail system in western Taiwan were connected Oct. 24, 1908.
The president also used the occasion to tout Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and to pan Hsieh's rival, Ma Ying- jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang.

Chen said that during Hsieh's term as premier between 2005 and 2006, he helped bail out the cash-strapped THSRC to enable it to complete the 345-km railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south.

He touted Hsieh's resolve, saying that the high speed railway is a major development project and that if Hsieh had chosen to keep his distance and leave the financial problem to the THSRC, the public would not be able to enjoy the convenience of the system today.
"The public will return justice to Hsieh, " he predicted, referring to Hsieh's controversial use of government-affiliated foundations to bail out the THSRC.

Chen noted that people have recently been saying that "Taiwan is dragging its feet, " but he claimed that if they have the opportunity to board the bullet train, they will witness Taiwan's progress and development.
He said that conducting smear campaigns and "belittling Taiwan" will not be "a boost to oneself, " an apparent oblique reference to Ma.
Chen urged a "gentlemen's battle" in the 2008 presidential election and asked that "all trading of barbs" be ended.
He also described THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing as an "iron lady, " praising her resilience and saying that she was only criticized because she once was a "member of his advisory group."

The multimillion-dollar high speed railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project built under the BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula in which private investors build the system and will return control of the project to the government after a specified period of operation.

Hsieh helped the cash-strapped THSRC over financial difficulties by instructing two government-affiliated foundations -- the China Aviation Development Fund (CADF) and the China Technical Consultant Inc. (CTCI) -- to invest NT$7.5 billion in the project in 2005.
The THSRC was able to resolve its financial problems after the government bailout.

According to THSRC tallies, the company's founders (or original shareholders) hold a 28.52 percent stake, the government and state-owned enterprises jointly control an 11.89 percent stake, foreign institutional investors hold a 3.34 percent stake, other institutional shareholders -- including the CADF and the CTCI - control a 41.25 percent stake and individual investors have a 15 percent stake.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: of a new partnership agreement between Moscow and Brussels, officials said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet meeting turned down Tuesday a draft bill on social order and security which would introduce a package of new measures against criminalities. There were too many different opinions on the issue, Minister of Social Solidarity Paolo Ferrero said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG A levels face axe in favour of diplomas A levels could be scrapped within six years and replaced by work-based diplomas, under the biggest exams shake-up in 20 years, the Government announced yesterday. Ed Balls, the Schools Secretary, refused to guarantee the future of the exam in a reversal of the position taken by the Blair Government. He said that the diplomas could become the jewel in the crown of the education system.

DOC.HEADLINE: 24,700 cases of wiretapping from January to September: MOJ

TEXT.P: The investigation authorities have resorted to wiretapping in 24,700 cases in the first nine months of this year, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Wednesday.

The cases, 70 percent of which involved drug-related criminal activities, include those handled by the Coast Guard Administration, the Bureau of Investigation, the National Police Agency and prosecutors, Shih said.

He made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Judiciary Committee when he was asked to comment on a claim by a political commentator on a TV talk show that 4 million people are currently being wiretapped by the authorities.

Shih said he had no idea where the commentator got his figure from, but he pointed out that the Supreme Prosecutors Office has established a complete monitoring mechanism to prevent the authorities from abusing their authority to wiretap.
On the cases handled by the Bureau of Investigation, bureau Director Yeh Sheng- mao said the bureau carried out 49,000 wiretapping missions during the first nine months of this year.
Yeh explained that as the authorities are required to renew their applications for wiretapping every month, many of the reported taps were actually simply extensions of existing wiretaps.
The number of cases in which wiretapping is still going on totals 5,500, according to Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police seize counterfeit sportswear imported from China

TEXT.P: Police seized 600 pairs of counterfeit sports shoes and 300 sports shirts imported from China and arrested a suspect surnamed Lai in a raid in central Taiwan, Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials reported Wednesday.
The officials said they were patrolling the Internet when they came across a Web site selling brand-name sports shoes at one-third of the normal price.

They contacted police in Taichung County who investigated the matter and raided two warehouses where they discovered the counterfeit Puma, Adidas and Nike sports shoes and shirts in Taiping and Wufeng villages in Taichung county.

Lai told police he got acquainted with a counterfeit ring in Guangzhou in southeastern China three years ago and began to collaborate with them. They ran ads on an overseas Web site to evade police detection.
He said the counterfeit products were imported at a price of between NT$200 and NT$300 (US$6.06-US$9.09) but sold for between NT$1,000 and NT$2,000.

He admitted that he had sold nearly 10,000 items, but claimed to have a monthly income of between just NT$20,000 and NT$30,000, with the lion's share of the huge profits going to the counterfeit ring in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Export orders for September hit single-month high: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders received in September amounted to US$30.92 billion, setting a single-month record and marking an increase of 16.10 percent from the year-earlier level, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.
The amount was high because September is the traditional peak season for export orders and also because of high demand from European and Asian markets.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's export orders from January to September were worth US$250.7 billion, an increase of 14.78 percent over the same period of last year, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Terry Fox Run set for Nov. 11 in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2007 Terry Fox Run for cancer research is slated to kick off Nov. 11 at the Taipei City Hall plaza, an event organizer announced Wednesday at a news conference.

The event is now entering its 13th year in Taiwan and is aimed at raising public awareness of the importance of cancer prevention and treatment, according to Liang Yung-fei, chief of the Taipei Sports Office under the Taipei City Department of Education.
Noting that he lost 10 kg through jogging and keeps healthy by maintaining good exercise habits, Lian said he knows a lot about the benefits of running.

He added that Chang Gung Memorial Hospital donates 40,000 T-shirts to be used for the event every year and that this year the hospital held the 10th Terry Fox Cancer Research Symposium Oct. 6 in the hope of incorporating the concept of exercise into cancer prevention practice.

On the same occasion, liver transplant recipient Hu Yu-wang also advocated physical exercise to keep healthy, saying that he relapsed repeatedly during the initial period after surgery, but through exercising, his health has improved and is now almost back to normal.

In addition to the road run, the city government will also set up a consultation booth and hold a series of activities and performances, while giving away a variety of gifts through lot-drawing to promote knowledge of cancer prevention.

The Terry Fox Run is an international charity event supporting cancer research that was launched by Canadian cancer activist Terry Fox, who was an outstanding athlete before being diagnosed with osteogenic sarcoma, a rare bone cancer, at the age of 18.

Fox had his right leg amputated and was so moved by the suffering of cancer patients he saw while he was in the hospital that he decided to run across Canada to raise money for cancer research. He died aged just 23.
To date, more than US$400 million has been raised worldwide for cancer research in Fox's name through the annual Terry Fox Run.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Ruling bloc to let Moriya testify over Yamada links
Facing mounting calls from the opposition camp, the ruling bloc said Tuesday it will allow ex-Vice Defense Minister Takemasa Moriya to testify under oath in the Diet over his alleged dubious ties to defense equipment trader Yamada Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan Air Base to hold open day Oct. 27

TEXT.P: The Tainan Air Force Base will hold an open day Oct. 27 to allow the public to view the aircraft and weapons used by the Air Force and to watch an air display by a range of jet fighters.

The open day will run from 9 a.m. until 3:30 p.m. As Tainan Airport is located on the base, which serves both military and civil functions, officials at the Tainan Police Bureau cautioned passengers trying to catch flights that day to get to the airport early to avoid traffic congestion.

According to the Air Force, in addition to a performance by a skydiving team, there will be fly-pasts by a range of fighters, including the F-16, the F-5, the Mirage 2000 and the Indigenous Defense Fighter.

The planes will also be on display on the ground, along with other aircraft such as the Cobra AH-1H attack helicopter, the OH-58D Kiowa Warrior reconnaissance- attack helicopter, the UH-1H helicopter, and the B-234 helicopter.
Also on display will be 40 mm anti-aircraft cannon, .50 caliber machine guns, and a variety of military and special purpose vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head calls for debate with opposition on defense budget cuts

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, who is also chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , called Wednesday for debate with the opposition parties on defense budget cuts.

Chen made the appeal at a meeting of the DPP's Central Executive Committee after the opposition parties recently slashed the whole research and development budget for the military to develop the country's own advanced weapons.

Chen instructed the DPP legislative caucus to endeavor to have the budget reinstated. He said if this does not happen, he will ask for a public debate with the opposition parties on the issue of whether the country needs defenses.

Noting that Beijing had deployed some 200 missiles targeting Taiwan by 2000 when he became president, Chen said the number of missiles has now increased to 988. China's military spending has seen double-digit growth during the past 18 years since the Tiananmen massacre in Beijing in 1989, Chen added.

However, he went on, Taiwan's arms purchase plan and several military projects have lagged behind schedule due to boycotts by the opposition, and he lamented that the military's R&D budget for weaponry development is again being blocked by the opposition.
Chen said a debate on the issue with the opposition might allow the public to get a better understanding of who is the real defender of Taiwan and who is standing on China's side.

DOC.HEADLINE: German professor advocates `cradle to cradle' design

TEXT.P: Rather than the traditional linear method of production, consumption and recycling, a different approach that makes products economically successful, healthy for users and supportive for the environment and future generations is making its mark, visiting German professor Michael Braungart said Wednesday.

Braungart, a chemistry professor and entrepreneur, is scheduled to conduct two workshops on the "Cradle to Cradle Design" idea during his stay in Taiwan, which is being organized by the German Culture Center.

"Instead of being less bad, we can be good, " is how Braungart sums up his concept, on which he collaborated with U.S. architect William McDonough and which calls for the transformation of human industry through ecologically intelligent design.
Braungart's idea is a "wake-up call" to mankind, said German Culture Center Director Jurgen Gerbig.

The design advocates two types of products that can be conducted safely, either as "products for consumption," into biological systems or as "products for service, " into technical systems for future product generations.

Products can be used, recycled, and used again without losing any material quality in the "cradle to cradle cycle, " he said. It's called "cradle to cradle" because the whole process is different from the traditional product cycle of "cradle to grave."

"The design is not all about the environment. It's first about human rights, " said the former environmental protection activist, who added that "it's not about overpopulation or the ethical problem unlike what former U.S. Vice President Al Gore has said."
What the world has been doing is reducing greenhouse gas emissions and advocating recycling, but this is like "asking you to beat your children less often, " according to Braungart.

There are more than 600 products with zero pollution on the market using the design process, Braungart said. An international congress and exhibition will be held in Frankfurt, Germany Nov. 12-14, 2008, showcasing 2,000-3,000 "cradle to cradle" products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker calls for Suao-Hualien Freeway construction

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Wednesday urged residents of Hualien, in eastern Taiwan, to each post a letter to the government commission evaluating the environmental impact of construction of the proposed Suao-Hualien freeway.

Lu Po-chi, representing Hualien County, launched the "one man, one letter" campaign in the eastern county earlier in the day, calling on locals to convey their urgent need for the long planned new road and to push the commission affiliated with the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to give the green light to the project on the basis of "humanitarian concerns."

Lu said the EPA environmental evaluation commission is scheduled to review a report on the environmental impact of the planned Suao-Hualien freeway on the first day of November. He will take part in that meeting, at which he will propose a plan to build the controversial freeway in several stages, Lu added.

Citing a report by Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei to the legislative Committee on Transportation in April, Lu indicated that the existing Suao-Hualien highway -- the only road connecting Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan with the north -- was severed 84 times during the years 1994 - 2006, and caused many fatal motor accidents.
Additionally, in the 2001-2006 period, 133 traffic accidents occurred on the highway built along a cliff on the northeastern coast, causing 142 deaths and 38 injuries, the report showed.
"Road safety is the most humble request and wish of Hualien residents, " the lawmaker said, underlining the importance of a "safe and reliable" Suao-Hualien freeway to Hualien's citizens.

Under regulations governing the environmental impact study, construction of the planned Suao-Hualien freeway, which won a construction permit from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications Dec. 27, 2002, cannot take place before the EPA completes its review of the environmental analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65.5% of Halloween toys bear substandard labels

TEXT.P: A total of 57 Halloween toys or 65.5 percent of the 87 samples inspected by the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection were found to have substandard Chinese labels, an economic official said Wednesday.

Wang Cheng-huei, deputy director of the bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the bureau collected 87 samples from department stores and toy shops such as Toys 'R' Us for safety inspection. Of those toys, 69 were made in China, 12 were made in Taiwan, while the others gave no indication of their origins.

The bureau proceeded to inspect the products' flammability, heavy metals concentrations, hazardous sharp points, small detachable parts, and Chinese labels, and discovered that two samples failed flammability tests, one failed a sharp point test, and three used substandard packing materials.

Wang explained that packaging for toys should be of a certain thickness to prevent accidents when children play with the materials. He added that ropes or cords attached to toys should not be longer than 30 cm in order to safeguard children from becoming entangled.

The bureau has already asked the companies concerned to remove toys which failed the flammability, hazardous sharp point, and packing bag thickness tests, and to improve Chinese labels within a specific time limit, the official said. He added that parents should be aware of such hazards when choosing Halloween toys for their kids.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local mutual funds allowed to invest in Chinese stocks

TEXT.P: Mutual funds issued by Taiwan-based securities investment and trust companies will be permitted to invest in Chinese stocks, the Executive Yuan decided Wednesday during its weekly meeting.

The first-ever opening allows mutual funds issued by local securities investment and trust companies to invest in Chinese stocks as well as the China- incorporated "red-chip" and "H" shares issued by Hong Kong-based Chinese enterprises on the Hong Kong and Macau bourses up to a level of 0.4 percent and 10 percent, respectively, of their overall net asset values -- the same cap set for offshore funds on sales in Taiwan since Jan. 31, 2005.

The opening will allow Taiwan-issued mutual funds to compete with foreign-issued mutual funds on an equal footing -- removing the cause of a longstanding complaint of local securities investment and trust companies which were previously banned from investing in the Shanghai and Shenzhen bourses or in China's red-chip stocks listed on the Hong Kong and Macau stock markets.

Vicky Hsiao, secretary-general of the Securities Investment Trust & Consulting Association (SITCA) of the ROC, hailed the government's removal of the ban as a long-expected boon for the domestic sector and called for a wider opening.

Differential treatment in the past has put Taiwanese companies at a great disadvantage in courting clients and has hardly been effective in warding off capital outflows or helping local companies upgrade their operations, she said.

On the contrary, the opening will help the government better manage securities and investment companies and collect more taxes from them, she said, adding that the domestic mutual fund sector cannot exclude China if it hopes to be more competitive in global markets.

According to SITCA estimates, as much as NT$40 billion (US$1.23 billion) worth of investment capital managed by some 15 so-called "China-concept" or "greater China" local mutual funds will be permitted to enter the Chinese bourse and purchase "red-chip" and "H" shares listed on the Hong Kong and Macao stock markets.

However, local fund managers said they would not rush to rashly allocate further funds to the purchase of Chinese or Hong Kong stocks out of fear that these markets might undergo a downward correction after reaching historic highs in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to continue investigations of political assassinations

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration will continue investigating political assassinations that occurred during Taiwan's infamous martial law era.

At a meeting of the DPP's Central Executive Committee, Chen, who also serves as DPP's chairman, stressed that the government will continue the investigations into several high-profile murder cases during the Kuomintang's (KMT's) authoritarian rule in response to popular demands for a true historical account and transitional justice.

Chen was referring to the murders of Chinese-American writer Henry Liu, Chen Wen-cheng, and members of Lin I-hsiung's family -- all members of the pro- democracy elite or critics of then-president Chiang Ching-kuo -- during the 1980s. Lin was a former DPP chairman.

Recently, an action movie star, Jimmy Wang, revealed in an interview that a KMT official once tried to hire him to assassinate another former DPP chairman, Hsu Hsin-liang, when Hsu fled to the United States to evade the KMT's crackdown on pro-democracy activists. Wang said he did not carry out the murder as he did not obtain a written contract from the KMT.

The assassination of Liu was carried out by members of Taiwan's underworld Bamboo Union gang, including its spiritual leader Chen Chi-li, who was released after being imprisoned for the murder for six years. In 1996, he fled to Cambodia to evade imprisonment for participating in organized crime. Chen Chi-li died recently in Hong Kong and his corpse was sent back to Taiwan last week.

The news of Chen Chi-li's death and his funeral in Taipei were featured in the headlines of some local media outlets, for which they were criticized by President Chen, who expressed discontent that anyone in the media would treat Chen Chi-li as a hero.

Noting that Taiwan is a country ruled by law, President Chen said his administration will never allow collusion between political parties and gangs nor provocation by gangsters against the government.

In consideration of the approaching of legislative and presidential elections early next year, Chen asked the Cabinet and law enforcement authorities to step up its crackdown on organized crime to provide the people with a peaceful living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ Administration approves 11 investment projects

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone (EPZ) Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has approved 11 investment projects worth NT$838 million (US$25.64 million) so far this month, an economic official said Wednesday.
The investment projects are expected to create more than 300 job opportunities, the official said.

Four of the 11 projects will be located in the Kaohsiung Software Technology Park in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, including investments in three companies in the technology industry and one in maritime transportation service.
The figure shows that investors are optimistic about the development of the park, the official said.

The Chungkang Export Processing Zone in Taichung County in central Taiwan as well as the Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone and the Linkuang Export Processing Zone in Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, each received two investment projects, the official said.
Meanwhile, the official said the Pingtung Export Processing Zone in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan received one investment project from a producer of laboratory equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier recommends 'travel in Taiwan' for youth

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chung-hsiung endorsed Wednesday a "Youth Travel in Taiwan" program launched by the Cabinet- level National Youth Commission (NYC) , hailing it as an effective means to present Taiwan's beauty and uniqueness to the youth, both foreign and local.
Chang made the comments after being briefed by NYC officials on the program during a weekly Cabinet meeting.
According to Chang, it is worthwhile for the government to further develop the program as it has enjoyed initial success after being initiated two years ago.

The program will not only help foreign and local youth come to know Taiwan's culture and nature in depth, but could also help promote related businesses, Chang said, adding that the program is of great importance in selling Taiwan's tourism both at home and abroad.

The premier gave his full backing to the program and asked relevant agencies, such as the NYC, the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, to better coordinate with the private sector to further polish the country's international image.

DOC.HEADLINE: This year's fullest moon to occur Oct. 26: astronomers

TEXT.P: The fullest moon of this year will appear Friday night, astronomers in Taipei pointed out Wednesday.

Astronomers at the Taipei Astronomical Museum said the moon will become full at 12:52 p.m. Oct. 26, and that at 8 p.m. members of the public will be able to look east at a 35-degree angle to view the fullest moon of 2007. At that time the Moon will reach the closest point of its orbit around Earth.
They explained that Friday's moon will be 14 percent larger than the smallest full moon of this year, seen April 3 when the moon was farthest from Earth.
The full moon this Friday is also expected to be 30 percent brighter than lesser full moons seen earlier in the year.

The average distance between the Earth and the Moon is 382,500 km. According to astronomers, the distance varies because the moon travels around Earth in an elliptical orbit. At perigee -- the closest point -- the moon is approximately 360,000 km from Earth. At apogee -- its farthest point from Earth -- the distance is approximately 405,000 km.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show opens

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show (TITAS) opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Wednesday, with 350 Taiwan and foreign suppliers showcasing their latest innovative, functional textile products in 650 booths.

The annual exhibition -- Taiwan's foremost textile trade show -- is jointly organized by two semi-official organizations: the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF).
The show last year attracted more than 18,000 buyers from 44 countries, including 2,113 buyers from abroad.

The 2007 exhibition will run for three days until Oct. 26 alongside the annual meeting of the International Apparel Federation (IAF), which focuses on the theme "Asia -- from a global production base to an emerging consumer market."
The meeting has brought together hundreds of apparel suppliers from around the world and is expected to create many business opportunities for exhibitors at the TITAS show.
The current IAF membership includes apparel associations from 32 countries representing over 150,000 companies that provide products and services to the apparel industry.

The range of products on display at the exhibition include yarns, fabrics, functional textile products, apparel accessories and peripheral products, with many Taiwanese exhibitors presenting their newly developed, innovative textile products.
Organizers said the 2007 TITAS show continues to stress not only the functionality of the products, but also their fashionableness.
They said that Taiwan's functional textile suppliers will use the opportunity to form partnerships with international buyers and provide them with full package services.

Taiwan is among the world's leading suppliers of functional textiles. The TTF and Taiwan's major manufacturers have developed a Taiwanese functional textiles certification and labeling system to help consumers identify guaranteed quality products. The label has been registered in Taiwan, the United States, the European Union, Japan and China.

Currently there are 13 categories within Taiwan's functional textile certification system: wrinkle-free textiles, oil-repellent textiles, water- repellent textiles, flame-resistant textiles, anti-static textiles, far- infrared textiles, moisture-absorbing and quick-drying textiles, stain-release textiles, sun-protective textiles, electromagnetic-shielding textiles, breathable-waterproof textiles, anti-bacterial textiles for medical use and anti-bacterial textiles for apparel and home use.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hog prices expected to gradually rebound: COA

TEXT.P: Local hog prices will gradually rebound later this year, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Wednesday.

Chu Ching-cheng, a COA division chief in charge of livestock industry affairs, made the remarks after a ruling party lawmaker urged the government to pay heed to the plight of local pig farmers who face a slump in hog prices and skyrocketing prices for feed corn.

Speaking in a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Yen Wen-chang said the average hog price has dropped from NT$6,124 (US$188) per kilogram to NT$5,013 in the past two months, while the price for feed corn more than doubled to NT$ 5.5 per kilogram. At these prices, farmers are set to lose NT$3,000 in production costs for each pig raised for sale, he pointed out.

Should this situation continue, about 60 percent of pig farmers in central and southern Taiwan would be forced to shut down their operations by the end of this year, and related business, including restaurants, food processing and feed factories, would be seriously affected, Yen warned.
He also voiced his suspicion that a vested interest involving importers might be behind the soaring feed prices and urged the government to look into the case and fully address the issue.

Yen suggested that the government purchase substandard agricultural goods and provide them for local hog farmers to feed their animals. The practice will help resolve a glut of some farming products while offsetting the impact of falling hog prices, he added.

In response, Chu said the COA has drawn up a long-term strategy to deal with the issue, and it is expected to help push up hog prices by the middle of next year. The state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation has shown a willingness to release its stock of corn to help hog farmers tackle their feed cost problems, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic fowl breeders urged to be inoculated against avian flu

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) urged domestic fowl breeders and medical care professionals to be vaccinated against avian influenza as the two high risk groups seem to be reluctant to receive inoculation, a senior CDC official said Wednesday.

Citing statistics, CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said the vaccination rate among the elderly, aged 65 and above, has reached 36.5 percent so far this year -- a decline of 5 percent compared with the level of the same period last year.

Senior citizens, children aged between six months and two years of age, professional fowl breeders, and health care professionals are entitled to receive vaccinations against avian flu free of charge.

However, Shih said that only 20 percent of professional fowl breeders in the country have received the vaccination so far this year -- an obvious drop compared with the 60 percent rate in the same period last year -- while the vaccination rate among medical and health care personnel was 67 percent, lower than the 90 percent rate recorded in 2006.

The CDC has found that most professional fowl breeders were not fully aware of the threat posed by avian flu, and that low inoculation rates among medical personnel were due to local governments appropriating those vaccine stocks for use with the elderly and infants, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oct. 24 designated as 'U. N. Day'

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Wednesday that Oct. 24 will be designated as "U.N. Day" for Taiwan to further highlight the country's desire to enter the world body.
According to Chang, it is both mainstream public opinion and an established government policy that the country should pursue full U.N. membership under the name Taiwan.

To further underscore this cause and raise public understanding of its importance, the Executive Yuan decided to set Oct. 24 as "U.N. Day" in Taiwan because the day has been observed worldwide as U.N. Day in commemoration of the entry into force of the U.N. Charter on Oct. 24, 1945, he explained.

Earlier the same day, President Chen Shui-bian kicked off a round-the-nation torch relay in front of the Presidential Office. The torch will pass through 25 cities and counties, including the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, before returning to Taipei Nov. 3 to muster greater public approval for Taiwan's U.N. membership bid.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been engaged in a signature drive and hopes to collect over 2 million signatures endorsing its petition for a referendum on whether the country should join the U.N. under the name Taiwan, which the DPP hopes to hold alongside the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid torch relay reaches Kinmen

TEXT.P: A round-the-nation torch relay initiated by the government to solicit support for the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan arrived on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen Wednesday, the closest it will get to China.

The torch was escorted by a Sports Affairs Council (SAC) official and four athletes of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association (CTRRA) to Kinmen after President Chen Shui-bian led government officials and members of the public at the start of the relay in downtown Taipei early that morning.

After arriving on Kinmen by plane, the torch carriers were joined by only around 10 members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , as Kinmen is a stronghold of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which does not support the DPP's U.N. bid referendum idea.
Welcoming the torch, Chen Tsang-chiang, head of the DPP's Kinmen chapter, said it is the common aspiration of the Taiwanese people to join the international community.

However, he described the KMT's campaign to promote the country's U.N.-membership bid under the country's national title, the Republic of China, as not workable because he said it would mean that the People's Republic of China would have to give up its seat in the world body to Taiwan.
Chen said that only the DPP's campaign to push for the country's U.N. bid under the name Taiwan will succeed and called on Kinmen County citizens to support the government's bid.
Despite the Kinmen county government's refusal to cooperate in organizing the event, the four CTRRA runners ran around the entire island.
When the torch reached the Cihhu dike at Guningtou, there was only 10 km between the torch and the Chinese coastal city of Xiamen, marking the closest the torch will get to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: China should recognize Taiwan's international status: SEF

TEXT.P: China should respect the continued existence of the Republic of China and recognize Taiwan's international status to pave the way for the signing of a peace agreement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the head of a quasi- official intermediary body said Wednesday.

Hung Chi-chang, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the appeal at a seminar held on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen to mark the sixth anniversary of the opening of direct shipping services between Kinmen and three port cities in China's southeastern province of Fujian -- Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou.

Hung said he welcomes Chinese President Hu Jintao's call for an end to cross- strait enmity and the signing of a bilateral peace agreement under the principle of "one China" to ensure lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait. Hu issued his call in a speech delivered at the just-concluded annual congress of the Communist Party of China in Beijing.
Noting that Taiwan's leadership also aspires to forge a stable framework to maintain cross-strait peace, Hung said such a goal can be realized only through bilateral talks on an equal footing.

Against this backdrop, Hung said, China should not insist on its "one China" principle and should instead recognize Taiwan's proper status -- a political entity that exercises sovereignty over Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu. Such a recognition also means China's respect for the uninterrupted existence of the ROC, he added. Should that be the case, he said, the two sides will be able to sit down to talk on the possibility of singing a peace agreement.
The seminar brought together some 100 scholars and experts from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to swap opinions and views on cross-strait matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 25, 2007

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 25, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five- yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.
2001: Government agencies mobilizes over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China should recognize Taiwan's international status: SEF

TEXT.P: China should respect the continued existence of the Republic of China and recognize Taiwan's international status to pave the way for the signing of a peace agreement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the head of a quasi- official intermediary body said Wednesday.

Hung Chi-chang, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the appeal at a seminar held on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen to mark the sixth anniversary of the opening of direct shipping services between Kinmen and three port cities in China's southeastern province of Fujian -- Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou.

Hung said he welcomes Chinese President Hu Jintao's call for an end to cross- strait enmity and the signing of a bilateral peace agreement under the principle of "one China" to ensure lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait. Hu issued his call in a speech delivered at the just-concluded annual congress of the Communist Party of China in Beijing.
Noting that Taiwan's leadership also aspires to forge a stable framework to maintain cross-strait peace, Hung said such a goal can be realized only through bilateral talks on an equal footing.

Against this backdrop, Hung said, China should not insist on its "one China" principle and should instead recognize Taiwan's proper status -- a political entity that exercises sovereignty over Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu. Such a recognition also means China's respect for the uninterrupted existence of the ROC, he added. Should that be the case, he said, the two sides will be able to sit down to talk on the possibility of singing a peace agreement.
The seminar brought together some 100 scholars and experts from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to swap opinions and views on cross-strait matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hog prices expected to gradually rebound: COA

TEXT.P: Local hog prices will gradually rebound later this year, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Wednesday.

Chu Ching-cheng, a COA division chief in charge of livestock industry affairs, made the remarks after a ruling party lawmaker urged the government to pay heed to the plight of local pig farmers who face a slump in hog prices and skyrocketing prices for feed corn.

Speaking in a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Yen Wen-chang said the average hog price has dropped from NT$6,124 (US$188) per kilogram to NT$5,013 in the past two months, while the price for feed corn more than doubled to NT$ 5.5 per kilogram. At these prices, farmers are set to lose NT$3,000 in production costs for each pig raised for sale, he pointed out.

Should this situation continue, about 60 percent of pig farmers in central and southern Taiwan would be forced to shut down their operations by the end of this year, and related business, including restaurants, food processing and feed factories, would be seriously affected, Yen warned.
He also voiced his suspicion that a vested interest involving importers might be behind the soaring feed prices and urged the government to look into the case and fully address the issue.

Yen suggested that the government purchase substandard agricultural goods and provide them for local hog farmers to feed their animals. The practice will help resolve a glut of some farming products while offsetting the impact of falling hog prices, he added.

In response, Chu said the COA has drawn up a long-term strategy to deal with the issue, and it is expected to help push up hog prices by the middle of next year. The state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation has shown a willingness to release its stock of corn to help hog farmers tackle their feed cost problems, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show opens

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show (TITAS) opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Wednesday, with 350 Taiwan and foreign suppliers showcasing their latest innovative, functional textile products in 650 booths.

The annual exhibition -- Taiwan's foremost textile trade show -- is jointly organized by two semi-official organizations: the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF).
The show last year attracted more than 18,000 buyers from 44 countries, including 2,113 buyers from abroad.

The 2007 exhibition will run for three days until Oct. 26 alongside the annual meeting of the International Apparel Federation (IAF), which focuses on the theme "Asia -- from a global production base to an emerging consumer market."
The meeting has brought together hundreds of apparel suppliers from around the world and is expected to create many business opportunities for exhibitors at the TITAS show.
The current IAF membership includes apparel associations from 32 countries representing over 150,000 companies that provide products and services to the apparel industry.

The range of products on display at the exhibition include yarns, fabrics, functional textile products, apparel accessories and peripheral products, with many Taiwanese exhibitors presenting their newly developed, innovative textile products.
Organizers said the 2007 TITAS show continues to stress not only the functionality of the products, but also their fashionableness.
They said that Taiwan's functional textile suppliers will use the opportunity to form partnerships with international buyers and provide them with full package services.

Taiwan is among the world's leading suppliers of functional textiles. The TTF and Taiwan's major manufacturers have developed a Taiwanese functional textiles certification and labeling system to help consumers identify guaranteed quality products. The label has been registered in Taiwan, the United States, the European Union, Japan and China.

Currently there are 13 categories within Taiwan's functional textile certification system: wrinkle-free textiles, oil-repellent textiles, water- repellent textiles, flame-resistant textiles, anti-static textiles, far- infrared textiles, moisture-absorbing and quick-drying textiles, stain-release textiles, sun-protective textiles, electromagnetic-shielding textiles, breathable-waterproof textiles, anti-bacterial textiles for medical use and anti-bacterial textiles for apparel and home use.

DOC.HEADLINE: This year's fullest moon to occur Oct. 26: astronomers

TEXT.P: The fullest moon of this year will appear Friday night, astronomers in Taipei pointed out Wednesday.

Astronomers at the Taipei Astronomical Museum said the moon will become full at 12:52 p.m. Oct. 26, and that at 8 p.m. members of the public will be able to look east at a 35-degree angle to view the fullest moon of 2007. At that time the Moon will reach the closest point of its orbit around Earth.
They explained that Friday's moon will be 14 percent larger than the smallest full moon of this year, seen April 3 when the moon was farthest from Earth.
The full moon this Friday is also expected to be 30 percent brighter than lesser full moons seen earlier in the year.

The average distance between the Earth and the Moon is 382,500 km. According to astronomers, the distance varies because the moon travels around Earth in an elliptical orbit. At perigee -- the closest point -- the moon is approximately 360,000 km from Earth. At apogee -- its farthest point from Earth -- the distance is approximately 405,000 km.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA passenger flow down 0.2% year-on-year

TEXT.P: The passenger flow of the Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) amounted to 111.84 million for the first eight months of this year, down a marginal 0.2 percent over the same period of last year, according to a report released Wednesday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The figure compared with a sharp decrease of 23.3 percent in domestic air passenger volume for the eight months to August, which indicates that the domestic airline industry has suffered much greater impact than the traditional railway services since the launch of the high-speed railway early this year, MOTC officials said.

For the January-August period, the TRA's daily passenger flow averaged 460,000, with each passenger traveling an average 53.9 km, down 3.9 percent compared with 56.1 km recorded during the same period of last year, the report shows.

While 72.2 percent of the passengers traveled short distances -- no more than 50 km -- middle-distance passengers (those traveling 50 km -199 km) and long- distance passengers (those traveling more than 200 km) accounted for 23.2 percent and 4.6 percent, respectively.

The figures mark a rise of 1.1 percentage points year-on-year in the ratio of short-distance passengers but a fall of 0.7 percentage points and 0.4 percentage points in the ratios of middle-distance passengers and long-distance passengers, respectively.
The changes indicate that the launch of the high-speed railway has impacted the middle-to-long-distance services of the TRA but not the short-distance services, the report said.
Meanwhile, the report went on, the inauguration of the Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei and the northeastern county of Yilan has resulted in a decrease in the rail passenger flow to Yilan.

For the first eight months of this year, there was a decrease of 12 percent to 14.8 percent in the number of passengers alighting at major stations in Yilan, including Chiaohsi, Yilan, Lotung and Suao, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Program to help underprivileged children to benefit 106,000

TEXT.P: A program to help 5-year-old children from underprivileged families with their pre-school education will benefit 106,000 people rather than the original estimate of 81,000, an education official said Thursday.

Chuang Kuo-jung, secretary-general of the Ministry of Education (MOE), made the remarks one day after a meeting with local government officials to confirm the exact number of families eligible for the government subsidies. The meeting was called after local governments found that the number of applications for the subsidies was greater than expected.
Chuang estimated the total cost of the subsidies will amount to at least NT$2.4 billion (US$72.72 million) per year.

He said the subsidy program was devised because the ministry wanted to lessen the burden on underprivileged families, the thinking being that the parents of 5 -year-olds are mostly aged around 30, have not been in the workforce for long and have comparatively low incomes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT trade barbs over voting format

TEXT.P: A legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is insulting the Taiwan people by saying that the adoption of a "one-stage" voting format will result in chaos.
DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh also suggested printing the presidential candidates and referendum proposals on one ballot "so that the KMT will have no reason to object."

Wang made the remarks one day after 18 mayors and magistrates from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the KMT issued a joint statement that if votes on referendum proposals are held alongside the January legislative and March presidential elections next year, they will follow the previous "two- stage" voting format to ensure the smooth operation of the elections.

"Two-stage" voting format refers to voters receiving presidential election and referendum ballots separately. After casting their presidential ballot in one box, voters will receive a referendum ballot to cast in another box. This method was used in the 2004 presidential election, but many voters chose to leave the polling stations after casting their presidential ballots, without bothering to vote on a referendum held at the same time.

Under the "one-stage" format, two ballots -- presidential and referendum ballots -- are handed out at the same time and voters then cast the two ballots in separate boxes. This format is generally considered to boost the participation rate.
Wang said that the act of the "pan-blue" local chiefs is tantamount to publicly splitting the country.
The remarks that a "one-stage" formula will create chaos or disturbance is also "an intimidation of the Taiwan people and a slight on their judgment," he continued.

The KMT's rhetoric has no basis in either theory or practice, Wang said, pointing out that the KMT is just worried that a DPP-initiated referendum proposal on U.N. membership under the name Taiwan will be passed if there is a high participation rate.

The KMT is hoping the rate will be less than half of the eligible voters so that the proposal will fail, Wang said, adding that this is also the hope of the Communist Party of China, so that it can continue to oppress Taiwan.
"The request by the `pan-blue' city and county chiefs is dancing to China's tune," Wang alleged.

Under the Referendum Law, a proposal will be considered passed if the referendum participation rate exceeds half of all eligible voters and if 50 percent of those who cast ballots vote in favor of the proposal.

In the 2004 presidential election, two proposals initiated by President Chen Shui-bian and put to a referendum -- one on purchasing more missiles to counter the military threat from China, and the other on engaging in dialogue with China -- failed because although 90 percent of those who cast ballots in the referendum voted in favor of the proposals, the participation rate was only 45 percent of all eligible voters.
Meanwhile, Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT's presidential candidate, came to the defense of the 18 pan-blue local chiefs, saying that ensuring the smooth operation of the elections is their duty.

In addition, the KMT's proposal on a referendum on the return to the United Nations under its official name the Republic of China will also be put to a vote, but the KMT has no intention of boycotting or confronting the central government, he continued.

He noted that in the 2004 presidential election when the first national referendum was held, local election commissions suggested to the Central Election Commission (CEC) that the "one-stage" format would create problems and requested a separate handout of the ballots, a proposal the CEC accepted.
The CEC is scheduled to meet Friday to discuss the two voting formats. It is widely expected that the "one-stage" format will be adopted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-China exchanges should not impair Taiwan's security: MOFA

TEXT.P: Military exchanges between the United States and China should not impede Taiwan's security in any way, Ministry of Foreign Affairs deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-bi said Thursday.

Yeh was responding to media reports that U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates will visit China next month. It will be Gates' first trip to China since he assumed the helm at the Pentagon in December 2006.

According to the reports, Washington and Beijing are expected to sign an agreement during Gates' visit on the establishment of a military hotline between their respective defense chiefs. A similar hotline has been in place between senior Taiwanese and U.S. defense officials since 2002.

Asked about the ministry's stance on Gates' planned visit at a regular MOFA news conference, Yeh said the ministry has consistently kept a close watch on developments in U.S.-China military exchanges.

"As is usual, we will closely monitor Washington-Beijing exchanges, including Gates' upcoming trip to China, " Yeh said, adding that the MOFA would also ask the U.S. not to waver in its security commitment to Taiwan because of its military exchanges with China.
Hopefully, Yeh added, the U.S. defense secretary's visit will not result in any detriment to Taiwan's national security or interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate pushes 'wetland bank' concept

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh proposed a "wetland bank" concept Thursday, suggesting that efforts be made to conserve and restore the country's wetlands.

Efforts should be made to systematically research and plan wetland conservation and restoration so that Taiwan's wildlife habitats can be conserved and the sustainable development of wetlands can be secured, Hsieh said.
Some of these efforts could be commissioned to NGO groups, he added.

Noting that conserving the environment is a move reflecting "the power of progress, " Hsieh said Taiwan should seek to link itself to the "global power of progress" and make the nation a stronghold of this concept.

The DPP presidential candidate made the remarks during a ceremony held in Taipei to mark the inauguration of the NGO group Taiwan Ecological Engineering Development Foundation (EEF Taiwan), which is committed to becoming a platform for dialogue and communication between development and conservation interests for the benefit of the sustainable development of the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 31% of bicycle helmets below standard: survey

TEXT.P: Thirty-one percent of bicycle helmets recently surveyed by the Consumers' Foundation are below standard, according to the results of the survey released Thursday.
The survey of 29 locally available bicycle helmets found that six carried substandard labels, three had chin straps that broke easily and one contained no inspection label at all.
Meanwhile, a survey by the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) on the inspection labels of 363 bicycle helmets found 14 to be below standard.
Foundation and bureau officials advised consumers to select products bearing labels to indicate that they have passed inspection by the BSMI when shopping for bicycle helmets.
Also, consumers should replace helmets that have suffered any impact or are damaged, they said.

Results of a study conducted last year by the Taipei Medical University for the Bureau of Health Promotion show that between 1999 and 2002, an average 3,700 people were injured every year while riding a bicycle.
Minor cuts and bone fractures accounted for the majority of the injuries, with the death rate for bicycle accidents registering between 3 percent and 5 percent, according to the results.
The results mean that at least 10 people were injured per day while riding a bicycle and that one person died in a bicycle accident every two days on average during the survey period.
According to the results, all of those killed were not wearing helmets at the time of the accidents, which made them vulnerable to fatal neck or head injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 141 points to close at 9,598, with 42,192 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December gained 138 points to finish at 9,594, with 307 contracts traded, while March futures rose 105 points to close at 9,604, with eight contract transactions. Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

November TE futures rose 6.65 points to close at 400.5, with 3,609 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained seven points to finish at 400.3, with 12 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 4.9 points to close at 398.9, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices soar on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 125.64 points to close at 9,568.26.
The bourse opened at 9,546.85 and fluctuated between 9,573.29 and 9,503.83 during trading. A total of 4.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$136.34 billion (US$4.19 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down 0.2 percent and textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both decreasing 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers, more than 1,000 to 856, with 275 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president to drum up support for TSU legislative candidates

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will attend an evening rally in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Friday to drum up support for candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the coming legislative elections, TSU Chairman Huang Kun-hui said Thursday.
Huang made the remarks as he accompanied three TSU legislative candidates to a temple to pray for victory in the January elections.

Huang noted that faced with the new "single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system and a streamlined legislature, which is generally considered to favor the major parties over the smaller ones, the TSU expects a tough battle to ensure its continued existence.
The TSU will hold four rallies around the country in the hope of "rekindling the passion for the TSU," he said.

He urged the public to vote for TSU candidates for three reasons, claiming that the party is the only party in the legislature that guards the interests of the Taiwan people, that the party can serve as a crucial force between the two main rival parties and that it can play a middle-to-left role that takes care of the underprivileged.

He admitted that the party has recently met with figures from the private sector, including business tycoon Winston Wang, chairman of the Grace THW Group, to exchange views on how to join hands with a so-called "third force" to solidify the "indigenous" political parties.
He noted that Lee, the "spiritual leader" of the TSU, has repeatedly said that the political landscape in Taiwan should move from pro-independence vs. pro- unification to two "indigenous" parties.
In addition to the DPP, there should be another "indigenous" party, Huang quoted Lee as saying.
Huang also said there are eight out of 73 regional constituencies in which both the DPP and the TSU have fielded candidates.
He said the DPP and the TSU must coordinate and field only one candidate in these constituencies to avoid letting the KMT benefit by playing off one party against the other.
He proposed coordination between the two parties and said that if that fails, public opinion polls should have the final say on who should run.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments have no say on voting format: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that local governments have no say in the voting format for the coming legislative and presidential elections.

The president made the remarks one day after 18 mayors and magistrates from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the main opposition Kuomintang issued a joint statement that if votes on referendum proposals are held alongside the January legislative and March presidential elections next year, they will follow the previous "two-stage" voting format "to ensure the smooth operation of the elections."

Chen pointed out, however, that the Central Election Commission, which will meet Friday to discuss whether to adopt the "one-stage" or "two-stage" voting formats for the coming elections, will not be considering local but national elections.

"Local governments have no power to decide the format, " Chen said, adding that if cities and counties fail to follow the voting format passed by the CEC, then it will be a "one country, two systems" situation.
The CEC, comprised mostly of pro-DPP members, is widely expected to pass the "one-stage" voting format.

A referendum proposal initiated by the DPP to retrieve ill-gotten assets amassed by the KMT during its five decades of rule of Taiwan and another one initiated by the KMT on opposing corruption will be put to a vote in conjunction with the legislative election.

The DPP also plans another referendum on a proposal to bid for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan to be held in tandem with the presidential election, while the KMT plans a referendum on a proposal to return to the world body under its official name, the Republic of China, or any other "pragmatic name" on the same date.

The "two-stage" voting format refers to voters receiving presidential election and referendum ballots separately. After casting their presidential ballot in one box, voters will receive a referendum ballot to cast in another box. This method was used in the 2004 presidential election, but many voters chose to leave the polling stations after casting their presidential ballots, without bothering to vote on a referendum held at the same time.

Under the "one-stage" format, two ballots -- presidential and referendum ballots -- are handed out at the same time and voters then cast the two ballots in separate boxes. This format is generally considered to boost the participation rate.

Under the Referendum Law, a proposal will be considered passed if the referendum participation rate exceeds half of all eligible voters and if 50 percent of those who cast ballots vote in favor of the proposal.

In the 2004 presidential election, two proposals initiated by President Chen Shui-bian and put to a referendum -- one on purchasing more missiles to counter the military threat from China, and the other on engaging in dialogue with China -- failed because although 90 percent of those who cast ballots in the referendum voted in favor of the proposals, the participation rate was only 45 percent of all eligible voters.
