DOC.HEADLINE: Export orders for first 3 quarters up 14.78%

TEXT.P: Export orders received by local companies during the first three quarters of this year amounted to US$250.7 billion, marking a 14.78 percent growth over the same period of last year, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Thursday.

Of the figure, US$66.12 billion comprised orders from Hong Kong, which included those from China, up 20.05 percent over last year, said Huang Ji-shih, director- general of the MOEA's Department of Statistics.

He added that US$61.86 billion was made up of orders from America, representing an annual growth rate of 5.81 percent, and US$44.76 billion was for orders from Europe, an increase of 26.04 percent from the year-earlier level.

Export orders received in September above amounted to US$30.92 billion, setting a single-month high and marking an increase of 16.1 percent over last year. Of this figure, orders from Hong Kong, including those from China, reached US$8.46 billion, higher than the US$7.56 billion from America, Huang said.
Meanwhile, industrial production for September decreased 4.44 percent from August but increased 8.13 percent over the same period of last year.

Of the total, manufacturing production gained 9 percent over last year and water, electric power and gas increased by 2.77 percent, while mining and quarrying decreased 10.45 percent and construction decreased 7.21 percent.
Manufacturing production for the third quarter had an annual growth rate of 11.39 percent, which was the highest rate for the past three years, Huang said.

Increasing demand from European and Asian markets for consumer electronic products, laptops, flat panels, wireless telecommunications and petrochemical raw materials stimulated the growth of manufacturing production, Huang said.

He added that 25.36 percent of firms surveyed are optimistic that export orders received in October will increase, while 50.34 percent said the situation will remain unchanged and 24.3 percent said orders will drop.

The MOEA predicted that manufacturing production and export orders will continue to grow throughout the fourth quarter and that orders received through the whole year will amount to US$340 billion, up 13 percent from last year's US$299.3 billion, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New autoimmune treatment for brain tumors developed

TEXT.P: A new autoimmune treatment for brain tumors has been developed by the Taichung- based China Medical University Hospital (CMUH) , with a superior survival rate of 85.8 percent, hospital sources said Thursday.

CMUH Neurosurgery Department Director Cho Der-yang explained that the new therapy employs dendritic cells extracted from a patient's blood to fight malignant gliomas cells in the brain -- both to minimize side effects and increase the chances of survival.

Cho further explained that the dendritic cells extracted are first cultivated in vitro along with malignant gliomas cells, a process that induces dendritic cells to better understand their enemy and trigger the immune mechanism against this type of tumor cell.
The "educated" dendritic cells are then injected back into the patient to stimulate his human T-lymphocytes, which will then turn on the remaining brain tumor cells or malignant gliomas cells.
"A single course of treatment takes six months and 10 injections of cultivated dendritic cells," Cho added.

In previous clinical experiments, among the 21 volunteers with malignant gliomas, 18 survived the observation period of up to 32 months and only three died during the course, representing a three-year survival rate of 85.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to set aside eateries for jobless

TEXT.P: A civic group urged the government Thursday to set aside eateries for the jobless so that those who are unemployed can live and look for jobs with dignity.

Su Tseng, who heads a human rights promotion group for the jobless, suggested that the government open up restaurants for the jobless on a trial basis on college campuses or in government agencies in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung.
Government-funded vocational service agencies could give free coupons to the jobless for two meals a day in the eateries on weekends, and give cash at Chinese New Year, Su said.

He also suggested that those who are unemployed for more than a year and those with a monthly income of less than 60 percent of the basic wage of NT$17,280 (US$523) would be eligible for the free coupons, although they would also need to take vocational training courses.
Su pointed out that tallies released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that the number of those who were jobless for more than a year totaled 55,000 in 2006.

If there are three members in a family, then the government would need to spend around NT$4 billion a year on the project, or NT$2 billion if practiced in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung on a trial basis, Su estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Firefighters Get Control as Questions Rise
Inquiries were being made about how the firefight has been coordinated and how resources have been deployed.
The Wall Street Journal: BANK OF AMERICA IS forcing out the top executive at its investment- banking unit and plans to cut about 3,000 jobs as part of a review of the operation. 12:00 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lack of U.N. membership hampers Taiwan's farm, fishery development

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Thursday that lack of U.N. membership has hampered Taiwan's normal development in many sectors, including agricultural and fishery development.

DPP Legislator Wu Ming-min called on the government and people at a news conference to press home DPP-initiated efforts to seek membership of the United Nations under the name Taiwan, claiming that the lack of U.N. membership has barred Taiwan's agricultural and fishery products from entering the world market.

Wu said Taiwan's agricultural products, including eels, rice, organic tea, star fruit and bellfruit, have been successful in the world market because of their quality. These products are so hotly sought after that they are counterfeited by Chinese traders and sold at high prices on the world market, Wu added.
Taiwan producers, unfortunately, have been unable to clarify and reclaim their names due to the fact that Taiwan has been routinely excluded from the world stage, according to Wu.

Also speaking at the news conference, Chang Ching-jung, executive director of the Farmers' Association in Tashu, in southern Kaohsiung County, said the fact that Taiwan is excluded from the U.N. is not only a sad thing for Taiwan citizens, particularly when they travel abroad, it has also impeded Taiwan's agricultural products from being sold worldwide.

Chen You-ching, executive director of the Taiwan Provincial Fishermen's Association, said that Taiwan-produced fishery products are of world-class quality, while the equipment and facilities of Taiwan-based ocean-going fishing boats are generally advanced, with total catches amount ranking one of the world's highest. However, he claimed, "because Taiwan is not a U.N. member, " its fishing sector cannot join international fishery organizations and its catches are unfairly restricted.
Chen claimed that these problems would be solved if Taiwan were able to join the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls attention to Asia's rise as major consumer market

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Asia's rise as a major textile and apparel market means both opportunities and challenges for these industries, which he said is an issue worth in-depth study.
For the 1990-2004 period, the world's trade volume in textiles and apparel rose by 50 percent, with the increase in Asia's purchasing power being the main driving force, Chen noted.
The textile industry is also a pillar of Taiwan's economy, has created numerous jobs and has contributed greatly to the nation's economic progress, Chen said.

In tandem with Taiwan's technological development, Chen continued, more than one-third of the country's textile manufacturers are now engaging in the development of "functional textiles" and are receiving widespread recognition in the international market.

Taiwan's textile manufacturers are also seeking industrial upgrades, expanding their global presence, trying to work out a product differentiation strategy and developing high value-added textiles to enhance their competitiveness, he said.

According to the president, the situation has greatly boosted the stock prices of many textile companies, with shares of Formosa Chemicals and Fibre Corp., Far Eastern Textile Ltd. and Makalot Industrial Co. having become hot picks among investors.
He predicted that with the arrival of the irresistible global wave calling for environmental protection, eco-friendly textiles will inevitably become a mainstream product of the industry.
The president made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 23rd annual meeting of the International Apparel Federation (IAF) in Taipei.

The two-day IAF World Apparel Convention 2007 focuses on the theme "Asia -- from a global production base to an emerging consumer market" and is being held alongside the Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show.

Founded in 1972, the IAF is a global association open to entrepreneurs and executives from the apparel chain worldwide. Its membership includes national clothing associations and companies whose core businesses are sourcing, design, development, manufacturing, distribution or retailing of apparel and related products.

The IAF's membership now includes apparel associations from 32 countries representing over 150,000 companies that provide products and services to the apparel industry -- a membership that represents over 5 million employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC advises parents on coping with graphic TV broadcasts

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) advised parents Thursday on how to cope with the opening of adult programs in cable TV by ensuring that children are denied access to profanity and sexually explicit programs.

Defending their licensing of a cable TV system to provide free pornographic programs on basic cable TV broadcasting, as the Apple Daily reported Thursday, NCC officials clarified that opening the airwaves to programs with sexual content on cable TV presupposes that such programs cannot be viewed without proper equipment, that the equipment will be subject to strict control by adults, and that such program will be shown only late at night.
To access to adult programs on basic cable TV broadcasting, the subscribers need not to pay extra, save for the installation of a special cable box.

NCC officials said that the opening is being made in accordance with regulations stipulated in 2000 that TV programs in Taiwan be divided into four categories: suitable for all audiences, parental protection recommended for children under 6, parental accompaniment recommended for youths aged 6-18, and restricted.
NCC officials said the Rainbow Channel and Look TV are already operating adult programs on two cable TV channels in accordance with government regulations.

In addition, they said, in order to protect children and teenagers from viewing adult-oriented content TV programs, the government in 2003 demanded that cable operators improve the control mechanisms by asking subscribers to install an analog decoder with a digital address requiring a secret access code.
The NCC, established less than two years ago, is Taiwan's highest media regulator.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA halts opening to China-made garments

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Thursday that his ministry has decided to temporarily halt a plan to allow China-made garments to enter Taiwan due to the negative response from the domestic industry.
Chen made the comments to reporters while accompanying President Chen Shui-bian to attend an international garment conference and workshop in Taipei.

According to the minister, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has decided not to authorize a planned opening to China-made garments to enter Taiwan as a result of negative reactions from the local industry.

The MOEA will continue working to forge a consensus with local garment makers although it has decided not to allow the opening at the moment out of a fear that it might deal a heavy blow to related businesses at home, the minister said, adding that his ministry's top concern is that the local sector must remain intact in the wake of such a move.

The minister said that after consulting and exchanging viewpoints with local industry representatives, the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) has postponed a meeting, originally slated to be held Tuesday to discuss the opening to 54 items of Chinese manufacture in an effort to assuage their grave concerns. He added that the domestic industry has great reservations about such an opening at this time.
Steve R. L. Chen also denied a media report that the BOFT delayed the Tuesday meeting owing to political pressure, stressing that the MOEA is the top decision-making agency in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH probing flow of illicit antibiotic-containing Chinese shrimps

TEXT.P: A shipment of frozen white shrimp imported from China in June has been found to contain Enrofloxacin, an illicit antibiotic in animal husbandry and fish farming, with much of the shipment believed to have been sold to consumers, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

Cheng Huei-wen, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the problematic 20-ton shrimp shipmen was imported by a local company in Taoyuan County. The bureau has requested that the Taoyuan County government investigate the whereabouts of this lot of shrimp and ask sellers to recall the remaining ones.
Cheng said the drug is used in humans as a bacteriostat. It has no serious impact to human health though it might cause gastrointestinal discomfort, allergies or crystaluria.

The Council of Agriculture prohibits the use of the drug in raising animal and fish farming in order to prevent drug resistance from arising in humans after eating foods containing drug residues over a long period, Cheng said.

The DOH banned imports of frozen shrimp from China beginning Aug. 22 after discovering that seven lots of shrimp from China contained a carcinogenic drug, Cheng said, adding that shrimp imported from China before that date may still be on the market.

According to Cheng, the National Animal Industry Foundation inspected shrimp samples acquired in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan Sept. 3, with the authorization of the DOH, under a program to monitor aquatic product quality on market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture officials recommend 16 quality rice brands

TEXT.P: Agriculture officials said Thursday that they will recommend to consumers 16 high-quality rice brands produced in southern Taiwan at an exhibition in Tainan this coming weekend.

The two-day exhibition, held by the Southern Region Branch of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture, will take place Oct. 27-28 at a farmers' holiday market on Linsheng Road.
According to the officials, all 16 rice brands have been award winners in various national competitions. Visitors will be able to buy a two-kilogram pack of rice at an average price of NT$200.
Marketed under three brands -- Lungpo, Junghsing and Shan Shui -- is Cultivar Tainung No. 71, a taro-scented japonica rice, which is celebrated as "Taiwan's national treasure."

Tainung No. 71 is also called Yi Chuan Aromatic Rice. It is a mixed breed between Japan's Kinuhikari variety and Taiwan's Taikeng No. 4 in memory of Dr. Guo Yi-cuan, a research fellow at the Agricultural Research Institute of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture who developed the hybrid variety after devoting nearly his whole life to rice research and development.

Several other brands, including Lanli and Shan Shui, have Taikeng No. 9 rice -- also a mixed breed -- in their packages. This variety was developed in 1982 by Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station and received its name in 1993. It has remained popular on the domestic market because of its chewiness.

Other rice varieties in Shan Shui's rice series include the 2004 and 2005 champion rice, Taikeng No. 2, which is ideal when consumed as fried rice; Tainan No. 11, a new variety named in November 2004; and Tainung No. 71.

Hsin Nung rice is made of Taikeng No. 16 -- a high-quality hybrid developed from Taikeng No. 2 and Tainung No. 67 in 1996 by researchers in Hualien -- while Langchiao rice will present an organic rice made with Taiken No. 16.
Chingchuang rice will tout the Kaohsiung No. 145 variety, which was selected as one of 10 top rice brands in a national competition earlier this year.

Also on display and for sale are Meinung rice, which won second place in a national rice competition in 2004, Chihshan rice produced in Tainan County's Liuchia township, and rice grown in the Szuchung Creek Hot Spring area of Pingtung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, EU to continue talks on auto trade issues

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and the European Union have agreed to have experts from both sides carry on talks regarding automobile trade-related issues.
Both sides arrived at the consensus Wednesday at an annual Taiwan-EU trade consultative conference held in Taipei.

Vice Economic Minister Fadah Hsieh led the negotiations along with Karl Falkenberg, deputy director-general of external trade division of the European Commission -- the executive arm of the European Union.
The EU side expects the Taiwanese government to ease restrictions governing the energy efficiency of vehicles and the uniform certification criteria for automobiles and components.
The EU also hopes that Taiwan will exempt imported European vehicles from being branded with engine numbers.

European auto makers regard the branding policy as a technical trade barrier and have expressed concerns about the issue many times as they have great confidence in their anti-theft systems and complain that the application of such a policy would increase their production costs.
Starting this year, new cars in Taiwan are required to be imprinted with their engine numbers as part of the government's efforts to prevent vehicle theft.
Taiwan might accept that each European car company can choose one type of vehicle to be excluded from the compulsory policy for one year on a trial basis.
If that type of vehicle's anti-theft system proves effective, then in the following year, European vehicles using the same anti-theft system could be exempted from the branding policy.

If Taiwan agrees to allow European car makers to be conditionally freed of the policy, it should also apply the same treatment to car makers from other countries according to World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's flower exports aim to surpass US$100m next year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's floral exports are expected to surpass US$100 million next year, boosting the fast-growing industry already substantial contribution to Taiwan's agriculture, Council of Agriculture (COA) deputy minister said Thursday.

"While the domestic floral consumption leaves a lot to be desired, I'm proud to say that we're looking at surpassing a US$ 100 million mark in floriculture exports next year, showing the robust development and competitiveness of Taiwan's floriculture industry, " said Lee Chien-chuan at the press conference announcing the upcoming 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition (TIFE).
Taiwan's Phalaenopsis Orchids, which are commonly known as Butterfly Orchids, have been especially popular as one of the world's two Butterfly Orchids varieties come from Taiwan, Lee said.

Led by the orchid-growing industry, floriculture has been an unsung hero of Taiwan's agriculture, he said. From 1985 to the present, market output has increased from NT$9.5 billion to NT$12.5 billion and exports have increased from US$9.5 million to US$77 million, he said.

Visitors will be able to see for themselves what Taiwan has to offer in the 2007 TIFE, which will be held in Exhibition Hall I of the Taipei World Trade Center from Oct. 31-Nov. 4, alongside an exhibition of foreign floriculture products from Australia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Japan and the Netherlands.
The exhibition will be a "warm-up" for the 2011 International Flower Exposition, which is scheduled to be held in Taipei, said TIFE chief executive Wang Tien- shou.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF vice chairman given 11-year prison sentence for embezzlement

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was sentenced by Taipei District Court Thursday to an 11-year jail term for embezzlement of corporate funds.

Chang Chun-hung, one of the founders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, was accused of embezzling most of the corporate assets of a private telecommunications company several years ago while acting as the company's chairman. He was given the prison sentence Thursday by a panel of judges on charges of fraud and violating the Business Accounting Law and Securities Transaction Law.

Responding to the sentence, officials of the SEF -- founded in 1990 as an intermediary body authorized by the government to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait given greater demands for such services since Taiwan began allowing its people to travel to mainland China in 1987 to visit relatives -- said the foundation respects the judicial decision.

SEF officials also said that the case has nothing to do with SEF affairs and that the SEF will come to a decision regarding Chang's future with the organization after a comprehensive assessment of whether Chang's conviction will have an adverse impact on his acting as aboard member of the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N.-bid torch reaches Hualien leg

TEXT.P: A nationwide torch relay to drum up support for the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan has arrived in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, a local official said Thursday.

The torch relay was launched Wednesday morning in Taipei City, with President Chen Shui-bian leading the way to promote the government's campaign to solicit support for the country to gain U.N. membership.
The Hualien County Athletics Federation, organizer of the torch relay's local activities in Hualien, greeted the arrival of the torch and held a public concert to celebrate its progress that day.

According to the official, participants in the torch relay will run along the main roads of Hualien City starting at the Tohsing Sports Center at 7 a.m. Friday, with the city run ending around 8 a.m. to depart for the next leg.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lu Po-chi said joining the United Nations is the goal of all of Taiwan's people. He encouraged the public to take part in the torch relay to make the voices of Taiwan people heard around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust gambling ring in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau's anti-crime center in central Taiwan smashed an online gambling ring Thursday and arrested the ring leader and nine accomplices.

A spokesman for the center said that police raided 12 locations in Taipei, Taichung and the counties of Taichung and Changhua after receiving tips that the ring was operating three gambling Web sites and an underground gambling outlet that used sports match results and the ups and downs of indices for futures as the bases for winning or losing.
The law-enforcement officers arrested ring leader Lin Min-chi and nine members, and seized their book-keeping records and equipment, including computers, monitors and telephones.

According to the spokesman, Lin confessed that his ring has been operating the gambling outlets since 2005. An estimate based on the ring's bookkeeping records show that their monthly turnover topped NT$100 million (US$3.08 million).
Lin and his accomplices will be referred to the Taichung Public Prosecutors' Office and charged with gambling and organized crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: JTB to open office in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/07 21:51:11 (By Yang Ming-chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The JTB -- Japan's major tourist and travel agencies association -- is planning to establish an office in Taiwan next year with an aim at nurturing Mandarin- speaking tour guides.

An executive with the JTB Asian Travel Company (JTB-ATC) told the CNA Thursday that in light of the ever-increasing number of Chinese-spoken tourists visiting Japan each year, particularly from Taiwan, the association considers it as necessary to allow Taiwanese citizens to serve their compatriots as tour guides on trips to Japan.
More than 1 million Taiwanese people visit Japan on sightseeing tours each year, according to JTB tallies.
The JTB-ATC office to be established in Taiwan will mainly offer classes to Taiwan citizens who are interested in becoming a Mandarin-speaking tour guide in Japan, the executive said.

The Japanese Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transportation co-sponsored a test in Taiwan last year for potential Mandarin-speaking tour guides. Only 22 out of the 1,140 people who registered to take the test passed. Many of the test sitters complained that the questions of that test were too difficult to tackle, according to the JTB-ATC executive.

DOC.HEADLINE: President prods pan-blues to go all out for U.N. cause

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he is willing to take part in any events sponsored by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" to spotlight Taiwan's U.N. cause.

"I would like to participate in any 'pan-blue' sponsored activities to underline the country's bid to enter the United Nations in the name of Taiwan, no matter whether a jogging or bike tour, " Chen said, adding that because full U.N. membership is the common desire of the people of all walks of life in Taiwan and an issue free from political affiliation concerns.

"It is impossible to join the United Nations under the name of the Republic of China, " he insisted, urging the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party to stop daydreaming.

Chen kicked off a round-the-nation torch rely in front of the Presidential Office Wednesday, which critics claim is part of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) efforts to drum up support for its proposal to put the issue whether the country should pursue U.N. membership under the name Taiwan to a referendum alongside the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

Chen said that he was deeply touched seeing the public enthusiastically take part in the activity, and extended an invitation to Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition KMT's presidential candidate, and other KMT heavyweights to take part in the torch relay that is slated to wrap up Nov. 3 after passing through 25 cities and counties, including outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

According to Chen, the DPP has, as of Oct. 24, collected 1.65 million signatures endorsing its U.N. membership referendum proposal and by the end of this month hopes to hit the target of 2 million signatures.
"No one should miss the opportunity to sign his or her name to the petition at this historical juncture," he said.

Vice President Annette Lu urged both Ma and Frank Hsieh, the DPP presidential candidate, to stop bickering and instead seek effective ways to push for Taiwan's U.N. membership by delving into the links between Taiwan and the ROC and those between the ROC and the United Nations. "This is a very serious and professional political task, " she argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County promotes 140 police officers amid controversy

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei promoted 140 of the northern county's middle- ranking police officers Thursday, defying repeated central government warnings that the head of a quasi-municipality lacks the authority to advance the ranks of policemen serving in the constituency.

Chou presided over the promotion ceremony in which he presented the higher rank -- designated by the insignia of two stripes and three stars -- to the county's 140 two-stripes-two-stars police officers.

Claiming that the county's Oct. 1 upgrade to the status of a quasi-special municipality legally authorizes the county government to promote its police officers, Chou said the large-scale promotion exemplifies the "rule of law" and underlines the county's resolve to improve law enforcement.

Given the fact that Taipei County is the country's most populous constituency with a population of 3.8 million and covers a vast area of land, Chou said the county's police force assumes an unusually heavy workload and deserves more access to promotions.

Chou, a stalwart of the main opposition Kuomintang, said there will be a second, and even a third, wave of promotions of higher-ranking police officers to boost morale as police will have to take on additional security responsibilities with the approach of next legislative and presidential elections in early 2008.

According to amendments to the Local Government Act passed by the opposition- controlled Legislative Yuan in May, Chou claimed that the Taipei county government enjoys the same budget and personnel promotion rights as the country's two existing special municipalities -- Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.

However, National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih reiterated later in the day that the Taipei County government-presented promotions are invalid because the existing law does not authorize its magistrate to act in this regard.

Unless the Executive Yuan confirms that the existing special municipality police recruitment and management regulations are applicable to a quasi- municipality, Hou said the Taipei county government does not have a legal authority to administer police personnel affairs.

Although Ho Cheng-cheng, the NPA's personnel department chief, said previously that the department had agreed with the Taipei county government that heads of police precincts in the county would not be reshuffled before next year's two crucial elections, Hou said that consensus is still subject to change.

"If necessary, the county's police precinct chiefs may still be reassigned to cater to practical needs, " Hou said, adding that stability is the top concern and that all personnel reshuffles will take into account the overall well-being of the country's 68,000-plus police officers.

Under the country's civil service law and regulations, NPA personnel officials said, only the minister of the interior has the authority to appoint and promote high-ranking police officers, meaning those of three-stripes-two-stars rank and higher grades.

As to promotion of police officers under the three-stripes-two-stars rank, the officials said the Ministry of the Interior tends to authorize the NPA chief to decide on promotion. Without the MOI's authorization, the officials insist that the Taipei county government lacks the authority to promote police officers.

Nominally, the 140 "promoted" Taipei County police officers are entitled to pay raises ranging between NT$2,600 and NT$4,150 per month, but the Ministry of Civil Service under the Examination Yuan has already denied the validity of their promotions and is not expected to offer them any increased salaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: New political party laments oppression from powerful counterparts

TEXT.P: The more powerful political parties in Taiwan -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- are trying to oppress emerging political forces, which will be detrimental to the development of Taiwan's democracy, the leader of a newly-established party said Thursday.

"As the two-party political system is taking shape and the number of legislators will be halved from 225 to 113, the maneuvering space for a small political party like us has been shrinking because powerful parties are trying to limit the development of other parties through regulation of the electoral system, " said Jou Yi-cheng, leader of the Third Society Party (TSP) which was established in September.

As a new party, the TSP will have a hard time fielding candidates in the upcoming legislative election. That could become still more difficult, Jou said, referring to the latest rumors that the Central Election Committee (CEC) is considering raising the guarantee deposit of each candidate from NT$200,000 to NT$500,000, and the minimum number of regional legislative candidate nominations from 10 to 20 to be listed in the party lists.
If the rumors are true, the amendment of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law will deal devastating financial and political blows to small parties such as TSP, Jou said.

The new legislature to be elected under the new "single-member constituency, two ballots" electoral system Jan. 12, 2008 will comprise 73 regional seats, 6 seats for aboriginals, with the remaining 34 seats to be filled from party lists. The 34 legislators-at-large will be elected from the lists of political parties in proportion to the number of votes won by each party that obtains at least 5 percent of the total vote cast in the election.

The more established parties should nurture emerging political forces to cultivate a sound democratic environment, former CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said, adding that currently political parties placed their own benefit above the welfare of the people and the country.
"I would blatantly say that they are not real political parties. They are gangs. And why would people pay taxes to subsidize gangs? " Huang asked.

Taiwan needs to make up its mind to determine what is the best electoral system for the country, said Pan Han-shen, Secretary-General of Green Party Taiwan, another smaller political party. Pan said that most European electoral systems, which are dominated by proportional systems, stress negotiation and consensus-seeking while the American system is more like a "cowboys' dual."
"Taiwan has to know what it wants to be, " Pan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Australian official hails purchasing power of Taiwan tourists

TEXT.P: Taiwan is a very significant source of tourists for Australia and their contributions to Australia's economy is on the rise, Tourism Australia Executive General Manager Richard Beere said Thursday.

Speaking at a news conference in Taipei, Beere said that Australia attaches a high degree of importance to the Taiwanese tourist market, and that Taiwanese tourists in his country have increased spending in that country from $20 million Australian dollars (about US$18 million) per year to $50 million.

Although the number of Taiwanese tourists traveling to Australia in 2006 decreased by 16 percent from the 2005 figure, Beere said that their purchase power remains strong and will continue growing to make an even a greater contribution to the Australian economy in 2007.

According to statistics compiled by Tourism Australia, tourist arrivals from Taiwan totaled some 93,000 in 2006, down by 16 percent from the previous year's level. Australian officials said they expect that Taiwanese tourists will spend more in their country this year.

To lure a larger number of increasingly quality-conscious Taiwanese tourists, Tourism Australia has designed high-end and luxury tour packages, which will be introduced to the Taiwanese market in November, Australian tourism officials said.
Beginning next month, the Taipei-based China Airlines will increase the number of flights to Australia in cooperation with Tourism Australia, which is keen to embrace more Taiwan tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red Leaf Little League baseball team to be inaugurated Nov. 3

TEXT.P: The primary school in eastern Taiwan whose baseball team defeated the Little League world champion team from Japan in 1968 will try to revive its past glory by relaunching its Little League team early next month.

Yu Hsien-teh, principal of the Hongye (red leaf) Primary School, told reporters Thursday that the school will relaunch a "Red Leaf" baseball team Nov. 3, with the initial target of winning the championship in the 2008 Red Leaf Cup Little League International Baseball Tournament.

The school's baseball team is remembered by baseball fans for defeating the Little League world champions, the Wakayama team from Japan, 7A-0, in a nine- inning game played in Taipei in 1968. Baseball has become a popular sport in Taiwan ever since.

In recent years, the declining population in the school's catchment area has resulted in shrinking enrollment and made it impossible for the school to maintain a baseball team. At present, the school's total enrollment is only 39 students, spread over six grades.
Yu said, however, that all the pupils have been training hard in baseball, although they alone cannot form a team.
The principal added that his school will work with three other neighboring primary schools to form a "Red Leaf United Baseball Team" with the inauguration set fir Nov. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Illegal solicitation of organ transplants to be punished: MAC

TEXT.P: All those involved in the illegal solicitation of organ transplants, reportedly connected to a visit by a Chinese medical doctor to Taiwan earlier this year, will be punished if the results of an investigation confirm the report, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

The council has also asked the Cabinet-level Department of Health to investigate whether the organization that invited the Chinese medical doctor to Taiwan, and the doctor himself, were involved in other illegal medical practices during his stay in Taiwan, the official noted.

The remarks came after the Taipei-based Liberty Times recently reported that Zhu Zhijun, director of the organ transplant center of Tianjin First Central Hospital in the northern Chinese city of Tianjin, visited Taiwan in March under the cover of medical exchanges, but instead conducted assessments of liver disease patients in the company of two Taiwanese doctors with a view towards traveling to China for a transplant.
The Tianjin hospital is touted as the biggest liver transplant center in Asia.

If the reports are confirmed, Zhu could face a prison term of between six months and five years should he ever return to Taiwan, and if the Taiwanese doctors who helped Zhu are found to have engaged in the sale of human organs they could be disciplined for violating medical ethics and have their licenses to practice revoked.
Meanwhile, the council warned the Taiwanese public of the possibility of violating Chinese laws by having liver transplant surgeries in China, the official said.
The Chinese government outlawed the sale of human organs in May and will issue huge fines to those who violate the laws, the official said.

In addition, violators will face criminal prosecution as Chinese laws require that a written approval be obtained from the organ donor and the organ transplant surgery be conducted only at third-class, first-grade hospitals, a category equivalent to Taiwan's top-grade medical centers, the official went on.
Despite the Chinese government's efforts, the official said that the illegal trade in human organs remains rampant and that organs often come from unknown donors.

International media outlets have also reported that Beijing often illegally harvests organs from executed prisoners or Falun Gong practitioners for transplant, the official said, urging the public to beware of possible moral and human rights violations in receiving organ transplant in China.
The MAC urged locals who intend to receive such transplants in China to consult Taiwanese hospitals first and to work through legal channels, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President blasts late presidents over loss of U.N. seat

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that late President Chiang Kai-shek should be held responsible for the country's loss of the U.N. seat in 1971 and that his son, Chiang Ching-kuo who was the premier and the president between 1972 and 1988, failed to push for the country to reenter the U.N.

Touting the government's campaign to promote the country's U.N. bid under the name Taiwan this year, Chen criticized the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for continuing to push for the U.N. bid under the country's national title, the Republic of China, describing the act as "self-deceiving."

Chen made the remarks while attending the opening of an exhibition organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and Historica Sinica on the retrospect of the country's loss of U.N. membership and outlook for the country's quest for U.N. seat under the name Taiwan.
Also present at the opening ceremony were Vice President Annette Lu and Foreign Minister James Huang.
The exhibition, which features historical and official documents and books, will run through Nov. 1 at the National Central Library in Taipei.
Chen said that in an act of protest against Communist China's admission into the United Nations, Chiang Kai-shek decided to give up the country's U.N. seat.
Chen noted that the ROC's U.N. seat has already been taken over by the People's Republic of China and that it is impossible to promote the country's U.N. bid under its national title.

By contrast, he said that his administration's current campaign to promote the bid under the name Taiwan is aimed at gaining representation for the country's 23 million people in the world body, not retrieving the U.N. seat from China.
He also noted that it wasn't until 1991, when former President Lee Teng-hui was in office, that the government again sought to enter the U.N.

However, over the past decade, the government's campaign to push for U.N. membership under the national title, the Republic of China, has been proven ineffective; he went on to describe the government's new bid under the name Taiwan as a correct and historical step.

Citing the results of a recent poll, Chen said that 75 percent of the Taiwanese public responding to the poll regard Taiwan as an independent, sovereign country, not as a part of China, while 85 percent think that Taiwan's sovereignty does not cover the territory of China.

On the occasion, Chen also sang the first few lines of a song honoring the Republic of China and said that the song touts the massive area of grass in China's Qinghai Province and the view of the Himalayan Mountain Range, which he said are impossible for people to see in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County promotes 140 police officers amid controversy

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei promoted 140 of the northern county's middle- ranking police officers Thursday, defying repeated central government warnings that the head of a quasi-municipality lacks the authority to advance the ranks of policemen serving in the constituency.

Chou presided over the promotion ceremony in which he presented the higher rank -- designated by the insignia of two stripes and three stars -- to the county's 140 two-stripes-two-stars police officers.

Claiming that the county's Oct. 1 upgrade to the status of a quasi-special municipality legally authorizes the county government to promote its police officers, Chou said the large-scale promotion exemplifies the "rule of law" and underlines the county's resolve to improve law enforcement.

Given the fact that Taipei County is the country's most populous constituency with a population of 3.8 million and covers a vast area of land, Chou said the county's police force assumes an unusually heavy workload and deserves more access to promotions.

Chou, a stalwart of the main opposition Kuomintang, said there will be a second, and even a third, wave of promotions of higher-ranking police officers to boost morale as police will have to take on additional security responsibilities with the approach of next legislative and presidential elections in early 2008.

According to amendments to the Local Government Act passed by the opposition- controlled Legislative Yuan in May, Chou claimed that the Taipei county government enjoys the same budget and personnel promotion rights as the country's two existing special municipalities -- Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.

However, National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih reiterated later in the day that the Taipei County government-presented promotions are invalid because the existing law does not authorize its magistrate to act in this regard.

Unless the Executive Yuan confirms that the existing special municipality police recruitment and management regulations are applicable to a quasi- municipality, Hou said the Taipei county government does not have a legal authority to administer police personnel affairs.

Although Ho Cheng-cheng, the NPA's personnel department chief, said previously that the department had agreed with the Taipei county government that heads of police precincts in the county would not be reshuffled before next year's two crucial elections, Hou said that consensus is still subject to change.

"If necessary, the county's police precinct chiefs may still be reassigned to cater to practical needs, " Hou said, adding that stability is the top concern and that all personnel reshuffles will take into account the overall well-being of the country's 68,000-plus police officers.

Under the country's civil service law and regulations, NPA personnel officials said, only the minister of the interior has the authority to appoint and promote high-ranking police officers, meaning those of three-stripes-two-stars rank and higher grades.

As to promotion of police officers under the three-stripes-two-stars rank, the officials said the Ministry of the Interior tends to authorize the NPA chief to decide on promotion. Without the MOI's authorization, the officials insist that the Taipei county government lacks the authority to promote police officers.

Nominally, the 140 "promoted" Taipei County police officers are entitled to pay raises ranging between NT$2,600 and NT$4,150 per month, but the Ministry of Civil Service under the Examination Yuan has already denied the validity of their promotions and is not expected to offer them any increased salaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: New political party laments oppression from powerful counterparts

TEXT.P: The more powerful political parties in Taiwan -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- are trying to oppress emerging political forces, which will be detrimental to the development of Taiwan's democracy, the leader of a newly-established party said Thursday.

"As the two-party political system is taking shape and the number of legislators will be halved from 225 to 113, the maneuvering space for a small political party like us has been shrinking because powerful parties are trying to limit the development of other parties through regulation of the electoral system, " said Jou Yi-cheng, leader of the Third Society Party (TSP) which was established in September.

As a new party, the TSP will have a hard time fielding candidates in the upcoming legislative election. That could become still more difficult, Jou said, referring to the latest rumors that the Central Election Committee (CEC) is considering raising the guarantee deposit of each candidate from NT$200,000 to NT$500,000, and the minimum number of regional legislative candidate nominations from 10 to 20 to be listed in the party lists.
If the rumors are true, the amendment of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law will deal devastating financial and political blows to small parties such as TSP, Jou said.

The new legislature to be elected under the new "single-member constituency, two ballots" electoral system Jan. 12, 2008 will comprise 73 regional seats, 6 seats for aboriginals, with the remaining 34 seats to be filled from party lists. The 34 legislators-at-large will be elected from the lists of political parties in proportion to the number of votes won by each party that obtains at least 5 percent of the total vote cast in the election.

The more established parties should nurture emerging political forces to cultivate a sound democratic environment, former CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said, adding that currently political parties placed their own benefit above the welfare of the people and the country.
"I would blatantly say that they are not real political parties. They are gangs. And why would people pay taxes to subsidize gangs? " Huang asked.

Taiwan needs to make up its mind to determine what is the best electoral system for the country, said Pan Han-shen, Secretary-General of Green Party Taiwan, another smaller political party. Pan said that most European electoral systems, which are dominated by proportional systems, stress negotiation and consensus-seeking while the American system is more like a "cowboys' dual."
"Taiwan has to know what it wants to be, " Pan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red Leaf Little League baseball team to be inaugurated Nov. 3

TEXT.P: The primary school in eastern Taiwan whose baseball team defeated the Little League world champion team from Japan in 1968 will try to revive its past glory by relaunching its Little League team early next month.

Yu Hsien-teh, principal of the Hongye (red leaf) Primary School, told reporters Thursday that the school will relaunch a "Red Leaf" baseball team Nov. 3, with the initial target of winning the championship in the 2008 Red Leaf Cup Little League International Baseball Tournament.

The school's baseball team is remembered by baseball fans for defeating the Little League world champions, the Wakayama team from Japan, 7A-0, in a nine- inning game played in Taipei in 1968. Baseball has become a popular sport in Taiwan ever since.

In recent years, the declining population in the school's catchment area has resulted in shrinking enrollment and made it impossible for the school to maintain a baseball team. At present, the school's total enrollment is only 39 students, spread over six grades.
Yu said, however, that all the pupils have been training hard in baseball, although they alone cannot form a team.
The principal added that his school will work with three other neighboring primary schools to form a "Red Leaf United Baseball Team" with the inauguration set fir Nov. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: Illegal solicitation of organ transplants to be punished: MAC

TEXT.P: All those involved in the illegal solicitation of organ transplants, reportedly connected to a visit by a Chinese medical doctor to Taiwan earlier this year, will be punished if the results of an investigation confirm the report, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

The council has also asked the Cabinet-level Department of Health to investigate whether the organization that invited the Chinese medical doctor to Taiwan, and the doctor himself, were involved in other illegal medical practices during his stay in Taiwan, the official noted.

The remarks came after the Taipei-based Liberty Times recently reported that Zhu Zhijun, director of the organ transplant center of Tianjin First Central Hospital in the northern Chinese city of Tianjin, visited Taiwan in March under the cover of medical exchanges, but instead conducted assessments of liver disease patients in the company of two Taiwanese doctors with a view towards traveling to China for a transplant.
The Tianjin hospital is touted as the biggest liver transplant center in Asia.

If the reports are confirmed, Zhu could face a prison term of between six months and five years should he ever return to Taiwan, and if the Taiwanese doctors who helped Zhu are found to have engaged in the sale of human organs they could be disciplined for violating medical ethics and have their licenses to practice revoked.
Meanwhile, the council warned the Taiwanese public of the possibility of violating Chinese laws by having liver transplant surgeries in China, the official said.
The Chinese government outlawed the sale of human organs in May and will issue huge fines to those who violate the laws, the official said.

In addition, violators will face criminal prosecution as Chinese laws require that a written approval be obtained from the organ donor and the organ transplant surgery be conducted only at third-class, first-grade hospitals, a category equivalent to Taiwan's top-grade medical centers, the official went on.
Despite the Chinese government's efforts, the official said that the illegal trade in human organs remains rampant and that organs often come from unknown donors.

International media outlets have also reported that Beijing often illegally harvests organs from executed prisoners or Falun Gong practitioners for transplant, the official said, urging the public to beware of possible moral and human rights violations in receiving organ transplant in China.
The MAC urged locals who intend to receive such transplants in China to consult Taiwanese hospitals first and to work through legal channels, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 26, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
2001: A passenger ship sails from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China, marking a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of 2001 on a trial basis.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential residence guard shoots himself with gun

TEXT.P: A military officer serving as a guard at President Chen Shui-bian's residence reportedly shot himself with his pistol Friday.

The officer, identified as Captain Lu Tseng-hsiang from the National Security Bureau, served as a guard at the presidential residence on Nanchang Road in downtown Taipei. He was rushed to the nearby National Taiwan University Hospital immediately after he shot himself with his gun around 8:30 a.m.

The police, who were not allowed to enter the presidential residence for investigation after the mishap, proceeded to the hospital to gain better understanding of why Lu committed suicide, police sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: European Parliament members back Taiwan's U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/26/07 11:31:50 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of 84 members of the European Parliament released a joint statement Thursday to express their support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

The members representing various political groups, who have gathered in Strasbourg, France for the European Parliament's plenary session, noted in their statement that Taiwan is a sovereign state that has never been governed by the People's Republic of China and that it is wrong and unfair for U.N. Secretary- General Ban Ki-moon to claim that Taiwan is part of China and deny Taiwan's eligibility for membership.

They pointed out that in a report on China issued last September, the European Parliament called for representation for Taiwan's 23 million people in international organizations and that to this day, Taiwan remains excluded from most of these organizations.

Calling Taiwan a full-fledged democracy with a highly developed economy that can make valuable contributions to the international community, the members urged the European Union's 27 member states and other U.N. members to seriously consider Taiwan's application for membership in the world body.
Taiwan has not been represented in the United Nations since 1971, when the Republic of China's U.N. seat was given to the People's Republic of China.

While the ROC has tried since 1993 to get the United Nations to consider the issue of its representation, this year marks the first time the country has applied to join the world body under the name Taiwan. However, as on previous occasions, the issue of Taiwan's membership application was excluded from the agenda of the 62nd session of the General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan expresses concerns about Argentina's safeguard duties on CD-Rs

TEXT.P: Taiwan trade officials expressed grave concern at a World Trade Organization (WTO) meeting in Geneva, Switzerland Wednesday that Argentina has unilaterally imposed "safeguard duties" on imports of Taiwan-made compact discs-recordable (CD-Rs) beginning May this year.

Argentina had notified the WTO that it was imposing "safeguard duties" of US$13 cents per unit in the first year (May 30, 2007 to May 29, 2008), US$11 cents in the second year (May 30, 2008 to May 29, 2009) and US$8 cents in the third and final year (May 30, 2009 to May 29, 2010) on CD-Rs imported from Taiwan.

Taiwan delegates said at the WTO Committee on Safeguards meeting held Wednesday at the world trade regulatory body's headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland that Taiwan is very concerned about the measure, emphasizing that it reserves its rights under WTO rules to take "whatever step to protect the interests of its industry."

The Taiwan officials expressed concern that Taiwan CD-R manufacturers and exporters have not been given adequate opportunity for prior consultations and to state its case; that Argentina's accusation that Taiwan charges a higher f.o.b. price for the product was unsubstantiated; and that Argentina has failed in establishing a causal link between imports and injury (including salary adjustments, inflation and debt costs) to domestic industry but has attributed the cause of the so-called "injury" to imported CD-Rs only.

The officials also said that the measure has harmed the rights and interests of Argentina's consumers. According to Argentine tallies, Taiwan-originating CD-Rs commanded 61.29-percent share of the market in Argentina in the Jan.-July period of this year, nearly double that of CD-Rs imported from India, which was the second largest exporter.

Responding to Taiwan's complaint, Argentine officials posted at the WTO headquarters stressed that Argentina had given WTO member countries the opportunity for consultations and that in fact, two rounds of talks were conducted with Chinese Taipei -- one held in Buenos Aires and the other in Geneva.

According to WTO rules, a WTO member may restrict imports of a product temporarily -- in other words, take "safeguard actions -- if its domestic industry has been harmed or faces the threat of being harmed by a surge in imports.

It has been learned that Taiwan manufacturers of high-technology products have considered establishing manufacturing plants in the four Mercosur member states -- Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay -- in view of the huge market potential of the region and with the aim of skirting various trade barriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA urges public to report soot-emitting vehicles

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) urged the public Friday to report soot-emitting vehicles in order to help safeguard the nation's air quality.

EPA officials said that it had received 50,000 reports of soot-emitting vehicles in the first nine months of this year. Among the vehicles inspected as a result of the reports, five percent were fined fro failing to pass inspections two times in a row.
The maximum fine for motorcycles that fail to pass the inspection is NT$6,000 (US$182), while that for diesel-fueled oversized vehicles is NT$20,000, they said.

The officials further said that according to figures released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, there were 6.75 million cars and 13.8 million motorcycles registered in Taiwan as of the end of August, for an average of one car for every 3.4 people, and one motorcycle for every 1.7 people.
There were 568 vehicles per square kilometer, showing the strain on the environment, they added.

Hsiao Huei-chuan, director general of the DOH's Department of Air Quality, Protection and Noise Control, said that diesel-fueled trucks had the highest failure ratio in the inspections, followed by two-stroke motorcycles.

The diesel-fueled trucks normally emit black smoke, and the two-stroke motorcycles usually emit white smoke, and the soot they cause has been the largest source of pollutants found in trees that line sidewalks, he said.

Hsiao noted that a prize-drawing activity to encourage the public to report soot emission has entered its eighth year, adding that it is gratifying to see that the participation rate has gradually increased and that the ratio of vehicles failing the inspection has decreased.

Hsiao noted that around 4,300 people are eligible to join a draw for the 1,127 prizes this year, including LCD televisions, digital video cameras, bicycles and digital cameras. The names of the winners will be posted on the EPA's Web site at http://polcar.epa.gov.tw soon, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential residence guard commits suicide

TEXT.P: A guard at President Chen Shui-bian's residence who shot himself with his own pistol Friday morning was declared dead by National Taiwan University Hospital at 12:20 p.m. the same day.

The officer, identified as Capt. Lu Tseng-hsiang from the National Security Bureau (NSB), was on guard duty at the presidential residence on Nanchang Road in downtown Taipei at the time of the shooting incident.
Lu was rushed to the nearby National Taiwan University Hospital for treatment immediately after he shot himself at around 8: 30 a.m., NSB officials said.
They further said that Lu, 27, may have been suffering from depression due to a failed relationship.
President Chen Shui-bian, who was on an inspection tour in Shulin, Taipei County was informed about the tragedy in "real time, " the officials said.
They added that the bureau has also notified Lu's family about the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan businesses urged to invest more in branding

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses should shift their focus from production to intangible assets such as intellectual property right and brands to enhance their international competitiveness, Industrial Technology Research Institute of Taiwan Chairman Lin Hsin-I said Friday.

According to Lin, with stiffer competition from developing countries such as China, Vietnam and India where production costs are relatively low, it is crucial for Taiwan to develop a branding strategy to persuade international buyers to spend 10 percent to 20 percent more to purchase Taiwan's products.

Noting that Taiwan businesses always concentrated on production and neglected marketing and branding in the past, Lin said businesses should now take advantage of marketing and branding, make good use of the international division of labor, outsource the production of products with low added value, and allow domestic production of competitive products.

Lin pointed out that "quality, brand names and taste" are what customers are looking for and that a lot of effort is required to make consumers develop trust in and preference for a particular product.
He said branding is a "national affair" that requires the participation of the entire nation and cannot rely solely on the support of certain funds established by the government.
Lin made the remarks while addressing the Branding Taiwan Forum 2007 held in Taipei by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former premier acquitted of defamation charges

TEXT.P: Former Premier Yu Shyi-kun was acquitted of defamation charges Friday over his reference to the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) acquired assets as "loot" during his premiership in 2004.

The Taiwan High Court rejected an appeal by the KMT, upholding a previous ruling by the Taipei District Court in which Yu was determined not guilty, on the grounds that the controversies surrounding the KMT's assets are issues open for public comment and that Yu only made the comment passively while responding to related questions.
At issue was a statement made by Yu Oct. 5, 2004, during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, when he was asked about the Cabinet's effort to reclaim the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets.

In his reply, Yu said the assets were like "loot, " which he claimed would remain illicit regardless of who were to receive them. Yu made similar remarks while receiving interviews by the media Oct. 21 and Nov. 9.

In his testimony during the trial, Yu said he used the term "loot" to refer to the KMT's assets because an investigative report by the Control Yuan had already determined that many of the party's assets were embezzled from the government during the party's 55-year rule of Taiwan and that it was not his intent to slander the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 83 points to close at 9,677, with 36,848 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December rose 81 points to finish at 9,675, with 248 contracts traded, while March futures gained 31 points to close at 9,635, with seven contract transactions. June futures increased 17 points to finish at 9,630, with one contract traded, while September futures moved up 108 points to close at 9,498, with eight contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 9,594 for November, 9,594 for December, 9,604 for March, 9,613 for June and 9,390 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

November TE futures rose three points to close at 403.45, with 2,968 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained three points to finish at 403.3, with 11 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures moved up nine points to close at 1,058.4, with 2,397 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures rose 11.4 points to finish at 1,061.4, with 14 contracts traded. September TF futures gained 7.2 points to close at 1,055, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing urged to resume talks on cross-strait flights and tourism

TEXT.P: China should resume negotiations with Taiwan on issues concerning the operation of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights and visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists to show its sincerity in improving relations between the two sides, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday.
Chen made the remarks during a Taipei seminar on the situation in cross-strait relations after the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China.

Noting that Taiwan considers the two policies to be milestones paving the way for the full opening of direct cross-strait shipping and air links, Chen predicted that direct cross-strait transportation will be achieved within one year of the implementation of the policies.

According to Chen, representatives of Taiwan and China have held many rounds of talks on technical issues surrounding the operation of cross-strait passenger and cargo charter flights and have reached a consensus on the issues.
If China resumes talks with Taiwan to resolve the remaining problems, Chinese citizens will soon be able to travel to Taiwan on cross-strait charter flights, Chen said.

In what has been considered by the MAC as the main obstacles impeding the progress of cross-strait talks, China has referred to Taiwan as a tourist destination within China, and insisted that cross-strait visits do not constitute travel "between two countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forms Myanmar affairs division at liaison office in Thailand

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Thailand, Taiwan's liaison office in that country, set up a division Friday in charge of Myanmar affairs, according to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) press release.

Major tasks of the division include observing the political situation in Myanmar where the ruling military junta recently cracked down on peaceful protests staged by monks and democracy advocates on the streets of the capital city, Yangon.

The new unit will also work to share Taiwan's experience in promoting democracy with Myanmarese people while seeking cooperation with other countries and international groups which show sympathy for the battered democratic movement in Myanmar to help that society open up and embrace a democratic system, according to the press release.
In addition, the Myanmarese division is also commissioned to join efforts to promote regional stability, safety and prosperity, the press release said.
Taiwan has no representative office in Myanmar, with which it maintains no diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headlline news

TEXT.P: Italian Premier Romano Prodi urged the allied parties to fully support the government Thursday after his administration and the ruling center-left alliance were defeated in seven votes in the Senate on measures annexed to the budget for the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 63.25 points to close at 9,631.51.
The bourse opened at 9,637.49 and fluctuated between 9,661.94 and 9,573 during trading. A total of 4.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$139.41 billion (US$4.3 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares, machinery and electronics shares and construction issues all at 0.6 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down 0.7 percent and textile stocks dropping 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 982, with 279 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trial of vice president over alleged fund misuse to begin next month

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court said Friday that the trial of Vice President Annette Lu and two other heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over "special allowance fund" misuse has been set for next month.
Lu's trial is set for Nov. 19, while the trial of Yu Shyi-kun, former DPP chairman, is set for Nov. 26 and that of Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general of the National Security Council, for Dec. 3.

An investigation task force of the Supreme Prosecutor's Office announced last month the completion of an extensive probe into the use of "special allowance funds" by the trio, as well as that of Frank Hsieh, DPP presidential candidate, and his running mate Su Tseng-chang.

Lu, Yu and Chen were indicted on charges of forgery and embezzlement for collecting invoices from others to claim reimbursement from the "special allowance funds." Hsieh and Su were cleared after a thorough probe, the prosecution said.

The indictment said that from December 2000 to May 2006, staff of Lu's office and her guards collected 1,005 invoices worth NT$5.63 million (US$169,580) to claim reimbursement from her "special allowance fund."

Yu's wife, Yang Pao-yu, Yu's staff during his premiership, and his guards allegedly collected 516 invoices to claim NT$2.38 million from his special fund between October 2000 and December 2005, the prosecution said.

Tan Sun Chen, who has served as Presidential Office secretary-general and as minister of foreign affairs, is said to have used his staff in those two posts to collect 106 invoices to claim NT$368,199 from his fund between July 2004 and June 2006.

The prosecution explained that Hsieh and Su were spared because they deposited their "special allowance funds" into their bank accounts during their terms of service as Kaohsiung mayor and Taipei county magistrate, respectively, but the funds withdrawn from the accounts were greater than the amount of "special allowance funds" deposited into the accounts.

During their terms as premier, and Su's term as secretary-general of the Presidential Office, both claimed their "special allowance funds" in the form of cash, so there is no way for the prosecution to trace the money.
After reviewing the income tax returns and the personal asset reports filed by the two over the years, the prosecution found no abnormal increases in their personal wealth.

Because defendants do not have to make statements unfavorable to themselves or submit evidence to prove their innocence, the prosecution could not prove that they used part of the funds for non-official purposes.

All executives holding public office are given a "special allowance fund" every month. Although the use of the money is left to the discretion of the administrative chief, half of the fund can be spent without any proof of spending, while use of the other half must be substantiated with receipts or invoices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate proposes 'English day' for elementary schools

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing proposed that an "English Day" be held at selected elementary schools when he inspected two elementary schools in the southern Taiwan county Friday.
Yang expressed hope that all students will speak English on that day and that they will master English in addition to their mother tongues.

The two schools -- Wufu Elementary School and Fengshan Elementary School -- are located in Fengshan district and have been included in an "English village" program planned by the Kaohsiung county government.

The two schools will put idle classrooms to good use in setting up "English villages." Wufu Elementary School will set up an international learning section that will have a restaurant taking orders in English, an overseas experience section with a simulated airport, a customs and flight cabin, as well as household environments and a supermarket.
Fengshan Elementary School will also set up a service center, and a simulated customs office, MRT station, hospital, newsroom, bakery and theater.

Yang said that the county has chosen the two schools in Fengshan district as well as Tsaiwen Elementary School in Kangshan district and Chishan Elementary School in Chishan to set up simulated English environments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local school opens applications to provide homestay services

TEXT.P: National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) in Keelung City in northern Taiwan is soliciting applications from members of the public willing to provide host family accommodations for the school's foreign students, a spokesman for the school said Friday.

The school is organizing the program to increase the opportunity for cultural exchanges between its foreign students and local families, the spokesman said, adding that the application period will last until Nov. 2.

The school has a total of 35 foreign students in graduate programs, with most coming from France, Guatemala, South Korea, Indonesia, Panama, Belize, and the Philippines. These students came to Taiwan to benefit from both formal studies and life experience, the spokesman said.
Families willing to provide accommodation services will need to have some family members with an ability to speak a foreign language in order to communicate well with their foreign guests.
Those families will have the opportunity to invite foreign students to family get-togethers and to introduce Taiwanese festivals and lifestyles to them, the spokesman said.

As the NTOU has already arranged boarding and lodging for the students, host families need only provide short-term homestay experience and occasional assistance, such as airport pickups to foreign students.
People who are interested in providing the service can download the application form via the NTOU's Web site, the spokesman said.
