DOC.HEADLINE: Farmers encouraged to grow compost crops on fallow land

TEXT.P: Agriculture experts working for the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) are making efforts to persuade farmers in central and southern Taiwan to grow cover and compost crops on fallow land in order to reap multiple benefits.

According to the Tainan District Agricultural Research and Extension Station, its experts have been assisting farmers in the counties of Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan to grow crops suitable for mulching, such as sunflowers, common cosmos, yellow cosmos and zinnias.

The program, already under way in more than a dozen rural townships, will not only create beautiful landscapes and promote tourism agriculture, but will also increase soil fertility and help achieve sustainable farming.

The experts believe that soil should never be left fallow because this makes it vulnerable to erosion and weed invasion. Instead, they say, growing a compost crop, termed as "green manure," is as easy as throwing out a handful of seed onto freshly cultivated ground and simply covering it with a thin layer of soil.
Flowering can be expected 40-60 days after sowing, and the stunning blossoms can last from two or three weeks up to three months, beautifying the landscape.

In addition to providing a feast for the eye, cover and compost crops can suppress weeds, increase the soil's available nitrogen and moisture retention, prevent soil erosion and interrupt pest and disease cycles in much the same way as crop rotation, according to the experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 80% of Japanese supports Taiwan's U.N. bid: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that over 80 percent of Japanese citizens would support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations if a proposed referendum to ask Taiwanese voters whether the country should apply for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan passes next year.
The president made the remarks while speaking at a meeting of the Rotary Club of Taipei.

Quoting the results of a recent opinion poll to explore Japanese citizens' attitude toward Taiwan's U.N. bid, Chen said that 74 percent of Japanese people responding to the survey are in favor of Taiwan's U.N. membership and that the percentage of proponents would even increase to 81 percent if the proposed referendum on the bid passes next year.

With such a high level of support for Taiwan's bid among the Japanese, he said Taiwan should have more confidence in itself. When a referendum proposal initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is put to a vote alongside the March 22 presidential election next year, the president urged Taiwan's citizens to cast their votes in support of the proposal.

He again criticized a proposal by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to apply for r-joining the United Nations under the nation's official name, the Republic of China, or other "pragmatic names, " which he described as "self-deceiving."
Chen noted that the ROC's U.N. seat has already been taken over by the People's Republic of China and that it is impossible to promote the country's U.N. bid under its official title.

The president also said that in an earlier poll of Americans, 55 percent of Americans said they support Taiwanese membership in the United Nations, and that if a referendum on Taiwan's bid passes next year, that support rate will increase to 70 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Festival celebrates lifting of import ban on Canadian beef

TEXT.P: A Canadian beef festival opened in Taipei Friday to officially celebrate the lifting of an import ban of more than four years on Canadian beef out of concern over mad cow disease.

The Taiwan government's decision to lift the ban is very much appreciated, said George Groeneveld, minister of agriculture and food of the government of Alberta, the province from which 95 percent of Taiwan's imported Canadian beef came from prior to the ban.

Taiwan re-opened its doors to Canadian boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age in a partial lifting June 23, more than four years after an import ban on beef from Canada, the United States, Japan, Britain and several other European countries was announced Dec. 31, 2003 amid fears over the threat of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, also known as mad cow disease.

"The safety of meat products is ensured by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency of the government of Canada, based on scientific principles and consistent with applicable international standards and rules, " said Ron McIntyre, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei.
In 2003, Taiwan was Canada's fifth-largest export market for beef. Overall, Taiwan is Canada's fourth-largest market in Asia for agriculture products, said McIntyre.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vienna Boys Choir to perform in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Vienna Boys Choir has arrived in Taiwan in preparation for seven performances to be staged in northern, central and southern Taiwan from Oct. 27, according to a spokesman for the Lawrence S. Ting Memorial Fund, which is organizing the tour.

At a news conference held Thursday to promote the tour, the choir performed the popular Chinese folk song "Jasmine, " which, along with another Chinese song, will be featured in the program to bring the choir closer to Taiwanese audiences.

Speaking at the news conference, conductor Kerem Sezen said singing in Chinese is easy for the boys compared to the hardships they have to endure during their grueling travel schedule and countless hours of practice.

Sezen said that through physical training and aesthetic cultivation, he finds children's abilities to be beyond imagination. He also expressed hope that Asian audiences will learn more about European musical culture through the beauty of the boys' voices.

A youth ensemble affiliated with the Taiwan-based Syinlu Welfare Foundation, a group dedicated to helping people with mental or physical disabilities, also staged a performance at the news conference to welcome the European choir. Foundation CEO Sung Chin-yi said singing is a good way to help the disabled express their emotions while demonstrating their skills and abilities.
The event organizer will provide free tickets to the Nov. 2 performance at the Taipei National Concert Hall for underprivileged groups.

Founded in 1948, the Vienna Boys Choir is one of the oldest and best known musical organizations in the world. There are approximately 100 choristers between the ages of 10 and 14. The boys are divided into four touring choirs in the names of renowned Austrian composers Mozart, Haydn, Schubert and Bruckner.
The choir will perform works of all four composers, as well as works by Johann Strauss and a variety of Austrian and Taiwanese folk songs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Food Show attracts international buyers

TEXT.P: The upcoming 2007 Kaohsiung Food Show, which focuses on southern Taiwan specialties, has aroused the interest of many international buyers, a spokesman for the fair's organizer said Friday.

The fair will be held at the Kaohsiung Business Exhibition Center in the southern port city of Kaohsiung from Nov. 8-11. It was organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council with authorization of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

According to the spokesman, the fair will include the participation of international buyers from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, China, Singapore, and Indonesia. The Japanese supermarket group Daiei Inc., an Okinawan fruit importer, South Korean aquatic products importers, and Hong Kong fruit importers will come to Kaohsiung during the fair to negotiate trade deals.
The would-be buyers will join more than 100 rounds of procurement trade talks with domestic suppliers during the food show to seek business opportunities, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA adopts measures to stabilize hog and feed prices

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has adopted several measures to stabilize hog and feed prices amid the surge in corn prices in international markets and a glut of pigs in the domestic market, a COA official said Friday.

The official noted that while corn and oil prices have been increasing, hog prices have been dropping, leading to a sharp decline in hog farmers' profits. Some farmers have claimed that they are going to quit raising pigs, he added.
In order to stabilize hog prices, the COA has asked the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) to investigate whether some traders have monopolized the country's cereal market.

In addition, the COA has adopted several measures to remedy the situation, including releasing 50,000 metric tons of unpolished rice as hog feed and asking the Animal Technology Institute Taiwan (ATIT) to help hog farmers replace their feed formula with other cereals.

Other measures include importing of corn from China on a case-by-case basis and increasing corn imports from other countries to help reduce the impact on the local livestock industry, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local banks' non-performing loan ratio drops to 2.16%

TEXT.P: The ratio of non-performing loans incurred by locally-owned had dropped to 2.16 per percent as of the end of September, a decrease of 0.08 percentage points from the end of August, a Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) official said Friday.

The FSC Vice Chairwoman Susan Chang said in a report on the quality of bank assets that the total of loans offered by domestic banks had reached NT$17.68 trillion (US$544 billion) as of the end of September, an increase of NT$21.4 billion over the level at the end of August.
Of the amount, overdue loans totaled NT$381.8 billion, down from the NT$394.8 billion registered at the end of August, with the average of bad loan ratio reaching 2.16 percent.
The overdue loan ratio of domestic banks reached its height at 11.74 percent in 2002, but has been falling ever since, with the ratio falling to 2.8 percent in the third quarter of 2005.
The ratio has oscillated between 2.8 and 2.0 percent since then, with the percentage once dropping to 2.13 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006.
Among the 39 locally-owned banks, 34 had a non-performing loan ratio of under 5 percent, with 26 registering a bad loan ratio of less then 2.5 percent.
Chang stressed that the FSC will continue pushing banks with higher ratios of bad loans to improve their asset quality and financial structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fair Trade Commission to investigate rice price hike

TEXT.P: Officials of the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) said Friday that they will investigate whether there has been any manipulation of rice prices by traders on the local market.

The officials made the announcement after media reports said that rice production has been heavily affected by Typhoon Krosa, which hit Taiwan early this month, resulting in a surge in rice prices, with the price of wet rice rising to NT$5.43 per kilogram in central and southern Taiwan.
The average price of wet rice oscillated between NT$4.51 and NT$5.12 in July.

It was reported that some traders have conspired to increase the price of wet rice in several stages. As a result, dry rice will be far more expensive than wet rice after additional costs of drying and husking are taken into account.

Officials stressed that they would respect rice price hikes if the situation was the result of fair competition or normal market mechanisms. If that is not the case, traders may have violated the fair trade law by forcing up prices through market manipulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier blasts issuing of license to adult TV channel

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the opening of a new free cable adult TV channel could have a negative impact on the younger generation.
Chang made the remarks while fielding questions from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung at the Legislative Yuan.

His remarks came after the Apple Daily recently reported that the National Communications Commission (NCC) , Taiwan's top media regulator, had granted an operating licence to a cable TV system, Star-Winged Corp., to run a new satellite channel to provide free pornographic programs on basic cable TV broadcasting.
Chang said the Executive Yuan has no right to interfere with the NCC's decision to issue the licence because the NCC is independent of the Executive Yuan's jurisdiction.

Noting that as there are many double-income families in Taiwan, it would be impossible for working parents to prevent their children from watching the channel, Hsu demanded to know how the Ministry of the Interior plans to respond to the controversial issue.

Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said his ministry also opposes the NCC's decision from the point of view of protecting children and teenagers, but said it is difficult for the ministry to negotiate with the NCC as it is not under the Cabinet's control.
NCC Chairman Su Yeong-chin defended the issuance of the license, describing it as an individual case and claiming that it is not a new policy nor a free channel.
Su argued that the lawmaker was commenting on exaggerated and false media reports. "There is no point in having a discussion based on wrong information," he added.

According to Su, no R-rated pornographic programs will be permitted to be aired on the new channel and the NCC will issue fines to the operator according to relevant laws in the event of any transgressions.
Later, when fielding questions from ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chen Ying, Su said the NCC issued the license based on existing laws and policies.
He also said the channel will be encoded, which requires the purchase of a set- top decoder box to view its programs.
Su also said that if lawmakers and the public think it is necessary to review the existing laws and policies, the NCC will be "willing to do that."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan business leader in Japan to donate cherry saplings to Chiayi

TEXT.P: A Taiwan business leader in Japan told Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen Friday that he will donate a batch of cherry saplings to further beautify the landscape in the Alishan National Scenic Area.
Kin Man Hayashi, 93, president of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce in Japan, made the pledge to Chen while paying the magistrate a courtesy call at County Hall.
Mayashi, who has resided in Japan for 67 years, said he has found a cherry variety suitable for growing in the mountainous Alishan area.

He noted that although Alishan is already well-known for the blooming of cherry flowers in spring, some of the trees are aging and suffering from disease, and that the young trees he will donate to Chiayi County can inject new vitality to Alishan's beauty.

Chen expressed his appreciation to Mayashi and instructed county government agriculture officials to conduct an evaluation with regard to the environment, the cherry variety, the quantity needed and related quarantine issues.
The Alishan National Scenic Area is well-known for its large numbers of cherry trees of different varieties, including indigenous ones and some varieties from Japan.

The cherry blossom season on Alishan begins March 15, with the blooming of some 1,000 Yoshino cherry trees -- a Japanese variety -- lasting a full month, followed by the blooming of 4,600 cherry trees of other varieties, including Yaebenishidare, Kurile and Taiwan cherries.

DOC.HEADLINE: China urged to allow full access to Taiwanese news Web sites

TEXT.P: The Chinese government should allow its Internet users to gain free access to Taiwan's news Web sites to demonstrate its sincerity toward Taiwan, a Mainland Affairs Council official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun renewed the council's call to China on the issue at a regular news conference.
Liu said there is a serious imbalance in information exchanges between Taiwan and China due to Beijing's tight control over Chinese people's access to Taiwanese news Web sites.
He noted that the distance between Taiwan and China has resulted in different mentalities and living backgrounds on the two sides, which have resulted in cross-strait misunderstandings.
The most direct and effective way for people in China to understand their Taiwanese counterparts is to visit Taiwanese Web sites in addition to visiting Taiwan personally, Liu said.
Citing statistics released by the Chinese government in July, Liu said China has 162 million Internet users, the second-largest number in the world after that of the United States.
The Internet penetration rate in China, however, was a mere 12.3 percent in that month, which is much lower than the world average of 17.6 percent, Liu went on.
Liu also pointed out that the rate has grown rapidly in the past six months and that the increased percentage is close to that of the whole of last year.

Despite the growing need for information in China, the Beijing authorities have a tight grip on local media and present only select and partial images of Taiwan on Chinese media, which he said does not help Chinese people get a complete picture of Taiwan.
To reduce the gap between Taiwan and China, people on both sides need to have long-term and direct exchanges of information, Liu noted.

There are also many Taiwanese people in China who need Internet access to Taiwanese media to know the situation in Taiwan, Liu said, adding that China has no right to deprive them of the right to knowledge and the connection to their home country.

The Chinese government recently formed a special Internet police task force and shut down a number of Chinese Web sites, which Liu said is a disappointing development that shows the world Beijing has not fulfilled its promises made after winning the right to host the 2008 Olympics Games to improve press freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local firm busted for using pirated software

TEXT.P: A multinational electronics company in the northern county of Taoyuan is being probed for allegedly using pirated software with a combined value of over NT$30 million (US$920,527) , a spokesman for the Taiwan chapter of the Business Software Alliance (BSA) said Thursday.

The BSA spokesman urged local firms to attach more importance to the use of legal software and warned corporate employees not to become accomplices in their employers' violation of intellectual property rights (IPR).
The BSA is an organization dedicated to promoting a safe and legal digital world.
The spokesman said IPR protection police raided the headquarters of the company -- which he did not identify -- a day earlier and found unauthorized software installed on the company's computers.
Local prosecutors were questioning the owner of the company and the employees about their roles in the IPR violations, the spokesman went on.
The company has offices in the United States and China and has approximately 100 employees, the spokesman said, noting that the company has been previously awarded the ISO 9001:2000 certification.

Warning that using pirated software can result in criminal and civil charges, the spokesman said the company might have to pay damages of up to NT$1 million for each pirated software license and will also need to purchase legal versions of the software.

Speaking of similar cases in the past, the spokesman noted that enterprise owners often attempt to pass the blame by accusing their employees of illegally downloading pirated software, which some employees have been found guilty of.

The spokesman said the BSA's Taiwan chapter launched an online poll on its Web site Oct. 16 in an effort to raise local office workers' awareness about their role in the use of pirated software at work.
The Web site has received nearly 180,000 visits since then, the spokesman noted.

In addition, he went on, up to 76 percent of the 50,000 office workers who have used the poll to test their likelihood of violating IPR chose to report their companies' failure to use authorized software to the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Raw materials to make 1,000 kg amphetamine seized

TEXT.P: Agents of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) raided an amphetamine lab in Hsinchu City Thursday, where they discovered enough raw materials to produce 1,000 kg of amphetamine with a street value of NT$1 billion, officials in charge of the case reported Friday.

According to the report, the raid was launched by MJIB agents stationed in the southern county of Chiayi and their colleagues from neighboring Yunlin, Tainan and Hsinchu counties at the command of Chiayi County District Prosecutor Tsao Ho-yi. In addition to the factory, a house in the heart of the city was also raided under suspicion of being used as a distribution outlet.
Four suspects were arrested during the raids and were found to be experts in refining amphetamine using a much faster, odor-free method than the conventional technique, according to the report.
During the raid, the inspectors also seized 50 kg of amphetamine with a street value of NT$50 million, as well as equipment used to produce the drugs.
The MJIB task force was continuing its investigation to find other members of the drug ring who escaped capture during the raid, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30% of people do not wash hands before, after visiting hospitals

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) officials urged the public Friday to remember to wash their hands before and after visiting patients in hospitals to prevent infection, as survey results show that more than 30 percent of the public fail to do so.

The officials made the appeal after the release of the results of a survey conducted by the Taiwan Joint Commission on Hospital Accreditation (TJCHA) that show only 47.5 percent of the public wash their hands before and after visiting patients in hospitals.
The DOH and the TJCHA have set the fourth week of October as "Patient Safety Week, " focusing this year on the importance of frequent hand-washing among the general public.

According to the TJCHA survey, 73 percent of the people surveyed believe it unnecessary to wash their hands before having a medical checkup, while 47 percent said they would not remind doctors to wash their hands after attending other patients.
The survey was conducted via telephone among 1,068 adults around Taiwan early this month.

Chang Shan-chwen, director of the division of infectious diseases of National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH), noted that between 80 percent and 90 percent of infections in hospitals are contact infections.
Noting that it is easy for medical personnel to become infection channels, Chang stressed the importance of promoting hand-washing among hospital staff.

Chang said NTUH has been promoting the correct way to wash hands since the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreak of 2003, a move that has caused the infection rate in hospitals to drop from 5.3 percent in 2006 to 4.7 percent at present.

According to a TJCHA report, every square centimeter of children's pants contains 1 billion bacteria, while every square centimeter of a telephone has 164,000 bacteria and every square centimeter of a computer keyboard has 21,000 bacteria.

As hand-washing is the most effective way to prevent infection, TJCHA officials suggested that the public wash their hands with water for at least 40 seconds to 60 seconds, or rub their hands for at least 20-30 seconds with hand sanitizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice prices to remain stable: food agency officials

TEXT.P: Thanks to abundant stocks of rice in state-controlled stockpiles, rice prices on the domestic market will remain stable in the coming months, officials of the Agriculture and Food Agency (AFC) under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said Friday.

The AFC officials made the remarks after local media reported earlier that day that rice prices are expected to increase by some 10 percent from next month -- the latest in a string of price hikes in food, gasoline and daily necessities in recent months.

At present, the government still has stockpiles of around 500,000 tons of rice harvested last year that can be provided at any time to meet local demand if prices increase unreasonably, the officials said, adding that crop prices in October averaged NT$18.21 per kilogram -- 5percent down from the previous year's level.
Despite the fact that rice harvests last year fell short of production targets, bumper crops this year have helped offset the gap, the AFC officials explained.

They stressed that they are closely watching rice price changes on a daily basis and will immediately release stockpiled rice onto the market to protect consumers' interests and ensure fair trade should it become necessary.
Traders will be subject to punishment by the Fair Trade Commission if they are caught manipulating rice prices or hoarding supplies to make extra profit, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers call for better management of key guards' morale

TEXT.P: The government should immediately conduct an evaluation of the mental health of all guards serving in crucial posts where the president and vice president live or work, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Friday.

DPP Legislator Chuang Ho-tzu said armed security guards and bodyguards assigned to protect the national leaders and who are found to be mentally unstable, to have obtained their positions through the efforts of political lobbyists, or who are not up to their jobs should be "retrained."
Chuang made the suggestions in the wake of an incident involving a military guard at President Chen Shui-bian's residence who shot himself with his own pistol early Friday.
The officer, identified as Capt. Lu Tseng-hsiang from the National Security Bureau (NSB), was on guard duty at the presidential residence on Nanchang Road in downtown Taipei when he shot himself.

The officer was immediately rushed to the nearby National Taiwan University Hospital at around 8: 30 a.m. but despite several hours of emergency treatment, the hospital authorities declared him dead at 12:20 p.m.
NSB officials said later in a news release that Lu may have been suffering from depression due to a failed relationship.

Commenting on the latest suicide, Chuang said the NSB, the Coast Guard Administration and other security agencies should draft a set of criteria to help regulate their staff in order to prevent further suicide attempts or fatal shootings.

Chuang spelled out seven points which she claimed would help the agencies draw up guidelines to help monitor staff: Watch their physical strength when they drill; observe their movements and sounds while they are asleep; inspect the amount of food they eat; listen to their tone of voice when they make phone calls; examine their luggage when they leave their barracks; and examine their expressions when they return.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Lin Chin-hsing pointed out that presidential bodyguards are only human and are just as susceptible to depression caused by failed relationships as anyone else. He called for higher-ranking security authorities to pay closer attention to this aspect of the lives of key personnel to reduce the possibility of suicide by bodyguards who have ready access to weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Web site for Myanmar democracy receives great support: VP

TEXT.P: A Web site established to help push for democracy for Myanmar has received more than 20,000 online signatures from supporters, Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

The Web site was established under the framework of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , an international body founded by Lu in 2005 and currently chaired by her with an aim to promote "democracy, peace, and prosperity" in the Asia- Pacific region and the world.
Lu said many parliamentarians from other countries have also posted video announcements showing support for democracy for Myanmar via the Web site.
She expressed hope that the Web site will draw more and more people to speak out for democracy for the junta-ruled Southeast Asian country.

Lu said the DPU will hold a seminar next week to introduce Myanmar's history, political system and economy to let Taiwan people and the international community have a better understanding of the Myanmarese people's efforts in striving for democracy.

The DPU will also invite students from other Asian countries studying in Taiwan to participate in a seminar Nov. 8-9 in which the DPU will introduce Taiwan's democratization and exchange views with the students on democratic developments in Asia.

She said Taiwan's experience with democracy will be beneficial to other Asian countries that are still struggling for their own democratic systems and explained that many Taiwan people who have studied in Japan, America or Europe have been nurtured by those countries' democracies and have later made contributions to Taiwan's democratization.
Lu called on the international community to help Myanmarese refugees and send representatives to better understand their needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan county magistrate recommends plan to upgrade airport

TEXT.P: Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun visited the Legislative Yuan Friday and called for a swift passage of a bill to upgrade the status and functions of the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the country's main gateway.

Speaking at a news conference in the Legislative Yuan, Chu said that the 30 -year-old airport, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, needs to effectively sharpen its competitiveness as its ranking has dropped to 85th place among the world's 136 major airports.

The airport must be made into a legally and professionally incorporated compound comprising a multinational business operations hub, a free trade zone, warehousing and distribution facilities, exhibition centers, tourism hotels, shopping malls and high-tech science park, so as to avoid being shunted aside and again become globally competitive, Chu said.

Driven by that goal, Chu said, he crafted a program to create a "Taoyuan Aviation Park", to be located in a 6,150-hectare land plot adjacent to the airport that could house eight different areas and attract over NT$1.2 trillion (US$37 billion) worth of investment, creating an annual business revenue of at least NT$600 billion and more than 80,000 jobs.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng addressed the occasion, hailing the "Taoyuan Aviation Park" bill prepared and submitted by Chu is an original and creative idea which will not only boost Taoyuan County's development but also galvanize Taiwan's entire economy.

To iron out a comprehensive bill allowing for the building of a state-of-the-art aviation park -- although that task could not possibly be accomplished during his second tenure -- Chu has in recent years traveled to Japan, the United States and South Korea, where he inspected modern airports in search of new ideas, Wang noted.
Wang called for support of legislators from all political parties for the proposal and the rapid passage of the bill before the end of the current legislative session.
To date, 113 legislators, half of the total number of lawmakers, have endorsed the bill, which was referred to the Legislative Yuan Friday afternoon for screening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 200 kg of ketamine seized from container in Keelung

TEXT.P: Law-enforcement personnel have seized more than 200 kg of ketamine from a container in Keelung Port and have arrested seven suspects, a spokesman for the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau said Friday.

The spokesman said agents from a local Marine Affairs Office of the Investigation Bureau, along with customs officials and military police, searched the Keelung container terminal after workers reported seeing suspicious-looking white powder leaking from a container.

They discovered 227.6 kg of ketamine with a street value of NT$100 million in 48 boxes of goods in the suspect container. According to the spokesman, the drugs would have been "enough for consumption by 1 million addicts."

The agents arrested the owner of the cargo but would only identify him by the surname Lin. They later tracked down the mastermind behind the smuggling operation, surnamed Cheng, along with five accomplices.
The suspects were referred to the Keelung Public Prosecutors Office on charges of violating the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act and the Act for the Control and Punishment of Smuggling.

Ketamine, a rapid-acting dissociative anesthetic used on both animals and humans, is being abused by an increasing number of young people as a "club drug." It can produce hallucinogenic effects and impaired perception in a user. It can also elicit an out-of-body or near-death experience and can render the user comatose.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP suggests making offshore islands into transshipment hubs

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu proposed Friday making Taiwan's offshore islands into cross-Taiwan Strait passenger and cargo transshipment hubs so as to offset the lack of direct links between Taiwan proper and China.
Lu made the proposal during a seminar with company representatives at an industrial park in Tucheng City in Taipei County.

Using offshore islands, such as Kinmen and Matsu, to serve as transshipping points between Taiwan proper and China would be a step forward from the existing "mini links," which refer to direct ferry and trade services maintained between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou ports in China's Fujian Province.
As China has not forsworn using force against Taiwan, national security remains a key concern for the government despite the fact that many Taiwan businesses have relocated to China, Lu said.
Currently, more than 71 percent of Taiwan's overseas investment goes to China -- a situation which she said imperils Taiwan.

The local trade and business community has long called for the establishment of full direct transportation, trade and postal links between Taiwan proper and China, and many Taiwan-based companies have moved their operations to China due to that factor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Textile industry production projected at NT$530 billion in 2009

TEXT.P: The textile industry's annual production is expected to reach NT$530 billion (US$16.26 billion) by 2009 as the government is set to invest up to NT$27.78 billion in the coming three years to promote innovation in the industry, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday.

Chang made the remarks at a catwalk show at the National Palace Museum in Taipei City, part of the activities of an annual conference of the International Apparel Federation (IAF) headquartered in the Netherlands, the second time since 2001 that Taiwan has hosted the IAF annual meeting.
Chang pointed out that Taiwan's textile industry has reached an average annual production of NT$460 billion, with an average annual trade surplus of more than US$9 billion.

The industry has maintained its competitiveness in the global market despite the challenges of cheap labor from developing countries and threats posed by high technology manufacturing techniques in advanced countries, Chang said.

The results of a report on global innovation rankings released by the Economist Information Unit predicted that Taiwan will rank sixth in the world and second in Asia in innovation between 2007 and 2011, Chang went on, adding that Taiwan has developed many innovative textile products that have won approval from the rest of the world.
He added that the government also aims to make Taiwan a world leader in the supply of innovative and functional textiles by 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Customs office hopes to have 80 sniffer dogs within 5 years

TEXT.P: The head of the Directorate General of Customs (DGC) expressed his wish Friday that the number of sniffer dogs used by customs offices can be increased from the existing six to 80 in five or six years to reinforce efforts to crack down on drug smuggling.
Of the six sniffer dogs on active duty, DGC Director-General Chien Liang-chi said, two serve with the Kaohsiung Customs Office and the other four work for the Taipei office.
Chien praised the sniffer dogs' excellent performance in cracking drug smuggling attempts at airports.

According to Kaohsiung Customs Office statistics, the combined value of heroin, ketamine and amphetamine seized by customs officials accounted for 7.2 percent of all seized smuggled cargo during the first nine months of this year, making drugs the third-largest smuggled cargo following tobacco/liquor and Chinese agricultural products.
The office attributes the result to increasing demand for drugs, as the population of addicts has been rising for several years, customs officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 Taiwanese entries to join Nuremberg Int'l Invention Exhibition

TEXT.P: A total of 10 Taiwanese inventions are slated to enter the contest at the Nuremberg International Invention Exhibition in Germany set for Oct. 31-Nov. 4, an education official said Friday.
A 13-member Taiwan delegation -- headed by creative inventor Teng Hung-chi, who has been dubbed "Taiwan's Edison" -- is scheduled to depart for Germany Oct. 30 for the event, the official went on.

Teng expressed his gratitude to the central Taiwan office of the Ministry of Education for offering subsidies to the 13 junior high, senior high and college students for their overseas expenditures, including lodging, meals and airfare.
All of the 13 students are likely to clinch medals for their impressive creativity during competitions held alongside the exhibition, Teng said.

The creative entries include a gadget for easily removing contact lenses from users' eyes; a gear to prevent car passengers from getting wet while boarding or alighting in the rain; a helmet with an adjustable buckle to increase the comfort of motorcyclists. Other contraptions feature faucets, containers, umbrellas and aluminum foil bags, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: President Visits Scene and Promises Help
President Bush toured Southern California on Thursday as investigators got down to the work of determining how one sunny fall day last weekend erupted into a 16-fire storm now in its fifth day.
The Wall Street Journal: Bonds' Pricing Is Questioned In Email Trail; Former Trader at RBC Alleges Mismarking Of Plain-Vanilla Issues
Growing distrust about Wall Street's ability to determine accurate prices for securities -- a foundation of the financial system -- isn't confined to esoteric mortgage- backed bonds.
In a series of emails to senior bank executives, a former Royal Bank of Canada trader alleged that some of his colleagues intentionally "mismarked, " or improperly valued, plain-vanilla government agency and corporate bonds in a bid to boost profits at the firm's New York-based investment-banking unit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 27, 2007

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Chen Shui-bian attending the opening ceremony for the 2007 Liudui Carnival and Sports Meet in southern Pingtung County. Date and Time: 10:00 a.m., Saturday, Oct. 27, 2007. Place: Hsinpei Junior High School, Pingtung County. Press Contact: Tel.: 2311-3731. Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 27, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages on the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers and reaches Chingkang Mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to being cracked down on in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, the association's director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express his condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, with more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attending the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan hold their first meeting since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urges Chen to convene a National Unification Council meeting.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces a decision to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.
2001: The 47th congress of the Asia Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) opens at a Auckland, New Zealand hotel with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."
