DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Fire threat to homes diminishes, 6 more bodies are found.
Stubborn fires continued to rage through wilderness areas of San Diego and Orange counties Thursday, and the toll rose with the grim discovery of six more bodies of people caught in the infernos, But the danger to homes and businesses subsided and many of those affected by Southern California's latest natural disaster began taking the first steps toward a return to normalcy. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: Straits Times: $6.3b solar plant to be set up in S'pore by 2010.
A massive $6.3 billion plant for making solar energy products is to be built in Singapore. It is set to be the largest plant of its type in the world.
Lianhe Zaobao: Norway's REC to build world's largest solar plant for S$6.3b.
Norway's Renewable Energy Corporation (REC) has confirmed that it will invest $3 billion Euro (S$6.3 billion^in next five years to build a solar manufacturing plant in Singapore - the largest in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: World energy congress to be held in Rome

TEXT.P: The 20th World Energy Congress will be held Nov. 11-15 in Rome, with the participation of some 3,500 delegates from more than 100 countries, the president of the organizing committee said Friday.

"The energy future in an interdependent world" is the main topic of the congress, which represents a unique opportunity to open debates on world energy issues not only from an industrial development standpoint but also from the sustainable development aspect, and will allow discussion of several issues arising from the new world scenario, according to Chicco Testa.

The congress will focus on social issues the developing and the emerging countries are facing in the international energy market, he noted, adding that discussions will also take place on how to ensure the best sustainable progress for developed countries, such as ensuring not only economic development but also the improvement of energy quality, he said.

Jose Manuel Barroso, president of the European Commission, and Pascal Lamby, director-general of the World Trade Organization, have been invited to deliver keynote speeches at the four-day meeting, which will also include a ministerial forum and 36 seminars and round-table sessions. A total of 144 selected papers will be presented at the meeting.

An exhibition that will run parallel to the meeting will showcase more than 300 enterprises with world-level operations, displaying their products, technological innovations and services related to energy.

The congress, considered the most important energy forum in the world, is held every three years. It is particularly important today, when the world is facing soaring oil prices and worsening environment and climate changes, said Testa.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Draghi: Italian salaries too low.
Bank of Italy Governor Mario Draghi said Friday that Italian salaries were too low and called for moves to lift income and spendings in order to giving the nation's young people a better prospect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor plans to turn Shuinan terminal into R.C. aircraft museum

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu announced Saturday that he wants to develop the remote- control (R.C.) model vehicle industry in his central city and that the first step in this direction will be to build an R.C. airplane museum at the defunct Shuinan Airport terminal.
Hu made the announcement at the opening of the third Taichung aviation festival being held at Shuinan Airport, which drew crowds of visitors on its first day.
In his address, Hu said his idea to develop the industry in Taichung was inspired by the large number of people attending the inauguration ceremony for the two-day festival.

He said the city has enough space and resources for the sector's development, referring to the old terminal of Shuinan Airport, which has been left idle since relocation of the city's commercial flight services to Chingchuankang a few years ago.
The former airport is now part of a local government urban renewal project aimed at constructing a multifunctional urban center on the vast plot of land.
Hu said the local government has two years to take advantage of the empty plot and terminal before work to carry out the new urban development project begins.
He said it could be used as a training area for operating R.C. aircraft, as well as serving as a venue for international R.C. competitions.
The annual festival, now in its third year, was organized by the city government and Thunder Tiger Corp., a leading domestic R.C. vehicle manufacturer.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. has flexible `one China' principle: Taiwan representative
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/27/07 16:21:46 (By Josie Chou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States Joseph Wu said Friday that the United States observes a flexible "one China" policy that is not based on the premise that Taiwan is part of China.

Wu made the remarks when he analyzed Taiwan-U.S. relations from the perspectives of Taiwan's strategic security stance, economic strength and democratic politics and the more complex Taiwan-U.S. relations in the wake of a rising China. He was speaking at the invitation of the Center on Democracy, Development and the Rule of Law of Stanford University in California.

According to Wu, those who lack an understanding of Washington's "one China" policy might think it is identical to that of Beijing "one China" principle. However, they could not be more wrong, he said.
The U.S. has adopted a flexible approach in handling its relations with China and Taiwan, an approach that is not based on the premise that Taiwan is part of China, as advocated by China, said Wu.

According to Wu, the United States observes a "one China" policy with its own interpretation of what it means. He did not elaborate, but could have been referring to the fact that Washington "acknowledges" Chinese advocacy that there is one only China and that Taiwan is part of China, although it does not necessarily accept or embrace Beijing's advocacy, and that the U.S. has always encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resolve their differences through peaceful dialogue.
He dismissed a "peace agreement" overture offered by Chinese President Hu Jintao for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait at the opening of the Communist Party of China National Congress Oct. 15.

Wu also noted that Hu used the word "democracy" 61 times during his speech and proposed conducting negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under the framework of Beijing's "one China" principle.
Wu said the "one China" principle is a pitfall set for Taiwan by China and that Beijing is simply using the rhetoric to suppress Taiwan internationally.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Home is where family bones lie:' KMT candidate

TEXT.P: Home is "the place where the family bones lie," opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday when he voiced his love for Taiwan and his identity with the country.
Ma, a former KMT chairman, was born in Hong Kong in 1950 to parents who were post-war immigrants from China. His father is buried in Taipei.
Addressing the idea of "Taiwan identity, " Ma cited a speech titled "Who are the French? " made by French President Nicolas Sarkozy during his presidential election campaign earlier in this year.
In his speech, Sarkozy said that "what makes us French is not only that we were born in France but also that we choose to stay in France."

Sarkozy is the son of a Hungarian immigrant father and his mother is the daughter of a Greek immigrant. Sarkozy's family "was not born in France but decided to stay in that country because they love France and the people who live there," Ma said.

"They are French people because they chose to fight alongside people living in that land for a better life, " Ma added, asking "why cannot we do what the French can? " referring to bickering between the weishengren -- people who immigrated from China to Taiwan near the end of the Civil War in 1949 and their descendants -- and the benshengren, who came to Taiwan from China hundreds of years ago.

The Republic of China government has existed in Taiwan for 57 years since its relocation by the KMT administration from China in 1949, Ma said, citing a local poet who wrote: "homeland is where a man has stayed for long."

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports of agricultural products to China `pipe dream': VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu claimed Saturday that Taiwan's exports of agricultural produce to China have "proved to be nothing but a pipe-dream" and a "hoax."
According to the vice president, a majority of Chinese people "cannot afford" to buy Taiwan agricultural produce even if the quality is superior.

Lu made the remarks as she visited the opening of an agricultural exhibition in central Taiwan's Yunlin County. The three-day exhibition, which features the latest agricultural machinery, seedlings, and technology exchanges, has attracted more than 300 manufacturers.
She noted that China offers tax-free treatment for certain items of farm produce from Taiwan, which lured a lot of Taiwanese farmers into exporting their premium produce to China.

The Chinese authorities have held promotions for the Taiwanese produce, but Chinese people cannot afford to buy it, while Chinese farmers have simply stolen the brands of Taiwanese agricultural produce, promoting inferior Chinese items as coming from Taiwan.
"Those who have a conscience should not promote the export of agricultural produce to China but should eye the rest of the world by moving toward high-tech agriculture," Lu said.
She said agriculture is no longer a traditional industry and that it should work with technology to upgrade quality, build brand names and pay attention to safety.
"Taiwan has premium agriculture, " she said, adding that although China's farming population is as high as 900 million, they are mostly illiterate.
In comparison, Taiwan's 900,000 farmers are knowledgeable, which gives the country's agriculture the edge, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH mulling setting up national nutrition foundation

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is planning to set up a national nutrition foundation that will conduct a nutrition census and provide nutritional education, a health official said Saturday.

Cheng Huei-wen, director-general of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety, noted that nutrition of the populace is a major indicator of a nation's progress and said the DOH will push for a national nutrition bill to provide the basis for the establishment of a nutrition foundation.

Cheng noted that the DOH has conducted six nutrition censuses since 1981. However, there have been disruptions during these years due to lack of funds, age or ethnic groups, so that the DOH has not been able to match its counterparts in the United States and Japan, which have conducted continuous and comprehensive censuses every year.

He pointed out that the nation's nutrition census and education has to rely on stable financial support, which is why the DOH is now planning to collect 0.01 percent of the turnover of the country's food and nutrition product manufacturers to finance the foundation.

Cheng said the DOH has decided to adopt the premise that "those who use it should pay, " the idea being that the food and nutrition product manufacturers will pass on their extra costs to consumers, so that it will actually be the public that has to pay for the foundation.

He said that based on the combined turnover of food manufacturers of around NT$600 billion in 2006, the DOH can collect NT$60 million a year, which he said will be enough to finance the expenses for a nutrition census and various nutritional education activities.
A continuous census on public nutrition is urgently needed, Cheng said, noting that it will allow the DOH to see the changes in public nutrition.

He noted that eating habits have undergone dramatic changes over the past decade, caused by the number of people eating out surging and newly arrived immigrants introducing their own cooking styles, while society is ageing and fewer children are being born, all of which are playing roles in the changes of public health.

He said the DOH is hammering out the draft of a national nutrition bill and estimated that it can be sent to the Executive Yuan by the end of the year and that the Legislative Yuan can start to review the draft bill in the new session that will begin next February.

DOC.HEADLINE: No disciplinary measures to be taken before probe into guard's death

TEXT.P: No disciplinary measures will be taken prior to the completion of a thorough probe into the suicide of a security guard at President Chen Shui-bian's official residence, a Presidential Office spokesman said Saturday.

Lee Nan-yang, director of the Public Affairs Department of the Presidential Office, made the remarks after a local newspaper reported that the National Security Bureau (NSB) held a meeting late Friday to discuss discipline for officials accountable for the security incident sparked by the suicide of Capt. Lu Tseng-hsiang earlier that day.
According to the Apple Daily, NSB Director Shi Hwei-yow proposed during the meeting that he himself should be disciplined over the tragic incident.

Moreover, the paper claimed, Maj. Gen. Chi Tai-lai, a division chief with the NSB's special service center, will be given a demerit and Fu Yung-mao, the Presidential Office's deputy chief aide-de-camp, who concurrently heads the security office at Chen's official residence, will also be subject to administrative discipline.
The NSB, which is responsible for presidential security, has made no announcement regarding disciplinary measures.
Asked about his views on the Apple Daily report, Lee said the NSB and military prosecution authorities are investigating the case.

"The cause of the incident and other relevant details must first be clarified, " Lee said, adding that the NSB will hammer out disciplinary measures only after it has ascertained all the relevant details.

Hsu Li-meng, deputy commander of the NSB's Special Service Center, echoed Lee's views, saying that the NSB will not deal with disciplinary issues until after military prosecutors have finalized their investigation and relevant legal proceedings have been completed.

He also dismissed a rumor that the scene of the suicide was compromised before the arrival of investigators. "Security personnel called the 119 emergency line for help immediately after the incident and the scene was kept intact to facilitate the investigation by military prosecutors," he added.

Hsu further rebutted speculation that Lu committed suicide because of a heavy workload -- standing guard for four shifts during the day and two at night -- and that he might have been bullied by senior security guards.
"The reality is that Lu worked for four hours during the day and two hours at night," Hsu said, adding that while Lu was young, he was by no means a rookie.
Lu, 27, a military police officer, shot himself to death at 8:35 a.m. Friday while on duty at the president's official residence near the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei.

"From our preliminary investigation, Lu shot himself because of difficulties in a relationship, " the NSB said in a press statement issued shortly after he was pronounced dead at National Taiwan University Hospital.

Meanwhile, President Chen confirmed during a community outreach tour in the southern county of Pingtung Saturday that he was in his official residence when the incident took place, although neither he nor his wife heard the gunshot.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pop group to perform for Japanese, South Korean fans

TEXT.P: A performance by local pop group F4 for nearly 5,000 fans from Japan and South Korea will take place at the main stadium of National Taiwan University Sunday, the Tourism Bureau said Saturday.
Tourism officials estimated that the fans will bring in at least NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) in tourism revenue.

The officials said the fans have come mostly on package tours, paying an average of NT$20,000 apiece. In addition to watching the performance, they will also be taken to various scenic spots around the country.
The bureau has also prepared limited edition notebooks and passport holders featuring the F4 members, as well as manuals on backpacking in Taiwan.

Sunday's F4 performance will be the second sponsored by the Tourism Bureau, following on the success of the first one in April, which brought 4,000 Japanese and 1,000 South Korean fans to see their idols.
Sunday's performance will be by attended 4,100 Japanese fans and around 500 South Korean fans, they said.

F4, originally four little-known actors, shot to fame after their appearance in a TV drama titled The Meteor Garden that began broadcasting in April 2001. The four members were cast in the drama as handsome and arrogant students from one of the richest and most influential families in Taiwan.
The band members have been invited by the Tourism Bureau to serve as Taiwan's tourism ambassadors in Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job fair in Taichung County helps 1,400 people find work

TEXT.P: About 1,400 people were hired Saturday at a job fair organized by the Taichung county government that attracted 42 companies seeking employees.
Over 5,000 job seekers visited the fair, county officials said.

The enterprises seeking new blood included 13 high tech companies such as AU Optronics Corp., Rexchip Electronics and Siliconware Precision Industries Co., as well as businesses in the fields of steel refining, precision machinery, pharmaceuticals and services, according to the county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese yacht makers attend international boat show in U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's booth at the 48th Fort Lauderdale International Boat Show has drawn many visitors since the trade fair opened in the U.S. city Thursday, Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) officials said Saturday.
The booth was set up by a delegation of 19 Taiwanese yacht makers organized by TAITRA, a semi-official trade promotion organization.

Taiwan used to be world famous for yacht manufacturing, with the number of vessels exported overseas reaching 1,755 in 1987, the TAITRA officials said. They added, however that exports had fallen to just 228 boats in 1994, while the number of yacht manufacturing-related businesses had dropped from more than 100 to just a little over 10.
They said the recession continued until just a few years ago, when the sector performed a number of business reforms in order to upgrade.

According to TAITRA statistics, U.S. shipping industry imports totaled US$1.4 billion in 2006, with Canada, Italy, Taiwan, Mexico and Britain serving as the top five sources of imports. The five countries took a 74 percent U.S. market share, the tallies show.
However, there are still many trade opportunities in that huge market, the officials said.
The Fort Lauderdale boat show will run through Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chechnya issue discussed at Taipei seminar

TEXT.P: Hundreds of Taiwan citizens attended a forum Saturday that focused on Chechnya, an autonomous republic of Russia that sought independence, and went home with a better understanding of events in the Central Asia and the cruelty of war.

The forum, titled "The Chechnya You Don't Know, " screened a documentary on Chechnya before a speech by Erkin Ekrem, who once taught in Taiwan and is now a history professor at Turkey's Hacettepe University.
The independence movement in Chechnya spans over 200 years against a complicated background of ethnicity, religion, geopolitics and political control of the Russian Federation, said Ekrem.

Russia will not tolerate Chechnya independence because of the autonomous republic's important strategic location and its rich oil resources, Ekrem said. Russia also fears a "domino effect" of independence movements among its 21 autonomous republics, he added.
He said international support of the Chechnya independence movement took a downturn after Chechen separatists began a string of suicide attacks and bombings in Moscow in recent years.

Since the first and second Chechen wars from 1994-2000, during which an estimated 300,000 Chechens were killed, there has been reconstruction and rebuilding in Chechnya, and the Russian government has regained control of the region. However, future unrest remains an issue, said forum moderator Wang Sing- shu, a professor at the Graduate Institute of Russian Studies of National Chengchi University.

Responding to a question from the audience, Ekrem doubted that a better economy will stop Chechnya from seeking independence because " nowadays, terrorists come from all walks of life, not just from poor families."
"It's all about survival. For the Chechens, survival means an independent country. For Russia, it means the federation cannot afford to lose Chechnya, " Wang summed up.

The forum was among a series of events organized by the Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation, which tries to raise Taiwanese citizens' understanding of international affairs. Upcoming forums are scheduled to discuss Cuba, Israel- Palestine relations and the Malay peninsula.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts DPP's efforts to resurrect Hakka culture

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian touted his ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) long-term devotion to preserving and resurrecting Hakka language and culture Saturday, saying that the DPP's efforts in this regard dates back to the 20th Century.

Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at the opening of an annual athletic event at Hsinpei Junior High School in Hsinpei township in the southern county of Pingtung, known locally as the Liutui Hakka Sports Meet, which was initiated 43 years ago to promote unity and harmony among the 12 Hakka communities in Pingtung and neighboring Kaohsiung County.

According to Chen, who doubles as DPP chairman, Taiwan's first Hakka language teaching materials were compiled by the Pingtung county government in 1990 when Su Tseng-chang, the DPP's vice presidential candidate for the 2008 presidential election, was at the county's helm.
In 1991, Chen said Su further designated the county's Wanluan Elementary School to serve as the model for Hakka teaching among young schoolchildren.
During his own tenure as Taipei mayor from 1994-1998, Chen said he organized the city's first-ever Hakka Festival, which included a Hakka-themed symposium.

"The seminar was also the first of its kind ever held in Taiwan," Chen said, adding that he felt regret after the then-opposition-controlled Taipei City Council killed the budget for opening a Hakka radio station.
Since he took over the presidency in May 2000, Chen said his administration has devoted even more energy and resources to promote Hakka language and culture.

Besides constructing the Liutui Hakka Culture Park in Pingtung County's Changchih township, Chen said a similar Hakka culture park will also be built in the northern county of Miaoli, also a Hakka-dominated region.

Noting that Hakka is the world's third dialect survived through strenuous government efforts after Maori dialects in Australia and Welsh English in Wales, a constituent part of the United Kingdom, Chen said construction of Liutui and Miaoli Hakka culture parks underlines his administration's resolve to turn Taiwan into an international hub for study and promotion of Hakka culture and language.

Chen further said the DPP, as Taiwan's first indigenous political party, is committed to promote Hakka cultural renaissance. "As DPP members have a deep affection for all endemic things, our commitment to preserving and reviving glory of Hakka culture will not be just an electoral campaign gimmick," he stressed.
More than 3,000 people took part in this year's Liutui Sports Meet, which include contests in many folk games as well as dancing and martial art performances.

Later in the day, Chen traveled to Changchih township to tour the Liutui Hakka Culture Park where he joined with many schoolchildren in making Hakka-style handicraft items, including oil-paper umbrellas.
The Liutui Hakka Culture Park will be built in three phases and it has been opened for commercial operations on a trial basis since Oct. 20 following the completion of first-phase construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: From CIA Jails, Inmates Fade Into Obscurity
On Sept. 6, 2006, President Bush announced that the CIA's overseas secret prisons had been temporarily emptied and 14 al-Qaeda leaders taken to Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. But since then, there has been no official accounting of what happened to about 30 other "ghost prisoners" who spent extended time in the custody of the CIA.
The Washington Times: Putin likens missile plan to Cold War
President Vladimir Putin yesterday evoked one of the most dangerous confrontations of the Cold War to highlight Russian opposition to a proposed U.S. missile defense system in Europe, comparing it to the Cuban missile crisis of 45 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Merrill Lynch Weighs Ouster of Top Officer
The board of Merrill Lynch, its frustration mounting over the brokerage firmzs credit losses and the decision-making of its embattled chief executive, E. Stanley OzNeal, has begun to actively consider whether to replace him and with whom, according to people briefed on the boardzs deliberations.
The Wall Street Journal: Merrill Board Weighs the Fate Of CEO O'Neal
Directors at Merrill Lynch & Co. were debating the fate of embattled Chief Executive Stan O'Neal in the wake of this past week's $8. 4 billion in write- downs and an unauthorized overture to Wachovia Corp., people familiar with the matter said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. membership crucial to national identity: DPP candidate

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs U.N. membership to underline its national identity and gain a decent status in the international community, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate said Saturday.

Speaking at a campaign rally in Hsinchuang, Taipei County, Frank Hsieh said that just like a newborn child who must be registered with a household registration office to obtain various welfare benefits and an identification card, a country needs to join the United Nations to obtain access to many other key international organizations and activities.

Rebutting main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's accusation that he does not care about the economy and popular livelihoods while placing excessive emphasis on the U.N. membership bid and other political issues, Hsieh said he has long made it clear that in his political platform, the economy is as important as national pride and dignity.

As a presidential candidate, Hsieh said he must outline his visions for long- term national development. "If we do not talk about pride and dignity and only focus on the economy, we could become Hong Kong and Macau whose only goal in life is to make money, " he claimed.

Noting that Taiwan's exclusion from the United Nations and its affiliated agencies, such as the World Health Organization, has compromised basic human rights of the 23 million people of Taiwan, Hsieh said he feels obliged to push for Taiwan's U.N. bid to arouse public awareness of Taiwan's separate status and identity.

"We have our own core values and national identity. We should not blindly follow the path imposed by outside forces; otherwise, we'll risk losing our unique identity. Without a sense of national identity, we could become slaves of an alien power, " Hsieh told a full house of enthusiastic supporters.
Hsieh further said he envisioned an economy where happiness is the ultimate goal and economic development is complemented by social justice.
The campaign rally at the Hsinchuang Stadium marked the first time that Hsieh and his running mate Su Tseng-chang have stumped together in Taipei County where Su was twice elected its magistrate.

President Chen Shui-bian also addressed the rally, accusing Ma, Hsieh's campaign rival, of having played a negative role in Taiwan's strive for democracy and political reform in the 1970s through 1990s.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 28, 2007

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate's Japan visit remains in pipeline: spokesman

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate's plan to visit Japan is still in the works, a campaign aide said Saturday.
Su Chun-pin, spokesman for Ma Ying-jeou's campaign office, made the remarks after Japan's Jiji Press news agency reported the same day that Ma is scheduled to visit Japan Nov. 13-15.
The Japanese news agency quoted unidentified KMT sources as saying that Ma plans to visit several Japanese cities, including Kyoto, Osaka, Yokohama and Tokyo, next month.

During the visit, Ma will meet with Japanese politicians and deliver speeches on his policy visions, the report said, adding that Ma wants to underline the importance he attaches to relationship with Japan through his visit.

Responding to the report, Su said Ma's campaign staff have indeed been in talks with the Japanese side on arranging for Ma to visit Japan, one of Taiwan's most important trading partners, in the near future. Nevertheless, he said, the travel plan is still in the works.
"We'll publicize them when the date and other technical details are fleshed out," Su added.

If the travel plan materializes, it will be Ma's first visit to Japan since he formally became earlier this year the KMT's standard bearer in the next presidential election slated for March 22, 2008. He last visited Japan in July 2006.
Meanwhile, Japanese sources told CNA that Ma's rival from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Frank Hsieh, originally planned to visit Kyoto in November, but the plan has been canceled.

According to the sources, Hsieh's alma mater, Kyoto University, had arranged for Hsieh to deliver an address Nov. 12. However, the sources said, the speech invitation has been dropped. Sources close to the Hsieh campaign said it remains uncertain whether he will visit Japan in the near future. Hsieh has a doctoral degree in law from Kyoto University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 28, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
2001: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines begins operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Big subsideies for treating hepatitis
The health minister said Saturday that the government will set up a seven-year subsidy program worth 100 billion to 200 billion Yen next March so it can double the number of hepatitis B to C patients treated with interferon each year to 100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Comelec gets P465 M for elections
The Commission on Elections (Comelec) said yesterday that the Department of Budget and Management (DBM), headed by Secretary Rolando G. Andaya Jr., has granted its request for the release of R465 million for the transportation allowance of public school teachers who will serve as chairmen and members of the boards of election tellers (BETs) that will conduct the voting and counting of votes in 238,000 clustered precincts set up for the Oct. 29, 2007 barangay and Sangguniang Kabataan (SK) elections.
The Philippine Daily InquirerG Anti-poverty job for Estrada?
MANILA, PhilippinesXWill a government post be open to Citizen Erap? A day after former President Joseph Estrada won executive clemency and reclaimed his freedom, Secretary Cerge Remonde yesterday said the government and the ousted leader could "work together" to fight poverty in the last three years of President Macapagal-Arroyo's term.
The Philippine StarG Erap adjusting to normal life
Released from detention when he was granted unconditional pardon by President Arroyo, former President Joseph Estrada is still adjusting to his newfound freedom.
The Manila TimesG Incineration: Solution or threat?
In 1995, the Department of Health, through a P504-million loan extended by Bank Austria, acquired 26 incinerators to help improve the management of medical wastes in hospitals that the department controls in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Foreclosures spread to state's affluent.
Californians lost their homes to foreclosure statewide hit a new high of 24,209, besting the previous record by 39% at the third quarter, according to DateQuick Information System. Default notices--the first step toward foreclosure--rose to 72,571 for the three months ended Sept. 30, breaking a record set in 1996. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan, U.S. relations in good shape: Taiwan envoy
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 27 (CNA) 10/28/07 15:32:18 (By Josie Chou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the United States are in good shape, even though the two sides do not always agree on all issues, Republic of China Representative to the United States Joseph Wu said Saturday.

Speaking at a gathering to mark the sixth conference of the Taipei-based Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace, Wu reassured those who had come from over the world to attend the conference that "Taiwan is on good terms with the United States."

Wu said that although Taiwan and the U.S. have "differing stances" on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan, he claimed that the U.S. "will accept" the U.N.-bid referendum that President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party are pushing as a way for Taiwanese people to express their desire for democracy and freedom.

In the future, he predicted, no matter whether the DPP-initiated U.N.-bid referendum or a referendum planned by the main opposition Kuomintang on the ROC's re-entry into the U.N. succeeds, the U.S. will perceive Taiwan from a different viewpoint that will be conducive to mutual understanding and communication between the two countries.
According to Wu, as one in five high-technology engineers working in San Francisco's Bay Area are Taiwanese, this proves the close ties between Taiwan and the United States.

He urged Taiwan expatriates in the United States to spare no efforts to push the U.S. administration and business sector to begin talks with Taiwan on the signing of a bilateral free trade agreement so that Taiwan can enjoy equal trade opportunities as those enjoyed by other countries.

Wu also noted that China has not relented in its oppression and containment of Taiwan in the international community, which he said has led Taiwan to strive to change its official name, which he said should be Taiwan rather than ROC, and to seek global publicity about "Taiwan identity."
He said that if Taiwan relents in these efforts, the island will risk becoming a part of China sooner or later, as Beijing has always claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improved quake detection system should allow for earlier alerts

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has continued to improve its earthquake detection system and has predicted that by the end of 2008, it will be able to detect a magnitude 4.0 or stronger earthquake and issue notification in 35 seconds, CWB sources said Sunday.

Taiwan suffered its deadliest earthquake in five decades Sept. 21, 1999, when a magnitude 7.3 temblor struck central Taiwan, leaving 2,415 people dead and more than 10,000 injured, and causing immeasurable damage to property and infrastructure islandwide.
At that time, it took the CWB Seismology Center 102 seconds to fully grasp the magnitude of the devastating earthquake and issue a notification, center officials said.

But with strenuous efforts made by staff at the center to develop instant detection and automatic calculation systems for earthquakes in recent years, the time the weather bureau takes to notify of earthquakes of magnitude 4.0 or stronger has been remarkably reduced, the CWB seismologists said.
The precision rates on the seismic intensity and location of quake epicenters have also been raised significantly, they noted.
The weather bureau hopes that quicker reports on strong tremors will help alert the public earlier and "thus reduce seismic damage."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate challenged to disclose source of campaign fund

TEXT.P: The campaign office of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh challenged opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou Sunday to explain where his "huge campaign fund" comes from.
Chao Tien-lin, a spokesman for Hsieh's campaign headquarters, claimed that Ma has spent nearly NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) on seven TV commercials and numerous radio and printed advertisements.

Ma should explain how he can afford such expensive ads run with such high frequency and whether they were financed with money from the KMT's ill-gotten assets, many of which have been sold only recently, Chao said.

Claiming that the DPP presidential ticket of Hsieh and former Premier Su Tseng- chang has spent less than NT$20 million on campaigning, Chao alleged that the ruling party is fighting an "asymmetric campaign" against the KMT.
According to Chao, the KMT has netted some NT$25.3 billion by liquidating some of its ill-gotten assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Beer to expand overseas markets

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTLC) plans to sell its star product, Taiwan Beer, to the U.S. and Canadian markets and will set up a liaison office in China to promote it, the company's star product, TTLC Chairman Martin Tsai said Saturday.

In the face of stiff competition from imported beer, Taiwan Beer nonetheless maintains a domestic market share of approximately 80 percent thanks to the development of new product lines and successful marketing strategies, according to Tsai.

Tsai made the remarks while addressing the Branding Taiwan Forum 2007 held in Taipei, which also featured speeches by Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Hochen Tan and ZyXEL Communications Corp. Chairman Chu Shun-i, who shared their experiences in brand building.

Noting the significance of marketing tactics, Tsai said that when the government opened the market to imported beer in 1987, Taiwan Beer's market share dropped sharply to 72 percent from 99 percent during the initial period.

However, the company then developed the new Gold Medal Taiwan Beer brand in 2003 and later hired entertainers and baseball players to tout the brand name among young people, Tsai said. He added that the marketing strategy proved successful, as the new brand's market share has jumped to 23 percent in just four years, making it the second-biggest brand after Taiwan Beer in Taiwan's beer market.

Building on this success, the company is planning to expand its overseas markets in addition to its operations in Japan and South East Asia, Tsai went on, adding that a liaison office in China will soon open if approved by the Chinese government.

Tan, meanwhile, said the key to a successful brand lies in quality, business scale and customized services. He added that the success of innovative products depends on cooperation between manufacturers and distributors, as well as close ties among various industries and government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai beauty wins Miss Young International 2007-2008

TEXT.P: Miss Thailand Vasana Wongbuntree emerged from among 25 international contestants Saturday as the winner of Miss Young International 2007-2008 in the finals of the beauty pageant in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

Wongbuntree, 23, received the crown from Paulina Camacho, Miss Ecuador and Miss Young International 2006-2007. She will spend the next year visiting charity organizations around the world and use her title to help children living in poverty.
Andressa Ramirez Penteado from Brazil and Taiwan's representative Lee Yan-jin were crowned as first and second runners-up, respectively.

Wongbuntree also won the Best National Costume award, while Liu Xiao-ou, 21, from China -- a student in Canada -- won the Most Photogenic award. The Miss Friendship award went to Australia's Jane Lundmark.

The awards presented in the previous week included the Best Smile award for Nguyen Ai Chau from Vietnam, the Best Skin award for Sophie Elizabeth Jones from the United Kingdom, and the Best in Long Gown award for Lee of Taiwan, who also captured the title of Miss Disco-Queen.
The Miss Young International beauty pageant began 37 years ago. The beauty contest's stated aim is to "seek representatives to increase young people's awareness of sensitive social issues."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan brands can shine globally with joint efforts: premier

TEXT.P: Taiwanese brands can shine in the global market and are likely to become one of the top 10 global brands with the concerted efforts of the government and private sector, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung claimed Saturday.
Chang made the remarks while making an address on the second day of the Branding Taiwan Forum 2007 held in Taipei by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council.
He said the forum gathers experts from academia, industry and government to engage in discussions and help lay the foundation for new ideas on "branding Taiwan."
Only through establishing their own brand names can Taiwan businesses strengthen their products' competitiveness and made inroads into international markets, according to Chang.

He said the Executive Yuan has earmarked NT$1.6 billion (US$48.04 million) over the past seven years for measures to help local industries build global brand names. As a result, in 2006, the value of Taiwan's top 10 brands reached US$5.2 billion, up from US$3.5 billion in 2003, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of gun crimes on decline: Interior Ministry

TEXT.P: The number of gun crimes handled by law enforcement agencies around the country totaled 331 in the first nine months of this year, down by a substantial 30 percent, or 135 cases, from the year before, Ministry of the Interior (MOI) officials said Sunday.
Most of the cases involved robbery, homicide, extortion, kidnapping, offenses against personal liberty, rape, and assault and battery, in that order, MOI officials said.

Of the total, 281 were solved with the perpetrators arrested, marking a crackdown rate of 85 percent, a figure that is 14 percent higher than the one posted for the same period of 2006, the officials noted.
One hundred and fifty cases, or 45 percent, involved robbery and 114 involved homicide, they added.

Taipei County in northern Taiwan had the largest number of armed crimes in the January-September period, with 73 cases, followed by the northern county of Taoyuan, with 35 cases and the southern county of Pingtung, with 22 cases. Taipei and Kaohsiung cities each had 18 such cases.
According to police statistics, most of the weapons and ammunition seized during crackdowns were from Taipei City and the central city of Taichung.

A total of 1,850 guns of various types were seized in the January-September period, down by roughly 20 percent year-on-year. Locally made or modified guns made up the bulk of those confiscated, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Semiconductor industry to account for 18 percent of global output

TEXT.P: The production capacity of Taiwan's semiconductor industry this year is likely to account for 18 percent of the total global output, the first time it will have surpassed the United States to take second place in the world after Japan, an analyst from the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said Sunday.

Peng Kuo-chu said that since 2,000, chip makers and the IC industry have played the main roles in the capacity expansion of Taiwan's semiconductor industry, adding that Taiwan and South Korea have the greatest number of 12 inch wafer plants and that their production capacities have increased most rapidly in the world.

Peng predicted that in the fourth quarter, the production capacity of Taiwan's 12 inch wafer fabs will reach 590,000 units, a 16 percent increase over the previous quarter. He forecast that in two years, five such fabs will each post a quarterly growth rate of more than 10 percent.

Although Japan's semiconductor industry will maintain its top position in terms of production capacity worldwide, its production value is forecast to drop to only 24 percent of the total this year, according to Peng.
The production capacity of South Korea's semiconductor industry is forecast at 17 percent of the global total, the same level as the United States, with which it will share third place in the world.

With the aggressive capacity expansion in Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and China, the ratio of the output of Asia's semiconductor industry is expected to reach 47 percent of the global total, Peng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA takes further action against counterfeiting, piracy

TEXT.P: Intellectual property rights police under the National Police Agency (NPA) took further action last week against counterfeiting and piracy, seizing pirated goods worth NT$640 million (US$19.71 million), an NPA spokesman said Sunday.
The spokesman said the Oct. 22-25 sweep against counterfeit and pirated goods was the fourth crackdown enforced by IPR police since early April.

He said that during the four-day sweep, police nabbed 581 suspects involved in 488 cases of IPR infringement, including operators of a Web site that allowed its 130,000 members to download 160 music albums and over 300 movies free, infringing upon the rights of the copyright holders.

The spokesman said added that in addition to hitting Web sites, the sweep also took place simultaneously in various cities and townships, covering stores, factories, night markets, warehouses and container terminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments urged to impose sewage charges

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan is urging local governments to impose fees on users of their sewage systems to replenish government funding for the expansion of the country's sewage network, according to a report issued by the council Sunday.

Noting that the government has spent over NT$30 billion (US$924.21 million) on the construction of the sewage system over the last three years, the report said most of the users of the system do not pay for it, while the government has to use its budget for the prevention of water pollution.
The report said the rate of treated waste water, including industrial effluent, in Taiwan had grown to 37.33 percent by September 2007 from 17.8 percent in 2002.

That figure is relatively low in comparison with the 2004 figures of 80 percent for Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea, and more than 95 percent for the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Switzerland and Germany, the report said, citing statistics carried in the 2007 World Competitiveness Yearbook compiled by the Lausanne, Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development.

However, the report said, the budget the government can set aside for expanding the sewage network to the whole island is far less than needed, which helps explain why the network covers only 16.76 percent of the country's households.
It is for this reason, the report said, that the CEPD is urging local governments to levy sewage fees on those who are connected to the network.
Taipei City is the only city in Taiwan that charges sewage fees along with water rates, said the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dispute rages over range of Taipei magistrate's authority

TEXT.P: A dispute between Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang continued to rage Sunday, with Chou challenging Lee to debate the matter in public only to have his challenge rebuffed by the minister.

Lee said there is no point arguing with Chou in public, as the promotion and appointment of police officers lies squarely within the authority of the National Police Administration according to the law, so that as a magistrate, Chou simply does not have the right to promote or appoint, irrespective of the fact that Taipei County was upgraded to a quasi-special municipality Oct. 1.

However, Chou, who tried to promote 140 middle-ranking police officers in his county only to have his promotions decreed null and void by the Ministry of the Interior, argued that his power to control police appointments and promotions should be the same as that of his counterparts in the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
He challenged Lee to explain in a public debate Wednesday why the chief of a quasi-special municipality cannot have the same power enjoyed by other special municipality chiefs.

In a related development that same day, police on Kinmen and in Nantou and Yunlin counties signed a public letter to support the Ministry of the Interior in the dispute, claiming that the promotions attempted by Chou were unfair and would disrupt the well-established order of promotions in the national police system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Divorced Chinese woman died with two others in her room

TEXT.P: A divorced Chinese woman and two others were found died Sunday in her bedroom at a cargo transportation company in Chiayi, central Taiwan, according to local police.

The woman Xu Jianchong, 34, worked as a handyman at the cargo transportation company after she was divorced from her Taiwanese husband four years ago, and lived alone in a room at the back of the company. Her body was found lying on a sofa, with her underpants around her ankles while the two other deceased were lying on a bed and there were ashes of burned out charcoal in a lead bucket in the room, said police.

The police cited the owner of the company, identified only by his surname of Wu, as saying that the two other deceased were 32-year-old woman Chang Yu-hui , and Chang's five-year-old boy child Chang Ting-wei. They came to visit Xu a couple of days ago and had since stayed with her.
The owner said he went to his company Sunday afternoon after a hiatus of two days and found Xu's room was locked inside. He opened the door with a backup key and found the three bodies.
Police said they could not ruled out the possibility of foul play in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 29, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
2001: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance approves an application from Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. -- the second-largest banking group in Japan and the world -- to upgrade its local representative office to a branch office.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."

DOC.HEADLINE: CSIST denies launching nuclear weapons program

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has never ordered the Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology (CSIST) to develop nuclear weapons, the head of the military- affiliated institute said Monday.

CSIST President Gong Chia-cheng said that the Cabinet's Atomic Energy Council has since 1988 been in charge of matters related to the research and development of nuclear applications, adding that the applications are all intended for peaceful purposes.

Gong further said that the institute has no plans, related talent or facilities to engage in the research and development of any nuclear weapons programs, and the institute has never received any order from Chen to do so.

Gong made the remarks when he was asked by reporters about a recent claim by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Su Chi that Chen has recently ordered the CSIST to begin developing nuclear weapons, including nuclear warheads.
Su claimed he overheard the information from a heavyweight ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator who disagreed with Chen's move.
Chen has denied Su's claim, giving his guarantee that "there is no nuclear missile in Taiwan" and that the DPP administration "is not going to develop any nuclear missiles."

DOC.HEADLINE: 26 percent of disposable chopsticks not properly packaged

TEXT.P: Twenty-six percent of disposable chopsticks randomly selected from around Taipei City for examination were found to be not properly packaged or labeled, the Taipei City Department of Health reported Monday.

Eight out of the 31 randomly-selected disposable chopstick samples were substandard in terms of packaging -- either failing to indicate on the chopsticks' outer plastic wrapping the manufacturer's name and address or the chopsticks' production and expiration dates, said Chiang Yu-mei, a section chief at the department in charge of drug and food safety.

Chiang said most of the suppliers and manufacturers of the poorly-packaged disposable chopsticks are based in Taipei County. Owners of these operations could face fines of up to NT$150,000 (US$4,601) in accordance with food safety laws.

Meanwhile, according to Chiang, six out of the 18 disposable chopstick samples were found to contain sulfur dioxide residue -- ranging from 9.3 parts per million to 27.8 ppm. The sulfur dioxide residue content, however, was far lower than the maximum acceptable level of 500 ppm that the Cabinet-level Department of Health has set, he added.
Chiang suggested that before using disposable chopsticks, consumers should place the chopsticks in hot water for a few minutes to remove most of the sulfur dioxide residue.
She noted that long-term exposure to sulfur dioxide can cause skin rashes, negatively affect pulmonary function or lead to chronic bronchitis.

Taiwan imports roughly 5 billion pairs of chopsticks a year, with imports from China accounting for 40 percent of the total. About 5 million pairs of chopsticks are used in Taiwan every day, according to the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ratio of optimistic manufacturers down: survey

TEXT.P: The ratio of Taiwan businesses with a positive outlook on the manufacturing sector has decreased owing to concerns over fluctuations in raw material prices, according to the results of a survey released Monday by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

The survey, conducted in September on the business climate for the manufacturing sector, found that only 26.3 percent of the respondents think conditions will improve over the next six months, down from 39.4 percent in an August survey.

A total of 18.6 percent of the respondents predicted that conditions will be worse over the next six months, down slightly from 19.1 percent in the previous month. Meanwhile, 55.1 percent said they think conditions will remain the same, up from 41.5 percent in August.
The composite business climate index for the manufacturing sector stood at 123.21, up 1.61 points from a revised 121.60 in the previous month.
Meanwhile, the composite business climate index for the service sector registered 115.27 in September, up 0.45 from a revised 114.82 in the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reaffirms benefits of free kindergarten education

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian recognized Monday the contribution that a new Ministry of Education program of offering free one-year kindergarten education has made to low-income families.

Speaking during a visit to a kindergarten run by the Chienchen Elementary School in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Chen said the new program -- launched Aug. 1 this year for low-income families with children aged under 5 -- has greatly helped alleviate the financial burden on young couples with children who are generally not faring very well financially.

Chen said that since Aug. 1, 38 preschool kids from low-income families in the Chienchen District area in Kaohsiung City have been admitted to study at the Chienchen Elementary School's affiliated kindergarten for free.

"The program has prevented kids from poor families from losing the education battle at the starting line -- enabling them to receive normal education on an equal footing with their peers from well-off families," Chen said.

Under the program, five-year-olds from families around the nation with an annual income of less than NT$300,000 (US$9,259) are entitled to receive free kindergarten education as part of the government's efforts to address the issue of declining birth rates in the country and help reduce the financial burden on families with children.
Meanwhile, five-year-olds from families with an annual income ranging from NT$300,000 to NT$600,000 are entitled to attend kindergarten without having to pay tuition fees.

Some 109,000 kids are expected to benefit from the program, which forms the first-phase of an Executive Yuan project to financially assist children from low-income or disadvantaged families. The program will cost the government about NT$2.5 billion a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Salary hikes for execs of state firms unrelated to elections: CPA

TEXT.P: The recently approved salary hikes for executives of state-owned enterprises are "unrelated to" the coming elections set for early next year, Chou Hung-hsien, minister of the Central Personnel Administration (CPA), said Monday.

Chou noted that at the national conference on sustainable economic development held in July 2006, a consensus was reached on raising the salary of the chairmen and presidents of the state-owned enterprises, and that the hikes have nothing to do with the January legislative and March presidential elections.

Chou was responding to reports by a local newspaper, the United Daily News, that the Executive Yuan approved last week a sharp salary increase for the chairmen and presidents of 12 state-owned enterprises that have proved to be "competitive." The hikes will take effect on Jan. 1, 2008.

The average monthly salary increase will be more than 90 percent, with the ceiling for the salary increases set at NT$300,000 (US$9,090), according to the reports. The raise will mean the current restriction that the salaries for top executives of state-owned enterprises cannot exceed those of ministerial-level officials will be lifted, the reports said.
The reports also said that the salary increase will be a "boost" for encouraging the top executives to canvass support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidates.
Chou said that the average salary for the top executives of the state-owned enterprises is about NT$160,000 per month, which is far lower than that of their counterparts in the private sector.

Noting that the chairmen and presidents of the state-owned enterprises are responsible for large operations, Chous asked how they will be able to compete with their counterparts at financial holding companies if their salary is too low.
Chou denied the reports of "a sharp increase in salary," stressing that "not every executive will see a monthly salary increase to NT$300,000."

According to the plan, there are presently 25 state-owned enterprises, and if the Bureau of National Health Insurance and the Bureau of Labor Insurance -- which are considered to be para-government agencies in nature -- and Taiwan Railway Administration and RSEA Engineering Corp. -- which are considered to be incompetitive -- are excluded, only 12 state-owned firms are considered to be "competitive."

The 12 "competitive" state-owned enterprises are Taiwan Power Co., CPC Corp., Taiwan, Taiwan Sugar Co., Taiwan Water Corp., CSBC Corp. Taiwan, Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp., Taiwan Post Co., Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan, the Export-Import Bank of ROC, Central Deposit Insurance Corp., and Aerospace Industrial Development Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese, Indonesian cops raid Indonesian drug factory

TEXT.P: Taiwanese law-enforcement personnel and their Indonesian counterparts recently raided a drug lab on Batam Island in central Indonesia, arresting six suspects including three Taiwanese men, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported Monday.

During the operation, nearly 600 kg of amphetamine worth around NT$500 million (US$15.45 million) in street value was seized, along with 1,000 kg of chemical raw materials and manufacturing equipment, CIB officials said.
According to the officials, the amphetamine factory was built and financed by the Taiwanese suspects, who also offered technical expertise in refining the drug to their Indonesian accomplices.
The amphetamines were shipped to Taiwan, China and other parts of Indonesia via air and sea, the officials said.
According to the officials, the CIB obtained tipoffs in March that Taiwanese and Indonesian criminals were cooperating to set up a drug production and smuggling operation.

One of the Taiwanese suspects began in September to transfer drug-making equipment from Taiwan to Batam with the intention of starting mass production the following month, when Indonesians celebrate the Muslim festival of Ramadan.

The raid, which took place Oct. 21, was planned and executed with the additional assistance of the Indonesian National Narcotics Bureau and U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents stationed overseas, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA budgetary plans unfrozen

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan unfroze two Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) budgetary plans for 2007 Monday after the Foreign Ministry decided to forego their implementation.

After the two budgetary plans are unfrozen -- NT$166.66 million (US$5.14 million) for financing the development of a Taiwan-El Salvador Park in the Central American country and NT$8.17 million (US$282,932) to foot the cost of remodeling the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy headquarters -- these budgets can be returned to the national coffers, legislators said.

According to a MOFA report submitted to the Legislative Yuan, the Foreign Ministry decided to call a halt to the Taiwan-El Salvador Park plan after failing to reach a consensus with the El Salvadoran government on the location of the proposed industrial park.

The development of the Taiwan Park in El Salvador was initiated by Vice President Annette Lu during a diplomatic trip to Central America in 2005, with government agencies such as the MOFA, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the National Science Council in charge of planning construction details.

The MOFA decided to cease the execution of the 2007 budgetary plan for remodeling the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy building on the grounds that a new headquarters will be built under another budget plan rather than simply remodeling the existing building.

Meanwhile, the legislators also unfroze a third MOFA budgetary plan for 2007 -- a whopping NT$648.74 million (US$20.02 million) for international cooperation projects -- but demanded that the Foreign Ministry submit a written report in two weeks to explain the content of the budget execution and the amounts for all the individual projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Italy scientific research cooperation accord signed

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) of Taiwan and the Italian National Research Council (NCR) have recently signed a scientific research cooperation agreement.

Taiwan's NSC deputy minister, Hung-duen Yang, and Italy's NCR acting president, Federico Rossi, inked the document(s) on behalf of their respective institutions at a ceremony held in Rome last Friday.
Under the agreement, the two parties will jointly organize seminars and cooperate in scientific research projects and the exchange of visits by researchers and students, according to Yang.

There will be at least two seminars, one in Taiwan and one in Italy, five research cooperation projects, and 10 visits by researchers from each country to the other country every year beginning from the next year, Yang said.
Biotechnology, industrial design, material technology and nanotechnology are on the priority list for the cooperation projects to be developed by the two sides, he said.
Taiwan has also decided to offer scholarships for five Italian graduate school students every year for two-month study visits in Taiwan during the summer vacation beginning from next year, he added.

Yang, who has been in Italy since Oct. 25, also attended the Italian university rectors conference CRUI where he exchanged opinions with CRUI members on university student and professor exchanges between the two countries.
Yang left for Vienna Monday after concluding his five-day visit to Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pilots working for foreign air carriers normal: CAA

TEXT.P: Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Billy Chang said Monday that it is normal for pilots to work for foreign air carriers that offer more generous pay than they can command at home.
Chang made the remarks while fielding questions at a legislative committee meeting.

Legislator Lee Hung-chun of the opposition People First Party cited statistics of the Civil Aviation Airman Association of the Republic of China to say that Taiwan pays foreign pilots US$12,000 a month, while local pilots get only US$8,000.
Lee claimed that this is the reason for an exodus of 40 Taiwanese pilots in the first eight months of this year to air carriers in other countries.
He urged the CAA to pay attention to the "pilot drain, " which he claimed could lead to insufficient pilots in Taiwan and could possibly mean pilots having to work overtime.
Chang pointed out that foreign pilots usually get better pay than their local counterparts, "a situation that is the same in every other country."
He also pointed out that although Taiwanese pilots might be working in other countries, there is a large number of foreign pilots working for Taiwanese carriers.
Chang said he was unaware that 40 local pilots have left to work for foreign carriers and said he did not believe the figure.
He also noted that pilots cannot work overtime and face steep fines if caught doing so.
"It is reasonable for pilots to go to the air carriers that offer the highest salaries, " Chang said, adding that Taiwan has around 1,900 pilots, more than 600 of whom are foreign.
