DOC.TEXT: At least 16 illegal immigrants were killed on Sunday morning when two ships with more than 100 people on board went aground and were broken into pieces off the Italian coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Department of Health updates Web site on health survey results

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has updated an interactive Web site providing survey results on the nation's health for reference by the public, a DOH official said Monday.

Chuang Yi-li, director-general of the Center for Population and Health Survey Research under the DOH Bureau of Health Promotion, said the public can access the Web site at http://olap.bhp.doh.gov.tw//.
The site carries the results of the center's surveys on national health interviews, families and fertility, juvenile health, birth registration and health of the elderly, he added.
Tallies related to high blood lipid levels, the declining birth rate and smoking are also available, said Chuang.
According to Chuang, the Web site was launched in March, 2005, but was not frequently visited due to its user-unfriendly information retrieval system.

The DOH updated the Web site in May this year to make it into a more convenient information retrieval system and a broader database, Chuang went on, adding that the DOH will add two more databases to the site each year.
Chuang said the Web site will allow people to become more aware of both regional and national health problems.
Local governments, academic institutes and teaching personnel can also use the site for evaluating or designing health policies, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: East Timorese politician to share referendum experience with Taiwan

TEXT.P: A close aide of East Timorese President Jose Ramos Horta is expected to share the experience of his country's push for an independence referendum during an international conference to be held by the Taiwan Thinktank in Taipei this weekend, officials said Monday.

Joao Boavida, vice president of the Democratic Party, who was involved deeply in East Timor's independence referendum and is now a confidant of Horta, will discuss issues concerning his country's fight for independence since 1975, the successful holding of an independence referendum in 1999 and the official independence of East Timor May 20, 2002, according to think tank officials.
The officials said the International Conference on the Comparative Studies of Referendum will review Taiwan's democratic development over the past four years since the Referendum Law was enacted.

In addition to Boavida, other foreign guests invited to the conference include Dane Waters, chairman and founder of the Initiative and Referendum Institute (IRI) at the University of Southern California, and Bruno Kaufman, president and co-founder of IRI-Europe, they said.

The Taiwanese participants will be Government Information Office Minister Hsieh Jhy-wey; Michael Hsin-huang Hsiao, executive director of Academia Sinica's Asia- Pacific Area Studies; Lo Chih-cheng, chairman of Soochow University's Department of Political Science; Tsai Chia-hong, an associate research fellow at National Chengchi University's Election Study Center; Taiwan Foundation for Democracy President Lin Wen-cheng; Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Lin Chia- lung; Tzeng Jiann-yuan, an associate professor at Chung Hua University's Department of Public Administration; Li Ming-juinn, secretary-general of the Taiwanese Society of International Law; Huang Yu-lin, a former member of the Cabinet's Referendum Review Committee; and Naiteh Wu, chairman of IRI-Asia's International Steering Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: President unveils new Fisheries Agency name plaque

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian unveiled a new plaque of the Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture (COA) Monday, formally re-opening the agency -- the first government unit relocated to southern Taiwan from the north.
At the ceremony, Chen, who was accompanied by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and COA Minister Su Jia-chyun, expressed hope that the agency will boost services for fishermen and fishing boat operators.
The relocation, Chen said, is part of the government's efforts to improve care for people living in central and southern Taiwan, and to balance the development of the north and south of the country.

The agency will also set up a branch office in northern Taiwan to maintain its services to fishermen there, Chen added, underlining the importance with which the government regards the country's fishery development.

The new Fisheries Agency is in the Ocean-Going Fisheries Development Center located in Kaohsiung's Chienchen Fishing Port complex. Kaohsiung is an important base of Taiwan's deep-sea fishing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: F.C.C. Set to End Sole Cable Deals for Apartments
The Federal Communications Commission, hoping to reduce the rising costs of cable television, is preparing to strike down thousands of contracts this week that gave individual cable companies exclusive rights to provide service to an apartment building, the agency's chairman says.
The Wall Street Journal: O'Neal Out as Merrill Reels From Loss
Whenever Goldman Sachs Group Inc. would report quarterly profits in recent years, the pain would be felt nearby, at the downtown headquarters of Merrill Lynch & Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Promises on Darfur Don't Match Actions; Bush Expresses Passion for Issue, but Policies Have Been Inconsistent
In April 2006, a small group of Darfur activists -- including evangelical Christians, the representative of a Jewish group and a former Sudanese slave -- was ushered into the Roosevelt Room at the White House for a private meeting with President Bush. It was the eve of a major rally on the National Mall, and the president spent more than an hour holding forth, displaying a kind of passion that has led some in the White House to dub him the "Sudan desk officer."
The Washington Times: Israel puts squeeze on Gaza Strip
Israel began scaling back fuel supplies to the Gaza Strip and closed a key crossing for humanitarian provisionsXsanctions seen by observers as a last-ditch attempt to squeeze the economy of the coastal strip before a more aggressive military offensive is ordered.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices surged across the board Monday, buoyed by gains on Wall Street last Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 178.37 points to close at 9,809.88.
The bourse opened at 9,743.73 and fluctuated between 9,822.37 and 9,735.43 during trading. A total of 5.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$180.85 billion (US$5.43 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.2 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2.7 percent, textile stocks at 2.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1 percent and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 726, with 245 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 185 points to close at 9,860 with 37,243 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December rose 200 points to finish at 9,875, with 289 contracts traded, while March futures increased 198 points to close at 9,833, with 19 contract transactions. June futures moved up 220 points to finish at 9,850, with five contract transactions, while September futures gained 166 points to close at 9,664, with 11 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 9,675 for November, 9,675 for December, 9,635 for March and 9,630 for June and 9,498 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

November TE futures rose 7.35 points to close at 410.6, with 2,798 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 7.2 points to finish at 410.5, with 21 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 6.05 points to close at 407.75, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

November TF futures gained 30.4 points to close at 1,088.6, with 3,417 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 27 points to finish at 1,088.4, with 22 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 26 points to close at 1,081, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister urges public to drive less

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen urged the public Monday to think about how to drive less or to purchase economy cars, claiming that this will inevitably become a trend amid soaring oil prices.

Noting that the Cabinet has since August been promoting a campaign encouraging government employees not to drive to work one or two days a week, Chen said he himself "almost" abides by this principle and that if he is making any trips to central or southern Taiwan, he will take the high-speed train.

Chen made the remarks to the media after his call during a legislative committee meeting for more people to use public transport drew criticism from legislators who said he paid no regard to the problems faced by people who live in areas with no access to public transport.
Domestic gasoline and diesel prices are expected to be further hiked by NT$0.7 to NT$0.8 next month following another rise in international oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Doctors acting as organ transplant brokers subject to penalties: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwanese doctors who are found to have helped solicit local patients seeking organ transplants in China are subject to legal penalties, an official with the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Hsueh Jui-yuan, director of the DOH Bureau of Medical Affairs, said such doctors could be disciplined for violation of medical ethics. The penalties, depending on the seriousness of the violation, range from an official reprimand to having their licenses to practice revoked, he added.

Hsueh made the remarks at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan by ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tien Chiu-chin who alleged that China might have become the world's "organ transplant supermarket."

Pointing out that many international human rights organizations have expressed concern about China's frequent execution of prisoners, Tien implied that many of those executed -- many of whom were reportedly young and strong -- might be executed for their organs rather than as punishment for their crimes.
Tien claimed that a "young and strong" executed prisoner would be worth about NT$5 million (US$154,320) if his organs were to be removed and sold to Taiwanese patients.

Tien also alleged that China has offered "organ transplant tourism" packages, soliciting Taiwanese citizens seeking organ transplants in China, taking only two or three weeks to match patients with suitable organs and make other relevant arrangements.
The DOH has instructed that a probe be conducted into reports of a Chinese doctor coming to Taiwan to solicit local patients seeking liver transplants in China, DOH officials said.

The Taipei-based Liberty Times reported Oct. 24 that Zhu Zhijun, director of the organ transplant center of the Tianjin First Central Hospital, came to Taiwan in March and conducted assessments in the company of two Taiwanese doctors on liver disease patients waiting to travel to China to get transplants. The Tianjin hospital is touted as the biggest liver transplant center in Asia.

Hsueh said the DOH has instructed the Taipei city government Department of Health to conduct a thorough probe into the matter, including who were the two Taiwanese doctors who reportedly accompanied Zhu during his visit in Taiwan.

He added that Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, which invited Zhu to come to Taiwan, should also be dealt with according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the people of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

Also speaking at the Legislative Yuan session, Yang Chia-chun, director of the Legal Affairs Department under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that doctors from three or four Taiwanese hospitals are suspected of having served as brokers between Taiwanese patients and Chinese organ suppliers. He added that the investigations into those cases are continuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.05 to close at NT$32.415.
A total of US$1.70 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.425 and fluctuated between NT$32.359 and NT$32.469.

DOC.HEADLINE: Normal for political appointees to campaign for ruling party: DPP

TEXT.P: A legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that it is normal for political appointees to campaign for the DPP.

Wang Tuoh made the remarks after the Taipei-based China Times reported that the Executive Yuan will inaugurate a campaign team made up of Cabinet members this week in preparation for the legislative and presidential elections early next year.

The reports said the Cabinet has planned for the members to come to the defense of the DPP's administrative policies in specific areas such as finance and economics, agriculture and culture, as well as diplomatic work, when they are on the campaign trail.

Some political appointees will be responsible for certain constituencies, the reports said, noting that Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun, who began his political career after serving as Sanchung mayor, and Minister Without Portfolio Lin Hsi-yao, who once served as Taipei deputy magistrate, should help the DPP in hotly contested Taipei County.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Su Jia-Chyuan, who once served as Pingtung magistrate, and COA Vice Minister Lin Tsung-nan, who formerly served as Nantou magistrate, have also made frequent weekend visits to the two counties recently, according to reports.
Hsieh Hsin-ni, a DPP legislator and director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said it is "only natural for a political appointee to serve the ruling party."

DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher echoed her views, saying that when political appointees are off duty, they are free to campaign and that if they take leave, it is also permissible for them to stump for DPP candidates during those periods.
The main opposition Kuomintang caucus in the legislature, however, blasted the Cabinet members, accusing them of "blurring the line" between their official duties and campaign work.
Kuo Su-chun, a KMT caucus whip, claimed that the Cabinet members are always on the campaign trail, whether on weekends, at night or during the working day.
Kuo cited the China Times reports that ranking Cabinet officials are serving in key posts in the campaign office of Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate.

Yeh Chu-lan, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, is serving as Hsieh's campaign manager; Chen Chi-mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, is serving as Hsieh's deputy manager; Cheng Li-chun, chairwoman of the National Youth Commission, is serving as the director of Hsieh's Youth Department; COA Minister Su Jia-Chyuan is deputy head of the mobilization department, and Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lu Tien-lin serves as the head of Hsieh's Labor Department, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academic urges Washington to upgrade U.S.-Taiwan dialogue level
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/29/07 19:10:12 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A U.S.-based Taiwanese academic urged the U.S. government Sunday to upgrade the level of its official dialogue with Taiwan, which he described as the only Chinese society that practices democracy.

Vincent Wei-cheng Wang, chairman of the Department of Political Science at the University of Richmond, Virginia, made the call in a speech to an academic conference held by the California-based Chinese American Professional Society in the City of Industry in California.
Wang said Taiwan and the United States are both democratic countries that share common values and suggested that the two reinforce cooperation in efforts to boost bilateral ties.

Wang said that although Washington has set many restrictions on its interactions with Taiwan since switching diplomatic recognition from the Republic of China to the People's Republic of China in 1978, the restrictions "have now become outdated."

Speaking of the important issues concerning U.S.-Taiwan ties, Wang suggested that the U.S. and Taiwan should navigate around the bureaucratic barriers to push for the signing of a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement.
As the eighth-largest trade partner of the United States, Wang said, Taiwan is more important to the U.S. than other trade partners such as Singapore and Jordan in terms of economic achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Tainan City Council PFP members return to KMT

TEXT.P: Three Tainan City Council members of the opposition People First Party (PFP) announced Monday that they had decided to return to the Kuomintang (KMT) , the PFP's ally in the "pan-blue alliance."
Lee Chin-chuan, Wang Chia-chen and Lin Mei-yan, who were all originally members of the KMT, told a press conference at the city council that they had applied to have their KMT memberships restored.
They said that by returning to the KMT, they hope to strengthen the unity of the "pan-blue alliance, " with the aim of winning the legislative and presidential elections in 2008.
They promised that they will continue to serve PFP supporters in their constituencies even after joining the KMT.

KMT Legislator Kao Su-po from Tainan and members of the KMT's Tainan City Council caucus, who accompanied the three former PFP members at the press conference, expressed a warm welcome to their return to the KMT fold.
According to officials at the KMT's Tainan office, as the applications need to go through a required procedure, their KMT memberships are not expected to be formally approved until mid-November.

The Tainan City Council caucus of the PFP, which will soon become history, is the last caucus of the party at the local government level. The PFP caucus on the Kaohsiung City Council ceased functioning in March, when one of the four PFP councilors gave up her PFP membership and joined the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGHouse price gloom as the wealthy turn away
House prices fell for the first time in two years this month, sending a shudder through millions of homeowners already hit by rising mortgage repayments and more expensive borrowing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nationwide health walk set for Nov. 11

TEXT.P: A national health walk activity called "1111 Happy Walk" to promote public health will kick off Nov. 11, with all local-level governments organizing similar activities in their constituencies, Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Chairman Yang Chung-ho said Monday.
The Department of Health designated Nov. 11 as the National Health Walk Day in 2006 to promote exercise, Yang said.
According to Yang, the activity's organizer, Taiwan's Chinese Healthy Life and Sports Association, will hold an international forum in Taipei City Nov. 9 as a warm up to the health walk campaign.

International health walk promoters and health professionals, such as Yoshiro Hatano of Japan, who recommends walking ten thousand steps aday, International Marching League (IML) Walking Association's former Chairman Luc Henau, and American pedometer expert W. Ron Sutton, will speak at the forum to share their experiences in promoting walking as a form of exercise.

Former Olympic medalist in track and field, Chi Cheng, who is also chairwoman of the Hope Foundation, one of the activity's organizers, started promoting the "1111 Happy Walk" event around the nation in July this year, winning support from every local government, Yang said.
Yang is encouraging the public to join the activity and to exercise regularly for good health.

An executive of the online job search firm 1111 Manpower Bank, the campaign's another organizer, said Taiwan's people, especially wage earners, need to take more exercise, as a recent survey showed that 65 percent of the country's work force do not exercise regularly and only 32 percent of employers encourage employees to take exercise.

The walking activity in Taipei City will cover 10 km and start from the Zhongshan Soccer Stadium, Yang said, adding that people who are interested in joining the activity can sign up on the Web site of the Hope Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to explore undersea hydrate gas

TEXT.P: The Central Geological Survey institute under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will begin a four-year research project in 2008 to investigate hydrate gases on the ocean floor off Taiwan's southwest coast, an institute official said Monday.
The announcement came after the institute geologically mapped the areas off Taiwan's southwest and northeast coasts over the last few years.

The institute kicked off a series of projects to map the areas in 2001 as part of the government's efforts to understand the country's marine resources in order to better explore the use of them, Chiang Chung-jung, deputy director of the institute, said.
In recent years, a massive amount of hydrate gas, also known as "combustible ice, " has been discovered in many parts of the world, including areas off Taiwan's southwest coast, Chiang said.
It is estimated that the total volume of combustible ice is twice that of all currently available petroleum fuels, Chiang added.
Given skyrocketing oil prices, many coastal countries -- including the United States, Japan, and Canada -- have begun studying the future use of combustible ice, Chiang went on.

According to the institute's preliminary estimates, there are approximately 500 billion cubic meters of hydrate gas in the region, enough for over 65 years of use, Chiang noted, describing hydrate gas as "a great potential source of future energy."

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum ballots not cast will not be counted in turnout rate: CEC

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Monday that if voters have received referendum ballots but decide not to cast them, the ballots will not be counted in turnout rate.

Chang made the remarks during a meeting with local election commission officials, noting that referendum proposals initiated by both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as well as the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will be held alongside the January legislative and March presidential elections next year, meaning that coming elections will be more complex than in the previous elections.

The participation rate is crucial to the passage of referendum proposals as under the Referendum Law a proposal will be considered to have passed only if the voter turnout rate exceeds half of all eligible voters and if 50 percent of those who cast ballots vote in favor of the proposal.

In the 2004 presidential election, two proposals initiated by President Chen Shui-bian and put to a referendum -- one on purchasing more missiles to counter the military threat from China and the other on engaging in dialogue with China -- failed because although 90 percent of those who cast ballots in the referendum voted in favor of the proposals, the overall participation rate was only 45 percent of eligible voters.

Chang said that after voters receive referendum ballots, they can express their intention not to vote and the ballots will be retrieved by the poll station staff, who then will mark that the ballots have been claimed but were not cast.

He said that since the ballots are not cast, there will be three categories -- "valid ballots, " "invalid ballots, " as well as "ballots claimed but not cast" -- in tallying the ballots, and that the last category will not be considered when calculating the participation rate.

One local election official, who asked for anonymity, said the coming elections will be "unprecedentedly complex" if the election staff have to ask each voter if they wish to claim their referendum ballots, and they have to mark whether the ballots have not been cast by the voters.
The staff member wondered how polling station staff are going to deal with long queues if they have to spend a significant amount of time with each voter inside the polling stations.
Meanwhile, officials from seven local election commissions proposed, during a Monday meeting with Chang, that the CEC adopt a two-step ballot distribution approach.

In response, Chang said that their suggestion will be presented to the next meeting of the CEC members for reference. The CEC will also solicit the views of election staff at the grass-roots level via questionnaires or public hearings, he added.

Election officials from Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Yilan County, Hsinchu County, Kinmen and Matsu suggested that it would be better to adopt the two-step distribution format as it would "ensure an impartial election and avoid disputes, " while the one-step ballot distribution "is prone to chaos and the consequences are not to be underestimated."

CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said that based on past experience, each polling station should be staffed by 10.7 people giving a one-step format, but will need between 13-14 people if a two-step format is adopted.

He said that the CEC has appropriated a budget for nine staff members per polling station for the legislative elections, but given the serious shortage of manpower, the Executive Yuan has agreed to use provisional funds to add an additional staff member.

Meanwhile, Taipei Deputy Mayor Wu Hsiu-kuang, who assumed the chairmanship of Taipei Election Commission last week, said that the commission would strongly recommend that the CEC maintain a two-step format.

Wu said that election polling falls under the purview of local governments, noting that the Election Law stipulates that local election commission can decide on the layout and management of the polling stations.
CEC members were originally set to decide whether to adopt a "one-step" or "two- step" ballot format during a meeting Friday, but postponed its decision after heated debate.

On the eve of the CEC meeting, 18 mayors and magistrates from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the main opposition Kuomintang, issued a joint statement that if votes on referendum proposals are held alongside the legislative and presidential elections early next year, they will follow the previous "two-step" voting format" to ensure the smooth operation of the elections."

The "two-step" voting format refers to voters receiving presidential election and referendum ballots separately. After casting their presidential ballot in one box, voters will receive a referendum ballot to cast in another box. This method was used in the 2004 presidential election, but many voters chose to leave the polling stations after casting their presidential ballots, without bothering to vote on a referendum being held at the same time.

Under the "one-step" format, two ballots -- a presidential and referendum ballot -- are handed out at the same time and voters then cast the two ballots in separate boxes. This format is generally considered to boost the participation rate.

A referendum proposal initiated by the DPP to retrieve ill-gotten assets amassed by the KMT during its five decades of rule of Taiwan and another initiated by the KMT on opposing corruption will be put to a vote in conjunction with the legislative election.

The DPP also plans another referendum on a proposal to bid for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan, to be held in tandem with the presidential election, while the KMT plans a referendum on a proposal to return to the world body under its official name, the Republic of China, or any other "pragmatic name" at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online voting on top 10 classical fruits of Taiwan to close Oct. 31

TEXT.P: Mango, known as the king of tropical fruits, has tentatively recovered its No. 1 status among Taiwan-produced fruits in an online vote held by the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

The vote, which began July 1 and will end Oct. 31, allows each voter to select up to 10 kinds of fruit. With only two more days to go, the mango has surpassed the strawberry as Taiwan's top classical fruit by capturing more than 122,400 votes, accounting for 8.35 percent of the votes cast.

The strawberry has lagged behind the mango after tentatively placing first in September because of support from many Internet users in Miaoli County who strongly endorsed their locally produced fruit. As of Oct. 29, the strawberry has received over 118,600 votes, accounting for 8.09 percent of the popular vote.
Bell fruit ranked third with 97,127 votes, followed by custard apples, also known as "Buddha-head fruit, " with 94,032 votes, and lychees with 93,002 votes.
Other fruits ranking from fifth to 10th places are pears, grapes, bananas, watermelons and pineapples.

According to the Agriculture and Food Agency, lots will be drawn in November to choose lucky winners from among those participating in the vote. Winners will receive a 42-inch liquid crystal display television set, 60 tourist farm coupons and 500 copies of a 2008 fruit calendar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to promote balanced economic development

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung vowed Monday to push for balanced economic development in an effort to narrow the gap between the nation's rich and poor.

Chang said the government has launched economic policies to help the nation's small and medium enterprises upgrade their management and production technology, to improve infrastructure in central and southern Taiwan, and to better care for people in the lower class.

In terms of taking care of people in lower social class, Chang said that since the transition of political power in Taiwan, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has adjusted the minimum wage, brought in a new retirement system for laborers, and provided care to elderly farmers and fishermen who do not enjoy the benefits of the social welfare system.
Chang made his remarks while attending a ceremony inaugurating the new headquarters of the Fisheries Agency in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Fisheries Agency was moved from Taipei City to Kaohsiung City in order to enhance the government's administrative management of the country's fishery industry, Chang said, adding that Kaohsiung has been Taiwan's most important deep sea fishing industry.

The agency's new office will be in charge of making policy for the fishery industry and of providing more direct and timely service to fishermen in southern Taiwan, in accordance with one of the Executive Yuan's economic policies, Chang said.
He added that servicing the fishery industry in northern Taiwan will be managed by the agency's office at its previous headquarters in Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Researchers concerned by investment in India, Vietnam

TEXT.P: In the midst of massive media coverage and interest in investing in India and Vietnam, researchers expressed concern with that frenzy in a forum that focusing on opportunities in the rapid-developing countries Monday.

Taiwan's manufacturing industry has been doing well in Vietnam, which opted to open its domestic market in late 1980s, but it is still risky to invest in Vietnam's stock market, said Ben Chang, General Manager of AEGON Securities Investment Consulting Co., in the forum organized by Taiwan Research Institute.

Vietnam's economy has shown robust growth during the last decade, during which it has registered an average gross domestic production (GDP) growth rate of more than seven percent, he said. However, given the small scale of its stock market and foreign investment restrictions, it's still a risky market for foreign investors.

India has been lauded as another promising market for investors all over the world, but opinions on its future economic development remain mixed, said Ma Daw, an assistant researcher of Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research.

India possesses a number of advantages for investors. The strength of its information technology (IT) sector, work force structure and large population are expected to be the driving force behind its strong growth in the future, Ma said.
On the other hand, Ma warned, investors have to be willing to take risks given the state of the infrastructure, complicated taxation code, government inefficiency and foreign investment restrictions.

DOC.HEADLINE: City councilors blast 'abusive' treatment of sidewalk trees

TEXT.P: Taipei city councilors asserted Monday that many city-owned trees planted alongside city sidewalks have been mistreated and requested that relevant authorities step up their efforts to protect them.

City Councilors Hsu Chia-ching and Wu Si-yiao made the assertion at the city council and cited many specific cases of "tree abuse" which showed old sidewalk trees were either cut down, ringed, or wounded by electrical cables connected to nearby distribution boxes set up by construction workers.

In response, Taipei City Parks and Street Light Office Director Chen Chia-chin indicated that under the city regulations governing sidewalk tree management and maintenance, a person found maliciously damaging a sidewalk tree must pay a compensatory fee six times higher than the basic cost, as well as replacement costs.

So far this year, Chen said the office has written five tickets, worth a combined value of NT$580,000, for offenses done to sidewalk trees. In the near future, the office will act to set up a reporting mechanism and reward persons acting to protect the "lungs of the city," the official added.
In Taipei City, there are now 8,800 sidewalk trees and 90,000 park trees, according to the city office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Indonesia fraud ring smashed

TEXT.P: A fraud ring, operated by several local men conspiring with illegal Indonesian workers in Taiwan, was smashed Sunday by police authorities in central Taiwan, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) announced Monday.

A total of 18 suspects, 10 Taiwanese men and eight illegal Indonesian workers, were detained a day earlier in separate police raids in Miaoli, Taichung, Nantou and Changhua counties, CIB officials said.

According to Miaoli Prosecutor Chang Wen-jie, who took charge of the case and organized the raids, the 10 Taiwanese men were involved in fraud and had previously been set freed on bail by a local court, while all the eight Indonesian are absconded workers who illegally left their factory positions.

The 18 suspects previously worked with a China-based fraud ring, which was tracked down by police early this year after a series of fraudulent plots hatched in Taiwan, Chang said, adding that the Taiwanese criminals, while awaiting the ruling in a second trial, again hired the Indonesian workers to con local people and Indonesian nationals.
The Taiwanese criminals had been planning to sneak into China in early November on board fishing ships from the outlying Kinmen Island to escape judicial punishment, police added.

According to the initial police probe, members of the fraud ring often disguised themselves as prosecutors, National Police Agency officers or Chunghwa Telecom officials to swindle money from locals in regions in central Taiwan. Police estimate that they took in more than NT$10 million using this fraudulent scam.

As the fraud ring was found to also use these illegal Indonesian laborers to swindle their compatriots both in Taiwan and Indonesia, Taiwan police authorities have been in contact with their Indonesian counterparts to investigate relevant cases, CIB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local medical charity to sign MOU with Japanese counterpart

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps. (TRMPC) will sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with its Japanese counterpart, Peace Winds Japan (PWJ), Tuesday in an effort to further expand the scope of its global reach, a TRMPC spokesman said Monday.
Liu Chi-chun, president of the TRMPC, said that both sides can integrate their educational and medical resources to provide a wider range of services to people around the world through the MOU.

Noting that the TRMPC is the only local non-governmental organization (NGO) using the name Taiwan that has been admitted to the Conference of Non- Governmental Organizations in Consultative Relationship with the United Nations, Liu said the TRMPC has rich experience in international cooperation.

Since its establishment 11 years ago, the TRMPC has been engaged in many humanitarian relief operations and in providing emergent medical aid at home and in 25 nations in Africa, Central and South America, as well as Asia, Liu noted.
Liu pointed out that during the Kosovo war in 1999, the TRMPC was the only Asian NGO to fly to Macedonia to offer assistance to refugees.
According to Liu, the TRMPC also provides free medical services to indigenous tribes in local mountainous areas on a monthly basis.
Peace Winds Japan, also an NGO, has dedicated itself to helping the poor, as well as war and disaster victims around the globe since it was founded in 1996, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Council of Labor Affairs to help women start own businesses

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will help women start their own businesses by providing them with appropriate job training and a loan of up to NT$500,000 (US$15,340), CLA officials in Kaohsiung said Monday.

According to officials at the CLA's center in charge of employment affairs in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas, women who hope to start their own businesses should join a CLA "Phoenix" training program which will begin at the end of October.
The officials said those women who have completed the needed training will be elegible to apply for a loan from the CLA after presenting a work plan.

They pointed out that 780 women from the Kaohsiung-Pingtung area have completed the job training, and that 170 women nationwide have already presented their work plans and obtained the needed loans to start their own businesses.

The officials said that three courses for beginners will start between Oct. 29 and Nov. 2 at three locations in southern Taiwan, followed by three advanced courses which will begin between Nov. 7 and 21 in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT U.N. bid referendum understandable to U.S.: Siew
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/07 23:24:39 (By Charles Kang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing's objections, Washington understands the motivation behind a U.N. membership bid referendum proposed by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , KMT vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew has claimed in a recent interview with a Singaporean Chinese-language daily.
The Lianhe Zaobao published the interview, conducted in Taipei last Friday, in its Monday edition.

Dismissing a public misconception that the KMT's drive to call for a referendum on "re-joining U.N." was following the lead of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Siew stated that the KMT launched the campaign with an aim of checking and impeding the DPP.
According to Siew, the DPP, with its plan to hold a referendum on what it described as Taiwan's U.N. cause, is moving in a direction extremely dangerous to Taiwan.

The DPP has been pushing for a public referendum, to be held along with the March 22, 2008 presidential election, on whether the country should pursue full U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, while the KMT, to counter the DPP, has aslo initiated a signature campaign to call a referendum to re-join the world body in the name of the Republic of China, Taiwan or some other feasible designations.

Now that President Chen Shui-bian has publicly said that holding a U.N. membership referendum "definitely has to be done," the KMT certainly will not back away from its own referendum proposal, Siew said.

Although Beijing would not presently agree to the political course the KMT is advocating, he argued, the ROC, as an independent sovereignty, has to communicate the desire of its people to all the world.

Siew, who visited the United States early this month in his capacity as the KMT's vice presidential candidate to explain the meaning for his party's call for a U. N. membership referendum, said that Washington is well aware of the KMT's purpose in doing so and that is exactly why the United States has not, to date, publicly voiced opposition to the KMT's U.N. bid referendum plan.

In contrast, both Beijing and Washington voiced their objections to the U. N. membership referendum proposed by the ruling DPP, saying that holding such a referendum would step on a red-line in sensitive cross-Taiwan Strait relations and mark a step towards "de-jure Taiwan independence."
The KMT's U.N. membership strategy is more pragmatic and flexible, as it includes the ROC, Taiwan and other designations that the country has used in other international organizations, he claimed.

During his recent visit to the United States, Siew said, he learned that Taiwan-U.S. relations have sustained "unprecedented" damage as a result of the DPP's failure to keep its promises to the United States regarding cross-strait ties.
If the KMT regains power in the March 22, 2008 presidential election, it will commit to making peace, rather than creating trouble, in the region, he said.

Commenting on the DPP's decision to make its "Taiwan-centric" notion a chief plank in the coming presidential election, Siew contended that such a concept should be more broadly defined, have a more profound meaning, and be more flexibly applied in international contexts.

A "Taiwan-centric" identity cannot be so narrow-minded that it is defined by ethnicity as the DPP has claimed, Siew reiterated, adding that those who live in Taiwan and contribute to the country are Taiwanese, not just those who were born in Taiwan.

He went on to say that the KMT maybe to blame for a great deal of wrongdoing during its rule of Taiwan, but its economic achievements in turning Taiwan from a poor society into a prosperous state are undeniable.
Siew asserted that it is important to make people realize that after eight years of reform, it is a revamped, clean and indigenous KMT which now seeks power in the next presidential election.
Siew also rebutted the president's misinterpretation of his proposal to develop a "cross-strait common market" between Taiwan and China as a market oriented to serve the "one China" position.

The idea of a "cross-strait common market" is based on free flows of personnel, merchandise and capital on a conditional basis between the two sides, and absolutely will not infringe upon Taiwan's sovereignty because the governments on both sides would first have to engage in normalizing two-way trade and investment at the negotiating table before agreeing to build a common market.

According to the KMT vice presidential candidate, a "cross-strait common market" could help create a security framework for Taiwan over the long term on the grounds that it would ensure steady and stable economic exchanges in the service of the common interests of Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businesses encouraged to advert to Middle East, Latin America

TEXT.P: As the majority of Taiwan's foreign investment went to China and the BRICs (Brazil, Russia, India and China) had been the "media darlings" in recent years, it's time for Taiwanese businesses to turn their focus to the Middle East and Latin America, two regions with vast potential, financial researchers said Monday.

Economic development of six Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) members -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, United Arab Emirates and Qatar -- has been so phenomenal that Taiwan has to be a part of it and take advantage of the great opportunity, said Wang Mei-ling, a researcher of Polaris International Securities Investment, in a forum which focused on investment opportunities in developing nations.

GCC member nations are expected to have high demands in information technology (IT) services, which is one of Taiwan's strengths. Therefore, it will be Taiwan's great opportunity to make its way into the Middle East market, she said.

For example, Qatar is seeking help from Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry (III) to plan for a science park. Taiwan will be able to provide with its top-caliber engineers, which are among the most sought-after work force in these Gulf nations, Wang said.

These countries knew very well that they need to take advantage of the current oil price surge and seek multi-faceted development to prepare for potential price downfall or oil depletion. And that's why they will increase investments in Asia dramatically while keep investing in the Western countries, Wang said.
Investors in the region has shifted their priority to Asia following the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and deteriorating U.S.-Middle East relations, she claimed.

A survey of more than a dozen Gulf investors found that they were planning to place 10-30 percent of their assets allocation in Asia, she said, adding that the amount could reach US$ 250 billion in the next five years and Taiwan should try to attract some of the Middle East investors.

The future of Latin America is intriguing as it has the advantages of large markets, rich resources and rapid-developing labor skills, but the economic integration and political stability in certain countries are still in doubt, said Hsieh Ming-jui, a professor at National Open University's Department of Business.

Given the region's uncertainties, Taiwanese businesses will probably hesitate in investing in Latin America, Hsieh said. However, the economic integration and development of Latin America is expected to be a factor in Taiwan's global competitiveness. Taiwan needs to understand more about the market and increase bilateral cooperation, he said.
The forum was organized by Taiwan Research Institute. Former president Lee Teng- hui served as the Honorary Chairman of the institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 30, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: Council of Labor Affairs to help women start own businesses

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will help women start their own businesses by providing them with appropriate job training and a loan of up to NT$500,000 (US$15,340), CLA officials in Kaohsiung said Monday.

According to officials at the CLA's center in charge of employment affairs in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas, women who hope to start their own businesses should join a CLA "Phoenix" training program which will begin at the end of October.
The officials said those women who have completed the needed training will be elegible to apply for a loan from the CLA after presenting a work plan.

They pointed out that 780 women from the Kaohsiung-Pingtung area have completed the job training, and that 170 women nationwide have already presented their work plans and obtained the needed loans to start their own businesses.

The officials said that three courses for beginners will start between Oct. 29 and Nov. 2 at three locations in southern Taiwan, followed by three advanced courses which will begin between Nov. 7 and 21 in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local medical charity to sign MOU with Japanese counterpart

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps. (TRMPC) will sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with its Japanese counterpart, Peace Winds Japan (PWJ), Tuesday in an effort to further expand the scope of its global reach, a TRMPC spokesman said Monday.
Liu Chi-chun, president of the TRMPC, said that both sides can integrate their educational and medical resources to provide a wider range of services to people around the world through the MOU.

Noting that the TRMPC is the only local non-governmental organization (NGO) using the name Taiwan that has been admitted to the Conference of Non- Governmental Organizations in Consultative Relationship with the United Nations, Liu said the TRMPC has rich experience in international cooperation.

Since its establishment 11 years ago, the TRMPC has been engaged in many humanitarian relief operations and in providing emergent medical aid at home and in 25 nations in Africa, Central and South America, as well as Asia, Liu noted.
Liu pointed out that during the Kosovo war in 1999, the TRMPC was the only Asian NGO to fly to Macedonia to offer assistance to refugees.
According to Liu, the TRMPC also provides free medical services to indigenous tribes in local mountainous areas on a monthly basis.
Peace Winds Japan, also an NGO, has dedicated itself to helping the poor, as well as war and disaster victims around the globe since it was founded in 1996, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister clarifies controversial statement about car sizes

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen apologized Tuesday for a controversial statement made a day earlier in which he defined cars with an engine capacity of 3,000 cc as "small cars."
Chen said his comment "was a relative statement and may not be precise enough, " pointing out that what he really intended was to encourage people to use more energy-efficient cars.

At issue is a statement made by Chen during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economics and Energy Committee Monday, in which he suggested that members of the general public drive less or replace their large cars with smaller ones to cope with soaring oil prices.

Asked if his 3,000 cc car can be considered a small car, Chen gave a positive response. The remarks immediately triggered widespread criticism that Chen is totally out of touch with Taiwan society, where cars below 2,000 cc are generally accepted as small, economy cars.

Chen explained to reporters Tuesday that what he meant was that he has replaced his 3,800 cc car with a 3,000 cc one, admitting that a 3,000 cc car is usually classified as a middle-to-large car in Taiwan.
Chen stressed that he replaced his large car with a smaller one and that he is considering changing to an even smaller car in the future and driving less to contribute to energy conservation efforts.

Also asked to comment on the issue Tuesday, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said that classifying car sizes according to engine capacity is a "technical matter, " adding that the main point is to use cars that consume less energy and cause less pollution.

On whether he has any plans to replace his 4,600 cc car with a smaller one, Chang said he will do so if related authorities come up with a comprehensive plan to replace the energy-wasting cars used by Cabinet members with cars with an engine capacity of below 3,000 cc or below 2,500 cc.

The issue has come to the forefront as domestic gasoline and diesel prices are expected to be further hiked by NT$0.7 to NT$0.8 per liter next month following recent increases in international oil prices.
