DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 51.95 points to close at 9,757.93.
The bourse opened at 9,854.27 and fluctuated between 9,859.65 and 9,727.58. A total of 5.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$159.59 billion (US$4.92 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares and textile stocks both at 0.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, and construction issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 615, with 243 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: No cars larger than 3,000 cc purchased for Cabinet members: official

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has not been allowed to purchase cars with an engine capacity larger than 3,000 cc for ministerial-level officials since 2001, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Tuesday.

Referring to measures adopted by the Democratic Progressive Party administration to conserve energy and cut costs, Chen said the upper limit for the value of cars purchased for ministerial-level officials has also been lowered from NT$1.4 million to NT$1.2 million since 2001.
In addition, from the start of 2008, the government will stop dispatching cars to transport senior-level civil servants to and from work, Chen said.
According to Chen, the Environmental Protection Administration has also been promoting the use of hybrid cars as part of an energy conservation campaign.

Chen stressed that many of the cars with large engine capacity, such as Cadillacs, currently used by Cabinet members were purchased before 2001 and that the vehicles have not been replaced because they have yet to reach the end of their targeted service duration.

Chen made the remarks amid public concerns about whether the Cabinet has any plans to replace the energy-wasting cars used by many of its members, in the wake of a recent proposal by Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen that members of the general public drive less or replace their large cars with smaller ones to cope with soaring oil prices.
While the economics minister himself currently uses a 3,000 cc car, Premier Chang Chun-hsing uses a 4,600 cc vehicle.

Accusing Chen Chin-jun of lying, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wu Yu-sheng claimed the Cabinet earmarked NT$4 million in its 2006 budget plan for the purchase of a car for then-Premier Frank Hsieh and that almost all the cars currently used by ministerial-level officials are larger than 3,000 cc.

KMT Legislator Kuo Su-chun claimed that a new car purchased for National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen is a 4,300 cc Japan-made sedan, while another one purchased for Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong is a 3,500 cc car which cost more than NT$1.2 million.

In related news, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei- pi said that the ministry purchased its first hybrid car in late September to be used as a limousine to receive foreign guests and that it will purchase more such eco-friendly vehicles in the future.

According to Yeh, the MOFA now has a total of 31 limousines and 30 cars for business use in Taiwan, and the MOFA uses cars more frequently than any other ministries do owing to the ministry's need to receive foreign guests.

Meanwhile, Yeh said the country's 121 diplomatic missions overseas have a total of 521 business cars and that in deciding what car models to purchase for use by these overseas missions, the MOFA will take into consideration local car and energy prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to help establish 18-inch-wafer plants

TEXT.P: The government will offer assistance to local semiconductor firms in the establishment of 18-inch-wafer plants in an effort to expand Taiwan's global reach in this regard, according to Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen.

Chen made the remarks Monday at a meeting held in Taipei with senior corporate executives, experts, and scholars in the semiconductor industry to hear their opinions on the future development of the industry.

The meeting, which came after another one held recently by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) with local solar energy firms, is part of the government's efforts to understand whether its policy direction is in line with the development of local industries.

Noting that Intel, the world's biggest chipmaker, has announced a plan to research and develop the next generation's 18-inch-wafer plants, Chen said that the government will help local enterprises introduce cutting-edge technologies.

Furthermore, the government will promote joint investment by local firms and the world's first-rate facility and equipment factories in the research and development of 18-inch-wafer plants in order to lower the total investment costs and risks, Chen went on.
Through these efforts, the government hopes to increase the global market share of Taiwan's semiconductor industry in order to maintain the industry's competitiveness in the future, Chen noted.
However, an executive of the firm said at the meeting that given the trend to set up 18-inch-wafer plants, it is necessary to note that by 2009, there will be 22 12-inch-wafer plants in Taiwan.

If the government suddenly changes its policy towards the development of 18 -inch-wafer plants, how to deal with existing 12-inch-wafer plants will be a big problem, the executive warned, citing the current problem of phasing out 8-inch- wafer plants as an example.

DOC.HEADLINE: October consumer confidence down: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence declined in October, with confidence in the stock market recording the greatest fall, according to the results of a monthly survey released Tuesday.

The survey results, published by the National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan's Economic Development, show that the consumer confidence index for October stood at 66.03, down 0.5 points from the previous month.
Three of the six sub-indices declined in October, including the sub-index for stock market investing over the next six months, which dropped 3.3 points from September and now stands at 82.90.

The sub-index for domestic consumer prices for the next six months dipped 0.3 points from September to 29.85, while the sub-index for employment opportunities for the next six months fell 0.15 points to 72.25.
Among the three sub-indices that increased in October, the sub-index for durable good purchases for the next six months rose 0.45 points to 113.80.
The sub-index for family finances for the next six months gained 0.15 points, rising to 50.55, and the sub-index for the domestic economic outlook also jumped 0.15 points to 46.85.
The survey, conducted via telephone Oct. 20-22 with 2,318 adults around Taiwan, had a margin of error of two percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 76 points to close at 9,786, with 35,685 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December dropped 75 points to finish at 9,800, with 509 contracts traded, while March futures lost 33 points to close at 9,800, with 11 contract transactions. June futures decreased 64 points to finish at 9,786, with five contracts traded, while September futures moved down 22 points to close at 9,642, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 9,862 for November, 9,875 for December, 9,833 for March, 9,850 for June and 9,664 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

November TE futures dropped 2.4 points to close at 408.2, with 2,695 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 2.5 points to finish at 408, with 25 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures moved down 10.8 points to close at 1,077.6, with 2,515 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures lost 8.8 points to finish at 1,079.6, with 28 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academics call for action to protect forests

TEXT.P: Several academics called Monday for significant action to be taken in Taiwan in terms of environmental protection, urging the public to "establish a new relationship with the forests."

The academics made the appeal on the first day of a two-day 2007 International Workshop on Global Environmental Governance being held at the Transworld Institute of Technology in Yunlin, southern Taiwan.

Chang Tze-chien and Chen Tai-an, both professors at the institute, have initiated an action plan to protect rainforests in Indonesia and organized the conference to call international attention to the excessive deforestation taking place in Southeast Asia.
Chang said they are promoting international cooperation in this regard and are planning concrete actions.

Cheng Hsien-yiou, dean of the College of Environmental Sciences and Ecology at the National University of Tainan, southern Taiwan, stressed that governments, businesses and regular citizens around the world have paid a heavy price for the blind and excessive development that has occurred at the expense of forests. He called for the establishment of a new relationship between people and the forests to break the "impasse that exists between humanity and nature."

Cheng suggested that countries around the world put the brakes on excessive deforestation and over-consumption, devote more resources to the study of forests, and encourage members of local communities to participate in forest administration and the establishment of the rule of law.

The conference is focusing on global experience sharing on environmental administration, with several reports being released on the situation of the forests in Sumatra, Indonesia, the preservation of endangered species of birds, the possibility of Taiwan-Indonesia technology cooperation in organic agriculture, as well as green consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.005 to close at NT$32.410.
A total of US$1.28 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.345 and fluctuated between NT$32.335 and NT$32.430.

DOC.HEADLINE: Award-winning French violinist to perform in Taipei

TEXT.P: A gifted French violinist is slated to perform at the National Concert Hall in Taipei City Tuesday evening, marking the second time that he will perform in Taiwan, organizers said Tuesday.

Born in Paris in 1965, violinist Christophe Boulier, who will be accompanied by the prestigious Academy of Taiwan Strings for the performance, will perform new violin versions of many orchestral music pieces and well-known classical opera compositions, the organizers added.

As first-place winner in the Marguerite Long-Jacques Thibaud Competition, which is one of the world's three most important music competitions, Boulier drew great admiration at the age of seven when he performed the "Violin Concerto No. 3 in G Major K. 216" by Austrian composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791), accompanied by a noted national French orchestra, organizers point out.
Boulier is considered by many to be one of the most promising violinists of the new generation of the French music circle, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan will not interfere with oil price

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will not interfere with the domestic price of oil, which is set to rise next month in accordance with a floating pricing mechanism, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Monday.
Under the current pricing mechanism, the government will freeze the price only when it has risen to a level 15 percent or more above that of Sept. 2 when the mechanism kicked into action.

Given that the 15 percent ceiling has yet not been reached, and that the pricing mechanism was formulated after extensive discussion and was just adopted Sept. 2, Chen said that the Cabinet has decided not to interfere in the oil market.

Chen made the remarks after Premier Chang Chun-hsiung held a Cabinet meeting to respond to a call, issued by legislators earlier in the day, to temporarily freeze prices on all oil products in the face of surging global oil prices.

Noting that domestic gasoline and diesel prices are still lower than those of neighboring countries, Chen called for calm and urged consumers to conserve oil and electricity in response to possible price hikes, noting that Taiwan is heavily dependent on imported oil.

Chen added that at the moment the government has no plans to adjust the prices of natural gas, tanked household gas or fuel oil. Such inputs impact the price fluctuations of common consumer goods, the basic costs of living, and the welfare of disadvantaged groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to boost ties with Pacific allies: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to act aggressively to boost and maintain diplomatic ties with its six South Pacific allies as Beijing is acting to supplant Taiwan in this strategically important area rich in marine resources, a senior foreign affairs official said Tuesday.

Donald C. T. Lee, director-general of the Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , made the remarks at the MOFA routine press conference, underlining the importance of strengthening the country's relations with its South Pacific allies.
Lee recently returned from Tonga where he attended the 38th Pacific Islands Forum, which took place Oct. 16-17 in Nukualofa, the capital city of the South Pacific island-state.

Lee indicated that none of the six Pacific countries -- including Palau, Tuvalu, the Marshall Islands, Solomon Islands, Kiribati and Nauru -- that maintains diplomatic ties with Taiwan occupies a vast territory.

However, Lee said Taiwan can help them in a wide range of fields, including medical treatment and health care, sanitary improvement, environmental protection, economic and trade cooperation, fishing resources, military strategy, and Austronesian culture.

Over the past year, Taiwan's aid policy to those Pacific friends has focused on "project-oriented" assistance, such as offering technical expertise to help the countries stand on their own, Lee said, noting that the policy can also save Taiwan from criticisms by New Zealand and Australia, both of which have accused Taiwan of conducting "checkbook diplomacy" in the region.

Speaking of military strategy, Lee said both China and Japan have displayed a great desire to extend their influence in the Pacific area, revealing China has never given up its attempt to re-erect a satellite monitoring station in the region since it dismantled a facility of this kind in Kiribati when the latter switched diplomatic recognition from China to Taiwan in 2003.
Without the Kiribati satellite monitoring station, Lee said that Beijing can no longer monitor movements at the U.S. missile base located in the Marshall Islands.
However, Taiwan is very much concerned about China's desire to rebuild a monitoring facility in the region, Lee added.

In terms of environmental protection, the MOFA official mentioned that Tuvalu and Kiribati face great threats from rising sea levels due to global warming. He said it is believed that Tuvalu could disappear below the waves in 50 years.
In the face of that crisis, Chen said Tuvalu has asked Australia and New Zealand to take in its immigrants and proposed cooperating with Taiwan to build sea wall against the coming flood.
That proposal is now being evaluated by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Pope urges pharmacists to oppose abortion and euthanasia.
Addressing an international Catholic pharmacists held at the Vatican Monday, Pope Benedict XVI called on pharmacists not to sell "immoral drugs" used for hastening the end of a life, such as abortion and euthanasia.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Immunity Deals Offered to Blackwater Guards
State Department investigators offered Blackwater USA security guards immunity during an inquiry into last monthzs deadly shooting of 17 Iraqis in BaghdadXa potentially serious investigative misstep that could complicate efforts to prosecute the companyzs employees involved in the episode, government officials said Monday.
The Wall Street Journal: Why Rate Cut Isn't a Sure Thing; Bowing to Market Pressure Could Prolong Dilemma For Fed's Policy Makers
The market is convinced the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates tomorrow, but for the Fed itself, it is a closer call.
The behavior of financial markets implies near certainty by investors of a quarter-point cut in the Fed's key short-term interest rate. But for policy makers, the decision is between the quarter-point reduction and no cut at all. A half-point cut is unlikely to get serious consideration from Fed officials, though some in the market expect it.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Immunity Jeopardizes Iraq Probe; Guards' Statements Cannot Be Used in Blackwater Case
Potential prosecution of Blackwater guards allegedly involved in the shooting deaths of 17 Iraqi civilians last month may have been compromised because the guards received immunity for statements they made to State Department officials investigating the incident, federal law enforcement officials said yesterday.
The Washington Times: Hillary backed lab of donor
Lawmakers, including Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton, have taken thousands in campaign cash from an embattled Nobel-prize winning scientist while earmarking federal money for his New York lab.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Judicial Yuan chief spared public fund embezzlement charge

TEXT.P: Former Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng was spared graft charges Tuesday as prosecutors said they found no irregularities in his use of a discretionary "special allowance fund" during his time at the head of the country's top judicial organ.

Chu Chao-liang, a member of a prosecutorial team responsible for investigating how Weng used his "special allowance fund" while in office, said Weng clearly recorded each item for which reimbursement was claimed from the special monetary fund and that no breaches of law had been detected after a thorough review and painstaking scrutiny.
According to Chu, most of Weng's "special allowance fund" was spent entertaining guests for official purposes, and he had earmarked NT$30,000 per month for use by his personal aides.

Weng, who retired from public service late last month, was among a group of senior officials whom the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus targeted in a legal suit filed Nov. 23, 2006 with the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office in a probe into suspected misuse of the "special allowance fund."

At the first, the case was handled by prosecutor Chen Jui-jen. After the Supreme Prosecutors Office formed a special task force in April this year to deal with cases involving official corruption and other major crimes, three prosecutors with the task force -- Chu Chao-liang, Wu Wen-chung and Lee Hai-lung -- were assigned to take over Weng's case.

Chu said the amount allocated for Weng's "special allowance fund" had declined steadily from a high of NT$180,000 (US$5,538.46) per month to a mere NT$105,500 last year. Until August 2006, reimbursement for half of Weng's "special allowance fund" was backed by original proofs of spending, such as uniform invoices, while the remaining half was claimed with Weng's duly signed receipts.

A senior Judicial Yuan official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Weng consistently entrusted half of the "special allowance fund" claimed with his signature to the management of one of his aides.

To the best of his understanding, the official said, Weng's "special allowance fund" was used legally and none of the surplus went to line his own pocket. On the contrary, he said Weng often overspent and had to make up the difference out of his own money.
Starting in September 2006, Weng claimed all of his "special allowance fund" with original proofs of spending or invoices.

While there are differing opinions concerning whether the nature of the "special allowance fund" set aside for discretionary use by certain public agency heads or local government chiefs is strictly a "public fund" or a "substantial subsidy" for public functionaries, the prosecutorial team said such a question was not involved in Weng's case since his claims on the fund were entirely legal and fully used for official functions.

The "special allowance fund" issue came into spotlight after main opposition KMT presidential candidate for the 2008 election Ma Ying-jeou was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million from his "special allowance fund" during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006. He was acquitted Aug. 14 in the first trial. His acquittal is now being reviewed by the Taiwan High Court after prosecutors appealed the case.

As a result of political wrangling between the KMT-led "pan-blue" alliance and the "pan-green" camp led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , many "special allowance fund"-related lawsuits have been filed with prosecutors.

Among others, three DPP heavyweights -- Vice President Annette Lu, former DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen -- have been indicted on charges of corruption and forgery over "special allowance fund" misappropriation.
Lu's trial is set for Nov. 19, while the trial of Yu is slated for Nov. 26 and that of Tan Sun Chen is scheduled for Dec. 3.

Like Weng, the DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate Su Tseng-chang were spared corruption charges in Spetember after prosecutors failed to find any irregularities in their use of their "special allowance fund" during Hsieh's tenures as premier and as Kaohsiung mayor and Su's tenures as premier, presidential secretary-general and Taipei County magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. membership signature drive on top of Taiwan

TEXT.P: In support of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) "U.N. membership for Taiwan" campaign, mountain climbers Tuesday submitted over 100 signatures to Frank Hsieh, the DPP's candidate in the March 22, 2008 presidential election, to endorse the party's referendum proposal on the country's U.N bid.

Chinese Taipei Alpine Association Secretary-General Liang Ming-pen handed more than 100 signatures, gathered at a campaign post he set up in Paiyun Village near the top of Jade Mountain -- Taiwan's highest mountain -- to Hsieh during a news conference called by the DPP at its headquarters.

"The 100-plus signatures from Jade Mountain, Taiwan's spiritual symbol, are of great significance to the DPP in its efforts to push for the country's full membership under the name of Taiwan at the United Nations, " Hsieh said, adding that "Taiwan's U.N. cause campaign will be written into history as a major 21st century movement."

According to Hsieh, the DPP has entered the second phase of a signature campaign aimed at collecting 2 million signatures for its petition calling for a referendum, to be held along with the coming presidential poll, on whether the country should join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
As of Tuesday morning, the DPP has garnered some 1.94 million signatures -- only some 60,000 short of its 2-million target, which it expects to reach in the coming days, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Lessons in hate found at leading mosques Books calling for the beheading of lapsed Muslims, ordering women to remain indoors \and forbidding interfaith marriage are being sold inside some of Britains leading mosques, according to research seen by The Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei flower exhibition train inaugurated in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: A train promoting the 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition was inaugurated Tuesday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the organizer said, adding that the train will carry people in central and southern Taiwan to attend the exhibition in Taipei.
The flower exhibition is slated to kick off Wednesday and will run through Nov. 4, a spokesman for the organizing Taiwan Floriculture Development Association (TFDA) said.
The 87-seat train is the result of collaboration between the TFDA and the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) to raise the profile of the flower fair, the TFDA spokesman said.
The train, which is colorfully painted with several kinds of flowers, will only run Tuesday and Nov. 3, the spokesman noted.
He added that the train will make two stops in the southern city of Tainan and the central city of Taichung on its way to Taipei.
Meanwhile, the TFDA is also collaborating with online travel agency EZ Travel to provide a two-day package tour in Taipei at a cost of NT$7,500 (about US$231) per person, the spokesman said.
The package includes round-trip train fares, a flower exhibition ticket, hotel accommodation, and meals, according to the spokesman.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan, Deputy Minister of Agriculture Lee Jen-chyuan, TFDA Chairman Kuo Cheng-ho, among others, attended the train's inauguration ceremony.
Yeh, who is a former acting Kaohsiung mayor, encouraged locals to take the train and take part in the exhibition, which she said will be opened by President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate calls for freeze in gasoline prices

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , urged the government Tuesday to temporarily freeze domestic gasoline prices and promised that he will quickly swap opinions with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung regarding the issue.
Hsieh issued the call at a news conference held at the DPP headquarters while answering questions from reporters.

Hsieh, who served as premier from 2005-2006, called for a temporary freeze on gasoline prices in the domestic market as the Executive Yuan has approved price increases for some oil products that are set to be implemented Friday in line with the government's floating oil pricing system.

Despite a set of official mechanisms to adjust oil product prices, the government has some flexibility when it comes to intervening in the short term to tackle hoarding or manipulating the prices of derivative goods in view of the high flying price of crude oil in international markets, Hsieh said.

"It will fuel the public's expectations that oil prices in the domestic market will further rise if the government sticks to the formula to deal with rising oil prices, " he argued, adding that he will suggest that the Executive Yuan conduct short-term adjustments so as to fend off the ensuing price hikes in other merchandise and mitigate the impact on people's daily lives.

"The government is obliged to take good care of the people, particularly at a time when the prices of everything are soaring, and this is the reason why I always did my best to reject hikes in water fees and electricity rates when serving as premier," he said.

Meanwhile, Hsieh is reported to have phoned Chang Chun-hsiung earlier the same day, inviting him to discuss the issue. The two men are likely to meet and exchange views concerning the matter later the same day, Hsieh's aides said.

According to ranking DPP officials, the viewpoints of both Hsieh and the Executive Yuan have to be fully respected, and a consensus is expected to be forged within the party following its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspected killer deported from West Africa to Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese first mate on a Japanese fishing boat, who allegedly killed a Vietnamese crew member during the boat's recent operations on the high seas in the Atlantic Ocean, was deported home from West Africa Tuesday.
The return was made possible by the efforts of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which helped bring the suspect back to Taiwan for trial, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials said.

The suspect, Chen Wen-ching, was escorted back to Taiwan via Charles de Gaulle International Airport in Paris, France, and will be referred to the district court in Penghu, where Chen comes from, for trial, the officials said, noting that this is the first overseas case in which the CGA has successfully gained assistance from countries with no diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The 45-year-old Chen reportedly used a private pistol to shoot dead the Vietnamese worker following a number of verbal and physical conflicts Oct. 19, the CGA officials said.
The Japanese fishing boat later stopped at the Ivory Coast where other crew members reported the case to local police, the officials noted.
After learning of the incident, the CGA officials said that they sought assistance from the foreign ministry to negotiate with officials in Ivory Coast over the deportation of the Taiwanese suspect.
Due to the absence of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Ivory Coast, and interference from China, Ivorian police initially refused to deport the suspect to Taiwan, the officials went on.

Police of the Ivory Coast later agreed to turn the suspect over to Taiwan's officials after the Taiwanese side insisted that the case fell within its jurisdiction on the grounds that the incident occurred on the high seas and the suspect is a Taiwanese citizen, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen ready for all-out war to exterminate rats

TEXT.P: The Kinmen county government is calling on all residents on the outlying island, including the military and civilians, to take part in a week-long campaign in November to exterminate rats.

A spokesman for the county government said the personnel in all of Kinmen's township governments will be asked to take part in the campaign Nov. 5-11 to help eliminate rats in order to reduce the incidence of rat-borne diseases.
He added that the tools to be used will include rat poison, rat cages and rat glue traps supplied by local government agencies.

Statistics compiled by the Kinmen County Health Bureau show that of the 90 scrub typhus cases reported in the first nine months of this year, 68 were confirmed, comprising 45 civilians and 23 soldiers.

Scrub typhus is an acute febrile, infectious illness transmitted by the bite of chigger mites that live on rats. Patients experience abrupt onset of high fever, severe headache, myalgia and scabs resembling cigarette burns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maokong Gondola's safety margin will not be lowered: city government

TEXT.P: The mandated margin of safety of the Maokong Gondola in Taipei will not be lowered, out of respect for the recommendations of the builder and to guarantee the safety of the public, deputy secretary-general of Taipei city government Yang Hsi-an said Tuesday.

Yang made the remarks in response to suggestions that the Taipei MRT, which operates the Maokong Gondola, lower the margin of safety of the Maokong Gondola, a four-kilometer long cable car system passing through scenic southern mountain area of Taipei, in order to avoid frequent suspension of the system due to minor mechanical failures.

Operations of the Maokong Gondola were suspended for one minute because of insufficient distance between carriages Tuesday morning, the day after it resumed service after an eight-day hiatus for cable trimming, a procedure necessary after a period of operation for any large-scale gondola system to maintain the required cable tension.
Yang explained that Tuesday's one-minute suspension was made in accordance with the sensitive detective system of the gondola.

Regarding the suggestions of some city government officials that the safety margin of Maokong Gondola be lowered to prevent frequent suspensions of service that have created a negative impression, Yang stressed that the safety margin of the gondola was established by the French builder POMA, and should be respected by the city government.

The Maokong Gondola began services July 4 this year to an enthusiastic reception from the public. However, the system has encountered frequent mechanical failures, causing many complaints and public criticisms.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 Chinese women arrested for holding fake ROC passports

TEXT.P: Six Chinese women have been apprehended Monday at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan for attempting to use fake Republic of China (ROC) passports to transit to the United States, local customs officials said Tuesday.
The Chinese women arrived in Taiwan from Hong Kong earlier that day, planning to use fake ROC passports to fly to the U.S., the officials said.
Customs officials stopped and questioned them after discovering that they were holding fake passports, the officials noted.
The six confessed that they come from the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian, and planned to work in the U.S., the officials said.
The Chinese women said that they came to Taiwan through an arrangement made by a human trafficking group in China, the officials went on.
The young women said they followed instructions by picking up fake passports and boarding passes to the U.S., which were hidden within the Taoyuan airport, the officials said.
Taoyuan prosecutors are investigating the case, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy Rep. to Japan to chair Association of East Asian Relations
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/30/07 20:18:04 (By Yang Ming-chu and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Deputy Representative to Japan Chen Horng-chi said in Tokyo Tuesday that he will assume his new post as chairman of the Association of East Asian Relations Nov. 1.
Chen made the announcement at the Narita Airport in Tokyo before departing Japan to take up his new post in Taiwan.

He told reporters that he was honored that Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) President Masaji Takahashi went to the airport to see him off. Chen said that the JIA president usually does not see off leaving deputy representatives to Japan.

As to future Taiwan-Japan relations, Chen said the focus should be on further cultural and academic exchanges in areas such as adolescent education and environmental protection, Chen said, adding that this would help strengthen bilateral diplomatic relations.
He suggested staff members of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan avoid being too conservative in seeking breakthroughs in bilateral relations.

Chen said he was impressed by Japan's efforts to improve friendship between the two sides, such as the visa-free treatment for Taiwanese visitors in recent years, and recognition of Taiwanese driver's licenses in September this year.

He expressed gratitude to Japan's former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe for refusing to endorse China's territorial claim over Taiwan in a communique signed by him and Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jia-bao when Wen visited Japan in April this year.
Taro Aso, former secretary general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party and a member of parliament friendly to Taiwan revealed that he is likely to visit Taiwan in December, Chen said.

He went on that he also visited Japanese parliamentary members friendly to China, such as Hiromu Nonaka, before taking his leave, to show goodwill that he hoped would contribute to future Taiwan-Japan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: School resumption rates for 2005-2006 academic year up 5.2%

TEXT.P: The 2005-2006 academic year saw school resumption rates of 76.04 percent, an increase of 5.2 percent over the previous year, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Tuesday.

Citing statistics compiled by the MOE, the official said 7,453 junior high and elementary students dropped out of schools during the same academic year, a decrease of 715 from the year-earlier level. Meanwhile, 5,668 students resumed their schooling during the same year, the official said.
Taipei County, Taoyuan County, and Kaohsiung County have the highest numbers of both dropout and school resumption rates, the official said.
The official attributed the increasing school resumption rates to counselling efforts made by related schooling institutes and organizations.
Of the total number of dropouts, 18.76 percent or 1,398 were elementary school students, while other 6,055 were junior high school students, the official said.
Some 992 dropouts were aboriginal students, the largest numbers of whom were in Taitung, Hualien and Hsinchu counties.

Students tend to drop out of school for reasons related to personal, family or social problems, the official said. He went on that 48.66 percent of dropouts come from single-parent families, and that the decision of most dropouts was influenced by their friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carrier offers discount tickets on Taipei-Kinmen flights

TEXT.P: To better serve Kinmen residents flying between Kinmen and Taipei, Taipei-based Trans Asia Airways will, beginning Nov. 1, upgrade its fleet and offer discount ticket prices on the route, Trans Asia General Manager Dennis Tien announced Tuesday.
Tien made the announcement following a meeting earlier the same day with Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng at the Kinmen County Government office.
Lee warmly welcomed the carrier's measures and expressed the hope that other aviation companies would follow the lead and provide better service to Kinmen residents.

According to Tien, starting Thursday, Trans Asia will use 150-seat A320s and 182-seat A321s to ply the Kinmen-Taipei route, and local residents with registered households on the outlying island will be entitled to a 50 percent discount on ticket prices onboard Trans Asia's Kinmen-Taipei flights until the end of December.
The adjustment will see eight of Trans Asia's jet planes fly between the two destinations per day, offering a total 1,044 seat capacity on a daily basis, up from the previous level of 740 seats.

Among Taiwan's 18 domestic airports, Shangyi Airport on Kinmen Island is the fourth-largest airport in terms of transportation volumes, only trailing behind Taipei's Songshan Airport, Kaohsiung International Airport and Makung Airport on Penghu Island, Tien said, adding that Shangyi Airport is rapidly catching up with Makung Airport.

As Kinmen has a great potential to develop its tourism thanks to its location and the direct ferry services maintained between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's Fujian Province, Trans Asia decided to upgrade and enhance its service on the Taipei-Kinmen route, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese, Taiwanese NGOs establish alliance for humanitarian work

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese non-government organization (NGO) Tuesday established an alliance with a Japanese NGO to strengthen the capabilities of both to further pursue international humanitarian works and deepen their global impact through collaboration.

Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) , an NGO devoted to humanitarian relief and emergency medical services, signed a memorandum of agreement with Peace Winds Japan (PWJ) , which is operating more than 50 relief projects around the world.
As the majority of its members are physicians and surgeons, TRMPC will be able to provide medical assistance which PWJ cannot, said TRMPC President Liu Chi- chun in a press conference.

PWJ will be able to help its Taiwanese ally to obtain visas to countries that do not have official diplomatic ties with Taiwan through foreign embassies in Tokyo, PWJ chief executive officer Kensuke Onishi said, adding that Taiwanese humanitarian workers could join PWJ missions in the future to avoid political interference.
TRMPC missions have failed to enter Tanzania, Lebanon and Pakistan in the past for political reasons, which was unfortunate because international humanitarian works should know no borders, Liu said.

The alliance is expected to begin collaborating on emergency relief work in the wake of earthquakes and on several projects in Africa, Liu said. Onishi added that PWJ, with an annual budget of 1.5 billion Yen, will be able to provide help with funding as the TRMPC does not conduct public fund-raising events.
Onishi said he would describe the alliance as the "integration of Japanese and Taiwanese civil societies", and therefore deeper than the simple collaboration of two NGOs.

The two parties will strengthen their mutual relations and promote cooperation for organizational interaction with international institutions. Staff exchanges will be carried out on all organizational levels through field visits, training seminars, internships, conferences, and consultations, Liu said.

TRMPC was established in 1995 and has participated in relief works in Kosovo, Macedonia as well as Taiwan. PWJ, one of the largest NGOs in Japan, was established in 1996 and currently employs about 50 paid staff members and 1,000 volunteers around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canada to strengthen educational exchanges with Changhua County

TEXT.P: The official responsible for educational affairs of British Columbia's School District Six, is visiting Changhua County to strengthen educational exchanges between both sides, county government officials said Tuesday.
Duane Sutherland met Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan to exchange views on educational policies and the recognition of diplomas issued by each other.
Saying that many students in the county are hoping to study in Canada, Cho expressed hope that these children can take advantage of the opportunity to learn about a different culture.
He also expressed hope that more Canadian children can come to Taiwan on study tours to learn about the history and culture and experience the beautiful scenery of Changhua County.
Sutherland noted that it was his third visit to Taiwan and he was impressed by the warm welcome he received in Changhua County.
He added that many Taiwan students have studied in Canada over the last 20 years and said he wanted to use his visit to have further discussions with Cho on exchanges of senior school students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-graft campaign headquarters wraps up street movements

TEXT.P: The "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign headquarters donated Tuesday all the money it has collected for the campaign since last year to five social welfare organizations in the country at the same time as it announced the end of the movement.

The headquarters' chief press director Chang Fu-chung, as well as two deputy chief commanders Wei Chien-fung and Hsu Po-yun held a press conference in Taipei City to present the donation. They also announced the failed campaign to topple scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian has come to its end.

In the future, there will be no more large-scale public movements concerning the campaign but the headquarters will continue to promote the idea of fighting against corruption and the formation of relevant laws through writing articles, Wei said.

Addressing the money issue, Chang explained that they collected more than NT$100 million (US$3.08 million) in total to finance the anti-corruption campaign initiated by Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party last August.
Currently, they still have NT$15.67 million on hand, an amount which has been independently audited and certified by the Taipei City Certified Public Accountants Association, Chang said.

Under strict public monitoring, Cheng stressed that the headquarters would never dare to allocate the so-called "promise money, " which the headquarters promised donors would only be used on anti-corruption campaigns, for other purposes or for the personal use of headquarters members.

Chang also indicated that the headquarters stopped spending the "promise money" in September, saying the cost of holding a "Return to the Ketagalan Boulevard" rally Sept. 9 was paid by the headquarters' deputy commander out of his own pocket.

Hundreds of thousands of the protesters, answering the call of the campaign headquarters, staged several large sit-ins and rallies on Ketagalan last September demanding that President Chen resign. The activities climaxed with a half-million people encircling the Presidential Office on National Day on Oct. 10. The movement had gradually died out by the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ urged to stamp out vote-buying in Kaohsiung County by-election

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing urged the Ministry of Justice Tuesday to stamp out vote-buying in a township election -- the fourth in five years -- so that his county will be spared the disgrace of having to hold a fifth election in six years.
Yang made the call in the wake of rampant rumors in the county about vote-buying by some of the candidates in the Nov. 10 by-election of the head of Niaosung township.
Yang said he had paid a call at the Ministry of Justice, asking law enforcement personnel to make more strenuous efforts to stamp out vote buying.

Noting that vote buying is the main reason why Niaosung township has to hold the fourth election in five years, Yang expressed the worry that if the next by- election is again ruined by vote buying, making it necessary to hold a fifth election, the township will be remembered as "the greatest disgrace" in the Kaohsiung County history.
Niaosung township has a population of 41,000 people, 31,000 of whom are elegible to vote.

In a Jan. 26, 2002 election, Chang Mei-yao was elected township head but removed from office after a court found her guilty of taking bribes in the run-up to the election of township council speaker and deputy speaker. Her husband Lin Jung- tsung won the township head by-election Nov. 1, 2003
Lin won re-election Dec. 3, 2005 but was later convicted of vote-buying and stripped of his post, prompting another by-election.

Chang, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), staged a comeback by declaring her candidacy in the Nov. 10 by-election, pitting herself against KMT candidate Chen Chin-chuan and a candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Wang Hui-lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County to switch to winter office hours

TEXT.P: The Yilan county government announced Tuesday that the county will implement winter office hours from Nov. 1 until Feb. 29, 2008.
A spokesman for the county government said the new office hours are from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m., with a one-hour break from noon to 1 p.m.
Summer office hours also start from 8 a.m. but end at 5: 30 p.m., with a 90-minute break from noon to 1:30 p.m.

The spokesman explained that Yilan County is prone to rain in the autumn and winter seasons and that with the days getting shorter in autumn and winter, the new office hours are aimed at allowing office workers to avoid having to drive in poor visibility and wet road conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meeting on biting midge eradication to be held in Taichung

TEXT.P: The government will hold a coordination meeting on small biting midge eradication in Taichung City Nov. 16 to exchange views with local governments on solving problems caused by the pest, the Taichung city government's Environmental Protection Bureau Chief Lee Li-to said Tuesday.

The meeting will be attended by representatives of the National Science Council (NSC), the Department of Health (DOH), the Council of Agriculture (COA), and six regions in central Taiwan whose residents are suffering from the biting midge problem, including Taichung City and the counties of Taichung, Miaoli, Yunlin, Changhua and Nantou, Lee said.

The tiny insect, barely visible to the naked eye, is known locally as the little black mosquito, although it is actually not a mosquito. Its bite causes severe itching and irritation that can last for days and leave scars that take even longer to heal.

According to Lee, the meeting marks the first time the central government convened a meeting on solving the biting midge problem since Taichung Mayor Jason Hu asked former Premier Su Tseng-chang for assistance in the matter in March.

Lee said the Central Taiwan University of Science and Technology in Taichung City started genetic research on reducing the population of biting midges, using subsidies provided by the NSC. The school set up a demonstration area in Taichung City and has carried out field experiments since August.

The NSC will present the research results at the coordination meeting for the reference of local governments, Lee went on, adding that the DOH and the COA will give briefings on efforts already made to solve the problem, while the six local governments will report on their efforts.
The meeting will be presided over by Yuan Shao-ying, director-general of the DOH Bureau of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Control, Lee said.

Lee said Taichung City has spent NT$1.75 million (US$53,850) on pesticide spraying and on hiring the Taichung Pest Control Association to monitor the effectiveness of the spraying, while a subsidy of NT$340,000 from the central government was used for research into biting midge densities by the Central Taiwan University of Science and Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: New laureates for Presidential Science Prize announced

TEXT.P: Three members of Academia Sinica have won the Presidential Science Prize this year, according to an announcement made Tuesday by Yeh Chu-lan, secretary- general of the Presidential Office, and Chi-Huey Wong, president of Academia Sinica.

Chen Ding-shinn, a former dean of the College of Medicine, National Taiwan University and an expert in hepatitis, won in the life science category. Chang Chun-yen, who is a former president of National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu and is considered the architect of the country's integrated circuit industry, got the prize for applied science, and Tien Tzou Tsong won in the mathematical physics category.
The three winners, all of whom were present at a news conference called to make the announcement, will receive their prizes from President Chen Shui-bian Nov. 2 at the Presidential Office, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's online shopping market to hit US$7.8 billion in 2008: MIC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's online shopping market value is expected to increase to NT$252.9 billion (US$7.8 billion) in 2008 from this year's level of approximately NT$185.5 billion, according to the latest assessment by the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) , a local ICT industry and market research firm.

MIC senior analyst Chou Wen-ching released the assessment, along with his research report on the online consumption behavior of Taiwanese people, at a conference organized by MIC on online consumptions trend and retail channels that was attended by local marketing executives.

Chou indicated in his report that the seven online activities conducted most frequently by Taiwanese Internet users in 2007 include using search engines, using instant messaging, sending e-mails, downloading software, shopping and booking tickets, reading blogs and visiting knowledge-oriented Web sites.

Chou said a survey conducted for the report also found that 80 percent of online shoppers read product reviews before purchasing and that 74 percent would take into account blog evaluations when choosing products.

The results show that most online shoppers place orders directly with Web-based shops, accounting for 39.8 percent of all shoppers on the Internet. Another 35.8 percent purchase goods directly on auction Web sites, 22.5 percent join online auctions, and 1.9 percent usually choose group buys to secure better prices.

The most popular online products include computer software and hardware and PDAs (31 percent) , cosmetics and health care products (30.1 percent) , women's clothing and accessories (29.5 percent) , books and magazines (29.1 percent) , and mobile phones and communication devices (21.2 percent), according to the report.

Chou assessed that the 2007 online shopping market value will amount to NT$185.5 billion, made up of some NT$108 billion in the business-to-consumer market and around NT$77.4 billion in the consumer-to-consumer market.

The MIC survey was conducted online July 9-22, with 5,773 valid questionnaires collected. It had an error margin of 1.29 percentage points, according to MIC, a division of the Taipei-based Institute for Information Industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 31, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai- shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
2001: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agree to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.
2001: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, accompanied by a two- member entourage for a three-day visit in the Republic of China, calls on Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROFER files anti-dumping charges against Taiwan steel exports
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/07 12:11:56 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The European Confederation of Iron and Steel Industries (EUROFER) has officially filed anti-dumping charges against certain steel products from Taiwan, China and South Korea, a EUROFER official said Tuesday.
EUROFER Director-General Gordon Moffat told the CNA that the charges targeting cold-rolled steel sheets from the three countries were filed Monday with the European Commission.

In addition to Taiwan's move to sell cold-rolled steel sheets at prices lower than the production cost, the sharp increase in the quantity of Taiwan's cold- rolled steel sheet exports to the European Union in recent years was another major reason behind the EUROFER's decision to file the anti-dumping charges, Moffat said.

He noted that Taiwan's cold-rolled steel sheet exports to the European Union rose from 45,000 tons in 2005 to 95,000 tons in 2006 and that the figure is expected to further increase to 168,000 tons for 2007, adding that Taiwan's cold-rolled steel sheet exports have attained a market share of over 1 percent in the EU.

When asked about the matter by the CNA, a European Commission official in charge of trade policy declined to confirm whether the commission has received official notification of any anti-dumping charges from the EUROFER.

According to European Commission rules, upon receiving notice of an anti-dumping charge, the commission will complete a study of the case within 45 days to determine whether formal anti-dumping investigations are warranted.

In addition to pressing anti-dumping charges against China's cold-rolled steel sheets, the EUROFER also lodged anti-dumping charges against China's galvanized steel sheets Monday. It is also planning to file similar charges against other steel products from China over the coming weeks, according to Moffat.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Temple U. to sign academic agreements with six Taiwan counterparts
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/07 13:40:08 (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Temple University in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania is set to sign pacts with six universities in Taiwan on academic cooperation, a Taiwan diplomatic source said Tuesday.

Temple University President Ann Weaver Hart is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Wednesday for a three-day visit in the company of several administrative officials of the university, mainly for the purpose of signing agreements with six Taiwan universities on joint efforts to promote double degree programs, according to officials from the Cultural Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York.

Vice President Annette Lu and Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng reportedly will attend a ceremony to be held at National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) in Taipei Thursday to mark the signing of the agreements on double degree programs between Temple University and NTNU; National Taiwan University of Science and Technology; National Cheng Kung University; National Sun Yat-sen University; Tunghai University and Chung Yuan Christian University, the Taiwan officials said.

Under the agreements on double degree programs -- sometimes called conjoint degree, dual degree, or simultaneous degree programs -- students from the six Taiwan universities will be able to attend Temple University after they finish three years of their undergraduate education in Taiwan to study in the same subject area or in different subjects.

Under the agreements, Temple University will recognize the credits that the Taiwan university students earn in Taiwan. The students will also be able to study at Temple University's graduate schools and will have a good chance of obtaining their master's degrees in two years, the officials said.
To attract Taiwan university students, Temple University will also offer exclusive English classes and scholarships for the students, the officials added.

A double degree program allows the two participating institutions to reduce the amount of time a student needs to earn degrees at both institutions. For example, a joint Master of Business Administration/J.D. typically takes four years to complete, as opposed to the five years it would take to complete each program separately.

Established in 1884, Temple University, a privately-run research university, maintains 18 schools and colleges, including four professional schools. It has eight campuses and sites in Pennsylvania, as well as international campuses in Rome, Tokyo and London, and programs in China, South Korea, Greece, Israel and other locations around the world. It ranks as the 26th largest university in the United States in terms of number of students and faculty members.

Among the Temple faculty members expected to accompany Weaver Hart on her forthcoming Taiwan visit is Hai-Lung Dai, dean and Laura H. Carnell Professor of the College of Science and Technology, who was born and raised in Taiwan and pursued advanced studies in the United States.
Dai will be a chief liaison officer for Temple University's double degree program, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier asks for preparations for gasoline price hikes

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday to "make preparations" for gasoline price hikes based on a floating oil pricing system.

Premier Chang made the remarks amid concerns that the MOEA will adjust fuel prices upward and add to the woes of the public who are already feeling the pinch of rising living costs due to a series of basic goods price increases.

The Cabinet had decided Monday to hike gasoline prices in line with the floating pricing system which is linked to world oil prices. However, Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), urged the government the following day to temporarily freeze domestic gasoline prices.

Despite a set of official mechanisms to adjust oil product prices, the government has some flexibility when it comes to intervening in the short term to tackle hoarding or manipulation of the prices of derivative goods in view of the high flying price of crude oil in international markets, Hsieh said.

Premier Chang asked the MOEA to prepare for gasoline and diesel price hikes. However, to avoid a serious impact on the average family, small shops, and small- and medium-sized enterprises, he added, prices for fuel oil, natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas cylinders will not be adjusted for the time being.
Whether gasoline prices will be raised or not should be clear after a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting slated for Wednesday afternoon.
Meanwhile, the Economics and Energy Committee of the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution Wednesday urging the MOEA not to adjust gasoline prices upward before the end of the year.
Committee members focused on gasoline prices when they met to review the MOEA's budget for the next year.
Vice Economics Minister Shih Yen-hsiang said the floating oil pricing mechanism was only implemented in September after extensive debates.
"Before the mechanism is revised, the ministry thinks it should continue to be followed," Shih said.

Committee members said that they are not asking for a scraping of the mechanism but instead for a "temporary freezing" of it. They also noted that the state- owned CPC Corp. has reached its targeted legal profit surplus for the year and that it should now consider the needs of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down seven points to close at 9,780, with 41,545 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December dropped 17 points to finish at 9,783, with 281 contracts traded, while March futures lost 50 points to close at 9,750, with two contract transactions. June futures decreased one point to finish at 9,785, with two contracts traded, while September futures moved down 53 points to close at 9,589, with five contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 9,787 for November, 9,800 for December, 9,800 for March, 9,786 for June and 9,642 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

November TE futures gained 0.75 points to close at 409, with 3,273 contracts traded, while December TE futures increased one point to finish at 409, with 28 contract transactions. March TE futures rose 0.15 points to end at 405.55, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

November TF futures moved up 10.2 points to close at 1,087.8, with 3,782 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures increased 11.4 points to finish at 1,091, with 35 contracts traded. March TF futures gained 8.6 points to finish at 1,096.6, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet set to launch second-phase flood control project

TEXT.P: The Cabinet is set to carry out the second phase of a national flood control and management project from 2008 to 2010, with the goal of accomplishing 90 percent of the targeted areas of work by the end of June 2008, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.

Making the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang noted that the project was worked out by the Cabinet in July 2005 in light of the significant increase in extreme rainfall events in Taiwan as a result of global climate change.

The project, which covers a series of measures to clean up rivers and improve regional drainage systems and sea dams in flood-prone areas, is set to be carried out in three phases over an eight-year period, Chang said.
While flood-prone areas in Taiwan total 1,150 square kilometers, the project gives priority to the 500 square kilometers where improvement is urgently needed, Chang said.
He said that during the past 15 months following the project's launch, the flood-prone areas have survived several extremely heavy rain events, which he said proves the effectiveness of the project.
In the second phase, related authorities will continue to remove silt from targeted rivers and drainage systems and try to finish work that has not been completed in the first phase, Chang said.

To ensure the passage of a special budget for the second phase of the project, the premier instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics to actively communicate with the various party caucuses in the Legislative Yuan after the Cabinet submits the budget draft to the legislature for review.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 46.56 points to close at 9,711.37.
The bourse opened at 9,777.58 and fluctuated between 9,787.9 and 9,664.64. A total of 5.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$184.93 billion (US$5.71 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.7 percent, and machinery and electronics shares and cement stocks both at 0.3 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues increasing 1.1 percent and banking and financial shares moving up 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 694, with 225 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet poised to set up price stabilization mechanism

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung put forward five contingency measures Wednesday, including setting up a price stabilization ad hoc task force, to cope with volatile inflation situations.

At a regular Executive Yuan meeting, Chang appointed Vice Premier Chiou I-jen as convener of the price stabilization ad hoc task force and the Council for Economic Planning and Development as the planning and executive body to activate a supra-division mechanism to monitor the supply situations of major commodities and keep inflation under control.

Chang said that in an Aug. 1 Executive Yuan meeting, he instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to monitor the price structures of raw materials and major commodities in Taiwan, the Ministry of Finance to be ready to halve taxes, and the Ministry of Justice to investigate any possible hoarding in the face of spiralling prices on the international market.
Since September, he said, the prices of raw materials and major commodities in the country have gone even higher as a result of several typhoons and ever- rising international oil prices.
Taiwan society has become increasingly jittery since late October, when the price of crude soared to US$90 per barrel, Chang noted.

To cope with this grave situation, Chang said, he issued a five-point directive to be implemented by the relevant Cabinet agencies, including that the MOEA make preparations for gasoline price hikes based on a floating oil pricing system; that the Council of Agriculture work with private suppliers to ensure adequate grocery supplies; that the Environmental Protection Administration and the MOEA work out plans for alternative energy, including liquefied gas and biofuel for automobiles; and that the Ministry of Justice and the Fair Trade Commission continue to monitor and investigate pricing irregularities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first maternal milk bank celebrates third anniversary

TEXT.P: The maternal milk bank affiliated with Taipei City Hospital's Branch for Women and Children celebrated its third founding anniversary Wednesday.

The bank, the first of its kind in Taiwan, was established in 2004 to store maternal milk donated by mothers with excess milk supply who have passed blood tests determining their health. The milk is being provided to seriously ill premature infants and newborns with poor-functioning digestive systems whose mothers cannot breastfeed or are unable to produce enough maternal milk.
According to officials of the branch, over the past three years, more than 200 mothers have donated maternal milk to the bank, with each mother donating 10,000 ml of milk on average.

A total of 173 infants have benefited from the program, including 50 percent who were born premature, 20 percent with poor-functioning digestive systems and others with immune deficiency or congenital defects and those requiring nutrient fortification after surgery, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hog breeders faced with surging-cost crisis: lawmaker

TEXT.P: Domestic hog breeders are losing profits due to surging international prices of the feed corn that comprises the major portion of pig fodder, along with increasing transportation costs, opposition People First Party Legislator Chung Shao-ho said Wednesday.

Chung, who represents Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan, revealed the plight of the pig farmers at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, saying the farmers have complained that each head of livestock equals a deficit of NT$1,200 (US$37) in real terms.
According to this calculation, a herd of 50 pigs represents a deficit of NT$60,000, he added.
Chung also accused two leading domestic feed suppliers, including the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp., of stockpiling feed corn for profiteering.

The lawmaker also said supply has outstripped demand in the domestic pork market. In Taiwan, he said, 6 million head of hogs is the number required to meet demand, but local raisers at present have a total of 7 million head.

The excessive supply has benefited pork traders, who have bought stocks at a low price, frozen them and are waiting until the market is short of fresh pork, Chung said, blaming the traders for controlling market prices and preventing hog price fluctuations to reflect rising breeding costs.

Chung suggested that the government take measures to help breeders. He proposed encouraging breeders who no longer want to raise hogs to quit the business by offering subsidies as part of efforts to control stock numbers.
He also demanded that the government probe the allegations of profiteering by local suppliers.
Meanwhile, Legislator Ko Chun-hsiung of the Farmers' Party called on the government to subsidize local hog breeders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heroin seized in parcel from Thailand

TEXT.P: Taiwan customs authorities recently seized 2.8 kg of heroin in an express parcel mailed from Thailand, officials said Wednesday.
Inspectors posted by the Taipei Customs Office at the Taipei Post Office came across the parcel while screening express parcels with an X-ray scanner Oct. 24, the officials said.
Their suspicions aroused, the inspectors opened the parcel and found the heroin disguised as two boxes of coffee and one box of powdered cream, the officials said.
The Taipei Customs Office has referred the case to the Bureau of Investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Justices Stay Execution, a Signal to Lower Courts
The stay indicates that a Supreme Court majority intends to block all executions until a lethal injection case is decided next spring.
