DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Cabinet approves measures to boost security.
The Cabinet meeting approved Tuesday a package of measures aimed at cracking down crimes and making cities safer. The measures on urban security, which are subject to approval by the parliament, include new anti-mafia provisions, toughening penalties and setting up a police DNA database.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, closing at NT$32.410.
A total of US$899 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.389 and fluctuated between NT$32.385 and NT$32.430.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of recipients of Taiwan scholarships rise to nearly 1,300

TEXT.P: The number of foreign student recipients of scholarships from Taiwan has increased to 1,274 this year, up 299 from the previous year, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Wednesday.

The Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the National Science Council are responsible for sponsoring the Taiwan Scholarship Program to encourage students from foreign countries to study in Taiwan and to enhance educational and academic exchanges, the official said.

This year marks the fourth year of the program and the number of recipients has continued to rise, with the greatest number of students receiving scholarships from the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs, at 578 and 540, respectively, according to the official.

The number receiving scholarships from the National Science Council was 101, while the number sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs totaled 55 this year, the official said, adding that the scholarship recipients will have their orientation Nov. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Freeways remain off-limits to heavy motorcycles: official

TEXT.P: Motorcycles over 550 cc will be allowed on most of the country's expressways from Nov. 1, but will still be excluded from freeways, a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) official said Wednesday.

The official of the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau under the MOTC reminded motorcyclists riding on the 15 expressways that are connected to freeways to pay attention to the exit signs to avoid going on to the freeway.
Motorcyclists who are caught riding on freeways will be fined NT$3,000 (US$92), the official said.
Hsiao Yu-lin, vice president of the J-Motors Professional Group, said the new regulation has boosted sales of heavy motorcycles by about 20 percent.

Meanwhile, a National Police Agency official said that during the early stage of the new regulations, the police will focus on serious violations by heavy motorcycle riders and will only give notices for minor irregularities, in order to help riders adjust to the new regulations.

The official advised heavy motorcycle riders to wear full-face helmets when riding on expressways and called on car drivers to respect heavy motorcycles on expressways, as they enjoy the same road rights as cars.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts `15 innovations' during his tenure

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian enumerated Wednesday what he called "15 innovations" that he has achieved during his tenure over the past seven years, rebutting allegations by the opposition that the country has made no progress under his leadership.

According to Chen, the innovations are the launch of the high-speed railway system, the completion of the Hsuehshan Tunnel -- the world's fifth-longest, the opening of Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest skyscrapers, the inauguration of the Central Taiwan Science Park, tax reforms, re- organization of state-owned enterprises, financial reforms, a strong export momentum, a bullish stock market, increased exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the improvement of flood prevention measures on the Keelung River, the improvement of water quality in the Kaohsiung area, the launch of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system, the start of a new retirement pension program and the push for a national pension program.
Chen claimed that many of these innovations were ideas that were thought of and discussed for years by the former Kuomintang administration but never realized.
"It's pointless paying lip service. What we need is the determination and ability to carry things out," he said.

The president said the achievements are items to be included in his end-of- presidency report card and that the opposition should not deny their existence just because of its differences and competition with the ruling party.
Chen made the remarks while receiving a group of domestic and foreign businessmen recognized for their excellence by the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan horticulture exports to top US$100 million in 2008: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian gave the thumbs-up to Taiwan's horticultural industry Wednesday, saying that with techniques continuing to advance, flower exports are expected to top US$100 million next year.

Addressing the opening of the 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center, Chen said that in order to increase horticulturists' incomes, his administration has in recent years pushed to improve growing techniques and plant hybrids.

The government has helped establish the Taiwan Orchid Plantation in Tainan, southern Taiwan, which has pushed Taiwan's status as the "kingdom of the butterfly orchid" even higher in the world, Chen claimed.
Meanwhile, the administration put forward in 2004 a statute governing plant species and seed and seedling development to better protect the rights of horticulturists, Chen said.

He added that Taiwan has also consulted advanced countries in a bid to allow Taiwanese plant and flower breeders to have species they have developed registered for patent rights. To date, many countries, including the European Union, the United States, Australia and Japan, have allowed patent right applications and registration by Taiwanese breeders.

Chen said he hopes the administration will also help horticulturists to build a world plant germplasm database and help them with plantation facilities, as well as assist them to secure patent protection from other countries.
By doing so, he said, Taiwan could easily become a hub for high-quality flower production in Asia.

Also speaking at the opening, Council of Agriculture Minister Su Jia-Chyuan said that in 1995, 9,661 hectares of land were devoted to flower cultivation, which generated production worth about NT$9 billion (US$276.92 million). By 2006, he went on, the amount of land had increased to 13,375 hectares, with production multiplying to NT$12.5 billion.
Meanwhile, Su said, Taiwan's flower exports totaled US$9.7 million in 1995, a figure that had jumped eight-folds in 11 years to US$78 million.
The bulk of such exports included butterfly orchids, Chinese orchids and paphiopedilum (lady's slipper) , making Taiwan a global stronghold of orchid cultivation and exports, Su said.

The 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition, which runs from Nov. 1-4, has attracted local horticulturists, as well as those from the Netherlands, Japan, the Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand and Australia to show their latest horticulture developments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Steelmakers to exchange know-how on greenhouse gas reduction

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC) will hold a seminar Nov. 1-2 to allow people in the steelmaking industry to exchange technical know-how concerning the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, a CSC spokesman said Wednesday.
Participants invited to the seminar include officials from the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and members of the Taiwan Steel and Iron Industries Association.

The participants will hear lectures by experts and academics on their experiences in reducing greenhouse gas emissions during the steelmaking process, how the Kyoto Protocol has affected Taiwan's energy policy and what the future holds for the efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, according to the spokesman.

He pointed out that the 1992 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change aims "to achieve stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a low enough level to prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system."

The international environmental treaty is legally non-binding but includes provisions for updates that would set mandatory emission limits. The principal update is the Kyoto Protocol, which went into effect Feb. 16, 2005 and requires all member countries to reduce the emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, the government has declared that as a member of the global community, Taiwan will strive to protect the environment and achieve sustainable development. The CSC spokesman added that this is why the company decided to hold the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate says it is appropriate to commemorate Chiang Kai-shek

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the late President Chiang Kai-shek made contributions to Taiwan and that "it is appropriate to commemorate him."

Ma made the remarks on the occasion of Chiang's 120th birthday anniversary when he and KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung attended the inauguration of a group of Ma supporters made up of Huangpu Military Academy servicemen. Chiang served as president of the academy, which was founded by the KMT in 1924 in China's Guangzhou Province.
Ma admitted that historical figures "have their merits and faults," but said Chiang's faults should not obscure his merits.
According to Ma, Chiang contributed in three areas: the rectrocession of Taiwan from Japanese colonial rule, the development of Taiwan, and the defense of the island.
Ma cited Chiang's well-known land reform program, the nine-year compulsory education and economic development projects.

Chiang also promoted resolutely self-government ordinance and women's emancipation, as well as scrapping the foster daughter system, which Ma claimed made a great contribution to advancing Taiwan's democracy and human rights.

Although Chiang achieved notoriety for his part in the infamous 2-28 incident and ensuing white terror -- referring to a 1947 brutal KMT crackdown on civilians rising up against KMT corruption and the ensuing KMT persecution of Taiwan's elite and intelligentsia, this "should not obscure his contributions to Taiwan," Ma claimed.

"Without Chiang's defense of Taiwan, it could have been swallowed up by China, and the following economic miracle and the advancement of education in the following stage would not have been possible, " according to Ma.
Meanwhile, vandalism against statues of the late president was reported in four townships in the southern county of Chiayi.
Police said that the statues in Shuishang, Chungpu, Talin and Minghsiung townships were splashed with paint between 1 a.m and 4 a.m. Wednesday and that the nose of one statue had been broken off.
Police said two of the statues had been splashed with paint previously and that they were checking monitoring devices to track down possible suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND declines to comment on China's order to hunt Taiwanese spy

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Lin Chen-yi declined Wednesday to comment on news reports that Beijing issued an order recently for the arrest of an "Internet spy" working for Taiwan's Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB).
Lin said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) was not aware of the matter.

Lin made the remarks while answering questions by Legislator Lin Chin-hsing of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan after a local newspaper reported that same day that the state security authorities of China had issued a warrant for the spy, identified as Lee Fang-jung.

The news report also said that Beijing had the Global Times, an affiliate of the Chinese government's mouthpiece People's Daily, publish Monday its accusation against Lee that he masterminded arecent online attack on Web sites of government units, military and national defense research institutes around China.
The report also quoted an official of China's Taiwan Affairs Office as having confirmed the warrant.
Asked whether the MND can protect Lee if the report about the warrant is true, Lin said the MIB has protection measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC urged to deliver on promise to relocate refinery

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Council Deputy Speaker Huang Shih-lung demanded Wednesday that the government deliver on its promise to relocate the refinery of the state- owned CPC Corp., Taiwan in the southern port city.

Huang made the appeal at a news conference in the wake of two accidents involving the company's main refinery in the city over the past three months. Also on hand were officials from various civic groups, as well as main opposition Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chao-shun and Pasuya Yao, a legislative candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Five borough chiefs of Houchin, in Kaohsiung's Nantze district -- where the refinery is located -- were also present.
They claimed that the Ministry of Economic Affairs, instead of thinking about delivering on the relocation promise, is planning to renovate the site and allow its continued operation.

Huang said the CPC often disseminates reports that the relocation of the refinery will result in 100,000 people losing their jobs on the eve of elections, and that they distribute leaflets in the communities claiming that the CPC has spent billions of dollars in improving the environmental situation and safety facilities.
"The approach of the CPC Corp. is both childish and ignorant, " Huang said.
He noted that two explosions occurred at a distillation plant of the CPC refinery July 29 and Oct. 26, respectively, which resulted in panic among Houchin residents.
He demanded that the CPC and the Ministry of Economic Affairs deliver on the promise made in 1990 to complete relocation by 2015.
If the government agrees only to renovate the existing site, the residents will demand that the refinery be closed, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese firm joins water technology expo in Israel
DOC.DATELINE: Tel Aviv, Israel, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/07 19:31:35 (By Yang Yi-feng and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese firm is among over 80 groups from 60 countries that are participating in a water technology exposition that kicked off Tuesday in the Israeli capital of Tel Aviv.
The expo, which will run through Nov. 1, has attracted more than 2,000 foreign visitors.
The Taiwanese firm's booth, sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , is showcasing products related to Taiwan's water industry.

Israeli Deputy Prime Minister Eli Yishai, who concurrently serves as minister of industry, trade and labor, announced the opening of the expo while presiding over a press conference with Infrastructure Minister Binyamin Ben-Eliezer and Minister of Environmental Protection Gideon Ezra earlier in the day.
Yishai said that due to a lack of water resources, the Israeli government attaches particular importance to the use, management and filtration of water.
He predicted that the total value of Israel's exported water technology this year will amount to US$1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: limited impact on economy even if oil price tops US$100: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy would not be significantly impacted even if international oil prices surge to US$100 per barrel in November or December, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh predicted Wednesday.
Ho made the remarks in a report on the country's general economic situation delivered at a weekly Executive Yuan meeting.

According to Ho, Taiwan's consumer price index would grow by some 1.7 percent for 2007 should the average world oil prices soar to US$100 per barrel between November and December. But she pointed out that global demand for crude oil might decrease next year, citing international research.

Ho said she is optimistic that, measured over the entire year, Taiwan's economy would expand by 4.6 percent as originally forecast thanks to stable growth in private consumption and investment despite high-flying oil costs.

Commenting on growing public concern that rice prices may rise next week in the wake of several typhoons, Ho said that the average rice price this year has actually been lower than the previous year's level.

Ho said that rice price hikes might just be a short-term phenomenon as the Council of Agriculture has sufficient stockpiles of the crop. "Theoretically, there is no reason for the domestic rice price to continue climbing over a long term," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid torch relay reaches Nantou County

TEXT.P: A nationwide torch relay promoting the country's bid to join the United Nations reached Nantou County in central Taiwan Wednesday.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators Tang Huo-shen and Lin Yun-sheng, and Ho Chin-liang, director-general of the Department of Sports for All under the Sports Affairs Council, greeted the torch in Chung Shan Park in the county's Nantou City.
More than 300 supporters of the government's bid to enter the U.N. under the name Taiwan assembled in the park to watch the torch handover ceremony.

Tang told reporters that the second phase of a petition organized by the ruling party to seek consensus on a referendum on whether the country should join the United Nations under the name Taiwan has collected more than its projected goal of 2 million signatures.
He predicted that the Taiwan people's efforts will eventually bring the nation into the world body.
The torch relay participants departed from Nantou County later that same day for the next leg covering neighboring Changhua County.
The round-the-nation torch relay started from the plaza in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei City last Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gasoline prices must not rise before year-end: KMT lawmakers

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) demanded Wednesday that the government temporarily freeze gasoline price hikes on the domestic market as the legislature has passed a resolution to that effect.

KMT legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chun and lawmaker Hsu Su-po made the comments in a Legislative Yuan news conference after its economics and budgetary committees approved a resolution earlier in the day during a joint meeting demanding that the government freeze gasoline prices until the end of the year to help relieve the growing financial burden on the public.

According to Kuo, the government should immediately announce a freeze in gasoline product prices as the state-run petroleum product provider is expected to rack up NT$20 billion in profits for the whole year. The government must stop gouging the people, she argued.
Hsu said that high consumer product prices brought by continuously rising oil and staple commodity prices have sparked widespread complaints.

The Executive Yuan must swiftly address the issue to ease grave public concerns now that the Legislative Yuan has endorsed a short-term price freeze, Hsu said, adding that the executive branch must be held fully accountable for the negative consequences if gasoline prices remain so high.

The Executive Yuan was slated to implement a spate of the latest gasoline price hikes Nov. 2 after upward adjustments in accord with a government-set floating oil pricing system which came in response to surging oil prices on the international market.

According to Wang Tuoh, legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), most caucus members are in favor of a temporary price freeze out of grave concerns about a possible string of implications in the people's daily lives.

Earlier the same day, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said at the weekly Executive Yuan meeting that he has asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs to "get ready" for possible gasoline prices hikes in compliance with the floating pricing system -- marking a departure from his Oct. 29 statement, when he announced that the newly adjusted price hikes were set to be implemented Friday.

Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling DPP, urged the Executive Yuan a day earlier to temporarily put aside the gasoline price hikes plan and flexibly address the issue to assuage deep public concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Youth Commission head accused of neglecting duty

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Wednesday censured Taiwan's top official in charge of youth affairs for neglecting her duty by playing a major role in the campaign office of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate.

KMT Legislator Chou Shou-hsun said that Cheng Li-chun, head of the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, ought to be "ashamed" of herself for accepting former premier Frank Hsieh's offer to be the director of the youth division in his campaign office to the detriment of her official duties.

Citing statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Chou pointed out that one in every four unemployed people in Taiwan is a university graduate, and that Cheng should be ashamed when facing Taiwan's university students.

Official statistics show that Taiwan had 116,000 unemployed university graduates as of September, representing an increase of 1,000 from August and accounting for nearly one-quarter of the total jobless population.

According to estimates by the Ministry of Education, about 250,000 graduates from all levels of schools in Taiwan enter the job market each year. Because those who suffer setbacks are mostly first-year job hunters, it is believed that about one out in every 2.5 new graduates ends up unemployed.

Huang Chih-chung, head of the KMT Youth League, also criticized Cheng for launching a "new patriotic movement" on behalf of the DPP presidential candidate. He said the problem now is not whether university students love Taiwan, but whether Taiwan loves its university students.
Huang said that in light of the high unemployment rate for university students, it is "extremely ridiculous" for Cheng to launch the "new patriotic movement."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition opens

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei International Flower Exhibition opened Wednesday in the Taipei World Trade Center, with flower suppliers from eight countries taking part.
The exhibition, sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and organized by the Taiwan Floriculture Development Association, will run for five days until Nov. 4.

Organizers said the first day of the exhibition was reserved for domestic and foreign buyers representing 500 businesses from 30 countries, and that from Nov. 1 through Nov. 4, the event will be open to the public.

Visitors will be able to see a wide range of flowers offered by Taiwanese growers alongside the products of floriculturists from Australia, Japan, Malaysia, the Netherlands, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.
In addition to eight theme areas, the exhibition hall has separate zones designated for international pavilions, commercial booths, enterprise demonstrations, floral shows and a display of orchids.
COA officials said the last flower exhibition of this kind was held in Taipei 12 years ago, with local flower sales then totaling NT$9 billion (US$277 million) and exports valued at US$9.7 million.

Statistics show that local flower output had since increased to NT$12.5 billion last year, while exports had surged to US$78 million, with the export total for next year expected to surpass US$100 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP not to interfere with Cabinet's decision on gasoline hikes

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not interfere in the decision of the Executive Yuan on gasoline price adjustments, a spokeswoman of the DPP said Wednesday.
Hsieh Hsin-ni, DPP legislator and director of the party's Department of Culture and Information, made the remarks after the conclusion of a weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee.

The public widely expected that the DPP would endorse the views of Frank Hsieh, the DPP presidential candidate, to temporarily freeze the floating oil pricing mechanism, which was put into practice in September to reflect fluctuations on the international oil market.

The Cabinet decided Monday to hike domestic gasoline prices after a recent price surge in the world oil market but Hsieh called for a freeze the following day in a show of empathy for the public, who are already feeling the pinch of rising living costs due to a series of price increases for basic goods.

Hsieh Hsin-ni quoted President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as the party chairman, as saying in the meeting that stabilizing prices is the responsibility of the government, and that price gouging or manipulation will not be allowed.
The government has ensured that water and electricity rates remained unchanged, and the Cabinet should focus on this rather than the volatile oil market, according to the president.

Hsieh Hsin-ni also said that the Central Standing Committee is "coordinating" between the party and the government and not "leading" the government as it would "not be appropriate to interfere with the Cabinet's decision."
DPP Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai said that the president asked the Executive Yuan to properly and cautiously tackle the gasoline price adjustment issue.
"The Executive Yuan will have the final say on gasoline price hikes, and the DPP will throw its weight behind the decision, " Cho said.

Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said the Cabinet has established a price stabilization task force, noting that Taiwan's domestic gasoline prices are the lowest among 11 neighboring countries and that the Cabinet will proceed in line with "relevant mechanisms."
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) earlier in the day to prepare for gasoline price hikes based on the floating oil price mechanism.

However, to avoid a serious impact on families, small shops, and small- and medium-sized enterprises, prices for fuel oil, natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas cylinders will not be adjusted for the time being, the premier also said.

Sources said that the Presidential Office, Cabinet, party and Frank Hsieh's camp have reached a consensus that national policies should not be formulated in the DPP Central Standing Committee meeting lest it gives rise to a negative impression that the party "is pulling strings behind the administration."

This is why Frank Hsieh and the DPP legislative caucus did not insist on a freeze or easing of gasoline price hikes and instead asked that the stability of water, gas and electricity rates be further publicized, sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police brace for opening of expressways to heavy motorbikes

TEXT.P: Taipei city police announced Wednesday that they will step up road patrols beginning Thursday when riders of motorcycles with engines exceeding 550cc are permitted to travel on nine expressways in the city, excluding the Xinsheng elevated road.

Same regulations used to address cars will be applied to heavy motorcycles, said police officers, who also indicated that their efforts will be strengthened to crack down on serious speeding by motor vehicles of this kind.
According to traffic police, heavy motorbikes are not allowed to make "two- stage" left turns as smaller motorcycles do, nor to ride on roads reserved for their smaller two-wheeled relatives.

As they are to be treated as cars, the two-wheeled large motorcycles cannot park slots designated for common motorcycles, but only in car parking spaces, and will be subject to the same parking fees as cars, according to the city police.

The Highway Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced Wednesday that a total of 26 expressways in around the country will be opened to heavy motorcycles beginning Nov. 1.

Addressing the opening, bureau officials underlined ongoing bans against heavy motorcycles traveling on freeways, riding alongside other vehicles in the same lane and cutting in, and advised riders to always ride with their headlight on and to wear full-face helmets.
A list of roads opened to, or banning heavy motorbikes is available on the Highway Bureau Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation looks to duplicate success of English Village nationwide

TEXT.P: An education foundation aims to duplicate the success of the first English Village in Taoyuan County and take it to other cities in Taiwan by setting up more English Villages by mid-2008, providing better English learning environments for students, a foundation executive said Wednesday.

"With the experience and success of the Taoyuan English Village, we are looking for establishing two to three villages by summer 2008. We are also calling for more corporate sponsors to join us in developing better English learning environments for the next generation, " said Morgan Sun, General Director of King Car Education Foundation.

The foundation established the first English Village in Taiwan, which began operation in September. The village has 12 situational classrooms and employs volunteer American English teachers. It has received much praise and has been popular among students, Sun said.

The village creates all-English situational environments, such as an airline passenger compartment, a bank and a restaurant. Students are able to enjoy a virtual flight in the cabin, withdraw money from an ATM (Automated Teller Machine), and order meals in the restaurant with the help and an introduction from foreign teachers.

"All counties and cities interested in building up a program are welcome to talk to us by Nov. 15, " Sun said, adding that it will only take an estimate of NT$6 million to establish an English Village because the foundation planned to utilize abandoned classrooms across the country and turn them into situational classrooms.
Expenditures to hire 10 English teachers will cost around NT$2 million annually, he estimated.

Sponsorship from corporations will definitely ease the financial burden in setting up these institutions, Sun said. Currently, EVA Air and the International Commercial Bank of China's Cultural and Educational Foundation have pledged to sponsor the situational classrooms.

Sun encouraged more local companies from the hotel, high tech, and other industries to contribute to Taiwan's English education. However, Sun insisted on undertaking the project with "civil effort" rather than directly cooperating with governments because going through the endless official procedures would be a "waste of time."
English Villages will be financially supported by the local government, corporate sponsors, visitors and the foundation itself, Sun noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan drops one notch in WEF global competitiveness survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 14th in the latest global competitiveness survey released by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF) Wednesday, one notch lower than its 2006 ranking.
Among Asian countries, Taiwan ranks fifth in the annual WEF survey, also one notch down from last year's level.

Taiwan's competitiveness lags behind that of its Asian neighbors Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Hong Kong, according to the Global Competitiveness Report 2007-2008, a survey of 131 countries and areas conducted by the WEF.
It marks the first time that Taiwan has been surpassed by its main rival, South Korea, in the annual WEF report.
South Korea's global ranking jumped to 11th place from last year's 24th place, reflecting its rapidly growing competitive might, the report says.

In a world competitiveness report issued by the Swiss business school in Lausanne -- the International Institute for Management Development (IMD) -- in May, Taiwan was in 18th place, ahead of Japan (24th) and South Korea (29th), while lagging behind Singapore, Hong Kong and China.
Topping the WEF report is the United States, followed by Switzerland, Denmark, Sweden, Germany, Finland, Singapore, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands, in that order.

In the WEF's Global Competitiveness Index (GCI) , which consists of three sub- indexes -- Basic Requirements, Efficiency Enhancers, and Innovation and Sophistication factors -- Taiwan ranks 19th, 17th (14th last year), and 10th (9th last year), respectively.
In the Business Competitiveness Index (BCI), Taiwan finds itself in 23rd place, down two notches from last year, the report shows.

Among the 12 pillar indicators under the three sub-indexes, Taiwan ranks fourth in "higher education and training, " sixth in "health and primary education, " and ninth in "innovation," according to the report.
In a measure of "financial market sophistication, " Taiwan ranks 58th, a decidedly poor performance which dragged down the country's overall ranking.
Taiwan's ranking of "institutions" fell to 37th place from last year's 32nd, the report says, adding that Taiwan ranks 26th in the "macroeconomic stability."

The WEF said in a press release that Taiwan "draws its greatest competitive strengths from education and innovation, " which the WEF described as being "in line with the government's development strategy in recent decades."
The WEF noted that Taiwan enjoys one of the highest enrollment rates in the world as the country ranks 3rd and 5th in primary and tertiary enrollment rates, respectively.

Taiwan also "gets excellent marks for the quality of its educational system, " particularly in "math and science, " the WEF noted, adding that this "has buttressed the country's potential for innovation, as demonstrated by the extremely high rate of patenting per capita."
Taiwan ranks 3rd in the "utility patents" category in the "innovation" sector.

Taiwan also performs well on the 11th pillar of the "business sophistication" -- in which it ranks 14th. In the "state of cluster development" sub-category under this pillar, Taiwan is the top-ranked country.
In terms of the country's stage of development, the WEF report regards Taiwan as being in a transitional period between "efficiency-driven" and "innovation-driven" development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 28 holidaymakers injured in central Taiwan bus accident

TEXT.P: Twenty-eight passengers were injured Wednesday, eight of them seriously, when a bus full of holidaymakers overturned on the Yilan section of the East-West Highway leading to Wuling Farm in central Taiwan.
According to local police, the injured are being treated in a hospital at Luodong township in Yilan County.

Police officers said the bus, with license plate number 296FF, was carrying 43 members of a Presbyterian Church in Kaohsiung on the first day of a three-day tour of central Taiwan, and that most of the passengers are elderly people.
The bus was on its way to the Wuling Guest House when it overturned shortly before 7 p.m. Among the injured was the owner of the bus who was also the driver.
According to the police, it appeared that the bus skidded and lost control before hitting the mountainside, causing it to veer off the road and plunge into a five-meter deep ditch.
Police officers said they were still trying to ascertain the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cancer forms top killer for wage earners: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) released Wednesday a list of the top 10 causes of death for the country's wage earners in 2006, with cancer, accident and chronic liver disease and cirrhosis rounding out the top three.

Shih Tung-sheng, chairman of the CLA's Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, said the death rate from cancer per 100,000 wage earners reached 54.41 in 2006, while accident death rate was 22.92, and that from chronic liver disease and liver cirrhosis hit 8.69.
The overall death rate for employed persons in 2006 was 138.25 per 100,000 people, the lowest rate in the past five years, Shih said.

Shih pointed out that although cancer is also the leading cause of death for the population as a whole, the second and third leading causes of death, nationally, are cerebrovascular disease and heart disease.

The fourth through 10th leading causes of death for wage earners were heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, diabetes, kidney disease, pneumonia, infectious disease and parasitic disease, and high blood pressure.

Female workers were less likely to suffer from chronic liver disease or cirrhosis of the liver than their male counterparts, as these health problems ranked sixth among women, but third for workers as a whole.
Putting a fine point on the death rate due to cancer, Shih said workers' three leading causes of death due to cancer were liver cancer, lung cancer, and oral cavity cancer.
Nationwide, lung cancer was most common, followed by liver cancer. Oral cavity cancer ranked sixth, Shih added.

Death rates from cancer per 100,000 male workers in 2006 was 70, with the three highest death rates attributed to liver cancer, 20.6, oral cavity cancer, 11.1, and lung cancer, 9.8, Shih said, adding that the three categories accounted for 58 percent of cancer deaths among male workers.

Meanwhile, the death rate from cancer per 100,000 female wage earners in 2006 was 38, with the top three types being breast cancer, 7.3, lung cancer, 5.3, and colorectal cancer, 4.6. The three accounted for 45 percent of female workers' death rate from cancer, Shih said.
For wage earners aged between 20 and 39, accident was the leading cause of death, while cancer killed most workers above 40, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run sugar company denies hoarding crop

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp.(Taisugar) denied a rumor Wednesday that one of its affiliates has stockpiled a large amount of corn to push up the crop's price in the domestic market.

As a state-own company, Taisugar is fully responsible for stabilizing consumer product prices at home despite soaring international prices of crude oil and raw materials, Taisugar officials said, stressing that it is impossible for the company to stockpile crops to make extra profits illegally.

According to Taisugar officials, since May this year the company has released 6,480 metric tonnes of maize and 15,930 metric tonnes of soybeans on the domestic market, meaning that its current stockpiles have decreased down below the company's safety margins.

Although Taisugar has also been hit by surging raw materials prices in the world market, officials said that it has still decided to release its stockpiled crop as part of government efforts to help bring down high prices in the home market.

As to allegations that one of its affiliates are hoarding maize, the officials explained that Taisugar controls only 40 percent of that company's shares and does not have a final say in that company's operations.

Quoting management at the branch company, the officials said that it called for understanding from the public because its stockpiles of maize have significantly dwindled to a point below its safety margins level.

In a related development, the officials said, Taisugar has also begun slashing the number of pigs raised for sale, with the current number dipping by 6,000 per month in comparison with past figures in a bid to help offset a slump in the hog-farming business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Joining legislative race aims to inspire DPP progress: hopeful

TEXT.P: Luo Wen-jia, a reformed-minded former lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Wednesday that his decision to run for a legislative seat again is driven by a desire to inspire advancements in the DPP.

Luo, who had been one of the DPP's most promising political stars before losing his bid for Taipei County magistrateship in late 2005, made the remarks shortly after the DPP passed a proposal to draft Luo to join the legislative race in Taipei City's Daan district, which has traditionally been dominated by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT)-led "pan-blue alliance."

Luo, a former legislator representing the northern county of Taoyuan, drew on a "kitchen theory" to elucidate his reasons for agreeing to the DPP's call to fight an uphill battle for the party's cause.

"If you enter a kitchen, you tend to get dirty and may not necessarily get an opportunity to cook, but if you don't enter the kitchen in the first place, you certainly will not have an opportunity to cook at all, " said Luo, who also once headed the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs.

Noting that the DPP has come to a bottleneck in its development, Luo said the party needs more reform-minded people to drive it forward in a rational, moderate direction, Luo said he doesn't want to see a vicious cycle of "the bad driving out the good" from its ranks.
